Editor's page logged out learn more Srikandi (Dewanagari: शिकण्ढी; ,IAST: Śikhaṇḍī, शिकण्ढी) is an androgynous character in the Indian epic Mahabharata. In the story, she is the daughter of King Drupada and Persati from the Panchala Kingdom. In the Adiparwa and Udyogaparwa sections of the Mahabharata, it is explained that she is the reincarnation of a Kasi princess named Amba, who died with a vengeful heart for Bisma, prince of the Kuru dynasty. Then Amba was reborn as the daughter of Drupada. But because of the word of the gods, he was raised as a boy. Another version says that he changed sex with a yaksa (supernatural being). The Javanese wayang version that adapts the Mahabharata contains almost the same story. However, in Javanese wayang it is told that she married Arjuna and this is a very big difference when compared to the Indian version of the Mahabharata story. The name Srikandi is the Indonesian version of Śikhaṇḍin in Sanskrit. The feminine form is Śikhaṇḍinī. Literally, the word Śikhandin or Śikhandini means "having a tassel" or "having a crest". In the Mahabharata, in a previous life Srikandi was born as a woman named Amba. The story of Amba is contained in the first volume of the Mahabharata, namely Adiparwa, and in the fifth volume of the Mahabharata, Udyogaparwa. In Adiparwa it is told that Bisma—a prince from Hastinapura, the capital of the Kuru Kingdom—brought Amba from a competition in the Kasi Kingdom, to marry Wicitrawirya, his half sister. Arriving in Hastinapura, Amba confessed that she had already chosen Raja Salwa as her future husband. Because Bhishma did not want Amba to marry forcefully, he sent Amba back so he could marry King Salwa. However, King Salwa, who felt his pride had been stepped on by Bisma, did not want to marry Amba. Amba returns to Bisma's residence to marry her, but Bhishma refuses because she vows to remain celibate forever.

Feeling humiliated, Amba persuaded the warriors in Bharatawarsha to help him subdue Bisma, but none of the warriors dared to do so. Amba asked Parasurama, one of Bisma's teachers, for help. But Parasurama was unable to force Bisma to marry Amba, even though he resorted to violence. Finally Amba decided to pray to the gods to find a way to kill Bhishma. According to C. Rajagopalachari's rewritten Mahabharata, Lord Subramanya gave him a puspamala and said that anyone who wishes to use it will become the killer of Bhishma. Amba is also looking for people who are willing to use it, but no one dares even though there is a guarantee of success from the god. After being rejected by various knights, finally Amba arrived at King Drupada's palace, and got the same result. Desperately, Amba threw the puspamala over the palace gates and no one dared to touch it. From Drupada's palace, Amba went and prayed to Lord Shiva with the wish to be the cause of Bhishma's death. Amba's request was granted by the god. However, as a woman who had never received military training, Amba asked Shiva about a way to kill Bisma. Lord Shiva replied that the killing did not occur in Amba's life at that time, but in Amba's next life. The god said that Amba would be reincarnated to be the one who caused Bhishma's death. After hearing the god's answer, Amba confidently took his own life. Amba was born as Srikandi, the son of King Drupada. In the Mahabharata, Srikandi is an androgynous figure. The story of her gender determination takes place in various versions. In one version it is said that when Srikandi was young, she found a puspamala (a gift from Amba) hanging above the gate of her palace.

The Puspamala is a gift from the gods that makes its wearer the cause of Bisma's destruction. Srikandi, who still remembers her reincarnation, wears the puspamala around her neck. Seeing this, Drupada was worried that Srikandi would become Bisma's enemy, so he expelled Srikandi so that his kingdom would not become Bisma's enemy. In the middle of the forest, Srikandi prays and changes gender to male. According to another version, he ran away from Panchala, then met a yaksa who then changed his gender to Srikandi. It is said that when he was not blessed with offspring, King Drupada wandered into the forest. There he found a baby girl. When he was picked up, a magical voice echoed from the sky and ordered Drupada to raise the baby like a boy. The child was also given the name Srikandi. As an adult, Srikandi was married to Raja Dasharna's daughter. However, the princess complained to her father that the Srikandi she married was a woman. When the king acts to confirm the truth, Srikandi panics and flees into the forest. There he met a yaksa who agreed to change sex with him. The Yaksa king also knew about this, so he cursed that the yaksa would remain a woman until Srikandi died. In various versions, the gender change causes Srikandi to become eunuchs; in other versions it is not. In some versions, Amba was indeed born as a boy named Srikandi. Sometimes told as a gentleman, sometimes as an eunuch. In another version, Srikandi is indeed a man but has a transgender status, because of Shiva's grace that causes Amba to still remember her previous life. In the Kisari Mohan Ganguli translation of the Mahabharata, and the Chatahurdi compilation, Srikandi has a son named Kesatradewa. During the Kurukshetra war, which was the main conflict of the Mahabharata epic, Bisma fought on the Korawa side, while Srikandi on the Pandawa side.

Previously, in the book Udyogaparwa (the story of the preparations for the Kurukshetra war) Bhishma said in front of the Kauravas that Srikandi was the reincarnation of Amba, and was born as a woman. Before the 10th day of the battle, the Pandavas came to Bisma at night to find out his weakness. Bhishma said that he was reluctant to fight with a woman, or someone with a ladylike name. Besides that, he always stays away from the battlefield whenever Heroine approaches him. Knowing that Bhishma would act in this way towards Srikandi, Arjuna devised a trick to hide behind Srikandi and attack Bhishma with a devastating arrow. On the 10th day of the battle, many warriors from the Korawa army attacked and injured Srikandi, some of whom also confronted the five Pandavas. Drona confronted Arjuna, Duryodana confronted Bima, Salya confronted Yudistira, Wrekasura confronted Nakula, and Uluka confronted Sadewa. First of all, Ashwatthama attacks Srikandi but Drupada fends him off, then Dursasana attacks Srikandi but Drestadyumna fights him off. Lastly, Shakuni attacked and stabbed Srikandi but Virata stopped him. Later, the injured Srikandi finally boarded Arjuna's chariot. Together, they drove towards Bhishma. Seeing Srikandi appear before him, Bhishma lowered his weapon, then Arjuna, who was hiding behind Srikandi, immediately released a barrage of arrow attacks. Thus, only with Srikandi's help, Arjuna was able to deal a death blow to Bhishma, who was virtually invincible to the end. In the epic Mahabharata, it is said that Srikandi continued to survive until the war ended on the 18th day, which was marked by the defeat of Duryodhana in a duel against Bima. Before dying, Duryodhana appointed Aswatama as the leader of the rest of the Korawa warriors, to launch a revenge attack on the Pandawa camp. In the Sauptikaparwa book, it is told that Aswatama carried out the guerrilla while the Pandawa army was sleeping, and succeeded in killing many knights.

The editor page has logged out learn more A map is a representation of the earth's surface displayed on a flat plane at a certain scale. Maps can be presented in a variety of different ways, from conventional printed maps to digital maps that appear on a computer screen. The term map comes from the Greek word mappa which means table cloth or cloth. But in general, the meaning of a map is a sheet of all or part of the earth's surface on a flat plane that is reduced using a certain scale. A map is a two-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional space. The science of making maps is called cartography. Many maps have a scale, which determines how large objects on the map actually are. A collection of several maps is called an atlas. Maps have several functions in various fields, including: Maps are a tool for conveying spatial information. Based on this function, a map should be equipped with various components/elements that aim to make it easier for users to read/use the map. Some components of map completeness that are generally found on maps are, for example: Reflecting the content as well as the type of map. Title writing is usually at the top center, top right, or bottom. However, as much as possible put it on the top right. The legend is a description of the symbols which is the key to understanding the map. In general, north is indicated by an arrow pointing up on the map. It is located in the appropriate place where if there are latitude and longitude, the coordinates can be used as directions. Scale is the ratio of the distance on the map to the actual distance on the ground. The scale is written under the map title, outside the outline, or below the legend.

The scale is divided into 3, namely: Map symbols are signs or images that represent features on the surface of the earth which are contained on their appearance maps, types of map symbols include: Map colors are used to distinguish features or objects on the surface of the earth, give quality or the quantity of symbols on the map, and for the aesthetic purposes of the map. The color symbol on the map consists of 8 colors, namely: The green color indicates an area that has a height of less than 200 m. Usually the shape of the earth's surface found at an altitude of <200 m is dominated by lowlands. The lowlands in Java are found along the north and south coasts. The red color indicates an active railway/mountain. Red color is often found on maps of a province. The light green color indicates an area that has an altitude between 200–400 m above sea level. The shape of the earth's surface in this area is in the form of a sloping area accompanied by wavy and hilly forms of the earth's surface. The distribution of this form of face is almost complete over the lowlands. The yellow color indicates an area that has an altitude between 500-1000 m above sea level. The shape of the earth's surface in this area is dominated by plateaus and hills and low mountains. The distribution of this landform is on the central edge of Central Java Province and is most extensive in the southeast of Sukoharjo Regency. Light brown color indicates areas that have an altitude between 1000-1500 m above sea level. The dominant form of the earth's surface in this area is medium mountains accompanied by low mountains. The distribution of this front shape is in the central part of Central Java, such as around Bumiayu, Banjarnegara, Temanggung, Wonosobo, Salatiga and Tawangmangu.

The brown color indicates areas that have an altitude of more than 1500 m above sea level. The shape of the earth's surface in this area is dominated by relatively high mountains. The spread of these mountains is mostly in the central part of Central Java. The blue color shows the color of the appearance of the waters. The blue-white color indicates water areas with a depth of less than 200 m. The shape of the seabed in this area is dominated by relatively gentle slopes. The zone in this region is called the neritic zone. The spread of this zone is around the coast. In inland water areas this color indicates lakes or marshes. In Wonogiri there is the Gajah Mungkur Reservoir, in Bawen there is Rawa Pening, in the vicinity of Kebumen there are the Wadaslinang and Sempor reservoirs and there are several other smaller reservoirs. The light blue color indicates areas of seawater that have depths between 200-2000 m. The shape of the seafloor in this region is dominated by relatively steep slopes. This region is a continuation of the neritic zone. But this area is not depicted on the general map. The dark blue color indicates marine waters with a depth of more than 2000 m. The shape of the seabed around Bali Island at depths > 2000 m is difficult to determine and cannot be interpreted from maps. But usually the shape of the earth's surface in the deep sea can be in the form of plains, sea depths, drempel and sea trenches. The shape of the earth's surface like this is also not depicted on general maps. Lettering serves to reinforce the meaning of existing symbols. Types of use of lettering: Astronomical lines consist of latitude and longitude which are used to indicate the location of a place or region which are formed in opposite directions to each other so as to form a vector indicating the astronomical location.

Editors logged out page learn more Postmodernism (or postmodernism, postmodernism, post-mo) is a late 20th century movement in art, architecture, and criticism, which continues modernism. Included in postmodernism are skeptical interpretations of culture, literature, art, philosophy, history, economics, architecture, fiction, and literary criticism. Postmodernism is often associated with deconstruction and poststructuralism because its use as a term gained significant popularity at the same time as poststructuralism, namely in the twentieth century. Postmodernism is an understanding that developed after the modern era with its modernism. Postmodernism is not a single understanding or a theory, but rather an umbrella for various scattered theories and it is difficult to find a single common ground. Many figures give the meaning of postmodernism as a continuation of modernism. But the continuation became very mixed. For Lyotard and Geldner, postmodernism is a complete break from modernism. For Derrida, Foucault and Baudrillard, postmodernism is a radical form of modernity which eventually "turns itself off" because of the difficulty of homogenizing various theories. For David Graffin, postmodernism is a correction of some aspects of modernism. In addition, for Giddens, postmodernism is a form of modernism that has become self-aware and has become wise. Finally, for Habermas, postmodernism is an unfinished stage of modernism. Based on the origin of the word, postmodernism, comes from English which means understanding (-ism) which developed after (post) modern. The term first appeared in 1930 in art by Federico de Onis to indicate a reaction from modernism. Then in the field of History by Toyn Bee in his book Study of History in 1947. After that it developed in other fields and carried out criticism of modernism in its own fields. Postmodernism is distinguished from postmodernity.

Editor's page logged out learn more Culture is a way of life that develops and belongs to a person or group of people and is passed down from generation to generation but not hereditary. Meanwhile, culture comes from Sanskrit, namely buddhayah, which is the plural form of buddhi (mind or reason), defined as matters relating to the mind and human reason. Another form of the word culture is culture which comes from the Latin cultura. Culture is a way of life that develops and is shared by a group of people, and is passed down from generation to generation. Culture is made up of many complex elements, including religious and political systems, customs, languages, tools, clothing, buildings, and works of art. Language, like culture, is an inseparable part of human beings so that many people tend to think that it is genetically inherited. One can communicate with people of different cultures and adjust for the differences between them, thus proving that culture can be learned. Culture is a whole way of life. Culture is complex, abstract, and broad. Many aspects of culture also determine communicative behavior. These socio-cultural elements are scattered and include many human social activities. Some of the reasons why people experience difficulties when communicating with people from other cultures are seen in the definition of culture: Culture is a complex set of values ​​polarized by an image that bears a view of its own privileges. This "coercive image" takes different forms in various cultures such as "crude individualism" in America, "individual harmony with nature" in Japan, and "collective obedience" in China. -its members with guidelines regarding proper behavior and defines a world of meaning and logical value that its most humble members can borrow to gain a sense of dignity and affinity with their lives.

Thus, it is culture that provides a coherent framework for organizing one's activities and enabling it to predict the behavior of others. Culture is very closely related to society. Anthropologists Melville J. Herskovits and Bronisław Malinowski argue that everything contained in society is determined by the culture that belongs to the community itself. The term for that opinion is cultural-determinism. Herskovits views culture as something that is passed down from one generation to another, which is then referred to as superorganic. Meanwhile, according to Andreas Eppink, culture contains the whole notion of social values, social norms, knowledge, as well as all social, religious, and other structures, in addition to all intellectual and artistic statements that characterize a society. According to Edward Burnett Tylor, culture is that complex whole which includes knowledge, belief, art, morals, law, customs, and any other capabilities acquired by a person as a member of society. Selo Soemardjan and Soelaiman Soemardi stated that culture is a means of creation, taste and creation of society. Meanwhile, M. Selamet Riyadi, culture is a form of love from our ancestors which is passed on to all their descendants, and according to Koentjaraningrat, culture is the entire system of ideas and actions created by humans in the context of social life that humans possess by learning. From these various definitions, it can be concluded that culture is something that will affect the level of knowledge and includes a system of ideas or ideas contained in the human mind so that in everyday life, culture is abstract. Meanwhile, cultural embodiments are objects created by humans as cultured beings, in the form of behavior, and objects that are real, for example behavior patterns, language, tools of life, social organization, religion, art, and so on. others, all of which are intended to help humans in carrying out social life.

There are several expert opinions that suggest the components or elements of culture, including the following: According to J.J. Hoenigman, the form of culture is divided into three: ideas, activities, and artifacts. Meanwhile, according to Koentjaraningrat, cultural forms are divided into cultural values, cultural systems, social systems, and physical culture. Based on these forms, culture has several elements or components, according to anthropologist Cateora, namely: The main elements of culture include: Technology concerns ways or techniques of producing, using, and maintaining all tools and equipment. Technology appears in the ways in which humans organize society, in ways of expressing a sense of beauty, or in producing artistic results. Small, nomadic communities or rural communities who live from agriculture are familiar with at least eight kinds of traditional technologies (also called systems of equipment and elements of physical culture), namely means of production, weapons, containers, tools for starting a fire, food. clothing, shelter and housing, and means of transportation Scholars' attention to this livelihood system has focused on traditional livelihood issues, including hunting and gathering, livestock raising, cultivating crops, and fishing. The kinship system is a very important part of the social structure. Meyer Fortes suggests that the kinship system of a society can be used to describe the social structure of the community concerned. Kinship are social units consisting of several families who are related by blood or marriage. Kinship members consist of father, mother, children, in-laws, grandchildren, brothers, sisters, uncles, aunts, grandparents, and so on. In socio-anthropological studies, there are several types of kinship groups, from relatively small to large numbers, such as the grabineal family, clan, fatri, and half of the community. In general, we also recognize other kinship groups such as the nuclear family, extended family, bilateral family and unilateral family.

Meanwhile, social organizations are social associations formed by the community, both those with legal entities and those without legal entities, which function as a means of community participation in the development of the nation and state. As creatures that always live together, humans form social organizations to achieve certain goals that they cannot achieve alone. Language is a tool or cultural embodiment that humans use to communicate or interact with each other, either through writing, orally, or gestures (sign language), with the aim of conveying the intentions of the heart or will to the interlocutor or other people. Through language, humans can adjust to the customs, behavior, manners of society, and at the same time easily assimilate themselves with all forms of society. Language has several functions that can be divided into general functions, and special functions. The function of language in general is as a tool for expression, communication, and a tool for integration and social adaptation, while the function of language in particular is to establish relationships in daily life, to create art (literature), to study ancient texts, and to exploit science and technology. Art refers to the value of beauty (aesthetics) that comes from the expression of human desire for beauty that is enjoyed with the eyes or ears. As creatures with high taste, humans produce various styles of art, ranging from simple to complex artistic manifestations. Sometimes knowledge, understanding, and human physical endurance in mastering and uncovering the secrets of nature are very limited. Simultaneously, there is a belief that there is a supreme ruler of this cosmic system, who also controls humans as a part of the cosmos. In this regard, both individually and in social life, humans cannot be separated from religion or belief systems in the rulers of the universe.

Religion and other belief systems are often integrated with the culture. Religion (English: Religion, which comes from the Latin religare, which means "to anchor"), is an important cultural element in human history. The Dictionary of Philosophy and Religion defines religion as follows: ... an institution with recognized membership and used to gather together for worship, and received a doctrinal package that offered what to do with the attitude an individual should take to attain true happiness. Editor page logged out learn more Purocana (Dewanagari: पुरोचन; ,IAST: Purocana, पुरोचन) is an architect and Duryodhana's confidant in the epic Mahabharata. It is said that he was one of the ministers in the government of Dhritarashtra. This character is told in the story of the attempted assassination of the Pandavas, the main character of the Mahabharata. Purocana's name is mentioned in Adiparwa, the first volume of the Mahabharata. It is said that he was recruited by Duryodhana to build a flammable palace, or laksagreha. The palace was planned to be burned after the Pandavas were persuaded to stay in it. This idea was first coined by Duryodhana's uncle, Shakuni, who was jealous of the Pandavas. Duryodhana and Shakuni also asked Purocana's help as a firelighter to burn the laksagreha. According to Hindu mythology, in a previous life (reincarnation), Purocana was born as Prahasta, a giant warrior who was accomplished and mighty, and was one of the governors/commanders trusted by King Ravana, an antagonist whose story is found in the Ramayana. So in his two reincarnations, he has lived the life of the evil figure's right-hand man. In the Mahabharata, Adiparwa's first book, it is told that there was a dispute in the Kuru Dynasty, between the sons of Dretarastra (Korawa) led by Duryodana, and the sons of Pandu (Pandavas) led by Yudistira. In an attempt to eliminate the Pandavas, Duryodhana plans to kill them in a fire, and make it appear that the fire was an accident. So he ordered Purocana to make a palace out of combustible materials, with the main constituent being shellac (a kind of resin, or wax). The construction site is in Waranawata. Then after conspiring with Duryodhana and Shakuni, Dhritarastra persuaded the Pandavas and their mother (Kunti) to take a vacation to Waranawata, as well as witness the festival that was taking place there.

Editor's page logged out learn more The Louvre Museum (French:Musée du Louvre; English: the Louvre Museum) is one of the largest and most visited art museums and a historical monument in the world. The Louvre Museum is located in the Rive Droite Seine, 1st Arrondissement in Paris, France. Nearly 35,000 objects from prehistoric times to the 19th century are exhibited in an area of ​​60,600 square meters. The museum is housed in the Louvre Palace (Palais du Louvre) which was originally a fortress built in the 12th century under Philip II. The remains of the fort can be seen in the basement of the museum. This building was expanded several times to form the Louvre Palace as it is today. In 1682, Louis XIV chose the Palace of Versailles as his private residence, leaving the Louvre to serve as a venue for displaying royal collections. In 1692, this building was occupied by the Académie des Inscriptions et Belles Lettres and the Académie Royale de Peinture et de Sculpture. The Académie remained at the Louvre for the next 100 years. During the French Revolution, the French National Assembly decreed that the Louvre should be used as a museum to display the nation's works. The museum was opened on August 10, 1793 by exhibiting 537 paintings. The majority of these works were obtained from church and royal property confiscated by the French Government. Due to structural problems with the building, the museum was closed from 1796 to 1801. The size of the museum's collection increased under Napoleon and the museum was renamed the Musée Napoléon. After Napoleon's defeat at the Battle of Waterloo, most of the works confiscated by his troops returned to their original owners. The museum's collection was further increased during the reigns of Louis XVIII and Charles X, and during the Second French Empire, the museum managed to acquire 20,000 collections.

The museum collection continues to grow with donations and gifts increasing steadily since the time of the Third French Republic. As of 2008, the museum's collection is divided into eight curatorial departments: Ancient Egyptian Collections, Near Eastern Antiquities, Greek, Etruscan, Roman, Islamic Art, Sculpture, Decorative Arts, Painting, Prints and Drawing. The Louvre Museum has a collection of more than 380,000 pieces and exhibits 35,000 works of art in eight curatorial departments. The department has a collection of more than 50,000 pieces, including artifacts from the Nile civilization which have dates from 4,000 years BC to the 4th century AD. The collection is one of the largest in the world, providing a complete picture of Egyptian society during ancient Egypt, the Middle Kingdom of Egypt, the New Kingdom of Egypt, Coptic Art, and Aegyptus (Roman province), the Ptolemaic period, and the Eastern Roman Empire period. The collection of this department was that of the French monarchy at the time, but was augmented by Napoleon on an expedition in 1798 with Dominique Vivant who later became director of the Louvre. After Jean-François Champollion translated the Rosetta Stone, Charles X of France issued a decree that a department of Ancient Egypt should be created. Champollion suggested purchasing the three collections, which were put together by Edmé-Antoine Durand, Henry Salt and Bernardino Drovet, adding to the collection of about 7,000. The number of collections was increased through acquisitions made by Auguste Mariette, founder of the Egyptian Museum in Cairo. Mariette brought several chests of archaeological excavations in Memphis, Egypt, including The Seated Scribe or the Sitting Author. Guarded by a massive Sphinx (dated to 2,000 BC), the collection is housed in more than 20 rooms. Some of the collections include art collections, Papyrus scrolls, mummies, tools, clothing, jewelry, games, musical instruments, and weapons.

Collections from the Ancient Egyptian period include the Gebel el-Arak knife from 3,400 BC, The Seated Scribe, and the head of King Djedefre. The art of the Middle Kingdom of Egypt, which is famous for its gold work and sculpture, is represented by a statue from Sekis depicting Amenemhatankh and a statue bearing a sacrificial object. The New Kingdom of Egypt and Coptic Egypt sections also contain extensive collections. But the statues of the goddess Nephthys and the limestone depictions of the goddess Hathor speak volumes about the sentiments and wealth of the New Kingdom of Egypt. The Near Eastern Antiquities Collection, the second most recent department, dates from 1881 and provides an overview of Near Eastern civilization and the first settlements in the area, before the arrival of Islam. The department is divided into three geographic regions: the Levant, Mesopotamia (Syria, Iraq), and the Persian Empire (Iran). The department's collections are closely linked to collections of archaeological research such as Paul-Émile Botta's 1843 expedition to Khorsabad and the discovery of Sargon II's palace. Medical terms related to blood begin with the word hemo- or hemato- which comes from the Greek haima which means blood. Blood is a suspension of cells and cytoplasmic fragments in a liquid called Plasma. Overall blood can be considered as a connective tissue in a broad sense, because basically it consists of elements of cells and intercellular substance in the form of plasma. The main function of blood is to transport oxygen needed by cells throughout the body. Blood also supplies body tissues with nutrients, transports waste products of metabolism, and contains various building blocks for the immune system which aims to defend the body from various diseases. Human blood is red, between bright red when it is rich in oxygen to dark red when it is deficient in oxygen. The red color of blood is caused by hemoglobin, a respiratory protein, which is found in red blood cells and contains iron in the heme form, to which oxygen molecules bind. In insects, blood (or better known as hemolymph) is not involved in oxygen circulation. Oxygen in insects is circulated through the tracheal system in the form of channels that deliver air directly to body tissues. Insect blood transports substances to body tissues and removes metabolic waste materials. In other animals, the main function of blood is to transport oxygen from the lungs or gills to the body tissues. The blood contains hemoglobin which functions as a binder of oxygen. In some invertebrates or small invertebrates, oxygen permeates directly into the blood plasma because the oxygen-carrying proteins are freely dissolved.

Hemoglobin is the most effective oxygen-carrying protein and is found in vertebrates. Hemocyanin, which is blue, contains copper, and is used by crustaceans and molluscs. It is suspected that squid may use vanabin (a protein containing vanadium) for respiratory pigments (light green, blue, or yellow-orange). Human blood is a liquid in the body that functions to transport oxygen needed by cells throughout the body. Blood also supplies body tissues with nutrients, transports waste products of metabolism, and contains various building blocks for the immune system which aims to defend the body from various diseases. The hormones of the endocrine system are also circulated through the blood. Human blood is red, between bright red when it is rich in oxygen to dark red when it is deficient in oxygen. The red color of blood is caused by hemoglobin, a respiratory protein that contains iron in the heme form, to which oxygen molecules bind. Humans have a closed circulatory system which means blood flows in blood vessels and is circulated by the heart. Blood is pumped by the heart to the lungs to release metabolic waste in the form of carbon dioxide and absorb oxygen through the pulmonary arteries, then brought back to the heart via the pulmonary veins. After that the blood is delivered throughout the body by the aortic blood vessels. Blood carries oxygen throughout the body through fine blood vessels called capillaries. Blood then returns to the heart via the superior vena cava and inferior vena cava. Blood also transports metabolic waste materials, drugs and foreign chemicals to the liver to be broken down and taken to the kidneys to be excreted as urine. Blood consists of several types of corpuscles that make up 45% of the blood, this number is expressed in the value of the hematocrit or the volume of red blood cells that are condensed which ranges from 40 to 47.

The other 55% is a yellowish liquid which forms the liquid blood medium called blood plasma. The blood corpuscle consists of: Blood Structure. blood serum or plasma consists of: Blood plasma is basically an aqueous solution containing: calcium, phosphorus, potassium and iron, nitrogen, etc.). Blood is one component of the transport system which is very vital to its existence. The vital functions of blood in the body include transporting chemical substances such as hormones, transporting waste products of the body's metabolism, and transporting oxygen and carbon dioxide. In addition, blood components such as platelets and blood plasma have an important role as the first defense against disease attacks that enter the body. The condition of an organism's blood can be used to determine the health condition that is being experienced by that organism. Fish physiological deviations will cause blood components to also change. Changes in blood picture and blood chemistry, both qualitatively and quantitatively, can determine the state of health. Hemoglobin is a protein consisting of protoporphyrin, globin and 2-valent iron (ferrous). One gram of hemoglobin can bind about 1.34 ml of oxygen. Low hemoglobin levels can be used as an indication of low protein content in the feed, vitamin deficiencies or fish getting an infection. Meanwhile, high levels indicate that fish are in a state of stress (Wells, 2005 in Kuswardani, 2006). Hematocrit is the volume percentage of erythrocytes (red blood cells) in fish blood. The results of examination of the hematocrit can be used as a benchmark to determine the health condition of fish, a hematocrit value of less than 22% indicates anemia.

This hematocrit level varies depending on nutritional factors, fish age, sex, body size and spawning period (Kuswardani, 2006). Erythrocytes (red blood cells) are the most numerous cells. The nucleus of the erythrocyte cell is located centrally with the cytoplasm and will appear clear bluish with Giemsa staining (Chinabut et al., 1991 in Mulyani, 2006). In teleost fish, the normal number of erythrocytes is 1.05×106 – 3.0×106 cells/mm3 (Robert, 1978 in Mulyani, 2006). As with the hematocrit, low erythrocyte levels indicate anemia. Meanwhile, high levels indicate that the fish is in a state of stress (Wedemeyer and Yasutake, 1977 in Purwanto, 2006). Leukocytes (white blood cells) have an oval or round shape, are colorless, and the number per mm3 of fish blood ranges from 20,000-150,000 items, and is an active unit of the body's defense (immune) system. Leukocyte cells will be transported specifically to the infected area. Leukocytes consist of two types of cells, namely granulocyte cells (consisting of neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils and agranulocyte cells) and granulocyte cells (consisting of lymphocytes, platelets, and monocytes) (Purwanto, 2006). Lymphocytes have a role in the immune response and monocytes are macrophage cells that play an important role in phagocytizing pathogenic microorganisms. Meanwhile, platelets play an important role in the blood clotting process and function to prevent loss of body fluids in surface damage (Nabib and Pasaribu, 1989 in Mulyani, 2006). Unlike the three cells above, neutrophils are very active in killing bacteria and are in large numbers in pus (Carboni, 1997 in Mulyani, 2006). These cells circulate in the blood and lymph fluids. Wounds can cause severe blood loss and loss of blood. Platelets cause blood to clot, closing small wounds, but large wounds need to be treated quickly to prevent blood loss.

Knowledge includes, but is not limited to descriptions, hypotheses, concepts, theories, principles and procedures that are Bayesian Probability correct or useful. In another sense, knowledge is a variety of symptoms encountered and obtained by humans through the observation of reason. Knowledge arises when a person uses his mind to recognize certain objects or events that have never been seen or felt before. For example, when someone tastes a new dish that he is familiar with, he will gain knowledge about the shape, taste, and aroma of the dish. Knowledge is information that has been combined with understanding and the potential to act; which then sticks in someone's mind. In general, knowledge has the ability to predict something as a result of recognizing a pattern. Where information and data only have the ability to inform or even cause confusion, then knowledge has the ability to direct action. This is called the potential to act. Knowledge possessed by a person, of course, comes from various sources. Here are the sources of knowledge: In the view of the philosophers, reason is the source of knowledge. This view arises from the fact that knowledge is not formed by soul and matter. Therefore, knowledge must be sourced from a substance that is not material in terms of substance or actualization. The degree of this source of knowledge must be higher than that of the soul. This is based on the view that the soul in its actualization is still bound by matter. This substance is then referred to as reason. Especially in the subject matter of Knowledge Management, there are two main types of knowledge when viewed from their explicitity: Implicit knowledge is knowledge that is still embedded in the form of one's experience and contains factors that are not real such as personal beliefs, perspectives, and principles.

One's silent knowledge is usually difficult to transfer to others either in writing or orally. The ability to speak, design, or operate complex machines or tools requires knowledge that cannot always be seen explicitly, nor is it so easy to transfer it to others explicitly. A simple example of implicit knowledge is the ability to ride a bicycle. Common knowledge of how to ride a bicycle is that in order to balance, if the bicycle turns to the left, then point the steering wheel to the right. To turn right, first turn the steering wheel to the left a little, then when the bike is leaning to the right, turn the steering wheel to the right. But knowing that alone is not enough for a beginner to be able to steer a bicycle. A person who has implicit knowledge is usually unaware that he actually has it and also how that knowledge can benefit others. To get it, learning and skills are needed, but not necessarily in written forms. Implicit knowledge often contains customs and culture of which we are not even aware. Explicit knowledge is knowledge that has been documented or stored in a tangible form in the form of media or the like. It has been articulated in formal language and can be disseminated relatively easily. Information stored in encyclopedias (including Wikipedia) is a great example of explicit knowledge. The most common forms of explicit knowledge are instructions for use, procedures, and how-to videos. Knowledge can also be mediated audio-visually. Art work and product design can also be seen as a form of explicit knowledge which is an externalization of human skills, motives and knowledge. How to make implicit knowledge explicit is a key function of a Knowledge Management strategy.

Knowledge that emphasizes observation and sensory experience is known as empirical knowledge or a posteriori knowledge. This knowledge can be obtained by making empirical and rational observations. This empirical knowledge can also develop into descriptive knowledge if one can describe and describe all the characteristics, characteristics, and symptoms that exist in the empirical object. Empirical knowledge can also be obtained through repeated personal human experiences. For example, someone who is often chosen to lead an organization will naturally gain knowledge about organizational management. Rationalist knowledge is knowledge acquired through reason. Rationalism emphasizes a priori knowledge; no emphasis on experience. For example knowledge of mathematics. In mathematics, the result 1 + 1 = 2 is not obtained through experience or empirical observation, but through a logical mind. A person's knowledge is influenced by several factors, including: Education is a process of changing the attitude and behavior of a person or group and also efforts to mature humans through teaching and training efforts, so it is clear that we can conjure up a vision of education, namely to educate humans. Media specifically designed to reach a very wide audience. So examples of this mass media are television, radio, newspapers, and magazines. The definition of information according to the Oxford English Dictionary, is "that of which one is apprised or told: intelligence, news". Other dictionaries state that information is something that can be known, but some emphasize information as the transfer of knowledge. In addition, the term information also has other meanings as defined by the information technology bill which defines it as a technique for collecting, preparing, storing, manipulating, announcing, analyzing, and disseminating information with a specific purpose.

Acne is an abnormal condition of the skin due to excessive interference with the production of oil glands (sebaceous glands) which causes blockage of the hair follicle ducts and skin pores. The most common causes of acne are hormones, piles of oil or sebum on the skin collaborate with bacteria. Genetic factors also affect each individual's sebum production by around 50-90%. Generally, acne is caused by an excess of oil glands due to the active production of androgen hormones. Acne occurs because the excess oil glands mix with dead skin cells. When the skin cells mix with the increased amount of dust or dirt, the mixture is thick and sticky. it can form plugs that become black or white spots. Many people think that acne only affects the face, but acne can also attack other parts of the body, such as the back, chest and upper arms. To complicate matters, a bacteria normally present on the skin, called P. acne, tends to multiply in the clogged sebaceous glands, which produce substances that irritate the surrounding area. The glands continue to swell, and may burst. then spread the inflammation to the skin of the surrounding area. This is what causes cystic acne the most likely type, which leaves long-term pigmentation and scars like smallpox that are permanent.

Pores are often clogged by the use of cosmetics that contain a lot of oil or the use of powder that blends with the foundation. In the field of philosophy, epistemology includes discussions about the origin, sources, scope, value validity, and truth of knowledge. Epistemology studies the nature of knowledge, justification, and the rationality of beliefs. Epistemology has become widely discussed in various fields, epistemology is centered into four areas, namely 1) Philosophical analysis related to the nature of knowledge and how this is related to conceptions such as truth, belief, and justification, 2) Various problems of skepticism, 3) Sources and scope of knowledge and justification for belief, and 4) Criteria for knowledge and justification. Epistemology addresses questions such as, "What makes justifiable truths justifiable?", "What does it mean to say that someone knows something?", and the fundamental question, "How do we know that we know?". The term 'Epistemology' was introduced to the philosophical field by the Scottish philosopher James Frederick Ferrier in 1854. However, according to Brett Warren, King James VI of Scotland had previously taken this philosophical concept by heart and personified it, with the term Epistemon, in 1591. In a In a philosophical debate, King James VI of Scotland wrote the character Epistemon as the personification of a philosophical concept to respond to a debate by arguing whether the perceptions developed by the ancient religion of witchcraft should be punished in the presence of Christian society. King James' argument shows that through the character of Epistemon, who bases his argument on theological ideas regarding reasoning and beliefs that develop in society, meanwhile his opponent Philomathes takes a philosophical stance on legal aspects in society, but seeks to gain greater knowledge of Epistemon, the Greek term for scientist.

This philosophical approach signifies a Philomath who seeks greater knowledge through epistemology by using theology. This dialogue was used by King James to educate the public on various concepts, including historical concepts and the etymology of the subject in dispute. Etymologically, this word comes from the classical Greek epistēmē which means knowledge and logos which means explanation or knowledge. Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. The Republic of Angola is a country located in southern Africa. Angola is bordered by Namibia, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Zambia and the Atlantic Ocean. Cabinda, an exclave-shaped province of Angola, borders the Republic of the Congo. Angola's area is almost twice the size of the island of Borneo; is ranked 22nd in the world (after Niger and before Mali). The country is one of the world's major coffee producers and is one of the richest countries in Africa thanks to its natural resources, especially iron ore, diamonds and copper. The early settlers of this area were the Khoisan hunter-gatherer tribe. They were massively replaced by the Bantu during the Bantu migration. In present-day Angola, Portugal made a stop in 1483 on the Congo River, where the Congo, Ndongo and Lunda States were located. The country of the Congo stretched from modern Gabon in the north to the Kwanza River in the south. In 1575 Portugal established a Portuguese colony in Luanda based on the slave trade. The Portuguese gradually took control of the coastline throughout the 16th century through a series of treaties and wars. They formed the Angolan colony. The Dutch occupied Luanda between 1641-48, giving impetus to anti-Portuguese states. In 1648 Portugal retook Luanda and began a process of military conquest in the Congo and Ndongo states that ended with a Portuguese victory in 1671. Full Portuguese administrative control of internal affairs did not occur until the early 20th century.

In 1951 the colony was reformed as an overseas province, also called Portuguese West Africa. As Portugal resisted the decolonization process 3 independence movements emerged: After 14 years of guerrilla war for independence, and the fall of Portugal's fascist government by a military coup, Angolan nationalist parties began negotiations for independence in January 1975. Independence would be declared in November 1975. Almost immediately, civil war broke out between MPLA, UNITA and FNLA, exacerbated by foreign interference. South African troops allied with UNITA and invaded Angola in August 1975 to ensure that there was no encroachment (by the newly independent Angolan state) on Namibia, then still under South African occupation (Hodges, 2001, 11). The Soviet Union began assisting the MPLA and providing much of the economic support, while Cuban troops arrived to support the MPLA in October 1975, putting them in control of the capital, Luanda, and keeping South African forces at bay. The MPLA declared itself to be the de facto government of the country when formal independence was declared in November, with Agostinho Neto as first president. In 1976, the FNLA was defeated by combined MPLA and Cuban forces, leaving UNITA (backed by the United States and South Africa) and the Marxist MPLA fighting for power. Conflict broke out, fueled by Cold War geopolitics and by the ability of the two parties to access Angola's natural resources. The MPLA creates a tax on offshore oil resources, while UNITA has access to alluvial diamonds which are easily smuggled across the country's porous borders (LeBillon, 1999). In 1991, the factions agreed to the Bicesse Accords that turned Angola into a multiparty state, but after then (and current) president Jose Eduardo dos Santos of the MPLA won UN-supervised elections, UNITA declared fraud and war broke out again.

The 1994 peace agreement (Lusaka protocol) between the government and UNITA provided for the integration of former UNITA rebels into the government. A national unity government was formed in 1997, but war broke out again in late 1998, leaving millions of people homeless. President José Eduardo dos Santos revoked the permanent functions of democratic institutions due to the conflict. On 22 February 2002, Jonas Savimbi, the leader of UNITA, was shot dead and a ceasefire was reached between the 2 factions. UNITA disbanded its armed wing and assumed the role of the main opposition party. Although it seems that the country's political situation will recover, the president of dos Santos still does not allow the democratic process to continue. Among Angola's main problems are a serious humanitarian crisis (a result of prolonged war), an abundance of mines, and the actions of the guerrilla movement fighting for the independence of the northern exclave of Kabinda (Frente para a Libertação do Enclave de Cabinda). Eventually Angola became one of the few African countries to join the Soviet bloc and become communist, along with the Portuguese colony of Mozambique. Angola, like many Sub-Saharan countries, is a site of periodic outbreaks of infectious diseases. In April 2005, Angola was in the midst of an outbreak of the Marburg virus which quickly became the site of the worst outbreak of a haemorrhagic disease in recorded history, with over 237 deaths out of 261 reported cases, and which had spread to 7 of the 18 provinces by 19 April 2005 Angola is bounded by Namibia to the south, Zambia to the south, the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the northeast, and the South Atlantic Ocean to the west. The exclave of Cabinda also borders the Republic of the Congo to the north. Angola's capital, Luanda, is located on the Atlantic coast in the northwest of the country.

The Dieng Mountains themselves are geographically located between the Rogojembangan Peak complex to the west and the pair of Mount Sindoro and Mount Sumbing on the east side. Roughly speaking, it can be said that the Dieng Plateau area occupies an area measuring 4-6 km wide (north–south) and 11 km long (west–east). Administratively, the Dieng Plateau is in the area of ​​Batur District and parts of Pejawaran District, Banjarnegara Regency, Kejajar District, Wonosobo Regency, and the southern part of Pranten Village, Bawang, Batang Regency, with the core of the tourist area being in the Dieng Kulon Village area (in Banjarnegara ) and Dieng Village ("Dieng Wetan" in Wonosobo). The elevation of the plains is at 1600 to 2100 meters above sea level with the surface flow direction to the southwest, towards the Serayu River valley. With temperatures ranging from 12–20 °C during the day and 6–10 °C at night, although during the dry season (July and August), the air temperature can reach 0 °C in the morning. subtropical and gives rise to frost that the locals call bun upas ("poison dew") because it causes damage to agricultural crops. Although quite remote, the Dieng Plateau has long been a residential area. A number of 8th century buildings can still be found, either still standing or in ruins. It is estimated, these buildings originate from the early Ancient Mataram period.

Agriculture in Dieng is the main source of livelihood for the population. Cultivating mountain vegetables is the main activity, such as potatoes, carrots, turnips, cauliflower, beets, and various onions. Dieng Plateau is the largest potato producer in Indonesia. The klembak and purwoceng plants are refreshing plants that are unique to Dieng, because they are only suitable for growing in this area. The name "Dieng" comes from a derivative of the Proto-Malay-Polynesian words: di which means "place" and hyang which means "ancestor". Thus, "dihyang" means the mountains where the ancestors or the gods reside. An inscription reveals that in the Dieng Plateau, ancient Javanese people had inhabited the area and used it for worship. It is stated in the Mount Wule Inscription in 861 AD that someone was ordered to maintain a sacred building in an area called Dihyang. The Dieng Plateau has a temperate but warm climate. Based on the Köppen climate classification, Dieng is included in the Cwb group, with a cold dry season and a relatively warm rainy season. The average annual temperature in Dieng is 14.0°C. Basically the Dieng Plateau is a caldera surrounded by surrounding mountains, including Mount Prahu (2,565 m) to the northeast of the caldera, Sikunir Hill (2,463 m), Mount Pakuwaja (2,595 m), Mount Bismo (2,365 m) to the south of the caldera, as well as the Mount Butak-Dringo-Petarangan complex (to the northwest). Below the surface of the caldera there is volcanic activity, such as Yellowstone or the Tengger Plateau. Here there are many craters and fractures (vents) which release the results of geological activity in various forms: fumaroles, solfatara, gas sources (CO2 and CO), and springs (hot and cold), as well as volcanic lakes. Several craters are still very active, such as Sileri, Candradimuka and Sikidang, which are used as natural tourist objects.

This condition has a potential danger to the people who inhabit the area. The last case that claimed hundreds of lives was the Sinila Crater gas eruption disaster in 1979. Not only toxic gas and eruptions, but also possible (volcanic) earthquakes, mud eruptions, landslides, and floods. Apart from the crater, there are also volcanic lakes which contain water mixed with sulfur so that it has a distinctive greenish-yellow color. From a biological point of view, volcanic activity in Dieng is interesting because in the hot springs near the crater several species of thermophilic ("heat loving") microorganisms have been found which have the potential to reveal early life on Earth. Dieng also has several unique plant species that are rarely found elsewhere due to its unique combination of climatic and geothermal conditions. Active craters on the Dieng Plateau indicate the presence of high volcanic activity below the surface. Apart from bursts of gas or water vapor, other forms of activity are eruptions and earthquakes. Secondary disasters that can occur are floods and lava flows. Activity monitoring is carried out by PVMBG through the Dieng Volcano Observation Post (PGA) in Karangtengah Village. The following are active craters found in the Dieng Plateau. This collection of craters is around Mount Sipandu. There are many craters around Sileri. This area is very active and has been used as a geothermal power plant (PLTP) by PT Geo Dipa Energi. Geothermal activity in the south is found around Mount Pangonan to the Mount Pakuwaja-Sikunir complex. This complex is also the closest to the temple complex in Dieng. In addition to active craters, there are also non-active or dead craters. The geothermal field around Sikidang has also been utilized for PLTP. Some distance away, to the west of the Sileri complex and to the north of the center of the Batur sub-district, there is a cluster of volcanic activity known for its record of lethal eruptions due to emissions of high concentrations of carbon dioxide gas.

Volcanic activity here is related to the existence of the Mount Butak-Petarangan complex which was previously a stratovolcano. Jalatunda well in 1937 Many lakes or ponds were formed in the Dieng Plateau because certain parts of this area were swampy and due to geological activity. The Dieng Plateau area has long been known as a center for archaeological finds; with the discovery of a number of temples and the remains of ancient non-worship buildings (fireplaces and drainage holes) as well as statues. Dutch East Indies records state that there were 117 ancient temples/buildings in the Dieng Plateau, but now only nine are still standing. The temples in Dieng are named after Mahabharata puppet characters and based on archaeologists' estimates, the ancient buildings in Dieng were built during the reign of the Kalingga Kingdom, namely in the 7th and 8th centuries. This makes the Dieng temple the oldest surviving building in Java. These temples are Hindu religious in nature and seem to have been built for the worship of Shiva and hyang (ancestors who were deified after death). In the concept of Hinduism, the shrine or temple is a miniature cosmic sacred mountain, although Schhoppert sees very little design motif associated with India. In his review published in 2011, Romain argues that the style of the Dieng temples can be related to the Dravidian and Pallava styles of southern India. In 2020, there are only nine temples that are still standing, the rest are just ruins, foundations, or just names. The stones of the temple ruins are used by residents for building foundations, roads, or bund barriers. The temple buildings in Dieng are in groups, but almost all of them are in the Dieng valley area around the center of Dieng Kulon village. The Arjuna group is the largest and in the best condition, although many statues have been stolen or damaged.

Now it is a tourist attraction that is managed for the benefit of regional/agency revenue. Included in this group are Arjuna Temple, Semar Temple, Sembadra Temple, Srikandi Temple, and Puntadewa Temple; slightly apart to the west is the partially restored Setyaki Temple. The Gatotkaca group is on the side of the main connecting road to Bima Temple. Included in this group are Gatotkaca Temple, Nakula Temple, Sadewa Temple, and Gareng Temple. Only the Gatotkaca temple is still in good condition. Dwarawati's group is in Krajan Hamlet, Dieng Kulon Village, near one of the hiking trails to Mount Prahu. Only one temple is still standing, namely Dwarawati Temple; other temples, such as Abyasa Temple, Pandu Temple, and Margasari Temple are in ruins. Bima Temple is a single temple, located on the south side of the Arjuna and Gatotkaca complex. Parikesit Temple (estimated to be located at the foot of Mount Sipandu) is only known from the Dutch East Indies archaeological records, as well as the Prahu Temple. Of the many non-temple buildings, one can mention the Gangsiran Aswatama, an ancient drainage channel in the form of a drain hole to keep the temple area from being flooded; the shrine of Tuk Bimo Lukar, as a place for pilgrims to purify themselves before performing puja at the temple; Ondho Budho (rediscovered December 2019, at the foot of Sipandu Hill), a stone structure resembling a ladder; and the headless Ganesha statue found at the end of December 2019 in Dieng Village, Wonosobo Regency. Residents of several hamlets in Dieng are also known to have a unique phenotype, with dreadlocks. It is suspected that this hair trait is genetically inherited. Every year a dreadlocks cutting ceremony is held for residents with these physical characteristics. This ceremony is now a cultural tourist attraction. The Dieng area is a highland vegetable producer for the Central Java region.

During the time of the two Temples in Jerusalem (i.e. during the time of Jesus Christ), they were responsible for the daily and special offerings and sacrifices on Jewish holidays in the Temple grounds known as the sacrifices. Since the destruction of the Second Temple, it was the rabbis who became prominent figures among the Jewish spiritual leaders. However, the role of the Kohen still exists, although it is far less important than in Bible times. In Israel, the Kohanim bless their congregation on Sabbaths and holidays.
