The importance of Spinoza's work was only recognized over the years, by laying the groundwork for the 18th century Enlightenment and modern biblical criticism, including modern conceptions of the self and the universe.

In his posthumously published Ethics, "Spinoza wrote the last undisputed masterpiece of the Latin language, and a pure conception of medieval philosophy that ultimately turned against them and destroyed them." Specifically, he opposed René Descartes' famous mind-body dualism, the theory that the body and soul are separate. Spinoza held the monist view, according to which the two were identical, and monism was a fundamental part of his philosophy. He is described as a "man intoxicated with God," and uses the word God to describe the unity of all substance. This view influenced philosophers such as Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, who said, "You are either a Spinozist or you are not a philosopher at all." Spinoza has been hailed as one of the great rationalists of 17th century philosophy and one of the most important thinkers of Western philosophy. Although the term "pantheism" was not coined until after his death, he is considered to be the most famous proponent of the concept. Ethics is the main source of the spread of pantheism in the West. Heinrich Heine, in his Concerning the History of Religion and Philosophy in Germany (1833–1836), writes that "I do not remember where I read that Herder once exploded with rage at his constant fascination with Spinoza, "If only Goethe had taken some Latin book besides Spinoza!" But this did not apply only to Goethe; quite a number of his friends, who later became famous as poets also paid homage to pantheism in their youth, and this doctrine developed actively in German art before attaining supremacy as a philosophical theory." Johann Wolfgang von Goethe rejected the Jacobi belief in God as "the hollow sentiments of the child's brain" (Goethe 15/1:446) and, in "Studie nach Spinoza" (1785/86), argued for the identity of being and the whole.

When Jacobi spoke of an "essentially stupid universe" (Jacobi 2000: 312), Goethe praised nature as his "idol" (Goethe 14: 535). In The Holy Family (1844), Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels noted, "Spinozism dominated the eighteenth century both in the French variation, which made matter into substance, and in deism, which gave matter a more spiritual name. . . . the French School Spinoza and the proponents of deism are just two sects arguing over the true meaning of his system. . . . " SM Melamed (1933) noted, "It is observable, however, that Spinoza was not the first prominent monist and pantheist of modern Europe. A generation earlier, Giordano Bruno conveyed a similar message to mankind. Bruno was however only a beautiful episode in the history of human thought, while Spinoza was one of his strongest strengths. Bruno was both a rhapsodist and a poet, surrounded by artistic emotion; however, Spinoza, was spiritus purus and, in his methods, the prototype of the philosopher." The first known use of the term "pantheism" in Latin ("pantheismus") was by the English mathematician Joseph Raphson in his work De Spatio Reali seu Ente Infinito, published in 1697. Raphson distinguished between "panhylists" atheists (from the Greek root pan, "all", and hyle, "matter"), who believed that everything was material, and Spinozan "pantheist" who believed in "a certain universal substance, matter and intelligence, which constitutes all existing things from its own essence." Raphson argued that the universe was immeasurable by human comprehension capacity, and he believed that humans could never comprehend it. In his work, he refers to the pantheism of the Ancient Egyptians, Persians, Syrians, Assyrians, Greeks, Indians, and Jewish Kabbalists, and specifically to the pantheism of Spinoza.

In the mid-eighteenth century, the English theologian Daniel Waterland defined pantheism as follows: "This view considers God and nature, or God and the entire universe, to be one and the same substance — one universal entity; so much so that the human soul is only a modification of divine substance." In the early nineteenth century, German theologian Julius Wegscheider defined pantheism as the belief that God and the world founded by God are one and the same. During the early 19th century, pantheism was the perspective shared by many prominent writers and philosophers, drawing on figures such as William Wordsworth and Samuel Coleridge in England; Johann Gottlieb Fichte, Schelling and Hegel in Germany; Knut Hamsun in Norway; and Walt Whitman, Ralph Waldo Emerson and Henry David Thoreau in the United States. Seeing as a growing threat by the Vatican, in 1864, pantheism was officially condemned by Pope Pius IX in the Syllabus of Errors. A letter written in 1886 by William Herndon, a legal partner of Abraham Lincoln, was auctioned off and sold for US$30,000 in 2011. In the letter, Herndon wrote about President Abraham Lincoln's religious views, including pantheism. "Mr. Lincoln's religion I know so well, that there is not the least bit of doubt about him; he was or was a Theist and Rationalist, who denied all that was extraordinary – be it inspiration or supernatural revelation. At one time in his life he is a Pantheist who doubts the immortality of the soul as the Christian world understands it. He used to believe that the soul loses its identity and the soul is immortal. After that, he came to believe in God, and these are all the changes he has ever experienced."

Comparisons with non-Christian religions Several 19th century theologians believed that various pre-Christian religions and philosophies were pantheistic. They consider that Pantheism is similar to ancient Hindu religion:pp. 618 Advaita (non-dualism). The 19th-century German Sanskrit linguist Theodore Goldstücker said that Spinoza's thought was "... a system of western philosophy which ranks first among the philosophies of all peoples and ages, and is a representation in common with Vedanta ideas, so we suspect its founder may have been has borrowed the basic principles of his system from the Hindus." 19th-century European theologians also considered Ancient Egyptian religion to contain pantheistic elements and pointed to Egyptian philosophy as a source of Greek Pantheism.:pp. 618–620 Ancient Greek thinkers Presocrates who held pantheistic views included Heraclitus and Anaximander. The Stoics too were pantheists, from Zeno of Citium to the king-philosopher Marcus Aurelius. During the pre-Christian Roman Empire, Stoicism was one of the three dominant philosophical schools, along with Epicureanism and Neoplatonism. The early Taoism of Laozi and Zhuangzi is also sometimes considered pantheistic although it is closer to Panentheism. Cheondoism, which emerged during the Korean Joseon Dynasty, and Won Buddhism are also considered pantheistic. The Canadian Realist Society believes that a conscious universe is a reality. This is also an alternative view of Pantheism. In a letter written to Eduard Büsching (25 October 1929), in reply after Büsching sent Albert Einstein a copy of his book Es gibt keinen Gott ("There is no God"), Einstein wrote, "We Spinoza followers see our God in miracles, regularity and the validity of all that exists and is in his soul Beseeltheit] as it manifests itself in men and animals." According to Einstein, Büsching's book only discusses the concept of personal God and not God in the perspective of impersonal pantheism.

In a letter written in 1954 to philosopher Eric Gutkind, Einstein wrote "God's word is to me nothing more than the expression and product of human weakness." In another letter in 1954, he wrote "I do not believe in a personal God and I have never denied this view but have expressed it clearly." In Ideas and Opinions, published a year before his death, Einstein expressed a specific conception of the word God: Scientific research can reduce superstition by encouraging people to think and see things in terms of cause and effect. What is certain is that a belief in the rationality and clarity of the world, akin to a religious feeling, lies behind all scientific work of a higher order. . . . ] This firm belief, this deeply feeling bound faith, in the superior thought which expresses itself in the world of experience, represents my conception of God. In common parlance this could be described as "pantheistic" (Spinoza). In the late 20th century, some scholars suggested that pantheism was the theology underlying Neopaganism, and pantheists began to form organizations devoted to pantheism and treat it as a separate religion. Dorion Sagan, son of scientist and science communicator Carl Sagan, published a book called Dazzle Gradually: Reflection on the Nature of Nature, which he co-authored with his mother Lynn Margulis in 2007. In the chapter "Truth of My Father", Sagan writes that "his father believed in The God of Spinoza and Einstein, God is not behind nature, but as nature, equal to it." In 2009, pantheism was named in the Pope's encyclical and in a statement on New Year's Day 2010, to criticize pantheism for denying human superiority over nature and for seeing the source of human salvation in nature.

In his 2009 review of the film Avatar, Ross Douthat described pantheism as "Hollywood's religion of choice for a generation now". In 2015, The Paradise Project, an organization "dedicated to celebrating and spreading awareness about pantheism," commissioned Los Angeles mural artist Levi Ponce to paint a 75-foot-tall mural in Venice, California near the organization's offices. This mural depicts Albert Einstein, Alan Watts, Baruch Spinoza, Terence McKenna, Carl Jung, Carl Sagan, Emily Dickinson, Nikola Tesla, Friedrich Nietzsche, Ralph Waldo Emerson, WEB Du Bois, Henry David Thoreau, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Rumi, Adi Shankara, and Laozi. Many traditional religions and beliefs including African traditional religions and Native American religions can be understood as pantheistic, or a mixture of pantheism and other doctrines such as polytheism and animism. According to some pantheists, there are elements of pantheism in some forms of Christianity. Ideas similar to pantheism also exist in East/South Asian religions before the 18th century (especially Sikhism, Hinduism, Confucianism and Taoism). While there is no evidence that these religions influenced Spinoza's work, there is evidence that these views influenced other contemporary philosophers, such as Leibniz, and later Voltaire. In Hinduism, the pantheistic view coexists with thepantheistic, polytheistic, monotheistic and atheistic views. In Sikhism, the stories attributed to Guru Nanak show that he believed God to be omnipresent in the physical world, and the Sikh tradition usually depicts God as a perpetuating force in the physical world, present in all material forms, each created as a manifestation from God. However, Sikhs see God as a transcendent creator, "immanent in the phenomenal reality of the world in the same way that an artist is said to be present in his art".

The editor page has logged out learn more Migraine is a chronic disorder characterized by the occurrence of mild to very severe headaches that are often associated with symptoms of the autonomic nervous system. The word migraine comes from the Greek ἡμικρανία (hemikrania), ie "pain on one side of the head", from ἡμι- (hemi-), "half", and κρανίον (kranion), "skull". Signs of migraine headaches are unilateral (only on one half of the head), throbbing, and lasting from 2 to 72 hours. Accompanying symptoms include nausea, vomiting, photophobia (increased sensitivity to light), phonophobia (increased sensitivity to sound) and the pain gets worse with physical activity. About a third of migraine headache sufferers experience an aura: a kind of visual, sensory, speech, or movement/motor disturbance that signals that the headache is coming soon. Migraines are believed to occur as a result of a combination of environmental and genetic factors. Approximately two-thirds of cases occur in people who are already married. Fluctuating hormone levels can also play a role: migraines are slightly more common in teenage boys than in prepubertal women, but in adults, they are about two to three times more common in women than men. Migraine tendencies usually diminish during pregnancy. The exact mechanism of migraine is not known. However, there is a belief that the disease is caused by neurovascular disorders. The main theory is that there is a relationship with increased cerebral cortex arousal and abnormal control of pain nerve cells in the trigeminal nucleus of the brainstem. The recommended basic management is simple analgesics such as ibuprofen and acetaminophen for headaches, antiemetics for nausea, and avoidance of migraine triggers.

Certain drugs such as triptans or ergotamines can be given when simple analgesics are not effective. More than 10% of the world's population suffer from migraines at some point in their lives. Migraines usually occur with severe and recurring headaches that prevent a person from carrying out normal activities, which are associated with autonomic symptoms. Approximately 15-30% of migraine patients have migraine with aura and patients who have migraine with aura also often have migraine without aura. The degree of pain, the duration of the headache, and the frequency of attacks vary. Migraines that last for more than 72 hours are called status migraineosus. There are four possible phases before the appearance of a migraine: Prodromal or precursor symptoms of migraine in ~60% of patients which begin two hours or two days before the onset of pain or aura symptoms These symptoms can present in a variety of phenomena including: mood, irritability, depression or euphoria, weakness, craving for certain foods, stiff muscles (especially in the neck), constipation/constipation or diarrhea, and increased sensitivity to smells or loud noises. These symptoms can appear in migraines with or without aura. Aura is a focal neurological phenomenon that appears before or during a headache. These symptoms last for more than a few minutes and usually last less than 60 minutes. The symptoms can be visual, sensory or motor and most patients experience more than one. The visual effect is most common and occurs in more than 99% of cases and specifically in more than half of the cases. Visual disturbances often take the form of a scintillating scotoma (a flickering, partial transition area in the visual field).

This disturbance usually begins near the center of vision and then spreads outwards in zigzag lines that have been described as resembling fortresses or castle walls. Usually the lines are black and white but some patients also see colored lines. Some patients lose part of their field of vision and this is known as hemianopsia while other patients experience blurred vision. Sensory aura is the second most common appearance in 30-40% of patients who experience aura. Often accompanied by a prickling feeling that starts in one hand and arm and then spreads to the nose-mouth area on the same side. Numbness usually occurs after the tingling has ended along with loss of position sense. Other symptoms of the aura phase include speech or language disturbances, a feeling of spinning and, less commonly, motor disturbances. Motor symptoms indicate that the migraine that occurs is of the hemiplegic type, the feeling of weakness usually lasts more than one hour unlike other auras. Auras rarely occur without a headache, known as a silent migraine. Simply put, these headaches are unilateral, throbbing, and range from mild to severe in intensity. Usually the pain occurs gradually and gets worse with increasing physical activity. However, in more than 40% of cases, the headaches that occur are bilateral, usually accompanied by neck pain. Bilateral headaches are only common in migraine patients without aura. Sometimes, the pain is especially felt in the back and top of the head. In adults, the pain usually lasts from 4 to 72 hours while in children, it often lasts less than 1 hour. The frequency of attacks varies, from just a few times in a lifetime to several times a week, with an average of once a month.

Headaches are often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light, sensitivity to sound, sensitivity to smell, weakness and irritability. In basilar migraine, migraine with neurological symptoms related to the brainstem or with neurological symptoms on both sides of the body, the usual effects include: a spinning sensation, lightheadedness, and confusion. Nausea occurs in almost 90% of patients, and vomiting occurs in a third. Therefore most patients want to be in a dark and quiet room. Other symptoms that may accompany it: blurred vision, stuffy nose, diarrhea, frequent urination, paleness, or sweating. Swollen or tender scalp can also occur, as can neck stiffness. General symptoms are less common in elderly patients. Migraine effects may last for several days after the core headache ends; this effect is called a posdromal migraine. Many patients report pain in the migraine affected area, some patients also report not being able to think normally for several days after the headache ends. Patients may experience fatigue or "hung over" and headaches, cognitive impairment, gastrointestinal symptoms, mood swings, and weakness. According to one overview, "Some patients are oddly refreshed or excited suddenly after an attack, while others feel depressed and restless." The main cause of migraines is unknown, however, the disease is believed to be related to a combination of environmental and genetic factors. The disease occurs in married people in as many as two-thirds of all cases and is rarely the result of a single gene defect. A number of psychological conditions are linked, including: depression, anxiety, and bipolar disorder as well as various biological events or triggers.

Twin studies show that there is a 34 to 51% genetic influence on the chance of developing migraine headaches. This genetic association was stronger for migraines with aura than for migraines without aura. A number of specific gene variants increase the risk of mild to moderate. There are rarely single gene disorders that cause migraines. One result of this disorder is known as familial hemiplegic migraine, a type of migraine with aura, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. These disorders are associated with variants of the gene coding for a protein involved in ion transport. Other genetic disorders that cause migraines are CADASIL syndrome or Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with subcortical infarction and leukoencephalopathy. Migraines are caused by a trigger, some patients report having an effect in a few cases while the majority are caused by other factors. Many things have been cited as triggers, but the strength and significance of the relationship is still uncertain. Triggers can appear up to 24 hours before symptoms start. Commonly cited triggers include stress, hunger, and fatigue (these things do contribute to tension headaches). Migraines are more common during menstruation. Other hormonal influences, including menarche, use of oral contraceptives, pregnancy, perimenopause, and menopause, also play a role. These hormonal influences appear to play a greater role in migraine without aura. Migraines usually don't occur during the second and third trimesters or during menopause after that. A study of triggers found that most of the available evidence was only based on subjective judgments and was not strong enough to prove or disprove certain triggers. Regarding specific agents there appears to be no evidence of an effect of tyramine on migraine while monosodium glutamate (MSG) is frequently reported as a food trigger but the available evidence does not consistently support this report.

It concluded that all available evidence to support potential triggers in the indoor and outdoor environment was lacking in quality, but it was still advised for migraine sufferers to take precautions regarding indoor air quality and lighting. It was once believed that migraines were more common in people with high intelligence, but this is not true. Migraine is believed to be a neurovascular disorder based on supporting evidence using a mechanism that starts in the brain and then spreads into the blood vessels. Some researchers think that neuronal mechanisms play a larger role, but others think that blood vessels play a key role. Others feel both are likely important. High levels of the neurotransmitter serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine, are also believed to play a role. Diffuse cortical depression or Leão diffuse depression is a burst of neuronal activity followed by a period of inactivity that is seen in migraine patients with aura. There are many explanations for this depression, including activation of NMDA receptors that cause calcium to enter cells. After a burst of activity, blood is pumped into the cerebral cortex in the affected area and then decreases within two to six hours. It is believed that when depolarization flows down the brain, the pain-sensing nerves in the head and neck are triggered. The exact mechanism of the headaches that occur during migraines is unknown. Some evidence supports a major role for central nervous system structures (such as the brainstem and diencephalon) while other data support a role for peripheral activation (eg via sensory nerves enveloping the vessels of the head and neck). Potentially suspected vessels include: dural arteries, pial arteries and extracranial arteries, namely those on the scalp.

The role of extracranial arterial vasodilation in particular is believed to be significant. Migraine diagnosis is based on signs and symptoms. Imaging tests are sometimes done to rule out other causes of headaches. It is believed that there are still many patients with this condition who have not been diagnosed. Diagnosis of migraine without aura, according to the International Headache Society, can be made based on the following criteria, namely the criteria "5, 4, 3, 2, 1": If a person experiences two of the following symptoms: photophobia, nausea, or unable to work/study during the day then the diagnosis is most likely migraine. Patients who experience four of the following five symptoms: throbbing headache, lasting 4–72 hours, pain on one side of the head, nausea, or symptoms that interfere with the person's activities of life, then the probability of a diagnosis of migraine is 92% . Patients who experience less than three of these symptoms only have a 17% chance. Migraine was first comprehensively classified in 1988. The International Headache Society created an up-to-date classification of headaches in 2004. Based on this classification, migraine is a primary headache accompanied by, among other things, tension-type headaches and cluster headaches. . Migraine is divided into seven subclasses (some of which are still divided into more subdivisions): The diagnosis of abdominal migraine is highly controversial. Some evidence suggests that recurrent abdominal pain over a period of time without a headache is also a type of migraine. Or at least a precursor of migraines. These episodes of pain may or may not appear with migraine-like symptoms and usually last minutes to hours. This situation usually occurs in someone with a typical individual or family history of migraine. Other symptoms that are also believed to be precursors are: Cyclical vomiting syndrome and benign paroxysmal vertigo in childhood.

Other conditions that can cause symptoms similar to migraine headaches include: temporal arteritis, cluster headaches, acute glaucoma, meningitis and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Pressure headaches usually appear on both sides, don't throb, and are less disabling. Migraine prevention treatments include: medication, nutritional supplements, lifestyle changes, and surgery. Prevention is recommended for those who experience headaches more than two days a week, cannot tolerate medication to relieve an acute attack, or have severe attacks that are difficult to control. The goal is to reduce the frequency, pain, and/or duration of migraines, as well as to increase the effectiveness of failed therapies. Another reason for prevention is to avoid overuse headaches. This condition is a common problem that can cause chronic daily headaches. Drugs to prevent migraines are considered effective if they can reduce the frequency or severity of migraine attacks by at least 50%. Guidelines fairly consistently rank topiramate, divalproex/sodium valproate, propranolol, and metoprolol as having the highest level of evidence. Recommendations regarding effectiveness, however, vary for gabapentin. Timolol is also effective for migraine prevention and reduces the frequency of migraine attacks and reduces their severity, while frovatriptan works effectively for the prevention of menstrual migraines. Amitriptyline and venlafaxine are also effective. Botox has been found to be useful in chronic migraines but not in episodic ones.

Acupuncture root extract is effective for treating migraines. The use of "true" acupuncture is no more efficient than dummy acupuncture, however, both appear to be more effective than routine treatments, with less adverse effects than prophylactic drug treatments. Chiropractic treatment, physiotherapy, massage and relaxation may be as effective as propranolol or topiramate in the prevention of migraine headaches; however, the study encountered difficulties with its methodology. There is a temporary hill of benefit for: magnesium, coenzyme Q(10), riboflavin, vitamin B(12), and Fever-few, although better quality trials need to be conducted to confirm these early results. Of all these alternative remedies butterbur provides the best evidence for its use. Medical devices, such as biofeedback and neurostimulators, have many advantages in preventing migraines, especially when various anti-migraine drugs are contraindicated or in conditions of overuse. Biofeedback helps patients become aware of several physiological parameters so they can control them and can relax and work efficiently for migraine treatment. Neurostimulation using a neurostimulator in the form of an implant such as a pacemaker to treat chronic migraines that are difficult to cure gives satisfactory results in severe cases. Migraine surgery, which involves decompression of certain nerves around the head and neck, is also an option for certain people who don't improve after treatment. There are three important aspects of treatment: avoidance of triggers, control of acute symptoms, and pharmacological prevention. Treatment is more effective when used in the early stages of an attack. Frequent drug use can lead to medication overuse headaches, a condition in which the headaches become worse and more frequent. This can occur with the use of triptans, ergotamines, and analgesics, especially narcotic analgesics. The types recommended as initial treatment for those with mild to moderate symptoms are simple analgesics such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs or NSAIDs) or a combination of paraseamol, acetylsalicylic acid, and caffeine.

Paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen), used alone or in combination with metoclopramide, is another effective treatment with low risk of adverse events. In pregnancy, paracetamol and metoclopramide are considered as safe as NSAIDs until the third trimester. Triptans such as sumatriptan are effective for both pain and nausea in up to 75% of sufferers. Triptans are the treatment initially recommended for those with moderate to severe pain or those with symptoms that do not respond to simple analgesics. A variety of preparations are available including oral forms, injections, nasal sprays, and lozenges. In general, all triptans appear to be equally effective, with similar side effects. However, one can respond better to more specific ones. Generally mild side effects, such as flushing; however, rare cases such as ischemic heart disease have occurred. So this drug is not recommended for someone with cardiovascular disease. This medication is not addictive, but it can cause excess headaches when used more than 10 days per month. Ergotamine and dihydroergotamine are the older medications still prescribed for migraines, the latter being the nasal spray and injectable preparations. There also appears to be an association with cervical artery dissection. Migraine without aura does not appear to be a factor. The link with heart problems is inconclusive, although a single study supports the link. In general, however, migraine does not appear to increase the risk of death from stroke or heart disease. Migraine sufferers are slightly lower in Asia and Africa than in Western countries. Chronic migraine occurs in about 1.4 to 2.2% of the population. These figures vary widely by age: migraines generally begin between the ages of 15 and 24 and occur most frequently in those aged 35 to 45. In children, about 1.7% of 7 year olds and 3.9% of 7 to 15 year olds suffer from migraines, with the condition being slightly more common in boys before puberty. Migraine was first divided into the two types currently recognized - migraine with aura (migraine ophthalmique) and migraine without aura (migraine vulgaire) in 1887 by Louis Hyacinthe Thomas, a French librarian. Trepanation, the intentional practice of drilling holes in skulls, was practiced as early as 7000 BC. Although there are occasional survivors, many people die from this procedure due to infection. Trepanation is believed to work by "breeding evil spirits out". William Harvey recommended trepanation as a treatment for migraines in the 17th century. After many migraine treatment methods were tried, in 1868 found the use of a substance that finally proved effective. This substance was an ergot from which ergotamine was isolated in 1918. Metisergides were developed in 1959 and the first triptan, sumatriptan, was developed in 1988. In the 20th century with better research designs, effective preventive methods could be found and confirmed. Migraines are a significant source of both medical costs and lost productivity. It is estimated that migraine is the most expensive neurological disorder in the European Union, costing more than 27 billion Euros per year. In the United States, the direct costs associated with migraines are estimated at 17 billion USD. Nearly one-tenth of this fee is for triptans. Indirect costs due to migraines are around 15 billion USD, of which abandoned work is the largest component. Among those who attended their jobs with migraines, job effectiveness decreased by about a third. Negative impacts also often occur in the patient's family. Calcitonin gene linked peptide (CGRP) was found to play a role in the pathogenesis of migraine-associated pain. CGRP receptor antagonists, such as olcepepant and telcagepant, have been studied in both in vitro and in clinical studies for the treatment of migraine.

Editor's logged out page learn more Mineralogy is an earth science that focuses on the chemical properties, crystal structure, and physical (including optical) properties of minerals. This study also covers the initial process of formation and also changes in minerals. In geology, mineralogy is included in basic geology. Mineralogy is a part of geology that specifically studies minerals. Mineralogy is also part of the earth sciences. The scientific scope in mineralogy includes physical, chemical, optical and mechanical properties of minerals. Mineralogy can be divided into two scientific branches, namely physical mineralogy and optical mineralogy. Physical mineralogy specifically deals with the arrangement of crystals in minerals. In the science of physical mineralogy. The main study is mineral crystallography. The study of mineral crystallography is based on an understanding of elemental chemistry, stoichiometry, geometry and vectors. The primacy of mineral crystallography in physical mineralogy is caused by the condition of each mineral which is crystalline. Because of this, minerals have crystalline properties that can be described and projected. This depiction and projection is done in the form of a graphic presentation. This presentation enforces the laws of the crystallization mechanism. Soil mineralogy discusses solid minerals in the form of crystals with boundaries in the form of flat planes. Certain minerals have certain flat plane features. The main discussion in soil mineralogy is rock. Meanwhile, soil organic matter is not discussed in soil mineralogy. The formation of metamorphic rocks is the result of crystallization within the Earth's crust. These metamorphic rocks range between 3–20 kilometers below the Earth's surface. Most of the formation of metamorphic rocks do not go through a liquid phase and immediately become solid. The new physical environment with a certain pressure and temperature produces a new structure and mineralogy in metamorphic rocks.

The process of forming metamorphic rocks that change their mineral content is called metamorphism. The main factor is the change in physical and chemical conditions in the Earth's crust. This process of metamorphism does not involve weathering and diagenesis. The minerals contained in metamorphic rocks can originate from the original rock or result from metamorphism. Minerals due to metamorphism can be divided into three types. First, the common minerals in igneous and metamorphic rocks include biotite, hornblende, pyroxene, olivine and iron ore. Second, common minerals in sedimentary and metamorphic rocks include quartz, muscovite, clay minerals, calcite and dolomite. Third, minerals that only exist in metamorphic rocks include garnet, andalusite, cyanite, sillimanite, staautolite, cordierite, epidote and chlorite. Clay minerals at the beginning of the development of mineralogy are defined as minerals with fine textured grains. The grain diameter is smaller than 2 μm. Observations of its structure can no longer be done using an ordinary microscope. In its development, clay minerals are no longer interpreted based on the diameter of the grains, but on the shape of the layers which are like a pile of paper. The definition of clay minerals then turns into minerals that have a layered structure with an aluminosilika structure as a constituent of the framework. Grain mineralogy analysis is an analysis that aims to determine the mineral composition or mineral content in a grain-shaped mineral. The grain mineraological analysis process uses samples in the form of sand grains, sediment deposits, soil and rocks that have previously undergone preparation. The preparation process is carried out by panning method until it becomes concentrate. A binocular microscope is used as a tool for making observations. Another method that can be used is the X-ray fluorescence method. This method is widely used in mineralogy and other scientific fields.

The advantage is that it only requires a small amount of grain mineral preparation so that the analysis process becomes faster. In addition, the results of his observations are also more accurate and less destructive. Mineralogy, especially physical mineralogy, is an early part of studying geology. Understanding mineralogy facilitates understanding of petrology. The learning outcomes from petrology serve as basic knowledge in studying geology, particularly related to the identification of geological conditions, processes and evolution. This geological knowledge can be applied to both the surface and the subsurface of the Earth. In a processing plant, knowledge of the mineralogy of a mineral is very important. This is because a mineral, especially in the form of ore, does not have standard procedures in terms of processing and refining it into metal. This level of importance is even more important in complex ores, because these ore types contain more than one type of metallic mineral. Initially, mineralogy focused more on the classification system of rock-forming minerals. Advances in experimental techniques (such as neutron defraction) and computational capabilities have made it possible to simulate the behavior of crystals on the atomic scale with great accuracy, this science has expanded to include more general problems in inorganic chemistry and solid physics. Despite this, the field continues to focus on the crystal structures commonly found in rock-forming minerals (such as perovskites, clay minerals and silicate skeletons). In particular, this field has achieved advances regarding the relationship between mineral structure and its uses in nature, a notable example being the accurate calculations and predictions of the elastic properties of minerals, which has opened up deep knowledge of the seismic behavior of rocks and depth-related unconformities on seismiograms of the Earth's mantle. . Thus, in terms of the relationship between atomic-scale phenomena and macro-characteristics, mineralogy (as is generally known today) is probably more related to materials science than any other science. [citation needed] The International Mineralogical Association is an organization whose members are representing mineralogists from each country.

Editor's page logged out learn more Communism (Latin: communis) is a philosophical, political, social and economic ideology whose main goal is to create a society with socio-economic rules based on common ownership of the means of production and the absence of social class, money , and country. The term communism is often confused with International Communism. Communism or Marxism is the basic ideology commonly used by communist parties around the world. Meanwhile, international communism is an ideological blend originating from Lenin's thoughts, so it can also be called "Marxism–Leninism". In communism, social change must start from taking over the means of production through the role of the communist party. In summary, the logic is that social change begins with the workers, or better known as the proletariat (see: The Holy Family), but the organization of workers can only succeed through party struggle. The party needs the role of the Politburo as a think-tank. It can be summarized that social change can only be successful if it is initiated by the Politburo. Communism as anti-capitalism uses the communist party system as a means of taking over power and strongly opposes the ownership of accumulated capital in individuals. In principle, everything is represented as belonging to the people and therefore, all means of production must be controlled by the state for the people's prosperity evenly. Communism introduces the use of a representative democratic system carried out by communist party elites. Therefore it greatly limits direct democracy to people who are not members of the communist party. Therefore, in communism, individual rights are not recognized as found in liberalism. International communism as an ideological theory began to be applied after the outbreak of the Bolshevik Revolution in Russia on November 7, 1917. Since then communism has been applied as an ideology and spread to other countries.

Malaysia's governance model is similar to Westminster's parliamentary system. Malaysia did not exist as a federal state until 1963. Prior to this, a series of colonies were founded by the United Kingdom in the late 18th century, and the western part of modern Malaysia consisted of several separate kingdoms. The group of colonies was known as British Malaya until its dissolution in 1946, when it was reconstituted as the Union of Malaya. As opposition grew, the group was reconstituted again as the Federation of Malaya in 1948 and subsequently achieved independence on 31 August 1957. On 16 September 1963, in accordance with United Nations General Assembly Resolution 1514, in the process of decolonization, Singapore, Sarawak, Borneo North or what is now better known as Sabah turned into a state of a newly formed federation called Malaysia including the Federation of Malaya.

Singapore was then expelled from Malaysia on August 9, 1965 and became an independent country called the Republic of Singapore. During the early years of the formation of the new federation, there was also opposition from the Philippines and military conflict with Indonesia. The nations of Southeast Asia experienced an economic boom and underwent rapid development at the end of the 20th century. Rapid growth in the 1980s and 1990s, averaging 8% from 1991 to 1997, has turned Malaysia into a newly industrialized country. International trade plays an important role in its economy because Malaysia is one of the three countries that control the Malacca Strait. At one time, Malaysia was the world's largest producer of tin, rubber and palm oil. The manufacturing industry has a major influence on the economy of this country. Malaysia is also considered as one of the 18 most biodiverse countries in the world. Malays make up the largest part of the Malaysian population. There are also sizable ethnic ("race") Chinese Malaysians and Malaysian Indians. Malay and Islam are the official state languages ​​and religions respectively. Malaysia is a pioneer member of ASEAN and participates in various international organizations, such as the United Nations. As a former British colony, Malaysia is also a member of the Commonwealth of Nations. Malaysia is also a member of D-8 (Developing-8), which is an agreement for development cooperation among its eight member countries: Bangladesh, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Egypt, Nigeria, Pakistan and Turkey. The name "Malaysia" was adopted in 1963 when the Federation of Malaya added Singapore, Sabah, and Sarawak to form the federation named Malaysia. However, the name itself was once confused when it was used to refer to areas in Southeast Asia. A map published in 1914 in Chicago displays the name Malaysia in certain areas of the archipelago.

Politicians in the Philippines used to call for their country's naming as "Malaysia", but Malaysia was the first to adopt the name in 1963 before the Philippines had succeeded in deciding or implementing any policy. Other names have been suggested for the federation that emerged in 1963, including Langkasuka (an ancient kingdom located in the upper reaches of the Malay Peninsula in the first millennium AD). Going even further back, a British ethnologist, George Samuel Windsor Earl, in volume IV of the Journal of the Indian Archipelago and East Asia in 1850 proposed to name the Indonesian archipelago as Melayunesia or Indunesia, although he preferred the latter. Archaeological remains were found all over the country. The Semang people have deep ancestry in the Malay Peninsula, dating back to the first settlements in Africa, more than 50,000 years ago. The Senoi also exist, as a mixed group; almost part of their genealogy comes from the Semang line of ancestors and partly from Indochina. This mix is ​​consistent with the suggestion that they represent the descendants of ancient Austronesian speakers, namely farmers who brought their language and technology to the southern part of the peninsula about 5,000 years ago and integrated with the indigenous people. The Proto-Malays were more diverse, and although they show some links to island Southeast Asia, some also have ancestry in Indochina from the Last Glacial Maximum, followed by an Early-Holocene dispersal through the Malay Peninsula to island Southeast Asia. The Malay Peninsula developed as a major trading center in Southeast Asia due to the growth of trade between China and India and other countries through the busy Malacca Straits. Claudius Ptolemaeus showing the Malay Peninsula on his early maps, "Golden Chersonese" with the Straits of Malacca written as "Sinus Sabaricus".

From the middle to the end of the first millennium, most of the peninsula, including the archipelago, was under the influence of Srivijaya. The earliest Malay kingdom recorded in history began to grow from a coastal port city that began to be inhabited in the 10th century. Among these kingdoms are Langkasuka and Lembah Bujang in Kedah, as well as Beruas and Gangga Negara in Perak and Pan Pan in Kelantan. All are thought to be Hindu or Buddhist kingdoms. Islam arrived in the 14th century in Terengganu. There were many Chinese and Indian kingdoms in the 2nd and 3rd centuries AD — as many as 30 according to Chinese sources. Kedah — known as Kedaram, Cheh-Cha (according to the I-Ching), or Kataha in the Palawan script or the ancient Sanskrit language — was on the thoroughfare of Indian merchants and kings. Rajendra Chola, an ancient Tamil emperor believed to be based around Kota Gelanggi, conquered Kedah in 1025, but his successor, Vira Rajendra Chola, had to quell the Kedah rebellion to overcome the invaders. The arrival of Chola succeeded in dampening the majesty of Sriwijaya, which gave great influence to Kedah and Pattani and even reached Ligor. The Buddhist government of Ligor immediately returned to control Kedah. Its king, Chandrabhanu, used this place as a base to invade Sri Lanka in the 11th century, an event carved on stone inscriptions at Nagapattinum in Tamil Nadu and in the Sri Lankan epic, the Mahavamsa. During the first millennium, people in the Malay Peninsula were Hindu and Buddhist and spoke Sanskrit, until they converted to Islam. There are some reports from other regions older than Kedah—for example, the ancient kingdom of Gangga Negara, around Beruas in Perak, pushing Malaysia's history further back.

If that weren't enough, a Tamil poem, Pattinapillai, from the 2nd century AD, describes goods from Kadaram piling up on the streets of the Chola capital. A 7th century Sanskrit play, Kaumudhimahotsva, refers to Kedah as Kataha-nagari. The Agni Purana also mentions an area known as Anda-Kataha with one of its boundaries depicting a mountain peak, which scholars believe to be Mount Jerai. Stories from Katasaritasagaram describe the luxury of life in Kataha. At the beginning of the 15th century, the Malacca Sultanate was founded under a dynasty founded by Parameswara, prince from Palembang, Indonesia, within the kingdom of Srivijaya. The conquest forced him and his supporters to flee Palembang. To avoid persecution, Parameswara sailed to Temasek to get the protection of Temagi, a Malay prince from Pattani who was appointed by the King of Siam as regent of Temasek. A few days later, Parameswara killed Temagi and appointed himself regent. About five years later, he left Temasek due to threats from Siam. During this period, Temasek was also attacked by a Javanese fleet from Majapahit. He later headed north to found a new settlement. In Muar, Parameswara wanted to establish his new kingdom in Bad Biawak or Kota Bad. Finding that the Muar location was not suitable, he continued his journey northwards. Along the way, he visited Sening Ujong (the old name for the modern Ujong River) before arriving at a fishing village on the banks of the Bertam River (the old name for the modern Malacca River). The place gradually developed into the location of modern-day Melaka. According to the Malay Annals, it was here that he witnessed a mouse deer tricking a dog while resting under a Malacca tree. He took what he saw as a good omen and later he founded a kingdom called Melaka, then he built and repaired facilities for trading purposes.

Parameswara's conversion to Islam is not clear. Sabri Zain stated that Parameswara became a Muslim when he married a Princess of Samudera Pasai and assumed the Persian style title "Shah", calling himself Iskandar Syah. There are also references indicating that some members of the ruling class and merchant community who settled in Melaka had become Muslims. Chinese legends say that in 1414, the son of the first ruler of Melaka visited the Ming to tell them that his father had died. Putera Parameswara was officially recognized as the second ruler of Melaka by the Chinese Emperor and had the title of Raja Sri Rama Vikrama, King Parameswara of Temasik and Melaka and he was known as the Muslim figure Sultan Sri Iskandar Zulkarnain Syah or Sultan Megat Iskandar Syah, and he ruled Melaka from 1414 to 1424 This kingdom controlled what is now the Malay Peninsula, southern Thailand (Pattani, and the east coast of Sumatra. This kingdom lasted for more than a century, and during this period spread Islam throughout the archipelago. Melaka, as an important trading port, was located almost in the middle of the Chinese and Indian trade routes. In 1511, Melaka was conquered by Portugal, who founded a colony there; thus ended the Sultanate of Melaka. However, the last Sultan fled to Kampar, Riau, Sumatra and died there. The last Sultan of Melaka founded two sultanates elsewhere on the peninsula & the Sultanate n Perak to the north, and the Sultanate of Johor (originally a continuation of the ancient Malacca sultanate) to the south. After the fall of Malacca, three states fought for control of the Malacca Straits: the Portuguese (in Melaka), the Sultanate of Johor, and the Sultanate of Aceh. This conflict lasted until 1641, when the Dutch (allied with the Sultanate of Johor) took Malacca. This kingdom was a continuation of the old Malacca Sultanate, but is now known as the Johor Sultanate, which still exists today.

After the fall of Malacca, three countries fought to take control of the Straits of Malacca: Portuguese (in Malacca), Sultanate of Johor, and Sultanate of Aceh; and the war ended in 1641, when the Dutch (allied with the Sultanate of Johor) captured Malacca. Great Britain established its first colony in the Malay Peninsula in 1786, with the lease of the island of Penang to the British East India Company by the Sultan of Kedah. In 1824, Great Britain controlled Malacca after the signing of the Treaty of London or the British-Dutch Agreement of 1824 which divided the ownership of the archipelago between Britain and the Netherlands, Malaya for Britain, and Indonesia for the Netherlands. In 1826, Britain established Crown Colonies in the Straits Settlements, consolidating its possessions in Malaya: Penang, Malacca, Singapore, and the island of Labuan. Penang was established in 1786 by Captain Francis Light as a commercial post awarded by the Sultan of Kedah. The Straits Settlements were initially managed under the British East India Company in Calcutta, before Penang, and then Singapore became the crown colony management center, until 1867, when management responsibility was transferred to the Colonial Office in London. During the 19th century, many Malay states tried to get British help to resolve their internal conflicts. The commercial importance of tin mining in the Malay states for merchants in the Straits States made the British government intervene in the tin producing states in the Malay Peninsula. British Gunship Diplomacy was tasked with establishing a peaceful resolution to the civil unrest caused by Chinese and Malay bandits. In the end, the Pangkor Agreement of 1874 became a way to expand British influence in Malaya. Entering the 20th century, the states of Pahang, Selangor, Perak, and Negeri Sembilan, known as the Federated Malay States (as opposed to the Federation of Malaya), were under the de facto control of British residents appointed to advise the Malay rulers.

The British were "advisers" on paper, but in actuality, they exercised significant influence over the Malay rulers. The other five states on the peninsula, known as the Allied Malay States, not ruled directly from London, also received British advisors in the late 20th century. Four of the five states: Perlis, Kedah, Kelantan and Terengganu were previously ruled by Siam. Another non-allied state, Johor, was the only state to maintain its independence for most of the 19th century. Sultan Abu Bakar of Johor and Queen Victoria were personal acquaintances, and recognized each other as equals. This never happened until 1914 when Sultan Abu Bakar's successor, Sultan Ibrahim, received a British adviser. On the island of Borneo, Sabah was ruled as the crown colony of North Borneo, while Sarawak was acquired from Brunei as the personal kingdom of the Brooke family, who ruled as the White King. Following the Japanese invasion of Malaya and its successive occupations during World War II, popular support for independence grew. Post-war British plans to unify the administration of Malaya under a single crown colony called the Malayan Union were established against strong opposition from the Malays, who resisted attempts to weaken the Malay rulers and allowed dual citizenship to Chinese-Malaysians and other immigrants. The Union of Malaya, established in 1946 and comprising all British holdings in Malaya, except Singapore, was dissolved in 1948 and replaced by the Federation of Malaya, which restored self-rule to the Malayan lands under British patronage. During this time, an insurgency under the leadership of the Malayan Communist Party carried out guerrilla operations planned to expel the British from Malaya and the event became known as the Malayan Emergency which lasted from 1948 to 1960, and involved an anti-disorder campaign by Commonwealth troops in Malaya.

Although the chaos was quickly contained, it still left the presence of Commonwealth troops, against the backdrop of the Cold War. Against this backdrop, independence for the Federation within the Commonwealth was granted on 31 August 1957. Independence for Malaya, Pulau Pinang and Melaka was achieved on 31 August 1957 under the name Federation of Malaya. Singapore was still under British rule at that time because of its strategic location. On 16 September 1963, the Federation of Malaya together with the British crown colonies, namely Sabah (North Borneo), Sarawak and Singapore, formed Malaysia. The Sultanate of Brunei, although initially interested in joining the Federation, withdrew from the proposed merger due to opposition from some of the population, as well as arguments about the payment of oil royalties and the Sultan's status in the proposed union. The early years of formation or independence were disrupted by conflict with Indonesia which was sparked by Soekarno through Dwikora due to discrepancies with the UN Secretary General's report regarding violations of the Manila Accord in the formation of Malaysia. In the course of this federation, it was followed by the departure of Singapore in 1965 due to another discrepancy. with the Formation of Malaysia Agreement which was triggered by the politics of discrimination, and inter-racial disputes in the May 13 Incident in 1969. The Philippines also made active recognition of Sabah with a peaceful settlement in that period based on the surrender of part of the Sultanate of Brunei's territory, namely the north-eastern part to the Sultanate of Malaysia. Malaysia has since maintained a mild ethnic political balance, with a system of government that combines economic growth with economic and political policies that favor the rapid inclusion of all races. Between the 1980s and mid-1990s, Malaysia experienced significant economic growth under the leadership of the fourth prime minister, Dr. Mahathir Mohamad. During this period Malaysia experienced a jump from an agriculture-based economy to a manufacturing- and industrial-based economy (especially in the areas of computers and home electronics). During this period too, Malaysia's landscape changed with the growth of various mega-projects. The most notable projects are the Petronas Twin Towers (once the tallest building in the world), Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA), North-South Lebuhraya, Sepang International Circuit, Multimedia Raya Corridor (MSC), Bakun hydroelectric dam, and Putrajaya. , the seat of the new federal government. In the late 1990s, Malaysia was rocked by the 1997 Asian financial crisis, as well as political instability caused by the detention of Deputy Prime Minister Dato' Seri Anwar Ibrahim. There is also opposition from socialists and reformists, to efforts to form an Islamic state. In 2003, Dr Mahathir, Malaysia's longest-serving prime minister, stepped down and was replaced by his deputy, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The new government advocates the moderate view of the Islamic state as defined by Islam Hadhari. In November 2007, Malaysia was rocked by two anti-government demonstrations. The 2007 Clean rally of 40,000 people was held in Kuala Lumpur on 10 November advocating constituency reform. It was sparked by allegations of corruption and discrepancies within Malaysia's electoral system which is tilted towards the ruling political party, Barisan Nasional, which has ruled Malaysia since independence in 1957. Another rally took place on November 25 in the Malaysian capital and was led by HINDRAF .

The initiator of this demonstration, the Hindu Rights Action Force, staged a protest regarding unfair policies, prioritizing the Malays. The number of participants is estimated to be between 5,000 and 30,000. In both cases, the government and the police attempted to tackle and prevent the kidnappings from the scene. On 16 October 2008, HINDRAF was banned as the government branded the unregistered organization a "threat to national security" for seeking to solicit aid and support from terrorist groups. Malaysia is the 43rd most populous country and the 66th most landlocked country in world, with a population of approximately 27 million and an area exceeding 320,000 km2. Such a population is roughly comparable to that of Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, and such an area is equal to the area of ​​Norway and Vietnam, or New Mexico, a state in the United States. Malaysia consists of two main areas separated by the South China Sea. Both have almost the same shape of the earth's surface, from a sloping seafront to dense forests and high hills. The highest peak in Malaysia (and also in Kalimantan) is Mount Kinabalu at 4,095.2 meters in Sabah. The local climate is equatorial and characterized by southwest (April to October) and northeast (October to February) monsoons. Tanjung Piai, located in the southern state of Johor, is the southernmost cape of the Asian continent. The Malacca Strait, located between Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia, is the most important shipping lane in the world. Kuala Lumpur is the official capital and largest city in Malaysia. Putrajaya on the other hand, is seen as the administrative capital of the federal government of Malaysia. Although many executive and judicial branches of the federal government have moved there (to avoid growing congestion in Kuala Lumpur), Kuala Lumpur is still seen as the legislative capital of Malaysia because it is where the Malaysian Parliament building complex is located.

Kuala Lumpur is also the trading and financial center of Malaysia. Other major cities include Ipoh, George Town, Johor Bahru, Kuching, Kota Kinabalu, Miri, Alor Star, Kota Melaka, and Petaling Jaya. The Federation of Malaysia is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state for the Malaysian federation is Yang di-Pertuan Agong, also known as the King of Malaysia. Yang di-Pertuan Agong was elected from and by the nine Sultans of Malaya, to serve for five years in rotation; the other four country leaders, who hold the title Governor, did not contest the election. The system of government in Malaysia is modeled on the Westminster parliamentary system, a legacy of the British Colonial Rulers. But in practice, power was concentrated more in the executive than in the legislature, and the judiciary was weakened by the continued pressure from the government during the Mahathir era, it was shared between the federal government and the state governments. Legislative power is divided between federal and state legislatures. A bicameral parliament consists of a lower house, the People's Council (similar to the "People's Representative Council" in Indonesia) and an upper house, the Senate or State Council (similar to the "Regional Representative Council" in Indonesian). The 222 members of the Dewan Rakyat are elected from single-member constituencies organized by population for a maximum term of 5 years. 70 Senators serve for 3-year terms; 26 of them were elected by the 13 state assemblies (sending two delegates each), two represented the federal territory of Kuala Lumpur, one each represented the federal territories of Labuan and Putrajaya, and 40 were appointed by the king on the advice of the prime minister. In addition to Parliament at the federal level, each state has a unicameral legislature (Council of State Legislation) whose members are elected from single-member constituencies. Parliamentary elections are held at least once every five years, with the last general election in March 2008.

Registered voters aged 21 and over can vote for candidates for the House of Commons and candidates for the state legislature as well, in some states. Voting is not required. Executive power is exercised by the cabinet headed by the prime minister; Malaysia's constitution stipulates that the prime minister must be a member of the lower house (Dewan Rakyat), which is sanctioned by Yang di-Pertuan Agong and has majority support in parliament. The cabinet is elected from among the members of the People's Council and State Council and is responsible to these bodies. ; while the cabinet is members of parliament who are elected from the People's Council or the State Council. The state government is headed by the Chief Minister in the states of Malaya or the Chief Minister in countries that do not maintain a local monarchy, namely a member of the state assembly from the majority party in the Dewan Undangan Negeri. In each state that maintains a local monarchy, the Chief Minister must be an ethnic Malay Muslim, although this ruler is subject to the discretion of the rulers. Political power in Malaysia is very important to fight for an issue and rights. Therefore power plays a very important role in making changes. Administratively, Malaysia has 13 states (11 in West Malaysia and 2 in East Malaysia) and 3 federal territories (all three federal territories combined into one in the Malaysian flag) which are represented as the fourteen stripes and angles of the star in the Malaysian Flag which are named " Jalan Gemilang": The Malay Peninsula and certainly Southeast Asia have been the center of trade in the region for centuries. Various commodities such as ceramics and spices were actively traded even before the emergence of the Sultanates of Melaka and Singapore. In the 17th century, they were founded in several states.

Later, as the United Kingdom began to take over as administrator of British Malaya, rubber and oil palm trees were introduced for commercial purposes. Over a long time, Malaya became the world's largest producer of tin, rubber and palm oil. These three commodities, along with other raw materials, set the better tempo for Malaysia's economy well into the 20th century. Instead of relying on the ethnic Malays as a source of labour, the British brought in Chinese and Indians to work in the mines, plantations and to fill the professional skills gap. Although many of them returned to their home countries after the contracts were fulfilled, some of them stayed in Malaysia. As Malaya moved toward independence, the government began implementing five-year economic planning, starting with the First Malaya Five Year Plan in 1955. When Malaysia was founded, the planning terms were replaced and numbered, starting with the First Malaysia Plan in 1965. In the 1970s, Malaysia began emulate the economies of the Four Asian Tigers (Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore) and commit to a transformation from an economy dependent on mining and agriculture to one based on manufacturing. With Japanese investment, heavy industries began to open up and a few years later, Malaysian exports became the country's primary growth engine. Malaysia consistently received more than 7% GDP growth accompanied by low inflation in the 1980s and 1990s. Basically, Malaysia's growth depends on the export of electronic materials such as computer chips and so on. As a result, Malaysia felt intense pressure during the economic crisis in 1998 and the slump in the information technology sector in 2001. KDNK in 2001 only increased by 0.3% due to an 11% reduction in export figures but a large package of fiscal incentives mitigated the impact .

During the same period, the government attempted to reduce poverty with the controversial New Malaysia Economic Policy (NEP), following the May 13 Incident, an inter-ethnic riot in 1969. Its main objective was to remove the link between race and economic functioning, and the first five-year plan began to implement NEP as the Second Malaysia Plan. The success or failure of the NEP is a matter of debate, although it officially ended in 1990 and was replaced by the National Development Policy (NDP). Recently much debate has emerged about the outcome and relevance of the NEP. Some argue that the NEP has clearly succeeded in creating upper-middle class Malay entrepreneurs and professionals. Despite some improvements in the general economic strength of the Malays, the Malaysian government maintains a policy of discrimination favoring the Malays over other ethnic groups - including prioritizing employment, education, scholarships, trade, access to cheap housing and assisted savings. This special treatment fuels jealousy and hatred among non-Malays and Malays. Chinese domination of the state's economic sector that is owned by local parties has been largely surrendered to benefit Bumiputra/Malays in many strategic/important industries such as the distribution of petroleum derivatives, transportation, agriculture, and others. Most of the professionals per capita are still predominantly Indian-Malaysians. The rapid economic boom led to all sorts of supply problems. The meager workforce was soon filled with a steady stream of millions of immigrant workers, many of whom were illegal. Cash-capital-rich PLC and a consortium of banks immediately benefited from the expansion and accelerated start-up of large infrastructure projects. This ended when the 1997 Asian financial crisis hit in the fall of 1997, delivering a major shock to the Malaysian economy. Like other countries affected by the crisis, there was a speculative short selling of Malaysia's currency, the ringgit. Foreign investment fell to dangerous levels, as capital evaporated out of the country, the value of the ringgit fell from MYR 2.50 per USD to MYR 4.80 per USD.

The Bursa Malaysia composite index plunged from nearly 1,300 points to around 400 points in a matter of weeks. After the controversial arrest of finance minister Anwar Ibrahim, a National Economic Action Council was formed to anticipate the monetary crisis. Bank Negara Malaysia maintains capital controls and pegs the Malaysian ringgit exchange rate at 3.80 to the US dollar. However, Malaysia rejected economic aid packages from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, moves that surprised foreign analysts. In March, 2005, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) published a paper on Malaysia's resources and recovery measures, written by Jomo K.S. from the department of applied economics, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur. The paper concludes that the controls imposed by the Malaysian government have neither exacerbated nor aided recovery. The biggest factor was the increasing number of electronic component exports, which was caused by the increasing demand for components in the United States, which was caused by fears of the impact of the arrival of the year 2000 (Y2K) on older computers and other digital devices. However, post-Y2K waning in 2001 did not affect Malaysia as much as many other countries. This provides clearer evidence that there are other causes and effects that may be more appropriate for recovery. One possibility is that currency speculators went bankrupt financially after falling in their attack on the Hong Kong dollar in August 1998 and after the Russian ruble collapsed. (See George Soros) Regardless of cause and effect claims, economic rejuvenation also rolled on with massive budget deficits and government spending in the years following the crisis. Then, Malaysia enjoyed a faster economic recovery compared to its neighbors. However, in many ways the country has not recovered to pre-crisis levels.

While the current pace of development is not as fast as it used to be, it feels more stable. Even though control and maintenance of the economy are not the main reasons for recovery, there is no doubt that the banking sector has become more resilient to foreign attacks. The current account is in structural surplus, providing a cushion for capital flotation. Current asset prices, a fraction of their pre-crisis highs. Malaysia has a number of stable macroeconomic elements (where inflation and unemployment rates remain below 3%), healthy foreign exchange reserves, and low external debt. This enabled Malaysia not to experience the same crisis as the Asian financial crisis in 1997. However, the long-term prospects are not looking good due to the lack of change in the legal entity sector, especially the sector dealing with high and competitive corporate debt. The pegged exchange rate was reopened in July 2005 to a supervised floating exchange rate after an hour of China's introduction of the same. In the same week, the ringgit strengthened 1 percent against other major currencies and is expected to appreciate further. But by December 2005, hopes of further appreciation were muted as capital flows exceeded USD 10 billion. In September 2005, Howard J. Davies, director of the London School of Economics, told a meeting in Kuala Lumpur, warning Malaysian officials that if they wanted flexible capital markets to return, they would have to lift the ban on short selling. In March 2006, Malaysia lifted the ban on short selling. Now, Malaysia is seen as a newly industrialized country. Malaysia has major roads connecting all major cities on the west coast of Peninsular Malaysia. As of 2006, the overall length of the Malaysian High Speed ​​Track System was 1,471.6 kilometers.

The network connected all major cities and their surroundings: Klang Valley, Johor Bahru and Pulau Pinang to each other. The main motorway (E1 and E2, E1 is the northern part of Kuala Lumpur, while E2 is the southern part), runs from the northern and southern tips of Peninsular Malaysia, at Bukit Kayu Hitam and Johor Bahru respectively. The line is part of the Asia Fast Track Network, which also links Thailand and Singapore. Roads in East Malaysia and the east coast of Peninsular Malaysia are relatively undeveloped. They were all very winding roads through the mountains and unpaved, gravel roads. As a result, rivers are still an important transportation route, in addition to airplanes as the main or alternative mode of transportation for inland residents. Rail services in West Malaysia are operated by Keretapi Tanah Melayu and have extensive lines connecting all the major cities and towns on the peninsula, which also extends to Singapore. There is also a short rail in Sabah operated by the Sabah State Railway which mainly carries commodities. There are also several ports in the country. Malaysia's main major ports are Klang Port in Selangor and Tanjung Pejuang Port in Johor. Other important ports can be found at Tanjung Kidurong, Kota Kinabalu, Kuching, Kuantan, Pasir Gudang, Penang, Miri, Sandakan and Tawau. Airports are found all over the country. Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is the largest airport in the country. Other important airports include Kota Kinabalu International Airport, Pulau Pinang International Airport, Kuching International Airport, Langkawi International Airport, and Senai International Airport. There are also airports in small towns, as well as pioneering domestic airports in the urban areas of Sabah and Sarawak.

There are daily flight services connecting East and West Malaysia. Malaysia is home to the region's low-cost airline, AirAsia. AirAsia is based in Sepang and has flights to Southeast Asia and China. Intercity telecommunications services are provided in West Malaysia primarily by shortwave radio riley. International telecommunications is provided via undersea cables and satellites. One of the most important and largest telecommunications companies in Malaysia is Telekom Malaysia (TM), which provides products and services from fixed line, mobile, as well as dial-up and broadband Internet access services. TM has a semi-monopoly on fixed line services in the country. In December 2004, Minister of Energy, Water and Communications Lim Keng Yaik reported that only 0.85% or 218,004 people in Malaysia used broadband services. However, this figure is based on the number of customers, while the household percentage unit reflects the situation more accurately. This represents a 0.45% increase across three quarters. He also reported that the government is targeting usage of 5% in 2006 and doubling to 10% in 2008. Lim Keng Yaik encouraged local telecommunications companies and service providers to open last mile and lower prices to benefit users. Malaysia is blessed with natural resources such as agriculture, forestry and mining sectors. In the agricultural sector, Malaysia is one of the largest exporters of natural rubber and palm oil, which together with resin and logs, cocoa, pepper, pineapple and tobacco dominate the sector's growth. Palm oil is also a major generator of Malaysia's international trade. Regarding the forest resources, it is known that the logging business started to make a significant contribution to the Malaysian economy in the 19th century. Now, it is estimated that 59% of Malaysia's land area is still forest.

The rapid expansion of the resin industry, especially after the 1960s, has resulted in erosion problems in the country's forests. However, with the government's commitment to protect the environment and ecological systems, forest resources are managed on a sustainable basis, the side effect is to reduce the rate of tree felling. In addition, a substantial area is being treated as production (silvicultural) forest and efforts to reforest the forest land have been undertaken. The Malaysian government plans to enrich the land area of ​​312.30 square kilometers with rattan under natural forest conditions and between natural rubber plantations as an intermediary crop commodity. To continue to enrich forest resources, fast-growing damar species such as copper meranti, merawan and sesenduk are also planted. At the same time, harvesting high value trees such as teak and other trees for pulp and paper is also encouraged. Rubber, once the mainstay of the Malaysian economy, has now been replaced by palm oil as Malaysia's main agricultural export commodity. Tin and oil are the two main mineral resources that support Malaysia's main economy. Malaysia was once the world's largest tin producer until the collapse of the tin market in the early 1980s. In the 19th and 20th centuries, tin played a dominant role in the Malaysian economy. In 1972 oil and natural gas overtook tin as the main commodity in the mineral refining sector. Meanwhile, the contribution of tin has decreased. Discoveries of oil and natural gas in the offshore oil fields of Sabah, Sarawak and Terengganu have made important contributions to the Malaysian economy.
