Malaysia's population consists of various ethnic groups, with Malays making up 50.4% of the largest race and natives or indigenous people in Sabah and Sarawak making up 11% of the total population. According to the constitutional definition of Malaysia, Malays are Muslims, speak the Malay language, and practice Malay customs and culture. Therefore, technically, a Muslim of any race who practices Malay customs and culture can be seen as Malay and has equal rights when dealing with Malay privileges as stated in the constitution. Over half of the population, non-Malay natives form the predominant group in the state of Sarawak (30% are Iban), and nearly 60% are Sabah (18% are Kadazan-Dusun, and 17% are Bajaus).

Non-Malay Bumiputras are divided into dozens of racial groups but share the same general culture. Until the 20th century, most of them practiced traditional beliefs but now many have converted to Christianity or Islam. The entry of other races more or less reduced the percentage of indigenous people in the two states. There are also a few aboriginal groups on the Peninsula, they are commonly called the Orang Asli. 22.6% of the population are Chinese-Malaysians, while Indian-Malaysians make up 6.8% of the population. Most of the Indian community is Tamil (85%), but various other groups also exist, including Malayalam, Punjabi, and Gujarati. Another part of the Malaysian population is of mixed Middle Eastern, Thai and Indonesian blood. European and Eurasian descent includes the British who have settled in Malaysia since colonial times, and the strong Kristang community in Melaka. Small numbers of Khmer and Vietnamese settled in Malaysia as Vietnam War refugees. The population distribution is highly unequal, with more than 17 million people living in West Malaysia, while not more than 7 million living in East Malaysia. Due to the growth of labor-intensive industries, Malaysia has 10% to 20% immigrant workers with great uncertainty over the number of illegal workers, especially from Indonesia. There are a million legal immigrant workers and possibly other illegal foreigners. The state of Sabah alone has nearly 25% of its 2.7 million residents registered as illegal immigrant workers according to the latest census. However, this figure of 25% is thought to be less than half of the figure estimated by non-governmental organizations. In addition, according to the World Refugee Survey 2008, published by the United States Refugee and Immigrant Commission, Malaysia hosts refugees and asylum seekers close to 155,700. Of this number, nearly 70,500 refugees and asylum seekers are from the Philippines, 69,700 from Myanmar, and 21,800 from Indonesia.

The United States Refugee and Migrant Commission named Malaysia as one of the ten worst places for refugees due to the country's discriminatory practices towards refugees. Malaysian officials reportedly returned migrants directly to people smugglers in 2007, and Malaysia commissioned RELA, a volunteer militia, to enforce the country's immigration laws. Malaysia is a multi-religious society and Islam is the official religion. According to the 2010 Population and Housing Census, approximately 61.3 percent of the population are Muslims; 19.8 percent Buddhist; 9.2 percent Christian; 6.3 percent Hindus; and 3.4 percent Traditional Chinese Religion. The rest are considered to adhere to other religions, for example Animism, Folk religion, Sikhs, and other beliefs; while 0.7% reported having no religion or not providing information. All Malays are considered Muslims (100%) as defined in Article 160 of the Malaysian Constitution. Additional statistics from the 2000 Census show that Chinese-Malaysians are predominantly Buddhist (75.9%), with significant numbers following Taoist (10.6%) and Christian (9.6%) teachings. Most Indian-Malaysians follow Hinduism (84.5%), with a small number following Christians (7.7%) and Muslims (3.8%). Christianity is the dominant religion for the non-Malay bumiputra community (50.1%) with an additional 36.3% identified as Muslim and 7.3% classified officially as following a folk religion. Malaysia's constitution theoretically guarantees freedom of religion. In addition, all non-Muslims who marry Muslims must renounce their religion and convert to Islam. Meanwhile, non-Muslims experience various restrictions in their religious activities, such as building places of worship and celebrating religious ceremonies in several states. Muslims are required to follow the decisions of the Sharia Court when they are concerned with their religion. The jurisdiction of the Sharia Court is limited only to Muslims regarding the Beliefs and Obligations as Muslims, including marriage, inheritance, apostasy, and internal relations among people.

No civil or criminal offenses fall under the jurisdiction of the Syariah Court, which shares the same hierarchy with Malaysia's Civil Courts. Despite being the highest court in the country, the Civil Courts (including the Commonwealth Court, the highest court in Malaysia) cannot in principle render judgments higher than those made by the Sharia Court; and usually they are reluctant to preside over cases involving Islam in the area or questions or challenges to the authority of the Sharia Court. This has led to quite a few issues, particularly involving civil cases between Muslims and non-Muslims, where civil courts have ordered non-Muslims to seek assistance from the Sharia Court. In early 2010 a High Court ruling which ruled allowing the Catholic newspaper the Herald to use the word Allah for God sparked the burning of more than 4 church buildings and several others vandalized by mobs in Kuala Lumpur, the capital city of Malaysia. Education in Malaysia is monitored by the Federal Government's Ministry of Education. Most Malaysian children start school at the age of three to six, in kindergarten. Most kindergartens are privately run, but there are a few government-run kindergartens. Children start primary school at the age of seven for the next six years. There are two main types of government-run or assisted primary schools. Indigenous language schools (SekolahType Kebangsaan) use Chinese or Tamil as the language of instruction. Before proceeding to the secondary education stage, students in grade 6 are required to take the Elementary School Achievement Test (Ujian Prestasi Sekolah Low, UPSR). A program called Stage One Assessment, PTS is used to measure the ability of bright students, and allows them to move from grade 3 to grade 5, skipping grade 4.

However, this program was abolished in 2001. The second phase of education in Malaysia is conducted at the National Middle School (equivalent to SMP+SMA in Indonesia) for five years. National Middle School uses the Malaysian language as the language of instruction. Specifically for Mathematics and Science subjects as well as non-Malay languages, this took effect from 2003, and before that all non-language lessons were taught in the Malaysian language. At the end of Form Three, which is grade three, students are tested in the Lower Secondary Assessment, PMR. In grade five education stage two (Form Five), students take the Malaysian Education Diploma exam (Sijil Belajar Malaysia, SPM), which is the equivalent of the former British Ordinary at stage 'O'. The oldest school in Malaysia is the Penang Free School, also the oldest school in Southeast Asia. Malaysia's second phase of national education is divided into several types, namely National Secondary School, Religious Secondary School, National-Type Secondary School which is also called Mission School (Dakwah School). , Technical School (Secondary School of Engineering), Full Boarding School, and MARA Junior Science College (Maktab Low Science MARA). There are also 60 Chinese Independent High Schools in Malaysia, most of which speak Chinese. Chinese Independent High School is monitored and standardized by the United Chinese School Committees' Association of Malaysia (UCSCAM, more commonly called in Chinese, Dong Zong 董总), however, unlike government schools, each independent school is free to make decisions. Studying in an independent school takes 6 years to graduate, divided into the Junior Stage (3 years) and the Senior Stage (3 years). Students will take a standardized test held by UCSCAM, known as the Unified Examination Certificate (UEC) (Joint Testing Diploma) in Junior High 3 (equivalent to Low Intermediate Assessment) and Senior High 3 (equivalent to stage A).

A number of independent schools conduct classes in Malaysian and English as well as Chinese, allowing students to take the Malaysian Lesson Assessment and Sijil as well. Prior to the introduction of the matriculation system, students wishing to enter public universities had to complete an additional 18 months of secondary schooling in Form Six (grade 6) and take the Malaysian Higher Education Certificate, STPM; the equivalent of British Advanced or 'A' stage. Due to the introduction of the matriculation program as an alternative to STPM in 1999, students who completed the 12-month program of matriculation courses (matriculation colleges in Malaysian) were able to enroll at local universities. However, in the matriculation system, only 10% of the seats are available for non-Bumiputra students and the rest are for Bumiputra students. There are public universities such as the University of Malaya, Malaysia Science University, Putra Malaysia University, Malaysia Technology University, Mara Technology University, and the National University of Malaysia. Private universities also have quite a reputation for international quality education and many students from all over the world are interested in attending these universities. For example Multimedia University, Petronas University of Technology, and others. In addition, four internationally reputable universities have opened branch campuses in Malaysia since 1998. A branch campus can be seen as an 'offshore campus' of a foreign university, offering the same lectures and awards as the main campus. Both local and international students can achieve these identical foreign qualifications in Malaysia at low cost. The foreign university branch campuses in Malaysia are: Monash University Malaysia Campus, Curtin University of Technology Sarawak Campus, Swinburne University of Technology Sarawak Campus, and University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus. Students also have the option of enrolling in private tertiary institutions after completing secondary education. Most institutions have educational links with overseas universities such as those in the United States, United Kingdom and Australia, allowing students to spend the period of their studies earning overseas qualifications.

One example is SEGi College in partnership with the University of Abertay Dundee. Malaysian students study abroad, such as in Indonesia, the United Kingdom, the United States, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, Singapore, Japan and countries in the Middle East, such as Jordan and Egypt. There are also Malaysian students at several universities in South Korea, Germany, France, the People's Republic of China, Ireland, India, Russia, Poland and the Czech Republic. Editor page logged out learn more Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health science Glaciology (from the French glace meaning ice and the Greek Λoγος (logos) meaning science) is the study of the physical and chemical properties of ice and snow (glacier), formation formation, movement and also its evolution. The study of glaciology also includes aspects of other sciences such as geophysics, geology, physical geography, geomorphology, climatology, meteorology, hydrology, biology and ecology. Glaciers are one of the natural phenomena that are extensively reviewed by glaciologists. Structural glaciology is a branch of glaciology that specifically deals with the structure of glaciers. The scope of the discussion is an understanding of the process of distribution and movement of ice debris in the glacier. The formation of the glacial structure is related to the transport of ice debris as a result of internal deformation. The study of glaciology, especially the study of ice masses, is a complex study because it requires an understanding of various processes of dynamics, thermodynamics and long-term behavior of ice sheets. On the other hand, this study was difficult to carry out because the environmental conditions were very cold and dark for a very long time. Remote sensing has provided useful results in glaciological studies, especially in the study of ice masses. Since the 1950s, radar systems have been developed as a remote sensing method for measuring ice thickness. One of the radar systems that is widely used in remote sensing in glaciology is radio echo sounding. The working principle utilizes electromagnetic waves that can penetrate the ice layer. Radio echo sounding is used to obtain information about the electromagnetic properties of different interfaces. These interfaces include ice cubes, ice water, and ice on sea water. The resulting sound echoes back into the radar.

The large use of energy characterizes radio echo sounding. Its power consumption is between 10 Watts and 10 kiloWatts pulse-width that is supplied on a variable basis. The delivery speed is around 0.5 nanoseconds to a few microseconds. Radio echo sounding is used to investigate the characteristics of bedrock down to the thickest permafrost zone. The maximum thickness of the ice it reaches is 4,755 meters. Prior to the 1980s, glaciology was not considered important in international policy studies on climate change. The initial study that started to tie the knot was a project called the Vostok Ice Core which had been under way since the 1970s. The study was conducted at a Soviet Union station located at a remote point in the arctic part of East Antarctica. The Soviet Union and France then collaborated on this study in the mid-1980s. Then in 1987, the two countries published the results of their collaboration regarding the relationship between stable water isotopes and greenhouse gas concentrations. These greenhouse gases include methane and carbon dioxide. The identification process is carried out in air bubbles in the ice core. The isotope ratios in the ice make it clear that there is a clear relationship between the concentration of greenhouse gases and the temperature of the air above the ice sheet. At a depth of 2 kilometers in the ice core, the signal conditions of the glacial-interglacial cycle for about 110 thousand years were recorded. The results of deep-sea sediment records have provided information that temperature signals do not only respond to changes in the geometry of the Earth's orbit. The temperature signal is also getting stronger due to the presence of greenhouse gases. This is why the United Nations launched the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change in 1988. This scientific panel then produces regular reports that provide summaries of the current state of knowledge about the climate system.

Vertigo is divided into three types. The first type is known as objective where the sufferer feels the objects around him are moving. The second type is known as subjective where sufferers feel they are moving when they are still. The third type is known as pseudovertigo, in which the patient feels a spinning sensation in his head. The word vertigo comes from the Latin vertere which means to rotate (2). This disorder occurs due to balance disorders either central or peripheral, abnormalities in the ear often cause vertigo. To determine the abnormalities that cause vertigo, ENT-KL doctors will usually perform an ENG (electronistagmography) examination. Other tests are a CT scan or MRI of the head, which can show bone abnormalities or tumors pressing on nerves. If an infection is suspected, a sample of fluid from the ear or sinuses or from spine. If it is suspected that there is a decrease in blood flow to the brain, then an angiogram will be examined, to see if there is a blockage in the blood vessels leading to the brain. Vertigo is divided into several types, but in general based on the involvement of the vestibule, vertigo is divided into 2 types, namely direct/vestibular vertigo and indirect/non-vestibular vertigo. It is characterized by: a lesion in the peripheral parts of the vestibular apparatus such as: the vestibular organs or the vestibulocochlear nerve. Patients feel that the surrounding environment is spinning (oscillopsia), it feels up and down like being on a ship. Vestibular vertigo is often accompanied by autonomic symptoms such as nausea and vomiting and nystagmus. There are also vestibular lesions in the central part, for example, lesions in the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem.

Central vestibular lesions can also cause direct vertigo, but are generally milder than peripheral lesions. Autonomic symptoms also tend to be minimal or even absent. BPV is by far the most common cause of vertigo. It results from free-floating calcium carbonate crystals that inadvertently enter the long arms of the posterior semicircular canal. Normally these crystals are attached to the utricular macula. With a change in position, the crystals move in the endolymph and displace the cupula, causing vertigo. It is a type of epidemic disease and can affect several members of the same family at once. This disease is more common in spring or early summer. These risk factors suggest that the disease is a viral infection and pathological studies reveal atrophy of one or more of the vestibular nerve trunks, which most closely corresponds to an infectious or postinfectious process. Based on pathological findings, the underlying cause of this disease is an increase in endolymph volume associated with distention of the entire endolymphatic system (endolymphatic hydrops). Rupture of the labyrinth membrane may explain the sudden characteristic of the episodes in this syndrome. Nonvestibular vertigo is often difficult for patients to describe clearly. Patients usually complain of feeling dizzy, empty in the head, and dark in the eyes. Oscillopsia and autonomic symptoms were never found. Lesions in the central nervous system can cause pathological nystagmus. Nonvestibular vertigo can be caused by lesions in the nonvestibular parts of the balance regulatory system or it can be caused by errors in information processing in the central nervous system (eg, due to cerebellar lesions). Orthostatic hypotension and aortic stenosis can be causes of nonvestibular vertigo. Migraine-induced vertigo is due to vasospasm or inherited metabolic defects. It is usually caused by atherosclerosis of the subclavian, spinal, and basilar arteries.

The editor's logged-out page learn more about Mesopotamia (from Ancient Greek: Μεσοποταμία: the land between the rivers; Arabic: بلاد الرافدين‎ (bilād al-rāfidayn); Syriac: ����� having the waters of the waters of the rivers" lies between the two great rivers, the Euphrates and the Tigris. The area that is now the Republic of Iraq was anciently called Mesopotamia, which in Greek means "(area) between the rivers". With long tracts of land and narrow crescent-shaped and fertile soil, this area is also called the "Fertile Crescent".The name Mesopotamia was used by ancient Greek and Latin writers, such as Polybius (2nd century BC) and Strabo (60 BC-20 AD) This fertile land has given rise to many glorious ancient civilizations and collectively known as the Mesopotamian civilization.It is the earliest civilization in West Asia and one of the oldest in the world.According to Christian and Jewish beliefs such as That is to say, in the Old Testament, there is an attempt to link Abraham's family (later called the "Fathers of the Faith" and recognized by the world's three monotheistic religions, Islam, Christianity, and Judaism) with Mesopotamia. In the book of Genesis 11:31 it is said, at one time Abraham's family moved from Ur Kaśdim to Haran before finally moving to Canaan (Areas of Israel and Palestine today). The location of Ur Kaśdim is usually referred to as Tell el-Muqayyar, the site of the ruins of the ancient city of Ur from the Sumerian period. Meanwhile, Haran was located in the northern part of Mesopotamia, on the banks of the Euphrates River. The regional toponymy of Mesopotamia comes from the Ancient Greek roots μέσος (mesos) "middle" and ποταμός (potamos) "river" and literally means "(land) between the rivers". This toponymy is used in the Greek Septuagint (ca.

250 BC) as a translation of its Hebrew equivalent Naharaim. This toponymy was used even earlier by the Greeks as evidenced by the Anabasis of Alexandria, which was written at the end of the 2nd century AD, but specifically refers to sources from the time of Alexander the Great. In the Anabasis, Mesopotamia is used to refer to the region extending east of the Euphrates River in northern Syria. The Aramaic term biritum / birit Narim is related to a similar geographic concept. Later, the term Mesopotamia was more generally applied to all the lands between the Euphrates and Tigris rivers, thus incorporating not only parts of Syria but also almost all of Iraq and southeastern Turkey. The steppe plains west of the Euphrates and the western part of the Zagros Mountains are also often included under the broader term Mesopotamia. A further distinction is usually made between upper or northern Mesopotamia and lower or southern Mesopotamia. Northern Mesopotamia also known as the Jezirah, is the area between the Euphrates and Tigris to Baghdad. Southern Mesopotamia comprises southern Iraq, Kuwait, and western Iran. In modern academic usage, the term Mesopotamia also has a chronological connotation. Often used to refer to this area up to the time of the Muslim Conquest. Names such as Syria, Jezirah, and Iraq were used to describe the region after this time. It has been argued that this euphemism is a Eurocentric term applied to this area during the encroachment of 19th century Westerners. Mesopotamia encompasses the area between the Euphrates and Tigris rivers, which both originate in the Armenian Highlands. The two rivers also receive additional water supplies from many tributaries, and the entire network of these rivers drains a vast mountainous area.

Overland routes in Mesopotamia usually followed the Euphrates River because the banks of the Tigris were for the most part steep and difficult to navigate. The region's climate is semi-arid with vast expanses of desert in the north and 15,000 square kilometers (5,800 square miles) of swampy, muddy, and bubbling terrain in the south. Far to the south, the Euphrates and Tigris join and empty into the Persian Gulf. The arid environment extends from the rain-fed agricultural areas in the north to the south where irrigated agriculture is essential if one is to expect the acquisition of an energy surplus generated over the energy invested (Energy Returned On Energy Invested, EROEI). Irrigation is facilitated by high groundwater levels and melting snow from the high peaks of the Zagros Mountains in the north and from the highlands of Armenia, the source of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers for which the country is named. The benefits of irrigation depend on being able to deploy sufficient manpower to construct and maintain the canals. Thus, it is this factor that since the beginning of time has helped the growth of urban settlements and a centralized system of political power. Agriculture throughout Mesopotamia was supported by nomadic cattle herding. Nomads living in tents herded sheep and goats (and later camels) from the pastures along the rivers in the dry summer months, to the seasonal pastures along the border with the desert in the cold winter months. wet. The Mesopotamian region was generally deprived of stones for building materials, precious metals, and wood, and thus depended throughout its history on the long-distance trade in agricultural produce to obtain these scarce goods from outside the region. In the marshy areas of the south, there existed an elaborate culture of fishing with transport vessels since prehistoric times, which added to the cultural diversity of Mesopotamia.

These periodic failures in the cultural system result from a number of factors. The need for labor has over time resulted in population increases that push the limits of ecological carrying capacity, and when the region experiences a period of climatic chaos, the collapse of the central government and population decline can occur. On the other hand, the military's vulnerability to attacks from fringe tribes from the hill regions or pastures has resulted in a collapse of commerce and the neglect of irrigation networks for a time. Likewise, the centralizing tendencies that existed in the city-states were only centralized government over all of Mesopotamia. When enforced, it tends to be short-lived, and the regional spirit is also fragmented as a whole power into smaller ethnic or regional units. This kind of tendency still continues in Iraq until now. The history of Mesopotamia begins with the growth of a civilization, which is believed to be the center of the oldest civilization in the world, by the Sumerians. The Sumerians built several famous ancient cities, namely Ur, Ereck, Kish, etc. The presence of an imperialistic figure from another nation who also inhabited the Mesopotamia region, the Akkadians, led by Sargon the Great, apparently carried out a political conquest, but not a cultural conquest. In many ways, the Sumerian and Akkadian cultures even acculturated, so that this era of leadership is often called the Sumerian-Akkadian volume. Sumerian interference cannot be underestimated, when the Akkadians were pressured by the Gutti people, the Sumerians who supported the Akkadians, so that they could still rule in the "land between the two rivers". Several other accounts can be put forward to show the relationship between Abraham and Mesopotamia. In Deuteronomy 26:3; The Prophet Musa invited the people to pray to God when offering the first harvest by starting it, My father was an Aramean, a wanderer.

Elsewhere it is said that Isaac, the son of Abraham, was ordered by Abraham to find a wife from the Aram-Mesopotamia (aram-naharayim) region (Genesis 24:2,10). Likewise with Jacob, Abraham's grandson, he was told to go to Padan-Aram to get a wife there (Genesis 28:2). In the Greek Septuagint translation, these last two names are called Mesopotamia. Apart from the explicit indications in the Bible, other information can be found which indicates a strong Mesopotamian influence. The parallels between the stories of Enkidu/Shamhat and Adam/Eve have long been recognized by researchers. The story of the Garden of Eden and the famous story of the Flood, which are told at the beginning of the book of Genesis, are actually heavily influenced by Mesopotamian literature. Usually three works of Mesopotamian literature are designated, namely the Enuma Elis (from 17th century BC), the Epic of Gilgamesh (20th century BC), and Athrahasis (18-17th century BC). These texts are quite well-known and widespread because they are found in various versions and languages, such as Akkadian, Sumerian, Hittite, and Assyrian versions. The similarities between Mesopotamian literature and Biblical texts are so striking that it is often concluded that there is a dependency between the two. Since the Mesopotamian texts date from a much older period than the Biblical texts, it is not surprising that it can be concluded that the Biblical text depended on this Mesopotamian literature. Israeli writers seem to have taken and used these Mesopotamian texts to express their beliefs, and at the same time adapted them to them, especially in the area of ​​monotheism. One possible Mesopotamian influence in the book of Genesis is that Mesopotamian stories were brought to Palestine and then spread during the large-scale migration of people from Mesopotamia which was caused by the somewhat chaotic situation around the 19th century BC. Presumably this is also the context in which Abraham's family moved from Ur to Haran, then to Canaan.

The various customs and regulations reflected in the book of Genesis also find many similarities with the customs and regulations that lived in the Mesopotamian region. For example, Abraham's concern that because he had no children and therefore had to leave everything he owned to his faithful servant, Eliezer (Genesis 15:1-4), turned out to be parallel to the practice of the Nuzi people who lived east of the Tigris River. This can be known through an analysis of legal texts in force at Nuzi, which date back to the 15th century BC. The story of Abraham coming to a foreign land and claiming his wife as his sister (Genesis 12:10-20) often confuses people. Now, however, with the discovery of texts belonging to the Horites in northern Mesopotamia, close to Haran, this can be understood better. In Hori society, the strongest marriage bond is when one wife simultaneously obtains sister status legally. Because of this, it often happens that after the wedding another ceremony is held to adopt the wife as a sister. This is legalized with two documents. First, documents regarding marriage. Second, related to her appointment as a sister. Matthias Henze points out that Nebuchadnezzar's madness in the Book of Daniel refers to the Epic of Gilgamesh. He claims that the author used elements from Enkidu's description to paint a sarcastic and mocking portrait of the Babylonian king. One of the most valuable legacies of the Ancient Mesopotamian civilization for mankind is a collection of laws commonly called the Codex Hammurabi. The collection of laws in the form of black stone blocks was discovered in Susa in 1901 during an expedition by French archaeologists under the leadership of M de Morgan. At the top of the beam, which is now in the Louvre Museum, Paris, there is a relief depicting King Hammurabi of Ancient Babylon (1728-1686 BC) receiving law from the god Shamash, the sun god who is also the patron god of justice.

A comparison with the body of laws found in Exodus 21-23 reveals close parallels. The dependence between the two sets of laws cannot be determined with certainty, but an indirect effect seems very plausible. The Codex Hammurabi, which consists of 282 chapters plus the Prologue and Epilogue, influences not only the body of laws contained in the Bible, but also the legal system in later periods. What's interesting and perhaps makes us (should) be ashamed is that this collection of laws also reminds us that since the 18th century BC, in Mesopotamia there has been a great leader who truly has the awareness that humans must be treated fairly as humans. The Ancient Mesopotamians held ceremonies every month. The theme of the ceremonies and celebrations for each month was determined by at least six main factors: Hunting was popular with the Assyrian kings. Boxing and wrestling are frequently featured in the fine arts, and some form of playing polo is apparently a popular sport, with players sitting on people's shoulders rather than horses. They also play majore, a game similar to rugby, but played with a wooden ball. They also played a board game similar to senet and backgammon, and which is known today as the "Royal Game of Ur." Cultivation of food crops assisted by irrigation systems spread from the Zagros mountains southwards along with the Samara civilization and the Hadji Muhammed civilization from around 5,000 BC. The Sumerian temples served as banks and developed the first large-scale systems of loans and credit, but it was the Babylonians who developed the first commercial banking systems. Mesopotamian economics is in one way or another comparable to post-Keynese economics, but with an "anything goes" approach.

From the beginning of Mesopotamian history up to the time of Ur III, temples controlled up to one-third of all land, but this number decreased over time as court and private ownership of land increased. Ensi is the word used to refer to the person in charge of managing the work of all kinds of agricultural enterprises on the shrine grounds. Commoners were known to be the group that most often worked in agriculture as sharecroppers, especially on land belonging to temples or palaces. The geographical conditions of southern Mesopotamia only allow agriculture to be carried out if it is managed with good irrigation and drainage. This fact had a major impact on the evolution of early Mesopotamian civilization. The need for irrigation prompted the Sumerians, and later the Akkadians, to build their cities along the banks of the Tigris and Euphrates and their tributaries. Major cities, such as Ur and Uruk, were located around tributaries of the Euphrates River, while other cities, notably Lagash, were founded near tributaries of the Tigris. Rivers also have other uses as a source of supply for fish (either as food or as fertilizer), reed, and clay (for building materials). Thanks to irrigation, the food supply in Mesopotamia was comparable to that of the Canadian prairies. The Tigris and Euphrates River basins form the northeastern part of the Fertile Crescent stretch which also includes the Jordan River valley and the Nile River valley. If getting closer to the river makes the land fertile and good for planting, on the other hand the farther the distance from the river makes the land dry and most of it uninhabitable. That is why the development of irrigation was so important to the inhabitants of Mesopotamia. Other Mesopotamian innovations were controlling the flow of water with dams and the use of aqueducts.

The early settlers of Mesopotamia's fertile soil used wooden plows to loosen the soil before planting barley, onions, grapes, turnips, or apples. The inhabitants of Mesopotamia were counted among the first people to make beer and wine. The involvement of skill in farming in Mesopotamia meant that farmers did not depend on slaves to complete the work of their fields, but there were some exceptions. The high risk of employing slaves (slaves running away or rebelling) made many farmers avoid them. Although the rivers supported the life of the people of Mesopotamia, they also destroyed it with floods that often overflowed and destroyed entire cities. The unpredictable Mesopotamian weather often worked against farmers; food crops were often damaged by weather so people needed to maintain reserve food sources such as cattle and sheep. Over time, the southernmost areas of Mesopotamia suffered from the increasing salinity of the soil, resulting in the gradual abandonment of cities and the concentration of power in even more northern Akkadia. The geography of Mesopotamia greatly influenced the political developments in that region. Between the rivers and streams, the Sumerians founded the first cities with their irrigation canals separated from each other by large, open expanses of desert or swamp, where nomadic tribes roamed. Communication between isolated cities is difficult and sometimes dangerous to do. Therefore, each Sumerian city became an independent city-state and staunchly defended its independence. Occasionally one city would try to conquer and unite cities of its own territory, but such attempts were met with resistance and failed for centuries. As a result, the political history of Sumer is full of wars that went on incessantly.

In the end, even Sumer was united by Eannatum, but the union was fragile and failed to last, as the Akkadians triumphantly conquered Sumer in 2331 BC just one generation later. The Akkadian Empire was the first empire that was able to survive beyond a generation and see the peaceful succession of kings. The lifespan of this empire was relatively short, as it was conquered by the Babylonians after surviving for generations. The Mesopotamians believed that their kings and queens descended from the citizens of the City of the Gods, but unlike the Ancient Egyptians, they never believed their kings were true gods. Most of the kings called themselves "king of the universe" or "great king". Another title that is commonly used is "shepherd", because kings must pay attention to the lives of their people. As it grew into an empire, Assyria's territory was divided into regions called provinces. Each province was named after its main city, such as Nineveh, Samaria, Damascus, and Arpad. All provinces are headed by their respective governors whose job is to ensure that everyone pays their taxes. The governors are also obliged to raise troops to go to war and distribute labor when there is a temple construction. A governor is also responsible for enforcing laws in the province he or she presides over. This method made it easier to control a large empire. Although previously just a small country in Sumer, Babylon grew rapidly during the reign of Hammurabi. He was known as the "creator of the rule of law," and soon Babylon became one of the main cities in Mesopotamia. Babylon was later called Babylonia, which means "archway of the gods." The city is also one of the greatest centers of learning in history. With the end of the Uruk era, walled cities grew and many isolated villages from the Ubaid era were abandoned implying an increase in group violence.

An early king, Lugalbanda, is thought to have built white walls around the city. As city-states began to grow, their spheres of influence overlapped, giving rise to debates among other city-states, especially over land and canals. These debates were recorded on clay tablets several hundred years before the outbreak of major wars—the first record of war was written around 3200 B.C. However, it did not become commonplace until about 2500 BC. An Early Dynasty II (Ensi) king of Uruk in Sumer, Gilgamesh (2600 BC), was praised for his success in fighting Humbaba, guardian of the Aras Mountains, and later in many verses and carols he was also praised as being two-thirds god and only one third man. The Late Early Dynastic III (2600–2350 BC) Stele of Vultures, which commemorates Eannatum of Lagash's victory over the neighboring rival city of Umma, is the oldest monument in the world extolling an act of massacre. From that time onwards, warfare was made a part of the Mesopotamian political system. Occasionally a neutral city can act as a mediator for two cities that are fighting each other. This situation encouraged the formation of inter-city unions which later developed into regional states. When empires formed, they also went to war but more often against foreign countries. King Sargon for example, conquered all the cities in Sumer, some cities in Mari, and then went to war against northern Syria. Many Assyrian and Babylonian palace walls were decorated with pictures of victorious battles and enemies fleeing or hiding behind reeds. The Mesopotamian city-states drew up their legal texts based on judicial decrees and laws of kings.

The legal texts of Urukagina and Lipit Isytar have been found. The most famous legal texts come from Hammurabi, who became famous after his death for his legal instruments, namely the Hammurabi Legal Texts (compiled c. 1780 BC), which are one of the oldest legal instruments ever found and one of the first examples of such documents dating from Ancient Mesopotamia. Hammurabi established over 200 laws for Mesopotamia. The study of these rules shows the weakening of women's rights, and the increasingly cruel treatment of slaves. Mesopotamian art rivals Ancient Egyptian art both in terms of grandeur, sophistication, and the level of complexity in the western region of Eurasia from the 4th millennium BC to it was conquered by the Persian Achaemenid Empire in the 6th century BC. The remains of Mesopotamian art are mainly in the form of highly durable stone and clay sculptural types; few surviving paintings remain, but they suggest that Mesopotamian painting was mainly in the form of applying color to ornate geometric and floral patterns, although most of the statues were also coloured. During the early literacy era, when Mesopotamia was under the rule of Uruk, sophisticated works such as the Warka Vessel and cylinder stamps were produced. The Guennol Lioness is an attractive small limestone statue from Elam circa 3000–2800 BC, half human, half lion. Not long after that time, there appeared a number of statues of large-eyed priests and worshippers, mostly made of alabaster and up to a foot high, who were seen attending pagan temple ceremonies, but only a small number of these statues are still alive. survive. Statues from the Sumerian and Akkadian periods generally have large, wide-eyed eyes and long beards on male figures.

Many masterpieces have also been found in the royal tombs at Ur (ca. 2650 BC), including two figures of a lamb in a thicket, a copper bull, and an ox head on one of the lyres from Ur. From the later ages before the rise of the New Assyrian Empire, Mesopotamian art survived in several forms: cylindrical stamps, relatively small whole statues, and reliefs of various sizes, including inexpensive plaques of molded earthenware for the home. lived, some related to religion and some apparently not. Burney's relief is an unusually large (20 x 15 in) terracotta plaque of unusual complexity showing a winged and legged goddess of a bird of prey, escorted by owls and lions. This relief dates from the 18th or 19th century BC, and may also be a print. Stone inscriptions, votive offerings, or plaques commemorating war victories and ceremonial feasts, were also found in temples, which, unlike their more formal government counterparts, did not contain enough lots of writing to explain the stuff; The fragment of the Stele of the Vultures is an early example of written materials, and the Assyrian Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser III is a large, sturdy inscription from later times. The conquest of all of Mesopotamia and the surrounding areas by the Assyrians made the country larger and more prosperous than before, and the display of stunning works of art in palaces and public places was also meant to rival the splendor of the fine arts of their neighbours. Egyptian Empire. The Assyrians developed a style of art consisting of vast backgrounds filled with meticulously detailed narrative flat reliefs set in stone for palaces, depicting scenes of war or hunting; The British Museum has a collection of such reliefs.

The Assyrians produced very few fully carved statues, except for giant guardian figures, often in the form of a human-headed lamassu, carved into bas-reliefs on two sides of a rectangular block, with the head fully carved (as well as the five limbs, so they appear to be sculpted). intact from each side of the beam). Even before taking control of Mesopotamia they had carried on the tradition of making cylindrical stamps with designs that were often vivid and artistic. The study of the architecture of Ancient Mesopotamia is based on available archaeological evidence such as drawings of buildings, and texts on construction practices. Scholarly works usually concentrate on temples, palaces, city walls and gates, and other monumental structures. However, occasionally scientific works related to residential architecture are also produced. Surface surveys in archeology have also made it possible to make studies of the urban layout of early Mesopotamian cities. Bricks were the most widely used building material because they were readily available and affordable, while building stones had to be imported from places quite far from most of the cities. The ziggurat was the most prominent form of building, and cities often had large gates. The most famous of these is the Ishtar Gate of the city of Babylon which was built during the New Babylonian era, decorated with animals sculpted in colorful bricks, most of which are now in the collection of the Pergamon Museum in Berlin. The most prominent remains of early Mesopotamia are the temple clusters at Uruk from the 4th millennium BC, temples and palaces at Early Dynastic period sites in the Diyala River valley such as Khafajah and Tell Asmar, remains of the Third Dynasty of Ur at Nippur (Sacred of Enlil) and Ur (shrine of Nanna), remains from the Middle Bronze Age at Syrian-Turkish sites such as Ebla, Mari, Alalakh, Aleppo and Kultepe, palaces late Bronze Age palaces at Bogazkoy (Hattusha), Ugarit, Assyria and Nuzi, Iron Age palaces and temples at Assyrian (Kalhu/Nimrud, Khorsabad, Nineveh) sites, Babylon (Babylon), Urartu (Tushpa/ Van, Kalesi, Cavustepe, Ayanis, Armavir, Erebuni, Bastam) and New Hittites (Karkamis, Tell Halaf, Karatepe).

Jordan (Arabic: اَلأُرْدُن‎; Al-'Urdun), formally the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan (اَلمَمْلَكَة اَلأُرْدُنِيَّة اَلهَاشِمِيَّة; Al-Mamlaka al-Urduniyya al-Hashemiyya) is a kingdom in the West Bank Jordan River. The country is bordered by Saudi Arabia to the east and southeast, Iraq to the northeast, Syria to the north, and Israel and Palestine to the west, sharing control of the Dead Sea. Jordan's only port is on the southwest tip of the Gulf of Aqaba, parts of which are also controlled by Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. More than half of Jordan is covered by the Arabian Desert. However, the western part of Jordan is forested and arable land. Jordan is part of the Fertile Crescent. The capital and seat of government is Amman. Jordan was founded in 1921, and recognized by the League of Nations as a state under a British mandate in 1922 known as the Emirate of Transjordan. In 1946, Jordan joined the United Nations as an independent state, officially known as the "Hashimid Kingdom of Jordan". In ancient times, the region that is now Jordan was the heart of an ancient civilization that benefited from its geographical location in the Fertile Crescent region that included Babylon and Canaan. Later, Jordan became home to several ancient kingdoms including: The Kingdoms of Edom, Moab, Ammon, and the prominent Nabathic kingdom: Petra. However, across different historical eras, parts of the country came under the control of neighboring powers, such as Ancient Egypt during its wars with Babylon and the Hittites; and at various times by the Israelites who were taken during the Babylonian captivity, and who were later defeated by the Moabites as recorded in the Moabite Stone.

Furthermore, and because of its strategic location in the middle of the ancient world, Jordan was also under the control of the ancient Greek, Persian, Roman and later empires of the Byzantines. Still, the Nabataeans established an independent kingdom covering most of modern Jordan and adjacent areas, for several centuries, before being finally conquered by the Roman Empire. However, apart from Petra, the Romans maintained the prosperity of most of the ancient cities in Jordan which enjoyed a sort of city-state autonomy under the umbrella of the alliance of the Decapolis. With the decline of the Roman Empire, Jordan came under the control of the Arab kingdom of Ghassan. In the 7th century, and because of its proximity to Damascus, Jordan became one of the important domains for the Arab-Islamic Caliphate and thereby also secured several centuries of stability and prosperity, which allowed the current Islamic Arab identity to emerge. In the 11th century, Jordan witnessed a phase of instability, as it became one of the core zones of the Crusades which ended in defeat by the Ayyubid dynasty. Jordan also suffered from the Mongol attacks which were blocked by the Mamluks. In 1516, Jordan became part of the Ottoman Empire and remained in this state until 1918, when the Great Arab Rebel Army took over, and secured modern Jordan with the help and support of local Jordanian tribes. As a witness to Jordan's rich history, the Nabeth civilization left behind many great archaeological sites in Petra, which is considered one of the New Seven Wonders of the World and has been recognized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) as a World Heritage Site. Apart from Petra, other civilizations also left their archaeological traces in Jordan such as Hellenistic and Roman through ruins in the cities of the Decapolis: Jerash, Umm Qais, Amman, Kapitolias (Beit Ras), Rafana, Pella, and Irbid and the Byzantine site Umm ar- Rasas (a World Heritage Site).

The Arab-Islamic caliphate also left a unique architectural imprint which manifested itself in desert palaces including Qasr Mshatta, Qasr al Hallabat, and Qasr Amra which were recognized as World Heritage Sites; in addition to the castles of Ajloun and Al Karak which combines the era of the Crusades, the Ayyubid Dynasty, and the Mamluks. The latter left the Ottoman Empire some features of the city, such as mosques, cemeteries, train stations and castles. Most of modern Jordan was urban. Jordan is classified as a country with a high level of "human development" according to the 2010 Human Development Report. Furthermore, Jordan is also classified as a growth market with a free market economy according to the CIA World Factbook. Jordan is also seen as an "upper-middle income" economy. The free trade agreement with the United States effective since December 2001 removes all levies for almost all commodities between the two countries. Jordan also enjoys "advanced/leading status" with the European Union since December 2010 as well as being a member of the Europe-Middle East free trade area. Jordan follows more free trade agreements than any other country in the region. Jordan has a "pro-Western" policy with very close ties to the United States and the United Kingdom, and has been a major ally (non-NATO member) of the United States since 1996. Jordan is a founding member of the Arab League, and the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OKI). Recently, Jordan has been invited to join the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC). The Jordanian government is one of three 22-nation Arab League members that have diplomatic relations with Israel, the other two being the Egyptian government and the Palestinian government. Jordan is a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO), Arab Fund for Social and Economic Development, Arab Parliament, Arab Mining and Industrial Development Organization, Arab Monetary Fund, International Monetary Fund, International Criminal Court, United Nations Human Rights Council, Region Greater Arab Free Trade, United Nations Social and Economic Commission for West Asia, European Environmental Policy, and United Nations.

Jordan has received an influx of Palestinian refugees for more than 3 decades, making it one of the world's largest refugee hosts. Like Thales, he and Anaximenes are classified as philosophers from Miletus who became the pioneers of Western philosophy. Anaximander was the first philosopher to leave evidence of writing in prose. However, only one fragment of Anaximander's writings has survived to this day. According to Apollodorus, an ancient Greek writer, Anaximanders (610-546 BC) was 63 years old when the 58th Olympiad was held in 547/546 BC. Therefore, it is estimated that Anaximander was born around 610 BC. Then it is also stated that Anaximander died not long after the Olympics ended, so the time of his death is estimated at 546 BC. According to ancient Greek tradition, Anaximander had services in astronomy and geography. For example, Anaximander is said to be the first person to make a map of the earth. His efforts in geography can be seen when he led an expedition from Miletus to found a new overseas city to Apollonia on the Black Sea. Additionally, Anaximander had invented, or adapted, a simple sundial called the gnomon. Plus, he is able to predict when an earthquake will occur. Then he also investigated natural phenomena such as eclipses, lightning, and also about the origin of life, including the origin of humans. Although he was 15 years younger than Thales, he died two years before his teacher. Although Anaximander was a pupil of Thales, he became famous precisely for criticizing his teacher's view of water as the basic principle (arche) of all things. According to him, if water is the basic principle of all things, then water should be present in all things, and there should be no substance to oppose it.

But in reality, water and fire are opposites so that water is not the substance that is in everything. Because of this, Anaximander argued that it was impossible to find these basic principles from empirical matter. The basic principle must be in something deeper and cannot be observed by the five senses. Anaximander said that the basic principle of everything is to apeiron. To apeiron comes from the Greek, which is a combination of a and peras which means without limit. It is an abstract principle which is the basic principle of everything. He is divine, eternal, irreversible, and all-pervading. It is from this principle that everything that exists in the universe as opposing elements (hot and cold, dry and wet, night and light) originates. Then to this principle all will eventually return. With the principle to apeiron, Anaximander builds his view of the universe. According to Anaximander, from to apeiron come all opposites, which are constantly at war with one another. The hot covers the cold so that the cold is contained within. From that cold came the liquid and frozen. What is frozen is what then becomes the earth. The flames that covered the cold were then shattered as well. The fragments swirled and then separated to form the sun, moon and stars. The Earth is said to be cylindrical in shape, which is three times as wide as it is tall. The earth did not fall because it is at the center of the universe, at the same distance from all other objects. Regarding the earth, Thales has explained that it floats above the seas. However, it is also necessary to explain the origin of the oceans.

An ecosystem can also be said to be a complete and comprehensive unitary arrangement between all elements of the environment that influence each other. An ecosystem is an amalgamation of each biosystem unit that involves reciprocal interactions between organisms and the physical environment so that the flow of energy leads to a certain biotic structure and a material cycle occurs between organisms and inorganics. The sun is the source of all existing energy. In an ecosystem, organisms in a community develop together with the physical environment as a system. Organisms will adapt to the physical environment, otherwise organisms also affect the physical environment for the purposes of life. This definition is based on the Gaia Hypothesis, namely: "organisms, especially microorganisms, together with the physical environment produce a control system that maintains conditions on earth suitable for life". This has led to the fact that the chemistry of the atmosphere and Earth is very controlled and very different from that of the other planets in the solar system. The presence, abundance and distribution of a species in an ecosystem is determined by the level of availability of resources and conditions of chemical and physical factors that must be within the range that can be tolerated by the species, this is what is called the law of tolerance. For example: Pandas have a wide tolerance for temperature, but has a narrow tolerance for its food, namely bamboo. Thus, pandas can live in ecosystems under any conditions as long as the ecosystem has bamboo as a food source. Unlike other living things, humans can widen their range of tolerance because of their ability to think, develop technology and manipulate nature.

Ecosystems are formed from environmental elements that have two roles, namely autotrophic and heterotrophic. Autotrophic is the role of environmental elements as food providers independently with the help of solar energy. While heterotrophic is the role of environmental elements as beneficiaries of the existence of food. The food produced can be either organic or inorganic. The environmental elements that form ecosystems are abiotic, biotic, producers, consumers, and decomposers. Based on their roles and functions, living things are divided into two types, namely: The heterotrophic component consists of organisms that utilize organic materials provided by other organisms as food. Heterotrophic components are also called macroconsumers (fagotrophs) because the food eaten is smaller. Heterotrophs include humans, animals, fungi and microbes. Decomposers or decomposers are organisms that decompose organic matter derived from dead organisms. Decomposers are also called macroconsumers (sapotrophs) because the food they eat is larger. Decomposing organisms absorb some of the results of this breakdown and release simple materials that can be reused by producers. Classified as decomposers are bacteria and fungi. The editor page that has logged out learn more Homeostasis is the automatic processes and mechanisms by which living things maintain constant conditions so that their bodies can function normally, despite changes in the environment inside or outside the body. This constant state includes variables, such as body temperature and body fluid balance, which are maintained within predetermined limits (which are called homeostatic ranges). Examples of other variables are the pH of the extracellular fluid, the concentrations of sodium, potassium, and calcium ions, and blood sugar levels. These things need to be maintained even though the environment, diet, and body activities are constantly changing. Each of these variables is controlled by one or several mechanisms that together sustain life. When things are in optimal conditions, homeostasis appears as a natural resistance to change. Balanced conditions are maintained and regulated by many mechanisms. All mechanisms that control homeostasis have at least three interdependent components, namely receptors, control centers, and effectors, each of which has its own for each regulated variable. Receptors are sensing components that monitor and respond to changes in the environment, both external and internal. Receptors include temperature receptors and mechanical receptors. Control centers such as the respiratory center and the renin-angiotensin system. The effector is the target that is acted upon so that changes are returned to their normal state. The concept of regulation of the internal environment was explained by the French physiologist Claude Bernard in 1849, while the word homeostasis was coined by Walter Bradford Cannon in 1926. In 1932, Joseph Barcroft, a British physiologist, said that the higher functions of the brain require the most internal environment. stable. For Barcroft, homeostasis is not only regulated by the brain, but also serves the brain. Homeostasis is an almost exclusively biological term, which refers to the concept explained by Bernard and Cannon, regarding the constant internal environment in which the body's cells live and survive.

The term cybernetics is applied to control systems such as thermostats, which function as mechanisms to maintain homeostasis, but are often defined much more broadly than the biological term homeostasis. The word homeostasis itself combines new Latin words from Ancient Greek: ὅμοιος homoios, "similar to" and στάσις stasis, "to remain still", which results in the compound word "remaining the same". Metabolic processes in all organisms can only occur in a very specific physical and chemical environment. Conditions vary from organism to organism and depend on whether chemical processes take place inside the cells or in the interstitial fluid that bathes the cells. The best known mechanisms of homeostasis in mammals are regulators which keep the composition of the extracellular fluid (or "internal environment") constant, especially with regard to temperature, pH, osmolality, and concentrations of sodium, potassium, glucose, carbon dioxide, and oxygen. There are many other homeostatic mechanisms that regulate various aspects of physiology in the body. When the level of a variable is higher or lower than required, each of these conditions is often preceded by hyper- and hypo-, such as hyperthermia and hypothermia or hypertension and hypotension. If an entity is controlled through homeostasis, that does not imply that its values ​​must be strictly stable to maintain health. Core body temperature, for example, is regulated by homeostatic mechanisms by temperature sensors, one of which is the hypothalamus in the brain. However, the set point of a regulator is reset regularly. For example, core body temperature in humans varies throughout the day (influenced by circadian rhythms), with the lowest temperature occurring at night and the highest in the afternoon. Normal temperature also varies due to the menstrual cycle. The temperature regulator set point is reset during infection to produce fever. Organisms are able to adapt to various conditions, such as changes in temperature or oxygen levels at a certain altitude, through the acclimatization process.

The editor's page is out of the log learn more The plow (also known as Luku and Tenggala) is an agricultural tool used to loosen the soil before planting and sowing seeds, it is also one of the simplest and most useful tools in history. reference] In the early days when agriculture began to develop, humans only used shovels. It was easy for the people who lived in very fertile areas such as the banks of the Nile, where the annual floods renewed the soil in the area. However, for regular farming in less fertile areas, the soil must be loosened so that afterwards it can make furrows for sowing seeds. The main purpose of the plowing is to bring the fertile inner soil to the surface. The plow is usually pulled by an ox. However, in some areas of both poor and developing countries, plows are pulled by horses. Meanwhile, in developed countries, plow engines powered by fossil fuels have been used. Piracy starts from hoeing activities. When agriculture was first developing, hoes and similar tools were used in areas where annual flooding restored soil fertility, such as the banks of the Nile. Hoes are used to make furrows for planting seeds. The hoe is an innovation developed independently between tribes and cultures. Digging is still a method of tillage in tropical countries and steep farmlands. However, modern farmers still use hoes, although rarely, to cultivate narrow areas of land when using tractors is not efficient. The Ard plow is found in Egypt, thought to have been originally pulled by humans, but after the domestication of the ox around 6000 BC by the Indus Valley Civilization, the ox was used as a puller for the ard plow.

The part that touches the ground is the sharp part that moves and makes a groove along the ground. Ard is more suitable for soils containing clay or sand which are naturally fertile with annual flooding such as in the Nile valley and around the fertile new moon. Plow plow develops especially in areas that do not get annual flooding to restore soil fertility; usually in areas far from rivers. In areas with this type, the soil must be turned periodically so that the fertility of the inner soil rises to the top so that it can be used by plants. The short plow design allows deeper penetration while lifting the soil from the inside to go to the surface and the soil on the surface goes down by turning it over. The short plow design made of wood tends to be brittle and easily damaged when working on heavy ground. Also, for deeper penetration in heavy soils, wooden plows cannot be used. Before the Han dynasty, plows in China were made primarily of wood except for the metal plowshares. This is the era where the first known use of metal (iron) in the plow to increase the weight of the plow and increase its strength against the ground. Roman civilization began to develop similar plows with added wheels, in the 3rd and 4th centuries AD. The design of the calipers has not changed for at least a thousand years. A new fundamental change occurred when the Age of Enlightenment began. Joseph Foljambe at Rotherham designed the Rotherham Plow. Developments in metallurgy have led to the development of plows to be more planned with thicker but softer iron alloys for plowshares so they don't break easily.

Resi Wiswamitra is a well-known figure in Hinduism and appears in many Hindu legends and mythologies with various versions. Utopian ideals often emphasize the egalitarian principles of equality in the fields of economy, government, and justice—though by no means exclusive—with the method and structure of the proposed implementation varying by ideology. According to Lyman Tower Sargent, "there are socialists, capitalists, monarchists, democratic, anarchists, ecologists, feminists, patriarchals, egalitarians, hierarchists, racists, leftists, rightists, reformers, free loves, nuclear families, extended families, and many more. utopians". This word was coined from the Greek by Sir Thomas More for his book Utopia in Latin published in 1516; the book describes a society on a fictional island in the Atlantic Ocean. The term is then used to describe both the intentional community that seeks to create an ideal society, and the imaginary society depicted in works of fiction. Various alternative views regarding the structural and qualitative attributes of society have given rise to other concepts, the most prominent of which is dystopia. The term utopia was coined in Greek by Sir Thomas More for his book Utopia published in 1516, describing a society on an imaginary island in the Atlantic Ocean. The word is derived from the Greek words οὐ ("nothing") and τόπος ("place") and means "no place", and expressly describes any 'non-existent' society. In standard usage, however, the word's meaning has been narrowed and is now commonly used to describe a non-existent society which is meant to be seen as a far better representation of contemporary society. Eutopia, derived from the Greek words εὖ ("good" or "good") and τόπος ("place"), means "good place", and is actually the correct term to describe a positive utopia.

The five books of the Torah are: The word torah is from the Hebrew verb yarah. In the hifil conjugation, the word ירה (yarah) means "to teach, teach, show" (eg Leviticus 10:11). So the word torah can mean "teaching" or "instruction", it can be teachings from the mother, teachings from the father, or teachings from God. The most frequently used translation, "law", is actually a misnomer, since the Hebrew word for "law" is din. Misunderstanding "Torah" as "Law" can be an obstacle to "understanding the thoughts which are abstracted by the talmudic term torah (תלמוד תורה, "Torah lessons").. Furthermore, the word "torah" is more used in a broad sense, covering both written and oral regulations and eventually encompasses all the teachings of Judaism, including the Mishnah, the Talmud, the Midrash and others. In addition, it can also be translated as "teaching, instruction, commandment", or "custom" or system.In the Hebrew Bible, this title is used for the first part ("Ta-" of "Tanakh") is "Torah of Moses". This title is actually never found in the Torah itself or in the literature of the Babylonian exile period. This name is used in the book of Joshua (Joshua 8:31–32 ; Joshua 23:6) as well as the Books of 1 and 2 Kings (1 Kings 2:3; 2 Kings 14:6; 2 Kings 23:25), although it is uncertain whether this actually includes all 5 books.

On the other hand, it is possible that its usage after the Babylonian exile (Malachi 3:22; Daniel 9:11, 13; Ezra 3:2; 7:6; Nehemiah 8:1; 2 Chronicles 23:18; 30:16) is understood to mean the whole . Other ancient titles "Book of Moses" (Ezra 6:18; Nehemiah 13:1; 2 Chronicles 35:12; 25:4; compare 2 Kings 14:6) and "Torah" (Nehemiah 8:3) appear to be an abbreviation of the full name, "The Book of the Law of God" (Nehemiah 8:8, 18; 10:29–30; compare Nehemiah 9:3). The term Pentateuch, first used by Greek-speaking Jews in the city of Alexandria, means "five books", or as "Law", or "Law of Moses". Muslims call the "Torah" the Tawrat (Arabic: توراة‎, "Laws"), the Arabic word for the revelation given to the prophet Musa (موسى, Musa in Arabic script). The first five books are considered important because they contain the rules that are believed to have been written or compiled by Moses. In rabbinical literature, the word "torah" refers to these 5 books as follows: as well as orally, revealed to Moses on Mount Sinai. According to manuscripts dated by Orthodox rabbis, this revelation occurred in 1312 B.C.; or according to another calculation, in 1280 BC. Medieval Jewish mysticism believed that the Torah was created before the creation of the world, and was used as the blueprint for creation in the Book of Genesis. Some rabbinical sources state that the entire Torah was given at once on this occasion. Other rabbinical sources generally believe that the Torah was revealed to Moses over a period of years, and was completed at his death. All classical rabbinical views hold that the Torah is wholly or almost entirely of Mosaic origin and of divine origin. Ultimately, of the more than 300,000 letters in the Torah, there are at most a dozen where a letter is questioned. This means that the current text of the Torah is more than 99.99% correct. Torah reading (Hebrew: קריאת התורה, K'riat HaTorah ; "Torah reading") is a Jewish religious ritual involving the public reading of a passage from the Torah Scroll (Sefer Torah). This term often refers to the entire ceremony from the removal of the Torah scroll from its place (ark), singing the appropriate song in a special cantillation, until the return of the scroll to the ark. This is different from the academic study of Torah. The public reading of the Torah was introduced by Ezra, the scribe, after the Jews returned from exile to Babylon (~ 537 BC), as recorded in the Book of Nehemiah. Editor logged out page learn more A predator is any type of animal that has a habit of eating other animals. Animals that are hunted by predators are called prey. The predator usually comes from the carnivore type. Some types of predators are ants and birds. The presence of predators can control the population of an animal species, especially on agricultural land. One of the ways that predators are threatened is by the use of pesticides. In an ecosystem there are conditions in which living things eat and are eaten by each other. These conditions in a certain sequence form a food chain. The formation of a food chain is caused by the existence of two types of living things, namely prey and predators. Living things that eat are called predators. Meanwhile, living things that are targeted to be eaten are called prey. In the food chain, predators are generally referred to as consumers. The position of predators in the food chain is at the middle and top trophic levels. In the food chain, carnivore predators prey on herbivore animals. Predators kill their prey to satisfy their food needs. The process of predation by predators can occur at any stage of development in the prey. Predators usually immobilize their prey before eating it. Once the prey is motionless, the predator eats it quickly. Predators need prey of more than one type. Predatory growth can occur if the predator eats more than one type of prey during its life. Carnivorous predators prey on other animals to eat the meat, bones and eggs of their prey. In general, predators are animals that have a larger body than other animals that become their prey. For example, snakes that eat mice, or eagles that eat rabbits. However, some predators are smaller than their prey. For example, tigers and lions prey on giraffes and buffalo.

In tropical ecosystems, ants are an important predator group. The ability of ants as predators is the biological control of ants. Ant species that have a major role in biological control, for example weaver ants. Its ability is to prey on eggs, larvae, pupae and imago insects that become pests. However, ants can experience a decrease in their ability along with changes in the structure of the vegetation in their habitat. Ants in this case play a role in controlling pest populations. Another advantage is that ants are able to engineer ecosystems by aerating the soil and making nutrient circulation better. On the other hand, ants play a detrimental role in tropical habitats. Ants have the ability to invade and then attack and dominate, thereby threatening the local fauna and flora. These harmful species, for example, are ants from the Wasmania punctata species, which drastically reduce the diversity of other ant species, causing the extinction of other ant species. Birds are a type of predator with the main prey being insects. In ecosystems, birds play a role in controlling insect populations. Humans engineer the presence of predators to control plant-disturbing organisms. Predators are one of the natural enemies for plant-disturbing organisms and the main natural controllers for pests. Humans use basic ecological knowledge about the natural regulation of populations and the balance of ecosystems. Biological control that is carried out with predators as biological agents is the control of population density of pests. Predator populations as natural control agents in biological control are influenced and determined by the development of pest populations. The existence of plant pest predators is maintained by providing refugia land. This land is mixed cropping land with plant species that act as habitat, food sources and resources for plant pest predators. Several types of refugia plants, namely sunflowers, four o'clock flowers, marigolds, vinca flowers, chicken's comb and bougainvillea.

In 1894 B.C.E., the Amorites established a small sovereign state that also included the administrative city of Babylon. During the time of the Akkadian Empire (2335–2154 BC), Babylon was just a small city in one of its tributaries. This situation changed during the time of the Old Babylonian Empire. Babylon During Hammurabi's reign, Babylon was enlarged and made the capital. Throughout and after Hammurabi's reign, Babylonia was called "Land of the Akkadians" (Akkadian: Māt Akkadī) in memory of the former glory of the Akkadian Empire. In the Christian Bible and the Hebrew Bible/Tanakh, the two countries of Babylon and the capital city of Babylon are referred to as Babylon, or simply the Land of Babylon. The term "Babylon" (Hebrew: בָּבֶל‎ Bavel, Tib. בָּבֶל Bāḇel; Syriac: Hirjik Bāwēl, Aramaic: בבל Bāḇel; Arabic: بَابِل‎ Bābil) is interpreted in Genesis as "confusion", from the verb bilbél (בלבל, "toss about"). Babylonia was often involved in rivalry with the Assyrian Empire in the north and the Elamite Kingdom in the east. Although it did not last long, Babylon became a major power in the Mesopotamia region after Hammurabi (acting ca. 1792–1752 BC according to the Intermediate Chronology or ca. 1696–1654 BC according to the Short Chronology) a new empire, following in the footsteps of the glorious Akkadian Empire, the New Sumerian Empire , and the Old Assyrian Empire. Not long after Hammurabi died, the Babylonian Empire went into decline and returned to being a small kingdom. Like Assyria, the Babylonian Empire preserved written Akkadian (the language of the native peoples) for official affairs, although the founding kings were Amorites who spoke a Northwest Semitic language and the successor kings were Kasi speakers of one of the isolated language.

The Babylonian Empire also preserved the Sumerian language for religious matters (as well as the Assyrian Empire), although Sumerian was no longer the spoken language at the time the Babylonian Empire was founded, having been completely replaced by Akkadian. The customs of the Akkadians and the Sumerians from ancient times became a major element in Babylonian and Assyrian culture. The Babylonian region remained a major center of culture, even after the Babylonian Empire was colonized by other countries. The oldest written record mentioning the existence of the city of Babylon is a clay tablet from the reign of King Sargon the Great (2334–2279 BC) around the 23rd century BC. At that time Babylon was only a city of religion and culture, not yet a big city, let alone an independent city-state. The city of Babylon was then subject to the Akkadian Empire, a state that united all Akkadian and Sumerian-speaking peoples under one government. After the fall of the Akkadian Empire, southern Mesopotamia was under the control of the Gutians decades before the founding of the New Sumerian Empire, which ruled all of Mesopotamia (except the northern region of Assyria), including the city of Babylon. The history of Mesopotamia has been going on for a long time before Babylon was born. The Sumerian civilization emerged in the area around 3500 BC, while Akkadian-speaking societies emerged in the 30th century BC. citation needed] In the 3rd millennium BC, an intimate cultural symbiosis developed between Sumerian and Akkadian speakers, which includes the expansion of bilingualism. The influence of the Sumerian language on Akkadian and vice versa is evident in all aspects, from the absorption of large-scale vocabulary, to syntactic, morphological, and phonological integration. This fact has led scholars to call the Sumerian and Akkadian languages ​​in the 3rd millennium a sprachbund.

Akkadian gradually replaced Sumerian as the spoken language of the peoples of Mesopotamia around the turn from the 3rd millennium BC to the 2nd millennium BC (the exact time frame is still a matter of debate). From about 3500 BC until the rise of the Akkadian Empire in the 24th century BC, the Mesopotamian region was dominated by Sumerian cities and city-states, such as Ur, Lagaš, Uruk, Kiš, Isin, Larsa, Adab, Eridu, Gasur, Assyria , Hamazi, Akšak, Arbela, and Uma, although Akkadian names of Semitic origin began to appear in the king lists of some of these cities (eg Esynuna and Assyria) between the 29th and 25th centuries BC. The religious center throughout Mesopotamia for generations was the city of Nipur, where Enlil was worshiped as the supreme god. The primacy of the city of Nipur remained until it was replaced by the city of Babylon during the reign of Hammurabi. citation needed] During the time of the Akkadian Empire (2334–2154 BC), the Akkadians who were of Semitic blood and the Sumerians who were originally from Mesopotamia were united under one leadership. The Akkadians were able to completely rule over the Sumerians, and eventually came to dominate most of the ancient Near East. The empire eventually fell apart due to economic decline, climate change, and civil war, following invasions by the Guti people from the Zagros Mountain region. Sumer revived when the 3rd kuwangsa of Ur came to power in the 22nd century BC, and expelled the Gutians from southern Mesopotamia in 2161 BC, as surviving tablets and astronomical simulations suggest. It seems that this Kulawangsa also controlled most of the sovereign territory of the Akkadian Assyrian kings in northern Mesopotamia. After the Sumerian Empire once again collapsed with the fall of the kulawangsa "Ur-III" at the hands of the Elamites in 2002 BC, the Amorites (westerners), a people who spoke the languages ​​of the Northwest Semitic family, began to migrate to southern Mesopotamia from northern Syria, and gradually took over most of southern Mesopotamia.

In that area they formed a number of small kingdoms, while the Assyrians re-established their independence in the north. The countries of the south were unable to stem the advance of the Amorites, and may have relied on help from their (Akkadian) compatriots in Assyria.
