An Amorite chief named Sumu-abum purchased a piece of land including the small city of Babylon from the Kingdom of Kazalu, the city-state ruled by his countrymen. His land he made a new country. During his reign, Sumu-abum was busy upholding the sovereignty of his kingdom among the many small city-states that had mushroomed in southern Mesopotamia. Even so, Sumu-abum seemed reluctant to bother with calling himself King of Babylon. This implies that Babylon was still a small city and not yet worthy of being called a kingdom. The Babylonian kings after Sumu-abum were Sumu-la-El, Sabium, and Apil-Sin, who successively ruled without regard for the title king as their predecessors, as can be seen from written records from that era which do not mention Babylon as a kingdom. Sin-Mubalit was the first Babylonian ruler to be officially called King of Babylon, and even then only on a single tablet of clay. During the reign of these Amorite kings, the Babylonian kingdom was still a small state with very limited sovereign territory, and was still overshadowed by its older, larger, and more powerful neighboring kingdoms, such as Isin, Larsa, Assyria in north, and Elam to the east. The Elamites had a large territory in southern Mesopotamia, and most of the early Amorite rulers were subject to the Elamites. Babylon remained a small city in a small country until the reign of the sixth Amorite king, Hammurabi (1792–1750 BCE, or c. 1728–1686 BCE according to the Short Chronology). He initiated the great building in Babylon, and transformed it from a small city into a large city worthy of a king. This leader with a myriad of achievements formed a bureaucracy along with a centralized system of taxation and government. Hammurabi liberated Babylon from Elamite rule, and even expelled the Elamites from southern Mesopotamia.

The area then he conquered systematically. The cities he conquered included Isin, Larsa, Esynuna, Kis, Lagasy, Nipur, Borsipa, Ur, Uruk, Uma, Adab, Sipar, Rapiqum, and Eridu. His conquests brought stability to the south of Mesopotamia which had previously been mired in chaos and united the many small states in the region into one nation. It was during the time of Hamurabilah that the area south of Mesopotamia began to be called Babylon (Greek: Βαβυλωνία, Babylonia). Hammurabi sent his army to the east and invaded the area that a thousand years later became the territory of the Iranian state. He conquered the Elamites, the Gutis, the Lulubi, and the Kasi. To the west, he conquered the Amorite states of Syria (now Syria and Jordan), including Mari and Yamhad, two fairly powerful kingdoms. Hammurabi next fought against the Old Assyrian Empire. The war for sovereignty over Mesopotamia and the Near East was protracted. The Assyrians had controlled most of the Hurian and Hatice areas of southern Anatolia since the 21st century BC, and controlled northeastern Syria and central Mesopotamia in the second half of the 20th century BC. After decades of warring against the great Assyrian kings, Shamsyi-Adad I and Isyme-Dagan I, Hammurabi was finally able to force the next King of Assyria, Mut-Assykur, to pay tribute to Babylon around 1751 BC. This success made Babylonia sovereign over the territories of the Hati people and Hurian people in Anatolia, which had been colonized by Assyria for hundreds of years. One of Hammurabi's most important and last great works was the compilation of Babylonian laws, completing Sumerian, Akkadian, and Assyrian laws that had existed long before. The law was drafted by order of Hammurabi after he had succeeded in expelling the Elamites and establishing his kingdom.

In 1901, a stele containing a copy of the Acts of Hammurabi was discovered by Jacques de Morgan and Jean-Vincent Scheil in Susa, a former Elamite territory. Probably brought from Babylon to Elam as war booty. This inscription is now stored in the Louvre museum. From before 3000 BC to the reign of Hammurabi, the main cultural and religious center in southern Mesopotamia was the city of Nipur, where Enlil was worshiped as a divine being. Hammurabi made the city of Babylon the new cultural and religious center, and made Marduk the supreme god of southern Mesopotamia, while the Assyrian god, and to a certain extent also the goddess Ishtar, remained the main god of the Assyrians in northern Mesopotamia. The city of Babylon came to be known as the "holy city," the obligatory location for the ceremonial coronations of all the legitimate rulers of southern Mesopotamia. Hammurabi transformed the city of Babylon from a small administrative city into a large and powerful city, extending Babylonian power throughout southern Mesopotamia, and erecting a number of magnificent buildings in the city. The Babylonians ruled by Amorite rulers, like their ancestors in earlier regimes, traded regularly with the Amorite city-states and the Canaanites to the west. These well-established trade relations allowed Babylonian officials and military troops to visit Syria and Canaan on occasion, and Amorite merchants to trade freely throughout Mesopotamia. The closeness of the Babylonian kings to the west lasted long enough. Ami-Ditana, great-grandson of Hammurabi, still calls himself "king of the land of the Amorites." Both father and son Ami-Ditana also had typical Amorite names, namely Abi-Esyuh and Ami-Saduqa. The area south of Mesopotamia did not have fortified natural boundaries that could be used as defense bases that made it easy for enemies to enter.

After Hammurabi died, the empire quickly disintegrated. During the reign of Hammurabi's successor, Samsu-iluna (1749–1712 BC), the southern tip of Mesopotamia fell to Ilum-ma-ili, an Akkadian-speaking native king who opposed the sovereignty of the Amorite kings of Babylon. The far south became the Kingdom of the Coastal House, the indigenous nation-state of Mesopotamia that was able to maintain its independence from Babylon until 272 years later. Around 1740 B.C.E., the Akkadian governor of Assyria named Puzur-Sin expelled the Babylonians and their Amorite rulers from Assyria to the north. Puzur-Zin considers King Mut-Assykur to be both a foreigner and a former Babylonian slave. After six years of civil war in the Assyrian Empire, an indigenous king named Adasi succeeded to the throne around 1735 BC, and subsequently ruled over the former Babylonian and Amorite colonies in central Mesopotamia. The same action was also taken by his successor, Bel-bani. The Amorites still had sovereignty over Babylonia, even though their territory had shrunk. Abi-Esyuh, the replacement for Samsyu-iluna, failed to recapture the territory that had been controlled by the kulawangsa Pesisir, and was even defeated by King Damqi-ilisyu II. By the end of his reign, Babylon had fallen into the small and relatively weak state it had initially appeared in, although the city of Babylon was already much larger than it had been before the reign of Hammurabi. Abi-Esyuh was replaced by Ami-Ditana, who was later replaced by Ami-Saduqa. Both Ami-Ditana and Ami-Saduqa were not too weak to try to recapture the areas that were separated from Babylon after the death of Hammurabi, and limited themselves to development activities carried out in a peaceful atmosphere. Syamsu-Ditana was the last Amorite King of Babylon. Early in his reign, Babylon was undermined by the Kasi, a people who spoke an isolated language from the mountainous regions of what is now northwestern Iran.

In 1595 BC, Babylonia was invaded by the Hittites, an Indo-European speaking community from Anatolia. Syamsu-Ditana was overthrown from the throne after the city of Babylon fell into the hands of Mursili I, the Hittite king. The Hittites did not rule Babylonia for long, but the damage they caused eventually opened up an opportunity for their Kasi allies to seize power. In Babylonia, the abundance of clay and the scarcity of stone made mud bricks more widely used.

The Babylonian, Sumerian, and Assyrian temples were gigantic buildings with rough brick walls supported by buttresses and equipped with drains to drain rainwater. One of the drain filters found at Ur was made of lead. The use of bricks became the basis for the development of pseudo and true pillars, frescoes and enamel-coated tiles. Walls were painted in striking colors, and sometimes covered with zinc or gold plates, or with tiles. Painted terracotta cones were glued to the walls with plaster to hold torches. In Babylon, instead of relief, a large number of three-dimensional sculptures were made. The oldest examples of such statues are those of Gudea, which look realistic but seem clunky. The rarity of stones in Babylon caused each stone to be highly valued. It was this respect for the value of stones that pushed the Babylonians to a high degree of perfection in the art of cutting precious stones. Tablets thought to be from the time of the Old Babylonian Empire record the application of mathematics to calculating the variation in the time of day throughout a solar year. The activity of observing celestial phenomena that has been going on for centuries is enshrined in a series of cuneiform tablets known as "Enūma Anu Enlil". The tablet that contains the oldest significant astronomical text extant today is Enūma Anu Enlil Loh 63, namely the Venus Ami-Saduqa tablets. This tablet contains a list of the first and last time Venus rises to the eye in 21 years, and is the oldest evidence showing that planetary phenomena are known to occur periodically. The oldest rectangular astrolabe is thought to be from Babylonian times around 1100 BC. The MUL.APIN manuscript contains lists of stars and constellations as well as schemes for predicting the appearance and setting of the stars, the length of day based on water hours, gnomons and shadows, and intercalation.

The brief renaissance of Babylonian culture in the 7th to 6th centuries B.C. occurred concurrently with a number of important cultural advances. The sexagesimal system is the origin of dividing 1 minute into 60 seconds, dividing 1 hour into 60 minutes, and dividing 1 circle into 360 (60x6) degrees. The Babylonians were able to achieve great achievements in mathematics due to two factors.

First, the number 60 is divisible by many other numbers (2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 10, 12, 15, 20, and 30), making calculations easier. Moreover, unlike the Egyptians and Romans, the Babylonians had a true place-value system. The series of numbers are ordered from left to right, from the largest to the smallest value, very similar to the decimal system used today (734 = 7×100 + 3×10 + 4×1). One of the achievements of the Babylonians in the field of mathematics was correctly calculating the square root of the number 2 up to seven decimal places (YBC clay tablet 7289). The Babylonians seem to have understood the Pythagorean theorem before it was coined by Pythagoras himself, as evidenced by the contents of clay tablets with a date of approximately 1900 BC which Dennis Ramsey translated as follows: The length is equal to 4 and the diagonal is equal to 5. What is the width? The size is not known.4 times 4 is 16 and 5 times 5 is 25. Subtract 16 from 25 and it leaves 9. How many times is 9? 3 times 3 is 9. So the width is 3. Ner (multiple of 600) and sar (a multiple of 3600) is formed from the number 60, corresponding to a distance of 1 degree on the equator. Tablets containing calculations to powers of two and powers of three from 1 to 60 have been found at the Senkera site. Moreover, people who are familiar with sundials, water clocks, levers and pulleys must have qualified knowledge of mechanics. Lathe lenses of lead glass were found by Austen Henry Layard at the Nimrud site together with glass vessels bearing the name Sargon.

The lenses answered the mysteries of the minuscule scripts on some Assyrian tablets. The Babylonians may have been used to applying general rules for measuring the area of ​​a flat shape. They calculated the length of the circumference of a circle using the formula three times the length of the diameter, while the area was calculated using the formula one-twelfth the length of the circumference raised to the power of two, and could be right if π was taken to equal 3. The volume of a cylinder is calculated using the formula for area of ​​base times height, but volume frustum of a cone or square pyramid is calculated in the wrong way, namely with the formula half the area of ​​the base times the height. Recently found a tablet that uses π with a value of 3 1/8 (three eighths). The Babylonians are also known for producing the Babylonian mile, which is roughly equal to today's 11 kilometers (7 miles). The unit used to measure this distance was eventually converted to the mile-time unit which is used to measure the distance traveled by the sun, and therefore a measure of time. The Babylonians also used spacetime graphs to calculate Jupiter's speed. This calculation is a fairly modern idea, which traces back to England and France in the 14th century and predates the integral calculus. Outgoing editor page learn more In geology, a fault or fault is a planar fracture or discontinuity in a volume of rock, where there has been significant displacement as a result of the movement of the rock mass. Large faults in the Earth's crust are the result of the action of plate tectonic forces, with the largest forming boundaries between plates, such as subduction zones or transform faults. The released energy causes rapid movement of active faults which are the main cause of earthquakes. According to geophysics, faults occur when rocks are subjected to low pressure and temperature so that they become brittle. Fault plane is a plane that represents the surface of the fracture on the fault. A fault trace or fault line is the intersection of a fault plane with the ground surface. A common fault trace is plotted on a geological map to represent a fault. Because faults do not usually exist alone, geologists use the term fault zone when referring to complex deformation zones associated with fault planes. Two adjacent non-vertical faults are known as the hanging wall and the footwall. By definition, the hanging wall occurs above the fault plane and the footwall occurs below the fault plane. This terminology comes from the world of mining: when they are working on a tabular mineral body, the miner stands on a footwall under his feet and with the hanging wall above them. Due to the friction and stiffness of the rocks, the rocks cannot slide or flow past one another easily and sometimes all motion stops. When this occurs, stress builds up in the rock and when it reaches a level that exceeds the strain threshold, the accumulated potential energy is dissipated by the release of tension, which is focused onto a plane along which the relative motion is accommodated - the fault.

Stress occurs accumulatively or instantaneously, depending on the rheology of the rock; the ductile lower crust and mantle accumulate deformation gradually through shear forces, whereas the brittle upper crust reacts by fracture - instantaneous release of stresses - causing movement along faults. A fault in ductile rock can also loosen suddenly when the strain rate is too great. The energy released by instantaneous stress-discharge causes earthquakes, a general phenomenon along transform boundaries. Slip is defined as the relative motion of the geological features present on both sides of the fault plane, and is a displacement vector. sense of slip is defined as the relative movement of the rock on each side of the fault with respect to the other side. In measuring horizontal or vertical separation, the throw of the fault is the vertical component of the dip separation and the heave of the fault is the horizontal component, such as . The slip vector can be assessed qualitatively by studying the drag folds of the strata on both sides of the fault. The direction and magnitude of the heave and throw can be measured simply by finding the same point of intersection on both sides of the fault (called the Piercing point). In practice, it is usually only possible to find the slip direction of the fault, and the approximate vectors of the throws and heaves. Based on the direction of release, faults are classified into three: Based on the direction of motion relative to the hanging wall to the foot wall: Based on whether there is rotational motion: Also known as gravity faults, referring to gravity as the main force that moves it. It is also known as an extension fault because it lengthens the layers, or thins, of the Earth's crust. Normal faults that have a flattened fault in the interior of the earth are known as electric faults. This electric fault is also associated with a growth fault, where the deposition and movement of the fault occur simultaneously.

The country can be divided into five natural areas: the narrow, fertile marshy plains along the Atlantic coast (lower coastal plains) where most of the population lives; the belt of white sands further inland (areas of hilly sands and clays), which contains most of Guyana's mineral deposits; dense rainforest (Forested Highland Region) in the south of the country; drier savanna areas in the southwest; and the smallest interior lowlands (interior savannah) consisting mostly of mountains that gradually rise to the Brazilian border. Some of the highest mountains in Guyana are Mount Ayanganna (2,042 m or 6,699 ft), Monte Caburaí (1,465 m or 4,806 ft) and Mount Roraima (2,772 m or 9,094 ft - highest mountain in Guyana) at the Brazil-Guyana-Venezuela border tripoint, part of from the Pakaraima range. Mount Roraima and table mountain in Guyana (tepuis) ​​are said to have been the inspiration for Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's 1912 novel The Lost World (Arthur Conan Doyle). There are also many escarpment volcanoes and waterfalls, including Kaieteur Falls which is believed to be the world's largest single-drop waterfall by volume.

Archaeological experts agree that cultivation in wetlands has its origins in China.

The first evidence of rice paddy fields was found to be dated to 6280 years ago based on carbon dating of rice grains and soil organic matter found at the Chaodun site in Kushan County. At a Neolithic site in Caoxieshan, archaeologists excavated and found a site that is believed to have been a rice field. It is estimated that the site at Caoxieshan dates from 4000 to 3000 BC. In addition there are 10 archaeological sites related to rice fields in Korea. Two of the oldest are in Okhyun and Yaumdong, Ulsan, built during the Mumun pottery period. There is also archaeological evidence that rice (rice that has been removed from the husk) was stored for military use and funeral processions from the Neolithic to the Han Dynasty in China. Paddy fields as an ecosystem are called by an American anthropologist, Geertz, namely very stable or durable rice fields. The rice fields can continue to produce crops that are virtually undiminished from year to year, often even twice a year. The role of water in the paddy ecosystem is very influential on the dynamics of paddy field life. Here, the thin tropical soil character is overcome by adding nutrients to the rice fields with irrigation water to replace nutrients taken from the soil; nitrogen uptake by blue-green algae growing in warm water; bacterial chemical putrefaction of organic matter, including harvested crop residues left in water; filling the air in the soil with the slow movement of water in the fields; and of course the other ecological functions carried out by irrigation are still unknown. Furthermore, in the paddy field ecosystem there are abiotic and biotic components. The abiotic components consist of edaphic factors or soil fertility as seen from the parameters of Cation Exchange Capacity (CEC), soil organic matter content, total N content, available P, and available K in the soil; and the hydrological factor as seen from the parameter of the depth of the paddy water inundation.

Editor's page out log learn more Hipparchus (Greek Ἳππαρχος) (190 BC – 120 BC) was an ancient Greek astronomer, geographer, and mathematician, during the Hellenistic period. Hipparchus was born in Nicaea (now Iznik, Turkey), and probably died on the island of Rhodes. Hipparchus is considered the greatest astronomer of the classical era. He was the first to build an accurate and quantitative model of the motion of the Sun and Moon. For this work he used the observations and knowledge accumulated over centuries by the Chaldeans of Babylonia. He was also the first to compile trigonometry tables, which allowed him to solve triangle problems. With his theory of the sun and moon and his numerical trigonometry, he succeeded in developing a method for predicting solar eclipses. His other accomplishments include the discovery of precession, the compilation of the first star catalog and, possibly, the creation of the astrolabe. Claudius Ptolemaeus, three centuries later, depended heavily on the work of Hipparchus. Ptolemy's astronomical treatise subsequently supplanted the works of Hipparchus. Although Hipparchus wrote at least 14 books, only his commentary on the popular astronomical poem by Aratus has survived by contemporary copyists. Consequently we know very little about the life and work of Hipparchus. Most of what is known about Hipparchus comes from Ptolemy's 2nd century AD work, the Almagest, with additional references to Pappus of Alexandria and Theon of Alexandria (4th century AD) in their commentaries on the Almagest. Hipparcus' work is also known from Strabo's Geographia, and from Pliny the Elder's Naturalis Historia (1st century). The exact history of his life is unknown, but Ptolemy attributes his name to astronomical observations from 147 BC to 127 BC; although it is suspected that the observations had been made earlier than about 162 BC.

The editor's page has logged out learn more Kaharingan is the indigenous religion of the Dayak tribe on the island of Borneo. The Kaharingan religion has existed for a long time in Kalimantan, even before other religions entered Kalimantan. Currently Kaharingan is one of the ancestral religions in Indonesia that still survives and is still adhered to by some Dayak tribes, especially in Central Kalimantan and South Kalimantan. Kaharingan means to grow or live, as in the term danum kaharingan (water of life). Kaharingan adherents believe in God Almighty (Ranying Hatalla Langit), which has been passed down from generation to generation and is internalized by the Dayak people in Kalimantan. The Kaharingan religion has its own symbol, namely the Batang Garing symbol which means the tree of life. The Batang Garing symbol is familiar to the Dayak people because it is often found in many buildings in Central Kalimantan. As a result of the Indonesian government requiring residents and citizens to adhere to one of the religions recognized by the government of the Republic of Indonesia, since 20 April 1980 the Kaharingan religion was finally categorized as a branch of Hinduism (the name became Hindu Kaharingan). So that when making a KTP, adherents of the Kaharingan religion will include Hinduism in their religion column. Like the Tollotang religion, the Bugis tribe has similarities in the use of means of life in carrying out rituals for victims (offerings) which in Hinduism is called Yadnya, which later became Hindu Tollotang. Kaharingan was first introduced to the public by Tjilik Riwut in 1944, when he was the Resident of Sampit based in Banjarmasin. In 1945, the Japanese occupation proposed Kaharingan as the designation of the religion of the Dayak tribe, but this proposal was rejected by the Indonesian government on the grounds that the Kaharingan religion had not yet spread throughout the Indonesian archipelago/regions.

In the end, the Kaharingan adherents chose to integrate the Kaharingan religion with Hinduism so that Kaharingan adherents could have equal rights to life with people of other religions in Indonesia. Gradually, the followers of Kaharingan in Central Kalimantan had a place of worship called Balai Basarah or Balai Kaharingan. Their religious scriptures are the Panaturan and other Kaharingan religious books such as the Song of Kandayu, Talatah Basarah (Collection of Prayers), Tawur (instructions on how to ask for God's help by sowing rice), and so on. Every year the Kaharingan people in Central Kalimantan will hold a festive event called the Kaharingan Diamond Sign Festival where the activities include several Kaharingan religious competitions such as the Karungut chanting competition, the Panaturan holy book reading competition, the Kandayu chanting competition, the traditional Dayak dance competition, and many more. again. Kaharingan adherents in South Kalimantan also have a place of worship called the Kaharingan Traditional Religion Hall. One of the Kaharingan religious ceremonies that is often performed in South Kalimantan is the Aruh Adat or Aruh Baharin ceremony. The Aruh Adat ceremony aims to express gratitude to the Almighty for bestowing abundant rice yields, and at the same time respecting the spirits of the ancestors who are believed to always protect them from disaster. In East Malaysia (Sarawak and Sabah), the Kaharingan religion is not recognized as part of the Hindu community, so it is considered a society that has not adhered to any religion. Now most of the Dayak tribes in Malaysia are Christians, as well as the Dayak tribes in West Kalimantan, where this happened along with the widespread spread of Protestant Christianity in Kalimantan which began in the 1830s. Meanwhile, most of the Dayak tribes in East Kalimantan and North Kalimantan have embraced Islam.

The editor page that has logged out learn more Agriculture is the activity of utilizing biological resources by humans to produce food, industrial raw materials, or energy sources, as well as to manage their environment. The activities of utilizing biological resources that are included in agriculture are commonly understood by people as cultivating plants or cultivating crops and rearing livestock, although its scope can also be in the form of using microorganisms and bioenzymes in the processing of advanced products, such as making cheese and tempeh, or simply extraction, such as catching fish or forest exploitation. The largest part of the world's population makes a living in fields within the scope of agriculture, but agriculture only contributes 4% of world GDP. The agricultural sciences group examines agriculture with the support of supporting sciences. Because agriculture is always bound by space and time, supporting sciences, such as soil science, meteorology, agricultural engineering, biochemistry, and statistics are also studied in agriculture. Farming is a core part of agriculture because it involves a set of activities carried out in cultivation. "Farmers" is a term for those who carry out farming businesses, for example "tobacco farmers" or "fish farmers". Those cultivating livestock are specifically referred to as breeders. Agriculture in a broad sense includes all activities involving the use of living things (including plants, animals and microbes) for the benefit of humans. In a narrow sense, agriculture is defined as plant cultivation activities. Agricultural businesses are given special names for certain farming business subjects. Forestry is farming with plant subjects (usually trees) and cultivated on semi-wild or wild land (forest). Livestock use is subject to dry land animals (particularly all vertebrates except fish and amphibians) or insects (eg bees). The fishery has the subject of aquatic animals (including amphibians and all non-aquatic vertebrates).

An agricultural business can involve these various subjects together for reasons of efficiency and increased profits. Consideration of environmental sustainability results in aspects of natural resource conservation also being part of agricultural business. All agricultural businesses are basically economic activities, so they require the same basic knowledge of business location management, selection of seeds/seedlings, cultivation methods, yield collection, product distribution, product processing and packaging, and marketing. If a farmer looks at all of these aspects with consideration of efficiency to achieve maximum profit then he does intensive farming. Agricultural business viewed in this way is known as agribusiness. Programs and policies that direct agricultural businesses to this perspective are known as intensification. Because industrial agriculture has always applied intensive farming, the two are often confused. The side of industrial agriculture that pays attention to its environment is sustainable agriculture. Sustainable agriculture, also known as its variations such as organic farming or permaculture, incorporates aspects of the sustainability of the carrying capacity of the land as well as the environment and local knowledge as important factors in calculating its efficiency. As a result, sustainable agriculture usually yields lower yields than industrial agriculture. Modern agriculture today usually employs some components of both poles of the agricultural "ideology" mentioned above. In addition to these two, there are also known forms of extensive farming (low input agriculture) which in the most extreme and traditional forms will take the form of subsistence farming, which is only carried out without business motives and solely to meet one's own needs or that of the community. As a business, agriculture has two important characteristics: it always involves large volumes of goods and the production process has a relatively high risk. These two characteristics arise because agriculture involves living things in one or several stages and requires space for these activities and a certain period of time in the production process.

Some modern forms of agriculture (eg algae cultivation, hydroponics) have reduced these characteristics but most of the world's agricultural endeavors still do. The domestication of dogs is thought to have been carried out even when humans were not familiar with cultivation (hunting and gathering communities) and was the first animal rearing and cultivation activity. In addition, the practice of using forests as a source of food is known as the oldest agro-ecosystem. The use of forests as gardens begins with forest-based culture around rivers. Agricultural activities (cultivation of crops and livestock) is one of the earliest activities known to human civilization and completely changes the form of culture. Prehistoric experts generally agree that agriculture first developed around 12,000 years ago from culture in the "fertile crescent" region of the Middle East, which includes the Tigris and Euphrates River basins extending westward to present-day Syria and Jordan. The first evidence found points to the cultivation of grain crops (cereals, especially ancient wheats such as emmer) and legumes in the area. Agriculture changed forms of belief, from worship of hunting gods to worship of gods symbolizing fertility and food availability. As far back as 5300 years ago in China, cats were domesticated to catch rodents which were pests in fields.

Plant cultivation techniques then expanded to the west (Europe and North Africa, at that time the Sahara had not completely become a desert) and east (to East Asia and Southeast Asia). Meanwhile, the peoples of the American continent developed cultivated plants and animals that were completely different from the start. The first livestock to be domesticated were goats/sheep (7000 BC) and pigs (6000 BC), together with the domestication of cats. Cows, horses, buffaloes, yaks began to be developed between 6000 to 3000 years BC. Poultry began to be farmed much later. Silkworms are known to have been domesticated 2000 years BC. Freshwater fish cultivation has only been known since 2000 years ago in China and Japan. Marine fish farming was only known to humans in the 20th century. The cropping system may vary for each farming area, depending on the availability of resources and constraints; geography and climate; government policy; economic, social, and political pressures; and peasant philosophy and culture. Agriculture is one that affects climate change, and climate change has an impact on agriculture. In physics, light is electromagnetic radiation, with both visible and invisible wavelengths. Moreover, light is a packet of particles called photons. Packages of light called the spectrum are then perceived visually by the sense of sight as colors. The field of study of light, known as optics, is an important research area in modern physics. The study of light began with the emergence of the era of classical optics which studied optical quantities such as: intensity, frequency or wavelength, polarization and phase of light. The properties of light and its interaction with the surroundings are carried out using a geometric paraxial approach such as reflection and refraction, and an approach to its physical optical properties, namely: interference, diffraction, dispersion, polarization. Each study of classical optics is called geometrical optics (en:geometrical optics) and physical optics (en:physical optics). At the peak of classical optics, light was defined as an electromagnetic wave and sparked a series of discoveries and thoughts, dating back to 1838 by Michael Faraday with the discovery of cathode rays, 1859 with the theory of black mass radiation by Gustav Kirchhoff, 1877 Ludwig Boltzmann said that the energy states of physical systems can be became discrete, quantum theory as a model of black mass radiation theory by Max Planck in 1899 with the hypothesis that radiated and absorbed energy could be divided into discrete quantities called elemental energies, E. In 1905, Albert Einstein made an experiment on the photoelectric effect, light which shines light on the atom excites electrons to shoot out of their orbits.

In 1924 experiments by Louis de Broglie showed that electrons have particle-wave duality properties, so that the theory of particle-wave duality was born. Albert Einstein then in 1926 made a postulate based on the photoelectric effect, that light is composed of quanta called photons which have the same duality properties. The work of Albert Einstein and Max Planck won the Nobel Prizes in 1921 and 1918 respectively and became the basis for the theory of quantum mechanics developed by many scientists, including Werner Heisenberg, Niels Bohr, Erwin Schrödinger, Max Born, John von Neumann, Paul Dirac, Wolfgang Pauli, David Hilbert, Roy J. Glauber and others. This era was later called the era of modern optics and light was defined as the dualism of electromagnetic transverse waves and streams of particles called photons. Further development occurred in 1953 with the discovery of the maser beam, and laser light in 1960. The era of modern optics did not necessarily end the era of classical optics, but introduced other properties of light, namely diffusion and scattering. The editor page has logged out learn more Species or type is a taxonomic rank used in biological classification to refer to one or more groups of individual living things (populations) that are similar and can fertilize each other in their groups (share genes with each other) ) to produce fertile offspring. A number of groups within a species may not fertilize each other due to geographical barriers but if they are met and mated they can produce fertile offspring. If two different species fertilize each other, they will face the problem of biological inhibition; if it produces healthy offspring, these offspring are usually sterile or sterile. In some cases, this definition is not met, so that the problem of defining the species arises. In these cases, the parameters often used to define species differ, such as DNA similarity, morphology, or ecological niche. Furthermore, the emergence of certain distinctive features can divide species into smaller taxa, such as subspecies. Species that are hypothesized to have a common ancestor are placed in a single genus. Species similarity is assessed based on a comparison of physical attributes and if available, their DNA sequences. All species (except viruses) are given a name in two parts, called the "binomial name", or simply "binomial". The first part of the binomial is the generic name, which is the genus of the species. The second part is called the specific name (a term used only in zoology) or the specific epithet (a term used in botany, which can also be used in zoology). For example, the Boa constrictor is one of four species in the genus Boa. Genus names start with a capital letter, while specific epithets do not. Binomials are italicized when printed and underlined when handwritten.

Species, when referred to in scientific names, abbreviated as sp. (Example Phalaenopsis sp.—means "a kind of Phalaenopsis", shortened by spp. in the plural). A usable definition of the word "species" and reliable methods for identifying specific species are important for stating and testing biological theories and measuring biodiversity, although other taxonomic levels, such as family (tribe), can also be used. considered in larger-scale studies. Extinct species are known only from fossils where it is usually difficult to determine the exact taxonomic level, so higher taxonomic levels, such as family, are often used for fossil-based studies. In animal taxonomy there is one taxon level under species: subspecies (abbreviated as ssp. (but usually not written in the animal's scientific name). In plant, fungal, and bacterial taxonomy there are other taxa under subspecies: varieties, subvarieties, and forms. Total the total non-bacterial and non-archaean species in the world has been estimated at 8.7 million, with previous estimates ranging from two to one hundred million.Most modern textbooks use Ernst Mayr's 1942 definition, known as The Concept of Biological Species as a basis for discussion more on the definition of a species. This is also called the concept of reproduction or isolation. Mayr defines a species as a group of natural populations that are actually or potentially interbreeding, reproductively isolated from other such groups. Scientists have argued that this definition is a consequence of the effects of sexual reproduction on the dynamics of natural selection. The use of the adjective "berpo tension" by Mayr has been a subject of debate; some interpretations exclude unusual or artificial matings that occur only in captivity, or which involve animals that are capable of mating but usually do not do so in the wild.

In the earliest works of science, a species was simply an individual organism representing a group of similar or nearly identical organisms. No other connection beyond that group is implied. Aristotle used the words genus and species for general and specific categories. Aristotle and other scientists chose species as distinct and fixed (unchanging) with "essence" like chemical elements. When early researchers began to develop systems of organization in living things, they began to place previously isolated species into context. Many of these early description schemes were considered odd and included relationships based on color (all plants with yellow flowers) or behavior (snakes, scorpions, and certain stinging ants). John Ray (1686), an English naturalist, was the first scientist to give a biological definition of the term "species," as follows: "...there is no more definite criterion in determining species for me than appearance/the special features which distinguish them after they have grown. develop from the seed, so that it does not matter what variations occur in the individuals or species, if they develop from the same seed, the variations are consequential variations and not due to variations are carried out by species differentiation... Likewise with animals, different animals specifically permanently distinguish their species; one species never grows from the seed of another species or vice versa". In the 18th century, the Swedish scientist Carl Linnaeus classified organisms on the basis of shared physical characteristics and not simply on the basis of differences. He also gave rise to the idea of ​​a taxonomic hierarchy, a classification hierarchy based on observable characteristics and intended to reflect natural relationships. Nikolai Ivanovich Vavilov developed the concept of Linnaeus' species as a definitive system.

In 1802, his teacher handed over the leadership of Uddhawa Sampradaya to him before he died. Sahajanand Swami organized a gathering and taught the Swaminarayan mantra. From then on, he became known as Swaminarayan and was considered an incarnation of God by his followers. Then Uddhawa Sampradaya was known as Swaminarayan Sampradaya. Swaminarayan has good relations with the British Royal Government. He not only has followers from Hindus, but also from Islam and Zoroastrianism. He built six temples during his lifetime and appointed 500 paramhansa to propagate his philosophy. In 1826, Swaminarayan wrote Shikshapatri, a book on social principles. He died on 1 June 1830 and was cremated according to Hindu rituals at Gadhada, Gujarat. Prior to his death, Swaminarayan appointed acaryas to lead the two Swaminarayan Sampradaya groups. Swaminarayan is also remembered in the religion for reforming women and the poor, performing yajnya or large-scale sacrifices and performing miracles.

edit page out log learn more Gas is one of the four basic states of matter (the others are solid, liquid, and plasma). Pure gases can be composed of atoms (for example noble gases such as neon), molecular elements composed of one type of atom (eg oxygen), or compound molecules composed of many different types of atoms (eg carbon dioxide). The gas mixture will contain a variety of pure gases such as air. What distinguishes gases from liquids and solids is the separation of the very large gas particles. This separation usually makes the colorless gas invisible to human observation. The interaction of gas particles in the presence of electric and gravitational fields can be neglected as shown by the constant velocity vector in the figure. One type of gas that is commonly known is steam. Gaseous matter is found between the liquid and plasma states, note 1] the latter provides an upper temperature limit for gases. The lower limit of the temperature scale lies degenerative quantum gases note 2] which are receiving increasing attention. note 3] High density atomic gases that are supercooled at very low temperatures are classified according to their statistical behavior as either Bose gases or Fermi gases. For a complete list of the forms of this exotic matter see list of states of matter. The only chemical elements that make up the diatomic homonuclear molecule at STP are hydrogen (H2), nitrogen (N2), oxygen (O2), and two halogens: fluorine (F2) and chlorine (Cl2). When grouped together with the monatomic noble gases – helium (He), neon (Ne), argon (Ar), krypton (Kr), xenon (Xe), and radon (Rn) – these gases are referred to as "elemental gases." " or "elemental gases". Alternatively, they are sometimes known as "molecular gases" to distinguish them from molecules which are also chemical compounds.

The term gas was first used in the early 17th century by the Flemish chemist J.B. van Helmont.note 4] Van Helmont's term appears to simplify the phonetic transcription of the ancient Greek term χάος Khaos – the Dutch g is pronounced like kh in "end" – in this case Van Helmont is simply following an established alchemical usage first attested in the work of Paracelsus . According to Paracelsus' terminology, chaos meant something like "ultra-scarce water". Another story is that van Helmont's words are truncated from gahst (or geist), which means ghost or spirit. This is because certain gases depict a supernatural origin, such as from their ability to cause death, extinguish fires, and occur in "mines, well bottoms, churchyards and other deserted places". Because most gases are difficult to observe directly, they are described by four physical properties or macroscopic characteristics: pressure, volume, number of particles (chemists classify them by moles) and temperature. These four characteristics have been repeatedly observed by scientists such as Robert Boyle, Jacques Charles, John Dalton, Joseph Gay-Lussac and Amedeo Avogadro for various gases in various situations. Their detailed studies eventually yielded a mathematical relationship between these properties which is expressed by means of the ideal gas law (see simplified models section below). Gas particles are separated far from each other and, as a result, have weaker intermolecular bonds than liquids or solids. These intermolecular forces result from electrostatic interactions between gas particles. The similarly charged gas regions with different gas particles repel each other, while the differently charged regions attract one another; gas containing permanently charged ions is known as plasma. Gaseous compounds with polar covalent bonds contain a permanent charge imbalance and thus experience relatively strong intermolecular forces, even though the net charge of the compound remains neutral.

Meanwhile, randomly induced charges are present in non-polar covalently bonded molecules and the electrostatic interactions caused by them are referred to as Van der Waals forces. The interaction of these intermolecular forces varies within the substance which determines many of the physical properties unique to each gas.note 5]note 6] A comparison of the boiling points for compounds formed by ionic and covalent bonds leads us to this conclusion. The moving smoke particles floating in the image provide some insight into the behavior of low pressure gases. Compared to other states of matter, gases have low density and viscosity. Pressure and temperature affect the particles in a given volume. This variation in particle separation and velocity is referred to as compressibility. The separation and size of these particles affect the optical properties of gases as can be found in the following list of refractive indices. Finally, the gas particles spread apart or diffuse to distribute them evenly throughout the vessel. When observing gases, it is usually determined using a frame of reference or a length scale. The larger length scale corresponds to the macroscopic scale or global point of view of the gas. This region (called the volume) must be deep enough to accommodate a large sample of gas particles. The resulting statistical analysis of this sample size yields the "average" behavior (i.e. velocity, temperature or pressure) of all gas particles in this region. Conversely, the smaller length scale corresponds to the microscopic scale or point of view of the particle. On a macro level, the gas characteristics that are measured are in terms of the gas particles themselves (velocity, pressure, or temperature) or their surroundings (volume). For example, a small part of Robert Boyle's career was studying pneumatic chemistry. One of his experiments concerned the macroscopic properties of gas pressure and volume. His experiment used a J-tube manometer that looked like a J-shaped test tube. Boyle trapped an inert gas with a column of mercury at the closed end of the test tube, thereby keeping the number of particles and temperature constant.

He observed that as the pressure in the gas was increased, by adding more mercury to the column, the volume of trapped gas decreased (this is known as the inverse relationship). Furthermore, when Boyle multiplied the pressure and volume of each observation, the result was a constant. This relationship held for every gas Boyle observed, leading to Boyle's law, PV=k{\displaystyle PV=k}, which is named after his work in this field. There are many mathematical instruments available for analyzing the properties of gases. Due to the extreme gas conditions, these instruments are slightly more complex, from the Euler en] equation for non-viscosity flow to the Navier–Stokes equation which fully takes into account the effects of viscosity. These equations are adapted to the conditions of the gas system in question. Boyle's laboratory equipment made it possible to use algebra to derive the results of his analysis. The results were possible because he studied gases under relatively low pressure situations, situations in which the gases behaved "ideally". This ideal relationship is applied to safety calculations for various flight conditions for the materials used. The high-tech equipment used today is designed to help us safely explore exotic operating environments where gases no longer behave "ideally". This high-level mathematics, including statistics and multivariable calculus, allows solving complex dynamic situations such as the reentry of the shuttle back to Earth. An example is the analysis of images of the shuttle's entry into the Earth's atmosphere to ensure the properties of materials are suitable under such extreme conditions. In this flight area, gas no longer behaves ideally. The symbol or symbol used to represent pressure in the equation is p or P with the SI units of Pascal. When describing a container of gas, the term pressure (or absolute pressure) refers to the average force per unit area exerted by the gas on the surface of the container.

Within this volume, it is sometimes easier to visualize the gas particles moving in straight lines until they hit the walls of the container (see the diagram at the top of this article). The force exerted by the gas particles on the container during these collisions is the change in the momentum of the particles. During a collision, only the velocity of the normal component changes. Particles moving parallel to the wall do not experience this change in momentum. Therefore, the average force on the surface of the container wall must be the average change in linear momentum over all the collisions of these gas particles. Pressure is the sum of all the normal component forces exerted by the particles striking the walls of the container divided by the surface area of ​​the walls. The symbol or symbol used to indicate temperature in the equation is T with the SI unit kelvin. The speed of gas particles is directly proportional to their absolute temperature. The volume of the balloon in the video shrinks as the trapped gas particles are slowed down by the addition of supercooled nitrogen. The temperature of any physical system is related to the motion of the particles (molecules and atoms) that make up the gaseous system]. In statistical mechanics, temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy stored in particles. This energy storage method is dictated by the degrees of freedom of the particles themselves (energy mode). The kinetic energy added (endothermic process) to the gas particles through collisions results in linear motion, rotation and vibration. In contrast, adding heat to the molecules of a solid can only increase its vibrational mode because the crystal lattice structure prevents both linear and rotational motion. These heated gas molecules have a greater range of velocities which are always varying due to constant collisions with other particles. The speed range can be described by the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution. Use of this distribution implies an ideal gas near thermodynamic equilibrium for the particle system under consideration.

The symbol used to represent the specific volume in the equation is "v" and the SI unit is cubic meters per kilogram (m3/kg). The symbol used to represent volume in the equation is "V" with the SI unit cubic meter (m3). When carrying out thermodynamic analysis, it is customary to discuss extensive and intensive properties. Properties that depend on the amount of gas (both mass and volume) are called extensive properties, while properties that do not depend on the amount of gas are called intensive properties. Specific volume is an example of an intensive property because it is the ratio of volume to a unit mass of gas that is identical throughout the system at equilibrium. A thousand gas atoms occupy the same space as 1000 other atoms at a given temperature and pressure. This concept is easier to visualize for incompressible solids like iron en] than for gases. Volume is an extensive property, because a gas fills any container it occupies. The symbol used to represent density in the equation is ρ (rho) with the SI units of kilograms per cubic meter. This term is the inverse of the multiplication en] of the specific volume. The mass of a gas is usually characterized by its density, because the gas molecules can move freely within the container. Density is the amount of mass per unit volume of a substance, or the reciprocal of specific volume. For gases, the density can vary over a wide range because the particles are free to move closer together when constrained by pressure or volume. This variation in density is referred to as compressibility. Like pressure and temperature, density is a state variable en] of a gas and the change in density during any process is governed by the laws of thermodynamics. For a static gas, the density is the same throughout the container. Therefore, density is a scalar quantity. It can be shown by kinetic theory that density is inversely proportional to the size of the container where there is a fixed gas mass limitation.

In this case of fixed mass, the density decreases as the volume increases. If one could observe a gas under a powerful microscope, one would see a collection of particles (molecules, atoms, ions, electrons, etc.) with no definite shape or volume, which are in more or less random motion. These neutral gas particles only change direction when they collide with other particles or hit the side of a container. In an ideal gas, these collisions are very elastic. This particle or microscopic appearance of gases is explained by the kinetic theory of gases. The assumptions behind this theory can be found in the postulates section of Kinetic Theory. Kinetic theory provides insight into the macroscopic properties of gases by considering their composition and molecular motion. Starting with the definitions of momentum and kinetic energy,note 7] one can use the conservation of momentum and the geometric relationships of a cube to relate the properties of macroscopic systems of temperature and pressure to the microscopic properties of the kinetic energy per molecule. This theory provides an average value for these two properties. This theory also explains how gas systems respond to change. For example, when a gas is heated from absolute zero, when it is at rest (in theory), its internal energy (temperature) increases. When the gas is heated, the rate of the particles is accelerated and the temperature rises. This results in a greater number of collisions with the container per unit time as the particle speed becomes higher with respect to the increase in temperature. The increase in pressure is directly proportional to the number of collisions per unit time. The editor's page has logged out learn more Sampit (abbreviated: SPT) is the capital city of East Kotawaringin Regency in Central Kalimantan, Indonesia. The location of the city of Sampit is in the Mentawa Baru Ketapang sub-district and the Baamang sub-district. The population is 166,733 in 2019 according to BPS data for East Kotawaringin Regency. The city of Sampit is divided by the Mentaya River and is in the middle of the Mentaya River. Sampit has an area of ​​1,365.95 km² with the geographical conditions of the lowlands and parts of the swampy area, having a height of 0 to 25 meters above sea level. At the beginning of Indonesian independence, Sampit was located in the Kotawaringin area with three administrative areas in the form of kawedanan which includes Sampit West, East Sampit, and North Sampit. This refers to the decision of the Governor of Kalimantan on August 3, 1950 with Decree Number 154/OPB/92/04 which stated that the Kotawaringin Region (Onder Afdelling Kotawaringin) was merged with three kawedanan (Sampit Barat, Sampit Timur and Sampit Utara) into an area The Kotawaringin Autonomous regional government with its capital in Sampit. In an effort to be able to regulate their respective regions, the people of Kalimantan province requested that the Indonesian government form district autonomous regions that were at the same level as districts. Then, the government stipulated the Emergency Law of the Republic of Indonesia Number 3 of 1953 concerning the Formation of (Official) Autonomous Regions/Special Regions at the Regency and Big City Levels within the Province of Kalimantan. Based on this legal basis, Kotawaringin district was formed which includes West Sampit kawedanan, East Sampit kawedanan, North Sampit kawedanan and Kotawaringin Swapraja. Along with the development of the region and the need to increase harmony in running regional government, it is necessary to increase the number of Level II Regions in Kalimantan, by dividing several old Level II Regions into several new Level II Regions and forming new Municipalities.

In supporting the formation of new regions, the government stipulates the Law Concerning the Establishment of Emergency Law No. 3 of 1953 concerning the Formation of Level II Regions in Kalimantan (State Gazette of 1953 No. 9), As Law. Thus, the Kotawaringin district is divided into two, where the East Kotawaringin Regional Government is located in Sampit and West Kotawaringin which is a Kotawaringin Swapraja based in Pangkalan Bun. Judging from its history, Sampit is one of the oldest settlements in East Kotawaringin Regency, the name of this city has already been mentioned in the Kakawin Nagarakretagama which was written in 1365 and in the Hikayat Banjar, the last part of which was written in 1663. In 2001, this city took place Ethnic riots between Madurese and Dayak tribes. During the riots, more than 400 people died and 40,000 people had to flee. Sampit as the capital city of East Kotawaringin Regency is one of the most important cities in Central Kalimantan Province. Apart from being economically a relatively advanced district, it is also because it is located in a strategic position. Judging from the regional map of Central Kalimantan, the city of Sampit was previously located in the middle and this made its position very strategic. The usual sacrifice was an animal, such as a sheep or buffalo, and was often cooked and eaten by the offeringr, with some being given to the Kohanim and some being burned on the altar (altar). Fruits, incense and cereals can also be offered. In Hebrew the noun sacrifice (or sacrifice) is used to refer to the various offerings commanded in the Hebrew Bible. The most common traditional usages are "animal sacrifice" (zevah זֶבַח), or "peace offering", and "burnt offering" (olah). Such offerings were usually made by the Priests (Kohen) at the Temple in Jerusalem. This practice continued until Solomon's Temple was destroyed, then resumed when the Second Temple was built, and then ended when that temple itself was destroyed in AD 70. It was unofficially resumed during the Jewish-Roman Wars in the 2nd century AD, and later in certain communities. Rabbinic Judaism maintains that the Torah permits the observance of Jewish law without animal sacrifice based on oral tradition and strong support from Scripture, for example Psalm 51:16-19 and Hosea 6:6. However, the practice and nature of sacrifice continue to have relevance in the 613 mitzvot, Judaic theology and halakha (Jewish laws), especially in Orthodox Judaism. According to Jewish perception the coming of the Messiah does not remove the requirement to keep all 613 commandments. The Semitic root √qrb (Hebrew: קרב‎) means "to be closer to something or someone"; other words from the same root are qarov "close; close" and qerovim "relative".

The variance is always non-negative: a low variance indicates that the data points are skewed very close to the mean (expected value) and between each other, while a high variance indicates that the data points are widely spread around the mean and from each other. The editor logged out learn more about Maoism or Mao Zedong Thought (Chinese: 毛泽东思想; pinyin: Máo Zédōng Sīxiǎng), is a variant of Marxism-Leninism derived from the teachings of the Chinese communist leader Mao Zedong (Wade-Giles Romanization: " Mao Tse-tung"). It should be noted that the term Mao Zedong Thought is preferred by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and that the term Maoism is never used in its English language publications except in pejorative usage. Similarly, Maoist groups outside China usually call themselves Marxist-Leninists and not Maoists. This reflects Mao's view that he did not change, but only developed Marxism-Leninism. Some Maoist groups, however, believe that Mao's theories have made significant additions to the foundations of the Marxist canon, and therefore call themselves "Marxist-Leninist-Maoist" (MLM) or simply "Maoist". In the PRC, Mao Zedong's thoughts are part of the official doctrine of the Chinese Communist Party, but since 1978, the beginning of Deng Xiaoping's market-oriented reform, with the concept of "socialism with Chinese characteristics" coming to the fore in politics, China's economic reform was introduced, and the official definition and meaning of Mao's original ideology in the PRC have been radically altered and reduced (see History of China). Outside the PRC, the term Maoism has been used since the 1960s, usually in a negative sense, to describe parties or people who support Mao Zedong and his form of communism. Since Mao's death and Deng's reforms, most parties that strictly call themselves "Maoist" have disappeared, but various communist groups around the world, particularly armed ones such as the Communist Party of India (Maoist), Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist) and the New People's Army in the Philippines, continued to advance Maoist ideas and gain press attention for it. These groups usually argued that Mao's ideas had been betrayed before they could be fully or properly implemented.

Maoism and its derivatives strongly supported the Soviet Union from the pre-Nikita Khruschev era and consider the development of the Secret Language to have initiated the country's "revisionism" and "social-imperialism". It is commonly assumed that the Maoists followed a political line that was anti-revisionist and generally more militant than the "peaceful co-existence" advanced by the Soviets and their followers after 1956. Usually most Maoists consider Joseph Stalin to be the last true socialist leader of the Soviet Union. In contrast to earlier forms of Marxism-Leninism, in which the urban proletariat was considered the main source of revolution, and the rural areas were generally ignored, Mao focused on the peasantry as the main revolutionary force, which, he argued, could be led by the proletariat and its bodyguard, the CCP. The model for this was the protracted people's war waged by the Chinese communists in the countryside in the 1920s and 1930s, which eventually brought the CCP to power. Furthermore, in contrast to other forms of Marxism-Leninism where massive industrial development was seen as a positive force, Maoism made overall rural development its priority. Mao felt that this strategy made sense during the early stages of socialism in a country where most of the people were agricultural labourers. In contrast to most other political ideologies, including socialist and Marxist ideologies, Maoism contains an integral military doctrine and clearly links its political ideology to military strategy. In Maoist thought, "political power comes from the muzzle of the gun" (one of Mao's sayings), and the working class can be mobilized to wage a "people's war" in an armed struggle involving guerrilla warfare in three stages. The first phase involved the mobilization and organization of the peasantry. The second phase involved building base areas in the countryside and increasing coordination among the guerrilla organizations.

Learn more. Limbat (Clarias nieuhofii) is a long-bodied and (usually) yellowish catfish. This fish is widespread in Southeast Asia, including the Malay Peninsula, Java, Sumatra, Kalimantan to the Philippines. In Kampar, Riau it is called limbek, Jambi is called lembat, in Jakarta it is known as lendi. Catfish with elongated gilig body, body length 8-9 1/3 times the height. Total length including tail up to 490 mm. At first glance, it is not unlike eels. The dorsal (dorsal) and anal (anal) fins are elongated and fused with the caudal fin, at least at the base. Dorsal fin with 87-106 rays, anal fin with 63-93 rays. The spines on the pectoral fins (commonly called patils) are rather weak, about 2/3 of the pectoral fins in length. Body color gray or yellowish; dark on the upper side and whitish on the underside of the head and body. There are 13–20 vertical rows of whitish spots on the back above the lateral line, and two longitudinal rows of similar spots below the line. The last row of spots is sometimes in the form of a series of slanted rows or without a clear pattern. In the wild this fish is often found inhabiting swamps with a relatively high quantity of aquatic plants as well as old wells in rice fields and dense forests. no longer used. There are several other catfish species that are similar to limbat, both in coloration patterns and in body shape. Many species have a pattern of rows of vertical spots on the dorsal side, but the dorsal and anal fins are separate (not fused) with the caudal fin. Some of them have limited distribution (endemic): The black limbat species (Clarias nigricans Ng, 2003) has dorsal and anal fins that are fused with the caudal fin, but the head is relatively narrower (11.7-12.3% SL) and the snout is also narrow .

Editor page logged out learn more In condensed matter physics, Superdense is an exotic state of matter, which simultaneously has superfluidity and supersolidity. The paradoxical existence of superdense matter, with apparently incompatible properties of order and superfluidity, has been predicted since the 1960s. Solid helium is a natural candidate, but supersolidity has not been observed, despite various attempts. Cold atoms with spin-orbit-coupling, contact interactions and remote interactions can provide systems for research of superdense phases. The superdense phase of matter juxtaposes two opposing physical properties: the long-distance phase regular structure and the nondissipating transport property of fluids. Little interest, due to a lack of experimental evidence, has attracted vigorous theoretical experimentation in recent years since Kim and Chan (Penn State, USA) reported evidence for a nonclassical inertial effect, a hallmark of superfluidity, in solid samples of Helium-4. To date no clear supersolid state of helium-4 has been observed. At temperatures below 2.176 K helium-4 enters a superfluid state and flows without friction. This "perpetual motion" makes superfluidity - perhaps even more so than its electronics, superconductivity - the most dramatic manifestation of quantum mechanics on a macrocosmic scale. Despite its attractiveness, despite the abundance of superfluidity liquefaction in other systems, it remains an uncommon phenomenon. From 1938, when superfluidity was discovered, helium-4 was the only known example until 1972 when the phenomenon was seen, at much lower temperatures, in helium-3. The temperature difference between the behavior of the two isotopes reflects the close relationship between superfluidity and Bose-Einstein condensation - the transition that occurs when 'bosons' collect in a single quantum mechanical state. The helium-4 atom is a boson, but the helium-4 atom is a fermion and must pair before it can condense into a single state.

Editor page logged out learn more Syphilis or lion king disease is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum sub-species pallidum. The main route of transmission is through sexual contact; This infection can also be passed from mother to fetus during pregnancy or at birth, causing congenital syphilis. Other human diseases caused by Treponema pallidum include yaws or patek (subspecies pertenue), pinta (sub-species carateum), and bejel (sub-species endemicum). Signs and symptoms of syphilis vary depending on which phase the disease occurs (primary, secondary, latent, and tertiary). The primary phase is generally characterized by the appearance of a single chancre (hard, painless, non-itchy skin ulceration), secondary syphilis is characterized by a diffuse rash that often appears on the palms and soles of the feet, latent syphilis usually has no or only few symptoms, and tertiary syphilis with gumma, neurological, or cardiac symptoms. However, this disease has been known as the "great imitator" because its appearance is characterized by dissimilar symptoms. Diagnosis is usually made through a blood test; however, bacteria can also be seen through a microscope. Syphilis can be treated effectively with antibiotics, especially penicillin G (which is injected for neurosyphilis), or ceftriaxone, and for patients who have a severe allergy to penicillin, doxycycline or azithromycin can be given orally. Syphilis is believed to have infected 12 million people worldwide in 1999, with more than 90% of cases occurring in developing countries. After case numbers declined dramatically since the worldwide availability of penicillin in the 1940s, infection rates have been increasing since the turn of the millennium in many countries, sometimes coexisting with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

This figure is due in part to unsafe sex practices and a decline in the use of protection during sex. Syphilis can appear in one of four different phases; primary, secondary, latent, and tertiary, and can also occur congenitally. This phase was called the "great imitator" by Sir William Osler because of its varied appearance. Primary syphilis is generally acquired from direct sexual contact with an infected person to another person. About 3 to 90 days after the initial infection (average 21 days) a sore on the skin called a chancre appears. These lesions are usually (40 % of the time) single, firm, painless, non-itchy skin ulcers with a clean base and sharp edges between 0.3 and 3.0 cm in size. However, wounds can be removed in almost any form. In the common form, sores progress from macules to papules and finally to erosions or ulcers. Occasionally, multiple lesions may appear (~40%). Multiple lesions are more common when co-infected with HIV. The lesions may be painful or sore (30%), and may occur outside the genitals (2–7%). The most common sites in women are the cervix (44%), the penis in heterosexual men (99%), and the anal and rectal relatively common (men who have sex with men) (34%). Enlarged lymph nodes (80%) often occur around the site of infection, occurring within 10 days of ulcer formation. The lesions can persist for three to six weeks without treatment. Secondary syphilis often occurs four to ten weeks after the primary infection. While secondary disease can be recognized in a number of distinct ways, the most common symptoms are associated with the skin, mucous membranes, and lymph nodes.

There may be a similar, reddish-pink, non-itchy rash on the trunk and extremities, including the palms and soles. The rash may be maculopapular or pustular. It can form flat, wide, whitish, wart-like lesions known as condyloma broad on the mucous membranes. All of the lesional bacterial deposits were infected. Other symptoms include fever, sore throat, malaise, weight loss, hair loss and headache. Other types of disease that occur less frequently include hepatitis, kidney disease, arthritis, periostitis, optic neuritis, uveitis, and interstitial keratitis. Acute symptoms usually resolve after three to six weeks; however, about 25% of people may relapse secondary symptoms. Many people who have secondary syphilis (40-85% of women, 20-65% of men) do not report having previously had a chancre from primary syphilis. Latent syphilis is defined as having serological evidence of infection without symptoms of disease. The disease is further described as early (less than 1 year after secondary syphilis) or late (more than 1 year after secondary syphilis) in the United States. The United States uses the cut of two years of early and late latent syphilis. Early latent syphilis may have relapses of symptoms. Late latent syphilis is asymptomatic, and not as contagious as early latent syphilis. Tertiary syphilis can occur approximately 3 to 15 years after the initial infection, and can be divided into three distinct forms; gummatous syphilis (15%), late neurosyphilis (6.5%), and cardiovascular syphilis (10%). Without treatment, all three of those infected progressed to tertiary disease. People with tertiary syphilis are not contagious. Gummatous syphilis or late benign syphilis usually occurs 1 to 46 years after the initial infection, with an average of 15 years.

This phase is characterized by the formation of chronic gummas, which are soft, inflammatory ball-like tumors that can be of various and very significant forms. Gummas generally affect the skin, bone, and liver, but can occur anywhere. Neurosyphilis refers to an infection involving the central nervous system that may occur early, become asymptomatic or in the form of syphilistic meningitis associated with impaired balance and flash pains in the lower extremities. Late neurosyphilis generally occurs 4 to 25 years after the initial infection. Meningovascular syphilis commonly presents with apathy and convulsions, and has been common with dementia and dorsalis. Also there may be Argyll Robertson's pupils, where the small bilateral pupils constrict when people focus on close objects, but do not constrict when exposed to bright light. Cardiovascular syphilis usually occurs 10-30 years after the initial infection. The most common complication is syphilitic aortitis, which can result in the formation of an aneurysm. Congenital congenital syphilis from birth can occur during pregnancy or during birth. Two out of three syphilis babies are born without symptoms. Common symptoms that later develop over the first few years of life include: hepatosplenomegaly (70%), rash (70%), fever (40%), neurosyphilis (20%), and pneumonitis (20%). If untreated late stage congenital syphilis can occur in 40% including: nose; saddle deformity, Higoumenakis sign, saber shin, or Clutton joints among others. Three other human-related diseases are caused by Treponema pallidum, including yaws or patek (subspecies pertenue), pinta (subspecies carateum) and bejel (subspecies endemicum). Unlike the pallidum subtypes, these diseases do not cause neurological disease. Humans are known to be the only natural host for the pallidum subspecies.

The subspecies “pallidum” cannot survive without a host for more than a few days. That's because its small genome (1.14 mDa) fails to encode the metabolic pathways needed to make most of its macronutrients. Its micronutrient production is twice as slow, much longer than 30 hours. Syphilis is mainly transmitted by sexual contact or during pregnancy from mother to fetus; spirochaetes are able to penetrate intact mucous membranes or skin disorders. As an example of transmission, a person injected with only 57 organisms has a 50% chance of being infected. Most (60%) of new cases in the United States occur in men who have sex with men. The disease can be transmitted through blood products. However, blood products have been tested in many countries and the risk of transmission is low. The risk of transmission from sharing needles is not much. Syphilis cannot be transmitted through toilet seats, daily activities, hot tubs, or sharing cutlery or clothing. The initial appearance of syphilis is difficult to diagnose clinically. The diagnosis is made through a blood test or direct visual examination using a microscope. Blood tests are a commonly used method, because they are easier to do. Diagnostic tests, however, are unable to differentiate between the stages of the disease. The treponemal antibody test usually becomes positive two to five weeks after the initial infection.
