Dark-field microscopy of the serous fluid from an ulcer can be used to make a direct diagnosis. However, hospitals do not always have the equipment or experienced staff members, while testing has to be done within 10 minutes of sample acquisition. Sensitivity has been reported to be nearly 80%, sensitivity and specificity can only be used to confirm the diagnosis but are not the only rule. Two other tests can be performed on the sample from the cup: the direct fluorescent antibody test and the nucleic acid amplification test. Direct fluorescent tests use antibodies tagged with fluorescein, which are inserted for specific syphilis proteins, whereas nucleic acid amplification uses techniques, such as the polymerase chain reaction, to detect the presence of a specific syphilis gene. The tests are unlike time-sensitive, as they do not need live bacteria to make a diagnosis. There is no effective vaccine for prevention. Abstaining from intimate physical contact with an infected person effectively reduces transmission of syphilis, as does the proper use of latex condoms. However, the use of condoms, does not completely eliminate the risk. Therefore, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends long-term relationships with one uninfected partner and avoiding substances such as alcohol and other illicit substances that can increase risky sexual behavior. Congenital syphilis in infants can be prevented by screening mothers during early pregnancy and treating those who are infected.

The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) strongly recommends universal screening of all pregnant women, while the World Health Organization recommends that all women be tested at their first antenatal visit and again in the third trimester. If they are positive, they recommend that their partners also be treated. Despite this, congenital syphilis is still common in developing countries, as many women have not received any antenatal care at all, and even other prenatal care received does not include screening, and this still occurs occasionally in developed countries, because they are the most likely to be infected. syphilis (through drug use, etc.) is the least likely to receive treatment during pregnancy. Several measures to increase access to testing appear to be effective in reducing rates of congenital syphilis in low- to middle-income countries. Syphilis is a notifiable disease in several countries, including Canada, the European Union, and the United States. This means healthcare providers are required to notify Public Health authorities, who will ideally then provide spousal notification to the patient's partner. The doctor may also encourage the patient to send the patient's partner to seek health care. The CDC recommends that sexually active men who have sex with men get tested at least once a year. The first treatment option for complicated syphilis remains a single intramuscular dose of penicillin G or an oral dose of azithromycin. Doxycycline and tetracycline are other options; however, because of the risk of fetal abnormalities, docycline and tetracycline are not recommended for pregnant women. Resistance to antibiotics has developed for a number of agents, including macrolides, clindamycin, and rifampin. Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic, may just be as effective as penicillin-based treatments. Azithromycin belongs to the Macrolides class of antibiotics, where the generic drug is available in Indonesia.

If one dose/cure hasn't healed, then it's a good idea to do an antibiotic resistance test (culture) to find out which types of antibiotics are still effective, but to do a culture you need to find a clinical laboratory that does a fairly complete test, you can do this by asking whether the clinical laboratory tests azithromycin or not, if testing, the clinical laboratory will usually also test other antibiotics that are thought to be effective for gram-positive bacteria such as syphilis, for example erythromycin which is also a macrolides type antibiotic and also tests moxifloxacin and levofloxacin which are Quinolones antibiotics or similar to ciprofloxacin , but cipro is often resistant (not working). If the person is allergic, ceftriaxone can be used or penicillin desensitization can be tried. Other late episodes may be treated with intramuscular penicillin G once weekly for three weeks. If allergic, as in early cases, doxycycline or tetracycline can be used, even for a longer period of time. Treatment in this phase limits further development, but has relatively little effect on the damage that has already occurred. One side effect that can occur from this medication is the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction. The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction often begins after an hour and persists for 24 hours, with fever, muscle aches, headache, and tachycardia. Tachycardia is caused by cytokines released by the immune system in response to lipoproteins secreted from the ruptured syphilis bacteria. Syphilis is believed to have infected 12 million people in 1999, with more than 90% of cases occurring in developing countries.

The disease affects 700,000 to 1.6 million pregnancies annually, resulting in sudden abortions, stillbirths and congenital syphilis. In sub-Saharan Africa, syphilis contributes to approximately 20% of perinatal deaths. Rates were higher on average for injecting drug users, those infected with HIV, and men who had sex with men. In the United States, the syphilis rate since 2007 is six times higher in males than females, and nearly the same in 1997. Nearly half of cases in 2010 were African Americans. Syphilis was common in Europe during the 18th to 19th centuries. In developed countries during the 20th century, the infection declined rapidly with the increasing use of antibiotics, until the 1980s and 1990s. Since 2000, syphilis rates have increased in the US, Canada, UK, Australia and Europe, especially among men who have sex with men. Syphilis rates among American women, however, remained stable during this period, and rates among British women increased, but were still below the rates for men. Increasing numbers among heterosexuals have occurred in China and Russia since the 1990s. This is associated with unsafe sex practices, such as multiple sex partners, prostitution, and decreased use of protection. If left untreated, the mortality rate is 8% to 58%, with males having a higher mortality rate. The severity of syphilis symptoms decreased during the 19th and 20th centuries, partly because of the increasing availability of effective treatments and because of the decrease in the virulence of the spirochaetes. With early treatment, there are fewer complications. Syphilis increases the risk of HIV transmission two to five times, and other infections are also common (30–60% in urban centres). The origin of syphilis is unknown.

Of the two main hypotheses, one proposes that syphilis was brought to Europe by crew members returning from Christopher Columbus' voyage to the Americas, the other proposes that syphilis existed before in Europe, but went unrecognized. These are referred to as the "Columbian" and "pre-Columbian" hypotheses, respectively. The Columbus hypothesis is strongly supported by the available evidence. Written records of an extraordinary occurrence of syphilis in Europe date back to 1494/1495 in Naples, Italy, during the French invasion. Because it was spread by returning French troops, it was originally called "French disease", its traditional name. In 1530, the name "syphilis" was first used by the Italian physician and poet Girolamo Fracastoro as the title of a Latin poem in dactylic hexameter describing the ravages of syphilis in Italy. In history this event is also known as the "Great Pox". The causative organism, Treponema pallidum, was first identified by Fritz Schaudinn and Erich Hoffmann in 1905. The first effective treatment (Salvarsan) was developed in 1910 by Paul Ehrlich, which was followed by trials of penicillin and confirmation of its effectiveness in 1943. Prior to the discovery of other effective treatments, mercury and isolation was widely used, with worse treatment of the disease. Artist Jan van der Straet painted a scene of a wealthy man receiving treatment for syphilis with the tropical wood guaiacum in circa 1580.

The title of the artwork is "Preparation and Use of Guayaco for Treating Syphilis". Why the artist chose to include this image in a series of works celebrating the New World demonstrated to European elites how important syphilis treatment was, even if it was ineffective at the time. The colorful and detailed work depicts four maids preparing a concoction as a doctor looks on, hiding something behind his back as the patient drinks. One of the most famous cases in the United States of medical ethics being questioned in the 20th century was the Tuskegee syphilis study. The research was conducted in Tuskegee, Alabama, and was supported by U.S. The Public Health Service (PHS) works closely with the Tuskegee Institute. The research began in 1932, when syphilis was a widespread problem and there was no safe or effective treatment. The study was designed to measure the progression of untreated syphilis. In 1947, penicillin was validated as an effective drug for syphilis and was used widely to treat the disease. The study director, however, continued the study and did not offer the study participants treatment with penicillin. This is disputed, and some people know that penicillin was given to many subjects. The study did not end until 1972. A syphilis experiment was also conducted in Guatemala from 1946 to 1948. The experiment was sponsored by the United States human experimenter, conducted during the reign of Juan José Arévalo in collaboration with Guatemala's ministry and health officials. Doctors infected soldiers, prisoners, and asylum patients with syphilis and other sexually transmitted diseases, without the consent of the subjects, then treated them with antibiotics. In October 2010, the US officially apologized to Guatemala for carrying out this experiment.

The name Denpasar comes from the words "den" (north) and "pasar" so that as a whole it means "North Market". This park was not like other parks in general, because it was the favorite garden of the King of Badung at that time, Kyai Jambe Ksatrya. Despite features that indicate a fairly strong role for Tethys in very ancient times, she is not mentioned much in ancient Greek texts, or historical records of ancient cults. Walter Burkert notes the presence of Tethys in the episode of Iliad XIV that the Ancients called the "Deception of Zeus", where Hera, to mislead Zeus, says she wants to go to Oceanus, "origin of the gods" and Tethys "the mother". Burkert sees in the name a transformation from Akkadian tiamtu or tâmtu, "sea," which is recognizable in Tiamat. Alternatively, her name may simply mean "old woman"; it bears obvious resemblance to ἡ τήθη, meaning "grandmother", and she is often described as a very ancient goddess. One of the few depictions of Tethis is a floor mosaic from the fourth century AD in Antiochus, and now in Harvard Business School in Boston, Massachusetts having previously transferred from Dumbarton Oaks. In the Dumbarton Oaks mosaic, Tethis's head, surrounded by fish, emerges from the water. On his shoulder is a ship's rudder, on his forehead are a pair of gray wings. As such, it is one of the four basic states of matter (the others being solid, gas, and plasma), and is the only state with a definite volume but no fixed shape. Liquids consist of particles of matter with fine vibrations, such as atoms, held together by intermolecular forces. Water is, by far, the most common liquid on Earth. Like gases, liquids can flow and take the shape of their container. Most liquids are incompressible, although others are compressible. Unlike gases, liquids do not spread to fill every space of the container, and maintain a fairly constant density. A characteristic property of the liquid state is surface tension, which leads to the wetting phenomenon. The density of liquids is usually close to that of solids, and much higher than that of gases. Therefore, liquid and solid are both called condensed matter. On the other hand, since liquids and gases share the ability to flow, they are both called fluids. Although water is abundant on Earth, this state of matter is actually the least common in the known universe, because the existence of liquid requires a relatively narrow temperature/pressure range. Most known matter in the universe exists in the gaseous state (with detectable traces of dense matter) as interstellar clouds or in the plasma form within stars. Liquid is one of the four main states of matter, along with solid, gas and plasma. Fluid is fluid. Unlike solids, molecules in liquids have much greater freedom of movement.

The forces that bind molecules together in solids are only temporary in liquids, allowing the liquid to flow while the solid remains rigid. Liquids, like gases, display fluid properties. Liquids can flow, imagine the shape of a container, and if placed in a closed container, will distribute pressure evenly over every surface of the container. If the liquid is placed in the bag, it can be pressed into any shape. Unlike gases, liquids are nearly incompressible. It has a nearly constant volume over a wide pressure range; it does not expand to fill the empty space in a container but forms its own surface, and does not always mix easily with other liquids. This property makes the fluid suitable for applications such as hydraulics. The liquid particles are held together tightly but not rigidly. They are able to move freely, resulting in a limited degree of particle mobility. As the temperature increases, the molecular vibrations increase causing the distance between molecules to increase. When the liquid reaches its boiling point, the cohesive forces holding the molecules together are broken, and the liquid turns into a gas (unless superheating occurs). If the temperature drops, the distance between the molecules gets closer and closer. When a liquid reaches its freezing point, the molecules usually lock together into a specific order, which is called crystallization, and the bonds between them become more rigid, turning the liquid into its solid state (unless supercooling occurs). There are only two elements that are liquids at standard temperature and pressure: mercury and bromine. Four other elements have melting points just above room temperature: francium, cesium, gallium and rubidium. Metal alloys that are liquid at room temperature include NaK, sodium-potassium alloys, galinstan, and some amalgams (alloys involving mercury). Pure substances that are liquids under normal conditions include water, ethanol and many other organic solvents.

Water is a vital fluid in chemistry and biology; it is believed to be a vital necessity for survival. Essential everyday liquids include aqueous solutions such as household bleach, other mixtures of substances such as mineral oil and gasoline, emulsions such as vinaigrette or mayonnaise, suspensions such as blood, and colloids such as paint and milk. In a hydraulic system, fluids act as power conductors. In tribology, fluids are studied for their properties as lubricants. Lubricants such as oil are selected for their viscosity and flow characteristics which are suitable for the entire operating temperature range of the components. The editor page has logged out learn more In physics, a quantum (plural: quanta) is the minimum amount of any physical entity (physical property) involved in an interaction. The fundamental idea that physical properties can be "quantized" is referred to as the "quantization hypothesis". This means that the magnitude of a physical property can only take on discrete values ​​consisting of integer multiples of one quantum. For example, a photon is a single quantum of light (or some other form of electromagnetic radiation). Similarly, the bond energies of electrons in atoms are quantized and exist only in certain discrete values. (Indeed, atoms and matter in general are stable because electrons can only exist at discrete energy levels within atoms.) Quantization is one of the foundations of the broader quantum mechanical physics. The quantization of energy and its effect on the way energy and matter interact (quantum electrodynamics) is part of the basic framework for understanding and describing nature. The word quantum comes from the Latin quantus, which means "how great". "Quanta" was used in a 1902 journal article on the photoelectric effect by Philipp Lenard, who quoted Hermann von Helmholtz for using the word in electricity. However, the word quantum was generally known before 1900. The word is often used in medicine, as in the term quantum satis. Both Helmholtz and Julius von Mayer were doctors and physicists. Helmholtz used quantum with reference to heat energy in his article on Mayer's work, and the word quantum can be found in Mayer's formulation of the first law of thermodynamics in his paper dated July 24, 1841. In 1901, Max Planck used quanta to mean "quanta of matter and electricity" , gas, and heat. In 1905, in response to the work of Planck and the experimental work of Lenard (who explained his results in terms of electric quanta), Albert Einstein suggested that radiation exists in spatially localized packets which he called "light quanta" (Lichtquanta).

The United Nations currently consists of five main bodies, namely: the General Assembly (the main deliberative council); the Security Council (a council that makes several binding resolutions on peace and security); Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) (council that promotes international social economic cooperation and development); Secretariat (which functions to provide studies, information, and facilities needed by the United Nations); and the International Court of Justice (the principal judicial body). Male circumcision is obligatory in Islam and Judaism. This practice is also present among the majority of the population of South Korea, America, and the Philippines. In 2012, the AMERICAN ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS released their study of experts showing that the health benefits of newborn male circumcision outweigh the risks. Specific benefits of male circumcision include prevention of urinary tract infections, HIV transmission, transmission of some sexually transmitted infections, and penile cancer. Circumcision in boys does not affect penile sexual function/sensitivity or sexual satisfaction. According to the 1999 AMA literature, US parents choose to circumcise their children primarily for social or cultural reasons rather than health reasons. However, a 2001 survey showed that 23.5% of parents did it for health reasons. Advocates of genital integrity condemn all acts of infant circumcision as they say it is a form of male genital mutilation comparable to female circumcision which is banned in the US.

Some experts argue that circumcision is beneficial to health, but this is only true if the patient is clinically proven to have a sexually transmitted disease. Some diseases that most likely require circumcision to speed up healing such as bleeding and penile cancer, however, these two things are rare. Phimosis can also be treated with circumcision, although now other techniques have also been developed. Postnatal circumcision is usually chosen by the parents for nonmedical reasons, such as religious beliefs or personal preference, which may be dictated by societal norms. Outside of parts of Africa with a high prevalence of HIV/AIDS, the positions of the world's major medical organizations on non-therapeutic postnatal circumcision range from having some health and hygiene benefits that outweigh the minor risks, to viewing it as a disadvantage with moderate risks. No major medical organization advocates universal postnatal circumcision and none is calling for a ban. The Royal Dutch Medical Association, which has raised some of the strongest opposition to the custom of postnatal circumcision, argues that even if there were good reasons to ban it, doing so could also turn parents who insist on performing the surgery towards unskilled practitioners rather than medical workers. Arguments keeping surgery within the realm of medical professionals are found in all major medical organizations. In addition, these organizations advise medical professionals to provide parents with several choices, often based on religious or cultural views, in their decision to have circumcision. The Danish College of General Practitioners states that circumcision should "only be performed] when medically necessary, unless it is a case of mutilation." Circumcision can be used to treat phimosis, refractory balanopostitis and acute or recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).

The World Health Organization promotes circumcision to prevent female-to-male transmission of HIV in countries with high HIV rates. The International AIDS Society-US also recommends male circumcision for those who have insertive anal sex with men, especially in areas where HIV is common. The finding that circumcision significantly reduces female-to-male transmission of HIV has prompted medical organizations serving communities affected by the HIV/AIDS epidemic to promote circumcision as an additional method of preventing the spread of HIV. The World Health Organization and UNAIDS (2007) recommend circumcision as part of an overall HIV transmission prevention program in areas with high HIV endemic rates, as long as the program includes “free, confidential, and informed consent”. Circumcision may be medically indicated in children with phimosis, refractory balanopostitis, and chronic and recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) in males who are chronically susceptible to them. The World Health Organization promotes circumcision as a preventive measure for sexually active men in populations at high risk for HIV. Circumcision is contraindicated in infants with certain structural abnormalities of the genitals, such as a faulty urethral opening (such as hypospadias and epispadias), a curved glans (chordee), or ambiguous genitalia, because the foreskin may be required for reconstructive surgery. Circumcision is contraindicated in premature infants and infants who are clinically unstable and not in good health. If an individual, child or adult, has a history of a serious bleeding disorder (hemophilia), it is recommended that the blood be checked for normal coagulation prior to circumcision. The foreskin extends outward from the base of the glans penis and covers the glans when the penis is not erect. Theories proposed for the purpose of the foreskin are that the foreskin serves to protect the penis while the fetus is developing in the mother's womb, helps keep the glans moist, or enhances sexual pleasure.

The foreskin can also be a route of infection for certain diseases. Circumcision removes the attachment of the foreskin to the base of the glans. For infant circumcision, circumcision equipment such as the Gomco clamp, the Plastibell and the Mogen clamp are commonly used in the United States. It follows the same basic procedure. First, the amount of foreskin removed is estimated. The practitioner opens the foreskin through the foreskin opening to expose the glans and make sure it is normal before separating the inner lining of the foreskin (preputial mucosa) from its attachment to the glans. The practitioner then places the circumcision device (sometimes requiring a dorsal slit), until the blood flow stops. Finally, the foreskin was amputated. For adults, circumcision is often performed without clamps, and nonsurgical alternatives such as radial compression controlled elastic ring devices are available. Neonatal circumcision is generally safe when performed by an experienced doctor. The most common acute complications are bleeding, infection, and removal of either too much or too little foreskin. These complications occur in less than 1%, and account for the majority of all acute circumcision complications in the United States. Minor complications have been reported in 3%. Specific complication rates are difficult to determine due to a lack of complication data and inconsistencies in the classification. Complications are greater when the procedure is performed by an inexperienced person, in unsterile conditions, or when the child is at an older age. Significant acute complications are rare, approximately 1 in 500 newborns in the United States. The death rate from circumcision is estimated to be 1 in every 500,000 neonatal procedures in the United States. Other complications may include hidden penis, urethral fistula, and meatal stenosis. These complications can be avoided with proper technique, and can often be treated without requiring a hospital visit.

Circumcision does not reduce penile sensitivity, harm sexual function, or reduce sexual satisfaction. In 2010 the Royal Dutch Medical Association noted that "complications in the area of ​​sexuality" had been reported. In addition, this procedure may carry a high risk of pain response for the newborn and dissatisfaction with the results. Circumcision is probably the most common procedure in the world. About one third of men in the world have been circumcised, most often for reasons other than medical indications. Circumcision is generally performed from infancy to their early 20s. The World Health Organization estimated in 2007 that 664,500,000 males aged 15 years and over were circumcised (30% global prevalence), nearly 70% of whom were Muslim. Circumcision is most common in the Muslim world, Israel, South Korea, the United States and parts of Southeast Asia and Africa. Circumcision is relatively rare in Europe, Latin America, parts of South Africa and Oceania and most of Asia. Almost universal prevalence in the Middle East and Central Asia. Non-religious circumcision in Asia, outside of South Korea and the Philippines, is quite rare, and prevalence is generally low (less than 20%) throughout Europe. The estimates for each country include Taiwan at 9% and Australia at 58.7%. The prevalence in the United States and Canada is estimated at 75% and 30%, respectively. Prevalence in Africa varies from less than 20% in some southern African countries to nearly universal in North and West Africa. Rates of routine neonatal circumcision over time have varied significantly by country. In the United States, hospital surveys estimated rates at 64.7% in 1980, 59.0% in 1990, 62.4% in 2000, and 58.3% in 2010.

This estimate is lower than the overall, as it does not account for non-hospital circumcisions, or procedures performed for medical reasons; Community surveys have reported a higher neonatal prevalence. Canada has shown a slow decline since the early 1970s, possibly influenced by statements from the AAP and the Pedriatic Society of Canada published in 1970 saying that the procedure had no medical indications. In Australia, rates declined in the 1970s and 80s, but have increased slowly since 2004. In the United Kingdom, prevalence was around 25% in the 1940s, but declined dramatically after the National Health Service failed to cover the cost of the procedure. Prevalence in South Korea has increased markedly in the second half of the 20th century, rising from near zero around 1950 to around 60% in 2000, with the most significant jump in the last two decades in that period. This may have been due to influence from the United States, which established a trusteeship for South Korea after World War II. Medical organizations can affect a country's neonatal circumcision rates by influencing whether the costs of the procedure are borne by the parents, insured, or covered by the national health care system. Policies that require a fee to be paid by the parents result in lower rates of neonatal circumcision. The decline in circumcision rates in England is one example, another example is the United States. Policy changes towards circumcision can be driven by new research results, and moderated by politics, demographics, and societal culture. Circumcision is the world's oldest planned surgical procedure, suggested by anatomist and hyperdiffusionist historian Grafton Elliot Smith. Circumcision is over 15,000 years old. There is no strong consensus on how circumcision is practiced around the world.

One theory is that it started in one geographic area and spread from there; another theory is that several different cultural groups started practicing it themselves. In his 1891 work History of Circumcision, the physician Peter Charles Remondino suggested that circumcision began as a less severe form of emasculating a captured enemy: a penectomy or castration might have been fatal, while a permanent circumcision would have marked defeat and left him alive to serve. as a slave. The history of migration and the evolution of the practice of circumcision is followed primarily through the cultures and peoples of two separate regions. In areas south and east of the Mediterranean, starting with Sudan and Ethiopia, circumcision was practiced in Ancient Egypt and the Semites, then by Judaism and Islam, where the practice was adopted by the Bantu people. In Oceania, circumcision is practiced by Aborigines and Polynesians. There is also evidence that circumcision was practiced in the Aztec and Mayan civilizations, but few details are available on that history. Evidence suggests that circumcision was practiced in the Arabian Peninsula as early as the fourth millennium BC, when Sumerians and Semites moved into what is now Iraq. The earliest historical record of circumcision comes from Egypt, in the form of a circumcision image of an adult carved in the tomb of Ankh-Mahor at Saqqara, c. 2400-2300 BC. Circumcision was performed by the Egyptians probably for health reasons, but it was also part of their obsession with purity and was associated with spiritual and intellectual development. There is no well-accepted theory explaining the importance of circumcision to the Egyptians, but it seems to have been endowed with great honor and importance as a ritual of coming of age, performed in a public ceremony emphasizing the continuation of the family's generations and fertility.

This may have been a sign of distinction for the elite: The Egyptian Book of the Dead describes the sun god Ra as having circumcised himself. Circumcision features prominently in the Hebrew Bible. The narrative of Genesis chapter 17 describes the circumcision of Abraham, his relatives and servants, making him the first named individual to undergo circumcision. In the same chapter, Abraham's descendants are commanded to circumcise their children on the eighth day. Many generations later, Moses was raised by the Egyptian elite, so circumcision was no doubt foreign to him. For the Jews of the time, circumcision was not so much a spiritual act as it was a physical sign of their covenant with God, and a prerequisite for the fulfillment of the commandment to produce offspring. As well as proposing purely Jewish circumcision as a religious mandate, academics have suggested that Judaism's ancestors and their followers adopted circumcision to make penile hygiene easier in hot, sandy climates; as a rite of passage into adulthood; or as a form of blood sacrifice. Alexander the Great conquered the Middle East in the fourth century BCE, and in the following centuries ancient Greek culture came to the Middle East. The Greeks hated circumcision, making life for circumcised Jews living among the Greeks (and later Romans) very difficult. Antiochus Epiphanes forbade circumcision, as did Hadrian, who helped cause the Bar Kokhba Rebellion. During this period in history, Jewish circumcision required the removal of only part of the foreskin, and some Hellenistic Jews attempted to appear uncircumcised by stretching the remaining portions of their foreskin. This was considered by Jewish leaders to be a serious problem, and during the 2nd century AD they changed the Jewish circumcision requirement to require complete removal of the foreskin, emphasizing the Jewish view of circumcision as intended to be not just the fulfillment of a Biblical commandment but also an important sign and permanent membership in a nation.

A narrative in the Gospel of Luke makes brief mention of Jesus' circumcision, but physical circumcision itself was not part of the teachings of Jesus. The Apostle Paul interpreted circumcision as a spiritual concept, arguing that physical circumcision was no longer necessary. The teaching that physical circumcision was not necessary for membership in the divine covenant was instrumental in the separation of Christianity from Judaism. Although not explicitly mentioned in the Quran (early 6th century), circumcision is considered essential to Islam, and it is almost universally practiced among Muslims. The practice of circumcision spread across the Middle East, North Africa and Southern Europe with Islam. The practice of circumcision is thought to have been brought to the Bantu-speaking tribes of Africa either by Jews after one of their many expulsions from European countries, or by Muslim Moors who fled after the Spanish conquest in 1492. In the second half of the first millennium, people from northeastern Africa moved south and met tribes of Arabia, the Middle East and West Africa. These people moved south and formed what are known today as the Bantu. The Bantu were observed enforcing so-called Jewish laws, including circumcision, in the 16th century. Circumcision and elements of Jewish taboos are still found among the Bantu tribes. Compared to the available history of circumcision in the Middle East, there is little verified evidence for the history of circumcision in Aboriginal Australia and Polynesia. What is known about it comes from the oral history of missionaries and explorers. For Aboriginal Australians and Polynesians, circumcision probably began as a blood sacrifice and test of courage, and became an initiation rite with attendant instructions in coming of age in more recent centuries.

The foreskin removal was performed with shells, and it is theorized that the bleeding was stopped with eucalyptus smoke. Several groups in America are known to have a history of circumcision. Christopher Columbus discovered the practice of circumcision by Native Americans. This was also done by the Incas, Aztecs and Maya. Circumcision probably began among South American tribes as a blood sacrifice or ritual mutilation to test courage and endurance, and its use later developed into an initiation rite. Circumcision did not become a common medical procedure until the late 19th century. At that time, British and American doctors began to recommend circumcision primarily as a deterrent to masturbation. Before the 20th century, masturbation was believed to be the cause of various physical and mental ailments such as epilepsy, paralysis, impotence, gonorrhea, tuberculosis, intellectual disability, and insanity. In some cultures, males must be circumcised shortly after birth, during childhood or around puberty as part of a rite of passage. Circumcision is commonly practiced in Judaism and Islam. Circumcision is very important to Jews, with more than 90% of adherents having it as a religious obligation. The basis for this obligation is found in the Torah, in Genesis chapter 17, where the circumcision covenant was made for Abraham and his descendants. Jewish circumcision is part of the brit milah ritual, which is performed by a specialist circumciser (a mohel) on the eighth day of a newborn boy's life (with certain exceptions such as illness). Converts to Judaism must also be circumcised, those who have been circumcised undergo a circumcision ritual symbolically. Although there is some debate as to whether circumcision is a religious requirement in Islam, circumcision (called circumcision) is practiced almost universally by Muslim men. Islam bases its practice of circumcision on the narrative of Genesis 17, the same chapter of the Bible referred to by the Jews.

This procedure is not mentioned explicitly in the Quran, but it is a tradition ordained by the Prophet Muhammad directly, so the practice is considered a sunnah (traditional prophet) and is very important in Islam. For Muslims, circumcision is also a matter of cleanliness. There is no agreement among Islamic societies about the age at which circumcision should be performed. It can be done from soon after birth until around age 15, but is most commonly done around six to seven years. The time may correspond to the completion of the child's reading of the entire Quran. Circumcision can be celebrated with family or community events. Circumcision is encouraged, but not required, for conversion to Islam. One of the chapters of the New Testament, Acts 15 notes that Christianity does not require circumcision. Christians also do not forbid it; The Gospel of Luke states that Jesus himself was circumcised. In 1442, the leadership of the Catholic Church declared that circumcision was not necessary. Coptic Christians practice circumcision as a rite. The Ethiopian Orthodox Church advocates circumcision, with almost universal prevalence among Orthodox males in Ethiopia. In South Africa, some Christian churches disapprove of circumcision, while others require circumcision for their members. Some tribes in Africa, such as the Yoruba and Igbo in Nigeria, practice circumcising their babies. This procedure is also practiced by some tribes or family lines in Sudan, Zaire, Uganda and southern Africa. In some of these tribes, circumcision appears to be cultural, performed without any particular religious significance or intention to discriminate among the members of the tribe. For others, circumcision may be performed for purification, or interpreted as a sign of conquest. Among these tribes even circumcision, which is performed for reasons of tradition, is often performed in a hospital.

Biomolecules include large macromolecules (or polyanions) such as proteins, carbohydrates, lipids and nucleic acids, as well as small molecules such as primary metabolites, secondary metabolites and natural products. The more common name for this group is biological matter. Biomolecules are essential elements for living organisms, which are often endogenous, or produced within the organisms themselves. However, organisms usually need exogenous biomolecules, for example certain nutrients, to survive. Biology and its branches, biochemistry and molecular biology, study biomolecules and their reactions. Most biomolecules are organic compounds and only four elements—oxygen, carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen—make up 96% of the human body by mass. However, many other elements, such as various biometals, are found in trace amounts. Uniformity of the types of biomolecules and metabolic pathways is an unchanging feature among the diversity of life forms; As such, these biomolecules and metabolic pathways are referred to as "universal biochemistry" or "theory of the material unity of living things", a unifying concept in biology, along with the cell theory and the theory of evolution. There is a wide variety of biomolecules, which include small molecules: lipids, fatty acids, glycolipids, sterols, monosaccharides, vitamins, hormones, neurotransmitters, and metabolites; as well as monomers, oligomers, and polymers as shown in the table below. Monosaccharides (mono- meaning 'one', -saccharides meaning 'sugar') are the simplest form of carbohydrates in the form of one sugar. In their structure, monosaccharides contain an aldehyde group (this group is called an aldose) or a ketone group (this group is called a ketose).

Monosaccharides with three carbon atoms are called trioses, four carbon atoms are called tetroses, five are pentoses, six are hexoses, and so on. Examples of monosaccharides are glucose, fructose, galactose, ribose, and deoxyribose. When consumed, glucose and fructose have different rates of gastric emptying, are absorbed differently and have different metabolic fates, opening up many opportunities for the two types of saccharides to influence food intake differently. Most of the saccharides are used as fuel for cellular respiration. Disaccharides are formed when two monosaccharides form a glycosidic bond by removing a water molecule. One disaccharide molecule can also be separated into two monosaccharide molecules by hydrolysis. Examples of disaccharides are sucrose, maltose, and lactose. Polysaccharides are monosaccharides polymerized into complex carbohydrates. Examples are starch, cellulose, and glycogen. Polysaccharide molecules are generally large and often have complex branched connectivity. The shorter polysaccharides, with 3 to 10 monomers are called oligosaccharides. Lipids are generally esters of fatty acids, and serve as the basic building blocks of biological membranes and energy storage (eg triglycerides). Most lipids consist of a polar or hydrophilic head region (usually glycerol) and a tail region consisting of one to three fatty acid molecules which are nonpolar or hydrophobic. Due to these two properties, lipids are referred to as amphiphilic molecules. Fatty acids consist of an unbranched chain of carbon atoms connected by single bonds (these types are called saturated fatty acids) or by single and double bonds (these types are called unsaturated fatty acids). The chains usually consist of 14 to 24 carbon groups, and this number is always even. (2) phospholipids, whose heads contain a positively charged group connected to the tail by a negatively charged phosphate group; or (3) sterols, whose heads contain a planar steroid ring, eg cholesterol.

Amino acids are biomolecules that contain amine (–NH2) and carboxyl (–COOH) functional groups, plus a side chain (the "R" group) that is specific for each type of amino acid. These molecules are monomers which, when combined, form peptides (both oligopeptides and polypeptides) and proteins. Apart from those used in protein synthesis, other amino acids that are important in biological processes include carnitine (used in lipid transport within cells), ornithine, GABA, and taurine. Nucleosides are molecules formed by attaching nucleobases to pentose sugar rings in the form of ribose or deoxyribose, for example cytidine (C), uridine (U), adenosine (A), guanosine (G), and thymidine (T). Nucleosides can undergo phosphorylation (addition of a phosphate group) to give nucleotides. Editor page that has logged out learn more Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health Science Physics (borrowed from Dutch: physica, from Greek: φυσικός, translit. fysikós meaning "natural" or Greek: φύσις, translit. fýsis meaning "nature" ; Latin: Physica; Arabic: فيزياء, translit. fīziyāʾ‎) is a science or natural science that studies matter and its motion and behavior in space and time, together with related concepts such as energy and force. As one of the most basic sciences, the main goal of physics is to understand how the universe works. a] People or scientists who are experts in physics are called physicists or physicists. Physics is one of the oldest academic disciplines, perhaps the oldest through which astronomy is included. For more than two millennia, physics was part of the Natural Sciences along with chemistry, biology, and certain branches of mathematics, but with the advent of the scientific revolution in the 17th century, natural science developed as a research program of its own. others, such as biophysics and quantum chemistry, and their physical boundaries are not clearly defined. New knowledge in physics is sometimes used to explain the underlying mechanics of other sciences as well as to pave the way for other research areas such as mathematics and philosophy. Physics also makes an important contribution to the development of technology that develops from theoretical thinking. For example, further understanding of electromagnetism or nuclear physics has led directly to the development of new products that have dramatically shaped modern society, such as televisions, computers, household appliances, and nuclear weapons; advances in thermodynamics led to the development of industrialization, and advances in mechanics inspired the development of calculus. Astronomy is the oldest natural science. The oldest recorded civilizations date back to around 3000 BC, such as the Sumerians, Ancient Egypt, and the Indus Valley Civilization.

All of them have predictive knowledge and a basic understanding of the movements of the moon, sun and stars. Stars and planets are sometimes used as targets of worship, they believe that it is their god. Despite the often unscientific explanations for this phenomenon and the lack of evidence available, these early observations became the basis for later astronomy. According to Asger Aaboe, the beginnings of Western astronomy can be found in Mesopotamia, and all Western endeavors in the exact sciences date back to late Babylon. Egyptian astronomers left monuments showing knowledge of the constellations and the motions of the celestial bodies, while the Greek poet Homer described various celestial bodies in his Iliad and Odyssey; later Greek astronomers gave the names, which are still used today, to most of the constellations visible from the northern hemisphere. Natural philosophy originated in Greece in the Archaic period, (650 BCE – 480 BCE), when pre-Socratic philosophers such as Thales rejected non-naturalistic explanations for natural phenomena and argued that every event had a natural cause. They proposed ideas that were proven by reason and observation, and many of their hypotheses proved successful in experiments; for example, atomism was finally confirmed 2,000 years after it was first proposed by Leucippus and his student Democritus. Islamic scholars had inherited Aristotelian physics from the Greeks and during the Golden Age of Islam increasingly advanced, placing observation and a priori thinking as their focus, developing early forms of the scientific method. The most important discoveries were in the field of optics and sight, resulting from the work of many scientists such as Ibn Sahl, Al-Kindi, Ibn al-Haytham, Al-Farisi and Avicenna. The most important work is The Book of Optics (also known as Kitāb al-Manāẓir), written by Ibn Al-Haitham, in which he was not only the first to reject the ancient Greek idea of ​​vision, but also gave a new theory.

In this book, he was also the first to study the study of pinhole cameras and develop them. By dissecting and using the knowledge of previous thinkers, he was able to begin to explain how light entered the eye, was focused and projected back into the eye, and created the world's first camera obscura hundreds before the development of modern photography. The seven-volume Book of Optics (Kitab al-Manathir) has greatly influenced interdisciplinary thinking from the theory of visual perception to perspectives on medieval art in both East and West, for more than 600 years. Many later European scientists and polymaths, from Robert Grosseteste and Leonardo da Vinci to René Descartes, Johannes Kepler and Isaac Newton, used his thinking. The influence of Ibn al-Haytham's optics is also included in one of Newton's works with the same title, which was only published 700 years later. The translation of The Book of Optics had a great impact on Europe. Starting from there, European scholars were able to manufacture the same tools as Ibn al-Haytham, and understand how light works. From here, several inventions such as glasses, magnifying glasses, telescopes, and cameras developed. Physics became a separate science when early modern Europeans used experimental and quantitative methods to discover the so-called laws of physics. page required] The main developments in this period included the replacement of the geocentric model of the solar system with the heliocentric Copernican model, the laws governing the motion of the planets were put forward by Johannes Kepler between 1609 and 1619, experiments on telescopes and astronomical observations by Galileo Galilei in the 16th and 17th centuries, and Isaac Newton's discoveries of the laws of motion and the law of universal gravitation. Newton also developed calculus,c] the study of mathematical change, which provided new mathematical methods for solving physical problems.

The discovery of new laws in thermodynamics, chemistry, and electromagnetism resulted from the research efforts of the Industrial Revolution because additional energy was needed. These laws of classical physics are still widely used today for everyday objects traveling at non-relativistic speeds, because they provide very good approximations of those conditions. Theories such as quantum mechanics and relativistic theory can be simplified to their classical equivalents. However, the inaccuracy of classical mechanics for very small bodies and very fast objects led to the development of modern physics in the 20th century. Modern physics has its origins in the early 20th century when Max Planck did research on quantum theory and Albert Einstein did research on the theory of relativity. Both of these theories arose due to the inaccuracies of classical mechanics under certain conditions. Classical mechanics predicts that the speed of light varies, not according to the constant speed predicted by Maxwell's equations of electromagnetism. This error was eventually corrected by Einstein through his theory of special relativity, which later replaced classical mechanics for fast-moving objects and their speeds approaching the speed of light. Black-body radiation was also a problem for classical physics, which was later corrected when Planck proposed that the excitation of a material oscillator is possible only in discrete steps proportional to its frequency. This theory, along with the photoelectric effect and later the more complete theory of predicting the discrete energy levels of electron orbitals, eventually allowed the theory of quantum mechanics to replace classical physics at the infinitesimal level. Quantum mechanics appeared pioneered by Werner Heisenberg, Erwin Schrödinger and Paul Dirac. From the results of this early work, the standard model of particle physics was derived. After the discovery of a particle with characteristics consistent with the Higgs boson at CERN in 2012, all the elementary particles predicted by the standard model emerged and were accounted for; however, physics beyond the Standard Model, such as the theory of supersymmetry, is a growing area of ​​research.

Mathematics in general is important in this field, as is the study of probability and groups. Physical research is progressing constantly in many fields, and will remain so far into the future. In condensed matter physics, the biggest unsolvable theoretical problem is the explanation of high-temperature superconductivity. A lot of condensed physics research was done to make spintronics and quantum computers work. In particle physics, the first pieces of experimental evidence for physics beyond the Standard Model have begun to yield. The most well-known is the designation that neutrinos have non-zero mass. Kelantan became part of the Federation of Malaya on February 1, 1948 and together with other states, achieved independence on August 31, 1957. On September 16, 1963, Kelantan became one of the states that formed the Federation of Malaysia. The state of Kelantan is one of the "traditional" states of the Malays. Kelantan and Terengganu are states that are not ruled by Pakatan Harapan. The PAS party won the state assembly election in 1990 in this state, and managed to survive until now. The Sultan of Kelantan since 2010 is Sultan Muhammad V and the Chief Minister is Ahmad Yaakob.

The Fair Work Act 2009 was passed during the Rudd administration and most of the provisions of the law went into effect on July 1, 2009, replacing the Workplace Relations Act 1996 (1996). In the province of Ontario, Canada, if you have a formal complaint, you can submit it to the Department of Labour.
