The editor logged out page learn more White is the representation of the presence of all the primary colors in maximum state with equal proportions. White, like black and gray, cannot be said to be defined as a particular color. White in an ideal sense means the presence of all colors with maximum light so that they can no longer be represented by the eye or the camera sensor, contrary to the ideal definition of black. However several approaches to white have been carried out with pigments, for example chinese white, pure white, or other white derivatives often used in fine art supplies such as pastels or acrylics. In process inks for printing, white means no use of any of the Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, or Key pigments. However, for certain purposes, white fields are formed with process white ink. In photography, white is a sign that the film or sensor has exceeded its ability to capture light. This often occurs in long exposure techniques or arises due to errors in measuring light so that it becomes over exposed. White has been generally accepted as the standard paper color in stationery. Because of that white is used by printers to determine areas that are not subject to ink. In making works of art, artists usually mix white with other colors to get colors called pastel colors, although this is not very precise because not all sticks of pastel produce these colors. Also in the use of pastels or acrylics, white that is superimposed firmly on top of the dried color will produce a flashing light effect. Psychologically, the effect of white can vary. This is influenced mainly by the local culture. For example, in Europe, white is considered calming, cool and timeless because of its association with snow.

Logout editor page learn more Yudistira (Dewanagari: युधिष्थिर; IAST: Yudhiṣṭhira, युधिष्थिर) alias Dharmawangsa, is one of the protagonists in the epic Mahabharata. He was a king who ruled the Kuru kingdom, with the center of government in Hastinapura. He is the eldest of the five Pandavas, or sons of Pandu. In the puppet tradition, Yudistira was given the title of king and had the nickname Puntadewa, while his kingdom was called the Kingdom of Amarta. The name Yudistira in Sanskrit means "firm or firm in battle". In the Mahabharata book, he is also referred to as Bharata (descendant of Maharaja Bharata) and Ajatasatru. He is also known as Dharmaraja, which means "Dharma king", because he always tried to uphold dharma throughout his life. Some of the other epithets that Yudhisthira had were Kururaja (कुरुराज, "leader of the Kuru race"), Kurunandana (कुरूनन्दन, "beloved of the Kuru Dynasty"), Kurupati (कुरुपति, "king of the Kuru Dynasty"), Pandava (पान्द्व, "son of Pandu"), Parta (पार्थ, "son of Prita or Kunti"). Some of the above names were also used by other figures of the Kuru Dynasty, such as Arjuna, Bhishma, and Duryodhana. In addition to the above names, in the Javanese puppet version there are still several other names or nicknames for Yudistira, for example: Puntadewa ("his degree of nobility is equal to the gods"), Yudistira ("skillful in fighting personal lust"), Gunatalikrama ("skillful speak the language"), Samiaji ("respect others as yourself"). Yudistira was the eldest son of Pandu and Kunti, king and queen of the Kuru Dynasty, with the center of government in Hastinapura. The first part of the Mahabharata book (Adiparwa) tells about the curse that Pandu experienced after killing a brahmin named Resi Kindama by accident. The Brahmin was struck by Pandu's arrow while he and his wife were having intercourse in the form of a pair of deer.

When his death came, Resi Kindama cursed Pandu that one day he would die while having sex with his wife. Regretfully, Pandu left the throne of Hastinapura and began life as a hermit in the forest to reduce his passions. His two wives, Kunti and Madri, faithfully followed him. After not having children for a long time, Pandu expressed his intention to have children. Kunti, who mastered the Adityahredaya mantra, immediately fulfilled her husband's wish. The mantra is the art of summoning a god to get a son. By using this mantra, Kunti managed to summon the god Dharma and get the gift of a son from him without having sexual intercourse. The first son was named Yudistira. Thus, Yudhisthira became the eldest son of Pandu, as a result of being gifted by Dharma, the god of justice and wisdom. The story in Javanese wayang is somewhat different. According to this version, Puntadewa is Pandu's biological son who was born in the palace of Hastinapura. The arrival of Bhatara Dharma was only to help the birth of Puntadewa and give his blessing. Thanks to the god's help, Puntadewa was born through Kunti's crown. In Javanese wayang, the name Puntadewa is more often used, while the name Yudistira is only used after he grows up and becomes king. This version depicts Puntadewa as a human with white blood, which is an allegory that he is a figure with a pure heart and always upholds the truth. Yudistira and his four younger siblings, namely Bima (Bimasena), Arjuna, Nakula and Sadewa returned to Hastinapura after their father (Pandu) died. At that time, Hastinapura was led by Dhritarastra, Pandu's brother who was blind. The five sons of Pandu—who are known as the Pandavas—make their cousins, namely the sons of Dretarastra (one hundred Korawas led by Duryodhana) feel jealous. Bhishma (an elder of the Kuru dynasty) and Widura (prime minister) favored Yudistira over Dhritarastra's son, so that Duryodhana was worried if Yudistira succeeded in being crowned as crown prince.

Duryodhana tried to get rid of the five Pandavas, especially Bima who was considered the strongest. On the other hand, Yudistira always tries to persuade Bima not to reply to the Korawa's actions. The Pandavas and Korawas then studied religion, law and state administration from Resi Krepa. In this education, Yudistira appeared as the smartest student. Krepa really supports it when the throne of Hastinapura is handed over to the oldest Pandawa. After that, the Pandavas and Korawas studied war science from Resi Drona. In this second education, Arjuna appeared as the most intelligent student, especially in archery. Meanwhile, Yudistira himself was more skilled in using spear weapons. As long as Pandu lived in the forest until he finally died, the throne of Hastinapura was temporarily held by his older brother, Dretarastra, the father of the Kauravas. When Yudistira reached adulthood, the time had come for Dhritarashtra to hand over the throne to Yudhisthira, as the eldest son of Pandu and the oldest prince in the Kuru dynasty. Meanwhile, Duryodhana tries hard to seize the throne and get rid of the Pandavas. With the help of Shakuni (maternal uncle), Duryodhana pretended to entertain his five cousins ​​in a building in Waranavata. The building itself is made of flammable material, and the architect (Purocana) called it Laksagraha, meaning "House of Candles". When night fell, the Kauravas set fire to the building where the Pandavas and Kunti, their mother, were sleeping. However, Yudistira had already prepared himself because his uncle, Widura, Pandu's younger brother, heard about the plan to kill him. As a result, the five Pandavas and Kunti managed to escape death. The Pandavas and Kunti then went through various difficult experiences. After surviving the assassination conspiracy by Duryodhana and Shakuni, the Pandavas and Kunti travel to the city of Ekachakra, where they live temporarily in the Panchala kingdom.

Arjuna won the competition in the kingdom and got a beautiful daughter named Draupadi. Kunti accidentally ordered Draupadi to be divided by five. As a result, Draupadi became the fifth wife of the Pandavas. From his marriage to Yudistira, Draupadi gave birth to Pratiwindya. His second wife was named Dewika, daughter of Gowasana of the Saibya tribe, and had a son named Yodeya. The Javanese version calls Draupadi by the name "Draupadi". According to Javanese wayang, after winning the contest, Arjuna handed over the daughter to Puntadewa as the eldest sister. At first Puntadewa refused, but after being pressured by his mother and four younger siblings, he finally agreed to marry Draupadi. From this marriage was born a son named Pancawala. So, according to the original version, the character of Dropadi is married to the five Pandavas, while according to the Javanese version, she is only married to Yudistira alone. After marrying Draupadi, the Pandavas returned to Hastinapura and received an extraordinary welcome, except from Duryodhana. The rivalry between the Pandavas and Korawas for the throne of Hastinapura is back. The elders finally agreed to give the Pandavas some of the kingdom's territory. The Korawas got the Hastinapura palace, while the Pandavas got the Kandawaprastha forest as a place to build a new palace. Even though the area was very arid and haunted, the Pandavas were willing to accept the area. In addition to its area covering almost half the area of ​​the Kuru kingdom, Kandawaprastha was also the capital of the former Kuru kingdom, before Hastinapura. The Pandavas were assisted by their cousins, namely Kresna and Baladewa, and managed to open Kandawaprastha into a new settlement. The Pandavas then received help from Wiswakarma, a builder from heaven, and also Anggaparna from the Gandharwa nation. Thus a magnificent and beautiful palace was created named Indraprastha, which means "city of the god Indra". In the Javanese wayang version, Indraprastha's name is better known as the kingdom of Amarta.

According to this version, the forest opened by the Pandavas was not called Kandawaprastha, but rather Wanamarta. The Javanese version tells that after the Dropadi contest, the Pandavas did not return to Hastinapura but went to the kingdom of Virata, where their relative named Prabu Matsyapati ruled. Matsyapati who sympathized with the experience of the Pandavas suggested that they open up an uninhabited forest area called Wanamarta into a new kingdom. Wanamarta Forest is inhabited by various ethereal beings led by five brothers, named Yudistira, Danduncana, Suparta, Sapujagad, and Sapulebu. The work of the Pandavas in clearing the forest encountered many obstacles. Finally after going through a conversation, the ethereal beings surrender Wanamarta to the Pandavas. Yudistira then moved Amarta's palace from the genie realm to the real realm to be inhabited by the Pandavas. After that, he and his four siblings disappeared. One version mentions that the five of them each merged into the five Pandavas. Puntadewa then became the King of Amarta after being pushed and forced by his four younger siblings. To remember and respect the genie king who had given him a palace, Puntadewa took the title Prabu Yudistira. After becoming the King of Amarta, Puntadewa tried hard to prosper his country. It is said that the news was heard that anyone who can marry the princess of Slagahima Kingdom named Dewi Kuntulwinanten, then the country where he lives will become prosperous and prosperous. Puntadewa himself has decided to have only one wife. But because Draupadi allowed him to marry again for the sake of the country's prosperity, he set off for the Kingdom of Slagahima. At the Slagahima palace many kings and princes have gathered who came to propose to Kuntulwinanten. But the princess was only willing to marry someone with a pure heart, and she found that criteria in Puntadewa. Then Kuntulwinanten was suddenly destroyed and merged into Puntadewa.

Actually, Kuntulwinanten is not a real human being, but an incarnation of the gods' gift for a just king who only thinks about the well-being of his country. While the original son of king Slagahima was named Tambakganggeng. He then served Puntadewa and was appointed as patih in the Amarta kingdom. The second part of the Mahabharata or Sabhaparwa tells the story of Yudhishthira's intention to hold the Rajasuya ceremony in order to spread dharma and get rid of the angry kings. Bhima, Arjuna, Nakula, and Sadewa led their respective armies to the four corners of Bharatawarsha (Ancient India) to collect tribute in the grand ceremony. At the same time, an angry Angkara king also held a ceremony to sacrifice a hundred kings. The king was named Jarasanda from the kingdom of Magadha. Yudhishthira sent Bhima and Arjuna accompanied by Krishna as advisors to defeat Jarasanda. Finally, through an exciting contest, Bima managed to kill Jarasanda. After all the requirements were met, Yudistira performed the Rajasuya ceremony which was attended by many kings and priests. On that occasion, Yudistira was designated as Maharajadhiraja. Then appeared an ally of Jarasanda named Sisupala who insulted Krishna in public. After passing the 100th insult, Krishna finally beheaded Sisupala in public. When he was a guest at the Rajasuya event, Duryodana was very impressed and envious of the beauty of the Indraprastha palace. His intention to seize the kingdom arose, especially after he was offended by Draupadi's speech in a meeting. Sangkuni helped Duryodhana's intentions by taking advantage of Yudhishthira's fondness for the game of dice. Yudistira was indeed a religious man, but on the other hand he loved the game very much. Duryodhana's invitation was accepted well. A dice game between the Pandavas against the Kauravas was held in the Hastinapura palace. At first Yudistira only bet small. But everything fell into the hands of Duryodhana thanks to Sakuni's skill in throwing dice.

Shakuni's instigation made Yudistira desperate to risk all of his wealth, even Indraprastha. Finally, the land that was built with great difficulty fell into the hands of the enemy. Yudistira, who had dark eyes, also bet his four younger siblings in succession. The four of them also fell into the hands of Duryodhana one by one, and finally Yudistira himself. Duryodhana still forced Yudistira, who had lost his independence, to continue the game, risking Draupadi. As a result, Draupadi also met the same fate. Draupadi's wailing when publicly humiliated was heard by Gandari, the mother of the Kauravas. He ordered that Duryodhana stop the game and return everything to the Pandavas. With a heavy heart, Duryodhana was forced to obey his mother's orders. Duryodhana who was disappointed again challenged Yudhisthira some time later. This time the rules changed. Whoever the loser must surrender the state and its contents, and live in the jungle for 12 years and undercover for a year in a kingdom. If the impersonation was discovered, it must repeat the disposal for 12 years and disguise a year, and so on. Finally, thanks to Sakuni's cunning, the Pandavas suffered defeat for the second time. Since then the five Pandavas and Draupadi have spent their exile in the forest. The life of the Pandavas and Dropadi during their 12 year exile in the forest is narrated in the third volume of the Mahabharata book known as Wanaparwa. Yudistira, who felt most responsible for what had befallen his family and country, tried to remain steadfast in serving his sentence. He often had disagreements with Bima, who wanted to return to Hastinapura to quell the Kauravas. Even so, Bima remained submissive and obedient to Yudhisthira's orders to serve the punishment according to the agreement.

Once upon a time the Korawas came into the forest to have a party to torment the feelings of the Pandavas. However, they were at odds with the Gandharwas led by Citrasena. In that event Duryodhana was caught by Citrasena. However, Yudistira instead sent Bima and Arjuna to help Duryodhana. He threatened to go alone if his two younger siblings refused orders. Finally the two Pandavas managed to free Duryodhana. Duryodhana's intention to come to the forest to torment the feelings of the Pandavas actually ended with the extraordinary shame he felt. Another incident that occurred was the kidnapping of Draupadi by Jayadratha, Duryodhana's brother-in-law. Bima and Arjuna caught Jayadratha and nearly killed him. Yudhisthira appeared and forgave the king of the Sindu kingdom. One day near the end of his exile, Yudistira and his four younger siblings helped a brahmin who lost his ceremonial equipment because it got entangled in the antlers of a wild deer. In pursuit of the deer, the five Pandavas felt thirsty. Yudistira also told Sadewa to find drinking water. After not returning for a long time, Nakula was told to follow, then Arjuna, then finally Bima followed. Yudhisthira is increasingly worried because none of his four younger siblings have returned. Yudhisthira then followed the Pandavas and found them dead on the edge of a lake. There is a stork (baka) who claims to be the owner of the lake. He said that the four Pandavas died of poisoning by the lake water because they refused to answer his questions. While holding back his thirst, Yudistira beckoned the crane to ask. The crane then transformed into a Yaksa. One by one question after question he managed to answer. These are some of the questions the Yaksa asked Yudhisthira: Yaksa: What is heavier than the Earth, higher than the sky, faster than the wind and more numerous than the haystacks?

Yudhishthira: The Mother is heavier than the Earth, the Father is higher than the sky, the Mind is faster than the wind and our worries are more numerous than a haystack. Yaksa: Who is the friend of a traveler? Who is the friend of a sick person and a dying person? Yudhishthira: A friend of a traveler is his companion. A doctor is the friend of a sick person and the friend of a dying person is charity. Yaksa: What things, if left behind, make someone loved, happy and rich? Yudhishthira: Arrogance, when abandoned makes one lovable. Desire, when left behind makes someone rich and greed, when left behind makes someone happy. Yaksa: What enemy is invisible? What diseases cannot be cured? What kind of man is noble and humble? Yudhishthira: Anger is an invisible enemy. Dissatisfaction is an incurable disease. Noble people are those who wish good for all beings and lowly people are those who do not know forgiveness. Yaksa: Who is truly happy? What is the greatest miracle? What's the way? And what's the news? Yudhishthira: One who has no debt is truly happy. Day after day countless people died. But those who are still alive hope to live forever. Lord, what greater miracle? The difference of opinion leads to an uncertain conclusion, the Śruti are different from each other, there is not even one Rishi whose thoughts can be accepted by all. The truth of Dharma and duty, hidden in the caves of our hearts. Therefore solitude is a path where there are big and small. This world filled with stupidity is like a wok. The sun is its fire, day and night are its fuel. The months and seasons are his wooden spoons. Time is the Chef who cooks all the creatures in that wok (with various such aids).

Here's the news. In the end, the Yaksa admitted defeat, but he was only able to revive one person. In this case, Yudistira chose Nakula to be revived. The Yaksa was surprised because Nakula was a half-sister, not a biological sister. Yudhisthira replied that he had to act fairly. His father, Pandu, had two wives. Because Yudistira was born to Kunti, the son he chose to live again had to be born from Madri, namely Nakula. The Yaksa was impressed by Yudhisthira's justice. He also returned to his original form, namely the God of Dharma. His arrival in the guise of a wild deer and a yaksa was to give the Pandavas a test. Thanks to Yudistira's justice and sincerity, it was not only Nakula who was revived, but also Bima, Arjuna and Sadewa. After 12 years of exile in the forest, the five Pandavas and Dropadi then entered a year incognito. As a hiding place, they chose the Matsya Kingdom led by Wirata. This story is found in the fourth volume of the Mahabharata or Wirataparwa. Yudistira disguised himself as Kanka as a Brahmin who taught King Wirata the game of dice. Bima becomes Balawa as a cook, Arjuna becomes Wrihanala as a sissy dance teacher, Nakula becomes Damagranti as a horseman, Sadewa becomes Tantripala as a cowherd, while Draupadi becomes Sailandri as a court lady. At the end of the Pandawa incognito year, there was an incident of the Kuru kingdom's attack on Virata's power. The whole power of the kingdom of Matsya kingdom soldiers were deployed to face Trigartha, an ally of Duryodhana. As a result, Matsya's palace became empty and was under threat from attacks by Hastinapura troops. Utara, the son of Wirata, who is assigned to look after the palace, departs accompanied by Wrihanala (Arjuna) as a coachman. On the battlefield, Wrihanala took off his disguise and appeared to face Duryodhana's army as Arjuna.

All alone he managed to beat back the troops from Hastinapura. Meanwhile, Wirata's army also won over Trigartha's army. Wirata proudly extols the greatness of Utara who managed to single-handedly defeat the Kauravas. Kanka alias Yudistira explained that the key to North's victory was Wrihanala. This made Wirata offended and hit Kanka's head until it bled. In the Javanese wayang version, Wirata is a royal name, not a person's name. While the king named Matsyapati. In that kingdom, Yudistira or Puntadewa disguised himself as the manager of the capital market named Dwijakangka. When the one-year deadline for incognito was completed, the five Pandavas and Draupadi opened their disguises. Knowing this, Wirata felt very sorry for treating them badly. He also promised to become an ally of the Pandavas in an effort to regain Indraprastha's throne. When the Pandavas returned to Hastinapura to claim their rights, Duryodhana was cynical about them. He did not want to hand over Hastinapura to Yudhisthira. Various peace efforts launched by the Pandavas but always rejected by Duryodhana. In fact, Duryodhana still refused when Yudistira only asked for five villages, not all of Indraprastha. At its peak, Duryodhana tried to kill the Pandawa ambassador, namely Krishna, but failed. The war in Kurukshetra between the Pandavas and Korawas could no longer be avoided. Javanese poets call this event the name Bharatayuddha. Meanwhile in the Mahabharata the story of the great war is found in the sixth to tenth volumes. During the war, Yudistira's chariot was decorated with banners depicting a golden moon surrounded by planets. Two drums named Nanda and Upananda are tied to the poles. In the Bhismaparwa section, it is told that before the first day of the war began, Yudistira got off his train and walked towards the Korawa army that was marching in front of him.

Duryodhana taunted him as a coward who gave up on seeing the power of Kauravas and their allies. However, Yudistira's arrival was not to surrender, but to ask for the blessing of the four elders who were fighting on the opposing side. They are Bisma, Krepa, Drona, and Salya. The four pray that the Pandavas will win. That of course made Duryodhana hurt. Yudhisthira returned to his army. He welcomes anyone who wants to move troops before the war actually starts. It turned out that the one who had moved was Duryodhana's half-brother who was born from a concubine, named Yuyutsu, who left the Korawas to join the Pandavas. Bhishma commanded the Korawa army for ten days. After he fell, his position was replaced by Drona, who received a mandate from Duryodhana to capture Yudistira alive. Drona was pleased with the task, even though Duryodhana's intention was to take Yudistira as a hostage to force his supporters to surrender. Drona used various methods to catch Yudhisthira. Countless Pandawa allies died at the hands of Drona for protecting Yudistira, for example Drupada and Virata. Finally, on the 15th day, the Pandawa advisor, namely Kresna, found a way to defeat Drona, namely by announcing the death of an elephant named Aswatama. Aswatama is also the name of Drona's only son. The name similarity was used by Krishna to trick Drona. On the orders of Krishna, Bima immediately killed the elephant and shouted announcing his death. Drona was worried when he heard the news of Ashwatthama's death. He immediately went to Yudhisthira, whom he considered the most honest human being, to ask about the truth of the news. Yudhisthira had to be dishonest. He confirmed the news of Ashwatthama's death without trying to explain that it was an elephant who died, not Drona's son. Yudhisthira's answer made Drona fall limp. He threw away all his weapons and sat in meditation.

Suddenly Drestadyumna son of Drupada came to him and cut off his head from behind. Drona was killed instantly. Yudhisthira was the one who felt the most guilt in this incident. Salya is Pandu's sister-in-law who is forced to help Korawa because of their trick. On the 18th day, he was appointed commander-in-chief by Duryodhana. Finally he was killed by Yudhisthira's spear. The Old Javanese Bharatayuddha text tells that Salya used a weapon called Rudrarohastra, while Yudistira used a weapon called Kalimahosaddha. He threw Yudistira's heirloom in the form of a book and suddenly it turned into a spear piercing Salya's chest. Meanwhile, according to the Javanese wayang version, Salya exerts Candabirawa's knowledge in the form of hideous dwarf giants, whose numbers actually increase when injured. Puntadewa advanced silent. Candabirawa was paralyzed immediately because Puntadewa had been possessed by the spirit of Resi Bagaspati, who was the original owner of this knowledge. Next, Puntadewa released Jamus Kalimasada who shot to hit Salya's chest. Salya died instantly. After running out of troops, Duryodhana hid at the bottom of the lake. The five Pandavas accompanied by Krishna managed to find the place. Duryodhana went ashore ready to face the five Pandavas at once. Yudistira refused Duryodhana's challenge because the Pandavas abstained from cowardly playing with the gang, like the Korawas when they killed Abhimanyu on the 13th day. Instead, Duryodhana was asked to fight one on one against one of the five Pandavas. If he loses, the kingdom must be returned to the Pandavas. Conversely, if he wins, Yudistira wants to return to living in the forest. Bima was surprised to hear Yudhisthira's decision, which seemed to give Duryodhana the opportunity to rule again, even though the Pandavas' victory was only one step away. In this case, Yudistira actually blamed Bima, who was considered to lack self-confidence. Duryodhana even though he is insolent but he is also a brave man.

He chose Bima as his opponent in the duel, the most valiant of the five Pandavas. After a fierce battle going on for quite a long time, finally towards dusk Duryodhana was defeated by being hit at his weak point, namely the thigh. This also completes Bima's oath that will kill Duryodhan because of his insult to Draupadi. Balarama was angry and determined to kill Bima because the thigh was a forbidden target in mace duels, but was warned by Krishna that Bima was only trying to carry out his oath. Duryodhana slowly died after exchanging tongues with Krishna. After the war ended, Yudistira performed the Tarpana ceremony to honor those who had died. He was later appointed as the king of Hastinapura as well as the king of Indraprastha. Yudistira patiently accepted Dhritarashtra as the old king of Hastinapura. He forbade his younger siblings to be rude and offend the Korawa father, but Bima always offended Dhritarashtra for the actions of his children so that the old king stepped down from the throne of Hastinapura. Yudistira then held Aswamedha Yadnya, which is a sacrificial ceremony to re-enforce dharma rules throughout the world. In this ceremony, a horse is released to wander for a year. Arjuna was assigned to lead the troops to follow and escort the horse. The kings whose territory the horse passed through had to choose to follow Yudhisthira's rules or be fought. Arjuna sent troops to the north, Bima to the east, Nakula to the west and Sadewa to the south. Finally after several battles, all the kingdoms chose to pay tribute. Once again Yudistira was crowned as the Maharaja of the World after the previous Rajasuya Ceremony. After the beginning of the Kaliyuga age and the death of Krishna, Yudhisthira and his four younger brothers retired from worldly affairs. The editor's logged out page learn more. Cantillations (or Canticles) are signs to assist with the ritual recital of readings from the Hebrew Bible in synagogue services. The cantillation is written and notated with special signs printed in the Masoretic text of the Hebrew Bible (or Tanakh) to complete letter dots and vowels. These signs are known in English as accents, notes or trope symbols, and in Hebrew as טעמי המקרא ta'amei ha-micra or simply טעמים te'amim. Some of these signs are also occasionally used in medieval Mishnah texts. The musical motifs associated with these signs are known in Hebrew as the niggun or neginot (as opposed to the Hasidic nigun) and in Yiddish as טראָפ trop; the word trope is sometimes used in English with the same meaning. Three systems of Hebrew punctuation (including vowel and cantillation symbols) are known to have been used: Babylonian, Palestinian and Tiberian; only the latter is currently in use. Babylonian Bible manuscripts from the Geonic period do not contain the hymn marks used today, but use small Hebrew letters to mark significant divisions in a verse. Up to eight different letters are found, depending on the importance of the break and where it occurs in the verse: these correspond approximately to the disjunctives of the Tiberian system. For example, in some codices the letter tav, for tevir (rest), is defined in the same way as the Tiberian tevir and zaqef. There are generally no symbols for the conjunctives, although some late manuscripts use these Tiberian symbols. There is also no equivalent for low-grade disjunctives such as telishah gedolah: these are generally replaced by the equivalent sign zaqef or revia.

There is no known musical realization of these signs, but it seems likely to represent a break or variation in the melodic set applied to each verse. (Somewhat similar to the system used in Qur'anic manuscripts to guide the reader in reciting verses: see Quran reading.) This system is reflected in the chant sign practices of the Yemenite Jews, who today uses Tiberian symbols, but tends to have musical motifs only for disjunctives and makes the conjunctives monotonous. The Yemenite Jews have only eight disjunctive motifs, thus clearly reflecting Babylonian notation. The same is true of the Karaite mode for haftarah; while in the Sephardi haftarah mode the different disjunctives often have the same or nearly the same motives, reducing the effective number of motives to the same amount. The Babylonian system, as mentioned above, is primarily concerned with indicating breaks in the verse. In contrast, the Early Palestinian texts are primarily concerned with the assignment of phrases: for example the sequences tifcha-etnachta, zarqa-segolta and pashta-zaqef, with or without the intervention of accented words. These sequences are generally linked by a series of dots, which are started or ended with dashes or dots in different places to indicate the sequence in question. Accented words (which in the Tiberian system denote conjunctives) are generally indicated by dots following words, ostensibly to link them to the next word. There are separate symbols for more complicated tropes such as pazer and telisha gedolah. Manuscripts are generally highly fragmentary, no two of them follow the same convention, and these marks may represent each reader's aide-memoire rather than a formal system of punctuation marks (for example, vowel signs are often used only where other words would be ambiguous). Within one manuscript, possibly of a younger date, there are separate signposts for the various conjunctives, completely outnumbering the Tiberian system (e.g., munach before etnachta has a different sign from munach before zaqef), and the overall system approaches the Tiberian in its completeness. .

In some other codices, especially those containing the Targumim rather than the original text, the Tiberian symbols were added by later hands. In general, it can be observed that the Palestinian and Tiberian systems are much more closely related to each other than the Babylonian system. This system of phrases is reflected in the Sephardic cantillation mode, in which conjunctives (and to some extent "close accompaniments" such as tifcha, pashta and zarqa) are given as flourishes leading to motifs following disjunctives rather than as motives of their own. The somewhat inconsistent use of dots above and below words as disjunctives is similar to that found in Syriac texts. Kahle also notes some similarities to the punctuation of the Samaritan Hebrew. By the tenth century AD, the chants used in Palestine had evidently become more complex, both because of the presence of pazer, geresh and telisha motifs in long verses and because of the realization that a phrase ending with a particular type of break varied according to the number of verses. words and syllables in the phrase. Because of this, the Tiberian Masoretes decided to create a comprehensive notation with symbols for each word, to replace the previously used separate system. In particular, it was necessary to create various accent words to show how to introduce and develop main motifs in long phrases. (For example, tevir is preceded by yan, a short flourish, in a short phrase but by darga, which is more complicated carrying the notes, in a long phrase.) The system they used is one used today, and is found in biblical texts such as Aleppo Codex. A Masoretic treatise called Diqduqe hate'amim (the exact rules of accent) by Harun ben Moses ben Asher survives, although the names and classification of accents differ somewhat from today.

As accents were not shown on Torah scrolls, it was deemed necessary to have a person making hand signals to the reader to indicate the pitch, such as the Byzantine neumes system. This system of cheironomy has survived in some communities to this day, especially in Italy. There is speculation that the shapes and names of some accents (e.g. tifcha, literally "hand width") may refer to hand signals rather than to the syntax of the function or melody they represent. Today in most societies there is no hand signal system and the reader learns the melody of each recitation beforehand. The Tiberian system spread quickly and was accepted in all societies by the 13th century. Each community reinterpreted the tradition of recitation so as to allocate a short musical motif to each symbol: this process has spread as far back as Western Ashkenazi and Ottoman (Jerusalem-Sephardi, Syrian etc.) traditions. Learning the accent and the music of the song is now an important part of preparing for a bar mitzvah, as it is the first occasion where one reads from the Torah in public. Early in the Reformation period there was a movement to abandon the system of hymn signs, and to give readings of the Scriptures in normal speech (in Hebrew or in the vernacular). In recent decades, however, traditional chant signs have been restored in many communities. The main purpose of hymn signs is to guide the chanting of sacred texts during public worship. Roughly speaking, every word of the text that has a cantillation mark on the main accent and corresponds to that sign is a musical phrase that tells how to sing those words. The reality is more complex, with some words having two or no signs and the musical meaning of some signs depending on context.

There are different sets of musical phrases associated with different parts of the Bible. The music varies with different Jewish traditions and individual office styles. Cantillation marks also provide information about the syntactic structure of the text and some say they are comments on the text itself, highlighting important musical ideas. Figures that are not random strings but follow a set and undescribed grammar. The word tambak, used in Hebrew to refer to a chant mark, literally means "sense" or "sense", meaning that the pauses and intonations indicated by the accent (with or without formal music) bring out the feeling of the passage. There are two systems of cantal signs in the Tanakh. One of them is used in twenty-one books of prose, while the other appears in the three poetic books of Psalms, Proverbs and Job. Unless otherwise stated, this article describes the "prose" of the system. Currently the cantillation note system has historical roots in the Tiberian masorah. The cantillation mark is entered in Unicode as the characters U+0591 to U+05AF in the block of the Hebrew alphabet . The names of some of the cantillation signs differ in Ashkenazi, Sephardi, Italian and Yemeni traditions; for example Sephardim use qadma which means the same as Ashkenazim pashta, and azla is the same as Ashkenazim qadma. In this article, as in most Hebrew grammars, Ashkenazi terminology is used. Names in other traditions are shown in the table below. The cantillation signs serve three functions: In general, each word in the Tanakh has one cantillation mark. It may be either disjunction, indicating a division between being and the following words, or a word, joining two words (like a slur in music). Thus, disjunctives divide the verse into phrases, and in each sentence, all the words except the last carry the conjunctives.

(There are two kinds of exceptions to the rule about words having only one sign. Groups of words followed by a hyphen are considered one word so they only have one accent between them. Conversely, long words may have two, for example, separators on the stressed syllable is related to the two-syllable word before it in place meteg.) Disjunctives are traditionally divided into four levels, with the lower level disjunctives marking the less important break. The general conjunctive is munach. Depending on which separates the following, it can be replaced by yan, mahpach, darga, qadma, telisha qetannah or yerach ben yomo. One of the other symbols is yan full, double yan. There is some debate about whether this is a link or an occasional replacement for tevir. Disjunctives function somewhat similarly to punctuation in Western languages. Sof pasuq can be thought of as full stop, atnach as semi-colon, second degree disjunctives as comma and third degree disjunctives as comma or unsigned. Where the two words are written in building a country (eg, pene ha-mayim, "the face of the waters"), the first noun (nomen regens) always carries a conjunction. The cantillation sign is often an important aid in the interpretation of a passage. For example, the words qol qore beautiful dead sea panu derekh YHWH (Isaiah 40:3) are translated in the Official Version as "a voice that cries out in the wilderness: Prepare the way for the LORD". As the word qore takes on a high degree of dissociation zaqef qaton this meaning despairs with the chant sign. citation needed] Thus, the New Revised Standard Version translates "A voice cries out: 'In the wilderness prepare the way of the LORD, ...'" while the New Jewish Publication The Society's version has "a voice rings out: 'Sky in the desert road to LORD'."

Most hymn signs are written on the consonants which emphasize the syllables of a word. It also shows where the most important note of motive music should go. Some signs always go on the first or last consonant of a word. This may be for the music, or perhaps to distinguish them from other accents of the same form. For example, pashta, which runs on the last consonant, is otherwise visible like qadma, which runs on the stressed syllable. Several written signs (and sung) are different when the word is not stressed on the last syllable. The pashta in words of this kind is doubled, one goes on the stressed syllable and the other on the consonant end. Geresh is doubled, unless it occurs in a non-finally-stressed word or follows qadma (to form the phrase qadma ve-azla). The hymn signs guide the reader in applying the Bible hymns to the reading. The incantation is technically considered a ritual form of speech intonation rather than a musical exercise like the rhythmic singing of hymns: for this reason, Jews always speak of reciting or reciting a passage rather than singing. (In Yiddish the word leynen 'read', comes from the Latin legere, giving rise to the English Jewish verb "leyn".) The reconstruction considers the signs representing the degrees of the various musical scales, that is, the individual notes, which puts it at odds with all existing traditions in which the signs always represent the melodic motive; it also does not take into account the existence of older systems of notation, such as the Babylonian and Palestinian systems. Musicologists have dismissed her results as dubious and her methodology as flawed. There is also the possibility of some convergence between Spanish and Portuguese and Iraqi London melodies during British rule in India and British Mandates in Mesopotamia. Jews from North Africa, the Middle East, Central Asia and Yemen all have local traditions of cantillation music. When the Jewish community emigrated (mostly to Israel) during the 20th century, they brought their musical traditions with them. But as the immigrants aged, many of the melodies of origin were forgotten, or became assimilated into the "Sefardi Jerusalem". For the Ashkenazim, there is only one chant for the Torah reading and a different song for the haftarot. Other communities, such as Syrian Jews, observe a difference between the two sets of hymns for the Ten Commandments but lack a specific melody for ta am 'elyon. The Ruth tune is generally the "default" tune for any book of Ketuvim (Hagiographa) that doesn't have its own tune. Unlike the Ashkenazi tradition, the eastern tradition, especially that of the Syrian Jews, includes the special melodic canticles of the Psalms, Proverbs and poetic passages from the Book of Job. In eastern societies, the Book of Proverbs is read on the six Sabbaths between Passover and Shavuot, the Book of Job on the Ninth Av, and the Book of Psalms read on many occasions. Editor's page logged out learn more Visakhi or Vaisakhi (Punjabi: ਵਿਸਾਖੀ) visākhī), also known as Baisakhi, Vaisakhi or Vasakhi is a festival celebrated throughout the northern Indian subcontinent, especially in the Punjab region by the Sikh community. Recently, this festival is also celebrated all over the world where there are Sikh celebrations. For Sikhs, this festival commemorates the founding of the Khalsa. It is also celebrated by Hindus and Buddhists for different reasons, including at the start of the new year. This festival is of great importance to Sikhs because on Vaisakhi Day i.e. in 1699, the 10th Sikh Guru, Guru Gobind Singh laid the foundation of the khalsa | Panth Khalsa] ], i.e. the Order of the Pure Ones. This day was also likened to a thanksgiving day by farmers, where farmers paid tribute, thanked God for a bountiful harvest and prayed for future prosperity. Vaisakhi is one of the important festivals which is celebrated with great joy and enthusiasm by people of other religions too. For Hindus, Vaisakhi is celebrated at the beginning of the New Year, and is celebrated with provisions for bathing, feasting and worship. . It is believed that thousands of years ago, Goddess Ganga descended to earth. And as a sign of respect for him, many Hindus gather along the sacred site of the Ganges for a ritual bath. This festival is centered in the holy cities along the Ganges River in northern India, or in the Srinagar Mughal Gardens, Jammu's Nagbani Temples, or anywhere in Tamil Nadu. Plant Hindu poles (wrapped in silk flags embroidered with gold) in front of their homes, and hang brass, copper or silver pots above. In Kerala, this festival is called 'Vishu'.

They do firework lighting, shopping for a new interesting dress called 'Vishu Kani'. And also arrangements of flowers, grains, fruits, cloth, gold, and money are seen in the morning, to ensure a year of prosperity. In Assamese, this festival is called Bohag Bihu, and people organize big parties, music and dancing. Swami Dayanand Saraswati founded Arya Samaj on Vaisakhi, in 1875. Apart from Sikhs and Hindus, Vaisakhi is an important day for Buddhists as well. This name is Vesakha, Vaisakha, Vesak or Vesak. It commemorates the Birth, Awakening and Far Enlightened Passing of Gautama Buddha who was born as prince Siddhartha. Vaisakhi is usually celebrated on April 13th, and sometimes on April 14th, in different areas of the world that as Sikhs have migrated abroad. The main celebrations take place at Talwandi Sabo (where Guru Gobind Singh stayed for nine months and completed his recompilation of Guru Granth Sahib), and at Gurudwara in Anandpur Sahib (see image above), Khalsa's birthplace and at the Golden Temple in Amritsar Vaisakhi separately. Widely celebrated by Sikhs in West Punjab (Pakistan) as well, with celebrations centered on the Hasan Abdal Panja Sahib complex, many Gurudwaras in the Nankana Sahib, and at various historical sites in Lahore. It is culturally and traditionally considered an important and significant Punjabi festival, further exemplified by the thousands of Sikh pilgrims from all over the world arriving every year to commemorate the day at the holy Sikh sites of Nankana Sahib and Hasan Abdal. Furthermore, Pakistani areas offer their good wishes and welcome incoming pilgrims. In April 2009, Pakistan's Sikh Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee announced plans to formally organize the event on a larger scale domestically as well as expressing intentions for an elegant arrangement.

In 2010, more than 20,000 pilgrims are expected to arrive in Pakistan for the celebrations, a significant increase over the previous years. In the United States, there is usually a parade commemorating the Vaisakhi celebration. In Manhattan, New York City Archived 2012-03-22 at the Wayback Machine. people go out to do "Seva" (selfless service) like give away free meals, and get any other work done that needs to be done. In Los Angeles, California, the local Sikh community of more than 20 Gurdwara s hold a full-day Kirtan (spiritual music) program followed by a two-mile parade in downtown Los Angeles with an estimated 15,000 participants. The local Sikh community in Vancouver, Abbotsford and Surrey, British Columbia, Canada holds an annual Vaisakhi celebration on the April long weekend, which often includes a Nagar Kirtan (parade) in which an estimated 200,000 people attend. The UK has a large Sikh community which was established in the 1960s with the arrival of immigrants from the Indian sub-continent, and which increased in the 1970s with refugees from East Africa and in the 1990s with refugees from Afghanistan. The largest concentration of Sikhs in the UK can be found in Birmingham in the West Midlands and Southall in west London. The Southall Nagar Kirtan is held on a Sunday one or two weeks before Vaisakhi, and draws between 40,000 and 75,000 people onto the streets. The Birmingham Nagar Kirtan is held at the end of April in association with the Birmingham City Council, http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/vaisakhi and it is an annual event attracting around 100,000 people starting with two separate Kirtan nagars departing from the Gurdwaras in the city and culminating in the Vaisakhi Mela at Handsworth Park The Sikh community is a minority in Malaysia. Editor page out log learn more Theory of Plate Tectonics (English: Plate Tectonics) is a major theory in geology developed to provide an explanation for the existence of evidence of large-scale movements carried out naturally by the Earth's lithosphere. This theory has included and replaced the Continental Shift Theory which was previously put forward in the first half of the 20th century and the concept of seafloor spreading which was developed in the 1960s. In short, because the outermost part of the Earth's interior is formed by two layers. At the top there is the lithosphere which consists of the crust and the top of the earth's mantle whose contents are rigid and solid. Beneath the lithosphere layer is the asthenosphere which is solid but can flow like a liquid very slowly and over a very long geological time scale due to its low viscosity and shear strength. Even deeper, the mantle below the asthenosphere becomes even more rigid. The cause is not colder temperatures, but high pressure. The lithosphere is divided into tectonic plates. On Earth, there are seven main plates and many smaller ones. These lithospheric plates ride on top of the asthenosphere. They move relative to one another at plate boundaries, either diverging (away), converging (collating), or transforming (sideways). Earthquakes, volcanic activity, mountain building, and oceanic trench formation all commonly occur in areas along plate boundaries. The lateral movement of the plates is usually at a speed of 50–100 mm/a. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, geologists assumed that the main features of the Earth were fixed. Most geological features such as mountains can be explained by the vertical movement of the crust as described in the geosyncline theory.

Since 1596, it has been observed that the shores of the Atlantic Ocean facing each other between the continents of Africa and Europe with North America and South America have a similar shape and appear to have once been one. This precision becomes even clearer when we look at the edges of the continental shelves there. Since then many theories have been put forward to explain this, but all have been deadlocked because the assumption that the earth is completely solid makes it difficult to find a suitable explanation. The discovery of radium and its heating properties in 1896 prompted a reassessment of the age of the earth, since previously estimates were obtained from its cooling rate and assuming the earth's surface was irradiated like a black body. From these calculations it follows that even if the Earth was a red-hot body at first, the Earth's temperature would decrease to what it is today in a few tens of millions of years. Given this newly discovered heat source, scientists think it plausible that the Earth is actually much older and its core is still hot enough to be in a liquid state. The theory of plate tectonics originates from the continental drift hypothesis proposed by Alfred Wegener in 1912 and further developed in his book The Origin of Continents and Oceans published in 1915. moving apart thus stripping the continents of the Earth's core like 'icebergs' of low-density granite floating on a sea of ​​denser basalt. However, without detailed proof and calculation of the forces involved, this theory was abandoned. It is possible that the Earth has a solid crust and a liquid core, but it still seems unlikely that the parts of the crust could move.

Later, the theory put forward by British geologist Arthur Holmes in 1920 proved that the link of these crustal parts might exist under the sea. His theory also proved that convection currents in the Earth's mantle were the driving force. The first evidence that the plates were moving came from finding differences in the direction of the magnetic fields in rocks of different ages. This discovery was stated for the first time at a symposium in Tasmania in 1956. Initially, this discovery was included in the theory of the expansion of the earth, but later it led to the development of a theory of plate tectonics which explained spreading as a consequence of vertical movement (upwelling) of rocks , but avoids the need for an earth whose size continues to grow or expand (expanding earth) by including subduction zones and translation faults. It was at this time that the theory of plate tectonics changed from a radical theory to a theory that was commonly used and then widely accepted among scientists. Further research on the relationship between seafloor spreading and geomagnetic reversal by geologist Harry Hammond Hess and oceanographer Ron G. Mason pinpointed the mechanism that explains the vertical movement of the new rock. As it was accepted that the Earth's magnetic anomaly represented by symmetrical parallel stripes with equal magnetization on the seafloor on both sides of the mid-oceanic ridge, plate tectonics became widely accepted. Rapid advances in early seismic imaging techniques in and around the Wadati-Benioff zone and a variety of other geological observations soon established plate tectonics as a theory of enormous explanatory and predictive capabilities. Research on the deep sea floor, a branch of marine geology which developed rapidly in the 1960s, played an important role in the development of this theory.

In line with that, the theory of plate tectonics was also developed in the late 1960s and has been universally accepted in all disciplines, as well as renewing the world of earth science by providing explanations for various kinds of geological phenomena and also their implications in other fields such as paleogeography and paleobiology. . The outer layer, the earth's interior is divided into lithosphere and asthenosphere layers based on mechanical differences and the way heat transfer occurs. The lithosphere is colder and stiffer, while the asthenosphere is hotter and mechanically weaker. In addition, the lithosphere loses heat by conduction, whereas the asthenosphere also transfers heat by convection and has an almost adiabatic temperature gradient. This division is very different from the chemical division of the Earth into a core, mantle, and crust. The lithosphere itself includes the crust as well as part of the mantle. A part of the mantle may become part of the lithosphere or asthenosphere at different times, depending on temperature, pressure and shear strength. The key principle of plate tectonics is that the lithosphere separates into distinct tectonic plates. This plate moves on top of the asthenosphere which has viscoelasticity so that it behaves like a fluid. Plate movement can be as fast as 10–40 mm/a (as fast as a fingernail grows) as on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, or as fast as 160 mm/a (as fast as a hair grows) as on the Nazca Plate. These plates are about 100 km thick and consist of a lithosphere mantle topped with a bed of one of two types of crustal material. The first is oceanic crust or "sima" as it is often called, a mixture of silicon and magnesium. The second is the crust. continent which is often called "unlucky", a combination of silicon and aluminum. These two types of crust differ in terms of thickness where the continental crust has a much higher thickness compared to the oceanic crust.

The thickness of the continental crust is 30–50 km, while the oceanic crust is only 5–10 km. The two plates will meet along plate boundaries, which are areas where geological activity commonly occurs such as earthquakes and the formation of topographical features such as mountains, volcanoes and oceanic trenches. Most of the world's active volcanoes occur along plate boundaries, with the Pacific Plate's Ring of Fire being the most active and widely known. Tectonic plates can be continental or oceanic crust, but usually one plate consists of both. For example, the African Plate includes the continent itself and parts of the bottom of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. The difference between continental crust and oceanic crust is based on the density of the material that forms it. There are three types of plate boundaries that differ in the way the plates move relative to one another. These three types each correspond to different phenomena on the surface. The three types of plate boundaries are: The movement of tectonic plates can occur due to the relative density of the oceanic lithosphere and the relatively weak character of the asthenosphere. Dissipation of heat from the mantle has been found to be the original source of the energy driving plate tectonics. The currently accepted view, though still somewhat disputed, is that the excess density of the oceanic lithosphere causing it to sink downward in subduction zones is the strongest source of plate motion. At the time of its formation on the mid-ocean ridge, the oceanic lithosphere was initially lower in density than the surrounding asthenosphere, but this density increases with aging due to cooling and thickening. The large density of the old lithosphere relative to the underlying asthenosphere allows for intrusion into the deep mantle at subduction zones so that it becomes the source of most of the driving force for plate movements.

The weakness of the asthenosphere allows the plate to move easily towards the subduction zone. Although subduction is believed to be the strongest driving force for plate movements, there are still other driving forces as evidenced by the presence of plates such as the North American plate, as well as the Eurasian plate which is moving but not subducting anywhere. This driving source is still a topic of intensive research and discussion among earth science scientists. Two- and three-dimensional imaging of the Earth's interior (seismic tomography) shows a laterally heterogeneous distribution of density throughout the mantle. These variations in density can be material (from rock chemistry), mineral (from variations in mineral structure), or thermal (through thermal expansion and contraction from heat energy). The manifestation of lateral density heterogeneity is mantle convection from buoyancy forces. How mantle convection relates directly or indirectly to planetary motion is still a field that is being studied and discussed in geodynamics. One way or another, this energy must be transferred to the lithosphere for the tectonic plates to move. There are two main types of forces that affect planetary motion, namely friction and gravity. In a study published in the January-February 2006 issue of the Geological Society of America Bulletin, a team of scientists from Italy and the United States argued that the westward component of the plates originates from the Earth's rotation and the tidal friction of the moon that follows it. They say because the Earth rotates eastward under the moon, the moon's gravity, even if it's minuscule, pulls the Earth's surface layers back west. Some have also advanced the controversial idea that these results might also explain why Venus and Mars lack plate tectonics, namely because there are no moons on Venus and the moons of Mars are too small to give it a tidal-like effect on Earth.

This idea itself is not new. This was originally proposed by the father of the hypothesis himself, Alfred Wegener, and later challenged by the physicist Harold Jeffreys who calculated that the magnitude of the tidal force needed would quickly bring the Earth's rotation to a halt long ago. Many plates also move to the north and west, even a lot of movement to the west of the Pacific Ocean floor is seen from the point of view of the spreading center in the Pacific Ocean which is facing east. It is also argued that relative to the lower mantle, there is a slight westerly component to the motion of all plates. The actual vector in the motion of a planet should be a function of all the forces acting on those plates. However, the issue is how much each process participates in the movement of each plate. The diversity of geodynamic conditions and the properties of each plate should make a difference in how actively those processes move the plate. one way of dealing with this problem is to look at the rate at which each plate moves and consider the available evidence for any driving force of these plates as far as possible.
