For example, the Pacific Plate is surrounded by a subduction zone (the Ring of Fire) and so it moves much faster than the plate in the Atlantic which is attached to adjacent continents and is not a subducted plate. Thus, the forces associated with the downward moving plate (slab pull and slab suction) are the driving forces that determine plate movement except for plates that are not subducting. However, the driving force of plate movement itself is still a matter of debate and research by scientists. References are needed] Earth has seven main plates and many small plates.

Editor page out log learn more Fairy or Elf is a term often used in folklore, fairy tales, fiction to describe beings who have supernatural powers who sometimes interfere in human affairs. The term fairy in Indonesian is often used in the translation of characters who describe them as elves or fairies (the term in English) in fictional stories and fairy tales from Europe. In modern fiction, the character of Peri is often borrowed from the original version and is used in today's fantasy fiction with various depictions depending on the author or creator. The word fairy comes from the Persian: پری Pari, which means fallen angel. In English, the name fairy originally came from the word elvish since before 1000 AD, which means the nation of fairies. In folklore these supernatural beings are a sacred race. According to the Indo-European root the name probably comes from albiz which, although of unknown origin, is a derivative of albho which means "white". These words became so popular among white people that today, in modern times, they can still be found in existence as nicknames and surnames such as Ælfræd "Fairy-counselor" (Alfred), Ælfwine "Fairy-friend" (Alvin), Ælfric The "elf government" (Eldridge), as well as female names like Ælfflæd "fairy-beauty". The fairy name is also associated with intertwined hair which is believed to bring bad luck if unhooked. Fairies are often told to have forms similar to humans, often also believed to be spirits or jinn who incarnate as beautiful women who like to disturb. In Europe (England) around 1592 by Shakespeare fairies were described as sprites or incarnated as beautiful women with wings (fairy), in Scandinavian countries and according to ancient stories from Northern Europe the naming of fairies was also given to spirits. described as metaphysical beings, supernatural or incarnations of nature.

Fairies are also often identified as mythological creatures. In its depiction, folklore that uses the term "fairy" often has different definitions of what a fairy is, on the one hand this name is often associated with supernatural beings such as demons, but at other times fairies are described as more real beings. The shape and appearance of these fairies vary, at times it is described that they are as tall as the average human being and at other times it is described that they are in the form of small creatures. In Europe fairies in "big" form are believed to have been "spoken" since before 1000 AD, while their "small" form followed later by forming their own appearance in the form of small creatures both winged and not, and believed to appear around 1250 - 1300M as a derivative term (from the Swedish alf, elfva) which was later translated as fairy (English) which means a small human-like creature. Fairies are sometimes described as having long, pointy ears, and having long hair. Fairies are also often depicted as changing forms, or taking the form of beautiful women who can suddenly disappear. Fairies can be described as good (helping humans) or evil. In fairy tales and love stories, fairies are often depicted as helpful creatures. Perhaps the most famous story in the depiction of fairies is the story of Cinderella, who, when in trouble, is helped by a fairy godmother. There is also the story of a goldfish from West Java, who is helping a kind-hearted child who is difficulties, fairies can take on animal manifestations such as langurs when they appear to Putri Purbasari. Another fairy who is described as kind-hearted is a house elf who lives with humans. In the story "The Cobbler and the Little Fairies," the cobbler's family life is uplifted when little fairies help him with his shoes who come out at night and make shoes.

In another story in Devon, the whole village can be lazy because the work of tailors, bakers, to winemakers is done by these little elves. However, not all house elves are described as coming out at night, there are also house elves that come out during the day. In one of the children's stories of Childcraft's world, the Swedish author describes a small house elf who comes out of her little door and with her magical powers shrinks the lonely child of the householder, who has been left behind by his working parents, to play with her. While the evil fairy is described as the cause of someone getting lost on his way. Fairies are also often depicted as mischievous (mischievous and playful), either mischief that brings good or bad. In Europe, mischievous and unruly children were often described as "just like little fairies". In the Peter Pan fairy tale, the little fairy Tinkerbell is described as a kind character to Peter Pan and evil to Wendy out of jealousy. Depictions of the origin of fairies are often associated with a kind/class of supernatural beings such as demons, who often come from mountainous areas. However, in its development, fairies are described as small creatures that can sleep on flowers, live in forests and guard trees so they are called forest fairies, or live in houses with humans like the house elf character described in the Harry Potter story. A common feature of fairies is their ability to use magic to change shape. Fairy gold is extremely unreliable, as it takes on the form of gold when used as payment but then turns into leaves, bushes, cakes, and various other useless things. There are also legends regarding fairy burials. William Blake claims to have witnessed it.

Allan Cunningham in his book, Lives of Eminent British Painters, records William Blake's claims. It is said that Blake one night in his garden saw creatures the size of grasshoppers in green and gray, placed a figure in a rose leaf and buried it with song. Fairies are sometimes believed to be creatures that are nosy to humans. They tangle sleeping people's hair, steal small objects, and mislead travelers. Tuberculosis is also sometimes attributed to fairies, who forced young men and women to dance every night. Animals (cows, pigs, ducks, etc.) ridden by fairies may become paralyzed or suffer from mysterious illnesses. In many legends, the fairies are prone to kidnapping humans, either as babies, leaving changelings in their place, or as young men and women. This abduction can happen temporarily or it can be permanent. In the Ballad from the 19th century, "Lady Isabel and the Elf-Knight", it is told that Isabel was taken away by a fairy knight. To save herself, Isabel killed the fairy knight. While the ballad "Tam Lin" tells of Tam Lin who lives among the fairies even though he is an "earth knight". In Sir Orfeo's poem, it is told that Sir Orfeo's wife was kidnapped by the king of fairies. While the poem Thomas the Rhymer tells of Thomas who has to spend seven years in the fairy world before making it back to the human world. Whereas in Oisín's story, the main character is kidnapped and is in the fairy world, when he intends to return, it turns out that in the human world time has passed for three centuries. Quite a lot of stories about fairies and changelings, namely a creature left by fairies as a substitute for the human child they kidnapped. Adults can also be kidnapped by fairies; a woman who has just given birth is usually prone to being kidnapped by fairies.

In some stories, a person can be kidnapped by fairies if they eat fairy food, such as Persephone and Hades. While the circumstances of people kidnapped by fairies vary according to some tales, some tell that captive fairies live happily while others always miss their old relatives. In Scottish folklore, fairies are divided into the Seelie Court, a fairy who is profitable but can be dangerous, and the Unseelie Court, a fairy who is evil. Fairies from the Unseelie court class often seek entertainment by doing things that are harmful to humans. Fairy troop refers to fairies that appear in groups and may establish settlements. By this definition, fairy is usually understood in a broader sense, as the term can also encompass a variety of mythical creatures primarily of Celtic origin; however the term can also be used to refer to similar creatures, for example Dwarves or Elves from Germanic folklore. The opponent is a solitary fairy, that is, fairies are not related to other fairies. There are several objects that are believed to prevent interference from fairies. The best known was cold iron while other methods were considered disturbing to the fairies: wearing clothes inside out, running water on them, bells (especially church bells), St. John's wort and St. John's wort. John's wort, and four leaf clover. Some lore is contradictory, such as Rowan trees in some tales been sacred to the fairies, and in other tales being protection against them. In Newfoundland folklore, the most popular protective object is bread. Bread is associated with the home and the hearth, as well as with industry and the taming of nature, and as such, seems to be disliked by some types of fairies. Fairies appear in medieval Romance as creatures that wandering knights might encounter.

A female elf appeared before Sir Launfal and asked for his love. Sir Orfeo's wife was brought in by the Fairy King. Huon of Bordeaux is helped by the fairy king Oberon. As the Middle Ages progressed, these fairy figures turned into witches and sorcerers. Morgan le Fay, whose connection to the world of Faerie is implied in her name, in Le Morte d'Arthur is a woman who has supernatural powers. Although their role declined, fairy characters never disappeared, among them the fairy story Sir Gawain and the Green Knight. Edmund Spenser featured fairies in The Faerie Queene. In many fictions, fairies are often confused with nymphs; while in others (e.g. Lamia), they were seen as displacing the Classical beings. 15th century poet and monk John Lydgate wrote that King Arthur was crowned in "the land of the fairy", and taken in his death by four fairy queens, to Avalon where he lies under a "fairy hill", until he is needed again. Fairies appear as important characters in William Shakespeare's A Midsummer's Night Dream, which is set in a wooded area and Fairyland, under the moonlight, and the disturbances of nature caused by the fairies' strife create tension that underlies the plot and guides the actions of the characters. Shakespeare's contemporary, Michael Drayton, featured a fairy in his story, Nimphidia. Fairies also appear in Alexander Pope's The Rape of the Lock. Madame d'Aulnoy coined the term contes de fée ("fairy tales", known in Indonesia as fairy tales). In the mid-1600s, a literary style called précieuses emerged, while stories told with précieuses included many fairies, fairies being less common in other countries; The Brothers Grimm included fairies in the first edition of their story, but they argued that they were not of German origin so they changed this in the second edition by replacing each word "Fee" (fairy) with a witch or wise woman.

J. R. R. Tolkien explains that these stories like this are set in fairy land. Fairies in literature took on new life with the emergence of Romanticism. Writers such as Sir Walter Scott and James Hogg were inspired by folk tales featuring fairies, such as the Ballad of the Border. During this time, fairy tales experienced an increase. This period was also marked by a revival of old fantasy themes, such as the Narnia books by C.S. Lewis, which featured ancient creatures such as fauns and dryads, and mixed them with old women, giants, and various creatures from folklore. Flower fairies of the Victorian period were popularized in part by Queen Mary, as well as by the British poet and illustrator Cicely Mary Barker who wrote eight books published from 1923 to 1948. Fairies, however, were depicted as more beautiful and smaller in size over time. Andrew Lang, complaining about "the fairies of the orchard and apple blossoms" in the preface to The Lilac Fairy Book, argues that "These fairies either try to be funny and fail, or they try to patronize and succeed." Fairies appear in the story Peter and Wendy by J. M. Barrie, published in 1911. In that novel, a fairy character named Tinker Bell is quite popular and has become an icon even today. Depictions of fairies appear as illustrations, for example in fairy tale books and sculpture. Several artists known for their depictions of fairies include Cicely Mary Barker, Arthur Rackham, Brian Froud, Alan Lee, Amy Brown, David Delamare, Meredith Dillman, Jasmine Becket-Griffith, Warwick Goble, Kylie InGold, Ida Rentoul Outhwaite, Myrea Pettit, Florence Harrison, Suza Scalora, Nene Thomas, Gustave Doré, Rebecca Guay and Greta James. The Victorian era was particularly distinct in its fairy paintings.

Editor page logged out learn more Copenhagen (/ˌkoʊpənˈheɪɡən/; Danish: København kʰøb̥m̩ˈhɑʊ̯ˀn] (listen)) is the capital and largest city of Denmark with an urban population (as of January 2015) 1,263,698 and a metropolitan area of 2,013,009 souls. The name comes from the word Købmandshavn, which means "merchant's harbor". Copenhagen is located on the east coast of the island (Sjælland) on the river Sont. The city is divided into several municipalities. The core "Municipality of Copenhagen" for example contains the Frederiksberg enclave, a municipality in its own right. Founded as a fishing village in the 10th century, Copenhagen became the capital of Denmark-Norway in the early 15th century. In the early 17th century, under Christian IV of Germany, Copenhagen developed into an important European regional center, consolidating its position as capital of Denmark and Norway with resources from both kingdoms. Various magnificent architectures were erected and remain tourist attractions to this day, such as Børsen (Bursa), Rundetårn (Round Tower), Rosenborg Castle and Frederiksstaden. After experiencing the effects of plague and fire in the 18th century, the city underwent a period of rebuilding. This included the establishment of the prestigious Frederiksstaden district and the establishment of several cultural institutions such as the Royal Theater and the Royal Academy of Fine Arts. After facing disaster in the early 19th century when Nelson attacked the Dano-Norwegian fleet and destroyed the city, rebuilding in the Danish Golden Age brought a Neoclassical look to the city's architectural appearance. After World War II, the Finger Plan further developed the business center and residential area along the rail line out of the city center. In the 21st century, Copenhagen is growing, supported by investment into existing infrastructure and institutions. The city is the cultural, economic and political center of Denmark, as well as one of the financial centers in Northern Europe with the Copenhagen Stock Exchange.

Since the completion of the Øresund Bridge, the Copenhagen metropolitan area has been connected to the Swedish province of Scania, with its largest city Malmö. Notable landmarks in Copenhagen include Tivoli Gardens, Little Mermaid Statue, Amalienborg and Christiansborg Palace, Rosenborg Castle and Frederik Church. Copenhagen has more than 94,000 students enrolled at universities and other institutions, such as the University of Copenhagen, the Danish Technical University and the Copenhagen Business School. The University of Copenhagen, founded in 1479, is the oldest university in Denmark. Copenhagen is also the home of football clubs FC København and Brøndby, as well as ice hockey teams Rødovre Mighty Bulls, Herlev Eagles and Hvidovre Ligahockey. Copenhagen is one of the best cities for cyclists. The Copenhagen Metro serves the city center along with a network of S-trains connected to the surrounding boroughs. Copenhagen Airport is the largest airport among the Nordic countries. Although the oldest recorded history of Copenhagen dates back to the late 12th century, recent archaeological finds of ruins near Kongens Nytorv date back to around 1020, thanks to the development of the city's rail network. Dredging at Pilestræde also uncovered a well from the late 12th century. Remains of an ancient church, with graves from the 11th century, were also found near Strøget. These discoveries suggest that the city's origins date back to at least the 11th century. During World War II in Denmark, Copenhagen was occupied by German troops along with the rest of the country from 9 April 1940 to 4 May 1945. Adolf Hitler hoped that Denmark could become a "model protectorate" and the Nazi authorities came aiming to come to terms with the Danish government. The 1943 Danish parliamentary elections were also allowed, except for the Danish Communist Party being barred from participating.

However in August 1943, after the government's cooperation with the occupying foreign forces had collapsed, several ships were deliberately scuttled in Copenhagen Harbor by the Royal Danish Navy to prevent use by German forces. At that time, the Nazis began to arrest Jews, although most fled to Sweden. In 1945 Ole Lippman, the Danish Chief Executive of Special Operations, invited the British Royal Air Force to assist their operations by attacking the Nazi headquarters in Copenhagen. Air Vice-Marshal Basil Embry then devised a plan to attack the Sicherheitsdienst and Gestapo buildings, the former offices of the Shell Oil Company. The political prisoners were kept in the attic to avoid air strikes, so the RAF only bombed the lower part of the building. This attack, known as "Operation Carthage", began 22 March 1945 with 3 waves. In the first wave, all six planes (each carrying a bomb) hit their targets, but one plane crashed near the Frederiksberg Girls School. As a result of the crash of this plane, 4 planes in the next wave thought that the school was a military target, and directed bombs at the school which caused the death of 123 civilians, 87 of whom were students. However, 18 of the 26 political prisoners in the Shell House managed to escape while the Gestapo archives were completely destroyed. On May 8, 1945 Copenhagen was officially liberated by British troops commanded by Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery who also handled 30,000 German soldiers who surrendered. Not long after the war ended, an urban development project called the Finger Plan appeared in 1947, encouraging the development of residential areas and business centers that spread out from the city center to the S-train routes. In addition, schools, hospitals, sports facilities were also rebuilt. As a result of the late 1960s student riots, the Bådsmandsstræde Barrack in Christianshavn was occupied, leading to the establishment of Freetown Christiania in September 1971.

Street traffic in the city increased dramatically and in 1972 the city trams were replaced by buses. From the 1960s, thanks to the initiative of the young architect Jan Gehl, pedestrian and bicycle paths were built in the city center. Copenhagen Airport was also enlarged, becoming a hub for the Nordic countries. In the 1990s, large-scale housing developments were realized in the port area and west of Amager. The national library's Black Diamond building on the waterfront was completed in 1999. Since the summer of 2000, Copenhagen and the Swedish city of Malmö are connected by the Øresund Bridge, which consists of a rail line and a road. Thus, Copenhagen became the new metropolitan center for both countries. This bridge brought significant changes to the public transport system and extensive development of the Amager area. The service and trade sectors in the city have developed and a number of banking and financial institutions exist. Educational institutions are also an important part, especially the University of Copenhagen with its 35,000 students. Another notable development in the city is the Copenhagen Metro, a rapid transit system opened in 2000 which in 2011 carried 54 million passengers annually. The Copenhagen Opera House, a gift from entrepreneur Mærsk Mc-Kinney Møller, was completed in 2004. In December 2009 Copenhagen hosted the COP15 world climate meeting. Copenhagen is part of the Øresund Region, consisting of Zealand, Lolland-Falster and Bornholm in Denmark and Scania in Sweden. Located on the east coast of the island of Zealand, part of the island of Amager and a number of other smaller islands. Copenhagen is bordered by Øresund to the east, the strait that separates Denmark from Sweden. The cities of Malmö and Landskrona lie across the strait from the city. By road, Copenhagen is 42 kilometers (26 mi) from Malmö, 85 kilometers (53 mi) from Næstved, 164 kilometers (102 mi) from Odense, 295 kilometers (183 mi) from Esbjerg and 188 kilometers (117 mi) from Aarhus via Sjaellands Odde.

The city center is located in the area originally within the fort, which until recently was known as the Fortification Ring (Fæstningsringen) and kept green all around. Then new areas emerged in the late 19th and early 20th centuries such as Østerbro, Nørrebro, Vesterbro and Amagerbro. The Kongens Enghave, Valby, Vigerslev, Vanløse, Brønshøj, Utterslev and Sundby neighborhoods developed from 1920 to 1960. These new areas were mostly residential areas, apartments, with parks and greenery. Copenhagen is in the oceanic climate zone (Köppen: Cfb). The weather is part of the low pressure area of ​​the Atlantic so conditions are unstable throughout the year. It rains frequently from July to September, moderate rainfall. While there can be snow from late December to late April, it can also rain with temperatures averaging around freezing. June is the most sunny month with an average of 8 hours a day. July is the warmest month with an average daily temperature of 20°C. In contrast, sunshine is least in November, averaging less than 2 hours a day and only 1.5 hours a day from December to February. In spring it warms again with an average of 4 to 6 hours of sunshine a day from March to May. February is the driest month of the year. There are some exceptions where under extreme conditions, up to 50 cm of snowfall can occur during a 24 hour period in winter, while summer temperatures have been as high as 33 °C (91 °F). Due to its location in the Northern Hemisphere, the amount of sunlight varies greatly in summer and winter. In summer, the sun shines from 04:26 and sets at 21:58, 17 hours 32 minutes.

Langelinie, a park and promenade along the inner coast of the Øresund, is home to one of Copenhagen's main tourist attractions, the Little Mermaid statue. In Copenhagen, many cemeteries double as gardens, even if only for quieter activities such as sunbathing, reading and meditation.

There is also Vestre Kirkegaard which is the largest cemetery in Denmark (54 ha (130 acres)) and contains many gardens, lawns, winding paths, monuments, lakes and many other park features. It is an official rule in Copenhagen that by 2015 all residents must be able to reach a park or beach on foot in less than 15 minutes. So, with this rule in place, several new parks were built, including the innovative Superkilen in the Nørrebro district. The city's historical center, Indre By or Inner City, contains many of the city's most popular monuments and attractions. The Frederiksstaden area, developed by Frederik V in the mid-18th century in Rococo style, contains the 4 mansions of Amalienborg, the royal residences, and the wide-domed Frederik Church at its center. Located directly across the water from Amalienborg is the recently completed Copenhagen Opera on the island of Holmen. South of Frederiksstaden, the Nyhavn canal is surrounded by colorful houses from the 17th and 18th centuries, as well as many restaurants and bars. This canal extends from the harbourfront to Kongens Nytorv square built by Christian V in 1670. Important buildings include Charlottenborg Palace, famous for its art exhibitions, Thott Palace (now the French Embassy), Royal Danish Theater and Hotel D'Angleterre, which has existed since 1755. Other landmarks of Indre By include the Christiansborg parliament building, the Town Hall and Rundetårn, formerly an observatory. There are also several museums in the area including the Thorvaldsen Museum which is named after the 18th century sculptor Bertel Thorvaldsen. Closed to traffic since 1964, Strøget is the longest pedestrian thoroughfare in the world at 32 km (20 mi) from Rådhuspladsen to Kongens Nytorv.

With shops, cafes, restaurants and buskers, this area is always busy and includes the ancient squares of Gammel Torv and Amagertorv. Rosenborg Castle on Øster Voldgade was built by Christian IV in 1606 as a summer palace in the Renaissance style. The castle contains the Danish crown jewels and crown regalia, the coronation throne, and tapestries depicting Christian V's victory in the Skanian War. Christianshavn is located southeast of Indre By on the other side of the harbour. This area was developed by Christian IV in the early 17th century. Impressed with the city of Amsterdam, he invited Dutch architects to create a canal inside the fort which is still well preserved today. The canal itself branches into the Christianshavn Canal and along the canal there are many houseboats and leisure boats which are one of the area's attractions. Then another place is Freetown Christiania, a fairly large area which was once occupied by students during a demonstration in 1971. Other important points in Christianshavn include the Church of the Savior and the Rococo Christian Church. The North Atlantic house which was once a warehouse today serves culture from Iceland and Greenland and inside is restaurant Noma, known for its Nordic cuisine. Vesterbro starts from Tivoli Park. This park is the most popular park in Denmark with its Pantomime Theater, Concert Hall and a number of restaurants and rides. The Carlsberg Quarter has a number of interesting remains of the old brewery with the same name, including the Gafar Gate and the Carlsberg Brewhouse. The Tycho Brahe Planetarium is located on the edge of Skt. Jørgens Sø, one of Copenhagen's lakes. Halmtorvet, the market behind Copenhagen Central Station, is a popular area with its cafes and restaurants. The former Øksnehallen cattle market has been transformed into a modern photography and art exhibition centre.

The Radisson Blu Royal Hotel, built by Danish architect and designer Arne Jacobsen for the Scandinavian Airlines System (SAS) airline between 1956 and 1960 was Denmark's tallest hotel at 6,960 m (22,830 ft) and the city's only skyscraper until 1969 Completed in 1908, Det Ny Teater (New Theatre) located on the road between Vesterbrogade and Gammel Kongevej has been a popular venue for musicals since its reopening in 1994. Nørrebro to the northwest of the city center has recently developed from a working district into a cosmopolitan area with a number of shops antique shops, ethnic food shops and restaurants. Most of the activity is centered on Sankt Hans Torv. Copenhagen's historic cemetery, Assistens Kirkegård, is the resting place of a number of famous people such as Søren Kierkegaard, Niels Bohr and Hans Christian Andersen but is also used by residents as parks and recreation. Situated north of the city centre, Østerbro is an upper-middle class district with a number of luxury residences, some of which are now embassies. This district extends from Nørrebro to the waterfront where the Little Mermaid statue can be seen from Langelinie. Inspired by the fairy tale by Hans Christian Andersen, this statue was created by Edvard Eriksen and completed in 1913. Not far from the Little Mermaid, you can see the Citadel (Kastellet). Built by Christian IV, the Citadel is one of the finest fortifications in Northern Europe. There is also a windmill. The Gefion Fountain (Gefionspringvandet) was designed by Anders Bundgaard and completed in 1908 standing just southeast of Kastellet. His image represents a Norse legend. As a separate municipality, Frederiksberg is located west of Nørrebro and Indre By and north of Vesterbro. Its famous landmarks include the Copenhagen Zoo which has been established since 1869 with more than 250 species from around the world and Frederiksberg Palace which was built as a summer retreat by Charles IV who was inspired by Italian architecture.

Now a military academy, the building overlooks Frederiksberg Park with its waterfall, lake and other decorations. The Frederiksberg Allé street connects Vesterbrogade with Frederiksberg Park and is filled with theaters and entertainment. Of the old theaters that have closed, the Betty Nansen and Aveny-T Theaters are still active today. Not far from Copenhagen Airport on the Kastrup coast is the National Aquarium of Denmark, which was completed in March 2013. With 53 aquariums, it is the largest facility in all of Scandinavia. Grundtvig Church, located in Bispebjerg, designed by P.V. Jensen Klint and completed in 1940. This church is a rare example of an expressionist church architecture. Apart from being the capital city, Copenhagen also serves as a cultural center for Denmark and Scandinavia. Since the late 1990s, the city has transformed from an ordinary capital city to an international metropolis of the class of Barcelona and Amsterdam. Copenhagen Fashion Week is the largest fashion event in Northern Europe, held annually in February and August. Copenhagen has several international class museums. The National Museum (Nationalmuseet) is the largest archaeological and cultural history museum in Denmark, containing the history of Denmark and foreign culture. The National Gallery of Denmark (Statens Museum for Kunst) is a national art museum with collections from the early 12th century to the present. As well as Danish painters, there are also collections by Rubens, Rembrandt, Picasso, Braque, Léger, Matisse, Emil Nolde, Olafur Eliasson, Elmgreen and Dragset, Superflex and Jens Haaning. Another important art museum is the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek which was founded by Carlsberg philanthropist Carl Jacobsen and contains much of his private collection. His main focus is more on statues and antiquities from Ancient Egypt, Rome and Ancient Greece. There is also a collection of Rodin sculptures, the largest outside of France.

In addition to a collection of sculptures, the museum also has a collection of paintings in the Impressionist and Post-Impressionist styles by Monet, Renoir, Cézanne, van Gogh and Toulouse-Lautrec. The Louisiana Museum of Modern Art is a modern art museum located on the northern edge of Copenhagen. The collection includes more than 3,000 pieces by Picasso, Giacometti and Dubuffet. The Danish Museum of Art and Design is located in the former Frederiks Hospital and displays a variety of Danish and international designs. Other museums are the Thorvaldsens Museum, dedicated to the works of the Danish romantic sculptor Bertel Thorvaldsen who lived and worked in Rome; the Cisternerne museum dedicated to modern glass art; and the Ordrupgaard Museum, located north of Copenhagen, containing collections of 19th-century French and Danish art and works by Paul Gauguin. Copenhagen has 2 of the oldest amusement parks in the world. Dyrehavsbakken is an amusement park founded in 1583, located in Klampenborg north of Copenhagen in the Dyrehaven forest area. Created as an amusement park complete with games, rides and restaurants by Christian IV, it is the oldest amusement park in the world. Dyrehavsbakken is usually shortened to just Bakken. Admission is free and Klampenborg Station on Line C is not far from the park. Tivoli Park is an amusement park located in the city center, between City Hall Square and Copenhagen Central Station. It opened in 1843, making it the second oldest amusement park in the world. Among the rides are the world's oldest surviving rollercoaster, Rutschebanen, dating back to 1915 and the oldest running ferris wheel, opened in 1943. Tivoli Park is also used as a venue for various performing arts. Copenhagen has over 94,000 students enrolled in some of its largest universities: University of Copenhagen (38,867 students), Copenhagen Business School (19,999 students), Metropolitan University College and University College Capital (10,000 students each), Danish Technical University (7,000 students), KEA (around 4,500 students), IT University Copenhagen (2,000 students) and Aalborg University – Copenhagen (2,300 students).

The higher education system in Copenhagen relies on public universities. One of them is the University of Copenhagen. Founded in 1479, this university is the oldest in Denmark. The university is also part of the International Alliance of Research Universities (IARU), which encourages international collaboration between the world's top universities such as Oxford, Cambridge, Yale, Berkeley and the Australian National University. The university also attracts around 1,500 international students each year. The Danish Technical University (DTU), Danmarks Teknikke Universitet, is located in Lyngby in the northern part of Copenhagen. As of 2013, the university is one of the best technical institutions in Northern Europe. Copenhagen IT University is the youngest university in Denmark, focusing more on the technical, social and business side of information technology. The Royal Danish Academy of Arts (Det Kongelige Danske Kunstakademi) has provided and taught art education in Denmark for over 250 years. These include the historic School of Visual Arts, which later developed into the School of Architecture, School of Design and School of Conservation. The Copenhagen Business School (CBS) is an EQUIS accredited business school located in Frederiksberg. University College Capital and Metropolitan University College also have branch campuses outside the city of Copenhagen. The Greater Copenhagen area has well-developed transportation infrastructure. Copenhagen Airport is the largest airport in the Scandinavian region which is located in Kastrup, on the island of Amager. This airport has been operating since 1925. It is connected to the city center by metro and other rail services. Copenhagen has a network of roads connecting it to other cities in Denmark and Sweden via the Øresund Bridge. Cars are still the most common form of transportation, accounting for two-thirds of the total distance traveled.

Editor page out log learn more Nucleotides are organic compounds consisting of a nucleoside and a phosphate group. It acts as a monomer that composes polymers in the form of nucleic acids, namely deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA); both are important biomolecules that make up living things on Earth. Nucleotides are obtained from food and also synthesized in the liver from nutrients. Nucleotides are composed of three subunits, namely a heterocyclic nitrogenous base group (which is called a nucleotide base or nucleobase), a pentose sugar (which is either ribose or deoxyribose), and at least one phosphate group. The four types of nucleobases in DNA are guanine (G), adenine (A), cytosine (C), and thymine (T); in RNA, the nucleobase used is uracil (U) instead of thymine. Nucleotides play an important role in metabolism at the basic and cellular level. Nucleotides contain chemical energy in the form of nucleotide triphosphates, namely adenosine triphosphate (ATP), guanosine triphosphate (GTP), cytidine triphosphate (CTG), and uridine triphosphate (UTP). These energy packages are distributed throughout the body's cells and provide energy for metabolic functions such as the synthesis of amino acids, proteins, cell membranes, and organelles; movement of cells and organelles (intracellular and extracellular); to cell division through mitosis and meiosis. In addition, the nucleotide participates in cell signaling via cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) and cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), and is a subunit for several cofactors, such as CoA, FAD, FMN, NAD, and NADP⁺. In cells, these cofactors play important roles in energy fixation (e.g. photosynthesis), metabolism, and cellular signal transduction. In experimental biochemistry, nucleotides can react with radionuclides to form radionucleotides. This process is called radiolabeling and is very important for exploring chemical reaction mechanisms.

A nucleotide is composed of three chemically distinct subunits: a sugar molecule with five carbon atoms (called a pentose), a heterocyclic nitrogenous base group (called a nucleotide base or nucleobase), and at least one phosphate group. The combination of a pentose sugar and a nucleobase is called a nucleoside. When the three subunits are joined, the nucleotide is also referred to as a "nucleoside monophosphate", "nucleoside diphosphate", or "monosaccharide triphosphate", depending on the amount of phosphate that makes it up. guanine) or pyrimidine (consisting of thymine, cytosine or uracil), and are referred to as ribonucleotides if the sugar is ribose or deoxyribonucleotide if the sugar is deoxyribose. In two adjacent nucleotide monomers, the phosphate group of one nucleotide is linked to the pentose sugar of the other nucleotide via carbon number 5 (called 5') by a covalent ester bond. This bond is called a phosphodiester bond. The bonds between one nucleotide and another form a long chain called a polynucleotide chain. This chain of combined sugar and phosphate molecules forms the strand as a 'backbone' in the form of a single or double twist. In one strand, the chemical orientation (direction) of the chain is said to be from the 5'-end to the 3'-end. This number refers to the five carbon sites in the sugar molecule in adjacent nucleotides. In a double twist, the two strands have opposite orientations. One chain has an orientation from 5' to 3', while the other chain has an orientation from 3' to 5'. This allows base pairs to be mutually complementary between them. All of these properties play an important role in DNA replication as well as the transcription of the genetic information encoded in DNA. Purine bases, namely adenine (A) and guanine (G), as well as pyrimidine bases, namely cytosine (C), are found in both DNA and RNA.

Meanwhile, the pyrimidine base, thymine (T), is only found in DNA, while uracil (U) is only found in RNA. Adenine pairs with thymine to form a base pair via two hydrogen bonds, whereas guanine pairs with cytosine via three hydrogen bonds. In addition to being the building blocks for nucleic acids, single nucleotides play a role in cellular energy storage and provision, cellular signaling, as a source of phosphate groups used to modulate the activity of proteins and other signaling molecules, and as enzymatic cofactors that often carry out redox reactions. Cyclic nucleotides in signaling are formed by attaching a phosphate group twice to the same sugar molecule, and bridging the 5' and 3' hydroxyl groups of the sugar. Some signaling nucleotides have different configurations of phosphate groups because they have multiple phosphate groups attached to different sites on the sugar. Nucleotide cofactors contain a wider range of chemical groups that are bonded to sugars via glycosidic bonds, including nicotinamide and flavin; in the case of flavin, the ribose sugar is more linear than the ring shape seen in other nucleotides. cAMP, a cyclic nucleotide that acts as a signaling molecule with a single phosphate attached to the 5- and 3- positions. pppGpp, a signaling molecule nucleotide with 5'- and 3'- phosphates. NADP, a dinucleotide as an enzymatic cofactor. FAD, an enzymatic cofactor dinucleotide with one of the ribose sugars adopts a linear configuration instead of a ring. Nucleotides can be synthesized both in vitro and in vivo. In vitro, protecting groups can be used in the production of nucleotides in the laboratory. The purified nucleosides are then shielded to form phosphoramidites, which are either used to form analogs not found on earth or used to synthesize oligonucleotides.

In vivo, nucleotides can be synthesized de novo or recycled via salvage reaction pathways. Components used in de novo synthesis of nucleotides are derived from biosynthetic precursors from carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism, and from ammonia and carbon dioxide. The liver is an important organ that performs de novo synthesis of all nucleotides. The de novo synthesis of pyrimidine bases and purines occurs in two different ways. Pyrimidine is synthesized first from aspartate and carbamoyl phosphate in the cytoplasm, forming the common ring precursor structure of orotic acid. The phosphorylated ribosyl group is then joined to the orotic acid structure, via covalent bonds. Purines are synthesized first from a sugar template where ring synthesis is carried out. Synthesis of pyrimidine and purine nucleotides is carried out by enzymes in the cytoplasm, not within specific organelles. The nucleotides are broken down and the useful parts can be reused in synthesis reactions to make new nucleotides. The synthesis of pyrimidine CTP and UTP takes place in the cytoplasm and begins with the formation of carbamoyl phosphate from glutamine and carbon dioxide. Next, the enzyme aspartate carbamoyl phosphate transferase catalyzes the condensation reaction between aspartate and carbamoyl phosphate to form aspartic carbamoyl acid, which is then cyclized to 4,5-acid dihydrotic with the help of the enzyme dihydroorotase. 4,5-dihydrotic acid is converted to orotate by the enzyme dihydroorotate oxidase. This reaction is: (S)-Dihydroorotate + O2 → Orotate + H2O2 Next, orotate is joined to a phosphorylated ribosyl group, via a covalent bond. The covalent bond between ribose and pyrimidine is at the 1 carbon position (C1) in the ribose group, which contains one pyrophosphate, and the 1 nitrogen position (N1), in the pyrimidine ring. Orotate phosphoribosyl transferase (PRPP transferase) catalyzes the reaction that produces orothidine monophosphate (OMP): Orotate + 5-Phospho-α-D-ribose 1-diphosphate (PRPP) → Orotidine 5'-phosphate + Pyrophosphate Orotidine 5'-monophosphate is then decarboxylated by orothidine-5'-phosphate decarboxylase to form uridine monophosphate (UMP).

PRPP transferase catalyzes ribosylation and decarboxylation reactions, forming UMP from orotic acid in the PRPP content. Another pyrimidine nucleotide is derived from UMP. Then, UMP is phosphorylated by two enzyme kinases to form uridine triphosphate (UTP) via two sequential reactions with ATP. First, the diphosphate forming UDP is produced, and then it is phosphorylated to UTP. Both reactions use ATP for energy through ATP hydrolysis: ATP + UMP → ADP + UDP UDP + ATP → UTP + ADP Next, CTP is formed by the amination reaction of UTP through the catalytic activity of the enzyme CTP synthetase. Glutamine is an NH3 donor and the reaction uses energy through ATP hydrolysis. UTP + Glutamine + ATP + H2O → CTP + ADP + Pi Cytidine monophosphate (CMP) is derived from cytidine triphosphate (CTP) through the loss of two phosphate groups. The atoms used to build purine nucleotides come from a variety of sources: The de novo synthesis for purine nucleotides is carried out with precursors inserted into the purine ring via a 10-step pathway to the intermediate IMP compound, the nucleotide from the hypoxanthine base. AMP and GMP are further synthesized from these intermediates via a two-step separate pathway. Therefore, the purine group is initially formed as part of a ribonucleotide, and not as a free base. Six enzymes are involved in the IMP synthesis reaction. Among the enzymes, three have multifunctional roles: The reaction pathway begins with the formation of PRPP. PRPS1 is an enzyme that activates R5P, which is formed by the pentose phosphate pathway, to PRPP which is made by reaction with ATP. This reaction is unusual because the pyrophosphoryl group is transferred directly from ATP to C1 from R5P, and the compound formed has an α configuration at C1.

This reaction also shares with the synthesis pathways of the amino acids Trp, His and pyrimidine nucleotides. This reaction is highly regulated because it is in the main metabolism and consumes a lot of energy. In a first reaction unique only to purine nucleotide synthesis, PPAT catalyzes the transfer of the pyrophosphate (PPi) group of PRPP via the amide nitrogen group donated by glutamine (N), glycine (N and C), aspartic acid (N), folic acid (C1) or carbon dioxide. This is the committed step in purine synthesis. This reaction occurs by inverting the configuration at ribose C1, which then forms β-5-phosphoribosylamine (5-PRA) and confirms the anomeric form of the future nucleotide. Next, glycine is supplied with energy from ATP hydrolysis and the carboxyl group makes the amine bond with NH2 from before. The one-carbon unit of the folic acid coenzyme N10-formyl-THF is then added to the amine group of the substituted glycine, followed by closure of the imidazole ring. Then, the second NH2 group is transferred from the glutamine to the first carbon of the glycine group. The second one-carbon carboxylation unit of the glycine group is added together. This new carbon group is then modified by adding a third NH2 group, this time transferred from the aspartate residue. Finally, a second one-carbon unit of formyl THF is added to the nitrogen group and the ring is covalently closed to form the common purine precursor inosine monophosphate (IMP) group. Inosine monophosphate is converted to adenosine monophosphate in two steps. First, hydrolysis of GTP provides the energy for adding aspartate to IMP by the enzyme adenylosuccinate synthase, replacing the carbonyl oxygen with nitrogen and forming the intermediate adenylosuccinate. Then, fumarate is cleaved to form adenosine monophosphate. This step is catalyzed by the enzyme adenylosuccinate lyase. Inosine monophosphate is converted to guanosine monophosphate through the oxidation reaction of IMP to form xantilate, followed by the insertion of an amine group at C2.

The Chinese calendar is still used today to observe various traditional Chinese festival days and to select the most auspicious day for a marriage or opening a business. The Chinese calendar is also known by other names such as "Agricultural Calendar" (nónglì 农历/農曆), "Yin Calendar 阴历/陰曆" (as it relates to the lunar aspect), "Old Calendar" (jìulì 旧历/舊曆) after "New Calendar" ( xīnlì 新历/新曆) namely the Gregorian Calendar, adopted as the official calendar, and the "Xià Calendar 夏历/夏曆" which is substantially different from the current calendar. The Chinese calendar began to be developed in the 3rd millennium BC, said to have been invented by the first legendary ruler, Huáng Dì, who reigned between 2698 BC-2599 BC, and further developed by the 4th legendary ruler, Emperor Yáo. The 60 year cycle (gānzhī or liùshí jiǎzǐ) came into use in the 2nd millennium BC. A more complete calendar was established in 841 BC during the Zhōu dynasty adding the introduction of a double moon and the first month of each year starting close to the winter solstice. The Sìfēn calendar (4 quarters), which came into use around 484 BC, was the first Chinese calendar to use more accurate calculations, using the solar calendar of 365.25 days, with a cycle of 19 years (235 months), known in Western science as the Circular. Metonic. The winter solstice is the first month and the double moon is inserted following the 12th month. In 256 BC, this calendar began to be used by the Qin state, then implemented throughout China after the Qin took over the whole of China and became the Qin dynasty.

This calendar remained in use throughout the first half of the Western Han Dynasty. Emperor Wǔ of the Western Han Dynasty introduced new calendar reforms. The Tàichū (Great Beginning) calendar of 104 BC had the year with the winter solstice in the 12th month and determined the number of days for the lunar calendar (a month of 29 or 30 days) and not according to the principles of solar terminology (which as a whole same as the sign of the zodiac), because the sun's motion is used to calculate the Jiéqì (signs of the seasons). Meanwhile, during the Jin and Tang Dynasties, the Dàyǎn and Huángjí Calendars were also developed, although they were never used. With the introduction of Western astronomy to China through missions spreading Christianity, the motions of the moon and sun began to be calculated in 1645 in the Qīng Dynasty's Shíxiàn Calendar, created by Missionary Adam Schall. The Chinese calendar has rules that are slightly different from the general calendar, such as: lunar reckoning is the moon's journey (revolution) around or orbiting the earth. This means that the first day of each month begins at midnight on the astronomical new moon day. (Note, the "day" in the Chinese Calendar starts at 23:00 and not at 00:00 midnight). There are 12 months in a year, but every 2 or 3 years there is a double moon (rùnyuè, 19 years 7 times). One alternate jiéqì (season) of the Chinese solar year is equivalent to one solar entry into the tropical zodiac sign. The sun always passes the winter solstice (enters Capricorn) during month 11. The main use in everyday activities is determining the phases of the moon, which is important to farmers and is possible because each day of the calendar corresponds to a specific phase of the month.

Because of this property, the topology is also called rubber geometry. It emerged through the development of concepts from geometry and set theory, such as space, dimension, shape, and transformation. The ideas now classified under topology had been stated since 1736, and in the late 19th century a distinctly separate science was developed. This science was called in Latin as site geometry ("geometry of places") or site analysis (Greek-Latin for "study of places"), and it later acquired the modern name of topology. In the middle of the 20th century, topology has become one of the main branches of mathematics. The word topology is used both for a branch of mathematics and for the family of sets with some properties used to define a topological space, the basic object of topology. Some of the important ones are homeomorphisms which can be defined as a continuous function with an inverse also. For example, the function y = 3x is a homeomorphism from the real number line to itself. Topology covers many subfields. The most basic and traditional sections of topology are: Some of the most active fields, such as low-dimensional topology and graph theory, don't fit neatly into this division. The motivating insight behind topology is that some geometric problems depend not on the exact shape of the objects involved, but rather on the way they are put together. For example, a square and a circle have many properties in common: they are both one-dimensional objects (from a topological point of view) and they both separate the plane into two parts, an inner and an outer part.

In one of the first papers on topology, Leonhard Euler showed that it was impossible to find a route through the city of Königsberg (now Kaliningrad) that would cross its seven bridges exactly once. These results do not depend on the length of the bridges or their distance from each other, but only on the property of connectivity: which bridge connects to which island or riverbank. The Seven Königsberg Bridges Problem led to the branch of mathematics known as graph theory. Similarly, the hairy ball theorem of topology algebra says that "one cannot brush hair flat on a hairy ball without licking the hair." This fact immediately convinces most people, even though they may not recognize the statement of the more formal theorem, that there is no continuous non-disappearing tangent vector field on a sphere. As with the Königsberg Bridge, the result is independent of the shape of the ball; this applies to any type of fine lump, as long as there are no voids. In order to deal with this problem that does not depend on the exact shape of the object, we need to be clear about what properties this problem does depend on. From this need comes the notion of homeospheric. The impossibility of crossing each bridge only once holds for any bridge arrangement that is homeomorphic to that of Königsberg, and the hairy ball theorem holds for any space that is homeomorphic to a sphere. Intuitively, two spaces are homeomorphic if one can deform into the other without cutting or gluing. The traditional joke is that topologists cannot tell a coffee cup from a donut, because a sufficiently pliable donut can be reshaped into a coffee cup by making a dimple and gradually enlarging it, shrinking the hole into the handle.

Topology, as a well-defined mathematical discipline, dates back to the early twentieth century, but some isolated results can be traced back several centuries. Among them are some of the questions in geometry investigated by Leonhard Euler. The 1736 paper on the Seven Bridges of Königsberg is considered one of the first practical applications of topology. On November 14, 1750, Euler wrote to a friend that he had realized the importance of the edges of a polyhedron. This leads to the polyhedron formula, V − E + F = 2 (where V, E, and F denote the number of vertices, edges, and faces of the polyhedron, respectively). Some authorities consider this analysis to be the first theorem, which heralded the birth of topology. Further contributions were made by Augustin-Louis Cauchy, Ludwig Schläfli, Johann Benedict Listing, Bernhard Riemann and Enrico Betti. Listing introduced the term "Topologie" in Vorstudien zur Topologie, written in his native German, in 1847, after using the word for ten years in correspondence before its first appearance in prin. The English form "topology" was used in 1883 in Listing's obituary in the journal Nature to distinguish "qualitative geometry from ordinary geometry in which it is quantitative geometry. Their work was corrected, consolidated, and greatly expanded by Henri Poincaré. In 1895, he published his groundbreaking paper on Site Analysis, which introduced the concepts now known as homotopy and homology, which are now considered part of algebraic topology.Combining the work on function spaces by Georg Cantor, Vito Volterra, Cesare Arzelà, Jacques Hadamard, Giulio Ascoli and others, Maurice Fréchet introduced spaces A metric space is now considered a special case of a general topological space, with any given topological space potentially giving rise to many different metric spaces.

In 1914, Felix Hausdorff coined the term "topological space" and provided a definition for what is now called a Hausdorff space. Today, topological spaces are a slight generalization of Hausdorff spaces, given in 1922 by Kazimierz Kuratowski. Modern topology relies heavily on the ideas of set theory, developed by Georg Cantor in the late 19th century. In addition to establishing the basic ideas of set theory, Cantor considered sets of points in Euclidean space as part of his study of Fourier series. For further developments, see point-set topology and algebraic topology. Topology can be defined as: Topology is concerned with the study of the topological properties of shapes, i.e. the properties that do not change in a one-to-one bicontinuous transformation (called homeomorphism). Two shapes that can be deformed from one into the other are called homeomorphic, and are considered to be the same from a topological view. For example, a solid cube and a solid sphere are homeomorphic. However, it is not possible to deform a sphere into a circle by a one-to-one bicontinuous transformation. Dimensions are a topological property. In a sense, a topological property is a deeper form property. The term topology is also used for a very basic mathematical idea in a branch of mathematics called topology. In simple terms, a topology provides a description of how the members in a set are related to each other spatially (eg the proximity between 2 points). The same set can also be given a different topology. For example, the real number line, the complex plane, and the Cantor set can be considered as the same set but with different topologies (all three have the same cardinality). Formally, let X be a set and τ is a family of subsets of X. Then τ is called a topology with respect to X if: If τ is a topology with respect to X then the pair (X, τ) is called a topological space.

An member of τ is called an open set in X. A subset A of X is said to be closed if its complement is in τ (its complement is open, X ∖ A ϵ τ). In the field of topology, a homeomorphism or topological isomorphism (from the Greek, homeos = identical and morphe = form) is a special isomorphism between topological spaces that satisfy topological properties. Two spaces with homeomorphism between them are called homeomorphic. From a topology review they are the same. If given two topological spaces X and Y and the homeomorphism f between them, the topological property for a subset A of X holds if and only if it holds for f(A). The most commonly used instruments are metallophones including gangsa, gender, bonang, gong, saron, slenthem played by wiyaga using a hammer (beater) and membranophones in the form of kendhang which are played by hand. Also, idiophones in the form of kempak and other metallophones are some of the commonly used gamelan instruments. Other instruments include the xylophone in the form of xylophone, the aerophone in the form of a flute, the chordophone in the form of a fiddle, and vocal groups called sinden. A set of gamelan is grouped into two, namely gangsa pekarmatan and gangsa ageng. Gangsapakrmatan is played to accompany hajad dalem (traditional ceremony for the palace), jumenengan (ceremony for coronation of a king or queen), tingalan dalem (commemoration of the ascension to the throne of a king or queen), garebeg (ceremony of important events), sekaten (ceremony for commemorating the birthday of the Prophet Muhammad). Gangsa ageng is played as an accompaniment to cultural arts performances, generally used to accompany beksan (dance), wayang (performing arts), uyon-uyon (traditional ceremonies/celebrations), and others. Currently, gamelan is widely used on the islands of Java, Madura, Bali and Lombok. While the gamelan with wide distribution and the most preservation is Gamelan Reyog from Ponorogo. The word gamelan comes from the Javanese word gamêl which means 'to hit' or 'to beat', which can refer to the type of hammer used to strike an instrument, followed by the suffix an which makes it a noun. The term karawitan refers to classical gamelan music and performance practices, and comes from the word rawit, which means 'complicated' or 'well done'.

This word comes from a Javanese word which has Sanskrit roots, 'rawit', which refers to the sense of refinement and elegance that is idealized in Javanese music. Another word from this root, pangrawit, means someone with such a meaning, and is used as a tribute when discussing respected gamelan musicians. The refined Javanese language (krama) for 'gamelan' is gangsa, formed from the words tiga and sedasa (three and ten) referring to the gamelan-making elements of a combination of three parts copper and ten parts tin. This combination produces bronze, which is considered the best raw material for making gamelan. The existence of the gamelan predates the Hindu-Buddhist cultural transition process that dominated the archipelago, in its early records and thus represents a native Indonesian art form. In Javanese mythology, the gamelan which was originally named Gamelan Lokananta, an intangible gamelan that sounds in the awang awang (air space) was created by Batara Guru in 167 Saka (or 230 AD), the king of the gods who ruled as the king of the entire universe from a heaven. palace at Wukir Mahendra Giri in Medang Kamulan (now Mount Lawu). Batara Guru ordered Batara Indrasurapati to create gamelan in the form of an intangible imitation of lokananta gamelan, namely gong, kethuk, kenong, gong, fiddle, as a signal to summon the gods. For more complex messages, he then created two other gongs, thus forming a complete gamelan set. The earliest images of a set of gamelan musical instruments (musical ensembles) are found on the wall reliefs of the Borobudur temple built in the 8th century by the Architect of the Borobudur Temple, namely Gunadharma during the Syailendra dynasty of the Ancient Mataram kingdom in Magelang Regency, Central Java. The reliefs display a number of musical instruments including flutes, bells, kendhangs of various sizes, harps, stringed and plucked string instruments, found in the reliefs.

However, the reliefs about the set of musical instruments are said to be the origin of gamelan. The Bantarangin kingdom in Wengker (now Ponorogo, East Java) made gamelan which was a condition for the competition from the 11th century Daha kingdom. The contents of the contest were to make musical instruments and artistic entertainment that had never existed in the world. Even though gamelan has existed before, the gamelan made by wengker produces music that is different from gamelan in general, which became known as Gamelan Reog. Gamelan instruments were introduced in the form of a complete set of musical instruments and developed during the Majapahit Kingdom, and spread to various regions such as Bali, Sunda and Lombok. According to inscriptions and manuscripts dating from the Majapahit period, the kingdom even had an arts hall in charge of supervising the performing arts, including gamelan. The arts hall supervises the construction of musical instruments, as well as schedules performances. In Bali, there are several selonding gamelan that have existed since the 9th century when Sri Kesari Warmadewa reigned. Several words referring to gamelan selonding are found in several ancient Balinese inscriptions and manuscripts. Today, gamelan selonding is kept and well preserved in ancient temples in Bali. It is considered sacred and is used for religious ceremonies, especially when large ceremonies are held. Gamelan Selonding is part of daily life and culture for some indigenous peoples in ancient villages such as Bungaya, Bugbug, Seraya, Tenganan Pegringsingan, Timbrah, Asak, Ngis, Bebandem, Besakih, and Selat in Karangasem Regency. In the process of penetrating Islam, Sunan Bonang composed gamelan, which at that time was very thick with Hindu aesthetics, also gave a new nuance. His compositions at that time gave a transcendental or wirid feel that encouraged a love of life, and added the bonang instrument to a gamelan set.

In Wengker or Ponorogo culture, in the 15th century the Reog Gamelan was used not only to accompany the Reog Ponorogo art, but also to be used in self-defense training until war, Ki Ageng Surya Alam's troops from the village of Kutu played the reog gamelan before the war took place against Majapahit, which was in a coalition with Demak when attacking Wengker, as a result Wengker always gets his victory before Ki Ageng Surya Alam's heirloom falls into the hands of the enemy. Editor page logged out learn more Metamorphism (Greek: meta: change; morph: form) is the process by which changes in mineralogy or texture occur in rocks due to increased pressure or temperature. Metamorphism occurs when the original rock (protolith) is exposed to a physical or chemical environment that is significantly different from the environment in which it was formed, so that the rock changes gradually until a state of equilibrium with the new environment is reached. The main factors that influence the process of metamorphism are as follows: The main source of heat that affects the process of metamorphism is magma intrusion and geothermal gradients. There are two kinds of pressure that affect it, namely lithostatic pressure and differential stress. Fluids accelerate the process of metamorphism by increasing chemical reactions, because fluids generally contain dissolved ions. This metamorphism occurs in areas of orogenic belts or convergent plates, which contain deformation processes that cause recrystallization. In general, this metamorphism produces rocks with mineral grains that are oriented and form belts that are hundreds to thousands of kilometers long. Orogenic metamorphism in which extensive deformation occurs simultaneously, resulting from contraction stress during lithospheric plate convergence in subduction zones and recrystallization due to increasingly thickened crust. The increase in temperature in the orogenic occurs due to a geothermal gradient that adapts to a crust that gradually thickens under pressure. In general the temperature is high enough at the bottom of the crust to cause partial melting. Because this process occurs, magma will rise to the shallow crust and precipitate as a granitoid. Orogenic usually evolve over hundreds of millions of years through several episodes of deformation and recrystallization. Contact metamorphism occurs in rocks that are heated in the vicinity of intrusive or extrusive igneous rock mass contacts.

Editor page out log learn more The goldfish (Carassius auratus auratus) is a freshwater fish in the family Cyprinidae and the order Cypriniformes. This fish is one of the first fish successfully domesticated, reared and cultivated by humans. Now ornamental goldfish or sometimes referred to briefly as goldfish, is one of the most popular aquarium ornamental fish. The Carassius auratus auratus variety which has been domesticated and displays a mutation of the body with double tail fins and a rounded compressed shape is called the goldfish. As a member of the carp family (which also includes koi and crucian carp), the ornamental carp is a domesticated version of the cultivation of the less colorful Carassius auratus fish whose natural habitat is in East Asia. This fish was first domesticated in China over a thousand years ago, and since then several different breeds have been developed. There is an incredible variety of goldfish in terms of size, body shape, fin arrangement and color (various color combinations include white, yellow, orange, red, brown and black). In Indonesia the term "goldfish" also refers to common carp or "carp fish" (Cyprinus carpio), which are relatives of fish that can be consumed as food. Carp rearing began in Ancient China thousands of years ago. Several species of carp (commonly known as "Asian carp") are being domesticated and reared as a food source through aquaculture. Naturally in nature, these fish are gray or silver in color, but some types have a tendency to experience color mutations by producing red, orange or yellow. This phenomenon was first recorded during the Jin Dynasty (265–420).

During the Tang dynasty (618–907), the custom and trend of keeping carp as ornamental fish in ponds and water gardens became popular. A genetic mutation in human domesticated goldfish produces a golden color (yellowish orange to be precise), whereas in nature this fish usually only displays a gray-silver color. This happens because in nature, the mutation that produces this yellow-orange color rarely occurs, because fish with this bright color are easy for predators to hunt; it is fish with natural camouflage that survive. The Chinese began breeding and cultivating varieties of goldfish rather than silvery ones, raising them in ponds rather than letting them in rivers or lakes. On special occasions at which they were expecting guests the goldfish would be transferred from the pond to a smaller container for display to their guests. By the Song dynasty (960–1279), efforts to domesticate carp had settled. In 1162, a Song dynasty queen ordered the construction of ponds to collect the red and yellow varieties of goldfish. At that time the general public outside the royal family was forbidden to raise goldfish of the golden (yellow) color variety, because yellow was the color of the Chinese empire. Perhaps because of this, there are now more orange and red goldfish than yellow goldfish, even though yellow goldfish are genetically easier to breed. During the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644), ornamental carp began to be kept indoors, this led to a selection of genetic mutations which caused some varieties of this fish to be unable to survive in outdoor ponds. The appearance of other colors (besides red and gold) is first recorded in 1276.

The first appearance of the beautiful double-tailed fish was first recorded during the Ming Dynasty. In 1603, ornamental carp were introduced to Japan, where the Ryukin and Tosakin varieties were developed. In 1611, the ornamental carp was introduced to Portugal and from there it spread to other parts of Europe. In the 1620s, goldfish were favored and regarded as prestigious in Europe because of their golden metallic yellow scales which symbolized good luck. At that time it was tradition for a husband to give a goldfish as a gift on his first wedding anniversary, as a symbol of prosperity in the years to come together. This tradition later disappeared due to ornamental goldfish becoming cheaper and easier to obtain, thus losing its status and prestige. Ornamental goldfish were introduced to North America around 1850 and soon became popular in the United States. In China, the carp was bred from the Prussian carp (Carassius auratus gibelio), and is genetically the closest living relative of the carp in the wild. Previously there was an opinion that the Crucian carp (Carassius carassius) as a wild version of the goldfish. However, the two differ in several respects, for example the muzzle of C. auratus is more pointed, while the snout of C. carassius is more rounded. C. gibelio is often gray-green in color, while the Crucian carp is always a golden bronze color. If the Crucian carp chicks have black spots on the base of the tail which will disappear with age, in C. auratus these tail spots never appear. C. auratus has less than 31 scales along the lateral line of the body, while the Crucian carp has 33 or more scales. In nature, C. auratus gibelio is olive green.

Introducing goldfish to nature can create problems for native species. Goldfish can interbreed with several species of carps. Within three spawning generations, generally the majority of hybrid offspring switch back to olive green in color. The mutations that gave rise to other types of domestic carp also occur in other cyprinide species, such as common carp and tench. Koi may also interbreed with goldfish to produce hybrid fish that are sterile (sterile). There are many varieties of domestic goldfish. Ornamental fish are unlikely to survive in the wild due to their bright colors and long fins; however, more resistant varieties such as Shubunkin and Komet survived long enough to mate with their relatives. Common and Comet goldfish varieties can survive, even thrive in any climate and pond environment. As of April 2008, the largest goldfish in the world was believed by the BBC to measure 19 inches (48 cm), and be living in the Netherlands. At the time, a goldfish named "Goldie", kept as a pet in a tank in Folkestone, England, was measured as 15 inches (38cm) and over 2 pounds (0.91kg), and named as the second largest in the world behind goldfish from the Netherlands. The chairman of the Federation of British Aquatic Societies (FBAS) stated of Goldie's size "I think there may be some bigger fish that are not considered record holders, maybe in lakes or ornamental ponds". In July 2010, a goldfish measuring 16 inches (41 cm) and 5 pounds (2.3 kg) was caught in a pond in Poole, England, thought to have been abandoned there after outgrowing a tank.

In the wild, goldfish prey on crustaceans, insects and various types of aquatic plants. Like most fish, they are opportunistic predators who eat constantly. They cannot consciously stop eating on purpose. Overfeeding can harm the health of these fish, such as blocking their intestines. This usually occurs in ornamental goldfish that have a convoluted digestive tract. If food is abundant, they will eat it all and produce quite a lot of waste. This is generally due to the imperfection of goldfish in digesting protein. Overfeeding can be diagnosed by examining the length of the droppings coming out of the fish's cloaca. Special goldfish diets contain less protein and more carbohydrates than general fish feeds. This type of food is sold in the form of floating chips and sinking pellets. Carp enthusiasts can add a variety of foods in the form of green peas that have been peeled off, vegetables scalded with hot water, or mosquito larvae. Goldfish puppies can be given small shrimp food. Goldfish eyesight is the most studied field in the study of fish vision. Goldfish even have the ability to see color better than humans. Goldfish have four kinds of light-receiving cones, each of which is sensitive to a different color: red, green, blue, and ultraviolet. The ability to distinguish the four primary colors makes the goldfish a tetrachromatic animal. Selective breeding over the centuries has produced several colors. Several colored varieties are so different from the golden color of the original ancestral fish. There are also differences in body shape, fins, and eye configuration. Some extreme varieties can only survive if keptinan aquarium, because they are more fragile than varieties thatarestill close to their ancestors from wild fish.

However, somevarieties are more resilient, such as the Shubunkin variety. Now, there are about 300 races (varieties) of ornamental carp in China. Most existing carp races are now bred and come from China, while some varieties are developed in Japan. In Indonesia, ornamental goldfish varieties with double tails and round bodies are called goldfish or goldfish. Some varieties include: Goldfish can only grow when they reach sexual maturity with enough water and proper nutrition. Most ornamental goldfish breed in fish farming spawning, particularly in spawning ponds. Breeding usually occurs after significant temperature changes, particularly in spring. Male goldfish will chase a female that is in heat and is carrying a lot of eggs, and pressures the female to release her eggs by grazing and bumping them. When they mate they release eggs and sperm together by swimming side by side together so that the eggs are fertilized. Goldfish, like most of their siprinide relatives, are spawners. The eggs have a layer that is attached, sticky to dense aquatic plants, for example Cabomba or Elodea or a kind of broom, straw or palm fiber as a spawning ground. The eggs will hatch in 48 to 72 hours. Within a few weeks, the embryo begins to reach its final form. It takes a year to reach the full adult growth rate. When they are juveniles, the fry are shaped and colored like their wild ancestors; brown metallic color. In the first few weeks of life, the fry grow rapidly — an adaptation brought about by the high risk of being eaten by the adults (or other fish and insects) in their environment. Several types of cultivated goldfish with extreme bodies can no longer reproduce naturally due to their changing body shape.

This musical instrument is shaped like a drum but is flat and round in shape, made of a short wooden tube, the end is rather wide, and on one side it is covered or covered with leather. Since 2011, several types of Kompang arts have been recorded and recognized by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Research and Technology as Indonesia's unique Intangible Cultural Heritage. And in 2021, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization or what is often known as UNESCO has designated Gamelan (a set of musical instruments that already includes Kompang) as the original Intangible Cultural Heritage originating from Indonesia. Etymologically, the word 'kompang' is absorbed from the Javanese term: ꦏꦺꦴꦩ꧀ꦥ꧀ꦭꦁ, translit. komplang which means "hollow", this refers to the shape of the kompang musical instrument itself which has a hollow or hollow part (on the back that is not covered with skin) so that it can produce loud sounds when hit. The history related to Kompang cannot be separated from the history of the gamelan itself, which is a set of musical instruments created on the island of Java centuries ago. This Kompang was originally created specifically by the Ponorogo people who at that time still adhered to animism and Kejawen beliefs, until finally the teachings of Hinduism and Buddhism entered. Gamelan (including kompang as a part of it) continued to be sustainable until the era of Islamic teachings entered Ponorogo, the people of Ponorogo who like gamelan art assimilated gamelan as a means of enlivening Muslim religiosity activities which are commonly recognized by Javanese people as prayer.

It is said that at first, the shape of the kompang itself was very large at first, it's just that it was slimmer which made it easier to hold with one side of animal skin on the kompang frame. Over time, Kompang now has various forms; from small to large. Although currently the medium size of the kompang is dominated, in Ponorogo very large sizes are still available and played. exists and is played. Gamelan instruments were introduced in the form of a complete set of musical instruments and developed during the Majapahit empire, and spread to various regions such as Bali, Sunda and Lombok. According to inscriptions and manuscripts dating from the Majapahit period, the Majapahit empire even had an arts hall in charge of supervising the performing arts, including gamelan (which includes kompang). The arts center supervises the construction of musical instruments, as well as schedules performances. In Ponorogo itself, there is the flying Ponoragan art which still uses Kompang percussion from small to large sizes. Apart from Kompang, the flying art is also accompanied by Reog musical instruments, such as the Reog drum and the Reog gamelan. Apart from that, Kompang in Ponorogo is still used in religious activities for the Javanese Muslim community such as ba'an, weddings, celebrations of Islamic holidays, to official ceremonies. The number of traditional pesantren in Ponorogo which are well-known, made the alumni of the Islamic boarding school in Ponorogo bring the Kompang musical instrument to various regions on the island of Java which was then developed in each area by the alumni of the santri. Kompang Ponorogo also spread to the Malay area because of the marriage of the son of the Tegalsari Pesantren kyai married to the daughter of the Sultan of Selangor. The Delegation of the Tegalsari Islamic Boarding School brought Kompang offerings when the wedding took place, until Kompang Ponorogo was also popular with the Malay community in Selangor.
