Halaman penyunting yang telah keluar log pelajari lebih lanjut Gulag (/ˈɡuːl ɑːɡ/; bahasa Rusia: ГУЛАГ; IPA: ɡʊˈlak] ( simak)) adalah singkatan untuk Главное управление исправительно-трудовых лагерей и колоний, "Glavnoye upravleniye ispravitelno-trudovykh lagerey i kolonii ", or the "Directorate (or Administration) Chief for Camps and Penal Labor Colonies" of the NKVD. Anne Applebaum, in her book Gulag: A History, explains: Literally, the word GULAG is an abbreviation, meaning Glavnoe Upravlenie Lagerei, or Main Camp Administration. Over time, the word "Gulag" came to mean not only the administration of the concentration camps but also the Soviet system of forced labor itself, in all its forms and variations: labor camps, penal camps, criminal and political camps, women's camps. , children's camp, transit camp. More broadly, "Gulag" came to be used to refer to the Soviet system of oppression itself, a series of procedures prisoners once called "a meat grinder": arrest, interrogation, transportation in unheated animal carriages, forced labor, destruction of families , the years spent in exile, death at an early age needlessly occurred. Archived 2007-10-13 at the Wayback Machine. Some authors refer to all the prisoners and camps throughout Soviet history (1917–1991) as the Gulag. In modern usage, the word is often not necessarily associated with the Soviet Union. For example, in expressions like "North Korean Gulag". Buru Island is also often referred to as "Indonesian Gulag". Note that the original Russian abbreviation (ГУЛАГ, never in the plural), describes not just one camp, but an entire government department responsible for the entire camp system. This word is almost never used in Russian - neither officially nor in everyday usage - because the term commonly used for the system of labor camps or for their respective camps, is usually referred to in Russian simply as "camp". ("лагеря") or "zona" ("зона", always in the singular).

The term "punishment forced labor" was proposed for official use by a meeting of the politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union on July 27, 1929, instead of the term concentration camp, which was in common use until then. A colloquial term for a prisoner in the Soviet Gulag was "zeka", "zek". In Russian, the word for "prisoner", "prisoner" is "заключённый", zakliuchyonnyi, usually shortened to 'з/к' in documents, pronounced as 'зэка' (zeh-KA), and gradually changed to 'зэк' and 'зек'. This word is still used in everyday speech, without necessarily referring to forced labor camps. 'з/к' was originally an abbreviation of "заключённый каналостроитель", "zakliuchyonnyi canalostroitel'" (captive canal builders), which came from members of the slave laborers of the Volga-Donau Canal. Later, the term came to mean "zakliuchyonnyi". Besides the most common category of camps practicing hard forced labor and prisons of various kinds, there are other forms. Since 1918 detention facilities of a type of detention camp were built. As an improved expansion of earlier forced labor camps (katorga), which operated in Siberia as part of the penal system in the Russian Empire. The two main types are "Vechecka special purpose camps" ("особые лагеря ВЧК") and forced labor camps (лагеря принудительных работ). They were built for various categories of people considered dangerous to the state, namely: for common criminals, prisoners of the Russian Civil War, officials accused of corruption, sabotage and embezzlement, various political enemies and dissidents, as well as former aristocrats, businessmen and landowners broad. The legal basis and guidelines for creating a system of "penalty labor camps" (Russian: "исправительно-трудовые лагеря", "Ispravitel'no-trudovye lagerya"), the backbone of what is usually called the "Gulag," is a decree secret from the Sovnarkom of 11 July 1929 concerning the use of punitive force (see Reference wikisource), which imitates a parallel additional section in the minutes of a meeting of the Politburo on 27 June 1929.

As an agency based entirely on the Soviet Union and a parent administration with the OGPU, the Soviet Secret Police, the GULAG was formally established on 25 April 1930 as "ULAG" by order of the OGPU No. 130/63 according to Sovnarkom order No. 22 p. 248 of April 7, 1930, and was renamed GULAG in November. In the early 1930's, drastic measures to tighten the Soviet penal policy led to a significant increase in the number of inmates in the internment camps. During the Great Terror (1937-1938), mostly arbitrary mass detentions led to another large increase in the number of prisoners. In recent years, hundreds of thousands of people were arrested and sentenced to long prison terms under one of the various paragraphs of the famous Article 58 of the Criminal Code of the Republics of the Soviet Union, which defines punishment for various forms of "counter-revolutionary activity." The hypothesis that economic considerations are responsible for causing arrests, for example during the time of Stalinism, has been refuted on the basis of ex-Soviet archives that have been opened since the 1990s. Although some archival sources also tend to support the economic hypothesis. However, the development of the camp system followed economic lines. (For the "corrective work colonies" this was lax, for special settlements almost nonexistent.) The growth of the camp system coincided with the culmination of the Soviet industrialization campaign. Because of this, most of the camps were set up to accommodate the large number of prisoners placed on specific economic assignments. This includes natural resources and the colonization of remote areas, as well as the realization of massive infrastructure facilities and industrial development projects. In 1931-1932, the Gulag had an estimated 200,000 prisoners in camps. In 1935 — about 800,000 in camps and 300,000 in colonies (annual average). Then in 1939 about 1.3 million in camps and 350,000 in colonies.

(Cf., e.g., Istorija stalinskogo Gulaga: konec 1920-kh - pervaia polovina 1950-kh godov; sobranie studitov v 7 tomach, ed. by V. p. Kozlov et al., Moskva: ROSSPEN 2004, vol. 4: Naselenie GULAGa) During World War II, the population of the Gulag declined sharply, due to the mass release of hundreds of thousands of prisoners who were recruited and sent directly to the frontier (often in penal battalions sent to the most dangerous areas of fighting and suffered high death rates). tall). The death rate peaked in 1942–1943. After World War II the number of prisoners in prison camps and colonies again increased sharply, reaching about 2.5 million in the early 1950s (about 1.7 million of these were in camps). While some of these were deserters and prisoners of war, there were also 339,000 Soviet citizens repatriated from refugee camps in Germany (including 233,000 former military personnel) who were accused of betrayal and aid to the enemy. Tens of thousands of them were eventually found guilty and transferred to detention camps. Large numbers of civilians from Russian territories occupied by other countries and areas annexed by the Soviet Union after the war were also sent there. It was not uncommon for survivors of the Nazi camps to be sent directly to Soviet labor camps. However, the main reason for the increase in the number of prisoners in the post-war period was the tightening of laws on property infringement in the summer of 1947 (at this time there was a famine in several regions of the USSR, which resulted in the death of 1 million people), which resulted in hundreds of thousands of people being sentenced to prison terms. long prison terms, not infrequently for petty theft or embezzlement. During the years after WWII, a small number of prisoners were Baltics and Ukrainians from the countries that had just joined the Soviet Union, as well as Finns, Poles, Romanians and others.

Instead, prisoners of war were held in separate camp systems, which were maintained by main administrations separate from the NKVD/MVD. The state continued to maintain this system of camps for a while after Stalin's death in March 1953. The amnesty program that was introduced was limited to those who had been detained for a maximum of 5 years, so that mostly only those who committed ordinary crimes were released. The release of political prisoners began in 1954 and became widespread, and was accompanied by mass rehabilitation, after Nikita Khrushchev rejected Stalinism in his Secret Speech at the 20th Congress of the CPI in February, 1956. According to later estimates based on archival documents, a total of about 18-20 million people who were prisoners in those camps and colonies during the period of Stalinism at any given point. By the late 1950s, practically all "corrective labor camps" had been disbanded. But the colonies still exist. The GULAG was formally dissolved by order of the MVD on January 25, 1960. The total number of documented deaths in the system of corrective labor camps and colonies from 1930 to 1956 totaled up to 1,606,748, including political and ordinary prisoners. This figure does not include the more than 800,000 executions of "counter-revolutionaries" during the "Great Terror" period, as they were generally carried out outside the camp system and were counted separately. From 1932 to 1940, at least 390,000 peasants died in working settlements. One can also conclude that many of those who survive suffer permanent physical and psychological damage. On the number of prisoners and their death rates, see Getty, Rittersporn and Zemskov's paper in American Historical Review, Vol 98, No 4 Deaths in certain camps are more fully documented than in others.

Extreme production quotas, malnutrition, harsh conditions, inadequate housing, health and healthcare, as well as brutal treatment by camp officials and guards and fellow prisoners are the main reasons for the high death rate, which in extreme cases can reach 80%. Logging and mining are the most common and one of the most strenuous activities. At a Gulag mine, one person's production (norm) quota might be as high as 13,000 kg of iron ore per day, with the quota being increased by tufta ("pretend work"), so that more work will be reported than what is actually done, and achieved through bribes, courtship, sexual favors or fraud. Failure to meet the quota will result in the loss of important rations (reduced to 300 grams of "black rye bread", 5 grams of flour, 25 grams of buckwheat or macaroni, 27 grams of meat and 170 grams of potatoes). Lower food rations mean lower productivity, and this vicious cycle usually results in fatal consequences through states of debility and devitalization, nicknamed "dokhodiaga" (доходяга), a term derived from the Russian verb "dokhodit" (reach (endurance limit)) and translates approximately as "hopeless person". However, dokhodyaga status can also occur even if a person has attained the status of an udarnik (super productive worker) and attained a higher ration (in a camp, the udarnik received one kilo of bread per day) and other privileges, such as housing conditions better. This is because the extra food obtained is not enough to compensate for the energy used in trying to reach the higher quota, which exceeds the standard norm by 50% or more.

Detainees were often forced to work in inhumane conditions. Despite the brutal climate, they hardly ever had enough clothing, food and medical care. They are also not given anything to overcome the lack of vitamins that cause them to often suffer from diseases caused by malnutrition (such as gingivitis). The nutritional value of the daily food ration is about 1,200 calories (5,000 kilojoules), mainly of low-quality bread distributed by weight. According to the World Health Organization, the minimum requirement for hard work is between 3,100–3,900 calories (13,000 to 16,300 kJ) per day. The administrators routinely stole from the camp various necessities for his personal use, and to please his superiors. As a result, prisoners are forced to work even harder to make up for their shortages. Administrators and confidants (prisoners who were given the task of serving the camp itself, such as cooks, bakers or warehouse workers), were nicknamed "pridurki" which translates as "stupid people" or "idiots", but actually are actually "people just playing around" {and not working}]) stealing drugs, clothes, and groceries. In the early days of the Gulag, the locations for the camps were chosen primarily for the convenience of isolating the prisoners. Remote monasteries in particular were often used as sites for new camps. The site on the Solovetsky Islands in the White Sea is one of the earliest and also most noteworthy, taking root soon after the Revolution in 1918. [17] The colloquial name for the islands, "Solovki", entered the vernacular as a synonym for the work camp force in general. This place was presented to the world as an example of the new Soviet way of "re-educating class enemies" and reintegrating them through work into Soviet society.

Initially the inmates, largely Russian intelligentsia, enjoyed relative freedom (within the natural confinement of the islands). Local newspapers and magazines were published and even some scientific research was carried out (e.g., a local botanical garden was maintained but unfortunately later lost completely). Eventually this place turned into a regular Gulag camp; in fact some historians maintain that it was a pilot camp of this type. See Solovki for more details. Maxim Gorky visited the camp in 1929 and published an apology for it. With a new emphasis on the Gulag as a way of concentrating cheap labor, new camps were created throughout the Soviet sphere of influence, wherever existing economic tasks required their existence (or were specifically designed to require them, such as the Belomorkanal or the Baikal Amur Main Line), including facilities in major cities — parts of the famous Moscow Metro and the new Moscow State University campus were built with forced labor. Many more projects during the rapid industrialization of the 1930s, the wartime and post-war years were carried out on the backs of prisoners, and the activities of the Gulag camps stretched across the vast Soviet industry. Most of the Gulag camps were located in very remote areas in northeastern Siberia (the best-known clusters were the Sevvostlag (Northeast Camps) along the Kolyma River and Norillag near Norilsk) and in the southeastern parts of the Soviet Union, especially in the steppes of Kazakhstan (Luglag, Steplag, Peschanlag). These were vast, uninhabited areas and had no roads (in fact, the construction of the roads themselves was assigned to prisoners from the camps who had the special task of building railroads) or any food sources. , but rich in minerals and other natural resources (eg wood).

However, these camps were generally spread across the Soviet Union, including in the European parts of Russia, Belarus, and Ukraine. There were also a number of camps located outside the Soviet Union, in Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Mongolia, all of which were under the direct control of the Gulag. Not all camps were fortified; in fact some of the camps in Siberia were marked only by outposts. Escape attempts were hindered by the violent elements, as well as the sniffer dogs stationed at each camp. While in the 1920s and 1930s native tribes often assisted escapees, many of the tribes also fell victim to fleeing thieves. Tempted by the generous bounty, they then started assisting the government in capturing the Gulag fugitives. Camp guards were also given tough incentives to guard their prisoners at any cost. If a prisoner escaped under the watch of a guard, the guard would often lose his uniform and become an inmate himself in the Gulag. Furthermore, if an escaped detainee was shot, the guards could be fined an amount that was often the equivalent of a week's or two weeks' wages. In some cases, teams of prisoners were sent to a new area with a limited supply of resources and left to set up a new camp or die. Sometimes this attempt is made several times before the next wave of colonists can withstand the elements. The area along the Indigirka River is known as the Gulag within the Gulag. In 1926, the village of Oimiakon (Оймякон) in this region recorded a low temperature of −71.2°C. The Gulag spanned nearly forty years of Soviet and Eastern European history and influenced millions of people.

The cultural impact is also very great. Many eyewitness accounts of Gulag prisoners were published before World War II. Julius Margolin's book A Travel to the Land Ze-Ka was completed in 1947, but such a book could not have been published in the Soviet Union at the time, immediately after World War II. Gustaw Herling-Grudziński wrote A World Apart, which was translated into English by Andrzej Ciolkosz and published with an introduction by Bertrand Russell in 1951. By portraying life in the Gulag in chilling personal accounts, this book provides an insightful analysis original and deep insight into the nature of the Soviet communist system. The book, which was written 10 years before Alexander Solzhenitsyn's book A Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich, made him famous internationally (except in France). Alexander Solzhenitsyn's book The Gulag Archipelago (Gulag Islands) is not the first literary work about labor camps. His earlier book on the same subject, "A Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich", about a typical day in the life of a prisoner in the GULAG, was originally published in the most prestigious Soviet monthly magazine, "Novij Mir", "New World", in November 1962, but was soon banned and withdrawn from all libraries. This is the first work to show the Gulag as an instrument of governmental oppression of its own citizens on a large scale. The Gulag exerts a major influence on contemporary Russian thought, and is an important part of modern Russian folklore. Many of the songs performed by authors and actors known as bards, particularly Vladimir Vysotsky and Alexander Galich, although neither were imprisoned in the camps in the Gulag, describe life in the Gulag and glorify the life of the "Zek".

Words and expressions originating from the labor camps became part of Russian/Soviet colloquialism in the 60s and 70s. The memoirs of Alexander Dolgun, Alexander Solzhenitsyn, Varlam Shalamov and Yevgenia Ginzburg, among others, became the epitome of resistance in Soviet society. These writings, particularly those of Solzhenitsyn, harshly criticized the Soviet people for their tolerant and apathetic attitude towards the Gulag, but at the same time testified to the courage and determination of those detained. Another cultural phenomenon in the Soviet Union associated with the Gulag was the forced migration of many artists and other cultural figures to Siberia. This gave birth to a kind of Renaissance in places like Magadan, where, for example, the quality of theatrical production was comparable to that of Moscow. Soviet state documents show that among the goals of the GULAG was the colonization of the sparsely populated interior areas. To achieve this goal, the notion of "free settlement" was introduced. When well-behaved persons have served the majority of their prison term, they can be released to live in "free settlements" (вольное поселение, "volnoye poseleniye") outside the confines of the camp. They became known as "free settlers" (вольнопоселенцы, "volnoposelentsy", not to be confused with the terms ссыльнопоселенцы, "ssyl'noposelentsy", "exile settlers"). In addition, for persons who have served the full term of detention, but are not given the freedom to choose their place of residence, it is recommended that they be placed in "free settlements" and given land in the vicinity of the place of detention. This regulation was also inherited from the katorga system. People serving periods of detention in camps or prisons are subject to restrictions on choosing a job from a wider range of options. Revealing past experience of detention is an offense that can be subject to the judicial process.

Editor page logged out learn more Eubacteria (Woese & Fox, 1977) Bacteria (scientific name: Bacteria) are a group of single-celled microorganisms classified at the domain level. Together with the Archaea domain, bacteria are classified as prokaryotes. Bacterial cells have a specific shape, such as a ball, rod or spiral, which is usually a few micrometers in size. Bacteria were one of the first forms of life to appear and currently inhabit the majority of habitats on Earth. Bacteria can live in soil, water, acidic hot springs, radioactive waste, to the Earth's crust. Bacteria also establish symbiotic relationships with plants and animals. Most of the bacteria are unknown, and only about 27 percent of the bacterial phyla have species that can be grown in the laboratory. The study of bacteria is called bacteriology, a branch of microbiology. Almost all animals depend on bacteria for their survival because only bacteria and some archaea have the genes and enzymes necessary to synthesize vitamin B12. This vitamin is obtained by animals through the food chain or produced by microorganisms that live in their digestive system. There are about 40 million bacterial cells in one gram of soil and one million bacterial cells in one milliliter of fresh water. Altogether, there are about 4–6 x 1030 bacteria and archaea on Earth, which form a biomass surpassed only by plants. Bacteria play an important role in the nutrient cycle, for example in the process of fixing nitrogen from the atmosphere and decomposing corpses. In communities of organisms around hydrothermal vents and cold vents, extremophile bacteria provide the nutrients needed to sustain life by converting dissolved compounds, such as hydrogen sulfide and methane, into energy.

In humans and most animals, bacteria are most abundant in the digestive tract. The skin is also inhabited by bacteria in large numbers. The majority of bacteria in the body are harmless because the body is protected by the immune system. In addition, many beneficial bacteria, especially as intestinal flora. However, several species of bacteria are pathogenic and cause infectious diseases, including cholera, syphilis, gonorrhea, anthrax, leprosy, and the plague. The most commonly found deadly bacterial disease is respiratory tract infection. Tuberculosis kills around two million people a year, mostly in Sub-Saharan Africa. Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections and are also used in agriculture, which has made antibiotic resistance a growing problem. In the industrial sector, bacteria play an important role in the treatment of waste and the decomposition of oil spills, the production of cheese and yoghurt through fermentation, the refining of gold, palladium, copper and other metals in the mining sector, as well as in biotechnology such as the manufacture of antibiotics and other chemicals. Bacteria are microscopic organisms that are difficult to detect, especially before the invention of the microscope. This organism was first observed in 1676 by Antony van Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch trader and scientist. He used a single-lens microscope he designed himself. Leeuwenhoek then published his observations in a series of letters to the Royal Society of London, which were published in English in 1684. Bacteria were objects within the limits of what Leeuwenhoek's simple lens could see and no one else could see them for over a century. Leeuwenhoek also observed protozoa, all of which he referred to as "small animals". Christian Gottfried Ehrenberg, German scientist, introduced the word bacterium in 1838. This word comes from a romanization of the Greek βακτηριον (bacterion), a diminutive form of βακτηρία (bacteria) meaning "rod" or "stick" because the first bacteria discovered were rod-shaped. .

In the mid-19th century, Ferdinand Cohn, a botanist from Breslau, Prussia (now part of Poland), became interested in heat-resistant bacteria. He found that a number of bacteria form endospores that are resistant to high temperatures, including Bacillus which is able to switch from a vegetative form to an endospore and vice versa. Cohn also initiated the grouping of bacteria based on their shape (spherical, rods, filaments, and spirals) and developed several methods to prevent contamination of bacterial cultures, such as using cotton as a cover for test tubes. Louis Pasteur, a French chemist, discovered that heating killed or deactivated bacteria and other microorganisms in wine so that the wine was less perishable and had a longer shelf life. This method was later called pasteurization. In the period from 1859 to 1864, Pasteur disproved the concept of spontaneous formation through his experiments which later became widely accepted. Together with his contemporary, Robert Koch, Pasteur was an early supporter of the germ theory of disease. At that time, microorganisms were known to cause infectious diseases. However, there was no definitive evidence to support this theory until Robert Koch, a German physician, was able to isolate and create pure cultures of bacteria, and grow them in a laboratory. Bacillus anthracis and Mycobacterium tuberculosis were the bacteria Koch used to prove the germ theory of disease until he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1905. Koch's postulates that he formulated to determine causality between pathogens and infectious diseases are still used today. Although various bacterial diseases were known, at that time there was no adequate treatment. Around 1910, Paul Ehrlich and his colleagues developed the first synthetic antibiotic, Salvarsan (later known as Arsfenamina) to treat syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.

Ehrlich received the Nobel Prize in 1908 for his work in immunology. He also pioneered the use of dyes to detect and identify bacteria, which became the basis for staining techniques such as Ziehl–Neelsen. A major development in bacteriology occurred in 1977 when Carl Woese published that archaea had a separate evolutionary lineage from bacteria. This phylogenetic taxonomy relies on sequencing of the 16S ribosomal RNA and divides prokaryotes into two domains, as part of a three-domain system. The ancestors of today's bacteria were unicellular microorganisms that were the first forms of life on Earth about 4 billion years ago. For about 3 billion years, the majority of organisms were microscopic, being dominated by bacteria and archaea. Although bacterial fossils are found, for example in the form of stromatolites, their less distinctive morphology means that they cannot be used to determine the evolutionary history of bacteria or the time of emergence of certain bacterial species. Nonetheless, gene sequences can be used to reconstruct bacterial phylogenies, indicating that it was bacteria that were the first to branch out and branch out from the archaean/eukaryotic lineage. The most recent common ancestor of bacteria and archaea was probably the hyperthermophiles who lived about 2.5 to 3.2 billion years ago. The earliest forms of life on land were probably bacteria which lived around 3.22 billion years ago. Bacteria were also involved in the second major evolutionary divergence that created the ramifications of archaea and eukaryotes. At that time, eukaryotes were formed from the entry of ancient bacteria into the ancestral eukaryotic cells (which may still be closely related to archaea) through endosymbiotic association. More specifically, proto-eukaryotic cells "engulfed" Alphaproteobacteria as symbionts to form either mitochondria or hydrogenosomes, which are still found in all known eukaryotic cells (sometimes in highly reduced forms, for example in ancient protozoa without mitochondria). ).

Later, some eukaryotes that already had mitochondria also engulfed organisms such as cyanobacteria that eventually formed chloroplasts in algae and plants. This is known as primary endosymbiosis. One group of bacteria, the cyanobacteria or "blue green algae," have left fossils far from the Precambrian. The oldest cyanobacteria fossils known to date are nearly 3.5 billion years old. Cyanobacteria are larger than most bacteria, and can secrete a thick cell wall. In addition, cyanobacteria can also form large layered structures, which are called stromatolites (if they are dome-shaped) or oncoliths (if they are round). These structures form as beds for cyanobacteria that grow in aquatic environments, forming sediments and sometimes excreting calcium carbonate. When cut very thin, well-preserved fossilized cyanobacteria and algae can be found in fossilized stromatolites. Other than cyanobacteria, there are not many published bacterial fossils. Under certain conditions, the bacterial cell can be confused with minerals, especially with pyrite or siderite (iron carbonate), minerals that can form replicas of living cells or pseudomorphs. Some bacteria also secrete an iron-coated coat that sometimes fossilizes. There are also bacteria that enter the shell or stone and form microscopic channels in the shell; These bacteria are known as endolytics. Bacteria have also been found in amber, fossilized tree resin, and in the tissues of mummies. Bacteria come in all shapes and sizes. Bacterial cells are about one-tenth the size of eukaryotic cells and are typically 0.5 to 5 micrometers in size. However, some species can be seen with the naked eye, for example Thiomargarita namibiensis which reaches half a millimeter in length and Epulopiscium fishelsoni which reaches 0.7 mm. The smallest examples of bacteria are members of the genus Mycoplasma which are 0.3 micrometers in size, roughly the same size as the largest viruses.

Some bacteria may be even smaller, but these types of ultramicro bacteria are not well understood. Most species of bacteria are spherical (called coccus; from the Greek kókkos meaning grain or seed) or rod-shaped (called bacillus, from Latin baculus meaning stick). Some types of bacteria are shaped like slightly curved or comma-shaped rods (called vibrios); other bacteria can be spiral (called a spirillum) or tightly coiled (called a spirocket). Unusual shapes have also been encountered, such as star-shaped bacteria. These various shapes are determined by the bacterial cell wall and cytoskeleton, which play an important role because they affect the ability of bacteria to obtain nutrients, attach to surfaces, swim in fluids, and escape from predators. Many bacterial species are single-celled, while others cluster in distinctive patterns: Neisseria are diploid (in pairs), Streptococcus form chains, while Staphylococcus cluster together like a bunch of grapes. Bacteria can also group together to form larger multicellular structures, such as Actinobacteria with elongated filaments, myxobacteria which form aggregates, and Streptomyces which have complex hyphae. These multicellular structures are often only seen under certain conditions. For example, when deficient in amino acids, myxobacteria detect nearby cells through a process known as quorum sensing to migrate towards one another and assemble to form fruiting bodies up to 500 micrometers in length and containing about 100,000 bacterial cells. Within this fruiting body, the bacteria perform separate tasks; for example, about one in ten cells migrate to the upper parts of the fruit body and differentiate into specialized dormant forms called myxospores that are more resistant to dry conditions and adverse environmental conditions.

Bacteria often attach to a surface and form dense aggregations called biofilms, while larger formations are known as microbial mats. These biofilms and mats are about a few micrometers thick while they can be up to half a meter deep, and may contain many species of bacteria, protists, and archaea. Bacteria living in biofilms display a complex arrangement of cells and extracellular components, as well as form secondary structures, such as microcolonies, within which a network of channels is in place to allow better diffusion of nutrients. In natural environments, such as soil or plant surfaces, most bacteria are bound together in the form of biofilms. Biofilms are important in medicine because these structures often appear during chronic bacterial infections or when medical device implants become infected. Bacteria that are protected in biofilms are much more difficult to kill than bacteria that live alone. Bacterial cells are surrounded by a cell membrane, which is mainly made of phospholipids. This membrane encloses the contents of the cell and serves as a barrier for nutrients, proteins, and other important components in the cytoplasm to keep them inside the cell. Unlike eukaryotes, bacterial cells usually do not have large membrane-enclosed structures within their cytoplasm, such as the nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplasts, and other organelles. However, some bacteria have protein-bound organelles, for example carboxysomes, which create compartments to separate aspects of the bacterial metabolism. In addition, bacteria possess a multicomponent cytoskeleton to regulate the localization of proteins and nucleic acids within the cell, as well as to manage the process of cell division. Many essential biochemical reactions, such as the generation of energy, occur due to concentration gradients across membranes. As a result, a potential difference similar to that of a battery is created. In general, the lack of internal membranes in bacteria results in these reactions, for example the electron transport chain, taking place across the cell membrane, either between the cytoplasm (on the inside of the cell) and the outside of the cell or with the periplasm.

However, in many photosynthetic bacteria, the plasma membrane is highly folded and fills most of the cell with light-collecting membrane layers. This light-collecting complex can form lipid-covered structures called chlorosomes in green sulfur bacteria. Bacteria do not have a membrane-enclosed nucleus. The genetic material is usually a nucleoid, that is, DNA located in the cytoplasm in an irregular manner that forms a single circular chromosome. The nucleoid contains complete chromosomes with their protein and RNA structures. Like all other organisms, bacteria possess ribosomes for making proteins, but the structure of the bacterial ribosome is different from that in eukaryotes and archaea. Some bacteria produce nutrient storage granules within their cells, such as glycogen, polyphosphate, sulfur, or polyhydroxy alkanoates. Some bacteria, such as photosynthetic cyanobacteria, have internal gas vacuoles that they use to regulate buoyancy so they can move up or down in layers of water that have different light intensities and nutrient levels. The layer that surrounds the outside of the cell membrane is the cell wall. The bacterial cell wall is made of peptidoglycan (also called murein), which is composed of polysaccharide chains cross-linked with peptides containing D-amino acids. Bacterial cell walls differ from plant and fungal cell walls, which are made of cellulose and chitin, respectively. Bacterial cell walls are also different from archaea in that they do not contain peptidoglycan. For many bacteria, the cell wall is essential for their survival because some substances, for example penicillin (an antibiotic produced by the fungus Penicillium), are capable of killing bacteria by blocking one step of the reaction in peptidoglycan synthesis. Broadly speaking, there are two types of cell walls in bacteria, which classify bacteria into Gram-positive bacteria and Gram-negative bacteria.

The naming is based on the reaction of cells to Gram staining, a method that has long been used to classify types of bacteria. Gram-positive bacteria have a thick cell wall containing many layers of peptidoglycan and teichoic acid. In contrast, Gram-negative bacteria have a relatively thin cell wall consisting of several layers of peptidoglycan surrounded by a lipid bilayer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides and lipoproteins. Most bacteria have cell walls of the Gram-negative type, and only the phyla Firmicutes and Actinobacteria (formerly known as low G+C and high G+C Gram-positive bacteria, respectively) have alternative Gram-positive arrangements. These structural differences can result in differences in susceptibility to antibiotics; for example, vancomycin can only kill Gram-positive bacteria and is ineffective against Gram-negative pathogens, such as Haemophilus influenzae or Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Some bacteria have a cell wall structure that is neither Gram-positive nor Gram-negative, including clinically important bacteria such as Mycobacterium which have a cell wall with thick peptidoglycan like Gram-positive bacteria, but also have a second lipid layer on the outside. In many bacteria, the S-layer consists of tightly packed protein molecules covering the outside of the cell. This layer protects the cell surface physically and chemically and can act as a barrier to the diffusion of macromolecules. S-layers have multiple functions, but many of their functions are poorly understood. So far, the S-layer is known to act as a virulence factor in Campylobacter and contains surface enzymes in Bacillus stearothermophilus. Many bacteria have other extracellular structures such as flagella, fimbriae, and pili which are used for locomotion, attachment, and conjugation. Flagella are rigid protein structures used for motility. Flagella are about 20 nanometers in diameter and up to 20 micrometers in length. Flagella are driven by energy released by ion transfer, which occurs due to electrochemical gradients across the cell membrane.

Fimbriae (sometimes called "adherent pili") are fine protein filaments, about 2–10 nanometers in diameter and several micrometers long. They are scattered over the cell surface and look like fine hairs when observed through an electron microscope. Fimbriae are believed to be involved in the attachment of bacteria to solid surfaces or to other cells, and play a role in the virulence of some bacterial pathogens. Meanwhile, pili are appendage structures that are slightly larger than fimbriae. These structures are known as conjugating pili or genital pili when they are the means of transferring genetic material between bacterial cells in a process called conjugation (see bacterial genetics below). They can also produce movements called type IV pili. Many bacteria produce glycocalyx to surround their cells. The structural complexity of the glycocalyx varies, from disorganized slime layers made of extracellular polymeric substances to highly structured capsules. These structures can protect bacterial cells from eukaryotic cells, such as macrophages (part of the human immune system), that would engulf them. The glycocalyx also has several other roles: it acts as an antigen, is involved in cell recognition, and aids in surface attachment and biofilm formation. The assembly of extracellular structures depends on the bacterial secretory system, which transfers proteins from the cytoplasm to the periplasm or to the environment around the cell. Scientists are familiar with the various secretory systems of bacteria and have found that the extracellular structures they produce often play an important role in determining the virulence of pathogens. Therefore, they are studied intensively. Several genera of Gram-positive bacteria, such as Bacillus, Clostridium, Sporohalobacter, Anaerobacter, and Heliobacterium, can form highly resistant structures called endospores. Endospores develop in the cytoplasm and generally there is one endospore developing in each cell.

Each endospore contains DNA and ribosomes which are surrounded by a layer of cortex and protected by layers of a rigid coat consisting of peptidoglycan and various proteins. Endospores show no signs of metabolism and can withstand extreme levels of physical and chemical stress, such as ultraviolet light, gamma radiation, detergents, disinfectants, heat, freezing, pressure, and drying. In this dormant state, an organism can remain alive for millions of years, and endospores even allow bacteria to survive the vacuum and radiation in space so that perhaps bacteria can be distributed throughout the Universe via cosmic dust, meteoroids, asteroids, comets. , planetoids, or via directional panspermia. Endospore-forming bacteria can also cause disease. For example, anthrax can be transmitted by inhaling Bacillus anthracis endospores, while deep puncture wounds contaminated with Clostridium tetani endospores can cause tetanus. In addition, the endospores of Clostridium botulinum protect it from high temperatures and pressures in canned food processing, which can lead to poisoning when consumed. Bacteria show a wide variety of metabolic types. The different metabolic traits within a group of bacteria were originally used to define their taxonomy, but these traits often do not align with modern genetically based classifications. Bacterial metabolism is divided into several groups of nutrients based on three main criteria: energy source, electron donor used, and carbon source used for growth. Bacteria obtain energy in one of two ways: by photosynthesis to convert energy from light (they are called phototrophs) or by breaking down chemical compounds using oxidation (called chemotrophs). Chemotrophic bacteria use chemical compounds as an energy source by transferring electrons from donors to terminal acceptors in redox reactions. This reaction releases energy that can be used to metabolize.

Chemotrophs are further divided based on the type of compound they use to transfer electrons. Bacteria that use inorganic compounds such as hydrogen, carbon monoxide, or ammonia as a source of electrons are called lithotrophs, while those that use organic compounds are called organotrophs. The compounds used to accept electrons are also used to classify bacteria: aerobic organisms use oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor, whereas anaerobic organisms use other compounds such as nitrates, sulfates, or carbon dioxide. Many bacteria obtain carbon for their cells from other organic carbon; they are called heterotrophs. Other bacteria such as cyanobacteria and some purple bacteria are autotrophs, meaning they obtain carbon by fixing carbon dioxide. In certain situations, methane gas can be used by methanotrophic bacteria as a source of electrons and as a substrate for carbon anabolism. In many ways, bacterial metabolism benefits ecological stability and human life. For example, some bacteria are capable of fixing nitrogen gas using the enzyme nitrogenase. This property is environmentally important and can be found in most of the types of bacterial metabolism mentioned above, leading to the processes of denitrification, sulfate reduction, and acetogenesis, all of which are ecologically important. Bacterial metabolic processes also play an important role in pollution; for example, sulfate-reducing bacteria are largely responsible for the production of highly toxic forms of mercury (methylmercury and dimethylmercury) in the environment. Nonrespiratory anaerobic bacteria use fermentation to generate energy and reduce power, and excrete metabolic by-products (such as ethanol in brewing) as waste. Facultative anaerobic bacteria can switch between fermenters and several different terminal electron acceptor forms, depending on the environmental conditions in which they are present. Bacteria live everywhere in abundance. The ecosystems in which bacteria live include terrestrial ecosystems, aquatic ecosystems, inside the bodies of other living things, and in man-made structures.

According to a 1998 study, the number of bacteria and archaea on Earth was estimated at 4–6 x 1030, the majority of which live in the deep biosphere. Approximately 3.5 x 1030 prokaryotes live in the deep biosphere in the ocean (seafloor layers deeper than 10 cm) and between 0.25–2.5 x 1030 in the deep biosphere in terrestrial (subsoil layers deeper than 8 m ). Lower numbers were found in terrestrial habitats, at 2.6 x 1029 cells, and in aquatic habitats, at 1.2 x 1029 cells. Much smaller proportions are found in the bodies of animals (including humans), in leaves and other plant parts, and in the air. Together they form the largest biomass on Earth, surpassed only by plants. In soil, which is an important habitat for a variety of organisms, the number and density of bacteria varies depending on the type of ecosystem. In general, the number of soil bacteria in forest ecosystems is lower than other types of ecosystems, such as desert scrub, savanna, and agricultural land. Up to one meter depth, the number of prokaryotes is estimated at 40 million cells per gram of forest soil, while in other types of terrestrial ecosystems it reaches 2 billion cells per gram of soil. In the aquatic environment, the highest density of bacteria was found in sediments at a thickness of 0 to 10 cm on the seafloor, namely 460 million cells per ml. In these seafloor sediments, bacteria have an important role in biogeochemical cycles, for example in the sulfur cycle played by Desulfobulbaceae. In the vicinity of hydrothermal vents and cold vents, extremophile bacteria provide the nutrients needed to sustain life by converting dissolved compounds, such as hydrogen sulfide and methane, into energy via chemosynthesis. Meanwhile, a lower concentration of prokaryotes was found in the ecosystems of rivers, fresh water lakes and salt lakes, namely 10 million cells per ml, while a density of 5 million cells per ml was found in continental shelf waters and in the open sea to a depth of 200 m. Bacteria can be found in the human body, especially in the digestive tract.

Many popular media and scientific writings state that the number of bacterial cells that inhabit the human body is about 10 times more than the number of human cells themselves, with an estimated 100 trillion bacterial cells and 10 trillion human cells. Even so, their number really depends on many things, such as age, body size, environment, to the food consumed. On the other hand, a study published in 2016 found that the ratio is about 1.3 bacterial cells for every human cell. The number of bacteria in the human digestive tract is quite varied. They are most commonly found in the large intestine, which is about 1011 cells per gram of intestinal contents, while in the small intestine as many as 108 cells per gram, and in the acidic stomach the number is 104 microbial cells per gram. In terms of variation, only two main phyla inhabit the human body, namely Firmicutes and Bacteroidetes. Apart from them, the phyla Actinobacteria, Proteobacteria, Fusobacteria, and Verrucomicrobia were also recorded. A common example is the lactic acid bacterium Lactobacillus acidophilus. This type is classified as probiotics, which are reported to be beneficial to the body and prevent health problems such as diarrhea and degenerative diseases. Bacteria can also be found on the surface of the skin and in the mouth. Inside the mouth, bacteria can form biofilms in the form of plaque which causes bad breath. Environmental conditions can stimulate or inhibit the growth and reproduction of bacteria. Environmental factors that greatly affect the life of bacteria are temperature, pH, water availability, and oxygen. However, similar to archaea, bacteria are able to live in environments that do not allow other organisms to live, for example environments that are too hot or too cold, too acidic or alkaline, and too salty. Extreme habitats require microorganisms to develop survival skills.

This group of microorganisms is referred to as extremophiles. Temperature is closely related to metabolism. As the temperature increases, enzymatic reactions will take place faster until they reach the optimum temperature which allows bacterial cells to grow at the highest speed. However, after passing a certain temperature, proteins and other cell components will experience denaturation so that the cell will die. Likewise, if the ambient temperature is below the cell's tolerance limit, the cell membrane will lose its semi-liquid state so that it cannot carry out its function. Based on the temperature range of their activity, bacteria are divided into four groups: psychrophiles living in a low temperature environment with an optimum temperature of around 4 °C, mesophiles living in a moderate temperature environment with an optimum temperature of around 40 °C, thermophiles living in a high temperature environment with a temperature optimum around 60 °C, and hyperthermophiles who live in very high temperature environments with an optimum temperature of 88 °C and even above. For example, Thermus aquaticus is a species of thermophilic bacteria that lives in hot springs. In Antarctica, some bacteria vetrify to survive temperatures down to −20 °C. Besides temperature, the growth and reproduction of bacteria is also determined by the degree of acidity (pH). Most natural environments have a pH between 3 and 9 so almost all bacteria live in this pH range. Each type of microorganism has its own optimum pH range, with a range of 2–3 pH units. Therefore, bacteria can also be grouped based on the pH of their environment. Neutrophilic organisms grow in a neutral pH, while acidophiles grow in an acidic environment and alkaliphiles grow in an alkaline environment. In general, bacteria require a relatively high relative humidity, approximately 85%. Relative humidity can be defined as the water content present in the air.

Reducing the water content of the protoplasm causes metabolic activities to stop, for example in the process of freezing and drying. For example, Escherichia coli bacteria will experience a decrease in the resistance and elasticity of their cell walls when the environmental RH is less than 84%. Gram-positive bacteria tend to live at higher air humidity compared to gram-negative bacteria due to changes in the structure of their cell membranes which contain a lipid bilayer. Light is one of the factors that affect the growth of bacteria. In general, bacteria and other microorganisms can live well in normal light exposure. However, exposure to light with high intensity ultraviolet (UV) rays can be fatal for bacterial growth. The technique of using UV rays, x rays, and gamma rays to sterilize an environment from bacteria and other microorganisms is known as irradiation technique which began to develop since the early 20th century. This method has been widely applied for various purposes, especially in food sterilization to increase shelf life and durability. Some examples of pathogenic bacteria that can be inhibited or eliminated include Escherichia coli 0157:H7 and Salmonella. Radiation at certain strengths can cause abnormalities and can even be lethal to living things, especially bacteria. For example in humans, radiation can cause acute liver disease, cataracts, hypertension, and even cancer. However, there is a certain group of bacteria that can survive very high radiation exposure, even hundreds of times greater than human resistance to radiation, namely the Deinococcaceae group. In comparison, humans generally cannot survive radiation exposure of more than 10 Gray (Gy, 1 Gy = 100 rad), while bacteria included in this group can survive up to 5,000 Gy.

In general, exposure to radiation energy can cause gene mutations and DNA chain breaks. If it occurs at high intensity, the bacteria can experience death. Deinococcus radiodurans has the ability to survive the mechanism of destruction of genetic material through an adaptation system and a very efficient DNA chain repair process. There are also halophilic bacteria that can live in environments with very high salt levels, such as Salinibacter ruber which grow optimally at salt concentrations between 20 and 30%. In addition, a number of other bacteria are able to live at high sugar content (osmophile group), low water content (xerophile group), as well as very high and low degrees of acidity. Some bacterial communities can survive in clouds up to 10 kilometers high. A research team using an old DC-8 aircraft modified as a flying laboratory managed to take samples of a number of bacteria in clouds under storm conditions. Bacteria living in ice nucleation are carried away by storms and survive in cloud ionization. In unicellular organisms, the increase in cell size (cell growth) and reproduction (through cell division) are two things that are closely related. Bacteria grow until they reach a fixed size and then reproduce through binary fission, a form of asexual reproduction. Under optimal conditions, bacteria can grow and divide very quickly; The bacterial population can double every 9.8 minutes. Cell division produces two identical daughter cells. While still reproducing asexually, some bacteria form more complex reproductive structures to help propagate the newly formed daughter cells. For example the formation of fruiting bodies by myxobacteria, the formation of hyphae by Streptomyces, and the formation of shoots. Budding occurs when a cell forms a bulge which then separates from the parent cell to become daughter cells.

In the laboratory, bacteria are usually grown using solid media or liquid media. Solid growth media, such as agar plates, are used to isolate pure cultures of a bacterial strain. Meanwhile, liquid growth media are used when scientists want to measure bacterial growth or require large volumes of bacterial cells. The liquid media can be stirred until an even cell suspension is formed so that the bacterial culture is easily divided and transferred to other containers. The use of selective media (medium with the addition or reduction of certain nutrients or with the addition of antibiotics) can help identify specific organisms. Most techniques for growing bacteria in the laboratory use high levels of nutrients to produce large numbers of cells cheaply and quickly. However, in the natural environment, the amount of nutrients is limited. This means that bacteria cannot continue to reproduce forever. Nutritional limitations cause bacteria to evolve different growth strategies (see r/K selection theory). Some organisms can grow very quickly when enough nutrients are available, such as the algae (and cyanobacteria) population explosions that often occur in lakes during the summer. Other bacteria are adapted to harsh environments, such as Streptomyces which produce some antibiotics to inhibit the growth of competing microorganisms. In nature, many organisms live in communities (e.g. biofilms), which allows for increased supply of nutrients and protection from environmental stresses. These relationships become important for the growth of a particular organism or group of organisms (referred to as syntrophy). Bacterial growth consists of four phases. When bacterial populations first enter a high-nutrient environment that allows growth, they need to adapt to their new environment. The first phase is the sluggish phase. Growth occurs slowly as bacterial cells adapt to the nutrient-rich environment and prepare for rapid growth.

The sluggish phase has a high biosynthesis rate because the proteins necessary for growth are produced quickly. The second growth phase is the logarithmic phase, which is also known as the exponential phase. The log phase is characterized by rapid exponential growth. The rate of increase in the number of cells during this phase is known as the growth rate (k), while the time it takes for cells to multiply is known as the formation time (g). During the log phase, nutrients are metabolized at maximum speed until one nutrient is depleted and growth is restricted. The third phase is the stationary phase or the stationary phase due to depleted nutrients. The cells reduce their metabolic activity and consume non-essential internal cell proteins. The quiescent phase is a transition from a state of rapid growth to a state that responds to stress. There is increased expression of genes involved in DNA repair, antioxidant metabolism, and nutrient transport. The final phase is the death phase when the bacteria run out of nutrients and die. Most bacteria have a single coiled chromosome that can range in length from 160,000 base pairs (bp) in the endosymbiotic bacterium Carsonella ruddii, to 12,200,000 base pairs (12.2 Mbp) in the soil-dwelling bacterium Sorangium cellulosum. There are many variations in the shape of bacterial chromosomes, for example some Streptomyces and Borrelia species have one linear chromosome, while some Vibrio species have more than one chromosome. Bacteria can also contain plasmids, small extrachromosomal DNA molecules that may contain genes useful for developing various functions, such as antibiotic resistance, metabolic ability, or virulence factors. The bacterial genome usually encodes several hundred to several thousand genes. The genes are generally arranged linked together on a single stretch of DNA and although several types of introns are found in bacterial genomes, their frequency is much less than introns in eukaryotes.

As asexual organisms, bacteria inherit an identical copy of their genome to their parent cell and are clonal in nature. Even so, all bacteria can evolve and undergo DNA changes due to genetic recombination or mutation. Mutations are caused by errors that occur during DNA replication or by exposure to mutagens. Mutation rates vary widely among different bacterial species and even among clones derived from a single bacterial species. Mutations can occur randomly during replication or as a result of “stress driving”, when the mutation rate increases in certain genes involved in growth-limiting situations. Some bacteria can transfer genetic material between cells in three main ways. First, bacteria can take up exogenous DNA from the surrounding environment through a process called transformation. Naturally, many bacteria are competent to take up DNA from the environment, while other bacteria must be chemically modified to induce them to take up DNA. This ability can be developed naturally and is usually associated with stressful environmental conditions, as an adaptation of bacteria to repair damaged DNA. The second way of transferring genetic material is by transduction, when a bacteriophage (a type of virus) inserts foreign DNA into the bacterial chromosome. There are many types of bacteriophages; some of them simply infect and lyse their host bacteria, while others enter into the bacterial chromosome. Bacteria fight phage infection through a restriction modification system that degrades foreign DNA and a system that uses CRISPR which allows them to block viral replication via RNA interference. A third method of transferring genes is conjugation, in which DNA is transferred by direct cell-to-cell contact. Under normal circumstances, transfer of DNA by transduction, conjugation, and transformation involves individual bacteria of the same species, but sometimes transfer of DNA can occur between individuals of different species and this can have significant effects, such as the transfer of antibiotic resistance capabilities.

Many bacteria are motile (able to move independently) using a variety of mechanisms. The most well-studied locomotor is the flagellum, a long, whip-like filament whose base attaches to a rotating rotor to produce a propeller-like motion. The direction of rotation of the flagella is reversible, which uses an electrochemical gradient across the membrane to create power. Different bacterial species have different numbers and arrangements of flagella. There are species that have a single flagellum (called monotric bacteria), there are also those that have flagella at each end (amphitric), have groups of flagella at the poles of the cell (lophotric), or flagella that are distributed throughout the cell surface (peritric). The flagella of the spirocket are found in a unique location, namely between two membranes in the periplasmic space. This group of bacteria has a characteristic helical body that rotates with them when they move. Motile bacteria approach or move away from certain stimuli. This behavior is called taxis, which includes chemotaxis, phototaxis, energitaxis, and magnetotaxy. In one special group, the mycobacteria, individual bacteria move together to form a wave of cells which then differentiate to form fruiting bodies that contain spores. Myxobacteria only move on solid surfaces, unlike E. coli, which moves in liquid or solid media. As intracellular pathogens, some Listeria and Shigella species move within host cells by taking over the cytoskeleton, which is normally used to move organelles within the host cell. By inducing actin polymerization at one of the poles of their cell, they can form a kind of tail to move around in the cytoplasm of the host cell. This form of communication between bacteria is found in biofilms. Bacterial cells that form aggregates exchange molecular signals to communicate and engage in coordinated multicellular behavior. Benefits of multicellular cooperation include regulating the division of cellular labor, accessing resources that cannot be used effectively by a single cell, collectively defending against antagonists, and optimizing population survival by differentiating into different types of cells.

For example, a collection of bacteria in a biofilm can increase resistance to antibacterial agents by more than 500 times compared to species-uniform planktonic (free-living bacteria). One type of intercellular communication that uses molecular signals is quorum sensing. This mechanism serves to determine the local density of similar bacteria. If the density is high enough, the bacteria will together do the same thing, for example secrete digestive enzymes or emit light. In quorum sensing, bacteria will generate, release, and detect molecular signals. If the molecular signals are numerous (as a result of the large number of conspecific bacteria), they then carry out coordinated gene expression, which produces proteins and initiates similar behavior. Taxonomy aims to describe the diversity of bacterial species by naming and grouping bacteria based on their similarities. Bacteria can be classified based on cell structure, cell metabolism, or differences in cell components, such as DNA, fatty acids, pigments, antigens, and quinones. Although this method allows identification and classification of bacterial strains, the differences found are still unclear, whether they represent variations among different species or between strains of the same species. This uncertainty is due to the lack of differentiating structures in most bacteria as well as the presence of horizontal gene transfer among unrelated species. As a result of horizontal gene transfer, a number of closely related bacteria can have very different morphologies and metabolisms. To address this uncertainty, modern bacterial classification employs molecular phylogenetics, which employs genetic techniques such as determination of the cytosine-guanine ratio, genome-genome hybridization, and sequencing of genes that have not undergone extensive horizontal gene transfer, such as rRNA genes. The classification of bacteria is determined by publications in the International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology and Bergey's Manual.

The International Committee on Prokaryote Systematics (ICSP) establishes international rules regarding the naming of bacteria, their taxonomic categories and their ranking in the International Regulations for Prokaryote Nomenclature. Initially, the term "bacteria" was used to refer to all single-celled microscopic prokaryotes. However, molecular phylogenetics suggests that prokaryotes consist of two separate domains, originally called Eubacteria and Archaebacteria, but now called Bacteria and Archaea; both evolved independently from a common ancestor. The kinship between archaea and eukaryotes is much closer than that between them and bacteria. All of them, namely Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya, form a three-domain system which is currently the most widely used classification system. However, because the application of molecular phylogenetics is still relatively new and the number of known genome sequences is increasing rapidly, bacterial classification remains a changing and evolving field. For example, Cavalier-Smith, an evolutionary biologist, argues that archaea and eukaryotes evolved from Gram-positive bacteria. Identification of bacteria in the laboratory is very relevant in medical science because the right therapy is determined by the accuracy of identifying the bacteria that cause infection. Consequently, the need to identify pathogens was a major impetus for developing bacterial identification techniques. The Gram stain, developed in 1884 by Hans Christian Gram, classifies bacteria based on the structure of their cell wall. The thick layer of peptidoglycan in the cell wall of "Gram-positive" bacteria shows a purple color, while the thin cell wall of "Gram-negative" bacteria appears pink. By combining morphology and Gram stain, most bacteria can be classified as one of four groups: Gram-positive cocci, Gram-positive bacilli, Gram-negative cocci and Gram-negative bacilli. A number of bacteria are better identified by stains than Gram stain, especially Mycobacterium or Nocardia, which show acid fastness on Ziehl–Neelsen stain or similar stains.

Other bacteria may need to be identified by growing on special media, or by other techniques, such as serology. Bacterial culture is designed to promote growth and identify specific bacteria, while limiting the growth of other bacteria in the sample. Certain types of specimens are usually treated by certain techniques; for example, sputum specimens are handled to identify pneumonia-causing organisms, while stool specimens are cultured on selective media that can identify diarrhea-causing organisms, while preventing the growth of nonpathogenic bacteria. Specimens that are normally sterile, such as blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid, are cultured under conditions designed to grow all possible microorganisms. Once pathogenic bacteria have been isolated, they can be further characterized based on their morphology, growth pattern (such as aerobic or anaerobic growth), pattern of hemolysis, and their response to staining. Like classification, bacterial identification techniques are also increasing with the advent of molecular methods. Diagnosis using DNA-based methods, such as the polymerase chain reaction, is gaining popularity because of its speed and specificity compared to culture-based methods. Molecular methods also allow the detection and identification of "viable but non-culturable" cells, that is, bacteria that are metabolically active but not dividing. However, even using modern methods, the number of bacterial species is not known and cannot even be estimated with certainty. Based on the current classification, the number of known species of prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea) is close to 9,300. On the other hand, studies that estimate the overall amount of bacterial diversity range from 107 to 109 species—and even these large interval estimates may be far off the mark. Despite their apparent simplicity, bacteria can form complex associations with other organisms. This symbiotic association can be divided into parasitism, mutualism, and commensalism. Because of their small size, commensal bacteria are everywhere, both on surfaces and inside the bodies of animals and plants, as well as on the surfaces of other objects.

Bacterial growth can be enhanced by warm temperatures and sweat; in humans, large populations of bacteria are responsible for body odor. Predator bacteria are species of bacteria that kill and then eat other microorganisms. An example is Myxococcus xanthus which forms swarms of cells that kill and digest any bacteria they encounter. Other bacterial predators are able to latch on to their prey to digest and absorb nutrients, such as Vampirovibrio chlorellavorus, or invade other cells and multiply within their cytosol, such as Daptobacter. Predatory bacteria are thought to have evolved from saprophages, which feed on dead microorganisms, through adaptations that allowed them to trap and kill other organisms. Several types of bacteria form close relationships with other organisms to maintain their survival. One such symbiotic mutualism is called interspecies hydrogen transfer, which occurs between groups of anaerobic bacteria that consume organic acids (such as butyric acid or propionic acid) and produce hydrogen and methanogenic archaea that consume hydrogen. These bacteria cannot consume large amounts of organic acids because the reaction produces hydrogen which accumulates around them. Only by being in close contact with hydrogen-consuming archaea can the hydrogen concentration be kept low enough for the bacteria to continue growing. In the soil, microorganisms in the rhizosphere (the zone covering the surface of the roots and the soil that adheres to the roots after gentle shaking) carry out nitrogen fixation, which converts nitrogen gas into nitrogen-containing compounds. This reaction serves to provide an easily absorbed form of nitrogen for many plants that cannot fix nitrogen on their own. Meanwhile, many other bacteria are found as symbionts in humans and other organisms. For example, there are more than 1,000 species of bacteria as normal flora in the human intestine that play a role in forming intestinal immunity, synthesizing vitamins such as vitamin B7, vitamin B9, and vitamin K, converting sugar into lactic acid (called lactic acid bacteria such as Lactobacillus), and fermenting complex carbohydrates that humans cannot digest.

The presence of this intestinal flora also inhibits the growth of potentially pathogenic bacteria (usually through competitive exclusion) so that these beneficial bacteria are sold as food supplements in the form of probiotics. If bacteria form a parasitic symbiosis with other organisms, they are classified as pathogens. Pathogenic bacteria are one of the causes of infectious diseases such as tetanus (caused by Clostridium tetani), typhoid fever (Salmonella serovar Typhi), diphtheria (Corynebacterium diphtheriae), syphilis (Treponema pallidum), cholera (Vibrio cholerae), leprosy (Mycobacterium leprae), and tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis), to various foodborne diseases. It is possible for a disease to be known as the causative pathogen many years later, such as the case of peptic ulcer disease and Helicobacter pylori. Bacterial diseases are also important in agriculture and animal husbandry, for example bacteria that cause leaf spot, fire blight and wilting in plants, as well as paratuberculosis, mastitis and anthrax in livestock. Each pathogen species has a unique spectrum of interactions with its host. Bacteria in the genera Staphylococcus and Streptococcus can cause skin infections, pneumonia, meningitis and sepsis, which are systemic inflammatory responses that can lead to shock, massive vasodilation and death. However, they are also part of the normal human flora and are usually present on the skin or in the nose without causing any disease. Other bacteria always cause disease in humans, such as Rickettsia which is an obligate intracellular parasite that is able to grow and reproduce only within the cells of other organisms. One species of Rickettsia causes typhus, while another species causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Chlamydia, another obligate intracellular pathogen, contains species that can cause pneumonia and urinary tract infections and may be involved in coronary heart disease. Several other species, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Burkholderia cenocepacia, and Mycobacterium avium, are opportunistic pathogens that cause disease especially in people suffering from immunosuppression or cystic fibrosis.

Bacterial infections can be treated with antibiotics, which are classed as bactericidal if they kill bacteria or bacteriostatic if they only prevent the growth of bacteria. There are many types of antibiotics that are grouped into several groups. Each class of antibiotics has a different action in preventing certain chemical processes in the bacterial cells found in the host. Examples of antibiotics that produce selective toxicity are chloramphenicol and puromycin. Both of these classes of antibiotics inhibit bacterial ribosomes, but not the structurally different eukaryotic ribosomes. Antibiotics are used to treat human diseases and to accelerate the growth of animals in intensive farming, which may have contributed to the rapid development of antibiotic resistance in bacterial populations. Bacterial infections can be prevented by antiseptic measures, for example by sterilizing the skin before piercing it with a syringe and maintaining the sterility of the catheter that will be inserted into the body. Surgical and dental equipment is also sterilized to prevent bacterial contamination. Disinfectants such as bleach are used to kill bacteria or other pathogens on surfaces to prevent contamination and reduce the risk of infection. The diversity of bacteria and their metabolic pathways causes bacteria to have a major role in the environment. For example, saprophytic bacteria decompose dead plants or animals and the remains or excrement of organisms. The bacteria decompose proteins, carbohydrates and other organic compounds into CO2, ammonia gas and other simpler compounds. Examples of saprophytic bacteria include Proteus and Clostridium. Not only act as decomposers of organic compounds, several groups of saprophytic bacteria are also opportunistic pathogens. Other groups of bacteria play a role in the nitrogen cycle, such as nitrifying bacteria. Nitrifying bacteria are a group of bacteria capable of compiling nitrate compounds from ammonia compounds which generally take place aerobically in the soil.

This group of bacteria is chemolithotrophic. Nitrification consists of two stages, namely nitritation (oxidation of ammonia (NH4) to nitrite (NO2-)) and nitration (oxidation of nitrite compounds to nitrate (NO3)). In agriculture, nitrification is very beneficial because it produces compounds needed by plants, namely nitrates. After the nitrification reaction is complete, a nitrification process will occur which is carried out by denitrifying bacteria. Denitrification itself is the anaerobic reduction of nitrate compounds into free nitrogen (N2) which is more easily absorbed and metabolized by various living things. Examples of bacteria capable of this metabolism are Pseudomonas stutzeri, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Paracoccus denitrificans. In addition, this reaction also produces nitrogen in other forms, such as nitrous oxide (N2O). These compounds can not only play an important role for the life of various organisms, but can also play a role in the phenomenon of acid rain and ozone depletion. N2O compounds will be oxidized to NO compounds and then react with ozone (O3) to form NO2- which will return to earth in the form of acid rain (HNO2). In agriculture, it is known that there is a group of bacteria that are able to symbiosis with plant roots or live freely in the soil to help enrich the soil. This group of bacteria is known as nitrogen fixing bacteria or nitrogen bacteria for short. Nitrogen bacteria are a group of bacteria that are able to bind nitrogen (especially N2) free in the air and reduce it to ammonia compounds (NH4) and nitrate ions (NO3-) with the help of the enzyme nitrogenase. This group of bacteria usually symbiosis with legumes and legumes to form a mutualism symbiosis in the form of nodules or root nodules to fix free nitrogen in the air which in general cannot be used directly by most organisms. In general, this group of bacteria known as rhizobia, includes the bacterial genera Rhizobium, Bradyrhizobium, Mesorhizobium, Photorhizobium, and Sinorhizobium.

An example of nitrogenous bacteria that live in symbiosis with leguminous plants is Rhizobium leguminosarum, which lives in roots to form root nodules or nodules. There are several groups of bacteria that are capable of carrying out the fermentation process and this has been widely applied to the processing of various types of food. Fermented foodstuffs generally have a longer shelf life, can also enhance or even give a new and unique taste to these foods. Some fermented foods and the microorganisms involved: Several species of pathogenic and decomposer bacteria can grow in foods. This group of bacteria is able to metabolize various components in food and then produce side metabolites that are toxic. Clostridium botulinum, which produces the toxin botulinin, is often found in canned food and is now used as a base for Botox. Some examples of food spoilage bacteria: Bacteria can also cause disease in plants. Ralstonia solanacearum is one of the bacteria that causes wilt in tomato plants. Affected plants show symptoms of sudden wilting and can even cause death. One of the diseases that attack orchids is soft rot caused by the bacterium Erwinia carotovora. In the development of the pathogen, the symptoms will quickly spread and can kill the growing point of the plant. Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae (Swings et al. 1990) is a plant pathogenic bacterium that causes leaf blight in rice, which is also known as crackle disease. Stem rot disease in soybean plants by Sclerotium rolsfii can cause low soybean production. This disease is often found in soybean plants both dry land, rainfed and tidal with an attack intensity of 5 - 55%. An attack rate of more than 5% in the field can be detrimental economically. Fusarium oxysporum f.sp.

cubense (Foc) causes fusarium wilt in banana plants. The infection will interfere with the process of absorption, transportation of water and nutrients in the soil, so that the plants wither and eventually die. Not only in the environmental and food fields, bacteria can also provide health benefits. Antibiotics are substances produced by microorganisms and have inhibitory power against the activities of other microorganisms and these compounds are widely used in curing a disease. Some of the bacteria that produce antibiotics are: Apart from their role in producing antibiotics, many types of bacteria are actually pathogenic. In humans, several types of bacteria that often become disease-causing agents are Salmonella enterica subspecies I serovar Typhi which causes typhus, Mycobacterium tuberculosis which causes tuberculosis, and Clostridium tetani which causes tetanus. Pathogenic bacteria can also attack livestock, such as Brucella abortus which causes brucellosis in cattle and Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax. For infections in plants that are commonly known are Xanthomonas oryzae which attacks rice shoots and Erwinia amylovora which causes rot in fruits. The process of degradation of living things is carried out by many organisms, one of which is bacteria. Several types of bacteria, especially heterotrophic bacteria, are able to degrade organic compounds and use them to support their growth. This decomposition process is assisted by several types of enzymes to break down macromolecules, such as carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, to be broken down into simpler compounds. For example, protease enzymes are used to break down proteins into simpler compounds, such as amino acids. This decomposition process also plays a role in returning elements, especially carbon and nitrogen, to nature to enter into the cycle again. The decomposition of living organisms is initiated by bacteria that live in the human body, starting with muscle tissues.
