edit page log out learn more Monosaccharides (from Greek mono: one, sacchar: sugar) are carbohydrate compounds in the simplest form of sugars..The functional group that makes up a monosaccharide is an aldehyde or ketone unit. In the stereoisomer form, monosaccharides have at least one asymmetric carbon atom. Monosaccharides are formed from the synthesis of simple compounds through the process of gluconeogenesis. The formation of monosaccharides can also be carried out through photosynthesis in certain plants and bacteria. In complex lipids, monosaccharides are the building blocks of nucleic acids and important compounds. Some monosaccharides have a sweet taste. The general properties of monosaccharides are water soluble, colorless, and crystalline solids. Examples of monosaccharides are glucose (dextrose), fructose (levulose), galactose, xylose and ribose. Honey is a natural food ingredient that contains mostly monosaccharides, especially fructose and glucose. Monosaccharides are compounds that form disaccharides (such as sucrose) and polysaccharides (such as cellulose and starch). Monosaccharides are classified based on the number of carbon atoms they contain (triose, tetrose, pentose, hexose, and heptose) and their active group, which can be an aldehyde or a ketone. These then combine, becoming for example aldohexoses and ketotrioses. Furthermore, each carbon atom to which the hydroxyl group is attached (except at both ends) is optically active, resulting in several different carbohydrates even though the basic structure is the same. For example, galactose is an aldohexose, but it has different properties from glucose because the atoms are arranged differently. With a few exceptions (eg deoxyribose), monosaccharides have the general chemical formula Cx(H2O)y, where x is at least 3. Monosaccharides can be grouped according to the number of carbon atoms (or the number of x) they contain: diose (2) triose (3) tetrose ( 4), pentoses (5), hexoses (6), heptoses (7), and so on. The most important type of monosaccharide, glucose, is a hexose.

An example of a heptose is the ketose manoheptulose and sedoheptulose. Monosaccharides with 8 or fewer carbon atoms are rare because they are somewhat unbalanced. Another example: Simple monosaccharides have straight, unbranched carbon chains with one carbonyl functional group (C=O), and one hydroxyl group (OH) on each remaining carbon atom. Thus, the molecular structure of a simple monosaccharide can be written as H(CHOH)n(C=O)(CHOH)mH, where n+1+m = x; then, the elemental formula is CxH2xOx. Most monosaccharides are colorless, and crystalline solids (sweet). With a few exceptions (eg deoxyribose or amino sugars), monosaccharides have a general chemical formula: Monosaccharides contain either a ketone or an aldehyde functional group. A common way of representing the cyclic structure of a monosaccharide is by using the Haworth projection. Usually the D,L system is used. Monosaccharides containing an aldehyde group are classified as aldoses, while those containing a ketone group are called ketoses. Monosaccharides can be formed through the hydrolysis of cellulose by cellulase enzymes, namely endoglucanase, exoglucanase, and cellobiase. Endoglucanase plays a role in random hydrolysis of the amorphous cellulose. Hydrolysis results in the form of molecules with a lighter mass, namely cellodextrin, cellobiose, and glucose. Exoglucanase destroys the crystalline structure of cellulose and produces disaccharides. Meanwhile, cellobiase converts disaccharides into two glucose molecules, a type of simple sugar, which is the basic ingredient in the manufacture of ethanol. Palm sugar is formed from microbial invertase on sucrose inversion in sap. The sugar content contained in the sap becomes a reducing agent for sucrose. This reducing agent is a monosaccharide consisting of a mixture of fructose and glucose. The sucrose inversion process occurs shortly after tapping the sap until the sap is cooked into sugar. Fructose and glucose are formed by hydrolysis by acids during the boiling of sucrose solutions.

The editoring page that has come out Log Learn further initial, Diwali, Din, (Sanskrit: दीपावली, Hindi: दिवाली, Marathi language: दिवाळी, Kannada Language: ದೀಪಾವಳಿ, Kokani: धाकली दिवाळी, Tamil: தீபாவளி, Telugu language: దీపావళి, దీపావళి, Urdu: دیوالی) is a Hindu religious festival which means "Festival of Lights". The celebration symbolizes the victory of Good (Dharma) over Bad (Adharma), and the Lamp or Lamp represents a celebration and human hope. The celebration of Dipawali is centered on Lights and Lights, especially on a traditional lamp (Diya). Fireworks are also used in the Celebration. In the Hindu religious calendar, the Dipawali celebration occurs in the month "Ashwauja", while in the Christian calendar, the Dipawali celebration occurs in October or November. The Dipawali celebration begins with a celebration called Navratri. In India, the Navratri Celebration is celebrated to pay homage to Goddess Durga and her embodiment in defeating a demon named Mahisasura. 20 days before Dipawali, there are several Festivals like Dussehra, Vijayadashami, Dasara and Dhanteras Festivals. The celebration of Dipawali is associated with Goddess Lakshmi, That is, the Goddess of wealth, Prosperity, Fertility and Victory. For adherents of Vaishnava Hinduism, Ashta Lakshmi is the embodiment of Adi Shakti Parashakti (the highest embodiment), the embodiment of Victory and the embodiment of aspects of the Universe. In several areas in India and in Indonesia, Adi Shakti Parashakti is always related to Lord Krishna, Lord Vishnu, Goddess Durga, Dewi Sri, Dewa Rama and Dewi Sita and Dewa Dhanwantari. Adherents of Hinduism, Jains and Sikhs consider the Celebration a Celebration of life. These religious adherents use the Dipawali Celebration as a means to strengthen kinship ties between family and friends. For Jains, This is one of the most important Festivals.

Because, will mark the start of a new year. Dipawali celebrations are determined based on the Hindu Religious Calendar (Calendar which includes Iunisolar). According to the Gregorian Calendar, Dipawali occurs in October or November. In 2005, Dipawali Celebration was celebrated on November 1st. In 2006, Dipawali Celebration was celebrated on 21 October. In 2007, Dipawali Celebration was celebrated on November 8, and in 2022, Dipawali Celebration was celebrated on November 12, more precisely on Sunday. Dipawali is a celebration that marks the victory of good (Dharma) over evil (Adharma). The word Dipawali is taken from Sanskrit, namely, the word Dipavali which means a line of light which signifies the victory of light over darkness. During the Dipawali Celebration, many Hindus wear new clothes, share sweets with those closest to them and set off fireworks. In northern India, Hindus begin a new financial period on Dipawali. During the Dipawali Celebration, Hindus celebrate the return of Rama (The King of Ayodhya), and his wife (Sita), and his younger brother who is an admiral from the City of Ayodhya. At one point, There was a Battle in the City of Ayodhya where Rama killed Asura Ravana (Ravana). Hindus believe that the lighting of the lamp symbolizes the Path of light that guides them in darkness. The first day of the Dipawali Celebration is called Vasu Daras. Vasu Daras is dedicated to Cows (Animals that are considered sacred according to Hindus). At the time of Vasu Daras, King Pithu liberated his people from Famine by capturing "Earth". In Hindu mythology, the cow is the embodiment of the Earth whose milk brings life and soil fertility. The second day of the Dipawali Celebration is called Dhan Teras.

Dhan Teras is dedicated to commemorating the arrival of Lord Dhanvantari from Samudera. The second day of the Dipawali Celebration is believed to be the best day according to Hindus. On this day, adherents of Hinduism buy various valuable items such as gold and silver because they are believed to bring good luck. The third day of the Dipawali Celebration is called Naraka Chaturdashi. Naraka Chaturdashi is the anniversary of when Lord Krishna killed a giant named Narakasura. This event is a day that is complemented by the making of Rangoli (a form of traditional Indian art in the form of decorations from rice and flour colored with spices). In addition, at the time of the Naraka Chaturdashi Celebration, adherents of Hinduism perform a form of worship of the god Krisna. The fourth day of the Dipawali Celebration is called Laksmi Puja. Laksmi Puja is complemented by a form of worship of Goddess Laksmi (Goddess who brings prosperity) and Dewa Ganesh (God who brings good luck). In the northern part of India, the fourth day is the highlight of the Dipawali Celebration. The fifth day of the Dipawali Celebration is called Bali Pratipada. Bali Pratipada is a day of remembrance when Lord Krisna saved the people and cows from a natural disaster, namely flooding by lifting Govadhana Hill. The sixth day of the Dipawali Celebration is called Yama Dwitiya. Yama Dwitiya is a day of remembrance to commemorate the visit of Dewa Yama (God of death) to the place of his sister, Dewi Yami. The visit was complemented by a shared meal. At the time of eating together, Lord Yama gave gifts to his sister. Therefore, on the sixth day, adherents of Hinduism have a tradition of visiting sisters and giving gifts. In Indonesia, the Dipawali Celebration is celebrated by Indians who adhere to Hinduism. The celebration was very lively in North Sumatra and Bali.

Page editor logged out learn more Tuberculosis (abbreviated Tbc), or Tb (abbreviation for "Tubercle bacillus") is a common, and in many cases fatal, infectious disease. The disease is caused by various strains of mycobacteria, most commonly Mycobacterium tuberculosis (abbreviated "MTb" or "MTbc"). Tuberculosis usually affects the lungs, but can affect other parts of the body. Tuberculosis is spread through the air when a person with an active TB infection coughs, sneezes, or disperses their saliva through the air. The majority of TB infections are asymptomatic and latent (often called latent TB). However, one in ten cases of latent infection develops into active disease (active TB). If tuberculosis is not treated, more than 50% of infected people will die. Before the discovery of effective antibiotics to treat TB (around the early 1900s) an estimated 1 in 7 people in the world died from this disease. The classic symptoms of active TB infection are a chronic cough with blood streaks in the sputum or sputum, fever, night sweats and weight loss. (TB used to be called a "consumption" disease because people who were infected usually lost weight). Infections in other organs cause various symptoms. The diagnosis of active TB depends on radiological results (usually through a chest X-ray) as well as physical examination and microbiological culture. Meanwhile, the diagnosis of latent TB relies on the tuberculin skin test (TST) and blood test (IGRA). Treatment of active TB requires regular administration of multiple antibiotics over a period of 6 to 12 months. People who come into contact should also be screened and treated if necessary. With the development of currently available antibiotics, TB treatment that is carried out properly will provide a cure rate above 90%.

However, often if treatment is not carried out regularly and for the required period of time, the TB bacteria can recur and adapt to become resistant to antibiotics. Antibiotic resistance is a major problem in the management of the TB epidemic. Multi-drug resistant tuberculosis infection (or often called MDR TB) requires much more severe treatment with much higher doses of drugs and a much lower cure rate. To prevent TB, everyone should have a screening test for the disease and get the Calmette–Guérin bacillus vaccination. Experts believe that one third of the world's population has been infected with M. tuberculosis, and new infections are occurring at a rate of one person per second. In 2007, there were an estimated 13.7 million active chronic cases globally. In 2010, it is estimated that there will be an additional 8.8 million new cases and 1.5 million deaths, the majority of which occur in developing countries. The absolute number of tuberculosis cases has been decreasing since 2006, while new cases have been decreasing since 2002. Tuberculosis is not evenly distributed throughout the world. Of the population in various countries in Asia and Africa who have a tuberculin test, 80% show a positive result, while in the United States, only 5–10% show a positive result. More and more people in developing countries are suffering from tuberculosis because their immune system is weak. Usually, they suffer from tuberculosis as a result of being infected with the HIV virus and develop into AIDS. In the 1990s, Indonesia was ranked 3rd in the world for TB sufferers, but the situation has improved and in 2013 it was ranked 5th in the world. Of the group that is not living with HIV but later becomes infected with tuberculosis, 5-10% show active disease development during their lifetime.

In contrast, of the group infected with HIV and also infected with tuberculosis, 30% showed active disease development. Tuberculosis can infect any part of the body, but most often it infects the lungs (known as pulmonary tuberculosis). When tuberculosis develops outside the lungs, it is called extrapulmonary TB. Extrapulmonary TB can also occur together with pulmonary TB. Common signs and symptoms include fever, chills, night sweats, loss of appetite, weight loss and lethargy. There may also be significant clubbing. When the tuberculosis infection that occurs becomes active, about 90% always involves the lungs. Symptoms include chest pain and a prolonged cough with phlegm. About 25% of sufferers do not show any symptoms (which are thus called "asymptomatic"). Sometimes, sufferers experience a bit of coughing up blood. In certain rare cases, the infection can erode into the pulmonary artery, causing severe bleeding called a Rasmussen's aneurysm. Tuberculosis can also develop into a chronic disease and cause extensive scarring of the upper lobes of the lungs. The upper lung is most commonly infected. The reasons are not yet clear. It might be because the upper lungs get more airflow or it could be due to poor lymph drainage in the upper lungs. In 15–20% of active cases, the infection spreads beyond the respiratory organs and causes other forms of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis that occurs outside the respiratory organs is called "extrapulmonary tuberculosis". Extrapulmonary TB commonly occurs in immunosuppressed adults and children. Extrapulmonary TB occurs in more than 50% of the HIV-infected group. Significant extrapulmonary TB sites include: the pleura (in TB pleurisy), the central nervous system (in TB meningitis), and the lymph system (in scrofuloderma of the neck).

Extrapulmonary TB can also occur in the urogenital system (ie in urogenital Tuberculosis) and in bones and joints (ie in Pott's disease of the spine). When TB spreads to the bones it can be called "bone TB", which is a form of osteomyelitis. There is more serious TB, namely TB that is widespread and is referred to as disseminated TB, or usually known as Milier Tuberculosis. Among cases of extrapulmonary TB, 10% are usually Miliary TB. The main cause of TB disease is Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is a small non-motile aerobic bacillus. The various unique clinical characters of this pathogen are due to its high fat/lipid content. The cells divide every 16 –20 hours. This cleavage speed is slow when compared to other types of bacteria which generally divide every less than an hour. Mycobacteria have an outer lipid bilayer. When a Gram stain test is performed, MTB will show a weak "Gram-positive" stain or show no color at all due to the high content of fat and mycolic acid in its cell wall. MTB can withstand weak disinfectants and can survive dry conditions for weeks. In nature, the bacteria can only grow within the host cells of certain organisms, but M. tuberculosis can be cultured in the laboratory. By using histological stains on expectorated sputum samples, researchers can identify MTB under ordinary (light) microscopy. (Phlegm is also called "sputum"). MTB retains its color even though it has been treated with an acid solution, so it can be classified as an Acid Resistant Bacillus (BTA). The two most common types of acid staining techniques are: the Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique, which will give the AFB bacteria a bright red color when placed on a blue background, and the auramin-rhodamine staining technique then viewed under a fluorescent microscope.

The M. tuberculosis complex (KMTB) also includes other mycobacteria that also cause TB: M. bovis, M. africanum, M. canetti, and M. microti. M. africanum is not widespread, but is an important cause of tuberculosis in parts of Africa. M. bovis is a common cause of tuberculosis, but the introduction of pasteurized milk has succeeded in eradicating this type of mycobacteria which has been a public health problem in developing countries. M. canetti is a rare species and seems to only occur in the Horn of Africa, although cases have been found in groups of African emigrants. M. microti is also a rare strain and is often found in immunodeficient individuals, however, this pathogen may be more common than we think. Other known pathogenic mycobacteria include M. leprae, M. avium, and M. kansasii. The last two types fall into the classification of "non-tuberculous mycobacteria" (MNT). MNT does not cause TB or leprosy, but it does cause other TB-like lung diseases. There are several factors that cause why people are more susceptible to TB infection. At the global level, the most important risk factor is HIV; 13% of all TB cases were also infected with the HIV virus. This problem is common in sub-Saharan Africa, where HIV rates are high. Tuberculosis is closely related to overcrowding and malnutrition. This linkage makes TB one of the main diseases of poverty. People who are at high risk of becoming infected with TB include: people who inject illegal drugs, residents and employees of places where vulnerable people congregate (for example, prisons and homeless shelters), poor people who do not have access to adequate health care adequate, high-risk ethnic minorities, and health workers serving these people.

Chronic lung disease is another important risk factor. Silicosis increases the risk up to 30 times greater. People who smoke have a two times greater risk of getting TB than those who don't smoke. The presence of certain diseases can also increase the risk of developing tuberculosis, including alcoholism/alcohol addiction and diabetes mellitus (the risk triples). Certain drugs, such as corticosteroids and infliximab (anti-αTNF monoclonal antibody) are also risk factors of increasing importance, especially in the developing world. Although genetic susceptibility can also play a role, researchers have not yet explained to what extent this plays a role. When someone with active pulmonary TB coughs, sneezes, talks, sings, or spits, they are spraying droplets of infectious aerosol with a diameter of 0.5 to 5 µm. Sneezes can release up to 40,000 tiny particles. Every droplet can transmit tuberculosis because the infectious dose of this disease is very low. (A person who inhales less than 10 bacteria alone can become infected immediately). People who are in contact for a long time, frequently, or are always in close proximity to TB sufferers, are at high risk of becoming infected, with an estimated infection rate of around 22%. A person with active TB and not receiving treatment may infect 10-15 (or more) other people each year. Usually, only those with active TB can transmit the disease. People with latent infection are not believed to transmit the disease. The likelihood of this disease being transmitted from one person to another depends on several factors. These factors include the number of infectious drops sprayed by the carrier, the effectiveness of ventilation of the living environment, the duration of exposure, the level of virulence of the M. tuberculosis strain, and the level of immunity of the uninfected person. To prevent multiple person-to-person spread, isolate people with active ("overt") TB and put them on anti-TB drug regimens.

After about two weeks of effective treatment, people with active, non-resistant infections usually stop transmitting the disease to others. If it turns out that someone is infected, it usually takes three to four weeks for the newly infected person to become infectious enough to transmit the disease to other people. About 90% of people infected with M. tuberculosis have asymptomatic latent TB infection, (sometimes called LTBI/Latent TB Infections). Throughout life, these people have only a 10% chance of their latent infection developing into overt active TB disease. The risk of TB in people living with HIV developing into active disease increases by about 10% each year. If not given effective treatment, the active TB mortality rate can reach more than 66%. TB infection begins when mycobacteria enter the alveoli of the lungs, then invade and replicate in the endosomes of alveolar macrophages. The primary site of infection in the lungs, known as a "Ghon focus", is in the upper part of the lower lobe, or in the lower part of the upper lobe. Pulmonary tuberculosis can also occur through a bloodstream infection known as Simon's focus. Simon's focus of infection is usually found at the top of the lung. Hematogenous (through blood vessels) transmission can also spread to other locations such as peripheral lymph nodes, kidneys, brain and bones. Tuberculosis affects all parts of the body, although it is not known why it rarely affects the heart, skeletal muscle, pancreas or thyroid. Tuberculosis is classified as a disease that causes granulomatous inflammation. Cells such as macrophages, T lymphocytes, B lymphocytes, and fibroblasts combine to form granulomas. Lymphocytes surround the infected macrophages. Granulomas prevent the spread of mycobacteria and provide a special environment for local cell-cell interactions within the immune system.

The bacteria inside the granuloma become dormant and then become a source of latent infection. Another feature of granulomas is the formation of abnormal cell death (necrosis) in the center of the tubercles. Viewed by the naked eye, necrosis has a smooth, cheesy white texture and is called caseous necrosis. TB bacteria can enter the bloodstream from the area of ​​damaged tissue. The bacteria then spread throughout the body and form multiple foci of infection, which appear as small white tubercles in the tissue. This very severe TB disease is called miliary tuberculosis. This type of TB is most common in children and people with HIV. The fatality rate for people with disseminated TB like this is quite high despite receiving treatment (about 30%). In many people, these infections often come and go. Tissue destruction and necrosis are often balanced by rapid healing and fibrosis. The infected tissue turns into a scar and the cavities are filled with the caseous necrotic material. During the active period of the disease, some of these cavities also enter the bronchial airways and the necrotic material may be coughed up. This material contains live bacteria and can spread infection. Treatment using appropriate antibiotics can kill these bacteria and make way for the healing process. When the disease has healed, the infected area turns into scar tissue. It is very difficult to diagnose active tuberculosis based on signs and symptoms alone. It is also difficult to diagnose the disease in people who are immunosuppressed. However, people who show signs that they have lung disease or constitutional symptoms that last more than two weeks may have contracted TB. A chest X-ray and multiple sputum cultures for acid-fast bacilli are usually a part of the initial evaluation.

Interferon-γ release tests (IGRAs) and tuberculin skin tests are not optimally applied in the developing world. IGRA has similar drawbacks when applied to HIV sufferers. The correct diagnosis of TB is made when the bacterium “M. tuberculosis” found in clinical samples (eg, sputum, pus, or tissue biopsy). However, the culture process for this slow-growing organism takes two to six weeks for blood and sputum cultures alone. Therefore, treatment is often started before culture results are complete. Nucleic acid amplification tests and adenosine deaminase tests can more quickly diagnose TB. However, this test is not routinely recommended because it rarely changes the way sufferers are treated. Blood tests to detect antibodies are not very specific or sensitive, so this test is also not recommended. The Mantoux tuberculin skin test is often used as a screening tool for someone at high risk of TB. People who have been previously immunized may give a false positive test result. Test results can give false negatives in people with sarcoidosis, Hodgkin's Lymphoma, and malnutrition. Most importantly, test results can be false-negative in people who have active tuberculosis. Interferon gamma release assays (IGRAs) for blood samples are recommended in people with a positive Mantoux test result. IGRAs are not affected by immunizations or most environmental mycobacteria, so they result in fewer false-positive tests. However they were influenced by “M. szulgai,” “M. marinum,” and “M. kansasii.” IGRAs can increase sensitivity when used as an adjunct to a skin test. But IGRAs are less sensitive than skin tests when used alone. Efforts to prevent and control tuberculosis depend on vaccinating infants and detecting and treating active cases.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has had some success with improvised treatment regimens, and there has been a small reduction in the number of cases. Since 2011, the only vaccine available is bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG). Although BCG is effective against childhood disseminated disease, there is inconsistent protection against pulmonary tuberculosis. However, it is the most commonly used vaccine in the world, with over 90% of children getting vaccinated. After all, the immunity generated would wane after about ten years or so. Tuberculosis is not common in most of Canada, the United Kingdom, and the United States, so BCG is only given to people at high risk. One reason this vaccine is not used is that it causes the tuberculin skin test to give a false positive, and so the test is not helpful in screening for disease. New types of vaccines are still being developed. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared TB a "global health emergency" in 1993. In 2006, the Stop TB Partnership developed a Global Stop Tuberculosis Plan movement aimed at saving 14 million people by 2015. This targeted number is unlikely to be reached in in 2015, largely due to the increase in HIV sufferers with tuberculosis and the emergence of multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).The tuberculosis classification developed by the American Thoracic Society is generally used in public health programs.Because TB germs are everywhere including in malls, offices and of course also in hospitals, so the most effective prevention is a lifestyle to support our body's resistance: TB treatment uses antibiotics to kill the bacteria. Effective TB treatment is difficult due to its chemical structure and composition. mycobacterial cell walls that do not normal.

The cell wall prevents the drug from entering, making the antibiotic ineffective. The two types of antibiotics commonly used are isoniazid and rifampicin, and treatment can take months. Treatment of latent TB usually uses a single antibiotic. Active TB disease should be treated with a combination of several antibiotics to reduce the risk of developing antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Patients with latent infection are also treated to prevent the emergence of active TB in later life. WHO recommends directly observed therapy or direct supervision therapy, in which a health supervisor supervises the patient taking the medicine. The aim is to reduce the number of sufferers who do not take their antibiotics properly. Evidence supporting direct supervised therapy independently is lacking. However, the method of reminding sufferers that treatment is important turns out to be effective. The 2010 recommendation for the treatment of new cases of pulmonary tuberculosis is a six-month course of a combination of antibiotics. Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for the first two months, and only rifampicin and isoniazid for the next four months. If resistance to isoniazid is high, ethambutol can be added for the last four months as an alternative. If tuberculosis recurs, do a test to determine which type of antibiotic is sensitive before deciding on treatment. If multiple drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) is detected, treatment with at least four types of effective antibiotics is recommended for 8–24 months. Primary resistance occurs when a person is infected with a resistant strain of TB. A person with susceptible TB may develop secondary (acquired) resistance during therapy. A person can also experience the development of resistance due to inadequate treatment, if the drug prescribed is not used properly (because of non-adherence), or because the drug used is of low quality. TB with drug resistance is a serious public health problem in developing countries.

Treatment for drug-resistant TB will take longer and require more expensive drugs. MDR-TB (Multiple Drug Resistance-TB) is often defined as resistance to the two most effective first-line TB drugs: rifampicin and isoniazid. Extensively drug-resistant TB is also resistant to three or more of the six classes of second-line drugs. Total drug-resistant TB is resistance to all types of drugs that have been used so far. TB with total drug resistance was first discovered in 2003 in Italy, but this was never reported until 2012. Nowadays there is a tendency to find out in advance whether it is really the TB bacteria or other bacteria that infects it and which drugs still work. , therefore it is necessary to do a bacterial culture before treatment. In 2007, WHO recommended using liquid media for TB bacterial culture to be more accurate and take up to 40 days. Progression from TB infection to overt TB disease occurs when bacilli overcome the immune system's defenses and begin to multiply. In primary TB disease (accounting for 1–5% of cases), this development occurs soon after the initial infection. However, in most cases, a latent infection occurs without obvious symptoms. These dormant germs produce active tuberculosis in 5–10% of these latent cases, and generally do not appear until many years after infection. The risk of reactivation is increased as a result of immunosuppression, such as that caused by HIV infection. In people who are also infected with “M. tuberculosis” and HIV, the risk of reactivation increases by up to 10% per year. Studies using DNA prints from the “M. tuberculosis” demonstrated that reinfection led to TB recurrence more frequently than expected.

Re-infection can account for more than 50% of cases where TB is common. The probability of dying from tuberculosis was approximately 4% in 2008, down from 8% in 1995. Approximately one third of the world's population has been infected with “M. tuberculosis.” One new infection appears every second on a global scale. However, most infections by “M. tuberculosis” does not cause TB disease, and 90–95% of infections remain asymptomatic. In 2007, there were an estimated 13.7 million chronic active cases. In 2010, there were 8.8 million new cases of TB diagnosed, and 1.45 million deaths, most of these in developing countries. Out of all 1.45 million deaths, around 0.35 million occurred in sufferers who were also infected with HIV. Tuberculosis is the second most common cause of death caused by infection (after death by HIV/AIDS). The exact number of tuberculosis cases ("prevalence") has decreased since 2005. New tuberculosis cases ("incidence") have decreased since 2002. China in particular has shown remarkable progress. China has reduced its death rate from TB by nearly 80% between 1990 and 2010. Tuberculosis is more common in developing countries. Approximately 80% of the population in various Asian and African countries tests positive for tuberculin, but only 5–10% of the population in the US tests positive. Experts hope that TB can be fully controlled. However, a number of factors make TB control impossible. An effective vaccine is very difficult to develop. It is very expensive and time consuming to diagnose the disease. Treatment takes several months. More people infected with HIV have TB. Drug-resistant TB emerged in the 1980s.

In 2007, the country with the highest estimated incidence rate was Swaziland, with 1,200 cases per 100,000 people. India has the largest total incidence, with an estimated 2.0 million new cases. In developed countries, tuberculosis is not common and is mostly found in urban areas. In 2010, the TB rates per 100,000 people in various parts of the world were: in the world 178, Africa 332, America 36, ​​Eastern Mediterranean 173, Europe 63, Southeast Asia 278, and the West Pacific 139. In Canada and Australia, tuberculosis is often more common among aboriginal people, especially in remote areas. In the United States, Aborigines experience a five times greater mortality rate from TB. The incidence of TB varies according to age. In Africa, it primarily affects the population between the ages of 12 and 18 and young adults. However, in countries where incidence rates have fallen sharply (such as the United States), TB is generally a disease of older people and those with susceptible immune systems. Tuberculosis has existed in human life since ancient times. The earliest detection of “M. tuberculosis” has evidence of the disease in bison carcasses dating to about 17,000 years ago. However, it is not certain whether tuberculosis originated in bovines, which were then transmitted to humans, or whether tuberculosis is a branch of a common ancestor. Scientists believe that humans contracted MTBC from animals during the domestication process. However, the “Micobacterium tuberculosis” complex (MTbC) gene in humans has been compared to MTbC in animals, and this theory has been disproved. Strains of the tuberculosis bacterium share a common ancestor, which has actually been able to infect humans since the Neolithic Revolution.

The skeletal remains show that prehistoric humans (4000 BC) had TB. Researchers found tuberculous decay in the spina bones of Egyptian mummies from 3000–2400 BC. “Phthisis” comes from the Greek for “consumption,” which is the ancient term for pulmonary tuberculosis. Around 460 BC, Hippocrates identified that phthisis was the most contagious disease at that time. People with phthisis have a fever and cough up blood. Phthisis is almost always fatal. Gene studies show that TB was present in America from about 100 AD. Before the Industrial Revolution, folklore often associated tuberculosis with vampires. If a family member dies of TB, the health of the other family members of the infected person slowly declines. People believe that the first person who gets TB drains the souls of other family members. The type of pulmonary TB associated with tubercles was defined as a pathology by Dr Richard Morton in 1689. However, TB has a wide range of symptoms, so TB was not identified as a single disease until the late 1820s. TB was not named tuberculosis until 1839 by J. L. Schönlein. During 1838–1845, Dr. John Croghan, owner of Mammoth Cave, brought those affected by TB into the cave in hopes of curing the disease with the constant temperature and purity of the air in the cave: they died after one year in the cave. Hermann Brehmer opened the first sanatorium in 1859 in Sokołowsko, Poland. The bacillus that causes tuberculosis, “Mycobacterium tuberculosis,” was identified and described on March 24, 1882 by Robert Koch. He received the Nobel Prize in physiology or medicine in 1905 for this discovery. Koch did not believe that tuberculosis in cattle (livestock) and humans was the same disease.

This belief delays the recognition that infected milk is the source of the infection. Later, the risk of transmission from this source was greatly reduced due to the invention of the pasteurization process. Koch announced a glycerin extract from tuberculosis bacilli as a "cure" for tuberculosis in 1890. He called it "tuberculin." Although "tuberculin" is ineffective, it has been adapted as a screening test for the presence of presymptomatic tuberculosis. Albert Calmette and Camille Guérin had their first successful anti-tuberculosis immunization in 1906. They used attenuated bovine strains of tuberculosis, and the vaccine was named BCG (Calmette and Guérin bacillus). The BCG vaccine was first used in humans in 1921 in France. However, the BCG vaccine only became widely accepted in the US, UK and Germany after World War II. Tuberculosis raised public concerns in the 19th and early 20th centuries as an endemic disease of the urban poor. In 1815, one in four deaths in England was caused by "consumption." In 1918, one in six deaths in France was caused by TB. After scientists determined the disease was contagious in the 1880s, TB was made a reportable disease in England. The campaign was started so that people stop spitting in public places and the poor infected with the disease are "encouraged" to enter a sanatorium that resembles a detention center. (A sanatorium for the upper middle class offers exceptional care and continual medical checkups.) The sanatorium was supposed to provide "clean air" and employment benefits. Yet even under the best conditions, 50% of the patients in them died after five years (“ca.” 1916). In Europe, tuberculosis rates began to increase in the early 1600's. TB case rates peaked in Europe in the 1800s when the disease accounted for nearly 25% of all deaths.

The mortality rate then decreased to almost 90% in the 1950s. Public health improvements significantly reduced tuberculosis rates even before streptomycin and other antibiotics were introduced. However, the disease is still a serious threat to public health. When the Medical Research Council was formed in England in 1913, its initial focus was tuberculosis research. In 1946, the development of the antibiotic streptomycin resulted in an effective treatment and cure for TB. Before the introduction of this drug, the only treatment (with the exception of sanatoriums) was surgical intervention. The “pneumothorax technique” collapses the infected lung and provides a “pause” so that the tuberculosis-induced lesions begin to heal. The emergence of MDR-TB has again made surgery a standard treatment option for TB infection. Current surgical interventions include removal of the cavity (“bullae”). ") pathologically in the lungs to reduce bacterial counts and increase drug exposure for bacteria still present in the bloodstream. This intervention simultaneously reduces the total bacterial count and increases the effectiveness of systemic antibiotic therapy. Although experts expect TB to be completely eradicated (compare smallpox), the emergence of drug-resistant strains in the 1980s made eradication of TB difficult. The resurgence of tuberculosis led to the WHO's declaration of a global health emergency in 1993. The World Health Organization and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation subsidized rapid diagnostic tests that new (fast-acting diagnostic test t) for use in low- and middle-income countries. Since 2011, many poor places only have access to sputum microscopy (examination of sputum using a microscope). In 2010, India had the highest number of TB cases in the world. One reason is poor disease management by the private health care sector. Programs such as the revised national TB control program are helping to reduce the number of TB among people receiving public health services.

Gopnik (Russian: го́пник; IPA: ˈɡopnʲɪk]) is a stereotype and subculture in Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, and in some countries of the former Soviet Union associated with lower-class young men from rural areas city ​​(usually Generation Z and Millennials) and come from low-income, educated families. The term for women is gopnitsa and those in groups are called gopota. The Gopnik subculture has its roots in the late Russian Empire, and flourished during the 20th century in many cities across the Soviet Union. By the late 2010s, the Gopnik subculture had largely faded, although young Gopnik-like gangs still exist in Russia and other Slavic countries. "Gopnik" most likely comes from the slang term for street-robbery: gop-stop (Russian: гоп-стоп). The term Gopnik can also be related to GOP, short for Gorodskoye Obshchestvo Prizreniya. The GOP were shelters for underprivileged people created by the Bolshevik Government after the October Revolution in 1917. According to Dahl's Ekalingual Dictionary, a monolingual dictionary of Russian (first published in the 19th century), an old slang word meaning "sleeping on the street". is "гопать" (literally "to gop") something related to the "mazuricks", or criminals of St. Petersburg. Gopniks are often seen crouching in groups "in the field" or doing crabstroke outside of blocks or schools with their heels on the ground. This behavior describes behavior learned from Russian prison culture to avoid sitting on the cold ground. Gopniks are often seen wearing Adidas or Puma tracksuits popularized by the Soviet Union team at the 1980 Moscow Olympics. Sunflower seeds are commonly eaten by gopniks, especially in Ukraine and Russia.

page editor logged out learn more Spices are the strong-aromatic or flavorful parts of plants that are used in small quantities in food as preservatives or flavorings in cooking. Spices are usually distinguished from other plants used for similar purposes, such as medicinal plants, flavorful vegetables, and dried fruit. Spices were the most valuable merchandise in precolonial times. Many spices used to be used in medicine, but now this is decreasing. Spices are one of the reasons why the Portuguese explorer Vasco Da Gama reached India and the Moluccas in Indonesia. These spices also caused the Dutch to follow them to the Moluccas. Meanwhile, the Spanish under the leadership of Magellan had already sought a way to the East by another route, namely through the Pacific Ocean and finally landed on the island of Luzon, Philippines. Some of the most important spice-producing regions in the world are India, Zanzibar, and the Maluku Islands. But most countries in the world import spices from India because India is the biggest spice center in the world. The spice trade in the Indian subcontinent began at least as early as 2000 BC (BC) with cinnamon and black pepper, while East Asians traded herbs and pepper. The practice of mummification and other needs of the Ancient Egyptians encouraged trade between countries. By 1000 BC, herb-based medical remedies were being used in China, Korea and India. In addition, spices were originally used for ritual, religious and traditional purposes. Cloves were already used by the Mesopotamians in 1700 BC. note 1] The ancient Romans used cloves in the first century AD, evidenced by the writings of Pilinius the Elder about this spice. The Ebers Papyrus is dated to 1550 BC. from Ancient Egypt describes eight hundred medical treatment procedures using herbs.

Indonesian traders traded spices, including nutmeg, to China, India, the Middle East, and the east coast of Africa, while Arab traders brought spices from the east to Europe for trade. This caused the City of Alexandria (Alexandria) in Egypt to become an important port city in the world's spice trade at that time. The discovery of monsoon winds caused trade routes to shift from those originally by land to sea routes. Spices were among the most expensive and desirable products of the Middle Ages, with the most common commodities being black pepper, cinnamon (and its alternative, cassia), cumin, nutmeg, ginger and cloves. Regarding the main theory in medieval medicine, humoralism, spices and herbs are considered important in balancing the "humor" in food. As well as their use in medieval medicine, the European elite also had a penchant for spices. One example is the King of Aragon who devoted a great deal of resources to bringing spices to Spain in the 12th century. He wasn't the only European monarch to look to spices for added wine. Most of the spices are imported from Asia and Africa so they are quite expensive. From the 8th to the 15th centuries, the Republic of Venice exercised a monopoly on the spice trade with the Middle East, along with the maritime republic and other cities in Italy. The trade made Venice and its environs rich. It is estimated that as much as 1,000 tons of pepper and 1,000 tons of other spices were imported into Western Europe during the Late Middle Ages. This commodity has a value equivalent to grain for 1.5 million people. :65 The most exclusive spice at that time was saffron which was used as a flavoring and food colorant. :15 The main function of spices is to flavor food.

Spices are also used as raw materials for cosmetic perfumes and incense. Since its initial discovery, spices have also become one of the important things in medical treatment. Expensive, rare, and exotic nature is often associated as a symbol of wealth and social class. Apart from providing aroma, taste and texture to food, spices also function as natural dyes which do not have side effects for humans. Some spices that function as natural dyes are saffron flowers, paprika, turmeric, and kesumba rivet. Saffron flowers contain active compounds, namely crocin and crocetin, which produce a natural yellow-orange color. The yellow-orange color is also produced from turmeric which contains curcuminoid color pigments with curcumin compounds. Kesumba rivet can also give a brick red color because the seeds contain a color pigment, namely the bixin compound. In America, peppers are also used as food coloring, such as orange juice, cheese, sauces, and egg yolks. However, the use of saffron as a coloring agent is very limited due to the high price of this spice. So that in some countries replace the use of saffron with safflower flowers as a coloring agent. There are popular claims that spices can be used to preserve food or hide the taste of spoiled meat. This claim dates back to the early 1500's, when there was no refrigerator technology to preserve food. In some countries like Greece, they use garlic to prevent food from spoiling. Likewise in India, using ginger, garlic, turmeric and cloves to preserve meat and fish. The process of mummification in ancient Egypt also used spices such as Sri Lanka cinnamon, white turmeric, and sarui cumin. In fact, spices are not nearly as effective at preserving food as salting, pickling, smoking, and drying, nor are they as effective at hiding the taste of spoiled meat.

In addition, the price of spices is quite expensive. In 15th century Oxford, a pig cost the equivalent of a pound of pepper, the cheapest spice at the time. :2-3 Michael Krondl in his book writes that "old cookbooks clearly point out that spices are not used as preservatives. They usually recommend adding spices at the end of the cooking process, which is not intended as a preservative." In the 16th century, Cristoforo in Messisbugo thought that the addition of pepper could actually accelerate decay. However, the use of spices as food preservatives will be more effective when combined with other types of spices. This is because the various microorganisms in each food make not all bacteria compatible with one type of spice. Spices also function as natural antimicrobial agents that can suppress bacterial growth. In previous studies, it was found that garlic solution was able to fight bacteria such as Escherichia Coli, Salmonella, Aeromonas hydrophila. This also applies to ginger extract which can kill Escherichia Coli bacteria. In addition, spices such as cloves, oregano, thyme, cinnamon, and cumin are also able to inhibit the growth of several types of bacteria. Starting from bacteria that cause spoilage in food such as Bacillus subtilis and Pseudomonas fluorescens, disease-causing bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus and Vibrio parahaemolyticus, to saprophytic fungi that cause disease in plants such as Aspergillus flavu. The ability of each type of spice is different in suppressing bacterial growth, because some types of spices are only able to work on certain bacteria. In a study conducted by Cornell University, it was found that only garlic, oregano and onions were able to kill all bacteria, while thyme, cinnamon, tarragon and cumin were only able to kill 80% of bacteria, chili only 75%, and for black pepper and white, ginger, anise and celery only up to 25%.

Therefore, the use of spices as antimicrobial agents will be more effective when combined with each other. Spices can be used by the body to fight free radicals and cancer. Spices contain compounds that can act as antioxidants, such as rosmanol in rosemary and sage, polyphenols in ginger, eugenol in cloves and others. These ingredients can slow down the oxidation process and protect cells from exposure to free radiation. In previous research, it was found that the use of rosemary-based essential oil was able to clean free radicals in the body as well as provide a therapeutic effect. There are several types of spices that have high antioxidant compounds, namely sage, rosemary, oregano, coriander, thyme and marjoram. The simplest tool for processing spices is a mortar and pestle. Currently, there are tools that are more energy-efficient, namely graters (for small quantities) or grinders (for large quantities). Some spices can also be ground by hand with the help of a special grinder. However, to maximize the taste characteristics of each spice, appropriate management methods are needed, such as chopping, grilling, frying, baking and so on. As in European and North American cultures, they boil cinnamon and coriander to bring out the distinctive flavors of these spices. Unlike the Indian culture, they use different techniques to bring out the flavors of each spice. Like cooking mustard/mustard seeds with the tempering method, where cooking with cooking oil is heated until very hot then the mustard seeds are added and fried. There is also a stir-fried technique for managing jalapenos. The difference in cooking methods is also based on the different characteristics of each spice. Because not all spices can be processed at high temperatures, there are also those that only need to be added when serving food, such as sesame seeds.

The taste of some spices comes from compounds (essential oils) that oxidize or evaporate when exposed to air. Ground spices can increase their surface area thereby increasing the rate of oxidation and evaporation. Thus, the taste of the spices is maximized by storing the spices intact and grinding them only when they are needed. Whole dry spices can be stored for about two years, while powdered spices and seeds can last for about six months. In addition to spoiling faster, the taste of powdered spices is much less durable. note 2] Spices should be stored in closed containers, protected from sunlight and high temperatures. This is so that the taste and aroma of the spices are not lost due to high temperatures and exposure to sunlight. In addition, temperatures that are too low also trigger changes in the characteristics of spices, such as color, aroma, and taste. Humidity that is too low can also trigger the appearance of bacteria in spices. Therefore, the best temperature for storing spices is between 10˚C to 15˚C with a relative humidity of around 55% to 60%. Some of the flavor elements of spices are readily soluble in water, while some are easily soluble in oil or fat. Generally, spices need time for their flavors to penetrate the food, so they should be added at the start of the cooking process. This is different from herbs which are added at the end of the process. A study conducted by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) of spice shipments to the United States in the 2007-2009 fiscal year found that approximately 7% of shipments were contaminated with Salmonella bacteria, some of which are resistant to antibiotics. Contaminated spices that are cooked before eating do not cause problems. However, some spices, such as pepper, are not cooked and can cause illness.

Editor's page out of the log learn more Feudalism is a delegation structure of sociopolitical power (social politic) that is run among the nobility/monarchy to control the various territories it claims through cooperation with local leaders as partners. In the original sense, this structure was embedded by historians in the political system in Europe in the Middle Ages, which placed knights and other noble classes (vassals) as rulers of certain areas or rights (called fiefs or, in Latin, feodum) appointed by monarchy (usually a king or lord). The term feudalism itself has been used since the 17th century and was never used by the actors themselves. Since the 1960s, historians have broadened the use of this term to include aspects of the social life of land workers on land controlled by landlords, giving rise to the term "feudal society". Because the use of the term feudalism has increasingly had a negative connotation, its critics now consider this term not helpful in clarifying the situation and are advised not to use it without clear qualifications. In everyday language use in Indonesia, this word is often used to refer to behaviors similar to those of tyrannical rulers, such as 'old-fashioned', 'always wanting to be respected', or 'holding on to old values ​​that have been many abandoned'. The ninth century in western Europe was a period of turmoil. Charlemagne had for some time created the integration of society that was the result of the invading Germanic peoples, and had united the warring tribes under a centralized government. But Charles magne's empire, as we have learned, did not last long. This empire broke up into several separate kingdoms. Charlemagne's successors in France, Germany, and Italy enjoyed little authority.

Editor page logged out learn more Hakka (Kèjiā 客家) are one of the largest Han Chinese groups in the People's Republic of China. The Hakka were the last Han group to migrate south from North China gradually from the 4th century AD due to natural disasters, wars, and conflicts. Migration of Hakka out of China also occurred on a large scale, so that now the Hakka community is spread across various provinces in China and countries around the world. The Hakka people are one of the largest Chinese groups outside of China. Initially, the term "Hakka" did not refer to any particular group. The term "to" (客) or "foreigners" first appeared in resident registration records during the Song dynasty to refer to migrants who had left their area and settled in different parts of the country. The term "Hakka" originates from the Cantonese term that first used it as an unfriendly term. Because they are present in the new environment, local people call them "Hakka" or "guests". This term was later accepted by the Hakka people as their group name. The origin of Hakka is still being debated by historians due to repeated migrations, while written historical records are not found. They have links with other Chinese subgroups that migrated to southern China. The displacement of the Han including Hakka from North China on a large scale occurred many times for various reasons such as wars or natural disasters. Historians conclude their migration was gradual. Some estimate that the earliest Hakka migration has occurred since the period of the Qin Dynasty, to be precise during the reign of Emperor Qin Shihuang, where there has been a large population movement from Zhong Yuan, the central land which is said to be the origin of the Chinese people, which now includes Henan, Shaanxi , Shanxi, Hebei and Shandong.

While others agree on the 4th century AD as the beginning. Foreign researchers such as Huntington and Campbell formulated the "3-wave displacement theory" which began in the 4th century AD. Meanwhile, D. Ball and E J Eitel in the late 19th century formulated the "5-wave theory" which was finally refined by Luo Xiang-lin to become the classical theory of Hakka migration. In the 17th century, the Qing dynasty government ordered the evacuation of residents from the coastal areas of Guangdong and Fujian to prevent piracy and smuggling by supporters of Zheng Chenggong, a servant of the Ming dynasty who had crossed into Taiwan. After Taiwan was conquered in 1863, the government withdrew the evacuation order, but few people returned to occupy the areas that had been vacated. Therefore, the government provides incentives for residents who occupy the area. This opportunity is used by people who come from areas that are overpopulated or affected by natural disasters. Most of them are Hakka people. Their arrival into populated areas has earned them the nicknames "Hakka" by the Punti or "Khek" by the Hoklo people, both of which mean "guest" or "newcomer". In the late Qing period, Hakka migration became more sporadic as a result of the defeat of the Taiping Rebellion led by the Hakka people against the Manchu government as well as conflict with the indigenous population in the Hakka-Punti War in Guangdong, causing thousands of Hakka refugees to migrate to Hainan, Taiwan, Southeast Asia, Hawaii and so on. . The identity that shows the main characteristics of Hakka, among others, is shown by the use of the Hakka language and Hakka traditions and culture. Hakka is not included in the 56 ethnic groups in China, thus the designation ethnicity, race, or nation is not appropriate. To complete this vague categorization, historians include the Hakka category within the "lineage" (minxi) of the Han people (Kejia Minxi).

At first the Hakka were often looked down upon by other Han groups and even considered to be less civilized because most of them were landless and poor. However, the Hakka people maintain their identity and history of origin from North China which is the center of Chinese culture, so they consider them pure Chinese who have inherited high civilization. The belief of origin from the north is firmly held by the Hakka people. Despite having moved and settled in various other areas of China, the Hakka people still retain their language and culture due to their habit of moving in large groups and settling together in new places to isolate themselves. In Southern China, the Hakka people were the last to arrive in other people's lands and often had to survive on infertile soil. They are looked down upon and not accepted thus forming a tenacious, courageous, persistent and steadfast nature. The conflict with the indigenous people caused them to become a community that has high solidarity and is closely related to each other. Men have heavy duties outside the home, while women work hard to take care of the house and fields. Unlike other groups of Chinese women, Hakka women refuse to tie their feet because it does not suit their role and work. Therefore, they are often ridiculed for their ugly and big legs. The main concept in electromagnetism is electromagnetic induction which is based on Faraday's law of induction. The principle of electromagnetism is applied to the working systems of transformers, inductors, electric motors, electric generators and solenoids. André-Marie Ampère was a French physicist, mathematician and chemist. Ampère discovered several important rules about electricity and magnetism which were then used as the basic concepts of electrodynamics and electromagnetism. He also made Ampere's law related to the electromagnet principle. The discovery of the laws of electrodynamics was the result of Ampère's follow-up to the experiment of current flowing near a compass conducted by Hans Christian Ørsted in 1820. Ørsted found that a compass needle moves if it is near a wire that is electrified. Ampère discovered that a coil behaves like a bar magnet when it is passed by an electric current. In addition, he found that the passage of electric current causes the soft iron in the coil to turn into a strong magnet and a force appears on two adjacent conductors. Ampère then made the laws of electrodynamics using mathematical equations. In addition, Ampère also made a galvanometer which was then used to measure electric current. Electrodynamics deals with the relationship between electromagnetism and mechanics. The focus of the concept of electrodynamics lies in the effects of electromagnetic fields on the mechanical properties of electrically charged particles. Electrodynamics forms the basis of very low-frequency instruments as well as in magnetotelluric devices and ground-penetrating radar. Electromagnetic induction is a symptom of the emergence of an electric current in an electric conductor due to a change in the magnetic field around the conductor.

The concept of electromagnetic induction is based on the discovery of Michael Faraday and Joseph Henry in 1831. A changing magnetic field produces a potential difference called an induced electromotive force and the resulting electric current is called an induced electric current. Alternating current is an electric current whose direction changes periodically. The alternating current curve is represented by a sinusoidal shape. The principle of electromagnetic induction is used as the basis for the formation of alternating currents. Faraday's law of induction states that an electric circuit has an induced electromotive force whose value is directly proportional to the speed of change of the magnetic flux surrounding it. The line of magnetic force enclosed by a certain area in a perpendicular direction is defined as the magnetic flux. In classical electrodynamic theory, the acceleration or deceleration of the movement of electrically charged particles will result in emission of electromagnetic waves. This phenomenon is called bremsstrahlung. The bremsstrahlung phenomenon is observed in the acceleration of electrons by applying an electric voltage of up to several tens of thousands of volts. The collision of the electrons on the metal surface will drastically reduce the speed of the electron movement. The enormous deceleration causes the electrons to emit electromagnetic waves. Certain solids can change when a certain force is applied and return to their original state when the force is removed. This property is called the elasticity of solids. Solids have a limit of elasticity. If the applied force is very large and exceeds the elasticity limit, the shape of the solid cannot return to its original state. The elasticity of a solid is determined by its constituent particles and is greatly influenced by electromagnetic forces. The elasticity of a solid can be observed in a thin sheet which can be turned into a wire by pulling. The interparticle elasticity in solids is observed in springs. Potential energy and kinetic energy will increase when the solid is heated.

The concentration of particles is very large as they approach the Earth's magnetic poles, so the intensity of the emission of electromagnetic waves is very high and can be observed with the eye. The phenomenon of the appearance of electromagnetic waves by the eye is called an aurora. The appearance of auroras that only occur around the poles is a real form of electromagnetism. Editor page logged out learn more Corpus Iuris Canonici Early Church Orders Collection of Ancient Canons Miscellaneous Holy Priesthood Eucharistic Confession Officer Juridical Persona A diocese or diocese is a term for the ecclesiastical territory or jurisdiction for several Christian denominations, which are regulated by a bishop. The Code of Canon Law (CRC) of the Roman Catholic Church defines a diocese as "that part of the people of God, which is entrusted to the bishop to care for with the cooperation of priests, in such a way that by following his pastor and united by him with the Gospel and the Eucharist in the Holy Spirit, forms a particular Church, in which the one, holy, catholic and apostolic Church of Christ is really realized and works." The diocese is a particular church in relation to the universal church headed by the Pope. Only the Pope has the authority to establish a diocese after hearing the reasons put forward by the bishops of the area. Generally a diocese is divided into smaller areas, called parishes, which are headed by a parish priest. All dioceses are led by a bishop, but a bishop does not necessarily lead a diocese. The bishop who presides over a diocese is called a diocesan bishop. Diocesan bishops are appointed and assigned to a diocese by the Pope, while he himself holds the position of Bishop of Rome. Meanwhile, a bishop who does not preside over a diocese is called a titular bishop. A titular bishop may be an assistant to the diocesan bishop (auxiliary bishop), a candidate for diocesan bishop (coadjutor bishop), or a former bishop (emeritus bishop) within a diocese. Within the Roman Catholic Church, there is a grouping of adjacent dioceses into an ecclesiastical province. Within this ecclesiastical province, a diocese is given the distinction of being the holder of the "metropolitan see", so that the diocese is also called "metropolis" or "metropolitan diocese", with its bishop being called the "metropolitan bishop".

The metropolitan see is the principal episcopal see (apostolic see of bishops) within the ecclesiastical province. However, this position actually does not have any power over other dioceses other than some special powers related to supervision of these dioceses. Generally, a metropolitan diocese is considered the same as an archdiocese. Dioceses that are not metropolitan dioceses within an ecclesiastical province are called "suffragan dioceses", with their bishops being called "suffragan bishops". The creation of metropolitan dioceses and ecclesiastical provinces aims to unite adjacent dioceses into a cluster, in order to care for people who are more or less similar in culture. Therefore, the formation of an archdiocese has nothing to do with the size of the territory or the maturity of the people's faith in general. Archdiocese is the term for the area of ​​the diocese headed by an archbishop. Archdioceses are generally formed from a bishopric by the Pope. The terms "archdiocese" and "archbishopric" are usually considered synonymous with "metropolitan diocese" and "metropolitan bishop", which is the holder of a metropolitan see (primary episcopal see) within an ecclesiastical province, although there are some exceptions, as noted in para. -the following paragraphs. For example, the Archdiocese of Jakarta which is a metropolitan diocese within the Ecclesiastical Province of Jakarta, which also consists of the Diocese of Bogor and the Diocese of Bandung. Although very rare, there are some that make the archdiocese a suffragan diocese within an ecclesiastical province. For example, the Archdiocese of Avignon and Aix are suffragan dioceses within the ecclesiastical province whose metropolitan see is held by the Archdiocese of Marseille. Both dioceses were originally metropolitan dioceses, but both were stripped of their metropolitan status in 2002 and merged into the Ecclesiastical Province of Marseille. In addition, there are also several archdioceses that do not form ecclesiastical provinces.

Outgoing editor page learn more Coordinates: 8°28′35″S 115°33′59″E﻿ / ﻿8.476383°S 115.566370°E﻿ / -8.476383; 115.566370 Tenganan Pegringsingan is a traditional village on the island of Bali. This village is located in Manggis District, Karangasem Regency in the east of the island of Bali. Tenganan can be reached from the Candi Dasa tourism area and is located approximately 10 kilometers from there. Tenganan Village is one of the three villages of Bali Aga, besides Trunyan and Sembiran. Bali Aga is a village that still maintains a lifestyle in which the community structure refers to the traditional rules of village customs passed down by their ancestors. The shape and size of the building and the yard, the arrangement of the location of the building, to the location of the temple are made according to customary rules which have been maintained from generation to generation. According to some versions of historical records, the word Tenganan comes from the word "middle" or "ngatengahang" which means "to move into a deeper area". The word relates to the movement of village people from the seaside area to residential areas in the middle of the hills, namely Bukit Barat (Bukit Kauh) and Bukit Timur (Bukit Kangin). Another history says that the people of Tenganan came from Peneges Village (now Candi Dasa), which at that time was still part of the Bedahulu Kingdom. According to folklore, King Bedahulu had lost one of his horses and people were looking for him to the east. The horse was found dead by Ki Patih Tunjung Biru, the king's confidant. For his loyalty, Ki Patih Tunjung Biru has the authority to regulate areas that have the scent of the horse's carrion. Ki Patih got quite a large area because he cut up the horse carcass and spread it as far as he could. That is the origin of the Tenganan Village area.

The population of Tenganan village as of 2016 consisted of 2,248 men and 2,379 women with a sex ratio of 94. Generally, residents of Tenganan village work as rice farmers, but some make various crafts. Some typical handicrafts from Tenganan are woven bamboo, carvings, and paintings on burnt palm leaves. In this village visitors can see village buildings and young craftsmen drawing lontars. Since long time ago, the people of Tenganan Village have also been known for their expertise in weaving gringsing cloth. The way gringsing cloth is made is called the double tie technique. This technique is the only one in Indonesia and the gringsing cloth produced is well-known to foreign countries. Tenganan residents still use the barter system in their daily lives. Daily life in this village is still governed by customary law called awig-awig. The law was written in the 11th century and updated in 1842. The Tenganan traditional house was built from a mixture of red stone, river stone and soil. While the roof is made of piles of rumbi leaves. Existing traditional houses have relatively the same shape and size, with a distinctive feature of the entrance which is only the size of one adult wide. Another feature is that the top of the door looks one with the roof of the house. The residents of this village have a unique tradition of recruiting potential village leaders, one of which is through the customary procession of mesabar-sabatan biu (banana war). Candidates for village leaders are educated according to local customs from childhood or gradually and these customary traditions are a kind of psychological test for prospective village leaders. On a predetermined date according to the local calendar system (around July) a ngusaba sambah will be held with a unique tradition of pandan mageret (pandan war).

Rickets is a disease that occurs in children in many developing countries, but if it is not handled properly it will have an impact into adulthood. The main cause is a deficiency of vitamin D, but a lack of adequate calcium in the diet can also cause rickets (severe cases of diarrhea and vomiting can be the cause of the deficiency). Although it can occur in adults, most cases occur in children suffering from malnutrition, usually as a result of starvation or starvation during the early stages of childhood. Osteomalacia is a term used to describe a similar condition occurring in adults, generally due to a deficiency of vitamin D. Osteomalacia is a condition in which bones cannot harden, so they are prone to bending or even breaking. The origin of the word "rakitis" may be from the Old English dialect word 'wrickken', to twist. The Greek word "rachitis" (ραχίτις, meaning "inflammation of the spine") was later adopted as the scientific term for rickets, primarily because of the words' similarity in sound. Changes in the skull also occur causing a distinctive "square headed" appearance. This defect persists into adult life if left untreated. Long-term consequences include permanent curvature or destruction of long bones, and curvature of the back. The main cause of rickets is a lack of vitamin D and health problems in absorbing nutrients. In addition, rickets is also caused by genetic disorders.

Rickets can be diagnosed with help: Treatment and prevention of rickets are known as antirachitics. If you are deficient in vitamin D, your doctor may prescribe vitamin D supplements or ask you to increase your intake of vitamin D, such as cereals, orange juice, fish and processed milk. In addition, the doctor will advise your child to bask in the sun every morning so that the bones become stronger and reduce the symptoms that arise due to rickets. Meanwhile, to correct the shape of a bent or unnatural bone, you usually have to use assistive devices or in rare cases, sufferers have to undergo bone repair surgery procedures so that they can become normal or at least better than before. Treatment involves increasing dietary intake of calcium, phosphate and vitamin D. Exposure to ultraviolet B light (sunlight when the Sun is highest in the sky), cod liver oil, halibut liver oil, and viosterol are all sources of vitamin D. Darker skinned babies need longer to be exposed to ultraviolet light. Vitamin D replacement has been shown to correct rickets using ultraviolet light therapy methods and drugs. The recommendation is to 400 international units (IU) of vitamin D per day for infants and children. Children who don't get adequate amounts of vitamin D are at increased risk of rickets. Vitamin D is essential for allowing the body to absorb calcium for use in proper bone calcification and maintenance. Adequate levels of vitamin D can also be achieved through dietary supplements and/or sun exposure.
