Editor page that has logged out learn more A computer is a tool used to process data according to a procedure that has been formulated. The computer is a hardware device that is closely related to technology. Computers can help a variety of human work. The word computer was originally used to describe people whose jobs were to perform arithmetic calculations, with or without assistive devices, but the meaning of this word was later transferred to the machine itself. Originally, information processing was almost exclusively related to arithmetic problems, but modern computers are used for many tasks not related to mathematics. In that sense there are tools such as the slide rule, mechanical calculators of all kinds from the abacus onwards, to all contemporary electronic computers. A better suitable term for a broad meaning such as "computer" is "information processing" or "information processing system." Over the years there have been several different meanings for the word "computer", and several different words are now referred to as computers. The word computer has generally been used to define a person who performs arithmetic calculations, with or without an auxiliary machine. According to the Barnhart Concise Dictionary of Etymology, the word was used in English in 1646 as the word for "one who counts" then before 1897 also used as "mechanical calculating device". During World War II the word referred to working women in the United States and Britain whose job it was to calculate the passage of war artillery with calculating machines. Charles Babbage designed one of the first calculating machines called the analytical engine. In addition, various simple machine tools such as slide rules can also be said to be computers. However, the definition above includes many specific tools that can only take into account one or a few functions.

When considering modern computers, the trait that most distinguishes them from earlier computing devices is that with proper programming, all computers can emulate any behavior (though perhaps limited by different storage capacities and speeds), and, indeed, it is believed that today's machines can emulate computing devices that humans will invent in the future (albeit slower). In a sense, this capability limit is a useful test because it recognizes "general-purpose" computers from earlier special-purpose devices. The definition of "general intent" can be formulated into the requirement that a machine must be able to emulate a universal Turing Machine. Machines that get this definition are known as Turing-complete, and the first ones appeared in 1940 amid a flurry of developments around the world. See the computer history article for more details on this period. About 20 years ago, many household devices, especially video game consoles as well as mobile phones, video cassette recorders, PDAs and myriad other household, industrial, automotive, and other electronic devices, all contained electronic circuitry like a fully qualified computer. Turing-complete above (with the caveat that the programming of these devices is often built directly into the ROM chip which will need to be replaced to change the machine programming). Another special purpose computer is generally known as a "microcontroller" or "embedded computer". Therefore, many restrict the definition of a computer to devices whose primary purpose is information processing, rather than being part of a larger system such as a telephone, microwave oven, or airplane, and which can be modified for various purposes by the user without physical modification. Mainframe computers, minicomputers, and personal computers (PCs) are the main types of computers that receive this definition.

A personal computer or personal computer (PC) is a term for a computer that is known to many people in general, so many people are not familiar with other forms of computers other than personal computers. Only certain people use this term exclusively to indicate a more specific and precise term. Personal computers were first introduced in Indonesia in 1980 by the late Eddy Liew, founder of Dragon Computer & Communication through the Sinclair brand from England. While the technology used in digital computers has changed dramatically since the first computers in the 1940s (see History of computing hardware for more detail), most computers still use the Von Neumann architecture, proposed in the early 1940s by John von Neumann. . The Von Neumann architecture describes a computer with four main parts: the Arithmetic and Logical Unit (ALU), the control unit, memory, and input and output devices (collectively called I/O). These sections are connected by bundles of wire, the "bus." In this system, memory is a sequence of numbered bytes (such as a "cell" or "pigeon hole"), each containing a small piece of information. This information can be commands to tell the computer what to do. Cells can contain data that the computer needs to perform a command. Each slot can contain any one, and what is now data may then become commands. A memory storing various forms of information as binary numbers. Information that is not yet in binary form will be encoded with a number of instructions that turn it into a number or sequence of numbers. For example: The letter F is stored as the decimal number 70 (or binary number) using one of the split methods. More complex instructions can be used to store images, sound, video, and various kinds of information.

Information that can be stored in one sell is called a byte. In general, memory can be rewritten over a million times - a memory can be compared to a blackboard and chalk that can be written on and erased again, rather than a notebook with an indelible pen. The size of each cell, and the number of cells, changed greatly from computer to computer, and the technology in memory creation has changed greatly - from electromechanical relays, to tubes filled with mercury (and later springs) in which acoustic pulses are generated, to the permanent magnet matrix, to individual transistors, to integrated circuits with millions of transistors on a single silicon chip. The Central Processing Unit's role is to process commands given by computer users, manage them together with the data on the computer. The processing unit or device will also communicate with input, output and storage devices to carry out interrelated instructions. In the original von Neumann architecture, it describes an Arithmetic and Logic Unit, and a Control Unit. In modern computers, these two units are located on a single integrated circuit (IC - Integrated Circuit), which is usually called the CPU (Central Processing Unit). Arithmetic and logic units, are tools that perform basic implementations such as arithmetic execution (addition, subtraction, and the like), logical execution (AND, OR, NOT), and comparison execution (for example, comparing the contents of two slots for equality). It is on this unit that the actual "work" is performed. The control unit stores the current command performed by the computer, instructs the ALU to execute and retrieves the information (from memory) needed to carry out that command, and moves the results back to the appropriate memory location. This unit functions to control the reading of computer program instructions.

I/O allows the computer to obtain information from the outside world, and put its work there, which can be physical (hardcopy) or non-physical (softcopy). There are various kinds of I/O devices, from the familiar keyboard, monitor and disk drive, to more unusual ones such as webcams (web cameras, printers, scanners, and so on. What all common input devices have in common is that they encode (convert) information of some kind into data that can be further processed by a digital computer system. This field arose in the Hellenistic period in the 3rd century BC from the use of geometry to study astronomy. Trigonometry is easy to relate to in the field of right triangles (with the result that the sum of the two acute angles equals the measure of the right angles). There is also a role for other than right triangles. Since a triangle that is not a right triangle can be divided into two right triangles, many problems can be solved by calculating right triangles. Because of this, most uses of trigonometry relate to right triangles. One exception to spherical trigonometry, namely trigonometry studies in spheres or surfaces of positive relative curvature in elliptical geometry (parts that play a role in astronomical discoveries and navigation). Trigonometry in negative curvature is part of hyperbolic geometry. The beginnings of trigonometry can be traced back to Ancient Egypt and Babylon and the Indus Valley civilization, more than 3000 years ago. The Indian mathematician was a pioneer in calculating algebraic variables which are used to calculate astronomy as well as trigonometry. Lagadha was the only mathematician known today to use geometry and trigonometry for astronomical calculations in his Vedanga, Jyotisha, most of his work destroyed by Indian colonists. The Greek mathematician Hipparchus around 150 BC compiled trigonometry tables to solve triangles. Another Greek mathematician, Ptolemy around the year 100 developed trigonometric calculations further. The Silesian mathematician Bartholemeus Pitiskus published an influential work on trigonometry in 1595 and introduced the word into English and French. If one of the angles is 90 degrees and the other angles are known, then a third angle can be found, because the three angles of a triangle add up to 180 degrees.

Therefore two angles (those less than 90 degrees) add up to 90 degrees: these are complementary angles. There are many applications of trigonometry. Primarily it is a triangulation technique used in astronomy to calculate distances to nearby stars, in geography to calculate between specific points, and in satellite navigation systems. Other fields that use trigonometry include astronomy (and includes navigation, at sea, air and space), music theory, acoustics, optics, analysis of financial markets, electronics, probability theory, statistics, biology, medical imaging (CAT scan and ultrasound), pharmacy, chemistry, number theory (and thus cryptology), seismology, meteorology, oceanography, various branches of physics, land surveying and geodesy, architecture, phonetics, economics, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, civil engineering, computer graphics, cartography, crystallography. In the 3rd century AD, astronomers first recorded the lengths of the sides and angles of a right triangle between each of the related sides: this is it, if at least one of the side lengths and one of the angle values ​​is known, then all angles and lengths can be determined algorithmically. These calculations are defined as trigonometric functions and are now commonplace in both pure and applied mathematics: for example to analyze basic methods such as the Fourier transform or wave equations, using trigonometric functions to understand phenomena relating to circles through many uses in fields as diverse as physics, engineering machinery and electricity, music and acoustics, astronomy, and biology. Trigonometry also has a role in finding surveying. There is a modern development of trigonometry which involves "spread" and "quadrance" instead of angles and lengths. This new approach is called rational trigonometry and is the work of Dr. Norman Wildberger of the University of New South Wales. Further information can be found on its website.

Aristotle divided philosophy into four issues, namely logic, physics, metaphysics and practical knowledge. Analysis of philosophy is done using a syllogism. During this time, he became a student of Plato who wrote many dialogues. Aristotle developed his own philosophical system at this time. Aristotle believed that abstractions form categories that can be applied to objects of thought. Man transcends physics when he begins to think while making observations. During thinking, the human mind escapes from observations that use the senses to feel everything that can be felt by its existence. General knowledge is then known from particular and real things. Physics knowledge is then formed through abstract knowledge and human reason. Furthermore, the abstraction of mathematics enables humans to understand invisible matter. Reason detaches itself from everything that can be understood. All the material characteristics of this abstraction then produce science. Aristotle argued that the method of discovering new knowledge and truth is divided into two. First, the inductive method and the second is the deductive method. In Greek mythology, Aegis (Greek: Αιγίς), as described in the Iliad, was a shield belonging to the goddess Athena or the god Zeus, which, according to Homer, was made by Hephaestus: Virgilus relates that the Cyclops in Hephaestus' workshops were "busily polishing the worn by Athena when she was angry--it was a fearsome thing with a golden surface like the scales of a snake, and the shield connected the snake and the Gorgon on the goddess' chest, as the stumps head rolled her eyes." The shield is decorated with gold strands and has a Gorgoneion (Medusa's head) in the center. Some Attic vase painters adopted the Archaic tradition that the string was originally a snake. When Athena was born, she brought Aigis with her. When the Olympian gods shook Aigis, Mount Ida was covered in clouds, thunders shook and people were filled with fear. "Zeus carrying Aigis", as mentioned in the Iliad, is sometimes credited with lending the shield to Athena.
