Editor page out log learn more Lutetium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Lu and atomic number 71. Lutetium is a white and silver mixed metal that is resistant to corrosion and a rare earth product. Lutetium is the hardest and densest metal in the lanthanide group, which is located in the last column of the group on the periodic table. Lutetium was first discovered in 1907 by Baron Carl Auer von Welsbach, Georges Urbain, and Charles James while each of them was conducting research in different locations. They examined a mineral thought to consist purely of ytterbium, but in the end it was discovered that this mineral was also a combination of lutetium and several other chemical elements. Because Georges Urbain took the swift step to publicize his discovery, the naming of the chemical element lutetium was chosen and officially recognized globally. Lutetium has the atomic number 71 and the electron configuration Xe] 4f145d16s2. Lutetium is resistant to corrosion and is a mixture of white and silver in color. The atomic mass of lutetium is large compared to its size, so it has high boiling and melting points. Actually, the electrons of the element lutetium do not completely fill the d orbitals, but they are still classified as lanthanides because they have physical and chemical characteristics that are very similar to the 14 other chemical elements of the lanthanide group. Lutetium has 59 isotopes, but only two are stable, namely Lu-175 and Lu-176. 97.41% of the total lutetium found on earth is Lu-175, while only 2.59% is Lu-176. Although less abundant and radioactive, elemental Lu-176 can last for 4x1010 years.

Editor page logged out learn more – in Europe   (green & gray)– in the European Union (green) Italy ( Italy (help·info)), officially the Republic of Italy (Italian: Repubblica Italiana), is a country unitary parliamentary republics in Europenote 1] Located in the heart of the Mediterranean Sea. Italy is bordered by France, Switzerland, Austria, Slovenia, San Marino and the Vatican. Italy covers an area of ​​301,338 km² (116,347 mi²), and is influenced by a temperate and Mediterranean climate. Judging from its shape, the map of Italy is shaped like a boot or in Italy it is often called lo Stivale. With a population of 61 million people, Italy is the third most populous European Union member state after Germany and France. Since the Classical Era, Italy has been inhabited by various nations and civilizations. Like the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, and ancient Greeks who settled in southern Italy, the Etruscans and Celts inhabited central and northern Italy, and Ancient Italic and Italic tribes scattered throughout the Italian Peninsula and Insular Italy (Sardinia and Sicily). . The Italic tribes or known as the Latins formed the Roman Empire which eventually became a republic which managed to conquer and assimilate other nearby civilizations. Rome eventually emerged as the dominant power in the Mediterranean basin, successfully conquering most of the ancient world and becoming the leading cultural, political and religious center of Western civilization. The legacy of the Roman Empire is widespread and can be seen in the global distribution channels of civil law, republican government, Christianity and Latin writing. During the Middle Ages, Italy experienced sociopolitical collapse amid costly barbarian invasions, but in the 11th century many Italian city-states and maritime republics rose to prosperity through shipping, commerce, and banking, laying the foundations for modern capitalism.

Independent statelets,note 2] which acted as Europe's principal trade center with Asia and the Near East, enjoyed a greater degree of democracy and wealth than the feudal monarchies that were consolidating across Europe at the time. Most of Central Italy remained under the control of the theocratic Papal States, while Southern Italy was feudal until the 19th century, as a result of a succession of Byzantine, Arab, Norman, Spanish and Bourbon conquests in the region. The Renaissance started in Italy and spread across Europe, bringing with it new interests in humanism, science, exploration and art. During this time Italian culture flourished, and produced famous scholars, artists and polymaths such as Leonardo da Vinci, Galileo, Michelangelo and Machiavelli. Also famous Italian explorers such as Marco Polo, Christopher Columbus, Amerigo Vespucci and Giovanni da Verrazzano discovered new routes to the Far East and the New World, which aided the European Age of Exploration. However, Italy's commercial and political power diminished with the opening of the Atlantic trade route and the route to the Indian Ocean via the Cape of Good Hope across the Mediterranean. Again, the Italian city-states engaged in bloody wars, culminating in the Italian Wars of the 15th and 16th centuries, which eventually exhausted them, with no one emerging as the dominant force. The weakened rulers soon fell victim to the conquests of European powers such as France, Spain and Austria. In the mid-19th century, a movement arose to support Italian nationalism and independence from foreign control. This movement led to a revolutionary political upheaval called the Risorgimento to unite the countries in Italy. After many failed attempts, the Italian War of Independence and the Thousand Expedition finally unified the countries of Italy in 1861, and are now a major power after centuries of foreign domination.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the New Kingdom of Italy was rapidly industrializing, especially in the north, and colonial kingdoms, while the south remained largely impoverished and excluded from industrialization, sparked a large and influential diaspora. Despite being a major player in World War I, Italy experienced a period of economic crisis and social turmoil, leading to the rise of the fascist dictatorship in 1922. Subsequent participation in World War II on the Axis side ended in military defeat, economic collapse, and civil war Italy. After liberation and rising resistance, Italy abolished the monarchy and restored democracy, enjoyed a prolonged economic boom, was free from sociopolitical turmoil (eg, Anni di Piombo, Mani pulite, Second Mafia War, Maxi Experiment and assassination of anti-mafia officials) and became a state main forward. Currently, Italy has the third largest economy in the Eurozone and the eighth largest in the world. It has a very high level of human development and is ranked sixth in the world for life expectancy. The country plays an important role in regional and global economic, military, cultural and diplomatic affairs, and is a regional power and great power. Italy is a founder and leading member of the European Union and a member of various international institutions such as the UN, NATO, OECD, OSCE, WTO, G7/G8, G20, Union for the Mediterranean, European Assembly, Uniting for Consensus and many others. As a reflection of its rich culture, Italy is home to 51 World Heritage Sites, is the most numerous, and is the fifth most visited country in the world. The assumptions of "Italian" etymology are numerous, and the collection of solutions proposed by historians and linguists is extensive. According to one of the more common explanations, the term Italia, from Latin: Italia, was borrowed via Greek from the Oscan Víteliú meaning "land of calves" (compare: Latin vitulus "calf", Umbrian vitlo "calf") .

The bull or cow was once a symbol of the tribes of southern Italy, and was often depicted goring a Roman wolf as a symbol of reluctance to give up Italian independence during the Social Wars. The Greek historian Dionysios of Halikarnassus states a treatise together with the legend that Italy was named in honor of Italus as mentioned by Aristotle, and Thucydides. The name Italia was originally used only for the area now called Southern Italy, according to Antiochus of Syracuse, the southern part of the Bruttium Peninsula (now Calabria, Province of Reggio, and part of the Province of Catanzaro and Province of Vibo Valentia). But it was during Antioch's time that Enotri and Italia became synonymous, and this name also applies to most of Lucania. The Greeks gradually applied the name "Italy" to a wider area, but it was during the reign of Emperor Augustus (late 1st century BC) that the term was extended to include the entire peninsula up to the Alps. Excavations throughout Italy have revealed the presence of Neanderthals who have existed since the Paleolithic era, approximately 200,000 years ago, Modern humans were present approximately 40,000 years ago. The ancient peoples of pre-Roman Italy – such as the Umbrians, Latins (from which the Romans flourished), Volscians, Samnites, Celts and Ligurians who inhabited northern Italy, and many others – were Indo- Europe; The main historical peoples that do not belong to Indo-European are the Etruscans, the Elimi people, the Sikani people of Sicily and the prehistoric Sardinians. Between the 17th and 11th centuries BC the Mycenaean Greeks established contact with Italy and in the 8th and 7th centuries BC Greek colonies were established along the coast of Sicily and the southern part of the Italian Peninsula became known as Great Greece.

Also the Phoenicians established colonies on the coasts of Sardinia and Sicily. Ancient Rome was originally a small agricultural community founded in about the 8th century B.C., which grew over the centuries into a splendid empire encompassing the entire Mediterranean region, in which the cultures of Ancient Greece and Ancient Rome merged into one civilization. This civilization is quite influential and its legacy can be felt throughout the world. Ancient Rome was immensely influential to, and left its mark on government, law, politics, administration, cities, engineering, philosophy, architecture, and modern art, laying the foundation for Western civilization. A slow decline since the late 2nd century AD, the empire eventually split into two parts in 395 AD: the Western Roman Empire and the Eastern Roman Empire. The western half – under pressure from the Franks, Vandals, Huns, Goths and other peoples of Eastern Europe – finally broke apart in AD 476, when the last Western Roman emperor was overthrown by the Barbarian leader Odoacer. After the fall of Rome, Italy was conquered by Germanic tribes (Ostrogoths), but in the 6th century the Eastern Roman/Byzantine Emperor (Justinian) conquered it. Invasions of other Germanic tribes (namely the Lombards) late in the same century narrowed the Byzantine presence to just a single land strip of Ravenna and Rome, plus other landmasses in southern Italy, destroying the unity of the Italian peninsula until 1870. The Lombard rulers in the north and center Italy was absorbed into the Frankish Empire by Charlemagne in the late 8th century. The Frankish kings also helped establish the Papal States in central Italy, extending from Rome to Ravenna, although for most of the Middle Ages the Papacy effectively controlled only Latium. The existence of this theocratic state spanned centuries of unification of the peninsula.

Until the 13th century, Italian politics were dominated by the relationship between the German Holy Roman Emperors and the popes with most Italian cities siding either to the former (Ghibellini) or to (Guelfi) for momentary convenience. During this power vacuum Italy saw the emergence of an unusual institution, the medieval commune. In the anarchic conditions that often prevailed in medieval Italian city-states, societies set themselves apart to restore order and disarm the feuding elites. In the 12th century, a league of communes, the Lombard League, conquered the German emperor, Frederick Barbarossa, and became the starting point for the process of granting effective independence to most of the cities of northern and central Italy. Despite the devastation caused by the various wars, Italy maintained, especially in the north, and center, a more developed urban civilization. During the same period, Italy saw the emergence of several maritime republics, the most notable of which were the Republic of Venice, the Republic of Genoa, the Republic of Pisa and the Republic of Amalfi. Involved in several Crusades, they took advantage of both commercial and political opportunities. Venice, and Genoa soon after became Europe's main gateways for trade with the East, establishing colonies as far as the Black Sea, and often controlling most of the trade with the Eastern Roman Empire (Byzantine) and the Islamic Middle East. The county of Savoy expanded into the peninsula in the Late Middle Ages, while Florence developed into a highly organized trading and financial city-state, and became the European capital of silk, wool, banking, and jewelry. In the south, Byzantine Sicily became an Islamic emirate in the 9th century, which flourished until the Italo-Normans conquered it in the late 11th century along with most of the Lombard and Byzantine states in southern Italy.

Through a complex series of events, southern Italy developed as a unified kingdom, first under the House of Hohenstaufen, then under the Capetians of Anjou and from the 15th century, the House of Aragon (although Sicily was a separate kingdom of the Aragonese from the late 19th century). 13th to 15th centuries). On Sardinia, the former Byzantine provinces became independent states known as giudicati (territories of judges), although most of the island was under Genoese and Pisan control until the Aragonese conquest of it in the 15th century. The pandemic Black Death in 1348 left its mark on Italy killing a third of the population. However, recovery from the Black Death sparked a revival of cities, commerce, and an economy that so powerfully stimulated the stages of Humanism and the Renaissance, the cultural movements that were both born on this peninsula and then spread throughout Europe. In the 14th and 15th centuries, central and southern Italy was divided into a number of warring city-states, while the rest of the peninsula was ruled by Naples and the larger Papal States. The strongest of these city-states annexed the surrounding territories giving birth to signoria, ie regional states ruled by merchant families who founded local dynasties. Dominated by a merchant oligarchy, they enjoyed artistic advancement, maintained academies, and relative freedom. Wars between states in the region were common, invasions from outside Italy confined to the sporadic attacks of the Holy Roman Emperors. These wars were fought primarily by merchant armies known as Condottiere, collections of soldiers from all over Europe, but especially Germany and Switzerland led by Italian captains.

Decades of war had seen the Republic of Florence, Duchy of Milan and the Republic of Venice grow as the dominant players in agreeing to the Treaty of Lodi in 1454, which saw relative calm reign in the region for the first time in centuries. This peace lasted for the next forty years and Venice's undisputed hegemony over the seas also led to an unprecedented peace during the 15th century. The Italian Renaissance reached its peak in the mid-16th century when foreign invasions plunged the region into the turmoil of the Italian Wars. However, Renaissance ideas and ideals persisted, and even continued to spread to the rest of Europe, inspiring the Northern and English Renaissance. Meanwhile, Christopher Columbus's Discovery, the Portuguese discovery of new routes to Asia, and the rise of the Ottoman Empire—all factors that eroded traditional Italian dominance in trade with the East—began to undermine the peninsula's economy. After the Italian Wars (1494-1559), Italy witnessed a relatively long period of peace, first under Habsburg Spain (1559-1713), and then under Habsburg Austria (1713-1796). Plague repeatedly returned to haunt Italy in the 14th to 17th centuries. In the first half of the 17th century, a plague is claimed to have killed 1.7 million people, or about 14% of Italy's population. When Spain went into decline in the 17th century, so did its Italian colonies, namely Naples, Sicily, Sardinia, and Milan. Southern Italy experienced decline, stagnation and a break with important events in Europe. Nevertheless, Italy continues to contribute to European culture, by giving birth to the Baroque Style. In the 18th century, as a result of the War of the Spanish Succession, Austria replaced Spain as the dominant foreign power, while the House of Savoy grew as a major regional power extending into Piemonte and Sardinia.

In this century, the ideas of the Enlightenment influenced Italian rulers, paving the way for reforms that initiated economic recovery in Tuscany and northern Italy. During the Napoleonic Wars, the northern and central parts of the country were occupied, then partly annexed to the Empire, and partly constituted as a new Kingdom of Italy—actually a client state of the French Empire—while the southern half of the peninsula was administered by Joachim Murat , brother-in-law of Napoleon, who was crowned King of Naples. In 1814 the Congress of Vienna restored the situation at the end of the 18th century, but the ideals of the French Revolution could not be erased. The establishment of the Kingdom of Italy was the result of efforts by Italian nationalists and royalists loyal to the House of Savoy to establish a unified state covering all of the Italian peninsula. In the context of the 1848 liberal revolutions that swept across Europe, a war that Austria failed to declare. The Kingdom of Sardinia again attacked the Austrian Empire in the Second Italian War of Independence in 1859, with assistance from France, resulting in the liberation of Lombardy. In 1860–1861, Giuseppe Garibaldi led the reins toward unification in Naples and Sicily, allowing the Sardinian government led by Camillo Benso to declare a unified kingdom of Italy on March 17, 1861. In 1866, Viktor Emmanuel II allied with Prussia in the Austrian War -Prussia, fought in the Third Italian War of Independence which allowed Italy to annex Venice. Finally, when France, in the Franco-Prussian War of 1870, abandoned its garrison in Rome, the House of Savoy swiftly filled the power vacuum by taking over the Papal States. The Statute of Albertino Sardinia of 1848, extended to the whole of the Kingdom of Italy in 1861, provided for fundamental liberties, but the electoral law excluded the affluent and uneducated classes from elections.

The new royal government took place within a parliamentary constitutional monarchy dominated by liberals. In 1913, the suffrage age for men was adopted. While Northern Italy was rapidly industrializing, the Southern Italian regions and the Northern countryside were still undeveloped, and experiencing overpopulation, this situation forced millions of people to emigrate, while the Italian Socialist Party grew stronger, challenging the conservative and liberal-traditional establishment. Since the last two decades of the 19th century, Italy developed into a colonial power by forcing Somalia, Eritrea, and later Libya and the Dodecanese under its rule. During World War I, Italy was initially impartial, but in 1915 it signed a secret agreement, namely the Treaty of London, entering into the Triple Entente with the terms of receiving Trento, Trieste, Istria, and Dalmasia from Austria-Hungary—as well as parts of the Ottoman Empire. During World War I, more than 650,000 Italian soldiers died and the economy collapsed. Under several peace agreements, namely the Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1919), Treaty of Rapallo (1920), and Treaty of Rome (1924), Italy acquired most of the promised territory, including the Hungarian port of Fiume, but not Dalmasia (except Zara ), allowed nationalists to define this triumph as a "truncated triumph". The upheaval after the devastation of World War I, inspired by the Russian Revolution, led to chaos and chaos. Fearing a socialist revolution, the established liberals began to support the National Fascist Party led by Benito Mussolini. In October 1922 the fascists attempted a coup ("Mars in Rome"), supported by King Viktor Emmanuel III. A few years later, Mussolini banned all political parties and curtailed individual liberties, in other words he imposed a dictatorship. In 1935, Mussolini invaded Ethiopia, resulting in international alienation, and leading to Italy's withdrawal from the League of Nations.

Consequently, Italy allied with Nazi Germany, and the Empire of Japan, and strongly supported Franco in the Spanish Civil War. In 1939, Italy occupied Albania, a de facto protectorate for decades and joined World War II in June 1940 on the side of the Axis Powers. Like the Blitzkrieg, Hitler's actions in Poland, and France, Mussolini wanted immediate glory in attacking Greece in October 1940, but was forced to accept an embarrassing stalemate after several long months. At the same time, after conquering British Somaliland and parts of Egypt, the Italians saw an Allied counterattack which led to the loss of their possessions in Africa. Italy was attacked by the Allies in July 1943, which resulted in the collapse of the Fascist regime and the downfall of Mussolini. In September 1943, Italy surrendered. The country remained a battlefield for the next few battles, as the Allies advanced from the south while the north was a base for Italian fascists, and German Nazi armies, also being fought by the Italian resistance movement. Hostilities ended on 2 May 1945. Nearly half a million Italians (including civilians) died as a result of the conflict and the Italian economy was devastated; per capita income in 1944 was the lowest since the beginning of the 20th century. Italy became a republic after a successful constitutional referendum which was held on 2 June 1946, a day that would later be celebrated as Republic Day. It was also the first time that Italian women were allowed to have their voices heard. The son of Viktor Emmanuel III, namely Umberto II, was forced to abdicate and exiled. The Constitution of the Republic was passed on January 1, 1948. Under the 1947 Paris Peace Agreement, most of Venice Giulia fell to Yugoslavia, and after that, the Free Territory of Trieste was divided between the two countries.

Fears of the Italian electorate of a possible Communist takeover proved crucial to the first universal suffrage electoral outcome on April 18, 1948, when the Christian Democrats, under the leadership of Alcide De Gasperi, won a landslide victory. As a consequence, in 1949 Italy became a member of NATO. The Marshall Plan helped revive the Italian economy, which, until the late 1960s, enjoyed a period of sustained economic growth known as the "Economic Miracle". In 1957, Italy was a founding member of the European Community (EEC), the forerunner of the European Union (EU) in 1993. From the late 1960s to the early 1980s, the country experienced a Hot Lead Period, a period characterized by economic crises. (especially after the 1973 oil crisis), widespread social conflict and terrorist massacres carried out by opposition extremist groups with the alleged involvement of US intelligence. The Tin Hot period culminated in the assassination of the Christian Democrat leader, Aldo Moro, in 1978, and in the massacre at the Bologna train station in 1980, in which 85 people died; this event deeply affected all of Italy. In the 1980s, for the first time since 1945, two governments were led by prime ministers who were not Christian Democrats: the first liberal (Giovanni Spadolini) and the second socialist (Bettino Craxi); but the Christian Democrats were still the main government party. During Craxi's reign, the economy recovered, and Italy became the world's fifth largest industrial nation, able to enter the G7 group. However, as a result of his policies, Italy's national debt ballooned during Craxi's time, exceeding 100% of GDP. In the early 1990s, Italy faced a significant challenge, when voters – disillusioned by political paralysis, massive public debt and a widespread system of corruption (known as Tangentopoli), exposed by the 'Clean Hands' investigation – sued radical reform.

The scandals involved all major parties, especially those in the governing coalition: the Christian Democrats, who were in power for nearly 50 years, underwent several crises, and actually even disbanded, splitting into several factions. The Communists recast their power as a Social Democratic force. During the 1990s and 2000s, a coalition of the centre-right (dominated by media magnate Silvio Berlusconi) and the centre-left alternated to govern the country, which entered a prolonged period of economic stagnation. Italy is located in Southern Europe and consists of the boot-shaped Italian Peninsula, and a number of islands including the two largest, Sicily and Sardinia. Italy is located between 35°N, and 47°N, and 6°E, and 19°E. The total area of ​​the country is 301,230 km², of which 294,020 km² is land, and the remaining 7,210 km² is water. Including its islands, Italy has a total coastline, and border of 7,600 km; namely the Adriatic Sea, Ionian Sea, Tyrrhenian Sea (740 km), and the borders with France (488 km), Austria (430 km), Slovenia (232 km) and Switzerland (740 km); and San Marino (39 km), and Vatican (3.2 km), both of which are enclaves. The Apennines form the backbone of the peninsula, and the Alps form the border in the north, where Italy's highest point is located at Mont Blanc (4,810 m).note 3] The Po River, the longest river in Italy (652 km), flows from the Alps on the western border with France, and across the Po Valley to the Adriatic Sea. The five largest lakes by size are: Lake Garda (367.94 km²), Lake Maggiore (212.51 km², shared with Switzerland), Lake Como (145.9 km²), Lake Trasimeno (124.29 km²), and Lake Bolsena (113.55 km²). The country is located at the meeting point of the Eurasian Plate and the African Plate, causing a lot of earthquake and volcanic activity.

There are 14 volcanoes in Italy, four of which are still active: Mount Etna (the traditional site of the mythological blacksmith Vulcan), Stromboli, Vulcano and Vesuvius. Vesuvius is the only active volcano on the Continent and is most famous for the disasters it created, Pompeii and Herculaneum. Several islands and hills have been formed by volcanic activity and there is still a large active caldera, namely Campi Flegrei to the north-west of Naples. Although the country includes the Italian Peninsula and most of the southern Alpine basin, some of Italy's territory extends beyond the Alpine basin and several islands lie outside the Eurasian continental shelf. The areas referred to are the communes: Livigno, Sesto, San Candido, Dobbiaco (part), Chiusaforte, Tarvisio, Curon Venosta (part), all of which form part of the Danube basin, while Val di Lei includes part of the Rhine basin, and the island of Lampedusa, and Lampione is included in the shelf of the African continent. After its rapid industrial growth, Italy has been dealing with environmental problems for a long time. After several improvements, Italy is now ranked 84th in the world for its ecological sustainability. National parks cover about five percent of the country's area. In the last decade, Italy has become one of the world's leading producers of renewable energy, ranking the world's 4th largest in terms of installed solar energy capacity, and the 6th largest wind energy capacity holder in the world in 2010. Renewable energies now contribute approx. 12% of total final, and primary energy consumption in Italy, with a future target spread of 17% for 2020. Despite this, air pollution remains a serious problem, especially in the more industrialized northern regions, ranking 1st 10th in the world in terms of industrial carbon dioxide emissions in the 1990s.

Italy is the 12th largest producer of carbon dioxide. Traffic congestion and congestion in the largest metropolitan areas continues to cause environmental damage and exacerbated health issues, although smog levels have decreased dramatically since the 1970s and 1980s, and its presence is becoming an increasingly rare phenomenon. and sulfur dioxide levels decreased. There are many waterways, and the coast is also polluted by industrial and agricultural activities, while due to rising sea levels, Venice has experienced regular flooding in recent years. Waste discharged from industrial activities does not always meet legal standards, and has caused permanent health impacts on residents in affected areas, as in the case of the Seveso disaster. The country also operated several nuclear reactors from 1963 to 1990, but after the Chernobyl Disaster, and the 1987 referendum the nuclear program was discontinued, a decision overturned by the government in 2008, which planned the construction of up to four nuclear power plants, with French technology. . This in turn was hit by a referendum following the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. Deforestation, illegal building developments, and poor land management policies have led to significant erosion throughout Italy's mountainous regions, and triggered major ecological disasters such as the 1963 Vayon Dam flood, the 1998 Sarno, and the 2009 Messina landslide. The climate in Italy is very diverse, influenced by the shape of the large, longitudinal, and mostly mountainous peninsula. In much of the northern, and central interior, the climate ranges from humid subtropical to wet continental, and oceanic climates. In particular, the climate in the geographic region of the Po Valley is continental, with harsh winters and hot summers.

The coastal areas of Liguria, Tuscany and most of southern Italy generally conform to the Mediterranean climate stereotype (Köppen climate classification Csa). Conditions in the coastal areas of the peninsula can be very different from the highlands and valleys in the interior, especially in winter when the highlands tend to be colder, damper and often snowy. Coastal areas have mild winters, and generally warm, dry summers, although the lowland valleys can be quite hot in summer. The average winter temperature varies from 0°C in the Alps to 12°C in Sicily, while in summer it varies from 20°C to 30°C or more. Italy has been a unitary parliamentary republic since 2 June 1946, when the monarchy was abolished by a constitutional referendum. The President of the Italian Republic (Presidente della Repubblica), now Giorgio Napolitano since 2006, is the head of state of Italy. The president is elected to carry out a single mandate for seven years by the Italian Parliament in a joint session. Italy has a written democratic constitution, as a result of the work of a Constituent Assembly which was formed by representatives of all the anti-fascist forces that contributed to the defeat of the Nazis, and the Fascists in the civil war. Italy has a parliamentary government based on a proportional voting system. The Italian Parliament is a perfectly bicameral parliament: its two chambers, the House of Representatives (which meets in the Palazzo Montecitorio), and the Senate of the Republic (which meets in the Palazzo Madama), have equal powers. The Prime Minister, officially President of the Council of Ministers (Presidente del Consiglio dei Miniistri), is the head of government of Italy. The Prime Minister, and cabinet are appointed by the President of the Republic, but must pass a vote of confidence in Parliament to take office. While its functions are similar to most other parliamentary systems, the Italian Prime Minister has less authority than some of his counterparts.

The prime minister is not vested with the power to request the dissolution of Parliament or dismiss ministers (which are the exclusive prerogative of the President of the Republic), and must receive a vote of approval from the Council of Ministers—which holds effective executive power—to carry out most of its political activities. Following the resignation of Silvio Berlusconi on November 12, 2011, the economist Mario Monti has been appointed as the technocratic Prime Minister. The four largest political parties in Italy are the People of Freedom, the Democratic Party, the League of the North and Italia dei Valori. In the 2008 general election these four parties won 590 of the 630 seats available in the House of Representatives, and 308 of the 315 seats available in the Republican Senate. Most of the remaining seats were won by smaller parties that only contest elections in parts of Italy, such as the South Tyrolean People's Party, and the Movement for Autonomy. Nonetheless, over the last three years, a camp also called the "Third Pole" has begun to grow, namely the UDC Christian Democrat coalition with some dissenting MPs from Berlusconi's cabinet. The peculiarity of the Italian Parliament is that a portion of the representation is allocated to Italian citizens living abroad: 12 Deputies, and 6 Senators are elected in four different overseas constituencies. In addition, the Italian Senate is also characterized by a small number of senators for life, who are appointed by the President "for outstanding heroic merit in the social, scientific, artistic or literary field". The former President of the Republic is a senator for life ex officio (because of his position). On February 22, 2014, Matteo Renzi was appointed Prime Minister of Italy, he replaced Enrico Letta. The former mayor of Florence is Italy's youngest prime minister at the age of 39.

He was appointed by President Giorgio Napolitano at the presidential palace in Rome. On 31 January 2015, Matteo Renzi elected Sergio Mattarella as the 12th President of Italy, replacing Giorgio Napolitano. Previously Mattarella was a constitutional justice of the Province of Sicily. The Italian judicial system is based on Roman law modified by the Napoleonic statutes, and more recent statutes. The Supreme Court of Cassation is the highest court in Italy, for both criminal and civil appeal cases. The Italian Constitutional Court (Corte Costituzionale) played a role in the harmonization of laws to the constitution, and was a breakthrough after World War II. Since their emergence in the mid-19th century, Italian organized crime and criminal organizations have infiltrated the social and economic life of many areas of Southern Italy, the most egregious being the Sicilian Mafia, which later expanded to several other countries, including the United States. . The mafia's income may be up to 9% of Italian GDP. A report from 2009 identified 610 communes with such a strong mafia presence, where 13 million Italians live, and 14.6% of Italy's GDP is generated. The 'Ndrangheta of Calabria, today perhaps the most powerful crime syndicate in Italy, accounts for 3% of the country's GDP. However, at 0.013 per 1,000 people, Italy is only the 47th highest number of murders (in a group of 62 countries), and the 43rd highest number of rapes per 1,000 people worldwide ( in a group of 65 countries), a relatively low figure for developed countries. Italy is a founding member of the European Community, now the European Union (EU), and of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). Italy has been a member of the United Nations since 1955, and it is also a member and a strong supporter of a number of other international organizations, such as the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), GATT/World Trade Organization (WTO), Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), the European Assembly, and the Central European Initiative.

Italy holds rotating leadership in several international organizations, among them the Conference for Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE), the predecessor of the OSCE, in 1994; G8; and the European Union in 2009, and from July to December 2003. Italy strongly supports multilateral international politics, advancing the United Nations, and international security activities. Italy sent troops to support UN peacekeeping missions in Somalia, Mozambique and East Timor, and provided support to NATO and UN operations in Bosnia, Kosovo and Albania. Italy has deployed more than 2,000 troops in Afghanistan in support of Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF) since February 2003. Italy is still supporting international efforts to rebuild, and stabilize Iraq, but withdrew its military contingent of 3,200 troops in November. 2006, and only retained humanitarian officers, and other civilian personnel. In August 2006 Italy sent approximately 2,450 troops to Lebanon for the UNIFIL peacekeeping mission. The Italian Army, Navy, Air Force and Military Police are all part of the Italian Armed Forces, under the command of the Supreme Defense Council, headed by the President of the Italian Republic. Since 2005, military service has become completely voluntary. In 2010, the Italian military had 293,202 active personnel, of whom 114,778 were in the Military Police. Italy's total military spending in 2010 was ranked 10th in the world, at US$ 35.8 billion, or equal to 1.7% of national GDP. As part of NATO's nuclear sharing strategy Italy is also home to 90 United States nuclear weapons, which are housed at Ghedi Air Base, and Aviano Air Base. The Italian Army has 109,703 personnel in 2008.

Its best known combat vehicles are the Dardo infantry fighting vehicle, the Centauro tank destroyer, and the Ariete tank, and among its aircraft is the Mangusta attack helicopter, recently used in a United Nations mission. The Italian Army also has many Leopard 1s, and the M113 armored personnel carrier. The Italian Navy in 2008 had 35,200 active personnel with 85 ships commissioned, and 123 aircraft. The Italian Navy is now equipping itself with a larger aircraft carrier (Cavour), destroyers, submarines and multi-purpose frigates. In modern times, the Italian Navy, being a member of NATO, has taken part in many coalition peacekeeping operations around the world. The Italian Air Force in 2008 had 43,882 active personnel, and operates 585 aircraft, including 219 fighter jets, and 114 helicopters. As a replacement for leased Panavia Tornado ADV interceptors, the Italian Air Force has leased 30 F-16A Block 15 ADF, and four F-16B Block 10 Fighting Falcons, with an option for more. The following years will also see the introduction of 121 Eurofighter Typhoons EF2000, which will replace the F-16 Fighting Falcons. The next possible updates are the IDS/IDT Tornado, and the AMX International AMX. The transport capability is guaranteed by 22 C-130J aircraft, and Aeritalia G.222, 12 of which are replaced by a new G.222 variant called the C-27J Spartan. An autonomous military corps, the Italian Military Police is the military police tasked with carrying out police functions within the military, and on the civilian population, as well as the other police forces in Italy. While the different branches of the Italian Military Police report to separate ministries for each of their individual functions, the corps reports to the Ministry of the Interior when maintaining security and public order.

Italy is divided into 20 regions, five of which have special autonomous status which allows them to enact legislation concerning some of their local affairs. The country is further divided into 110 provinces, and 8,100 communes. Only the Aosta Valley Region has one province. There are also 15 metropolitan cities (città metropolitane), established in 2009, but this zoning is not yet operational. Italy has a market economy characterized by a high GDP per capita, and low unemployment. In 2010, Italy was the 8th largest economy in the world, and the 4th largest in Europe in terms of nominal GDP, and the 10th largest economy in the world, and the 5th largest in Europe in terms of purchasing power parity. Italy is a founding member of the G8, the Eurozone and the OECD. After World War II, Italy transformed rapidly from an economy primarily based on agriculture into one of the most industrialized countries, and a leading country in terms of international trade. Italy is a developed country, with the 8th highest quality of life in the world in 2005, and the 24th Human Development Index in the same year. Despite the recent global economic crisis, Italy's per capita GDP (spending power balance) remains close to the European Union average, while the unemployment rate (8.5%) is the lowest in the European Union. The country is well known for its influential, innovative business economy sector, for its industrial character, and for its competitive agricultural sector (Italy is the world's largest wine producer), and for its creative, high-quality clothing, equipment, industrial, automotive design. . According to IMF statistics for 2010, the sectoral distribution of GDP in 2010 was dominated by the service sector, amounting to 73.3%; followed by industry at 24.9%; and agriculture by 1.8%.

Italy has a relatively small number of global multinational companies compared to other economies of its size, but there are a large number of Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) which are clustered in several industrial districts, and form the backbone of Italian industry. These SMEs produce a manufacturing sector that is often focused on exporting niche markets, and luxury products, which if on the one hand are less able to compete on that quantity, on the other hand are better able to deal with competition from China, and emerging Asian economies. , based on low labor costs, with high quality products. The country was the 7th largest exporter in the world in 2009. Italy's closest trade ties are with the rest of the European Union, which accounts for approximately 59% of its total trade. The EU's largest trading partners, in terms of market share, are Germany (12.9%), France (11.4%) and Spain (7.4%). Ultimately, tourism is one of the lucrative, and fastest growing sectors of the national economy: with 43.6 million international tourists arriving, and total receipts estimated at $38.8 million in 2010, Italy is the 5th most visited country, and highest tourism gain in the world. Despite these important achievements, the Italian economy is currently suffering from many problems. After strong GDP growth in the 5–6% per year range from the 1950s to the early 1970s, and a progressive slowdown in the 1980s and 1990s, the average annual growth performance in the most recent decade has been moderate. worse at 1.23% compared to the European Union's average annual growth rate of 2.28%. The stagnation of economic growth, and the political efforts to revive it with massive government spending since the 1980s onward, actually inflated the public debt which was quite serious.

According to the European Union statistics agency, Eurostat, Italy's public debt stood at 116% of GDP in 2010, ranking the 2nd largest debt ratio after Greece (by 126.8%). However, the largest chunk of Italian public debt is held by national subjects, a major difference between Italy and Greece. In addition, Italy's standard of living has a significant north-south gap. The average GDP per capita in the north far exceeds the European Union average, while many regions of Southern Italy fall far below. Italy is often called the sick man of Europe, characterized by economic stagnation, political instability, and problems associated with reform programs. More specifically, Italy suffers from structural weaknesses due to its geographical shape, lack of raw materials, and lack of energy resources: in 2006 the country imported more than 86% of its total energy consumption (99.7% solid fuel; 92.5% oil; 91% .2% natural gas and 15% electricity). The Italian economy has been weakened by a lack of infrastructure development, market reforms, and research investment, as well as a high public deficit. In terms of the 2008 Index of Economic Freedom, the country is ranked 64th in the world, and 29th in Europe, the lowest in the Eurozone. Italy still receives development assistance from the European Union every year. Between 2000 and 2006, Italy received €27.4 billion from the European Union. The country has an inefficient public service bureaucracy, poor protection of property rights, high corruption, heavy taxes, and public spending that accounts for half of national GDP. In addition, recent data show that Italy's spending on research and development in 2006 was equal to 1.14% of GDP, or below the European Union average of 1.84%, and the target of the Lisbon Strategy which advocated for 3% share of GDP for activities research and development.

According to Confesercenti, a major Italian business association, organized crime in Italy represents "the largest segment of the Italian economy", accounting for €90 billion in receipts or 7% of Italian GDP. In 2004 the transport sector in Italy generated revenue of 119.4 billion euros, employing 935,700 people in 153,700 companies. Regarding the national road network, in 2002 there were 668,721 kilometers of serviceable roads in Italy, including 6,487 kilometers of controlled access highways, owned by the state but managed by the private company Atlantia. In 2005, approximately 34,667,000 passenger cars (590 cars per 1,000 people) and 4,015,000 freight cars traveled on the national road network. The national railroad network, owned by the state, and managed by Ferrovie dello Stato, in 2003 of a total of 16,287 kilometers, 69 percent of which were electrified, and 4,937 locomotives and carriages passed on it. The national inland network of waterways covered 1,477 kilometers of navigable rivers and canals as of 2002. As of 2004 there were nearly 30 major airports (including two connecting Malpensa International Airport in Milan, and Leonardo da Vinci International Airport in Rome). , and 43 major ports (including the port of Genoa, the largest in Italy, and the second largest in the Mediterranean Sea). As of 2005 Italy maintains a civilian air fleet of approximately 389,000 units, and a merchant fleet of 581 ships. Italy's population is mostly religious, and speaks the same language but with diverse culture, economy, and politics. Italy has the fifth largest population density in Europe with 196 inhabitants per square kilometer. The indigenous minority group is small in number. Italy has 60,626,442 inhabitants according to municipal records (Anagrafe) as of 1 January 2011.

Its density, at 201 inhabitants per square kilometer, is denser than most of the countries of Western Europe. But the distribution of the population is not so evenly distributed. The most populous areas are the Po Valley (accounting for nearly half the national population), and the metropolitan areas of Rome and Naples, while large areas such as the Alpine highlands and the Apentines, Platon Basilicata, and the island of Sardinia are sparsely populated. Italy's population nearly doubled in the 20th century, but the pattern of growth has been highly heterogeneous due to massive migration from the rural South to the industrial North, a phenomenon which occurred as a result of the Italian economic miracle of the 1950s- the 1960s. Moreover, after centuries of net emigration, from the 1980s Italy has experienced massive immigration for the first time in modern history. According to the Italian Government, there were 4,570,317 foreign nationals in Italy as of January 2011. High fertility and birth rates lasted until the 1970s, after which they both began to decline dramatically, resulting in a rapid aging of the population. In the late 2000s, one in five Italians was over 65 years old. However, due to massive immigration in the last two decades, in recent years Italy has experienced significant birth rate growth. The total fertility rate has risen dramatically from 1.18 children per woman in 1995 to 1.41 per woman in 2008. The total fertility rate is expected to reach 1.6 - 1.8 in 2030. Italy has experienced mass emigration since the end of the 20th century -19 to the 1960s. In the period 1898-1914, the peak years of the Italian diaspora, almost 750,000 Italians emigrated each year.

This diaspora involves more than 25 million Italians, and is considered the largest mass migration today. As a result, more than 4.1 million people born in Italy now live abroad, while no less than 60 million people with full or partial Italian ancestry live outside Italy, mainly in Argentina, Brazil, the United States, Australia and Northern Europe. . The postwar economic miracle, ending long decades of poverty and emigration, included massive social changes such as a low birth rate, an aging population, and the consequent shrinking workforce. Under such circumstances, starting from the late 1970s, Italy began to receive an influx of immigrants from abroad. The current figure is approximately 4.6 million foreigners, approximately 7.5% of the total population, including more than half a million children born in Italy to second-generation immigrants, but does not include foreigners gradually applying for citizenship Italy; this applies to 53,696 people in 2008. The official figures also do not present illegal immigrants, whose number is very difficult to determine; they are estimated at no less than 670,000. Since the fall of the Berlin Wall and, most recently, the expansion of the European Union in 2004 and 2007, the main waves of migration have been from former socialist countries of Eastern Europe (notably Romania, Albania, Ukraine and Poland). The second most important area of ​​immigration to Italy was North Africa (notably, Morocco, Egypt and Tunisia), with arrivals increasing as a result of the rise of the Arab world. Furthermore, in recent years, increasing migration flows have been recorded from the Far East (mainly, China, and the Philippines), and Latin America (Ecuador, Peru). Today, approximately one million Romanians (or 10 percent of them are Roma) are officially registered as living in Italy, representing the most important country of origin, followed by Albanians, and Moroccans, with 500,000 each. .

The number of unregistered Romanians is difficult to estimate, but the Balkan Inquiry Reporting Network suggests that in 2007 there may have been half a million or more. note 5] Overall, by the end of the 2000s the foreign-born Italian population was of: European origin (54 %), Africa (22%), Asia (16%), America (8%), and Oceania (0.06%). The distribution of immigrants is uneven in Italy: 87% of immigrants live in the north, and center of the country (the most economically developed regions), while only 13% live in the southern half of the peninsula. The official language of Italy is Italian. The Ethnologue website estimates that there are approximately 55 million speakers of this language in Italy, and 6.7 million abroad. However, 120 to 150 million people use Italian as a second or cultural language, worldwide. Italian, which was adopted by the country after the unification of Italy, is based on the Florentine dialect of Tuscany, and is an intermediate language between the Italo-Dalmasian languages, and the Gallo-Romance languages. Its development was also influenced by the Germanic languages ​​of the Migration Period. Italy has many dialects spoken throughout Italy, and some Italians don't speak Italian at all. Nonetheless, the creation of a national education system has reduced the variety of spoken languages ​​in Italy. Standardization was expanded in the 1950s to 1960s, this situation was facilitated by economic growth, and the emergence of the mass media, and television (the state-owned broadcaster RAI helped standardize the Italian language). Several linguistic groups are recognized by law, and a number of minority languages ​​have co-official status in several regions of Italy. French has also gained sub-official status in the Aosta Valley—despite the fact that Arpitan is more commonly spoken there. As in parts of the province it is German, and Ladin has the same status in the province of South Tyrol, and in parts of Trentino.

Slovene is officially recognized in the Provinces of Trieste, Gorizia Province and Udine Province in Friuli–Venezia Giulia. In these regions official documents are presented bilingually (trilingual in the Ladin community), or made available upon request in Italian or a sub-official language. Traffic signs are also presented multilingually, except in the Aosta Valley – where with the exception of Aosta itself which retains its Latin form in Italian (as it does in English) – French toponyms are generally used, attempts to italicize them in the Fascist period have been abandoned . Education is possible to be held in the minority language used in the area where the school is located. Although Roman Catholicism is the majority religion (85% of Italian-born Christians are Catholics), there are several communities that are part of the Protestant Church, as well as the Bené Roma that have practiced Judaism in Italy for thousands of years. And there is also a Muslim immigrant community (see: Islam in Italy). Roman Catholicism is by far the largest religion in Italy, although Catholicism is no longer the state religion. The proportion of Italians who identify as Roman Catholics is 87.8%, although only a third of them identify as active members (36.8%). Most Italians believe in God, or some form of spiritual life force. According to a Eurobarometer survey in 2005: 74% of Italians responded that 'they believe in God', 16% answered that 'they believe that there is some kind of living spirit or power', and 6% answered that 'they do not believe in the existence of God'. spirit, God, or living power'. The Italian Catholic Church is part of the global Roman Catholic Church, under the spiritual leadership of the Pope, the curia in Rome, and the Italian Episcopal Conference.

Apart from Italy, two other sovereign nations belong to an Italian-based diocese, the enclave of San Marino, and the Vatican. There are 225 dioceses in the Italian Catholic Church. Italy is rich in Catholic culture, in particular there are many saints, martyrs and popes who came from Italy. Roman Catholicism is the religion, and the largest denomination in Italy, with approximately 87.8% of Italians identifying as Catholic. Italy is also home to the majority of the world's cardinals, and is the country with the largest number of Roman Catholic churches per capita. Although the main Christian denomination in Italy is Roman Catholicism, there are significant minorities, namely Waldensian, Eastern Orthodox, and other Christian churches. In the 20th century, the Pentecostal Church, non-denominational Evangelicalism, was the fastest growing Protestant church, as well as Jehovah's Witnesses, and Mormonism. Since the 1980s, Immigration from Sub-Saharan Africa has increased Baptist, Anglican, Pentecostal and Evangelical congregations in Italy, while immigrants from Eastern Europe have started Eastern Orthodox communities. At the start of the 21st century, there were more than 700,000 Eastern Orthodox Christians in Italy, including 180,000 Greek Orthodox, 550,000 Pentecostals and Evangelicals (0.8%), of which 400,000 belonged to the Assemblies of God, 235,685 Jehovah's Witnesses (0.4%), 30,000 Waldensians, 25,000 Seventh-day Adventists, 22,000 Mormons, 15,000 Baptists (plus about 5,000 Free Baptists), 7,000 Lutherans, 4,000 Methodists (affiliated with Waldensian Church) . One of the long-established religious beliefs in Italy is Judaism, Jews had a presence in Ancient Rome before the birth of Christ. Italy has seen many influential Italian-Jews, such as Shabbethai Donnolo (d. 982), prime minister Luigi Luzzatti, who took office in 1910, and Ernesto Nathan, prominent mayor of Rome from 1907 to 1913.

At the time of the Holocaust, Italy received many Jewish refugees from Nazi Germany. However, with the creation of the Nazi-backed puppet state of the Italian Social Republic, approximately 15% of Italian Jews were killed, despite the Fascist government's refusal to deport Jews to Nazi death camps. These events, together with the emigration before, and after World War II, have left a small Jewish community of only about 45,000 people in Italy today. The increase in immigration has been accompanied by an increase in non-Christian beliefs. In 2009, there were 1.0 million Muslims in Italy making up 1.6 percent of the population, although only 50,000 people had Italian citizenship. Independent parties estimate the total Muslim population in Italy ranging from 0.8 million to 1.5 million. There are over 200,000 adherents of the Indian subcontinent with approximately 70,000 Sikhs with 22 gurdwaras across Italy, 70,000 Hindus and 50,000 Buddhists. There were approximately 4,900 Baha'is in Italy as of 2005. Education in Italy is free, and compulsory for residents aged 6 to 16, and consists of five levels: kindergarten (scuola dell'infanzia), school elementary school (scuola primaria), junior high school (scuola secondaria di primo grado), high school (scuola secondaria di secondo grado), and university (università). Italy is home to a wide variety of universities, colleges and academies. Founded in 1088, the University of Bologna is one of the oldest universities in the world. In 2009, the University of Bologna was, according to The Times, the only Italian college to be included in the World's 200 Universities. The Luigi Bocconi Commercial University in the City of Milan is ranked among the top 20 business schools in the world by The Wall Street Journal's international rankings, specifically for its MBA program, which in 2007 was ranked 17th in the world in priority alumni recruitment by major multinational companies.

Bocconi was also ranked by Forbes as the best in the world in the special Value for Money category. In May 2008, Bocconi overtook some of the world's best business schools in the Financial Times executive education rankings, reaching 5th in Europe, and 15th in the world. The other best universities and polytechnics are the Polytechnic of Torino, Polytechnic of Milano (which in 2011 was ranked the 48th best technical university in the world according to THE-QS World University Rankings. ), University of Rome La Sapienza (which in 2005 was the 20th best university -33 in Europe, and ranks among Europe's 50 and the world's 150 best colleges), and the University of Milano (whose research activities, and teaching have developed over the years, and have received recognition of international importance. The university is the only Italian university which is a member of the League of European Research Universities (LERU), a prestigious group of 20 research-intensive universities in Europe.The university is also ranked: 1st in Italy, and 7th in Europe (Leiden Rankings – Leiden University).According to the Indicator National Science (1981–2002), a database produced by the Research Services Group which lists outputs, and statistics With citations for more than 90 countries, Italy has an above average scientific publication output (in terms of the number of papers written involving at least one Italian author) in astronomy (9.75% of world papers), mathematics (5, 51% of world papers), computer science, neuroscience, and physics; the lowest, but still above the world average, output in terms of number of papers produced is recorded in the social sciences, psychology, and psychiatry, and economics, and business. Italy has operated a universal public health care system since 1978. Nonetheless, health care is provided to all citizens, and residents by a mixed public-private system.

The public part is the Servizio Sanitario Nazionale, which is created under the Ministry of Health, and left to be managed by the regional governments. Spending on health services in Italy exceeded 9.0% of national GDP in 2008, slightly above the OECD country average of 8.9%. However, Italy is ranked 2nd best in the world in terms of health care system, and 3rd in the world in terms of health service performance. Italy achieved the world's 12th highest life expectancy in 2010, meanwhile, like in many other Western countries, it is witnessing an increasing proportion of people who are overweight, and obese, with 34.2% of Italians reporting being overweight. body weight, and 9.8% were obese. The proportion of daily smokers was 22% in 2008. Smoking in public places including bars, restaurants, nightclubs and offices has been restricted to ventilated spaces since 2005. Italy did not exist as a single country until the unification of the country in 1861 Because of this relatively recent unification, and the historical autonomy of each of the regions that make up the Italian Peninsula, many traditions and customs that are now recognized as belonging to Italy are clearly identifiable by region of origin. Despite the political and social differences in these regions, Italy's contribution to the cultural heritage and history of Europe and the world is still great. Italy is home to a large number of UNESCO World Heritage Sites (currently 47), and a rich treasury of art, culture and literature from many different periods. This country influenced many world cultures, also because there were many Italians who emigrated to other places during the time of the Italian Diaspora. Furthermore, the nation has, overall, an estimated 100,000 monuments of any sort (museums, palaces, buildings, statues, churches, art galleries, villas, fountains, historic houses and archaeological remains).

Italy has a wide variety of architectural styles, and types, which cannot be differentiated only on the basis of period, but also region, since Italy was still a collection of city-states until 1861. This situation, however, has created a wide variety of architectural designs, and sometimes in synergy. Italy is known for its outstanding architectural achievements, such as the construction of arches, domes and similar structures in Ancient Rome, pioneering the Renaissance architectural movement of the late 14th to 16th centuries, and being the birthplace of Palladian architecture, a style of construction inspired the neoclassical architectural movement, and influenced the designs used by respectable people to make their country homes around the world, particularly in the United Kingdom, Australia and the United States in the late 17th to early 20th centuries. Some of the finest masterpieces of Western architecture, the Colosseum, the Cathedral of Milano and the Cathedrals of Florence, the Tower of Pisa, and the plans for buildings in Venice were built in Italy. Italian architecture also influenced world architecture. British architect Inigo Jones, inspired by the designs of Italian buildings and cities, brought Italian Renaissance architectural ideas to England in the 17th century, inspired by Andrea Palladio. Additionally, Italianate architecture, which was widespread since the 19th century, is used to describe foreign architecture built in the Italian style, particularly as modeled on Renaissance architecture. Over the centuries, Italian art has gone through many stylistic changes. Italian painting has traditionally been characterized by warm, bright colours, as exemplified in the works of Caravaggio, and Titian, and a fondness for pictures, and religious motifs. Italian painting enjoyed pre-eminence in Europe for hundreds of years, from the Romanesque, and Gothic, and through the Renaissance, and Baroque periods, the latter two of which witnessed its fruition in Italy.

Other notable artists who fell within these periods were Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, Donatello, Botticelli, Fra Angelico, Tintoretto, Bernini, and Raphael. After that, Italy experienced a continual conquest by foreign powers which led to a shift in focus to political matters, and resulted in its decline as the artistic power in Europe. It was not until 20th century Futurism, especially through the works of Umberto Boccioni, and Giacomo Balla, that Italy was able to regain its former prestige as a place for artistic evolution. Futurism was replaced by the metaphysical paintings of Giorgio de Chirico, which greatly influenced the Surrealists, and generations after them. The foundation of the modern Italian language was formed by the Florentine poet Dante Alighieri, whose greatest work, the Divina Commedia, is considered one of the foremost literary statements produced in Europe in the Middle Ages. There is no shortage of literary figures venerated in Italy: Giovanni Boccaccio, Giacomo Leopardi, Alessandro Manzoni, Torquato Tasso, Ludovico Ariosto, and Petrarch, whose famous means of expression, the sonnet, is a native Italian find. Notable philosophers include Giordano Bruno, Marsilio Ficino, Niccolò Machiavelli and Giambattista Vico. Figures of modern literature, and Nobel laureates are the nationalist poet Giosuè Carducci in 1906, the realist writer Grazia Deledda in 1926, the modern theater writer Luigi Pirandello in 1936, the poets Salvatore Quasimodo in 1959, and Eugenio Montale in 1975, satirist, and theater writer Dario Fo in 1997. Italian theater can be traced back to the Roman tradition which was heavily influenced by Greece; as with many other literary genres, Roman dramatics tended to adapt, and translate, Greek works. For example, Seneca's Phaedra is based on Euripides, and many of Plautus' comedies are translations of Menander's works.

In the 16th century, and into the 18th century, the Commedia dell'arte was a form of improvisational theater, and it is still performed today. Troops of safari performers usually set up an outdoor stage, and provide entertainment in the form of juggling, acrobatics and, more commonly, playful playing based on a repertoire of established characters with outline plots, called canovaccio. From folk to classical music, music has always played an important role in Italian culture. Instruments related to classical music, namely the piano, and violin, were invented in Italy, and many common classical forms of music, such as the symphony, concerto, and sonata, can trace their roots back to Italian musical innovations of the 21st century. -16th, and 17th. The most famous composers of Italian origin are Renaissance composers (Palestrina, and Monteverdi), Baroque composers (Scarlatti, Corelli, and Vivaldi, classical composers (Paganini, and Rossini), and Romantic composers (Verdi, and Puccini). The modern Italian composer is Berio , and Nono proved to be significant in the development of experimental music, and electronic music, while the tradition of classical music is still strong in Italy, as evidenced by the fame of its numerous opera houses, such as La Scala in Milano, and San Carlo in Naples, and performers such as the pianist Maurizio Pollini, and the tenor Luciano Pavarotti, Italians are no less appreciative of the thriving scene of contemporary music.Italy is widely known for being the birthplace of opera.Italian opera is believed to have been pioneered since the early 17th century, in Italian cities such as Mantua, and Venice.Then, works created by native Italian composers of the 19th and early 20th centuries, such as Rossini, Bellini, Donizetti, Verdi, and Puccini, are among the most famous operas ever written, and are now performed in opera houses around the world.

Luke calls him "Silas" (Greek name) in Acts, while Paul and Peter write his name as "Silwanus" (Latin name, from "Silva", meaning "forest", meaning "one who loves forests"). Silas is first mentioned in Acts as one of the leaders of the church in Jerusalem (Acts 15:22) holding the office of anointed teacher. His Latin name indicates that he was apparently a Hellenistic (Greek culture) Jew and apparently of Roman citizenship. He was appointed as a member of the delegation that accompanied Paul and Barnabas back to Antioch by decision of the Council of Jerusalem. After fulfilling this assignment, he returned to Jerusalem. However, it seems that he came again to Antioch, because there he was later chosen as Paul's traveling companion for his second missionary journey. At Berea, Paul left Silas with Timothy, while Paul himself left for Athens. Then Silas reunited with Paul in Corinth. His presence in Corinth is recorded several times in Paul's letters (as Silvanus), most notably as co-author with Paul and Timothy for the two letters to the Thessalonians. There was a Silvanus who delivered Simon Peter's letter to Asia Minor. Most likely it was the same person as Paul's companion.

This hypothesis about social change grows out of resistance to revolutionary socialism, which argues that revolution is necessary for fundamental structural changes to occur. Reformism must be distinguished from pragmatic reform: reformism is the view that an accumulation of reforms can lead to the formation of a socio-economic system that is completely different from current forms of capitalism and democracy, whereas pragmatic reform represents an effort to maintain the status quo against fundamental and structural changes. There are two kinds of reformism. The former have no desire to bring socialism or fundamental economic changes to society and are used to resist structural change. The second is based on the opinion that while reform is not socialism itself, it can help unite its supporters for the cause of the revolution by popularizing socialism among the working class. The debate over the ability of social democratic reformism to lead the socialist transformation of society has been going on for a century. Reformism was criticized for being paradoxical: trying to overcome the existing capitalist economic system, but also trying to improve the conditions of capitalism so that it actually made capitalism look more acceptable to society. According to Rosa Luxemburg, under reformism, "(capitalism) is not overthrown, but on the contrary will be strengthened by the development of social reforms." In a similar vein, Stan Parker of the Socialist Party of Great Britain argued that reformism was a transfer of power away from the socialists and limited, because they had to obey the logic of capitalism. French social theorist Andre Gorz criticized reformism by advocating a third alternative to reformism and social revolution which he called "non-reformist reforms".

"Non-reformist reforms" are reforms that specifically focus on structural changes to capitalism, as opposed to reforms to improve living conditions within capitalism, or sustain it through economic intervention. In 1875 the German Social Democratic Party (SDP) adopted the Gotha Program which proposed "everything that lawfully serves" for the work towards a "socialist society" and was criticized by Karl Marx as requiring a communist revolution. One of the SDP congress delegates, Eduard Bernstein, expanded his concept by proposing evolutionary socialism. Bernstein was an advocate of social democracy in Germany. Reformism became an immediate target of criticism of revolutionary socialism, with Rosa Luxemburg condemning Bernstein's Evolutionary Socialism in 1900 in her essay Reform or Revolution?. When Luxemburg died in the German Revolution, the reformists began to confront the Bolsheviks and their satellite communist party for the support of the intelligentsia and the working class. In 1959, the Godesberg Program (adopted at a party convention in the West German capital Bad Godesberg) marked the shift of the German Social Democratic Party (SDP) from a Marxist program to end capitalism, to a reformist one focused on social reform. After Joseph Stalin consolidated power in the Soviet Union, the Comintern launched a campaign against the Reformist movement by denouncing them as "social fascists". According to The God that Failed by Arthur Koestler, a former member of the German Communist Party, the largest communist party in Western Europe in the period between World War I and World War II, the communists, in alliance with the Soviet Union, continued to consider the German Social Democratic Party "social fascist" became the real enemy in Germany, even after the Nazi Party came to power. In modern times, reformists are seen as center-left. Some social democratic parties such as the NDP in Canada and the Social Democratic Party of Germany are still considered reformists.notes needed] The term was used for elements within the British Labor Party in the 1950s, and later for the right-wing party.

Etymologically, the term empiricism comes from the Greek emperia, which means experience. In empiricism, truth can only be obtained through experience. The empiricist mindset relies on empirical evidence. Empiricism is a type of ontology. In empiricism, humans can gain knowledge from experience by observing and sensing. Empiricism is one of the three schools of philosophy of science in the Western world. Philosophical thinking on empiricism has a nature that is contrary to rationalism. Empiricism thought was pioneered by Thomas Hobbes as a reaction against rationalism. The development of empiricism thought took place rapidly in England and the surrounding area during the renaissance during the 17th to 18th centuries. Empiricism was first developed in England by John Locke (1632–1704), but has more influenced thinkers in the United States, particularly in the fields of environmental preservation and environmental psychology. Supporting figures come from adherents of Western philosophy, including Francis Bacon, Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, and David Hume. The empiricism of its leaders has contributed to the development of the scientific field. These figures include John Locke (social science and scientific method), George Berkeley (physics, mathematics and theology), and David Hume (historical science and science). Empiricism is also the basis for the development of philosophy in positivism. In addition, empiricism is also one of the main streams in educational philosophy which is the basis for the development of various models of education in the world. The understanding of empiricism has been put forward by Aristotle with the opinion that perception is the basis of science.

Empiricism first appeared in England as a thought that was contrary to the rationalism thought put forward by René Descartes. The initial idea of ​​empiricism was put forward by Thomas Hobbes (1588–1679) with the opinion that the beginning of all knowledge comes from sensory experience. The laws of mechanism are considered as the basis of the processes that take place in the world, including humans. Then, another idea about empiricism was put forward by John Locke (1632–1704) who argued that the source of knowledge received by reason comes from experience. The empiricism of thought was further developed by George Berkeley who argued that material substances do not exist at all, only observable characteristics exist. When the world entered the Industrial Revolution, humans began to rely on science and technology to determine policies to address various social problems in society. Mysticism and beliefs about the occult and magic have begun to be abandoned by society. Social problems began to be solved by compiling and testing various scientific theories. The benchmarks used are empiricism and the scientific method. The main teachings of empiricism can be divided based on their views on sources of knowledge, methods of thinking and models of reasoning used. The source of knowledge in the view of empiricism is only from experience. The method of thinking he uses is through empirical evidence and experiments. While the reasoning model he uses is inductive reasoning. The main teachings of empiricism are contrary to rationalism, because rationalism considers knowledge recognition by the senses to be unclear. Meanwhile, empiricism believes that the senses are the perfect and clearest means of recognizing knowledge. In another sense, empiricism prioritizes the use of a posteriori elements, while rationalism prioritizes the use of a priori elements. Another difference between empiricism and rationalism lies in the type of mindset used.

Empiricism uses an inductive mindset, while rationalism uses a deductive mindset. The epistemological view of empiricism is based on the principle that everything that exists in the mind exists in the form of sensory data. The epistemology of empiricism is based on the works of John Locke and David Hume. In his second thought, phenomenalism-nominalism is used as the basis of science. Something is considered as knowledge if it is a phenomenon that can be experienced directly. Status as knowledge cannot be given to statements that do not refer to independent objects. Revealing the reality is seen as the main thing, because the truth will be known naturally after the fact is revealed. Correspondence theory is related to empiricism because experience and sensory observation are used as the main source of acquiring knowledge.
