The use of this approach is then referred to as the inductive method or empiricism method. Each incident case which includes natural phenomena as well as social phenomena, is given a general conclusion or generalization in order to obtain scientific knowledge. This method creates a tool for the discovery of scientific knowledge called statistics. John Locke laid the foundation for empiricism in the process of thinking.

In 1669, he wrote a book entitled Essay Concerning Human Understanding which has the main premise of the statement that all knowledge is obtained through experience. Locke's thinking rejects Plato's opinion regarding the existence of innate ideas prior to the acquisition of experience. It rejects all ideas that support the existence of an innate idea. The empiricism developed by John Locke is also related to education. John Locke's empiricism is related to his view of the knowledge possessed by humans at birth. He believes that humans are born in a state of complete lack of knowledge. Locke also believed that children's development, especially in education, was fully influenced by the environment. Thomas Hobbes argues that the introduction of everything is always preceded by sensory experience. Truth is only possessed by something that can be felt by the senses. He believes that intellectual recognition is the result of the sum of the same sensory data, but in a different way. Hobbes considered the system of matter composed of the world and matter as his object of recognition. The existence of recognition object takes place continuously because of the law of mechanism. In the history of modern philosophy, Hobbes' thought is the first materialistic system. David Hume is a British empiricist figure. The empirical thoughts he put forward were radical. He interprets the substance of knowledge as a repetition of experience so that the whole knowledge is a total experience. David Hume's views tend to be skeptical because he only recognizes the results of knowledge by the senses broadly. He considers experience as a fantasy and assumption. In modern science, normative laws are separated from empirical laws. This normative law is interpreted as a relationship that links between humans and God. This condition makes modern science value-free and neutral.

In empiricism, this normative law is only associated with humans. Normative law is not related to religion so it is called a social contract. This view makes God and religion considered as non-existent in modern human consciousness. The end result of this thinking is modern science which relies on rationality and the scientific method to know about reality. In addition, a phenomenon is understood objectively and value-free through reductionism, universalism and absolute freedom. Epistemologically, empiricism is a notion of thought which is the basis for the construction of knowledge in modern science. Observations and experiences are used to carry out scientific hypothesis testing. This empirical knowledge completely relies on all kinds of human senses to form knowledge of the state of the world around humans. The content of this empirical knowledge includes ideas that are in accordance with empirical facts. The educational philosophy of pragmatism is a school of educational philosophy that emerged in America. This philosophical school is influenced by British empiricism. The main view is that humans can know something that has been experienced. Figure thinkers include Herakleitos, Charles Sanders Peirce, William James, and John Dewey. In the Western world, education with pragmatism is the result of a combination of empiricism and positivism. Empiricism is a major part of positivism. One of the influences of empiricism on positivism is the use of verification methods. The name positivism itself comes from the word "positive" which is related to the word "factual". The word "factual" is related to all facts that have empirical evidence. Sensory recognition and observation are then used in positivism to introduce knowledge into research. Observable phenomena are always associated with facts, so that facts cover everything that can be observed. Observation of empirical facts is carried out in order to reach conclusions that can be used to verify the truth of a statement.

A statement that cannot be verified will be considered as metaphysics in the view of positivism. In positivism, these metaphysical statements are not considered science. Empiricism is utilized in positivism to respond to the limitations of speculative philosophy. This limitation, for example, was put forward by Immanuel Kant. The flow of positivism was introduced by Comte de Claude Henri de Rouvray Saint-Simon (1760–1825) and developed by Auguste Comte (1798–1857). In the social science family, the positivism paradigm combines empiricism and rationalism. The combination of empiricism and rationalism also makes social reality in the view of positivism dualistic because it examines the existence of both subjects and objects. This positivism approach then forms objective truth claims obtained through scientific processes. The empiricism approach is used to analyze the problem of educational equity through a combination of methodology and substance. The assumption given as the cause of unequal opportunities in obtaining education is the existence of differences in social class with different interests. This social class is generally divided into populists and elites. The populists get an education by working hard, while the elite get an education by maintaining the status quo. Modern democracy is closely related to empiricism in terms of forms and sentiments. The idea of ​​a single visionary or rationality was replaced by the concept of the greatest number of observations. Empiricism also substitutes the qualitative character of rationalism for the number of individual cases collected. Empiricism has three weaknesses related to its characteristics. First, empiricism only relies on experience that is not directly related to objective reality when it acts as a concept. The meaning of experience is less clear to serve as a source of systematic knowledge. Second, the limitations and imperfections of the human senses make empiricism incapable of distinguishing between something imaginary and factual.

He is the brother of Basudewa, the father of Baladewa, Krishna, and Subhadra. She is also the biological mother of Yudhishthira, Werkodara (Bima), and Arjuna and is also the first legitimate wife of Pandu. In addition, Kunti is also Karna's biological mother. After Pandu's death, he took care of Nakula and Sadewa, the children of Pandu and Madri. After the Bharatayuddha (the great war of the Bharata family), he and his brothers-in-law—Dretarastra, Gandari, and Widura—went into asceticism until the end of their lives. Kunti's father was King Surasena of the Yadawa Dynasty, and when she was a baby she was given the name Pritha. He is the younger brother of Basudewa, Krishna's father. Then he was adopted by King Kuntiboja who had no children, and since then he was given the name Kunti. When Kunti was still young, she was given a magical spell by Resi Durwasa to be able to summon the Gods and Goddesses according to her wishes. One day, Kunti wanted to try the trick and called one of the Gods, namely Surya. Surya who felt called, asked Kunti, what she wanted. But Kunti told the God to return to his residence. Because Kunti had called the god to come to earth but did not want any blessing, the God gave a son to Kunti. Kunti did not want to have a son at such a young age, so she put the child in a basket and washed him away in the Aswa river. Then the son was picked up by a coachman in Hastinapura palace named Adirata; the child was named Karna. Kunti married Pandu, a king in Hastinapura, in a contest.

The editor's page has logged out learn more Hamburg (Lower Saxony: Hamborg), officially the Free and Hansa City Hamburg (German: Freie und Hansestadt Hamburg, Lower Saxony: Friee un Hansestadt Hamborg) is the second most populous city in Germany after Berlin, and one of the busiest cities in the world. Hamburg was founded in 825. With an area of ​​755 km2 and crossed by the river Elbe, this city is classified as a cosmopolitan city thanks to the reputation of its sons such as the famous classical composers Felix Mendelssohn and Johannes Brahms and director and theater player Gustaf Grudgens of the Deutsche Schauspielhaus. The city of Hamburg has a strong publishing industry which began to develop in the 17th century. The physical character of this city is marked by the canal system that divides it. Hamburg also has beautiful lakes, parks and museums including the Kunsthalle (1868), Museum of Arts and Crafts (1877), Museum of Ethnology and Prehistory (1878). Its official name reflects Hamburg's history as a member of the Hanseatic League in medieval times and an independent imperial city from the Holy Roman Empire. Prior to the German Unification in 1871, Hamburg was a fully sovereign city-state, and prior to 1919 it formed a civil republic governed constitutionally by the hereditary great burgher class or Hanseaten. Struck by disasters such as the Great Hamburg Fire, the North Sea floods of 1962 and military conflicts including bombing raids during World War II, the city has managed to recover and become more prosperous after each disaster. The history of the city of Hamburg is both tragic and romantic. Situated between the Elbe and Alster rivers, Hammaburg castle was built in 825 and became the home of the Archbishop of Ansgar, which made it a base for expanding Christian influence over the pre-Christian population of Northern Europe.

The city was burnt to the ground by the Vikings in 845, but was later rebuilt only to be burned again 8 times in 300 years. In the 13th century AD, Hamburg became part of the Hanseatic League, which included the Baltic trading cities of Lübeck, Breslau and Danzig. This league strengthened the economy of the cities of the unified North Germany. Trade flourished, and Hamburg became a major port of trade between Russia and Flanders with its position as ruler and guardian of the river Elbe. Although the Hanseatic League broke up in the late Middle Ages, Hamburg continued to grow. Its growth has outpaced Lübeck. The Hamburg stock exchange was founded in 1558. Between 1616-1625, Hamburg built its own defenses and also built public facilities such as an orphanage built in 1604 and a hospital built in 1605. In 1625, the city strengthened its defenses so that it could continue its trading activities went through hard times in the Thirty Years' War (1618-1648) which left other cities in a slump. It's just that when it was attacked by the French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte in 1830, Hamburg was subdued and then dissolved in the French Empire. However, after Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte fell, Hamburg was able to reclaim its former glory as a free Hanseatic port city. Trade also expanded to Africa, America and Asia. Since rebuilding the damage suffered by its port during World War II, Hamburg has reclaimed its position as Germany's main port and has become one of the most important ports in Northern Europe. In the early 1960s, members of the world famous band from Great Britain, The Beatles often performed regularly in the city of Hamburg and became so famous that it can be said that this city was the starting point of the band's success.

There are 5 main churches in the city of Hamburg which were rebuilt after the big fire. The development of the city of Hamburg is marked by the many areas in the suburbs of Hamburg that have sprung up along the shores of Lake Aussenalster, and the many consulates general that occupy the beautiful Patrisian style houses in this city . Hamburg is in a natural, protected harbor in the south of the Jutland Peninsula, between the European Continent to the south and Scandinavia to the north, with the North Sea to the west and the Baltic Sea to the northeast. It is on the River Elbe at its confluence with the Alster and Bille. The city center is around the Binnenalster ("Inner Alster") and Außenalster ("Outer Alster"), both formed by damming the Alster River to create a lake. The islands of Neuwerk, Scharhörn and Nigehern, 100 kilometers (60 mi) away in Hamburg's Wadden Sea National Park, are also part of the city of Hamburg. Hamburg has a marine climate (Köppen: Cfb), influenced by its proximity to the coast and maritime influences originating from the Atlantic Ocean. Its location in northern Germany gives it a more extreme climate than the usual maritime climate, but it definitely falls in the category due to the prevailing westerly winds. The nearby wetlands enjoy a temperate maritime climate. Hamburg Airport (Flughafen Hamburg) is the main international airport in Hamburg, Germany's second largest city. It is located 8.5 km (5.3 mi) north of the city center in the Fuhlsbüttel area and serves as a hub for Eurowings and a focus city for Condor. Hamburg Airport is the fifth busiest commercial airport in Germany, handling 17,231,687 passengers and 156,388 aircraft movements in 2018. The airport was formerly known as Hamburg-Fuhlsbüttel Airport, a name which is still sometimes used. Hamburg is served by long-distance and regional trains from Germany's main rail company, Deutsche Bahn AG.

The city's main train station for long-distance services is Hamburg Main Station (Hamburg Hauptbahnhof). There are permanent Intercity-Express (ICE) lines to Berlin, Frankfurt am Main (connecting to Stuttgart and München), and Bremen (continuing to Ruhr and Cologne). In the north, ICE trains connect Hamburg with Aarhus and Copenhagen in Denmark, and Kiel in Schleswig-Holstein. There are also several InterCity and EuroCity passenger train connections. Rapid transit is served by the Hamburg U-Bahn and Hamburg S-Bahn and several commuter rail lines. As of 2015, the system comprises a length of 930 km (580 mi), with 289 stations for the region. 1,969 vehicles owned by ten operating companies: AKN Eisenbahn, DB Regio, Eisenbahnen und Verkehrsbetriebe Elbe-Weser (EVB), Erixx GmbH, Hamburg Hochbahn AG (HHA), metronome Eisenbahngesellschaft, nordbahn Eisenbahngesellschaft (NBE-Bahn-Ostsee, NOB) (part of Veolia Verkehr GmbH), S-Bahn Hamburg plc, and Verkehrsgesellschaft Norderstedt (VGN). The company serving public buses is Hamburg Hochbahn AG (HHA) with over 100 lines and 120,000 km (75,000 mi) of buses driven per day. The other main operator is the regional and city bus company Verkehrsbetriebe Hamburg-Holstein (VHH), operating many of its own lines (mainly in the outer districts and exit lines) and sharing services with the Hamburger Hochbahn on some lines. In 2007, there were more than 450 bus lines departing per week with travel destinations in 27 European countries. Several motorways (Autobahn), and federal highways (Bundesstraße) connect Hamburg with other regions or cities. An important motorway for north-south connections in Europe is the A7 from Kiel and Flensburg in the North to Hannover in the south. The A1 connects Lübeck to Bremen, Münster and Dortmund. The B5 stretches from the Danish border in the North to Frankfurt (Oder) in eastern Germany.

Editor's logged-out page learn more Lao Tzu (Chinese: 老子, pinyin: Lǎo Zǐ; Ancient Han: *C.rˤuʔ *ts]əʔ (Baxter-Sagart); *ruːʔ *ʔslɯʔ (Zhengzhang Shangfang)). is the most popular philosopher and also the founder of Taoism (Chinese: 道教 or 道家) today. There is little history of his life in historical records, but his existence is evident in the Chinese historical record, Shiji. According to the Shiji, Lǎo Zǐ had the real name Lier (李耳; pinyin: LĭĚr), the polite name Boyang (伯阳) and the honorary name of the deceased Dan (聃). There is a group of scholars who say Boyang and Dan are polite names. Lǎo Zǐ (570-470 BC), was born in Ku(苦县), Chuguo (楚国), now known as Henan Province. He was the chief librarian of Chuguo during the Zhou dynasty. During his tenure, he benefited greatly from reading books and historical records, thereby attaining broad insight. Lǎo Zǐ's fame spread to Confucianism. According to Zhuangzi's records, Confucianism once met with Laozi to ask for a lesson in politeness. There are paintings based on this story. Based on these records, it is estimated that Confucianism was approximately 20 years younger than Lǎo Zǐ. According to Zhuangzi's references, Confucius first met Lǎo Zǐ at the age of 17 and then at the age of 34, and the third time at Xiangyi (相邑) and when he was 51 and 66. At the time of the collapse of the Zhou Dynasty, Lǎo Zǐ resigned and left his country with his koak. When he arrived at Hangu Castel (函谷关), Guan Yixi (关尹喜) asked him to renounce philosophy in written form. Upon this request, he created two works entitled Dao and De before leaving Chuguo.

Editor page that has logged out learn more A transformer or transformer is an electrical device that converts one form of electrical energy into another form of electrical energy. The value of the electric voltage generated by the transformer is determined by the need for electrical energy. Types of transformers include step-up transformers, step-down transformers, measuring transformers and electronic transformers. Transformers can be installed from one electrical circuit to another, or several circuits. The varying current in each coil of a transformer produces a varying magnetic flux in the transformer core, which induces varying electromotive forces in the other coils wound around the same core. Electrical energy can be transferred between separate coils without a metallic (conductive) connection between the two circuits. Faraday's law of induction, discovered in 1831, describes the effect of the voltage induced in each coil due to a change in the magnetic flux surrounded by the coil. Transformers are most commonly used to step up low AC voltages at high currents (step-up transformers) or step down high AC voltages at low currents (step-down transformers) in power applications, and to interconnect stages in signal processing circuits. Transformers can also be used for isolation, where the voltage equals the output voltage, with the separate coils not being electrically bonded to each other. Since the invention of the first constant potential transformer in 1885, transformers have become essential for the transmission, distribution, and utilization of alternative electric current power. A wide variety of transformer designs are found in power electronics and electrical applications. Transformer sizes range from RF transformers with a volume of less than one cubic centimeter, to units weighing hundreds of tons used to connect power grids. Three-phase transformers used in electric power systems will have a nameplate indicating the phase relationship between their terminals. Current transformer is a type of transformer that is used to determine the magnitude of the strong electric current at high voltage. The inside of the current transformer is composed of a primary winding and a secondary winding. The number of primary windings is very small, while the number of secondary windings is very large. The secondary winding is connected to an electric measuring instrument, namely the ammeter. The secondary is also connected to the control circuit and protection relay. Voltage transformer is a type of transformer that is used to determine the magnitude of the electric voltage at high voltage. The inside of the voltage transformer is composed of a primary winding and a secondary winding. The number of primary windings is very large, while the number of secondary windings is very small. The secondary winding is connected to an electric measuring instrument, namely a voltmeter. The secondary is also connected to the control circuit and protection relay. A step-up transformer is a transformer that has more secondary windings than the primary winding, so it functions as a voltage step-up. This transformer is commonly found in electric power plants as a step-up voltage generated by the generator to a high voltage used in long-distance transmission. A step down transformer has fewer secondary turns than the primary winding, so it functions as a step down. This type of transformer is very easy to find, especially in AC-DC adapters. This type of transformer consists of only one electrically continuous winding, with a center tap. In this transformer, part of the primary winding is also a secondary winding. The phase current in the secondary winding is always opposite to the primary current, so that for the same power rate the secondary winding can be made with thinner wire than an ordinary transformer.

The advantage of the autotransformer is its small physical size as well as lower losses than the two-winding type. But this type of transformer cannot provide electrical isolation between the primary winding and the secondary winding. In addition, the autotransformer cannot be used as a step-up voltage of more than a few times (usually not more than 1.5 times). Closed core transformers are constructed in a 'core form' or 'frame form'. Core shape design tends to be, as a general rule, more economical, and therefore more common, than shield shape design for high-voltage power transformer applications at the lower end of their voltage range and power rating (less than or equal to, nominally, 230 kV or 75 MVAs). The editor page has logged out learn more. The most common helicases are the DNA helicase and the RNA helicase. DNA helicase has EC number 3.6.4.12 and plays a role in the process of DNA replication. Unlike the DNA helicase, the RNA helicase has the EC number 3.6.4.13 and plays a role in the translation process. The meaning of the EC number 3 is that this enzyme belongs to the class of hydrolytic enzymes. The mechanism of action of the DNA helicase is to form a nucleoprotein complex, called a replisome, with primase and cut the bonds in the DNA double helix into 2 single DNA strands. The stability of the replisome will affect the replication process in the lagging strand, especially the length of the Okazaki fragment formed. The more stable the replisome, the longer the Okazaki fragment will be and the easier the task of RNA polymerase will be. The role of helicases is also seen in DNA repair and DNA recombination in all organisms. DNA helicase was first isolated from the bacterium Escherichia coli in 1976. Since then, helicase has been isolated from various other eukaryotic and prokaryotic organisms. DNA helicase requires energy from ATP hydrolysis to unwind the double-stranded DNA. Helicase will walk down the DNA chain. The mechanism of action of the helicase is to disrupt the hydrogen bonds between the two strands. The characteristic of RNA helicase is that it is highly conserved enzyme. Even so, RNA helicase plays an important role in many metabolic processes such as translation, RNA repair, and recombination. Even though DNA helicase and RNA helicase have different functions, there is one helicase that is able to work to open DNA and RNA strands, namely Hepatitis C Virus Helicase. NS3(HCV N53). The performance of HCV N53 is influenced by 2 catalytic sides, namely W501 and V432. W501 is an aromatic ring residue and plays a role in the process of opening the RNA chain. When the W501 catalytic site is replaced with a non-aromatic residue, the RNA unwinding process is disrupted, while the DNA unwinding process is relatively unaffected by the presence of this residue.

Editor page logged out learn more Xiongnu (Chinese: 匈奴; pinyin: Xiōngnú; Wade–Giles: Hsiung-nu; Middle Chinese Guangyun: xi̯woŋ˥˩nu˩) were an ancient, nomad-based people who founded a state or confederation in Mongolia and China. Most of the information about the Xiongnu comes from Chinese sources, so the names and titles of the Xinongnu known today are Chinese transliterations of the Xiongnu's native language. The core ethnic identity of the Xiongnu is not known with certainty, as few words, especially titles and personal names, exist in Chinese sources. Opinions from historians regarding the languages ​​spoken by the Xiongnu include Mongolian, Turkic, Yenisi, Tocharian, and Ural languages. The name Xiongnu may be a cognate for the name of the Huns, but the evidence for this view is controversial. Chinese sources from the 3rd century BC report that the Xiongnu founded an empire under Modu Chanyu, their supreme leader after 209 BC. This empire stretched beyond the borders of modern Mongolia. After defeating the previously dominant Yuezhi in the 2nd century BC, the Xiongnu became the dominant power in the steppes of eastern Asia. They are active in Siberia, Mongolia, western Manchuria, and the Chinese provinces of Inner Mongolia, Gansu and Xinjiang. The relationship between the early dynasties of China and the Xiongnu was complex, with repeated periods of military conflict and intrigue, as well as exchanges of tribute, trade, and marriage agreements. Sima Qian writes, based on earlier Chinese records (Babmu Chronicles), that the ruling clan of the Xiongnu were descendants of the Chunwei (淳維 "Chun tribe"), possibly the sons of Jie, the last ruler of the possibly legendary Xia Dynasty (c. 2070–1600 BC). The Xiongnu were originally a collection of small tribes living in the barren highlands of Mongolia.

They are recognized as one of the most famous nomans bordering the Han Empire. During the Eastern Zhou Dynasty (1045–256 BC), military campaigns by Zhou vassal states to suppress other evil "barbarians" allowed the Xiongnu to gain an opportunity to fill the power vacuum. These newly awakened nomads became a major problem for China, as their horse-based lifestyle allowed them to launch invasions quickly and raid villages and small towns. During the Warring States Period (476–221 BC), three of the seven warring states bordered the Xiongnu territory, and a series of successive fortifications were built, which were later combined to form the Great Wall. During the Qin Dynasty (221 to 206 BC), Chinese troops, under the command of General Meng Tian, ​​drove the Xiongnu people away. he also reconquered the Ordos area. The presence of the powerful Donghu tribe in the east and Yuezhi tribe in the west also put the Xiongu people under pressure, forcing them to move further north over the following decades. With the collapse of the Qin dynasty and the ensuing civil war (206–202 BC), the Xiongnu, under Chanyu Toumen, were able to migrate back to China's border regions. In 209 BC, three years before the founding of the Han dynasty, the Xiongnu united into a powerful confederation under a new chanyu named Modu Chanyu. This new political unity turned them into a more resilient nation by enabling the formation of a larger army and the ability to carry out better co-ordinated strategies. The reasons for creating the confederation are not known for certain. It has been suggested that they needed a stronger state to deal with Qin's unification of China that resulted in the loss of the Ordos to Meng Tian, ​​or the political crisis that hit the Xiongnu in 215 BC, when Qin troops drove them from their pastures on the Yellow River; Having forged domestic unity, Modi expanded his empire in all directions.

To the north, he conquered a number of nomadic peoples, including the Dingling tribe in southern Siberia. He annihilated the power of the Donghu tribe in eastern Mongolia and Manchuria, and defeated the Yuezhi at the Hexi Corridor in Gansu where his son Jizhu fashioned glass from the Yuezhi king's skull. Modu also reoccupied all the territory previously captured by the Qin general Meng Tian. Under Modu, the Xiongnu became a threat to the Han dynasty, nearly depriving Liu Bang of his throne in 200 BC. After Modu died in 174 BC, the Xiongnu had expelled the Yuezhi from the Hexi Corridor, killing the Yuezhi king in the process and establishing their presence in the Western Regions of Xinjiang. After Modu's time, subsequent Xiongnu leaders established a system of dualist political organization with left and right Xiongnu branches divided on a regional basis. Chanyu or shan-yü – the supreme ruler equivalent to the "Son of Heaven" in China – had direct authority over the area in the center. Longcheng (蘢城), near Khöshöö Tsaidam in Mongolia, became the annual meeting place and was made the capital of the Xiongnu. In the winter of 200 BC, following the siege of Taiyuan, Emperor Gao directly led a military campaign against Modun. At the Battle of Baideng, he was ambushed by a force thought to have numbered around 300,000 elite Xiongnu cavalry. The emperor was cut off from supplies and reinforcements for seven days, and barely escaped. After the defeat at Pingcheng, the Han emperors abandoned a military solution to the Xiongnu threat. Instead, in 198 BC, the court official Liu Jing (劉敬) was sent to negotiate. A peace agreement was eventually reached between the two sides, which included the marriage of the Han princes in a chanyu (called heqin 和親 for "harmonious kinship"); regular gifts to the Xiongnu of silk, liquor, and rice; equal status between the two countries; and the Great Wall as a common border.

The fiber sets out how to educate and raise children. Under his leadership, Rome was very peaceful and its natural resources were abundant.

But Tiberius and the emperors after him were not as clever as Augustus, so they fell into a slump. However, the peace and security laid down by Augustus in the Pax Romana persisted for 200 years afterward. Augustus Caesar died in AD 14. He ruled Rome for 40 years. Many consider Augustus to be the greatest Roman emperor. His various policies went beyond the time of the Roman Empire hence they initiated the famous Pax Romana or Pax Augusta. Editor page logged out learn more Actinobacteria or Actinomycetes is a bacterial phylum that includes Gram-positive bacteria. This bacterium was once classified as a fungus (mushroom, Mycota) because some of its members form hyphae-like bundles and produce antibiotics. While it was recognized that they shared some of the characteristics of bacteria (they are small and susceptible to virus attack by bacteriophages), this group was once thought to be neither fungi nor bacteria. It wasn't until DNA testing became possible that this group was identified as bacteria. Most Actinobacteria are found in soil. Others live inside plants and animals, including some pathogens such as Mycobacterium. They play an important role in the decomposition of organic matter such as cellulose and chitin. This activity increases nutrient reserves in the soil and is an important part of humus formation. The ability of Actinobacteria to live in a low nutrient environment and to consume lognocellulose (lignin and cellulose, substances that make up wood, usually difficult for most soil bacteria to digest) causes Actinobacteria to dominate the karst rock area. Giving cellulose-rich manure will increase the population of actinobacteria in the soil. Constant fertilization of ammonium or nitrate suppresses the population because Actinobacteria do not like pH below 6; conversely, liming to raise the pH also increases the population. Members of Actinobacteria are mostly aerobic, but some, such as Actinomyces israelii, can grow under anaerobic conditions. Unlike Firmicutes, another major group of Gram-positive bacteria, Actinobacteria have DNA with a high GC-content and some types of Actinobacteria produce external spores. Some actinobacteria cause health problems in humans, animals and plants. Streptomyces causes scabies (scabies) on potato tubers. S. griceus produces the antibiotic streptomycin. Frankia types form a mutualism symbiosis with plant roots so as to help plant growth.

Editor page out log learn more Dragons are legendary creatures with characteristics similar to reptiles that appear in many folklores in various cultures around the world. Belief in dragons varies from region to region, but dragons in western mythology since the Upper Middle Ages have been described as creatures that have wings, horns, four legs, and can breathe fire. Meanwhile, in eastern culture, dragons are usually described as wingless creatures, have four legs, have a shape like a snake with above average intelligence. In addition, dragons are described as possessing traits that are a combination of features in the Felin, Aves, and Reptilian races. The students believe that the dragon is most likely a representation of the crocodile, especially with the characteristics of its habitat, namely in swamps or dense forests, as well as its body structure, making this animal the origin of the modern Oriental dragon depiction. The term "dragon" is an absorption word from Sanskrit, namely nāgá (नाग) which means "cobra" which comes from the name of the Indian cobra (Naja naja). A synonym for nāgá is phaṇin (फणिन्). There are actually several words that also mean "snake" in general, and the one that is used most often is sarpá (सर्प). Sometimes, the word nāgá also has the meaning of "snake" in general. The word has the same origin as snake in English, and the word snake comes from the Germanic languages: *snēk-a-, Proto-IE: *(s)nēg-o- (with s movement). In English, the word dragon comes from Old French which entered English in the early 13th century, the word dragon also comes from Latin: draconem (normative form of draco) which means "giant snake, dragon", from Latin Ancient Greek δράκων, drákōn (genitive form of δράκοντος, drákontos) "sea serpent, giant serpent".

The term dragon in Greek and Latin refers to any large snake and is not necessarily a mythological creature. The Greek word δράκων most likely comes from the Greek verb δέρκομαι (dérkomai) meaning "I saw", and becomes ἔδρακον (édrakon) in the aorist form. The origin of this name, which may be a term for something that has a "deadly gaze" or eyes that emit an unusual or "sharp" light, can also mean to describe the eyes of a snake that seems to be always open and each of these eyes can see through her transparent, scaly eyelids, which were permanently closed. The Greek word is also possibly derived from the Indo-European base *derḱ- meaning "to see"; and the Sanskrit root दृश् (dr̥ś-) which also means "to see". Oops; Other names/spellings: Apophis is a creature in the form of a snake in Egyptian mythology, this creature lives in Duat which is the underworld of Egypt. The artifact was written around 310 BC on Bhemner-Rhind papyrus fibers and at the same time is one of the proofs from the Egyptian story which states that the setting of the sun was caused by Ra leaving for the Duat to fight Apep. In several other writings it is stated that Apep has the length of eight adults with a head made of chert. Thunderstorms and earthquakes are believed to be the result of Apep's roar and a solar eclipse is believed to be the result of Apep attacking Ra at noon. Although the description of its form varies, in general the specifications of the creature are described as being sacred. Dragons in eastern civilization have a place of honor, because even though they have tremendous power that can destroy, they are not arbitrary and can even protect. In the story of the Mahabarata as well as in the views of most Indonesians themselves before the Hindu Age, dragons or snakes were always associated with water, while water was absolutely necessary as a means of agriculture. In the Chinese tradition there is also a creature named Liong or Lung which is generally translated into Indonesian as dragon.

This creature is described as a giant snake, complete with horns, antennae and claws, so it is different from the description of the Indian version of the dragon. Some scientists argue that dragons in Chinese culture are imaginary creatures created by ancient people as a result of the discovery of dinosaur fossils. This creature is also known in Japanese culture as Ryuu. Dragon in zodiac has the meaning of truth. Another meaning is protection and might. According to the Kalimantan culture, the universe is the embodiment of the "Dwitunggal Universe" namely the upper realm is ruled by Mahatala or Pohotara, which is symbolized by an ivory hornbill (bird), while the lower world is ruled by Jata or Juata which is symbolized as a dragon (reptile). Editor's page out log learn more Empiricism is a school of philosophy that holds that all knowledge comes from human sensory experience. Etymologically, the term empiricism comes from the Greek emperia, which means experience. In empiricism, truth can only be obtained through experience. The empiricist mindset relies on empirical evidence. Empiricism is a type of ontology. In empiricism, humans can gain knowledge from experience by observing and sensing. Empiricism is one of the three schools of philosophy of science in the Western world. Philosophical thinking on empiricism has a nature that is contrary to rationalism. Empiricism thought was pioneered by Thomas Hobbes as a reaction against rationalism. The development of empiricism thought took place rapidly in England and the surrounding area during the renaissance during the 17th to 18th centuries. Empiricism was first developed in England by John Locke (1632–1704), but has more influenced thinkers in the United States, particularly in the fields of environmental preservation and environmental psychology. Supporting figures come from adherents of Western philosophy, including Francis Bacon, Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, and David Hume. The empiricism of its leaders has contributed to the development of the scientific field. These figures include John Locke (social science and scientific method), George Berkeley (physics, mathematics and theology), and David Hume (historical science and science). Empiricism is also the basis for the development of philosophy in positivism. In addition, empiricism is also one of the main streams in educational philosophy which is the basis for the development of various models of education in the world. The understanding of empiricism has been put forward by Aristotle with the opinion that perception is the basis of science.

Empiricism first appeared in England as a thought that was contrary to the rationalism thought put forward by René Descartes. The initial idea of ​​empiricism was put forward by Thomas Hobbes (1588–1679) with the opinion that the beginning of all knowledge comes from sensory experience. The laws of mechanism are considered as the basis of the processes that take place in the world, including humans. Then, another idea about empiricism was put forward by John Locke (1632–1704) who argued that the source of knowledge received by reason comes from experience. The empiricism of thought was further developed by George Berkeley who argued that material substances do not exist at all, only observable characteristics exist. When the world entered the Industrial Revolution, humans began to rely on science and technology to determine policies to address various social problems in society. Mysticism and beliefs about the occult and magic have begun to be abandoned by society. Social problems began to be solved by compiling and testing various scientific theories. The benchmarks used are empiricism and the scientific method. The main teachings of empiricism can be divided based on their views on sources of knowledge, methods of thinking and models of reasoning used. The source of knowledge in the view of empiricism is only from experience. The method of thinking he uses is through empirical evidence and experiments. While the reasoning model he uses is inductive reasoning. The main teachings of empiricism are contrary to rationalism, because rationalism considers knowledge recognition by the senses to be unclear. Meanwhile, empiricism believes that the senses are the perfect and clearest means of recognizing knowledge. In another sense, empiricism prioritizes the use of a posteriori elements, while rationalism prioritizes the use of a priori elements. Another difference between empiricism and rationalism lies in the type of mindset used.

Empiricism uses an inductive mindset, while rationalism uses a deductive mindset. The epistemological view of empiricism is based on the principle that everything that exists in the mind exists in the form of sensory data. The epistemology of empiricism is based on the works of John Locke and David Hume. In his second thought, phenomenalism-nominalism is used as the basis of science. Something is considered as knowledge if it is a phenomenon that can be experienced directly. Status as knowledge cannot be given to statements that do not refer to independent objects. Empiricism believes that the entire structure of science can be known using the induction method. Correspondence theory is a theory which argues that knowledge can be true and become truth when it is in accordance with reality. An idea, concept or theory is only considered correct if it corresponds to reality. Revealing the reality is seen as the main thing, because the truth will be known naturally after the fact is revealed. Correspondence theory is related to empiricism because experience and sensory observation are used as the main source of acquiring knowledge. Observation, experiment or testing empirically becomes something valuable in the view of correspondence theory to reveal the actual reality. Correspondence theory also emphasizes the use of knowledge and a posteriori way of working. Adila alias STIPRAM student lady. Aristotle used an empiricist approach to establish the foundations of science. He relies on the ability of the senses, especially sight (eyes) and hearing (ears). The use of this approach is then referred to as the inductive method or empiricism method. Each incident case which includes natural phenomena as well as social phenomena, is given a general conclusion or generalization in order to obtain scientific knowledge. This method creates a tool for the discovery of scientific knowledge called statistics. John Locke laid the foundation for empiricism in the process of thinking.

In 1669, he wrote a book entitled Essay Concerning Human Understanding which has the main premise of the statement that all knowledge is obtained through experience. Locke's thinking rejects Plato's opinion regarding the existence of innate ideas prior to the acquisition of experience. It rejects all ideas that support the existence of an innate idea. The empiricism developed by John Locke is also related to education. John Locke's empiricism is related to his view of the knowledge possessed by humans at birth. He believes that humans are born in a state of complete lack of knowledge. Locke also believed that children's development, especially in education, was fully influenced by the environment. Thomas Hobbes argues that the introduction of everything is always preceded by sensory experience. Truth is only possessed by something that can be felt by the senses. He believes that intellectual recognition is the result of the sum of the same sensory data, but in a different way. Hobbes considered the system of matter composed of the world and matter as his object of recognition. The existence of recognition object takes place continuously because of the law of mechanism. In the history of modern philosophy, Hobbes' thought is the first materialistic system. David Hume is a British empiricist figure. The empirical thoughts he put forward were radical. He interprets the substance of knowledge as a repetition of experience so that the whole knowledge is a total experience. David Hume's views tend to be skeptical because he only recognizes the results of knowledge by the senses broadly. He considers experience as a fantasy and assumption. In modern science, normative laws are separated from empirical laws. This normative law is interpreted as a relationship that links between humans and God. This condition makes modern science value-free and neutral.

In empiricism, this normative law is only associated with humans. Normative law is not related to religion so it is called a social contract. This view makes God and religion considered as non-existent in modern human consciousness. The end result of this thinking is modern science which relies on rationality and the scientific method to know about reality. In addition, a phenomenon is understood objectively and value-free through reductionism, universalism and absolute freedom. Epistemologically, empiricism is a notion of thought which is the basis for the construction of knowledge in modern science. Observations and experiences are used to carry out scientific hypothesis testing. This empirical knowledge completely relies on all kinds of human senses to form knowledge of the state of the world around humans. The content of this empirical knowledge includes ideas that are in accordance with empirical facts. The educational philosophy of pragmatism is a school of educational philosophy that emerged in America. This philosophical school is influenced by British empiricism. The main view is that humans can know something that has been experienced. Figure thinkers include Herakleitos, Charles Sanders Peirce, William James, and John Dewey. In the Western world, education with pragmatism is the result of a combination of empiricism and positivism. Empiricism is a major part of positivism. One of the influences of empiricism on positivism is the use of verification methods. The name positivism itself comes from the word "positive" which is related to the word "factual". The word "factual" is related to all facts that have empirical evidence. Sensory recognition and observation are then used in positivism to introduce knowledge into research. Observable phenomena are always associated with facts, so that facts cover everything that can be observed. Observation of empirical facts is carried out in order to reach conclusions that can be used to verify the truth of a statement.

A statement that cannot be verified will be considered as metaphysics in the view of positivism. In positivism, these metaphysical statements are not considered science. Empiricism is utilized in positivism to respond to the limitations of speculative philosophy. This limitation, for example, was put forward by Immanuel Kant. The flow of positivism was introduced by Comte de Claude Henri de Rouvray Saint-Simon (1760–1825) and developed by Auguste Comte (1798–1857). In the social science family, the positivism paradigm combines empiricism and rationalism. The combination of empiricism and rationalism also makes social reality in the view of positivism dualistic because it examines the existence of both subjects and objects. This positivism approach then forms objective truth claims obtained through scientific processes. The empiricism approach is used to analyze the problem of educational equity through a combination of methodology and substance. The assumption given as the cause of unequal opportunities in obtaining education is the existence of differences in social class with different interests. This social class is generally divided into populists and elites. The populists get an education by working hard, while the elite get an education by maintaining the status quo. Modern democracy is closely related to empiricism in terms of forms and sentiments. The idea of ​​a single visionary or rationality was replaced by the concept of the greatest number of observations. Empiricism also substitutes the qualitative character of rationalism for the number of individual cases collected. Empiricism has three weaknesses related to its characteristics. First, empiricism only relies on experience that is not directly related to objective reality when it acts as a concept. The meaning of experience is less clear to serve as a source of systematic knowledge. Second, the limitations and imperfections of the human senses make empiricism incapable of distinguishing between something imaginary and factual.

Editor's logged out page learn more In Buddhism, a Bodhisattva; Bodhisattva (Sanskrit) or Bodhisatta (Pali) or Photishat (Thai: โพธิสัตว์) is a Buddha-to-be who is perfecting the 10 paramis / virtues before becoming a Buddha. In Sanskrit, the term Bodhisattva consists of two words, namely bodhi which means enlightenment or illumination, and sattwa which means creature. Bodhisattva also refers to the Buddha in his previous life. In Mahayana teachings, Bodhisattvas take a vow not to enter nirvana until all beings have attained Buddhahood. This means that he postponed entering nirvana and chose to descend to earth to sacrifice himself to help other beings achieve enlightenment. That's why Bodhisattvas are known to have compassion and selflessness and self-sacrifice. This is not the same as in the traditional Theravada tradition, beings who attain enlightenment are Arhats, not Buddhas. The Bodhisattva meaning in the Pali Canon (collection of scriptures on Theravada teachings) and Theravada tradition does not say that a Bodhisattva makes a promise not to become enlightened until everyone else is enlightened. This is an innovation from Mahayana. So a Bodhisatta and a Bodhisattva are different things. Bodhisattvas are much admired in famous art, including one of the tallest statues of the Bodhisattva at Puning Monastery in China, built in 1755. The Pali word Bodhisattva is used by the Buddha in the Pali Canon to refer to himself in previous and present lives towards enlightenment and in the period when he was still moving towards liberation. Siddhartha Gautama's life as a Bodhisattva is recorded in the Jataka Book. When Siddhartha Gautama talks about himself first, he uses the term "when I was a Bodhisattva".

Editor logged off page learn more A mouse (literal translation from English: mouse) is a pointing device used to enter data and commands into a computer other than the keyboard. The mouse got its name because of the protruding cable that looks like a rat's tail. The mouse was first created in 1963 by Douglas Engelbart which was made of wood with a single button. The second model is equipped with three buttons. In 1970, Douglas Engelbart introduced a mouse that could determine the X-Y position on a computer screen, this mouse was known as the X-Y Position Indicator (X-Y Position Indicator). The most common form of mouse has two main buttons, one each on the top left and top right which can be pressed. Modern mice are generally equipped with a scroll button which can also be pressed as a third button. However, Macintosh-based computers usually use a single-button mouse. The mouse works by capturing motion with a ball that hits a hard, flat surface. More modern mice do not use the ball anymore, but use optical beams to detect motion. In addition, some are already using wireless technology, whether based on radio, infrared light, or Bluetooth. Currently, the latest technology allows mice to use laser systems, enabling resolutions reaching 2,000 dots per inch (dpi) to 4,800 dots per inch. Usually this model of mouse is intended for video game fans. The earliest written use of the term mouse to refer to a computer pointing device was in Bill English's publication in July 1965, "Computer-Aided Display Control" most likely derived from its resemblance to the shape and size of a rat, a rodent, with a mouse cord resembling a tail. rat.

The editor page has logged out learn more Mosalaparwa or Mausalaparwa is the sixteenth book in the Mahabharata series. The story tells of the destruction of the Wresni, Andhaka and Yadawa, a people in Mathura-Dwaraka (Dwarawati) where Lord Kresna ruled. This story also tells of the death of King Kresna and his brother, King Baladewa. It is said that when Yudistira ascended the throne, the world had entered the Kali Yuga or the dark ages. He had seen terrible signs in nature, which seemed to tell him that something terrible was about to happen. Krishna felt the same way. He felt that the glory of his nation would end, because he saw that many young Wresni, Yadawa, and Andhaka had become arrogant, arrogant, and liked to drink liquor until they were drunk. One day, Narada and several sages visited Dvaraka. Some ignorant youths are planning something to play tricks on the rishis. They dressed Samba (the son of Kresna and Jembawati) in women's clothing and paraded around the city and then were confronted by the rishis who were visiting Dwaraka. Then one of them said, "This person is the consort of Sang Babhru who is famous for his supernatural powers. You are sages who are smart and have high knowledge. Can you tell what will be born? A boy or a girl?". The rishis who knew they were being toyed with became angry and said, "This person is Sang Samba, a descendant of Basudewa. He will not give birth to a boy or a girl, but a mosala weapon that will destroy you all!" (mosala = mace) The curse came true. The Samba gave birth to an iron club from inside his stomach. By order of King Ugrasena, the weapon was then crushed to a powder. Some parts of the weapon are difficult to destroy leaving a small piece of iron.

After the weapon was destroyed, the powder and fragments were thrown into the sea. Then the Lord Baladewa and the Lord Krishna forbade people to drink alcohol. Legend has it that the powder returned to the shore, and from the powder grew a plant like grass but with very sharp leaves like swords. Small pieces that are difficult to destroy are eventually swallowed by a fish. The fish was caught by fishermen and sold to a Jara hunter. A hunter named Jara bought the fish and found a small piece of iron in the stomach of the fish he bought. The pieces of iron were then forged into arrows. After the weapon born by Sang Samba was destroyed, came Batara Kala, the God of Death, and this was a bad omen. At Krishna's suggestion, the Wresnis, Yadavas and Andhakas made a holy journey to Prabhastirtha, and they performed a ceremony on the shore. On the beach, the Wresni, Andhaka and Yadawa could not get rid of their bad habit, which is drinking alcohol until they get drunk. In a drunken state, Satyaki said, "Kertawarma, what kind of knight are you? In Bharatayuddha earlier, you killed the princes of Dropadi, including Drestadyumna and Srikandi in their sleep. What kind of deeds did you do?". The speech was met with applause from Pradyumna, which meant that he supported Satyaki's opinion. Kertawarma got angry and said, "You are also cruel, killing the unarmed Burisrawa, who was leaving the battlefield to recover his energy". After throwing insults at each other, they had a big fight. Satyaki took a sword and beheaded Kertawarma in front of Krishna. Seeing that, the Wresni got angry and attacked Satyaki. Prince Rukmini became fierce, then helped Satyaki. After some time, the two mighty knights died in front of Krishna.

Then everyone fights with each other, using anything as a weapon, including the eruka plant that grows around the place. When removed, the leaves of the plant turn into weapons as sharp as swords. By using this weapon, the descendants of Wresni, Andhaka, and Yadu killed each other. No matter friend or foe, even father and son kill each other. Surprisingly, no one intends to leave the place. With his own eyes, Krishna realized that his people were moved by the destiny of their destruction. Pulling the pain, he pulled out a handful of grass and turned it into a weapon that could explode at any time. After his sons and relatives died, he threw the weapon in his hand toward the Wadni and Yadawa who were fighting. The weapon exploded and ended their history. Finally, the descendants of Wresni, Andhaka and Yadu all died at Prabhasatirtha, and was witnessed by Krishna. Only the women and a few warriors are still alive, such as Babhru and Bajra. Krishna knew that he was able to get rid of the brahmin's curse that resulted in the destruction of his nation, but he did not want to change Gandari's curse and the course of destiny. After witnessing the destruction of the Wresni, Yadawa, and Andhaka people with his own eyes, Krishna follows Baladewa who is meditating in the forest. Babhru was ordered to protect the surviving women, while Daruka was ordered to tell the news of the destruction of Krishna's people to King Yudistira in Hastinapura. In the forest, Baladewa died in his meditation. Then dragons come out of his mouth and this dragon enters the ocean to join the other dragons. After witnessing the departure of his brother, Kresna remembers all the events that have befallen his people. As he lay under a tree, a hunter named Jara (accidentally) killed him with an arrow from a piece of iron coming from a mosala gun inside a crushed fish.

When he realized that the arrows were not a deer, Jara asked ma'af for Krishna. Krishna smiled and said, "Whatever was going to happen has happened. I've finished my life". Before Krishna's death, a friend of Krishna named Daruka was sent to go to Hastinapura, to inform Kuru's descendants that the Wresni, Andhaka, and Yadawa Houses had been destroyed. After Kresna's death, Dwaraka began to be abandoned by his inhabitants. When Daruka arrived in Hastinapura, he immediately informed the Kuru descendants that Yadu's descendants in the Dwaraka Kingdom had perished due to civil war. Some of them still survive with a number of women. After hearing the sad news, Arjuna bid farewell to visit his maternal uncle, Basudewa. Accompanied by Daruka, he went to Dwaraka. Arriving at Dwaraka, Arjuna saw that the city was deserted. He also met widows abandoned by their husbands, who wailed and begged Arjuna to protect them. Then Arjuna met Basudewa who was limp. After telling Arjuna his disappointment, Basudewa died. In accordance with the mandate given to him, Arjuna invited the women and several knights to flee to Kurukshetra. Because according to Sri Kresna's last message, the city of Dwaraka will be swept away by ocean waves, seven days after he dies. On the way to Kurukshetra, Arjuna's party was ambushed by a band of robbers. Surprisingly, Arjuna's strength vanished when he faced the robber. He was aware that the destiny of annihilation was in motion. In the end several people were rescued but many treasures and women were lost. In Kurukshetra, the Yadavas are led by Bajra. After regretting what had happened to him, Arjuna met his grandfather, Resi Byasa. On his advice, the Pandava and Dropadi decided to take a holy journey to leave worldly life.

The editor page has logged out learn more Condensation is the change of state of matter to a more dense state, such as a gas (or vapor) to a liquid. Condensation occurs when a vapor is cooled to a liquid, but it can also occur when a vapor is compressed (that is, the pressure is increased) to a liquid, or it undergoes a combination of cooling and compression. The liquid that has condensed from the vapor is called condensate. A device used to condense vapor into a liquid is called a condenser. A condenser is generally a cooler or heat exchanger that is used for various purposes, has a variety of designs, and many sizes from hand-held to very large. Condensation of vapor into a liquid is the opposite of evaporation and is an exothermic (heat-releasing) process. The water that shows up on the outside of a cold glass of water on a hot day is condensation. Water vapor in the air that naturally condenses on cold surfaces is called dew. Water vapor will only condense on a surface if the surface has a lower dew point than water vapor, or water vapor has reached an equilibrium in the air, such as saturated humidity. The air dew point is the temperature that must be reached so that condensation begins to occur in the air. Water molecules take some of the heat from the air. As a result, the temperature of the atmosphere will drop slightly. In the atmosphere, it is the condensation of water vapor that causes clouds to form. Small water molecules in large quantities will become water droplets due to the influence of temperature, and can fall to earth as rain. This is what is called the water cycle. Precipitation or sublimation is also a form of condensation. Precipitation is the direct formation of ice from water vapor, for example snow. This chemistry-related article is a stub.

The editor page has logged out learn more Nālānda is the name of an ancient temple and center of learning in India. The name Nālānda comes from Sanskrit and means giver of knowledge, (possibly from nalam, a lotus flower, a symbol of knowledge and da, to give). A Chinese monk, Xuanzang, who had made a pilgrimage to the place, gave several versions of the explanation regarding the naming of Nālandā. Nalanda is located about 55 miles southeast of Patna City, and was the center of Buddhist education from 427 to 1197 AD under the rule of the Pala Kingdom. Nālanda was identified by Alexander Cunningham with Baragaon Village. The Buddha is mentioned several times spending the night at Nalanda. According to the Kevatta Sutta, during the time of Gautama Buddha Nālandā had become a place of influence and prosperity. There is a record in the Samyutta Nikaya, regarding the city having experienced several times of famine. Sāriputta, a disciple of the Buddha, was born and died at Nālandā. Nālandā is also the home of Sonnadinnā. Mahavira is mentioned several times as staying at Nalanda. It is also said that Mahavisa attained Moksha at Pavapuri, which is located at Nalanda. King Asoka (250 BC) is said to have built a temple there. According to Tibetan sources, Nagarjuna taught there. According to historical data, Nalanda University was founded in 450 AD under the orders of several Gupta kings, most notably Kumaragupta. Nalanda was one of the world's first residential universities. In its heyday, the university accommodated more than 10,000 students and 2,000 teachers. This university is considered a masterpiece of architecture. Nalanda has eight separate gated gardens and ten temples, along with several meditation halls and classes. The library is located in a nine story building where many books are written here.

The subjects taught at Nalanda University cover all fields of study, and have attracted students and scholars from Korea, Japan, China, Tibet, Indonesia, Persia and Turkey. A number of teachings that are now considered Vajrayana teachings have their roots in traditions and teachings at Nalanda (late 9th to 12th centuries). Other schools of Buddhism, such as the Mahayana school, also originate from this university. Theravada tradition is also taught at Nalanda University, but Theravada teachings were not developed further at Nalanda. Due to the loss of influence of Buddhism in India in the 12th century, the university went into decline. In 1193, Nalanda University finally fell into ruins after being destroyed by a Muslim army under the command of Bakhtiyar Khalji; this event is considered to be the final end of the destruction of Buddhism in India. It is also said that Khalji asked where the Koran was at Nalanda University before destroying the university. When the Tibetan translator Chag Lotsawa visited the university in 1235, it was already in a state of disrepair, but still survived a small group of monks. Several ruined buildings have survived, near the Surya Mandir, a Hindu temple. The re-excavated ruins have an arena area of ​​150,000 m2, compared to Xuanzang's accounts of the area of ​​Nalanda, it is estimated that nearly 90% of the university has not been excavated. Nālandā is now no longer occupied. The nearest population center is in a village called Bargaon. In 1951, a center for modern Theravada education was founded nearby by Bhikkhu Jagdish Kashyap, named Nava Nalanda Mahavihara. The Nalanda Museum houses a number of manuscripts and displays some excavated historical items. On December 9, 2006, the New York Times reported on plans detailing the $1 billion redevelopment of Nalanda University near the ancient site.

Editor pages that have logged out learn more ντ (Tau neutrino): Mid 1970s A neutrino is an elementary particle that has neither mass nor electric charge. Neutrinos have a spin of 1/2 and are therefore fermions. It has a very small mass, although recent experiments (see Super-Kamiokande) show that it is not exactly zero. Neutrinos interact only through weak and gravitational interactions, neither through strong interactions nor electromagnetic interactions. A neutrino is a subatomic particle that is very similar to an electron, but has no electrical charge and a very small mass, which might even be zero. Neutrinos are one of the most abundant particles in the universe. Because they have very little interaction with matter, however, they are incredibly difficult to detect. To detect neutrinos, very large and very sensitive detectors are required. Typically, a low-energy neutrino will travel through many light-years of normal matter before interacting with anything. Consequently, all terrestrial neutrino experiments rely on measuring the tiny fraction of neutrinos that interact in reasonably sized detectors. For example, at the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory, a 1000 ton heavy water solar-neutrino detector picks up about 1012 neutrinos every second. About 30 neutrinos per day are detected. Neutrinos are created as a result of certain types of radioactive decay or as a result of nuclear reactions such as those that occur in the Sun, in nuclear reactors, or when cosmic rays strike a group of atoms. There are three types (or "flavors)" of neutrinos: electron neutrinos, muon neutrinos, and tauon neutrinos (or tau neutrinos); and each type also has a corresponding antiparticle, called an antineutrino.

Electron neutrinos (or antineutrinos) are produced when a proton changes to a neutron (or a neutron to a proton), which are two forms of beta decay. Interactions involving neutrinos are mediated through the weak interaction process. Because in the weak interaction process the nuclear cross section is very small, neutrinos can pass through matter almost unhindered. For typical neutrinos generated inside the Sun (with an energy of a few MeV) it would take about a light year (~1016m) of lead to block half of the amount. Neutrinos were first postulated in December, 1930 by Wolfgang Pauli to describe the energy spectrum of beta decay, the decay of a neutron into a proton and an electron. Pauli theorized that an undetected particle was responsible for the difference between the energy and angular momentum of the particles at the beginning and end of the decay. Due to its "ghost" nature, the first experimental detection of neutrinos had to wait 25 years since it was first discussed. In 1956, Clyde Cowan, Frederick Reines, F. B. Harrison, H. W. Kruse, and A. D. McGuire published the article "Detection of the Free Neutrino: a Confirmation" in the journal Science (see neutrino experiment), a result which was awarded the 1995 Nobel Prize. is a sub-atomic particle claimed by scientists at the CERN nuclear research center, based on recent research in Geneva, that neutrinos move faster than the speed of light, so that with this finding it breaks the laws of physics that have been established for more than 100 years, Einstein with his theory of relativity once said that if one day a new particle is discovered that can exceed the speed of light, then the theory of relativity will automatically be invalidated. The neutrino experiment was carried out at a distance of 730 km between the source in Geneva and the detector located in an underground laboratory in Italy.

In Judaism and Christianity, this figure is called Elisha. And Ishmael, Alyasa', Yunus, and Lut. Each of us increased (his rank) above other people (at his time), (and We also increased the rank) of some of their ancestors, their descendants and their brothers. We have chosen them (to be Prophets and Messengers) and We have guided them to the straight path. When the group of prophets from Jericho saw him from afar, they said, 'The spirit of Elijah has landed on Elisha.' They came to meet him, then they bowed down to him to the ground. The name Ilyasa' is mentioned in the Qur'an (Islamic holy book) twice.a] In the Tanakh (Jewish holy book) and the Bible (Christian holy book), Ilyasa' (called Elisha in Jewish and Christian) is mentioned in 1 Kings -Kings (M'lakhim) 19 and 2 Kings 2-13. The Bible mentions that Ilyasa' lived in the Kingdom of Samaria in the 8th century BC and acted as a prophet during the reign of King Joram, Jehu, Joahas, and Joash. He was a disciple of Ilyas and his successor as a prophet of the Children of Israel. The Bible mentions that Ilyasa' came from Abel-Meholah, a city next to the Jordan River. His genealogy is Ilyasa' bin Safat. There are several opinions from scholars regarding Ilyasa's family background. Muhammad bin Ishaq mentions that his genealogy is Ilyasa' bin Ukhtub. Ibn Asakir believes that he is a descendant of Ephraim bin Yusuf bin Ya'qub. Another testimony states that he is Ilyas' cousin. It is said that when Ilyas was on Mount Sinai after escaping from the pursuit of Queen Jezebel, God revealed to him to appoint Ilyas' as his successor in carrying out his prophetic duties.

When Ilyasa' was plowing in the field, Ilyas spread his cloak to Ilyasa'. So then Ilyasa' followed Ilyas and became his student and companion. The Qur'an does not mention the story of Ilyasa' and only briefly mentions his name. The Bible mentions the story of Ilyasa' which is full of miracles. Some of Ilyasa' miracles are related to healing and illness. It is said that the people of Jericho complained to Ilyasa' that their water was not good because it could cause pregnant women to miscarry. Ilyasa' then purified the water by throwing salt into the water source. While cooking with his students, one of them put a wild pumpkin in the pan, not knowing that it was poisonous. Ilyasa' ordered to put the flour in the pan and the food in the pan became safe to eat. Once, a rich woman in Shunem entertained Ilyasa' at her residence. Since then, Ilyasa' always visited his house when he was in Sunem. The woman was so convinced that Ilyasa' was a pious servant of God, that she and her husband made a special room for Ilyasa' to stay when he was in Sunem. Ilyasa' prayed that the woman would have a son and that the woman would actually give birth to a son the following year. When the woman's son was sick and died, Ilyasa' brought him back to life. Naaman, a commander from the Kingdom of Aram in Syria, asked Ilyasa' for healing from his leprosy. Ilyasa' told him to bathe in the Jordan River seven times and Naaman was healed. Ilyasa' refused the gift from Naaman and Naaman finally declared that he would worship God alone, abandoning his old gods. But Ilyasa's servant named Gehazi asked for a gift from Naaman without his master's knowledge. Gehazi then contracted leprosy because of Ilyasa's prayer. Ilyasa' is also recorded as blessing food until it becomes abundant.

There was a widow who was in debt and her children were to be made slaves in her place, even though she had nothing to sell but a small bottle of olive oil. Ilyasa' ordered the woman to go and borrow the empty bottles, then pour olive oil from the small bottle into each of the other bottles. The bottles became full of olive oil and were then sold by the widow to pay off the debt. Ilyasa' also ordered the waiter to feed a hundred people with only twenty loaves of bread and still have leftovers. It is also mentioned that Ilyasa' can know some of the upcoming events or know some secret things. When the Kingdom of Samaria was at war with the Kingdom of Aram, Ilyasa' informed the various strategies of the Aram side to Yoram, the King of Samaria at the time. The Arameans then sent a group of soldiers to capture Ilyasa', but they all became blind. Ilyasa' then led them to the capital of Samaria. Yoram initially wanted to kill them, but in the end he feasted and then sent them back because of Ilyasa's advice. But then Benhadad, the King of Aram at that time, ordered the siege of the capital of Samaria, causing a great famine to strike Samaria. Food prices skyrocketed, even to the point of cannibalism in the community. Yoram blamed Ilyasa' for this incident and tried to kill him. But Ilyasa' stated that the price of wheat will be very cheap. Yoram's personal guard did not believe it, but Ilyasa' remained firm with his statement, while adding that the guard would not enjoy the wheat. Outside the city, the Aram soldiers who besieged the city heard the roar of the army and thought that the army from Egypt had arrived to help the Samaritans, even though the sound was a miracle from God. The Aramean soldiers then ended the siege and fled, abandoning their camp along with their supplies of wheat, horses, and donkeys.

Knowing that, the townspeople flocked out to loot the contents of the camp. The king's guards who doubted Ilyasa's words were trampled to death by citizens while guarding the city gates. When he found out that Ilyasa' was in Damascus, Benhadad who was ill ordered his commander named Hazael to meet Ilyasa' and ask about his recovery. Ilyasa' said that Benhadad would die and Hazael would become king. When he returned, Hazael told Benhadad that he would recover. The next day, Hazael covered Benhadad's face with a wet cloth until he suffocated. Hazael then replaced him as king. The Bible also records Elijah's other miracles. Ilyasa' struck Ilyas' robe to the Jordan River and the water of the river split in two, forming a path in the middle that was used to cross. When there was a group of children trying to chase away Ilyasa', two she-bears suddenly appeared and tore the children to pieces. When the combined forces of the Kingdom of Samaria, Judah, and Edom ran out of water on their way to attack the Kingdom of Moab, Ilyasa' ordered the combined forces to dig trenches in the wadi and stated that the water would fill the wadi even if there was no rain. The next day, water from the direction of Edom flowed to fill the wadi as Ilyasa said. When one of his students dropped an ax point into the river, Ilyasa' threw a piece of wood where the ax sank, then the ax appeared and floated on the surface of the water. Ibn Jarir and Ibn Abi Hatim narrate that after Ilyasa' was old, he looked for someone who could continue guiding the community. He then gathered the people to find his successor among them, on the condition that he could always fast during the day, worship at night, and not get angry. A man who was considered contemptible volunteered, but Ilyasa' rejected the person's willingness.

Then another man volunteered and Ilyasa' accepted him. The man in this story is often identified as Dzulkifli. This story is not found in the Qur'an, nor is the information that states that he is Dzulkifli. The identity of Dzulkifli himself is also still debated and there are different opinions about this problem. Ilyasa' is a prophet in Islam. The Qur'an mentions his name twice, both mentioned together with other prophets. Ilyasa' is mentioned as a figure whose rank is higher than other people (Arabic: فَضَّلْنَا عَلَى ٱلْعَالَمِين‎ faḍḍalnā ʿalā l-ʿālamīna) and among the best people (Arabic: مِنَ ٱلْأَخْيَار‎ mina ’l-akhyāri). The Qur'an does not mention his story and scholars usually quote from Jewish and Christian sources. Ilyasa' is revered as a saint in a number of Christian Churches. The feast day is on June 14 in the Eastern Orthodox Church and the Eastern Catholic liturgical calendar (for churches using the traditional Julian calendar, June 14 falls on June 27 of the modern Gregorian calendar). John of Damascus compiled a canon in honor of Ilyasa' and a church was built in Constantinople in his honor. In Western Christianity he is commemorated in the calendar of the saints of Carmel, a Catholic religious order, following a decree of the General Chapter of Carmel in 1399. He is also commemorated as a prophet in the Calendar of Saints of the Lutheran Church - Missouri Synod. Both calendars also celebrate it on June 14. Both Orthodox Catholics and Roman Catholics believe that he did not marry and lived a celibate life. The Roman Emperor Julianus (ruled 361-363) gave the order to burn the relics of Prophet Ilyasa', Obadiah, and Yahya (John the Baptist) who were buried next to each other in Sebastia (West Bank), but were saved by Christians, and some of the relics were moved to Alexandria.

The roots of this language were originally thought to be from the Khari Boli language spoken by the inhabitants of the city of New Delhi. The origin of this language has many versions, one of which is that the year 413-583 Hijri was a time when Muslim people who spoke Persian and Turkish began to migrate to mainland Hindustan, especially the Punjab. These immigrants consisted of soldiers and scholars. Scholars began to spread Islamic teachings to this area at the same time. Mixed marriages between migrants from Persia and local residents also occurred. Until finally, there was a mixture of Persian and Punjabi which became the forerunner to the birth of Urdu. There is another version which reveals that during the transfer of power of Qutubuddin Aibak from Lahore to New Delhi in 1193 it also caused interaction between the rulers and local residents so that a language called Urdu appeared. Other Urdu names: Dakhini (Dakani, Deccan, Desia, Mirgan), Pinjari, Rekhta (Rekhti). In southern India the name changed to Dakhini, while in southwest India it became Gurjari. In New Delhi the name changed from Hindi to Hindavi and Hindustani. This language is used by approximately 100 million Muslim communities in Pakistan and India. Urdu is actually similar to Hindi, due to the same roots, namely from Sanskrit which is the mother of all languages ​​in this subcontinent. The number of native speakers of Urdu currently reaches 60,290,000 people and 104,000,000 people including those who use it as a second language (1999).

Apart from the two countries above, Urdu is also used by around 600 thousand Bihar Muslims who live in refugee camps in Bangladesh.
