The editor page has logged out learn more Optics is the branch of physics that describes the behavior and properties of light and the interaction of light with matter. Optics illuminates and is colored by optical phenomena. The word optics comes from the Latin ὀπτική, which means view. The field of optics usually describes the properties of visible, infrared and ultraviolet light; but since light is an electromagnetic wave, the same phenomena occur in X-rays, microwaves, radio waves, and other forms of electromagnetic radiation and the same phenomena as in a charged beam. Optics can generally be thought of as a subset of electromagnetism. Several optical phenomena depend on the quantum nature of light which is related to various fields from optics to quantum mechanics. In practice, most of the optical phenomena can be calculated using the electromagnetic properties of light, as described by Maxwell's equations. The field of optics has its own identity, society and conference. The scientific aspect is often called optical science or optical physics. Applied optical science is often called optical engineering. The application of optical engineering related specifically to illumination systems is called lighting engineering. Each discipline tends to differ slightly in its application, technical skills, focus and professional affiliation. More recent innovations in optical engineering are often categorized as photonics or optoelectronics. The boundaries between this field and "optics" are often blurred, and the terms are used differently in different parts of the world and in different fields of industry. Because of the wide application of "light" science to real-world applications, the fields of optical science and optical engineering tend to be highly cross-disciplinary. Optics is part of a variety of related disciplines including electrical engineering, physics, psychology, medicine (particularly ophthalmology and optometry), and others.

Also, the most complete description of optical behavior, as described in physics, is not necessarily complicated for most problems, so simple models can be used. This simple model is sufficient to account for some optical phenomena and ignore irrelevant and/or undetectable behavior on a system. In free space a wave travels at c = 3×108 meters/second. When entering a particular medium (dielectric or nonconducting) the waves travel with a speed v, which is characteristic of the material and is less than the speed of light itself (c). The ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to the speed of light in a medium is the index of refraction n of a material as follows: n = ​c⁄v Before quantum optics became important, its roots consisted of classical electromagnetic applications and high-frequency approaches to light. Classical optics is divided into two main branches: geometric optics and physical optics. Geometric optics, or ray optics, describes the propagation of light in terms of "rays". Light is deflected at the interface between two different media, and can take a curved shape in the medium where the index of refraction is a function of position. A "ray" in geometric optics is an abstract object, or "instrument," parallel to the wavefront of the actual optical wave. Geometric optics provides rules for the propagation of these rays through an optical system, which indicate how the wavefronts will actually propagate. This is a significant optical simplification, and fails to account for many important optical effects such as diffraction and polarization. This is a good approximation, however, if the wavelength of the light is very small compared to the size of the structures it interacts with. Geometric optics can be used to describe geometric aspects of imaging, including optical aberrations.

Geometric optics is often simplified further by the paraxial approximation, or "small-angle approximation." The mathematical behavior then becomes linear, allowing optical components and systems to be described in simple matrix form. This led to the techniques of Gaussian optics and paraxial ray tracing, which are used for first-order optical systems, such as estimating the position and magnification of images and objects. Gaussian beam propagation is an extension of paraxial optics which provides a more accurate model of coherent radiation such as laser beams. While still using a paraxial approximation, this technique takes diffraction into account, and allows calculation of the magnification of the laser beam proportional to the distance, as well as the minimum size of the beam that can be focused. Gaussian beam propagation bridges the gap between geometrical and physical optics. Physical optics or wave optics builds on the Huygens principle and models the propagation of complex wavefronts through an optical system, including the amplitude and phase of the waves. This technique, which is usually applied numerically on a computer, can calculate the effects of diffraction, interference, polarization, and other complex effects. However, in general the approximation is still used, so it does not completely model the electromagnetic wave theory of light propagation. Such a complete model is much more computationally demanding, but can be used to solve small problems that require more accurate solving. Modern optics encompasses the fields of optical science and engineering that came to prominence in the 20th century. These fields of optical science are usually concerned with the electromagnetic or quantum properties of light but do not include other topics. Optics are part of everyday life. Rainbows and shadows are examples of optical phenomena. Many people benefit from eyeglasses or contact lenses, and optics are used in many consumer goods including cameras.

This thing is judged by its usefulness for human action for life. The statement can be in the form of speech, proposition or theory. Pragmatism emerges as a tradition of thought originating in the West and developing especially in America. Its presence as a thought that seeks to answer the problems of human life. Pragmatism is classified as one of the 19th century philosophical schools in the history of Western philosophy. The pioneer of pragmatism thought was a philosopher from the United States named Chales Sanders Peirce (1839–1914). Influential figures in pragmatist thinking include William James (1842–1910) and John Dewey (1859–1952). The idea of ​​pragmatism was first put forward by Charles Sanders Peirce in the early 1870s at a meeting of a philosophical group called the Metaphysical Club. The meeting was held in Cambridge, Massachusetts informally. The discussion results from the meeting were written by Peirce into two articles entitled The Fixation of Belief (1877) and How to Make Our Ideas Clear (1878). Both of these articles were published in a magazine called Popular Science Monthly. The term "pragmatism" comes from the Greek, namely from the word pragma. This word has many meanings, including facts, objects, material, something that is made, activities, actions, results or work. From this collection of meanings, pragmatism is defined as a thought that prioritizes the function of ideas in action. On the other hand, the term "pragmatism" was obtained by Charles Sanders Peirce from the philosophical thoughts of Immanuel Kant. In Kant's thought there are two similar words with different meanings, namelypracticch and pragmatisch. These two words come from the Greek, namelypracticos and pragmatikos.

The term practicch is defined as an action carried out for his own sake. This type of action is not found in actual experience, but exists only in reason and intellect. Meanwhile, the term pragmatisch is defined as a movement produced by the human will to provide a definitive goal as an important stage for explaining thoughts correctly. Pragmatism becomes the logic of observation as its rationale. This view states that the reality of the world seen by humans is facts that are real, separate from one another and individual. The world is shown as is, so differences can be taken for granted. The manifestation of reality is always personal and not a public fact because it only arises from the human mind. The function of service and usability becomes a means of justifying an idea. Pragmatism does not discuss the philosophical study of truth, especially with regard to metaphysics. Pragmatism is a philosophical school that assesses the truth of a theory or belief based on its level of success or benefit in practical application. The main problem for pragmatism is about the usefulness of knowledge, not the nature of knowledge. This view is based on the idea that knowledge is a means of action. Pragmatism solves theoretical and practical problems in human life by relying on the use of reason. John Dewey is one of the most influential figures in pragmatist thought. The pragmatic thinking developed by Dewey is also known as experimentalism. This naming comes from his thinking which states that human growth is the goal of education. He calls it growth because he thinks that everything in this world is always changing. John Dewey's pragmatic thinking became one of the thoughts that influenced the start of mass education. William James (1842–1910) was one of the figures who studied the human way of overcoming life's problems in the form of industrialization and economic growth.

Another figure who studied the same problem was Karl Marx (1818–1883), who later became the pioneer of socialism. James is an adherent of relativism which produces pragmatic thinking on the American continent. This pragmatism is defined as a practicality and usefulness so that the criteria of truth are given to everything that can make everything workable. James believes that it is humans who create the truth so that the truth resides within humans. This pragmatism truth criterion has an impact on the world of business and politics in America. Pragmatism thinking makes socialism not develop in America. Max Scheler criticized pragmatism in his work entitled Erkenntnis und Arbeit. This book was first published in 1926. In Scheler's view, pragmatism failed to think about the deep relationships between human individuals and other individuals. This is marked by the absence of studies on the transcendence of love. He argues that pragmatism is only a method of thinking that focuses entirely on the desire to dominate nature. Pragmatism is an important thought for vocational education. In pragmatism, something is considered important based on the level of its usefulness. The main question in pragmatism is about "for what" and not about "what". Pragmatism is concerned with the practical consequences of an action. In vocational education, pragmatism divides between theory and practice. In theory development, pragmatism provides the foundation for normative ethics. While in practical development, pragmatism fulfills human needs through vocational education which produces a professional workforce. The existence of a balance between theory and practice makes pragmatism prevent education from practical goals that are only materialism. Pragmatism also prevents education from losing its function as a means of meeting the needs of society. Pragmatism is a school of educational philosophy that underlies the development of another school of educational philosophy, namely progressivism.

The editor's page has logged out learn more Deconstruction is a thought to understand the contradictions that exist in the text and try to rebuild the meanings that are already embedded in the text. Thinking about deconstruction does not accept a text constantly according to the meaning of the text. Deconstruction thinking believes that a text must have hidden meanings and have different meanings. Therefore, deconstruction thinking requires a process of searching for meaning structurally from a single meaning that has been generally agreed upon by readers. In writing historical texts, researchers do not find all historical sources directly and completely. Meanwhile, the theory and methodology of historical writing continues to develop. Therefore the writing of history is often done again. So the deconstruction method in writing history is usually used, in order to achieve a truth that can be accounted for. Meanwhile, in the research of literary works, deconstruction is a type of literary criticism that distorts a meaning so that it becomes paradoxical. This is intended to know the overall content of the literary work in depth. The idea of ​​deconstruction was pioneered by Jacques Derrida. Deconstruction thinking is the key to postmodern thinking. Derrida considers that scientific theory develops rigidly, so that it cannot be refuted. Derrida's thinking assumes that a science can be reviewed, its truth is not absolute, and its truth must be proven. Deconstruction is an approach to thinking developed by postmodernism. Deconstruction thinking uses social theory to understand history. For deconstruction thinkers, historical writings are equated with language works. This thought was born from a philosopher named Derrida. He developed his thoughts first in France, then continued to develop to the United States.

The editor page logged out learn more Nature (in a broad sense equivalent to the natural world, the physical world, or the material world) refers to the phenomena of the physical world as well as to life in general. The scale of nature extends from subatomic to cosmic. The study of nature is a large part of science. Although humans are part of nature, human activities are often understood as a separate category from other natural phenomena. The word nature is a translation of the English "nature", which comes from the Latin natura, or "essential quality, innate disposition", and in ancient times, literally means "birth". Natura is the Latin translation of the Greek word physis (φύσις), which originally related to the innate characteristics that plants, animals, and various other features of the world have. The concept of nature as a whole, or the physical universe, is an extension of the original concept; it began with the application of the Greek word physis (φύσις) by pre-Socratic philosophers, and has continued to grow ever since. This word was also used a lot during the emergence of the modern scientific method in the last few centuries. In the various uses of the word today, "nature" often refers to geology and wildlife. The word nature may refer generally to various kinds of living plants and animals, and in some cases to processes related to inanimate matter – to the existence of certain types of matter and how they change by themselves, such as the weather and geology on Earth, and matter. and the energy from which all these things are composed of. This word is often used to mean the "natural environment" or wild animals, rocks, forests, beaches, and in general those things which have not been substantially altered by human intervention, or which have survived despite human intervention.

For example, manufactured objects and human interaction are not generally considered part of nature, unless they are valued as, for example, "human nature" or "the whole of nature". This more traditional concept of natural things, which can still be found today, implies a distinction between the natural and the artificial, in that the artificial is understood as the product of human consciousness or thought. Depending on the particular context, the term "natural" can also be distinguished from the unnatural, the supernatural, or the synthetic. Earth is the only planet known today that can support life, and its natural features are the subject of many areas of scientific research. In the Solar System, it is the third closest planet to the Sun, the largest terrestrial planet and the fifth largest planet overall. The most prominent climatic features are two large polar regions, two narrow temperate zones, and a wide equatorial tropical to sub-tropical region. Rainfall varies greatly with location, from a few meters of water per year to less than a millimeter. 71% of the earth's surface is covered by oceans of salt water. The remainder consists of continents and islands, with most of the inhabited land in the Northern Hemisphere. Earth has evolved through geological and biological processes that have left traces of the original conditions. The outer surface is divided into several tectonic plates which migrate gradually. The interior remains active, with a thick layer of plastic mantle and a core full of iron that generates a magnetic field. Life has altered the state of Earth's atmosphere, which creates an ecological balance that stabilizes surface conditions. Although there are regional variations in climate due to latitude and other geographic factors, the long-term average global climate is quite stable during interglacial periods, and variations of a degree or two in mean global temperature have historically had a large effect on the ecological balance, and on environmental conditions. actual geography of the Earth.

Geology is the science and study of the solid and liquid matter that forms the Earth. The field of geology includes the study of the composition, structure, physical properties, dynamics, and history of the materials that make up Earth, and the processes by which these materials form, move, and change. This field is a major scientific discipline, and is also important for mineral and hydrocarbon mining, knowledge of and mitigation of natural disasters, some fields of geotechnical engineering, and understanding past climates and environments. The geology of an area evolves over time as rock units are deposited and embedded, and deformational processes change their shape and location. The rock units are placed either by deposition onto the surface or intrusion into the overlying rock. Deposition can occur when sediments settle to the surface of the earth and then lithify into sedimentary rock, or when volcanic materials such as volcanic ash and lava flows blanket the surface. Intrusive igneous rocks such as batholiths and laccoliths push overlying rocks, and crystallize when they intrude. After the initial sequence of rocks has been deposited, the rock units can undergo deformation and/or metamorphosis. Deformation usually occurs as a result of horizontal shortening, horizontal extension, or side-to-side movement (strike-slip). These structural modes are generally related to convergent boundaries, divergent boundaries, and changing boundaries, respectively, between plate tectonics. Earth is thought to have formed 4.54 billion years ago from the solar nebula, along with the Sun and other planets. The moon formed about 20 million years later. Originally liquid, Earth's outer layers cooled and formed a solid crust. Gas eruptions and volcanic activity produced the primordial atmosphere. The condensation of water vapor, most or all of which comes from ice carried by comets, produces the oceans and other sources of water.

High-energy chemical processes are believed to have produced a molecule capable of self-replicating some 4 billion years ago. Continents formed, then scattered and reformed as the Earth's surface went through a process of formation over hundreds of millions of years, sometimes several of them coming together to form a supercontinent. About 750 million years ago, the earliest known supercontinent Rodinia began to break apart. The continents then regrouped to form Pannotia which broke up about 540 million years ago, and finally Pangea which broke apart about 180 million years ago. There is significant evidence that glacial activity during the Neoproterozoic era resulted in large parts of the planet being covered in ice. This hypothesis is referred to as the "Snowball Earth" and is interesting because it predates the Cambrian eruption, which was the event when multicellular life forms began to proliferate about 530-540 million years ago. Since the Cambrian explosion there have been at least five mass extinctions. The last mass extinction occurred about 65 million years ago, when a meteorite impact likely triggered the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs and other large reptiles, but not the small animals such as mammals, which later resembled shrews. Over the last 65 million years, mammalian life has diversified. Several million years ago, a species of small African ape managed to acquire the ability to stand upright. Then came human life and the further development of agriculture and civilization allowed humans to impact the Earth more quickly than any previous form of life. Civilizations have influenced the nature and quantity of other organisms and influenced the global climate. In comparison, the Great Oxygenation Event, which was produced by the spread of algae during the Siderian period, took about 300 million years to reach its peak.

The current era is classified as part of the Holocene mass extinction event, which was the fastest-paced extinction event. Some, such as Harvard University's E. O. Wilson, estimate that human destruction of the biosphere could lead to the extinction of one-half of all species within the next 100 years. The outbreak of extinction events is currently being researched, debated and accounted for by biologists. Earth's atmosphere plays an important role in maintaining the planet's ecosystem. The thin layer of gas that surrounds the Earth is held back by the planet's gravity. Dry air is composed of 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, 1% argon and other inert gases, carbon dioxide, etc., but air also contains a variable amount of water vapor. Atmospheric pressure decreases with altitude, and has a scaled height of about 8 kilometers at the Earth's surface: the height at which atmospheric pressure has decreased by a factor of e (a mathematical constant equal to 2.71 ...). The ozone layer in Earth's atmosphere plays an important role in filtering out the amount of ultraviolet (UV) radiation that reaches the surface. Because DNA is easily damaged by UV rays, the ozone layer serves to protect life on the surface. The atmosphere also retains heat during the night, thereby reducing daily temperature extremes. Terrestrial weather occurs almost exclusively in the lower atmosphere, and functions as a convective system for distributing heat. Ocean currents are another important factor in determining climate, in particular the underwater thermohaline circulation which distributes heat energy from the equatorial oceans to the polar regions. These currents help to moderate the temperature difference between winter and summer in the temperate zone. Also, without the redistribution of heat energy by oceanic and atmospheric currents, the tropics would be much hotter, and the polar regions much colder.

Both beneficial and harmful influences can be caused by the weather. Extremes in weather such as tornadoes, hurricanes and hurricanes can discharge a great deal of energy in their path and result in devastation. Surface vegetation has evolved to depend on seasonal variations in the weather, and sudden changes lasting only a few years can have dramatic effects on both the plants and animals that depend on growth for their food. The planet's climate is a parameter of long-term trends in weather. Various factors are known to influence climate, including ocean currents, surface albedo, greenhouse gases, variations in sunlight, and changes in the planet's orbit. Based on historical records, Earth is known to have experienced drastic climate changes in the past, including ice ages. Several factors (especially latitude) affect the climate in an area. Latitudes with the same climatic attributes form climatic regions. There are a number of such areas, ranging from tropical climates at the equator to arctic climates in the far north and south. Weather is also affected by the seasons, which result from the Earth's axis being tilted relative to its orbital plane. So, at any given time during the summer or winter, one part of the planet is exposed to more direct sunlight. This exposure to the sun occurs alternately as long as the Earth rotates in its orbit. At any given time, regardless of the season, the northern and southern hemispheres experience opposite seasons. Weather is a chaotic system that can be modified by small changes in the environment, so accurate forecasts are currently limited to a few days. Overall, two things are currently happening around the world: (1) temperatures are increasing on average; and (2) the climate of the region has experienced a marked change.

Water is a chemical substance composed of hydrogen and oxygen and is essential for all forms of life known so far. In common usage, the term water refers only to its liquid form or state, but the substance of water can also be in a solid state, i.e., ice, and in a gaseous state, such as water vapor or steam. Water covers 71% of the earth's surface. On Earth, water is found mostly in the oceans and large bodies of water, with 1.6% of the water underground in aquifers and 0.001% in the air as vapor, clouds (formed from solid and liquid water particles suspended in the air), and rainfall. Ninety-seven percent of the water on the surface is in the oceans, meanwhile in glaciers and polar ice caps there are as much as 2.4%, and other surface water such as rivers, lakes and ponds 0.6%. In addition, some of the earth's water is also contained in biological bodies and various products. Oceans or seas are the largest collection of salt water and the main component of the hydrosphere. About 71% of the earth's surface (an area of ​​about 361 million square kilometers) is covered by oceans, which are a continuous body of water that is commonly divided into several main oceans and smaller seas. More than half of the area is more than 3,000 meters (9,800 feet) deep. The average recorded ocean salinity is around 35 ppt (3.5%), and almost all seawater has a salinity that ranges from 30 to 38 ppt. Although generally recognized as 'separate' seas, this body of water comprises one global, interconnected body of salt water and is often referred to as the World Ocean or global oceans. The concept of the global ocean as a continuous body of water with relatively free exchange between its parts is of fundamental importance to oceanography.

The division of the great oceans is determined in part by the continents, the various islands, and other criteria: these are (in order of size) the Pacific Ocean, the Atlantic Ocean, the Indian Ocean, the Southern Ocean and the Arctic Ocean. Areas smaller than oceans are called seas, bays, and other names. There are also salt lakes, which are smaller collections of land salt water that are not connected to the World Ocean. Two notable examples of salt lakes are the Aral Sea and the Great Salt Lake. Lakes are a collection of liquids on the surface of the Earth that collect at the bottom of a basin and flow slowly when they do flow. On land, a body of water is considered a lake when it is inland, not part of an ocean, is larger and deeper than a pond, and is fed by a river. The world other than Earth known to have lakes is Titan, Saturn's largest moon, which has lakes of ethane, most likely mixed with methane. It is not known whether Titan's lakes are fed by rivers, although Titan's surface has many river channels. Natural lakes on Earth are commonly found in mountainous areas, rift zones, and areas with ongoing or recent glaciation. Other lakes are found in endorheic basins or along older river channels. In some parts of the world, there are many lakes due to chaotic drainage patterns during the last Ice Age. All lakes are transient on the geological time scale as they will slowly fill with sediment or spill out of the basin. A pond is a stagnant body of water, either natural or man-made, that is usually smaller than a lake. A wide variety of man-made bodies of water are classified as ponds, including water gardens designed for aesthetic ornamentation, fish ponds designed for commercial fish nurseries, and solar ponds designed to store thermal energy.

Ponds and lakes are distinguished from streams by the speed of the current. While the currents in rivers are easy to observe, ponds and lakes have both thermally driven micro-currents and moderate wind-driven currents. These features distinguish a pond from other water terrain features, such as tide pools and tide pools. A river is a natural body of water, usually fresh water, that flows into an ocean, lake, sea or other river. In some cases, a river flows into the ground or dries up completely before reaching another body of water. While small rivers may also be referred to by other names, including stream, stream, gullet, tributary, and rill, there is no general rule that defines what can be called a river. Many names for small rivers are specific to geographic location; one example is Burn in Scotland and North East England. Sometimes a river is said to be larger than a creek, but this is not always the case, due to ambiguity in the language. A river is part of the hydrologic cycle. Water in rivers is generally collected from precipitation through surface runoff, groundwater recharge, springs, and the release of stored water in natural ice and snowpacks (i.e., from glaciers). In the United States a stream is classified as a small river less than 60 feet (18 meters) wide. Streams are important as conduits in the water cycle, instruments for groundwater recharge, and pathways for fish and wildlife migration. The biological habitat in the area around the river flow is called the riparian zone. Given the status of the ongoing Holocene extinction, rivers are playing an important role in connecting corridors of fragmented habitats and thereby in conserving biodiversity.

The study of rivers and waterways in general involves many interdisciplinary branches of natural sciences and engineering, including hydrology, fluvial geomorphology, aquatic ecology, fish biology, riparian ecology and others. Ecosystems are made up of various abiotic and biotic components that function in an interconnected way. Its structure and composition are determined by various interrelated environmental factors. Variation of these factors will initiate dynamic changes to the ecosystem. Some of the more important components are: soil, atmosphere, solar radiation, water, and living organisms. The main idea in the ecosystem concept is that living organisms interact with every other element in their local environment. Eugene Odum, founder of the concept of ecology, stated: "Any unit that includes all the organisms (i.e.: a "community") in a given area that interact with the physical environment so that the flow of energy leads to trophic structure, biotic diversity, and material cycles (i.e. the exchange of materials between living and non-living parts) in a system constitutes an ecosystem." In ecosystems, species are connected and dependent on each other in the food chain and in the energy-material exchange between themselves and with their environment. The human ecosystem concept is based on the deconstruction of the human/nature dichotomy and the premise that all species are ecologically integrated with each other, as well as with the abiotic constituents of their biotopes. A smaller unit of an ecosystem is called a micro-ecosystem. For example, a micro-ecosystem could be a rock and all the life beneath it. A macro-ecosystem can involve an entire ecoregion with its watershed. Wildlife is generally defined as areas that have not been significantly modified by human activity. The Wild Foundation further defines wilderness as: "The most intact, undisturbed natural area remaining on our planet - the last, wildest places not controlled by humans and within which no roads, pipelines or other industrial infrastructure have been built."

Wilderness areas can be found in wildlife reserves, plantations, farms, conservation, farms, national forests, national parks and even in urban areas along rivers, or areas that are not developed. Wildlife areas and protected parks are considered important for the survival of certain species, ecological studies, conservation, solitude and recreation. Some authors believe that wilderness areas are essential to the human spirit and creativity, and some ecologists consider wilderness areas to be an integral part of the planet's self-sustaining natural ecosystems (biosphere). The wild can also protect the genetic traits they provide habitat for wild flora and fauna that might be difficult to reproduce in a zoo, arboretum or laboratory. Although there is no consensus on the definition of life, scientists generally accept that the features of life are organization, metabolism, growth, adaptation, response to stimuli and reproduction. Life can also be said to be merely a characteristic of organisms. A property common to terrestrial organisms (plants, animals, fungi, protists, archaea and bacteria) is that they are composed of cells, are carbon and water based with complex organization, possess metabolism, capacity to grow, respond to stimuli, and reproduce. An entity with this property is generally considered to be alive. However, not all definitions of life consider all of these traits to be important. An analogue of man-made life can also be considered as having life. The biosphere is the outermost part of the Earth - including land, surface rock, water, air and atmosphere - where life exists. From the broadest geophysical perspective, the biosphere is a global ecological system that integrates all living things and their relationships, including their interactions with the elements of the lithosphere (rock), hydrosphere (water), and atmosphere (air). Currently the entire earth contains more than 75 billion tons (150 trillion pounds or about 6.8 x 1013 kg) of biomass.

More than nine-tenths of the total biomass on Earth is plant (animal life largely depends on it). More than 2 million species of plants and animals have been identified to date, and estimates of the actual number of species present range from a few million to more than 50 million. The number of living species continues to exist in several streams, with new species appearing and others going extinct over time. The total number of species is currently in rapid decline. Life is only known to exist on planet Earth. The origin of life is still a poorly understood process, but it is thought to have occurred some 3.9 to 3.5 billion years ago during the Hadean or Archean periods at a time when the primordial Earth had a substantially different environment from that found today. Life forms have basic properties of self-replicating and inherited traits. After life arose, the process of evolution by natural selection resulted in the development of more diverse life forms. Species that cannot adapt to environmental changes and competition with other living things have become extinct. However, the fossil record retains evidence of many older species. Recent fossil and DNA evidence show that all existing species can trace their ancestry back to the first primitive forms of life. The emergence of photosynthesis in a form that is so basic to plant life around the world allowed solar energy to be harvested to create the conditions that allowed life to become more complex. The resulting oxygen accumulates in the atmosphere and gives rise to the ozone layer. The fusion of small cells within larger cells resulted in the development of more complex cells called eukaryotes. Cells in a colony become increasingly specialized and produce multicellular organisms.

With the ozone layer absorbing harmful ultraviolet radiation, life abounds on Earth's surface. The first life forms to develop on earth were microbes, and they were the only life forms on the planet until about a billion years ago when multi-cellular organisms started to appear. Microorganisms are single-celled organisms that are generally microscopic in size and smaller than the human eye can see. They include bacteria, fungi, archaea, and protists. These life forms are found in nearly every location on Earth where there is water, including in the rocky interior of the planet. Their reproduction is fast and abundant. The combination of their high mutation rate and horizontal gene transfer ability makes them adaptable and able to survive in new environments, including outer space. They form an important part of the planet's ecosystem. However, some microorganisms are pathogenic and can pose a health risk to other organisms. Originally Aristotle divided all living things between plants, which generally don't move fast enough for humans to see them, and animals. In Linnaean's system it became the two kingdoms Vegetabilia (later Plantae) and Animalia. Since then, it is clear that the Plantae as originally defined included several unrelated groups, and several unrelated groups of fungi and algae were transferred to populate the new kingdom. However, they are still often considered plants in many contexts. Bacterial life is sometimes included in flora, and some classifications use the term bacterial flora separate from plant flora. One way to classify plants is by area which (depending on the purpose of the study) may also include plant fossils, or the remains of plant life from earlier eras. People in many regions and countries take pride in their individual array of plant characteristics, which can vary widely around the world due to differences in climate and terrain.

Regional plants are generally divided into categories such as native flora and agricultural and garden flora, and the last mentioned are those that are intentionally grown and cultivated. Some types of "native flora" were actually introduced centuries ago by people migrating from one region or continent to another and became an integral or natural part of the native flora. This is an example of how human interaction with nature can blur the boundaries of what is considered part of nature. The former category of weeds is also used for plants. Although the term is frowned upon by botanists, the informal use of the word "weed" to describe plants deemed fit to be exterminated is a reflection of the general tendency of people and society to seek to change or shape the course of nature. Similarly, animals are often categorized as household animals, farm animals, wild animals, pests, etc. according to their relationship to human life. Animals as a category have several characteristics that generally set them apart from other living things. Animals are eukaryotic and usually multicellular which differentiates them from bacteria, archaea and protists. They are heterotrophs and generally digest food in an internal chamber, which differentiates them from plants and algae. They are also distinguished from plants, algae, and fungi by the lack of cell walls. With a few exceptions, notably sponges (phylum Porifera), animals have bodies that are differentiated into separate tissues. This includes the muscles, which are capable of contracting and controlling motion, and the nervous system, which sends and processes signals. Usually there is also an internal digestive chamber. Eukaryotic cells shared by all animals are surrounded by a distinctive extracellular matrix consisting of collagen and elastic glycoproteins. This may classify to form structures such as shells, bones, and spicules, a framework within which cells can move and rearrange during development and maturation, and which supports the complex anatomy required for mobility.

Although humans currently constitute only a small proportion of the total living biomass on Earth, the human effect on nature is disproportionately large. Due to the extent of human influence, the boundaries between what humans consider nature and the "built environment" are blurred except at the extremes. Even at the extremes, the amount of natural environments free from human influence visible today is decreasing at an accelerating rate. Technological developments by mankind have enabled greater exploitation of natural resources and have helped to reduce some of the risks from natural hazards. Despite progress, the fate of human civilization is still closely related to environmental changes. There are highly complex feedback loops between the use of advanced technology and changes to the environment that are only slowly being understood. Examples of threats to nature created by humans are pollution, deforestation, and disasters such as oil spills. Humans have contributed to the extinction of many plants and animals. Humans use nature for pleasure and economic activity. Acquisition of natural resources for industrial use remains a major component of the world economic system. Some activities, such as hunting and fishing, are undertaken for both food and recreation, often by different people. Agriculture was first implemented around the 9th millennium BC. From food production to energy, nature influences economic wealth. Although early humans gathered plant materials for food and used the medicinal properties of plants for healing, most modern humans make use of plants through agriculture. The widespread clearing of land for plant growth has led to a reduction in forest and wetland areas, resulting in loss of habitat for many plant and animal species and increased erosion.

Natural beauty has historically been a common theme in art and books that fill large sections of libraries and bookstores. Nature has been described and celebrated by so much art, photography, poetry and other literature that many people associate nature with beauty. The reasons why these associations exist, and what these associations consist of, are studied by the branch of philosophy called aesthetics. Apart from certain basic characteristics that many philosophers agree on to explain what is seen as beauty, the opinions that exist are endless. Nature and wildness have been important subjects in various eras of world history. An early tradition of landscape art began in China during the Tang dynasty (618-907). The tradition of representing nature as it really is was one of the goals of Chinese painting and was a significant influence on Asian art. Although the wonders of nature were celebrated in the Psalms and Job, the depiction of wilderness in art was heavily practiced in the 1800s, especially in the work of the Romantic movement. British artists John Constable and J. M. W. Turner focused on depicting natural beauty. Previously, paintings usually had religious or humanist themes. William Wordsworth's poetry describes natural wonders, previously seen as threatening places. Furthermore, respect for nature has become an important aspect of Western culture. Some fields of science view nature as a moving object, which also follows certain rules. These rules then try to understand by scientists. So the most basic science is referred to as "physics" – the name used until recently to refer to the study of nature. Matter is generally defined as a substance composed of physical objects. These matter make up the universe.

The visible components of the universe are believed to currently comprise only 4 percent of its total mass. The remaining 23 percent, which physicists believe, is cold dark matter and another 73 percent is dark energy. How the natural state actually is still not known clearly and is currently the main investigation material for physicists. The known characteristics of matter and energy of the universe appear to obey the laws of physics. These laws have been used to produce cosmological models of physics that can accurately explain the structure and evolution of the universe we observe. Mathematical formulas of the laws of physics produce a set of 20 physical constants whose values ​​appear to be fixed for the known universe. The value of this constant has been carefully measured, but why it had to be so specific is still a mystery. Outer space is a relatively empty region outside the atmosphere of a celestial body. There is no clear boundary between the Earth's atmosphere and outer space because the atmosphere is composed of layers that thin out with increasing altitude. Outer space in the Solar System is called interplanetary space. The boundary between the space between planets and the interstellar medium is called the heliopause. Space is full of space, but not empty. Outer space is filled with some organic molecules tracked by microwave spectroscopy, radiation left over from the big bang, and cosmic rays. There is also some gas, plasma, dust and small meteors. Moreover, there is also space junk produced by humans, which can endanger flights into space. Although Earth is currently the only celestial body in the Solar System known to support life, current evidence suggests that Mars may have had surface water in the past.

Minimization of production costs is achieved by reducing workers' wages. Capitalism is carried out by an agency or individual outside the government. Thus, the government cannot intervene in the market to obtain mutual benefits, but government intervention is carried out on a large scale for personal interests. The perpetrators of capitalism are called Capital. Capitalism actually does not have a universal definition that can be widely accepted. Some experts define capitalism as a system that began to apply in Europe in the 16th to 19th centuries, namely during the development of European commercial banking where a group of individuals or groups could act as a certain entity that could own or trade in property. personal assets, especially capital goods, such as land and people for the process of changing from capital goods to finished goods. To obtain these capitals, capitalists must obtain raw materials and machinery first, then laborers who act as machine operators in order to obtain value from the raw materials processed. Capitalism has a long history, namely since the discovery of a trading system carried out by the private sector. In Europe, this is known as the guild as the forerunner of capitalism. Currently, capitalism is not only seen as a way of life that wants profit. The merging of capitalism with socialism without any modifications makes capitalism more malleable than it was two or three centuries ago. The term capitalism, in its modern sense, is often associated with Karl Marx. In his magnum opus Das Kapital, Marx wrote about the "capitalist mode of production" using the method of understanding now known as Marxism.

However, while Marx rarely used the term "capitalism", it is used twice in the more political interpretations of his work, notably written by collaborator Friedrich Engels. In the 20th century apologists for the capitalist system often replaced long term capitalism with phrases such as free enterprise and private enterprise and replaced it with rent capitalists and investors as a reaction to the negative connotations associated with capitalism. Governments dominated trade for centuries, which created economic inequality. These thinkers began to think that the bourgeoisie, which in the previous era began to play an important role in the state-dominated trade economy or better known as mercantilism, should start trading and production to support the pattern of people's lives. This phylum has diverse members inhabiting a very wide range of environments. According to taxonomy, they are grouped in the superphylum Ecdysozoa along with other arthropods and ecdysis animals. In contrast to the phyla Cnidaria and Platyhelminthes (flatworms), nematodes have a tubular digestive system with openings at both ends. Nematode species can be difficult to distinguish from one another. For this reason, estimates of the number of nematode species vary among scientists and can change rapidly. A 2013 animal biodiversity survey published in the journal Zootaxa put this figure at over 25,000. Estimates of the total number of surviving species have greater variation. A widely referenced article published in 1993 estimates there are over 1 million nematode species. A subsequent publication challenged this claim on the grounds that it was not supported by facts, and put the figure at only 40,000 species. Estimates supported by species richness grading curves, together with the use of DNA barcoding, and the increasing recognition of widely distributed cryptic species among nematodes, have put the figure closer to 1 million species. Nematodes have successfully adapted to almost every ecosystem, from marine (saltwater) to fresh water, on land, and from the polar regions to the tropics, as well as from the highest to the lowest altitudes. They are ubiquitous in freshwater, marine, and terrestrial environments, and they often outnumber other animals in both total individuals and species diversity. Nematodes are found in mountains, deserts, and oceanic trenches, and are found in every part of the Earth's lithosphere, even at a depth of 0.9 to 3.6 km) below the Earth's surface in gold mines in South Africa.

They represent 90% of all the animals on the ocean floor. Their numerical predominance, often exceeding one million individuals per square meter and representing about 80% of all animal individuals on Earth, the diversity of their life cycles, and their presence at various tropic levels points to an important role in many ecosystems. Many of the Nematodes become parasites, so they are categorized as pathogens, for most plants and animals (including humans). Nathan Cobb, a nematologist, explains the presence of Nematodes on Earth: In short, if all matter in the universe except for nematodes were wiped out, our world would still be dimly recognizable, and if, as disembodied spirits, we could then investigate it, we should find mountains, hills, valleys, rivers, lakes, and oceans are represented by the nematode film. City locations will be understood, because for every human mass replenishment there will be a specific nematode corresponding mob replenishment. Trees will still stand in ghostly rows representing our streets and highways. The location of various plants and animals will still be understood, and, if we have sufficient knowledge, in many cases even their species can be determined by examination of their past nematode parasites."
