The editor page has logged out learn more Schizophrenia is a mental disorder characterized by impaired thought processes and weak emotional responses. This condition is generally manifested in the form of auditory hallucinations, paranoia or bizarre delusions, or disorganized speech and thinking, and is accompanied by significant social and occupational dysfunction. Initial symptoms usually appear in young adulthood, with a global lifetime prevalence of around 0.3% – 0.7%. Diagnosis is based on observed behavior and reported experiences of sufferers. Important contributing factors are genetics, early environment, neurobiology, as well as psychological conditions and social processes; Several types of prescription and recreational drugs are likely to cause or exacerbate symptoms. Current research is focused on the role of neurobiology, although no specific organic cause has been found. The various possible combinations of symptoms have sparked debate as to whether a diagnosis represents one disorder or several distinct symptoms. Despite the etymology of the term being derived from the Greek roots skhizein (σχίζειν, "to split") and phrēn, phren- (φρήν, φρεν-; "memory"), schizophrenia is not the same as "split memory" and is not the same as dissociative identity disorder also known as "multiple personality disorder" or "split personality"—a condition that is often confused with the public perception. The mainstay of treatment is treatment with antipsychotics which generally suppress dopamine (and sometimes serotonin) activity. Psychotherapy and vocational and social rehabilitation are also important treatments. In more serious cases involving risks to oneself and others, it is necessary to resort to hospitalization by force, although the length of hospital stay is now shorter and not as frequent as before.

This disorder is thought to generally affect cognition, but also usually contributes to chronic problems related to behavior and emotions. Individuals with schizophrenia usually have other (comorbid) conditions, including major depression and anxiety disorders; incidence of abuse of certain compounds during life reaches 50%. Social problems, such as long-term unemployment, poverty and homelessness, are common. The average life expectancy of people with the disorder is 12 to 15 years shorter than those without it, which is a result of increasing health problems and higher suicide rates (about 5%). A person diagnosed with schizophrenia may experience hallucinations (most report hearing voices), delusions (usually strange or unusual), and disturbances in thought and speech. The latter can be in the form of losing the order of thought, to sentences whose meanings are not related, to incoherence which is known as messy words in more severe cases. Social withdrawal, messy and unhygienic clothing, and loss of motivation and judgment are common in schizophrenia. There is usually an observable pattern of emotional distress, for example an unresponsiveness. Disturbances in social cognition are associated with schizophrenia, as are symptoms of paranoia; Social isolation generally arises. Difficulties with working and long-term memory, attention, executive roles, and speed of processing are also very common. In any of the uncommon subtypes, a person becomes very quiet, and holds himself in very awkward positions, or exhibits slurred behavior, all of which are symptoms of catatonia. Late adolescence and early adulthood are peak periods for the emergence of schizophrenia, which are critical years of social and vocational development in a young adult.

In 40% of men and 23% of women diagnosed with schizophrenia, in which manifestations of this condition appeared before the age of 19 years. To suppress the developmental disorders associated with schizophrenia, many studies have been carried out to identify and treat the prodromal (pre-start) phase of the disease, which can be detected up to 30 months before symptoms appear. Those who have experienced the development of schizophrenia experience transient or self-limiting psychotic symptoms and nonspecific symptoms of withdrawal from surroundings, irritability, dysphoria, and clumsiness during the prodromal phase. In the early 20th century, a psychiatrist named Kurt Schneider listed the psychotic symptoms that he thought distinguished schizophrenia from other psychotic disorders. This list is called first-rank symptoms or Schneider's first-rank symptoms. These symptoms include the delusion of being in the control of an external force; the belief that thoughts enter or leave the subconscious; the belief that one's thoughts are radiated to another person; and hearing a hallucinatory voice commenting on a person's thoughts or attitudes or conversing in a hallucinatory voice. Although it contributes to the diagnostic criteria significantly, the specificity of the first-order symptom is still questionable. A review of diagnostic studies conducted between 1970 and 2005 found that they neither confirmed nor denied Schneider's claims, and suggested that first-degree symptoms should not be emphasized in future diagnostic systems. Schizophrenia is generally described as positive and negative (or deficit) symptoms. Positive symptoms are symptoms that are not experienced by most individuals normally but are experienced by a person with schizophrenia. These states include delusions, disorganized thought and speech, and tactile, auditory, visual, olfactory and gustatory hallucinations, usually described as manifestations of psychosis.

Hallucinations are usually related to delusional themes. Positive symptoms generally respond well to treatment. Negative symptoms are deficits in normal emotional responses or other thought processes, and the reaction is unfavorable to treatment. Common symptoms include emotion that is flat or blunted, withdrawn (alogia), inability to experience pleasure (anhedonia), lack of desire to form social relationships (asocial), and low motivation (avolition). Research shows that negative symptoms contribute to poor quality of life, functional limitations, and burdens on others compared to positive symptoms. Patients with prominent negative symptoms often have a history of maladjustment prior to the onset of the disease, and response to treatment is usually limited. A combination of genetic and environmental factors play a role in the development of schizophrenia. A person with a family history of schizophrenia who suffers from transient psychosis or self-limitation has a 20–40% chance of being diagnosed one year later. Estimates of heritability vary because of the difficulty in separating the effects of genetic and environmental factors. The greatest risk of developing schizophrenia is having a first-degree relative with the disease (6.5% risk); more than 40% of monozygotic twins of schizophrenics are also affected. It appears that many genes are involved, every bit continguous to the effect and transmission and expression of which is unknown. Many causes have been proposed, including specific ones such as copy number variation, NOTCH4, and histone protein loci. A number of things related to the genome such as the zinc finger protein 804A have also been linked. There is significant overlap in the genetics of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Assuming a hereditary basis, a question from revolutionary psychology is why a gene that increases the likelihood of psychosis developed, assuming that this condition may be caused by an imbalance of adaptation from an evolutionary perspective.

One theory implicates the involvement of genes in the evolution of language and human nature, but until recently such ideas remained theoretical by nature. Environmental factors associated with the emergence of schizophrenia include the living environment, drug use and stress during pregnancy. Parenting style does not seem to have a major effect, although sufferers who have parental support do better than sufferers whose parents are critical and abusive. Living in an urban environment during childhood or adulthood consistently appeared to double the risk of schizophrenia, even after taking into account factors such as drug use, ethnic group, and size of social group. Other factors that play an important role include social isolation and immigration related social hardship, racial discrimination, family dysfunction, unemployment and poor housing conditions. A number of drugs have been linked to the development of schizophrenia, including cannabis, cocaine and amphetamines. About half of people with schizophrenia are excessive drug and/or alcohol users. Cannabis may play a causal role, but other drugs can be used only as a way to treat depression, anxiety, boredom, and loneliness. Dependence on the use of high doses of cannabis is at risk of developing psychotic disorders whose frequent use is correlated with a twofold increased risk of psychosis and schizophrenia. Although cannabis use is accepted as a contributing cause of schizophrenia by many, it remains controversial. Amphetamines, cocaine, and to a lesser extent, alcohol, can cause a psychosis whose symptoms are very similar to those of schizophrenia. Although not generally believed to be a cause of the disease, people with schizophrenia use nicotine at a much greater rate than the general population.

Factors such as hypoxia and infection, or stress and malnutrition in the mother during fetal development, may result in a slightly increased risk of schizophrenia later in life. People diagnosed with schizophrenia are more likely to be born in winter or spring (at least in the Northern Hemisphere) which may be a result of the increased average exposure to the virus in utero. This difference is about 5 to 8%. Several attempts have been made to explain the relationship between altered brain function and schizophrenia. One of the most common theories is the dopamine hypothesis, which explains that psychosis is due to the mind's misinterpretation of the discharge of dopaminergic neurons. Many psychological mechanisms are involved in the growth and development of schizophrenia. Cognitive biases have been identified in people who are diagnosed with or at risk of developing schizophrenia, especially when under stressful or confusing situations. Some cognitive features may reflect global neurocognitive deficits such as memory loss, while others may relate to specific problems or experiences. Despite the apparent appearance of emotional blunting, recent studies have shown that many individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia are emotionally responsive, particularly to stressful or negative stimuli, and that this sensitivity can lead to susceptibility to both the symptoms and the disorder. Some evidence suggests that the content of psychotic delusions and experiences may reflect the emotional causes of the disorder, and how a person interprets these experiences can influence symptomatology. The use of "safe behavior" to avoid imaginative threats can contribute to chronic delusions. Further evidence of the role of psychological mechanisms comes from the effects of psychotherapy on schizophrenic symptoms. Schizophrenia is associated with subtle differences in brain structure, found in 40 to 50% of cases, and in brain chemistry during acute psychotic states.

Studies using neuropsychological tests and brain imaging technologies such as fMRI and PET to examine functional differences in brain activity have shown that differences seem to occur more frequently in parts of the frontal lobe, hippocampus and temporal lobe. Reduced brain volumes, smaller than those seen in Alzheimer's disease, have been reported in areas of the frontal cortex and temporal lobe. It is not clear whether these volumetric changes are progressive or preexist with the disease. This difference is associated with the neurocognitive deficits often associated with schizophrenia. Because the neural circuits change, alternatively it has been suggested that schizophrenia should be considered as a combination of neurodevelopmental disorders. Particular attention has been paid to the function of dopamine in the brain's mesolimbic pathways. It focuses largely on the accidental discovery that phenothiazines, which block dopamine function, can reduce psychotic symptoms. This is also corroborated by the fact that amphetamine, which triggers the release of dopamine, can amplify psychotic symptoms in schizophrenia. The high-impact dopamine hypothesis in schizophrenia was put forward in that overactivation of D2 receptors is the cause (positive symptoms of) schizophrenia. Although postulated for about 20 years based on the D2 inhibitory effect common to all antipsychotic drugs, it was not until the mid-1990s that PET and SPET imaging studies provided supporting evidence. The dopamine hypothesis is now considered an oversimplification, in part because newer antipsychotic medications (atypical antipsychotic medications) can be just as effective as older medications (typical antipsychotic medications), but also affect serotonin function and may have a slightly less inhibitory effect on dopamine. Concern has also focused on the neurotransmitter glutamate and reduced NMDA glutamate receptor function in schizophrenia, largely because of the abnormally low levels of glutamate receptors found in the postmortem brains of people diagnosed with schizophrenia, and the discovery of glutamate-blocking drugs such as phencyclidine. and ketamine may mimic the symptoms and cognitive problems associated with the condition.

Reduced glutamate function is associated with poor performance on tests requiring frontal lobe and hippocampal function, and glutamate can affect dopamine function, both of which result in schizophrenia, suggesting an important role in linking (and possibly initiating) glutamate pathways in these conditions. But positive symptoms failed to respond to glutaminergic treatment. Schizophrenia is diagnosed based on criteria from the American Psychiatric Association Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, version DSM-IV-TR, or from the World Health Organization's International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems, namely ICD-10. Schizophrenia in the DSM-5 can only be defined as a diagnosis if it has at least two types of symptoms. The first type of symptoms are those that occur for at least a month. These symptoms include delusions, hallucinations, slurred speech and catatonia. While the second type of symptom is a negative symptom. This criterion uses self-report experiences from sufferers and reported behavioral irregularities, which are then followed by a clinical assessment by a mental health professional. Symptoms associated with schizophrenia occur on a continuum in the population and must reach some degree of severity before a diagnosis is made. Until 2009 there was no objective test. The ICD-10 criteria are usually used in European countries, while the DSM-IV-TR criteria are used in the United States and around the world, and are often used in research studies. The ICD-10 criteria emphasize first-order Schneiderian symptoms. In practice, the agreement between the two systems is high. According to the fourth revised edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV-TR), in order to be diagnosed with schizophrenia, three diagnostic criteria must be met: If signs of the disorder are present for more than one month but less than six months, the diagnosis schizophreniform disorder is applied.

Psychotic symptoms that last for less than a month may be diagnosed as brief psychotic disorder, and many conditions may be classified as other unclassified psychotic disorders. Schizophrenia cannot be diagnosed if symptoms of a mood disorder are substantially present (although schizoaffective disorder may be diagnosed), or if symptoms of a pervasive developmental disorder are present unless prominent delusions or hallucinations are also present, or if the symptoms are the direct physiological result of a medical condition or substance common, such as drug abuse or medication. The DSM-IV-TR contains five subclassifications of schizophrenia, although the developers of the DSM-5 recommended that this subclassification be omitted from the new classification: The ICD-10 criteria provide for two additional subtypes: Psychotic symptoms may be present in several other mental disorders, including bipolar disorder, borderline personality, drug intoxication and drug-induced psychosis. Delusions ("non-bizarre"/not strange) are also found in delusional disorder, and social withdrawal in social anxiety disorder, avoidant anxiety disorder and schizotypic personality disorder. Schizophrenia is frequently coexisted with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and is significant in comparison to that which could occur purely by chance, although it is difficult to distinguish between the obsessions that occur in OCD and the delusions of schizophrenia. Further general physical and neurological examinations are needed to rule out diseases that can sometimes cause schizophrenia-like psychotic symptoms, such as metabolic disorders, systemic infections, syphilis, HIV infection, epilepsy, and brain lesions. It is necessary to exclude the possibility of delirium, which can be distinguished by visual hallucinations, acute onset, and fluctuating level of consciousness, and indicates an underlying medical illness. Investigations usually do not need to be repeated for relapse, unless there is a specific medical indication or possible side effect of antipsychotic drugs.

There is currently no conclusive evidence of the effectiveness of early intervention to prevent schizophrenia. Although there is evidence that early intervention in people with psychotic episodes can improve short-term outcomes, there is little benefit in these efforts after five years. Attempts to prevent schizophrenia in the prodromal/early phase have no clear benefit and therefore have not been recommended since 2009. Prevention is difficult because there are no reliable markers for future disease. However, some cases of schizophrenia can be delayed or perhaps prevented by preventing cannabis use, especially in adolescents. A person with a family history of schizophrenia may be more susceptible to cannabis-induced psychosis. And, one study found that cannabis-induced psychotic disorders were followed by the development of a persistent psychotic state in about half of cases. Theoretical research continues on strategies that might reduce the incidence of schizophrenia. One approach seeks to understand what happens at the genetic and neurological level that can cause disease, so that biomedical interventions can be developed. However, the multiple and varied genetic effects, each on a small scale, that interact with the environment, make this difficult. Alternatively, public health strategies could selectively address socioeconomic factors that are associated with a higher incidence of schizophrenia in some groups, such as immigration, ethnicity, or poverty. Population-scale strategies can provide services to ensure safe pregnancy and healthy growth, including in areas of psychological development such as social intelligence. However, there is insufficient evidence to implement such an idea at this time, and a wider number of problems are not specific to schizophrenia. The mainstay of treatment for schizophrenia is antipsychotic medication, often accompanied by psychological and social support.

Hospitalization may be provided for some episodes either voluntarily or (where permitted by mental health legislation) involuntary. Long-term hospital care has been rare since out-of-institutional care began in the 1950s, although it still occurs. Community support services including day care, visits by members of the community mental health team, employment support and support groups are common. Some evidence suggests that regular exercise has positive effects on the physical and mental health of people with schizophrenia. The first line of psychiatric treatment for schizophrenia is antipsychotic medication, which can reduce the positive symptoms of psychosis in about 7-14 days. However, antipsychotic drugs failed to significantly relieve negative symptoms and cognitive impairment. Long-term use lowers the risk of relapse. The choice of antipsychotic drug used is based on benefits, risks, and costs. It is still debated which is better, between typical or atypical antipsychotic drugs. Both have withdrawal rates and recurrence of symptoms when typical drugs are used at low to moderate doses. Good response is found in 40–50%, partial response in 30–40%, and treatment resistance (failure to show a satisfactory symptom response after six weeks of treatment with two or three different antipsychotic drugs) in 20% of people. Clozapine is an effective treatment for those who do not respond well to other drugs, but has the potential for a serious side effect, namely agranulocytosis (decreased white blood cell count) in 1–4%. Based on side effect considerations, typical antipsychotic drugs have higher extrapyramidal effects, whereas atypical drugs cause significant weight gain, diabetes, and risk of metabolic syndrome. Atypical drugs have fewer extrapyramidal side effects, but the differences are not large.

Some atypical drugs such as quetipepine and risperidone are associated with a higher risk of death compared with the typical antipsychotic drugs perphenazine, whereas clozapine is associated with a lower risk of death. It is unclear whether newer antipsychotic drugs reduce the likelihood of developing neuroleptic malignancy syndrome, a rare but severe neurological disorder. For people who are unwilling or unable to take medication regularly, long-acting depot antipsychotic drug forms may be used to control the disease. These drugs reduce the risk of increasing to a more severe degree compared to oral medication. When used in conjunction with psychosocial interventions, these drugs can improve long-term adherence to treatment. A number of psychosocial interventions can be useful for schizophrenia, including: family therapy, assertive community medication, job support, cognitive remediation, skills training, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), behavior modification interventions, and psychosocial interventions for substance use and weight management. Family therapy or education, which covers an individual's entire family system, can reduce relapses and hospitalizations. There is not much evidence regarding the effectiveness of CBT in either reducing symptoms or preventing relapse. Art or drama therapy has not been well researched. Schizophrenia has a huge individual and economic impact. This disease causes a decrease in life expectancy of 12–15 years, mainly due to its association with obesity, a sedentary lifestyle, and smoking, with the increasing suicide rate playing a smaller role. This difference in life expectancy increased between the 1970s and 1990s, and between the 1990s and the first decade of the 21st century, it did not change significantly in the health system with open access to health services (Finland).

Schizophrenia is a frequent cause of disability, with active psychosis ranking as the third most disabling condition after quadriplegia/paralysis of all four arms and legs and dementia, above paraplegia/paralysis of both legs and blindness. About three-quarters of people with schizophrenia have persistent disability with relapses. Some people recover completely and others are able to function well in society. Most people with schizophrenia live independently with community support. In people with a first episode of psychosis, good long-term outcomes were found in 42%, moderate outcomes in 35%, and poor outcomes in 27%. Recovery outcomes for schizophrenia appear to be better in developing than in developed countries. However, this conclusion is questionable. The suicide rate associated with schizophrenia is higher than average. This figure was stated to be 10%, but a recent analysis of various studies and statistics revised this estimate to 4.9%, most commonly occurring during the period following the onset or first hospitalization. Several times (20 to 40%) attempt suicide at least once. There are various risk factors, including male sex, depression, and high IQ (intelligence quotient). A strong link between schizophrenia and smoking has been shown in studies around the world. Cigarette use is particularly high among individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia, with an estimated 80% to 90% of sufferers being regular smokers, compared to 20% of the general population. Those who smoke tend to be heavy smokers, plus they consume cigarettes with high nicotine content. Some evidence suggests that paranoid schizophrenia may have better prospects than other types of schizophrenia for living independently and carrying out work functions.

Schizophrenia affects an estimated 0.3–0.7% of people at some point in their lives, or 24 million people worldwide as of 2011. The disease occurs 1.4 times more frequently in men than in women and usually appears earlier among men—the peak age at onset is 20–28 years for men and 26-32 years for women. Early childhood attacks are rare, as are early attacks in middle and old age. Although it is known that schizophrenia presents at similar rates worldwide, its prevalence varies across the world, within countries, and at the local and regional level. This accounts for approximately 1% of years of life with disability adjustment worldwide. Rates of schizophrenia vary up to three times depending on how the disease is defined. Historical records of schizophrenia-like syndromes are rare before the 19th century, although reports of irrational, incomprehensible or uncontrolled behavior are common. A detailed case report in 1797 of James Tilly Matthews, and notes by Phillipe Pinel published in 1809, are often considered to be the earliest cases of this disease in the medical and psychiatric literature. Schizophrenia was first described as a distinct syndrome affecting adolescents and young adults by Bénédict Morel in 1853, which he called démence précoce (literally 'early dementia'). The term dementia preecox was used in 1891 by Arnold Pick in a case report of a psychotic disorder. In 1893 Emil Kraepelin introduced a widely new distinction in the classification of mental disorders between dementia preecox and mood disorders (which are called manic depressions and include unipolar and bipolar depressions).

Kraepelin believed that dementia preecox was originally a disease of the brain, and a special kind of dementia, distinguished from other types of dementia such as Alzheimer's disease which usually present later in life. The word schizophrenia which translates roughly as “splitting of the mind” and comes from the Greek roots schizein (σχίζειν, "split") and phrēn, phren- (φρήν, φρεν-, "mind")—popularized by Eugen Bleuler in 1908 and intended to describe the separation of functions between personality, thinking, memory, and perception. Bleuler describes his main symptoms as the 4 As's: Flat “Affectiveness,” Autism, “Idea Association” Disorder, and Ambivalence. Bleuler realized that the disease was not dementia, as some of his patients improved rather than worsened, so he proposed the term schizophrenia for the disease. Medicine changed radically in the mid-1950s with the development and introduction of chlorpromazine. In the early 1970s, the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia generated a number of controversies that eventually resulted in the operational criteria used today. After the 1971 US-British Diagnostic Study, it became clear that schizophrenia was diagnosed far more frequently in America than in Europe. This is partly due to the looser diagnostic criteria in the US, which uses the DSM-II manual, in contrast to Europe and its ICD-9. A 1972 study by David Rosenhan's, published in the journal Science under the title "Being sane where insane is," concluded that the diagnosis of schizophrenia in the US is often subjective and unreliable. These were some of the factors that led to the revision of not only the diagnosis of schizophrenia, but also the revision of the entire DSM manual, which resulted in the publication of the DSM-III in 1980. The term schizophrenia is commonly misunderstood as having a “split personality”. While some people diagnosed with schizophrenia may hear voices and may experience voices as distinct personalities, schizophrenia does not involve a person changing into a distinct multiple personality.

The confusion arose, partly because of the literal interpretation of the term schizophrenia according to Bleuler (Bleuler originally associated schizophrenia with dissociation and included split personality in his category of schizophrenia). Dissociative identity disorder (having a “split personality”) is also frequently misdiagnosed as Schizophrenia based on the loose criteria in the DSM-II. The first known misuse of the meaning of schizophrenia as "split personality" was in an article by the poet T. S. Eliot in 1933. In 2002, the term schizophrenia in Japan was changed from Seishin-Bunretsu-Byō 精神分裂病 (split mind disease) became Tōgō-shitchō-shō 統合失調症 (integration disorder) to reduce stigma. This new name was inspired by the biopsychosocial model; the percentage of patients diagnosed with this disease increased from 37% to 70% within 3 years. In the United States, the cost of treating schizophrenia including direct costs (outpatient care, hospitalization, drugs, and long-term care) and non-health care costs (law enforcement, reduced workplace productivity, and unemployment) is estimated at $62.7 billion in in 2002. The book and film “A Beautiful Mind” depicts the life story of John Forbes Nash, a Nobel Prize-winning mathematician who was diagnosed with schizophrenia. Social stigma has been identified as the main obstacle in healing patients suffering from schizophrenia. Individuals who suffer from severe mental illness including schizophrenia have a much greater risk of becoming victims of crimes that involve both violence and non-violence. On the other hand, schizophrenia is sometimes associated with higher levels of violence, although this is mainly due to higher levels of drug use. The homicide rate associated with psychosis is similar to that associated with drug abuse, and parallels the overall rate in the region. The role that schizophrenia plays in non-drug violence is controversial, but specific aspects of an individual's history or mental state may be a precipitating factor.

Today, the term Celtic is also used to describe some of the inhabitants of the British Isles, the Brittany region of France, and the Galician region of Spain who retain some of the original Celtic features, particularly of their language. A clear feature of the Celts is that they are either spoken or descended from speakers of one of the Celtic languages. Other European regions associated with the Celts are Galicia in Spain, and Devon, Cumbria and Northumbria in England. Most cereals are members of the Poaceae family which are called true cereals. Editor page logged out learn more Mir (Мир, which can mean world or peace in Russian) was the Soviet Union's (hereafter Russia) space station which was considered the most successful. This facility is a long-term permanent residence for cosmonauts in space. Through several collaborations, international access has been enforced for this facility to be used by cosmonauts and astronauts from various countries. Mir was successfully put into orbit by connecting several modules which were launched separately one at a time from 19 February 1986 to 1996. The facility ceased operations and was lowered back to Earth on 23 March 2001 due to funding problems. Mir in Russian means peace or world, depending on the context in which the words are used. The Mir space station began to be built as an ambitious project in 1986, replacing the role of the smaller Salyut space station. The 20-ton Mir main body was launched from the Baikonur cosmodrome on the shores of the Aral Sea, Kazakhstan, on February 20, 1986. At the time of its construction, the world was in the midst of a cold war, while America froze its space activities due to the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on January 28, 1986 which killing all seven crew members. Mir occupies an orbit as high as 400 km above the Earth's surface. Originally, Mir was only planned to inhabit orbit for five years. However, in practice the Mir was able to last up to 15 years. Over the next 10 years, five additional modules were successively launched and combined with the Mir. The additional modules are Kvant-1, Kvant-2, Spektr, Docking and Priroda. The final module, Priroda, was launched in 1996 as part of geodesy research. The functions of these modules are different, so that as a whole Mir is a space station complex with quite a broad field of work, from research on the earth - the phenomenon of weightlessness - to research on gamma-ray emission from stars in the universe.

Mir also repeatedly broke the record for the longest human being in space - 3 years -, while America with its Space Shuttle and mini-laboratory on the cargo plane was only able to survive a maximum of 14 days. Until the end of his life Mir was inhabited by 104 people from various countries: Russia, America, France, Germany and several other countries. Not everyone is an astronaut or cosmonaut. Once it happened, a candy factory worker in England visited Mir after winning a contest. The modules inside Mir get the same pressure and air composition as the Earth's surface. Humidity was set to feel comfortable. To serve the needs of the scientists living within it, Mir is regularly visited by the Progress cargo spacecraft, which will dock at one of Mir's ports manually or electronically. Mir has four similar doors to allow several spacecraft to dock at once. Scientists who wish to visit Mir are transported in a Soyuz space capsule with a capacity of 3 people. On arrival at Mir, the Soyuz will lean against one of the Mir's doors and remain there, while Mir's longtime occupants leave in the old Soyuz they boarded upon arrival. Thus, the maximum capacity of Mir is only for 3 passengers. The placement of the Soyuz at one of Mir's doors is useful as a last resort for leaving Mir in an emergency. Apart from the Soyuz, American space shuttles have also repeatedly docked at Mir, especially since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. These Space Shuttles have docked via the docking module. As a large and complex space station, Mir presents its own difficulties. Control of Mir is managed from space and from Earth, specifically from the Korolyov station.

In Mir itself there are small rocket engines that are useful for adjusting the position and correction of the Mir's orbit. Various breakdowns occurred during Mir's operation. In February 1997 the Mir modules suffered a major fire due to a leak in an oxygen tank. A few months later, the Progress cargo spacecraft, which intended to carry out a manual leaning experiment, failed and crashed into the Spektr module. As a result, Mir shifted from its original position and Spektr's solar panels were damaged, resulting in only 55% of Mir's power supply. In addition, the Spektr module also has a hole 3 cm wide, which luckily was able to be patched with a tool by British astronaut Michael Foale, who happened to be in the module. Air leaks did not occur, but the humidity rose so that the atmosphere was hot. Coupled with the stress that befell the scientists in Mir, it was thought to evacuate Mir's scientists with the remaining Soyuz. Luckily, the worst scenario didn't happen so Mir was still able to function, even though it wasn't as normal as before. In the end, Spektr was forced to be isolated from Mir. The dissolution of the Soviet Union and the prolonged crisis in Russia caused a shortage of funds for the management of Mir. As a result, several times Mir almost touched the Earth's atmosphere. Because of that, in the decade of the 90s Russia decided to cooperate with America in managing Mir. But after several disruptions and catastrophic funding problems - Mir costs US $250 million a year - Rosaviakosmos has finally decided to drop Mir. The last time Mir was inhabited by humans was in August 2000. Until the end of his life, Mir had circled the Earth 80,000 times and produced tens of thousands of conclusions and articles from the studies conducted on it. The volume of research results is unmatched from other space missions.

Editor page logged out learn more in Europe   (gray) Iceland (Icelandic: Ísland), officially the Republic of Iceland, is a Nordic country located in northwestern Europe and north Atlantic Ocean, consisting from the Island of Iceland and several small islands around it. Iceland is located 300 kilometers east of Greenland and 1,000 kilometers from Norway. The country has a population of 332,529 inhabitants and an area of ​​103,000 sq km, making it the most sparsely populated country in Europe. The nation's capital and largest city is Reykjavík. Reykjavík and its surroundings are home to two-thirds of the population. The first people to live in Iceland were Irish monks who arrived in the early 9th century. In the mid-9th century, the Vikings migrated and settled in Iceland. The first Viking to live in Iceland was Flóki Vilgerðarson. It was he who gave Iceland the name it is today. Ingólfur Arnarson, a tribal chief from Norway, lived and settled in southwest Iceland and founded a city called Reykjavik. Around the 930s, Iceland's rulers began writing their country's constitution. They formed Althing, a type of parliament headquartered in the city of Þingvellir. Iceland can be said to be the country with the oldest democratic system that still survives today. In 985, Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for killing someone. He then sailed west and found Greenland. Erik's son, Leif Erikson, discovered America in 1000 and named it Vinland. The journey of Erik, Leif and their followers is told in a saga. In 1262 Iceland became part of Norway until 1814 Iceland became part of Denmark. At the end of the 19th century, many Icelanders wanted independence from Denmark.

In 1918, Iceland gained sovereignty, but the king of Denmark was still crowned king of Iceland. When Germany occupied Denmark on April 9, 1940, Althing decided that Iceland belonged to the Icelandic people. However, they still had not declared independence at that time. British troops and following later the United States took the initiative to occupy Iceland so that it would not be attacked by Germany. In 1944, Iceland finally declared its independence. After World War II, Iceland became a member of NATO, but not a member of the European Union. Between 1958 and 1976, there were three disagreements between Iceland and the UK over who had the right to take cod from the waters around Iceland. The war was called the Cod War. There were no casualties in the war. In 1980, Vigdís Finnbogadóttir was elected president. She is Iceland's first female president. Iceland is located at the junction of the North Atlantic and the Arctic Ocean. The main island is located south of the Arctic Circle, which passes through the small Icelandic island of Grímsey off the main island's north coast. The country lies between latitudes 63 and 68°N, and longitudes 25 and 13°W. Iceland is located closer to mainland Europe than mainland North America; thus, this island is generally included in Europe for historical, political, cultural, and practical reasons. Geologically, this island is part of both continental plates. The nearest land mass from Iceland is Greenland (290 km). The closest landmasses in Europe are the Faroe Islands (420 km); Jan Mayen Island (570 km); Shetland and Outer Hebrides, both about 740 km; and mainland Scotland and Orkney, both about 750 km. Mainland Norway is approximately 970 km away. Iceland is the 18th largest island in the world, and the second largest island in Europe after England.

The area of ​​the main island is 101,826 sq km, but the outer area of ​​the whole country of Iceland is 103,000 sq km, of which 62.7% is tundra. About 30 small islands are in Iceland, including the Grimsey and Vestmannaeyjar islands. Lakes and glaciers cover 14.3% of its surface; only 23% are vegetated. The largest lakes are the Þórisvatn reservoirs: 83–88 sq. km and Þingvallavatn: 82 sq. km; other important lakes include Lagarfljot and Mývatn. Jökulsárlón is the deepest lake, at 248 meters deep. There are many fjords along Iceland's coastline, which are also where most of the settlements are located. The interior of the island, the Icelandic Highlands, is a combination of sand fields, mountains and lava that makes it uninhabitable. The main major cities are the capital Reykjavík, along with cities such as Kópavogur, Hafnarfjörður, and Garðabær, Reykjanesbær where the international airport is located, and the city of Akureyri in northern Iceland. The island of Grímsey in the Arctic Circle is the northernmost inhabited place of Iceland, while Kolbeinsey is the northernmost point of Iceland. Iceland has three national parks. Vatnajokull National Park, Snaefellsjokull National Park, and Þingvellir National Park. Iceland has many geysers, including Geysir, which is the origin of its English definition, and Strokkur, which erupts every 8-10 minutes. After going through a dormant phase, Geysir started erupting again after a series of earthquakes in 2000. After that it became quieter and erupted less frequently. With the wide availability of geothermal power, and the use of many rivers and waterfalls for hydroelectric power, a large proportion of the population has access to hot water, heating and cheap electricity. This island is composed of basalt. Iceland has hundreds of volcanoes with around 30 active volcanic systems.

Surtsey, one of the youngest islands in the world, is part of Iceland. Named after Surtr, the island rose above sea level in a series of volcanic eruptions between 8 November 1963 and 5 June 1968. Only scientists researching the growth of new life are allowed to visit the island. On March 21, 2010, the volcano in Eyjafjallajökull in southern Iceland erupted for the first time since 1821, displacing 600 people from their homes. Additional eruptions on April 14 forced hundreds of people to flee their homes. The resulting cloud of volcanic ash disrupted air travel across Europe. Another major eruption occurred on May 21, 2011. This time it was the Grimsvotn volcano, located under the thick ice of Europe's largest glacier, Vatnajökull. Grimsvotn is one of the most active volcanoes in Iceland, and this eruption was much more powerful than the 2010 Eyjafjallajökull eruption, with ash and lava thrown 20 km into the atmosphere, creating a huge cloud. About 1,300 insect species occur in Iceland, a low number when compared to other countries (more than one million species have been found worldwide). The only native mammals when humans arrived were arctic foxes. Sometimes, bats are carried to the island by the wind, but they cannot breed there. Polar bears occasionally come from Greenland, but they are only visiting, and there is no known population in Iceland. There are no native reptiles or amphibians in Iceland. Iceland's animals include Icelandic sheep, cows, chickens, goats, sturdy Icelandic horses, and Icelandic sheepdogs, all breeds of animals imported by Europeans. Wild mammals include arctic fox, mink, rat, hare and deer.

Polar bears occasionally visit the island, driving up icebergs from Greenland. In June 2008, two polar bears arrived in the same month. Marine mammals such as the gray seal (Halichoerus grypus) and harbor seal (Phoca vitulina). Many species of fish live in the ocean waters surrounding Iceland, and the fishing industry is a large part of Iceland's economy, accounting for about half of the country's total exports. Birds, especially seabirds, are an important part of Iceland's animal life. Puffins, skuas and kittiwakes nest on sea cliffs. The Arctic fox is the only land mammal native to Iceland and also the only mammal that existed before the arrival of humans. An Icelandic sheep Icelandic horse Iceland is a representative democracy and a parliamentary republic. A modern parliament, Alþingi was founded in 1845 as an advisory body to the Danish king. They currently have 63 members, who are elected for a maximum term of four years. The president is elected by popular vote for a term of four years, with no term limits. Elections for the president, Alþingi, and local municipal councils are all held separately every four years. Iceland does not have a standing army, but the Icelandic Coast Guard, which also maintains the Icelandic Air Defense System, and the Icelandic Crisis Response Unit to support peacekeeping missions, carry out para-military work. The Icelandic Defense Forces (IDF) was the military command of the United States Armed Forces from 1951 to 2006. The IDF, created at the request of NATO, was created when the United States signed an agreement to provide for the defense of Iceland. The IDF also consists of Icelandic civilians and military members of other NATO countries. The IDF was downsized after the end of the Cold War and the US Air Force maintained 4-6 interceptors at Keflavik Naval Air Station, until they were withdrawn on September 30, 2006.

Since May 2008, NATO countries have periodically deployed guerrillas to patrol Icelandic airspace on the mission of the Icelandic Air Police. Iceland supported the 2003 invasion of Iraq despite much popular controversy, deploying a coastguard EOD team to Iraq, which was replaced by members of the Icelandic Crisis Response Unit. Iceland has also participated in the ongoing conflict in Afghanistan and Operation Allied Force of 1999. Despite the financial crisis, the first new patrol boat in decades was launched on April 29, 2009. According to the Global Peace Index, Iceland is the most peaceful country in the world, due to the lack of armed forces, low crime rates, and high levels of socio-political stability. Iceland is listed in the Guinness Book of Records as the "Most peaceful ranked country" and "lowest military spending per capita". As of 2007, Iceland was the seventh most productive country in the world per capita (US$ 54,858), and the fifth most productive by GDP at purchasing power parity ($40,112). About 85 percent of Iceland's total primary energy supply comes from domestically produced renewable energy sources. The abundant use of hydroelectric and geothermal electricity has made Iceland the world's largest producer of electricity per capita. As a result of its commitment to renewable energy, the 2016 Global Green Economy Index ranked Iceland among the 10 greenest economies in the world. Historically, Iceland's economy has been heavily dependent on fishing, which still provides 40% of export earnings and employs 7% of the workforce. The economy is vulnerable to declining fish stocks and falling world prices for its main export materials: fish and fish products, aluminum and ferrosilicon. Whaling in Iceland is historically significant.

Iceland is still heavily dependent on fishing, but its importance has waned from a 90% export share in the 1960s to 40% in 2006. Until the 20th century, Iceland was a fairly poor country. Today, it remains one of the most developed countries in the world. Strong economic growth has kept Iceland ranked first in the United Nations Human Development Index report for 2007/2008, although in 2011 its HDI rating dropped to 14th as a result of the economic crisis. However, according to the 2011 Economist Intelligence Index, Iceland has the 2nd highest quality of life in the world. Based on the Gini coefficient, Iceland also has the lowest level of income inequality in the world, and when adjusted for inequality, its HDI ranking is 6th. Iceland's unemployment rate has declined consistently since the crisis, with 4.8% of the labor force unemployed in June 2012, compared to 6% in 2011 and 8.1% in 2010. Many political parties remain opposed to EU membership, mainly due to Iceland's concerns about losing control over their natural resources (especially fisheries). Iceland's national currency is the Icelandic króna (ISK). Iceland is the only country in the world that has a population under two million but still has a floating exchange rate and independent monetary policy. A poll released on 5 March 2010 by Capacent Gallup showed that 31% of respondents support the euro and 69% against it. Another Capacent Gallup poll conducted in February 2012 found that 67.4% of Icelanders would reject EU membership in a referendum. Iceland's economy has diversified into manufacturing and service industries in the last decade, including software production, biotechnology, and finance; Industry accounts for about a quarter of economic activity, while services account for nearly 70%.

The tourism sector is growing, especially in ecotourism and whale watching. On average, Iceland receives around 1.1 million visitors annually, which is more than three times the original population. 1.7 million people visited Iceland in 2016, 3 times more than the number who arrived in 2010. Iceland's agricultural industry, accounting for 5.4% of GDP, mainly consists of potatoes, green vegetables (in greenhouses), mutton and dairy products. milk. The financial center is Borgartún in Reykjavík, which houses a large number of companies and three investment banks. Iceland's stock market, the Icelandic Stock Exchange (ISE), was founded in 1985. Iceland is ranked 27th in the 2012 Index of Economic Freedom, lower than in previous years, but still among the freest in the world. In 2016, it ranked 29th in the World Economic Forum's Global Competitive Index, one place lower than 2015. According to the INSEAD Global Innovation Index, Iceland is the 11th most innovative country. Inside the world. Unlike most Western European countries, Iceland has a flat tax system: the main personal income tax rate is a flat 22.75%, and combined with the city tax, the total tax rate equals no more than 35.7%, not including the many deductions available The average corporate tax rate is 18%, one of the lowest in the world. There is also a value added tax, while the net wealth tax was abolished in 2006. Employment regulations are relatively flexible and the labor market is one of the freest in the world. Property rights are strong and Iceland is one of the few countries where they apply to fisheries management. Like other welfare states, taxpayers pay various subsidies to each other, but spend less than in most European countries.

Despite low tax rates, agricultural assistance is the highest among OECD countries and a potential barrier to structural change. Also, health care and education spending have had relatively poor returns by OECD measures, although improvements have been made in both areas. The 2008 OECD Iceland Economic Survey highlights Iceland's challenges in currency and macroeconomic policies. There was a currency crisis that started in the spring of 2008, and on 6 October trading in Icelandic banks was halted while the government struggled to save the economy. A 2011 OECD assessment determined that Iceland has made progress in many areas, most notably in creating a sustainable fiscal policy and restoring the health of the financial sector; However, challenges remain in making the fishing industry more efficient and sustainable, and in improving monetary policy to tackle inflation. Iceland's public debt has declined since the economic crisis, and as of 2015 was the 31st highest in the world as a proportion of national GDP. Iceland's population is mostly Scandinavian. The language they speak is Icelandic, which has barely changed its spelling or grammar in 1,000 years. Icelanders can even read ancient sagas that tell about the adventures of the Vikings without much difficulty. Almost all Icelanders follow the Lutheran faith of Christianity. Last name unknown in Iceland. Icelanders use a patronymic, with the ending -son if a man and -dóttir if a woman. For example, Jón Stefánsson has a son named Gunnar. Gunnar's last name is not Stefánsson like his father, but Gunnar Jónsson which means Gunnar, son of Jón. The same goes for women. If Jón Stefánsson had a daughter named Katrín, then his last name would not be Stefánsson, but Jónsdóttir.

In this case, the name means Katrín, daughter of Jón. In certain cases, a person's last name may also be taken not from the parents' first names, but from their second names. For example, if Jón was the son of Hjálmar Örn Vilhjálmsson, he could be named Jón Hjálmarsson (Jón, son of Hjálmar) or Jón Arnarson (Jón son of Örn). The reason is that the parents prefer their child to be called by the middle name, not by the first name. This is quite common or maybe the middle name sounds better with the child's first name. Most Icelandic last names carry that of the father, but in certain cases, the mother's name is used for various reasons. Sometimes the child or the mother wants to break social ties with the father. Some feminists use this as a social statement. Some others choose it just because of a matter of taste. Either way, the convention remains the same. Guðjón, son of Bryndís, will take the full name Guðjón Bryndísarson which means Guðjón, son of Bryndís. In many countries people call others by their last name, but in Iceland people call others by their first name. For example, when people talk about Halldór Ásgrímsson they don't call him Ásgrímsson, but Halldór, almost the same as calling people in most parts of Indonesia. There is also a name that was chosen as the most used name in Iceland, namely Guðrún (Gwuthrun), Guð: God, Rún: Secret knowledge Reykjavik is the capital of Iceland and plays an important role as a port city. The editor page has logged out learn more Surfactants are chemical compounds that can lower surface tension. This compound also serves to reduce the interfacial tension between two liquids, between gases and liquids, or between liquids and solids. Surfactants can act as detergents, wetting agents, emulsifiers, foaming agents (English: foaming agent), and dispersing agents (English: dispersants). surfactant The term surfactant (English: surfactant) is short for surface-active agent. The Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) of the United States National Library of Medicine refer to surfactants as "pulmonary surfactants" (English: pulmonary surfactant). In a broader sense, surfactants are surface active substances. Surfactants are usually organic compounds that are amphiphilic, meaning they have both hydrophobic (tail) and hydrophilic (head) groups. Therefore, surfactants contain both a water-insoluble (or oil-soluble) component and a water-soluble component. Surfactants will diffuse in water and be adsorbed at the interface between air and water or the interface between oil and water, when water is mixed with oil. Hydrophobic groups that are insoluble in water can break out of the aqueous phase, towards the air phase or the oil phase, while the water-soluble head groups remain in the aqueous phase. World surfactant production is estimated at around 15 Mtons/year, of which about half is soap. Other surfactants produced on a large scale are alkylbenzene sulfonate (1700 kton/year), lignin sulfonate (600 kton/year), fatty alcohol ethoxylates (700 kton/year), and alkylphenol ethoxylates (500 kton/year). In the bulk aqueous phase, surfactants form aggregates, a kind of micelles, where the hydrophobic tails form the core of the aggregate and the hydrophobic heads remain in contact with the surrounding liquid.

Other types of aggregates may also form, such as spherical or cylindrical micelles, or lipid bilayers. The shape of the aggregates depends on the chemical structure of the surfactant, namely the size balance between hydrophilic heads and hydrophobic tails. A measure of this balance is the hydrophilic-lipophilic balance (KHL). Surfactants lower the surface tension of water by adsorbing at the air-liquid interface. The equation relating surface tension and surface excess is known as the Gibbs isotherm. The dynamics of surfactant adsorption is very important for practical applications such as in foaming, emulsifying or coating processes, where bubbles or droplets are generated rapidly and need to be stabilized. The adsorption dynamics depends on the diffusion coefficient of the surfactant. When an interface is formed, adsorption is limited by the diffusion of the surfactant into the interface. In some cases, there is the formation of an energy barrier for the adsorption or desorption of surfactants. If such a barrier limits the rate of adsorption, the dynamics are said to be 'kinetic limited'. The energy barrier can be caused by steric or electrostatic repulsion. The surface rheology of the surfactant coating, including the elasticity and viscosity of the coating, plays an important role in the stability of foams and emulsions. The interfacial and surface tensions can be determined by classical methods such as the pendulum drop method or the rotating drop method. Surface tension dynamics, namely surface tension as a function of time, can be obtained by means of maximum bubble pressure. The structure of the surfactant layer can be observed using ellipsometry or X-Ray reflectivity. Surface rheology can be determined by the oscillating drop method or sliding surface rheometers such as the double cone rheometer, double ring rheometer or magnetic bar rheometer. The "tails" of most surfactants are quite similar, consisting of a hydrocarbon chain, which is either branched, linear, or aromatic. Fluorosurfactants have a fluorocarbon chain. Siloxane surfactants have siloxane chains. Many important surfactants include polyether chains with highly polar anionic groups at the terminal.

The polyether group often consists of an ethoxylated sequence (such as polyethylene oxide) that is interleaved to enhance the surfactant's hydrophilic properties. In contrast, polypropylene oxide, can be added to enhance the lipophilic properties of a surfactant. Some surfactant molecules have one or two tails; those with two tails are said to be double chained. In general, surfactants are classified according to the polarity of their head groups. Non-ionic surfactants have no charged groups on their heads. Ionic surfactant heads carry a positive, or negative, charge. If the charge is negative, the surfactant is said to be anionic; if the charge is positive, it is called cationic. If a surfactant contains a head with two oppositely charged groups, it is called a zwitterion. The following surfactants are commonly encountered: Anionic surfactants contain anionic functional groups at their heads, such as sulfates, sulfonates, phosphates, and carboxylates. Well-known alkyl sulfates include ammonium lauryl sulfate, sodium lauryl sulfate (sodium dodecyl sulfate, SLS, or SDS), and the related alkyl-ether sulfates, sodium laureth sulfate (sodium lauryl ether sulfate or SLES), and sodium myrate sulfate. Other anionic surfactants include: Carboxylates are the most common surfactants and consist of carboxylate salts (soaps), such as sodium stearate. More specific species include sodium lauroyl sarcosinate and carboxylate-based fluorosurfactants such as perfluorononanoate and perfluorooctanoate (PFOA or PFO). pH dependent primary, secondary, or tertiary amines; primary and secondary amines become positively charged at pH < 10: octenidine dihydrochloride. Permanently charged quaternary ammonium salts: cetrimonium bromide (CTAB), cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC), benzalkonium chloride (BAC), benzethonium chloride (BZT), dimethyldioctadecylammonium chloride and dioctadecyldimethylammonium bromide (DODAB). Zwitter ion (amphoteric) surfactants have both cationic and anionic centers attached to the same molecule. The cationic moiety is based on a primary, secondary, or tertiary amine or quaternary ammonium cation.

The anionic moieties can be more variable and include sulfonates, such as the CHAPS sultaines (3-(3-cholamidopropyl) dimethylamonio]-1-propanesulfonate) and cocamidopropyl hydroxysultaine. Betaines such as cocamidopropyl betaine have carboxylates with ammonium. The most common biological zwitter ion surfactants have a phosphate anion with an amine or ammonium, such as the phospholipids phosphatidylserine, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylcholine, and spingomyelin. Non-ionic surfactants have hydrophilic groups that are covalently bonded to their oxygen, and are bonded to a hydrophobic parent structure. The water solubility of its oxygen groups is a result of hydrogen bonding. Hydrogen bonds decrease with increasing temperature, and so the solubility of non-ionic surfactants in water decreases with increasing temperature. Non-ionic surfactants are less sensitive to water hardness than anionic surfactants, and they also foam less strongly. There are no significant differences between the respective types of non-ionic surfactants, and the choice is primarily adjusted considering the cost of specific properties (eg, effectiveness and efficiency, toxicity, dermatological compatibility, biodegradability) or approval for use in food. Fatty acid ethoxylates are a very versatile class of surfactants. The molecule contains a pH sensitive weak anion head group and a stabilizing and temperature sensitive ethyleneoxide unit. The human body produces a variety of surfactants. Pulmonary surfactant (English: pulmonary surfactant) is produced in the lungs to facilitate breathing by increasing total lung capacity, TLC, and lung compliance. In respiratory distress syndrome or RDS surfactant replacement therapy helps patients have normal respiration by using surfactants in pharmaceutical dosage forms. One example of lung surfactant for pharmaceutical preparations is Survanta (beractant) or its generic form Beraksurf produced by Abbvie and Tekzima. Bile salts play an important role in digestion. Most anionic and non-ionic surfactants are non-toxic, having an LD50 equivalent to that of sodium chloride. The toxicity of quaternary ammonium compounds, which have antibacterial and antifungal properties, varies.

Dialkyldimethylammonium chloride (DDAC, DSDMAC) which is used as a fabric softener has a low LD50 (5 g/kg) and is basically non-toxic, while the alkylbenzyldimethylammonium chloride disinfectant has an LD50 of 0.35 g/kg. Prolonged exposure to surfactants can irritate and damage the skin because surfactants disrupt the lipid membranes that protect skin and other cells. Skin irritation increases in the following order of surfactants: non-ionic, amphoteric, anionic, cationic. Surfactants are deposited routinely in a variety of ways on land and into water systems, either as part of related processes or as industrial and household waste. Some surfactants are known to be toxic to animals, ecosystems and humans, and can increase the diffusion of other environmental contaminants. Anionic surfactants can be found in soils as a result of sludge applications, wastewater irrigation, and remediation processes. Relatively high concentrations of surfactants together with multimetals can indicate a degree of environmental risk. At low concentrations, surfactant application is unlikely to have a significant effect on the mobility of trace metals. In the case of the Deepwater Horizon oil leak, Corexit, in unprecedented quantities, was sprayed directly into the sea at the leak and on the sea surface. The obvious theory is that surfactants insulate the oil droplets, making it easier for oil-eating microbes to digest the oil. The active ingredients in Corexit are dioctyl sodium sulfosuccinate (DOSS), sorbitan monooleate (Span 80), and polyoxyethylene sorbitan monooleate (Tween-80). The two main surfactants, linear alkylbenzene sulfonate (LAS) and alkyl phenol ethoxylates (APE) decompose under aerobic conditions found in sewage treatment plants and in soil to nonylphenol, which is considered an endocrine disruptor. What has attracted a lot of attention is the non-biodegradability of fluorosurfactants, e.g. perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA).

The annual global production of surfactants was 13 million tons in 2008. In 2014, the world market for surfactants reached a volume of more than 33 billion US dollars. The editor's page has logged out learn more Cycadophyta (pronounced: si-ka-do-fi-ta) is a division of the group of open seed plants (gymnosperms). This plant is a seed plant that is primitive, with fossil remains unchanged and its age can be extended to the early Permian period, 280 million years ago. The distribution of this plant in the world is limited in the tropics and subtropics. The roots are fibrous and form structures called coralloid roots (because of their miniature coral appearance) which contain cyanobacteria in threadlike colonies of the genus Anabaena. This root symbiosis with cyanobacteria is called cyanobionta (cyanobiont) and is mutualism because these cyanobacteria can bind free nitrogen from the air to become nitrate which is beneficial for the host plant. Stems are generally thick with starchy pith. The outer surface of the stem is characterized by a pattern of detached patches. Sometimes the stem does not emerge from the surface or only slightly emerges, forming a rounded appearance called the caudex. The leaves are arranged in a rosette around the apex of the stem; the fronds are pinnate or pinnate, although there are some exceptions. The reproductive organs are arranged in structures called cones, which are botanically called strobili (plural: strobili). Male and female strobilus are found at the ends of trunks on different trees (all members of this division are dioecious). Members of Cycadophyta that still survive on earth are all included in the Cycadales, and consist of the Cycadaceae (the most primitive) and Zamiaceae (there is a version that separates them into Stangeriaceae). The remaining five tribes belong to the Medullosales people and are only known from fossils dating back to the Paleozoic era. Based on genetic tests, this plant group is most closely related to Ginkgo compared to other gymnosperms.

This kingdom is believed by some to have existed in Central Java, but no evidence of its existence has been found. This kingdom is said to be an ahistorical kingdom because it originates from mythology and archaeological evidence has never been found, such as inscriptions or ancient remains regarding its existence. Sources regarding this kingdom are only in folk stories, for example as in the legend of Rara Jonggrang, and its mention in several new texts. The Javanese version of the wayang story states that Medang Kamulan is the place where Batara Guru is enthroned. In the Aji Saka legend, Medang Kamulan is the land where the just Sri Ajiwo Pamungkas reigns. Other folklore, including the legend of Rara Jonggrang and the founding of Madura, states that Medang Kamulan was ruled by King Gilingwesi. In Sundanese legend, this kingdom is the predecessor of the Galuh Kingdom. The legend of Aji Saka himself says that Bledug Kuwu in Grobogan Regency is the place where Jaka Linglung appeared after conquering Dewata Cengkar. Lines 782 and 783 of the second manuscript of Bujangga Manik's Travels from the 15th century mention that after Bujangga Manik left Pulutan (now a village to the west of Purwodadi, Central Java) he arrived at "Medang Kamulan". Furthermore, it is also said that after crossing the Wuluyu River, he arrived at Gegelang which is located south of Medang Kamulan. This text was the first to mention that there really was a place called Medang Kamulan, even though it didn't say that it was a kingdom. Serat Centhini mentions that the Medang Kamulan palace is located in the northwest of the Kasanga area, which is the place where Jaka Linglung died. Jayengresmi could no longer find the remains of the palace as everything had turned to earth and was covered in dense forest.

The editor's page has logged out learn more Kidung is an old form of poetry, especially one that developed since the era of Javanese literature in the Middle period, namely from the late Majapahit period. As an old poem, its form is very much bound by a strict metrum, in setting the pattern of rhyme (rhyme) in a stanza, the number of syllables (syllables) in one line, and the number of lines in one stanza. In its development, especially in Bali, chanting also involves musical instruments so that the song/tone elements are connected in a stanza pattern. Rules of this kind are also known in other old poetic forms in Javanese literature, such as kakawin and macapat. Kidung can also be interpreted as a meter pattern. Lexically, the word "kidung" comes from Middle Javanese and has the equivalent of tembang or sekar, meaning 'singing' in new Javanese. The verb form of kidung in Middle Javanese becomes mangidung, 'to sing'. New Javanese also recognizes the term kidung which has more or less the same meaning as kidung in Middle Javanese, and the verb form becomes ngidung or angidung. This meaning is then often used in the use of the term "kidung" as a hymn of praise or religion in modern Javanese as well as Indonesian. The most obvious difference between kidung and kakawin is the use of language. Kakawin uses Old Javanese, while kidung uses Middle Javanese. Another difference can also be seen in the absence of the guru laghu (tone rule) in kidung, which in kakawin is one of the standard rules. The difference in metrics is of course also an important characteristic of the two forms of poetry. Kidung is used to present stories and ritual readings, especially in the Balinese Hindu tradition. Folk stories inherited from the pre-Islamic Javanese period are often enshrined in the form of songs, such as the stories of Panji (for example in the Song Malat, Song Wangbang Wideya, and Song of Waseng) or other contemporary stories, such as the Song of Harsawijaya, the Song of Sunda, Song of Sorandaka, and Song of Ranggalawe, There are also songs that process animal stories as contained in the Tantri Kamandaka (for example in the Song Tantri Pisacaharana and the Song Tantri Manduka Prakarana).

However, Hindus do not worship Brahman literally. Sometimes, Brahman is seen as the Absolute or Omnipotent, or the divine principle of all matter, energy, time, space, matter and things within or outside the universe. As a result of various contemplations about Brahman, He can be seen as God with attributes (Saguna-brahman), God without attributes (Nirguna-brahman), and/or God Almighty (Parabrahman), depending on the sect and sect. According to this school, a God who has a personality or possesses certain attributes is one of the phenomena of maya, or the illusive power of Brahman. In essence, Brahman cannot be said to have human qualities such as being protective, compassionate, caring, compassionate, and so on. According to this school, the human mind trapped in maya causes Brahman to be imagined as God with certain characteristics or attributes, which can be referred to as Iswara, Bhagawan, Vishnu, and other names. This school asserts that there is no prohibition against imagining a God with certain qualities, but that the real aim of life is to feel that the "real thing" in every being is in fact not different from Brahman. The Adwaita School can be said to be monism or pantheism because it believes that the universe does not merely originate from Brahman, but is "essentially" the same as Brahman. In Hinduism there is a belief that there is "something real" in each individual called atman, which is eternal or indestructible. According to monistic/pantheistic Hindu theology (such as the Adwaita Vedanta school), the individual soul is not at all different from Brahman. The individual soul is called Jiwatman, while Brahman is called Paramatman. Therefore, this teaching is called non-dualism. When the individual's body disintegrates, the soul does not disintegrate. Instead, he transfers to a new body through reincarnation (samsara). The soul experiences it because it is covered by awidya or "unconsciousness" that it is actually the same as Paramatman. According to the Adwaita school of thought, the purpose of life is to realize that atman is actually the same as Brahman. The Upanishads state that anyone who feels that atman is the essence of each individual, he will realize equality with Brahman, thus achieving moksa (freedom or independence from the process of reincarnation/samsara). The Yoga of Rishi Patanjali—as described in the Yogasutra—is different from the monism described in the Adwaita philosophy. Breaking down the "wall of human consciousness" to build a "unity" of individual identity (jiwatman) with the soul of the universe (paramatman), is the goal of yoga practice. The libraries are classified into two classes: Sruti and Smerti. Sruti (meaning "that which is heard") refers primarily to the collection of the Vedas, which are the oldest form of Hindu literature. There are four Vedas, namely the Rigveda (Ṛgveda), Samaweda (Sāmaveda), Yajurweda (Yajurveda), and Atharwaweda (Atharvaveda). The Rigveda is the first and most important Veda. Each Veda is divided into four sections: the main one—the standard Veda—is the Samhita (Saṃhitā), which collects mantras. The other three sections form a set of supplementary classes to the Samhita, usually in prose and believed to be younger than the Saṃhitā. The three sections are the Brahmins (Brāhmaṇa), Aranyaka (Āraṇyaka), and the Upanishads. The first two sections are called Karmakanda (Karmakāṇḍa; ritual portion), while the last is called Jnanakanda (Jñānakāṇḍa; knowledge portion). The Vedic collections focus on ceremonial performance, while the Upanishadic collections focus on spiritual insights and philosophical teachings, as well as discussing Brahman and reincarnation. Hindu scriptures which are not included in Sruti are classified under Smerti (memory).

The famous Smerti book is the Indian epic (Itihasa), consisting of the Mahabharata (Mahābhārata) and the Ramayana (Rāmāyaṇa). Itihasa is a part of Hindu literature which tells the story of the heroism of Hindu kings and knights in the past and combined it with religious philosophy, mythology and stories about supernatural beings. The Bhagavadgita (Bhagavadgītā) is an integral part of the Mahabharata, and is one of the most famous Hindu scriptures.
