The Puranas (Purāṇa)—which describe Hindu teachings through vivid stories—are classified under the Smerti. The Puranas contain ancient myths, legends and stories that Hindus believe to be true. The word Purana means "ancient history" or "ancient stories". The writing of the Puranas is thought to have started around 500 BC. There are eighteen books of the Puranas called the Mahapurana. Other scriptures belonging to the Smerti include Devimahatmya (Devīmahātmya), Tantra, Yogasutra, Tirumantiram, Siwasutra, and Religion (Āgama). Apart from that, there is the Manusmerti book, which is a prescriptive legal book that underlies social rules and social stratification which then guides society to form the caste system in India. The Tantra book contains details about the ways of worshiping each sect in Hinduism. The Tantra scriptures also regulate the construction of Hindu shrines and the placement of statues. The Nitisastra book contains leadership teachings and guidelines for becoming a good leader.

The Jyotisha Book is a book that contains the teachings of the traditional Hindu astronomical system. The Jyotisha Book contains guidelines about the heavenly bodies and their orbits. The Jyotisha Book is used for divination and foreseeing the coming of a season. James Mill (1773–1836), in his book The History of British India (1817), divided the history of India into three stages, namely Hindu, Muslim and British civilizations. This periodization has been criticized because of the misunderstanding it causes. Another periodization divides into ancient, classical, medieval, and modern periods. Smart and Michaels seem to follow a periodization according to Mill,j] while Flood and Muesse follow a periodization which is divided into ancient, classical, medieval, and modern periods. Different periods are defined as the time of Classical Hinduism: The first human race to colonize India (ca. 40,000–60,000 years ago, during the Paleolithic period) were Australoids who may have some connection with the indigenous peoples of Australia. There are suggestions that the race was almost extinct or pushed back by a wave of migration at a later time. After the Australoid occupation, the Caucasoid (including Elamo-Dravidian peoples ca. 4000 to 6000 BC] and Indo-Aryan people ca. 2000 to 1500 BC]) and Mongoloid (Sino-Tibetan) migrated to India. The Elamo-Dravidal peoples] probably originated in Elam, now a region of Iran. India's oldest prehistoric religion—which may have left its mark on Hinduism—dates from the mesolithic and neolithic ages. Several tribal religions in India have survived, predating the dominance of Hinduism, but it should not be assumed that there are many similarities between tribal society in prehistoric times and today. According to the anthropologist Gregory Possehl, the civilization of the Indus river valley (2600–1900 BC) provided a logical, or possibly arbitrary, starting point for several aspects of later Hindu traditions. The religion at this time contained worship of an omnipotent deity, whom some scholars (notably John Marshall) compared to a proto-Shiva, and possibly a Mother Goddess figure, underlying the figure of Sakti.

Other practices from the time of the Indus valley civilization that continued into the Vedic period included worship of water and fire. However, the relationship between the gods and religious practices of the Indus valley religion and contemporary Hinduism has been the subject of political disputes as well as scholarly debate. Vedic period—which lasted from ca. 1750 to 500 BCn]—so called because it was based on the Vedic-based religion adopted by the Indo-Aryans,o] who migrated to southwestern India after the decline of the Indus valley civilization (possibly from the steppes of Central Asia). This nation brought with them their language and religion. Their religion developed further when migrating to the plains of North India after ca. 1100 BC and became a pastoralist. Although the beliefs and practices of Preclassical Hinduism may derive from material from the (hypothetical) Proto-Indo-European religion, the literature underlying the tradition at that time was the Veda Samhita, for which the period is named. The oldest book among the Vedic literature is the Rigveda, which is thought to have been composed in the period 1700–1100 BC. p] Vedic literature focuses on worshiping gods such as Indra, Baruna and Agni, and performs the Soma ceremony. Sacrifices with fire, called yadnya (yajña) are performed by reciting Vedic mantras. Vedic literature was codified when the Indo-Aryans began to colonize the fertile plains of North India, then made the transition from a herding society to an agrarian society, so the need for a more structured organization arose. The new society involved residents who had previously settled in the fertile plains. They were assigned a color system according to the Aryans, with political and religious authority vested in the brahmins and warriors. During the Early Vedic Period (ca.

1500–1100 BC), the Vedic tribes were herding tribes, wandering around northwestern India. After 1100 BC, with the discovery of iron, the Vedic tribes moved to the western plains of North India, and adapted an agrarian lifestyle. Rudimentary forms of sovereign territory began to emerge, the most prominent or influential being the Kuru tribal kingdom. The kingdom was a group of tribes, which later developed into a state-level society—the first recorded in South Asian history—around 1000 AD. They blatantly changed the cultural heritage of the previous Vedic Period, collecting Vedic hymns into a collection, and developed the new rituals which were prominent in Indian civilization as the srauta ceremonies, which contributed to the "classical synthesis" or "Hindu synthesis". The 9th and 8th centuries BC saw the compilation of the oldest Upanishads. The Upanishads form a theoretical basis for Classical Hinduism and are known as the Vedanta (conclusions from the Vedas). The ancient Upanishads counteract the increasing intensity of the ceremonies. The various monistic speculations of the Upanishads are synthesized into a theistic framework in the Hindu scripture Bhagawadgita. Ethics in the Vedic scriptures is based on the concepts of satya and reta. Satya is the principle of integration rooted in absoluteness. Reta is an expression of satya, which regulates and coordinates the course of the universe and everything in it. Conformance with the rita will allow things to go as they should, while deviations will result in things that are not desirable. The term dharma has been used in Brahmanical philosophies, where it is seen as an aspect of reta. The term reta is also known in the Proto-Indo-Iranian religion, namely the religion of the Indo-Iranian people before the presence of the Vedic books (Indo-Aryan) and Zoroastrianism (Iran). Asha (aša) is an Avestan term similar to ṛta in the Vedas.

The Vedas were a library for the elite, and did not merely express popular ideas or practices. In the later period, Vedic-based religion coexisted with local religions—such as the Yaksa cult—and was itself the result of a mixture of Indo-Aryan and Harrapa cultures. The increase in urbanization in India in the 7th and 6th centuries B.C. led to the ascetic movement or Sramana against the fanaticism of rituals. Mahavira (ca. 549–477 BC, founder of Jainism) and Gautama Buddha (ca. 563–483 BC, founder of the Buddhist tradition) were prominent figures in the movement. According to Heinrich Zimmer, Jainism and Buddhism are part of the pre-Vedic cultural heritage, which also includes Samkhya and Yoga: Jainism does not derive from Brahman-Aryan cultural sources,q] but reflects the cosmology and anthropology of upper class pre-Aryan societies. who lived] in northeastern India–based on the same foundations of ancient metaphysical speculations as Yoga, Sankhya, and Buddhism, that is, other Indian teachings that are not based on the Vedas.r] In one passage, the Sramana tradition teaches the concept the cycle of birth and death (the cycle of reincarnation), the concept of samsara, and the concept of seeking liberation (from that reincarnation), which characterizes Hinduism. James B. Pratt in his book The Pilgrimage of Buddhism and a Buddhist Pilgrimage writes that Oldenberg (1854–1920), Neumann (1865–1915), and Radhakrishnan (1888–1975) believed that the Buddhist Tripitaka was influenced by the Upanishads, whereas la Vallee Poussin maintains no influence whatsoever, and other scholars assert that in certain places the Buddha makes a direct antithesis to the Upanishads. The period of Classical Hinduism begins with the period of Preclassical Hinduism, continues with the heyday of Hinduism during the Gupta Dynasty, and then closes with the Late Classical Hinduism period. This period of Classical Hinduism was followed by the arrival of Islam to South Asia, followed by the establishment of schools or sects within Hinduism.

In the period from 500 to 200 BC, and ca. 300 AD, the "Hindu synthesis" took place, absorbing Sramana and Buddhist influences, as well as the emergence of the devotional tradition in Brahmanism through Smerti literature. This synthesis arose under the pressure of the development of Buddhism and Jainism. According to Embree, several other religious traditions coexist with Vedic-based religions. These indigenous religions eventually found a place under the auspices of the Vedic religion. When Brahmanism began to lose its prestige and had to compete with Buddhism and Jainism, the popular religions had the opportunity to highlight their teachings. According to Embree: Brahmanists seem to have been active in expanding their religious development] in order to deal with the onslaught of more heterodox sects. At the same time, among existing indigenous religions, loyalty to the literary authority of the Vedas has provided a thin—yet so significant—line of unity between the plurality of gods and existing religious practice]. s] According to Larson, the the brahmins responded by assimilation and consolidation. This is reflected in the Smerti library which began to be compiled during that period. The Smerti scriptures from the period 200 BC–100 AD proclaim the authority of the Vedas, so that recognition of the authority of the Vedas is the main criterion for distinguishing Hinduism from heterodox schools that reject the Vedas. Most of the basic ideas and practices of Classical Hinduism are derived from the Smerti literature, which later became the basic inspiration for most Hindus. The two leading Indian epics—Ramayana and Mahabharata—which belong to the Smerti, were composed over a long period during the late BC and early Christian eras. The library contains mythological stories about leaders and wars in ancient India, and is interspersed with philosophy and religious teachings. The Purana literature composed at a later period contains stories about the gods, their interactions with humans, and their battles with the rakshasas.

The Bhagawadgita book reinforces the successful consolidation of Hinduism, by mixing and matching Brahmanical and Sramana ideas into a theistic devotional service. In the early Christian era, several schools of Hindu philosophy were formally codified, including Samkhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisesika, Purwamimamsa, and Vedanta. During this period, power over India was centralized, as trade to distant lands expanded, legal procedures standardized, and literacy was eradicated. Mahayana Buddhism spread, while orthodox Brahmin culture began to be revived under the patronage of the Gupta dynasty, led by Vaishnava kings. The position of the brahmins was strengthened again and Hindu temples began to be built as dedications to Hindu gods. During the reign of the Gupta dynasty, the literary Puranas began to be written, used to spread common religious ideology among the acculturated indigenous and illiterate people. The Gupta kings protected the nascent Puranic tradition for the sake of their dynasty. This led to the emergence of Hinduism-Puranism (Puranic Hinduism), which was different from the previous Brahmanism which referred to Dharmasastra and Smerti. The Bhakti movement emerged during this period. The Bhakti movement is a fast-growing development of the devotional tradition, originating in Tamil Nadu (South India). The Nayanar of the Saiwa school (4th – 10th century) and the Alwar of the Vaishnava school (3rd – 9th century) spread poetry and devotional traditions to various parts of India from the 12th to the 18th century. According to P.S. Sharma, the Gupta and Harsha periods form—from an intellectual point of view—the most glorious period in the development of Indian philosophy, when Hindu and Buddhist philosophies flourished side by side. Carwaka, a school of atheistic materialism, appeared in North India before the 8th century. After the collapse of the Gupta and Harsha empires, power in India was decentralized. Several large empires began to stand up, with very many conquered lands.

These kingdoms were ruled by a feudal system. The smaller kingdoms depend on the larger kingdoms. Maharajas are elusive, highly exalted and deified, as depicted in Tantric mandalas, and sometimes the king is depicted as the center of the mandala. The division of central power also leads to regionalization of religiosity, as well as religious competition. Local cults and languages ​​took precedence, and the influence of ritualistic Brahmanic Hinduism diminished. Folk and devotional movements began to emerge, along with the growth of] the Shaiva, Vaishnava, Bhakti, and Tantra traditions, although the division by sect occurred only during the early development of these traditions. Religious movements competed for recognition from local authorities. Buddhism lost its prestige after the 8th century and then began to fade in India. This is implied by the discontinuation of Buddhist puja rites in Indian court circles in the 8th century, when Hindu gods replaced the Buddha as royal protector. The ancient Puranic literature was composed to spread religious ideology that was common among the acculturated indigenous peoples. Along with the dadal period of the Gupta dynasty, virgin lands were collected by the brahmins, which not only guaranteed the agrarian profits from the exploitation of the lands owned by the kings, but also gave the new ruling class status. Brahmins spread across India, interacting with local people who adhere to different beliefs and ideologies. The brahmins used the Puranas to persuade the various clans to become an agrarian society, and to follow the religion and ideology of the brahmins. According to Flood, the brahmins who followed a Purana-based religion came to be known as Smarta, meaning people who worshiped according to Smerti, or Pauranika, namely followers of the Puranas. Local tribal chiefs and citizens were absorbed into the color system, in order to control the behavior of the "new knights and sudras".

Brahmin groups grew larger by including local people, such as local priests and clergy. This leads to stratification for the Brahmins, so that there are Brahmins who have a higher degree than other Brahmins. The interpretation of the caste system is more suitable for Puranic Hinduism than for the Sramana (Buddhist or Jaina) schools. The Purana literature includes an extensive genealogical history that can give a class a new status of warriors. Meanwhile, Buddhism describes government as a contract between the elect and the people, and Buddhist chakkavatti is a different concept from the conquering model of the Hindu warriors and Rajputs. Brahmanism based on the Dharmasastra and Smerti literature underwent a radical transformation at the hands of the compilers of the Puranas, resulting in the emergence of Puranic Hinduism, like a "giant" that crossed the "religious horizon", which then crossed all existing religions. Puranic Hinduism is a multifaceted belief system that grew and expanded by absorbing and integrating contradictory ideas and cult traditions. This religion is different from Smarta, which is its origin. The difference lies in fame, theological pluralism, sect pluralism, Tantric influence, and the emphasis on devotional service. Many local beliefs and traditions were assimilated into Puranic Hinduism. Vishnu and Shiva appear as the main gods, side by side with Sakti/Dewi. Worship of Vishnu eventually gave rise to the cults of Narayana, Jagatnata, Wenkateswara, and others. According to Nath: Several incarnations of Vishnu such as Matsya, Kurma, Waraha, and even Narasinga helped to integrate popular totem symbols and creation myths, especially those related to the wild boar, which generally permeated the mythology of [the library], while other incarnations such as Kresna and Balarama became a means of assimilation to local cults and myths centered on rural and agricultural gods. t] Rama and Krishna became central idols in the devotional tradition, which are especially expressed in the Bhagavata Purana.

Krishna worship traditions involve several cults based on dragons, yaksa, hills, and trees. Shiva absorbed local cults by adding the words Isa or Iswara to the names of local gods, for example Buteswara, Hatakeswara, Candeswara. Within the royal family in the 8th century, worship of Buddha began to be replaced by worship of Hindu gods. It was also during this period that Buddha was included as one of Vishnu's avatars. The non-dualistic Adwaita Vedanta school—which was influenced by Buddhism—was reformulated by Adi Shankara by systematizing the works of his predecessors. Today, due to the influence of Western Orientalism and Perennialism on Indian Neo-Vedanta and Hindu nationalism, Adwaita Wedanta has received wide acceptance in Indian culture and outside India as a paradigmatic example of Hindu spirituality. Although Islam had come to India as early as the 7th century (along with the arrival of Arab traders and the conquest of Sindhu), it became the main religion during the later period of Islamic conquest in South Asia. During this period, Buddhism faded away drastically, and many Hindus converted to Islam. Many Muslim rulers and their commanders, such as Aurangzeb and Malik Kafur, destroyed Hindu places of worship and oppressed non-Muslims; however, some Muslim rulers such as Akbar were more tolerant. Hinduism underwent major reforms due to the influence of the prominent Guru Ramanuja, as well as Guru Madhwa, and Sri Caitanya. Followers of the Bhakti movement moved away from the abstract concept of Brahman—advocated by the philosopher Adi Shankara centuries earlier—to a more fervent devotional tradition of the more easily imaginable idol worship, especially Krishna and Rama. According to Nicholson, between the 17th and 16th centuries, certain scholars began to draw threads from the wide variety of philosophical teachings in the Upanishads, epics, Puranas, and schools of philosophy known as the "six systems" (saddarsana) of common Hindu philosophy.

Lorenzen determines that the origin of a distinctly Hindu identity stems from interactions between Muslims and Hindus, and from a process of searching for an identity that differentiates oneself from Muslims, which began before the 1800s. Both Indian and European scholars—who popularized the term "Hinduism" in the 19th century—have been influenced by this philosophy. Michaels underlines that historicization emerged before later nationalism, which gave voice to the notion of the glory of Hinduism and its past. In the midst of the rule of the British Raj (British colonization of India), the Hindu Renaissance began to rise in the 19th century, which gave a big change to the understanding of Hinduism, both in India and in the West. Indology (the scientific discipline of studying Indian culture from a European perspective) was founded in the 19th century, led by scholars such as Max Müller and John Woodroffe. They brought the philosophy and literature of the Vedas, the Puranas and the Tantras to Europe. Orientalists searched for the "substance" of religions in India, and found them in the Vedic literature, while making the idea that "Hinduism" is a combination of various religious traditions and the popular image of 'mystical India'. This idea was adopted by some Hindu reform movements such as Brahmo Samaj, which was supported for a time by the Unitarian Church, along with the ideas of Universalism and Perennialism, namely the idea that all religions have a common basis of mysticism. "Hindu Modernism", with prominent figures such as Vivekananda, Aurobindo, and Radhakrishnan serving as role models in the popular understanding of Hinduism. Influential Hindu figures in the 20th century were Ramana Maharshi, B.K.S. Iyengar, Paramahansa Yogananda, Swami Prabhupada (founder of ISKCON), Sri Chinmoy, and Swami Rama, who translated, reformulated, and introduced the basic literature of Hinduism to today's lay audience with new imla, raised views on Yoga and Vedanta in the West , as well as attracting new followers and public attention in India and other countries.

In the 20th century, Hinduism also gained prominence as a political force and a reference for Indian national identity. Since the founding of the Hindu Mahasabha in the 1910s, many movements have grown with the formulation and development of Hindutva ideology in the following decades; founding of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) in 1925; and the RSS branch—later successful—namely the Jana Sangha and the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in electoral politics in post-independence India. Hindu religiosity also played an important role in the nationalist movement. Hindu society is categorized into four classes, called colors, which are as follows: The Bhagawadgita relates color to one's obligations (swadharma), nature (swabhāwa), and natural tendencies (guṇa). Based on the understanding of color according to Bhagawadgita, the Hindu spiritual figure Sri Aurobindo created the doctrine that one's work should be determined by one's natural talents and capacities. In the Manusmerti book there is a grouping of different castes. Mobility and flexibility in color refute allegations of social discrimination within the caste system, as argued by some sociologists, although some scholars disagree. Scholars debate whether the caste system is part of Hinduism which is governed by scriptures, or is it just a social custom.u] Various experts argue that the caste system was built by the British colonial regime. According to the Hindu spiritual teacher Sri Ramakrishna (1836–1886): Lovers of God does not belong to any particular caste... A brahmin without love of God is no longer a brahmin. And a pariah without love for God is no longer a pariah. Through bhakti (devotion to God), a lowly person can become pure and his rank increases. According to Vedanta literature, a person who is outside of the colors is called "warnatita". Scholars such as Adi Sankara assert that not only is Brahman beyond all colors, but one who can unite with Him can also transcend all differences and limitations of castes.

Traditionally, the life of Hindus is divided into four āśramas or chessasramas (four phases or four stages). The first part of one's life is Brahmacari, which is the period of studying. This stage is carried out before marriage, to be able to contemplate purely and wisely under Master's guidance, to build up the mind and spiritual foundation. The next stage is Grehasta, namely the stage of building a household life, carried out by getting married and fulfilling kāma (sensuous pleasures) and arta (prosperity). After getting married, the moral obligations that are carried out include: raising children, caring for parents, honoring guests and saints. After being married for a certain period of time, Hindus then go through the Wanaprasta stage, which is a period of retirement or a period of detachment from worldly activities. This stage can be carried out by handing over responsibility to offspring, so that retirees get more opportunities to carry out religious activities and visit holy places. The last stage is Sannyasa, which is the time to spend the rest of your life doing tapa brata, or trying to escape worldly ties. The release is done in order to find God, as well as to find a way to leave the mortal body peacefully, in order to achieve a condition called moksha. Hindu religious practice is usually aimed at seeking awareness of God, and sometimes seeking boons from the gods. Therefore, there are various religious practices within the body of Hinduism that are intended to help a person in their efforts to understand God in everyday life. In many religious practices and rituals, Hindus usually chant mantras. Mantras are invocations, calls, or prayers that help Hindus focus their minds on a particular God or deity, through words, sounds, and ways of chanting.

In the morning, on the banks of the sacred river, many Hindus carry out a cleansing ceremony while chanting the Gayatri Mantra or Mahamrityunjaya mantras. The Epic Mahabharata exalts japa (hymns) as the greatest obligation during the Kaliyuga (present day, 3102 BC–present). Many traditions have adopted japa as their primary spiritual practice. A quite popular Hindu spiritual practice is Yoga. Yoga is a Hindu teaching whose purpose is to train awareness for peace, health, and spiritual insight. This is done through a set of exercises and the formation of body positions to control the body and mind. Bhajans are the practice of chanting hymns. This practice takes various forms: it can be either simply mantras or kirtan, or it may be dhrupad or kriti with music based on ragas and tala based on Indian classical music. Usually, bhajans contain verses to express love for God. The term is the equivalent of bhakti meaning "religious devotion", implying the importance of bhajan to the devotional movement that spread from southern India across the Indian subcontinent during the Moghul period. Stories from scriptures, teachings of saints, and descriptions of gods have become the subject of bhajans. The dhrupad tradition, Sufi qawwali, and kirtan or songs in the Haridasi tradition are related to bhajans. Nanak, Kabir, Meera, Narottama Dasa, Surdas and Tulsidas were among the leading bhajan poets. Traditions in bhajans such as Nirguni, Gorakhanathi, Vallabhapanthi, Ashtachhap, Madhura-bhakti, and Sampradya Bhajan from South India have their own repertoires and ways of chanting. Many Hindus from various sects carry out daily religious rituals. Many Hindus practice it at home, but the practice varies depending on the region, village, and the tendencies of the people themselves. Devout Hindus carry out daily rituals such as the morning prayer after bathing (usually in the family shrine/shrine, and this is usually accompanied by lighting lamps and offering offerings to the statues of deities), reading the holy book over and over again, singing worship songs, meditation, chanting mantras, and so on.

A prominent feature in Hindu religious rituals is the distinction between pure and polluted. There are rules that indicate how conditions are said to be polluted or impure, so that the performers of the ceremony must carry out cleaning or purification again before the ceremony begins. Thus, purification—usually with water—is a common feature of most Hindu religious activities. Other characteristics include the belief in the efficacy of the ceremony and the concept of merits obtained through generosity or sincerity, which will accumulate over time thereby reducing suffering in the next life. Rites by means of fire (yadnya) are now not performed as often as possible, although their implementation is highly exalted in theory. However, in traditional Hindu wedding and funeral ceremonies, the performance of yadnya and the chanting of Vedic mantras are still adjusted to the norm. Some of the ceremonies also changed over time. For example, in the past several centuries, offerings of sacred dance and music according to the standard Sodasa Upachara rules—as stated in the Religion of Shastra—were replaced by offerings of rice and sweets. Events such as birth, marriage and death involve a detailed set of Hindu traditions. In Hinduism, ceremonies for the "cycle of life" include Annaprashan (when a baby can eat solid food for the first time), Upanayanam (auguration of middle and upper caste children when they begin their formal education), and Śrāddha (a ceremony of entertaining people with food for being willing to recite prayers to "God" so that the soul of the deceased may find peace). As for marriage, for most Indians, the engagement period of the young couple and the date and time of the wedding are determined by the parents in consultation with astrologers. For matters of death, cremation is an obligation that must be carried out by the relatives of the deceased, except if the deceased is a sanyasin, hijra, or a child under five years.

Usually, cremation is done by wrapping the body in clothes first, then burning it with a bonfire. Hindus advocate the practice of ahimsa (ahiṃsā; meaning "non-violence") and respect for all forms of life because they believe that a "spark from God" also permeates every living thing, including plants and animals. The term ahimsa is mentioned in the Upanishads and the Mahabharata epic. Ahimsa is the first of the five yama (pancayamabrata; five principles of self-control) in the Yogasutra of Patanjali, and is the first principle for all members of the Warnasramadarma (brahmanas, knights, waisya, and sudras) according to Manusmerti. The concept of ahimsa in Hinduism is not as strict as Buddhism and Jainism, because traces of the existence of sacrificial practices can be traced in the Vedic scriptures, for example the mantras for goat sacrifices (in the Rigveda), horse sacrifices (Aswameda, in the Yajurveda), and human sacrifices. (Purusameda, in the Yajurveda), while in the Jyotistoma rite there are three animals that are sacrificed through a ceremony, each of which is called Agnisomiya, Sawaniya, and Anubandya. The Yajurveda is considered a Veda of sacrifice and ritual, and mentions several rites of animal sacrifice, for example the mantras and procedures for sacrificing a white goat to Bayu, a calf to Saraswati, a spotted cow to Sawitr, a bull to Indra, a cow being castrated to Baruna, and etc. Responses against the implementation of the sacrifice came from the Carwaka sect who wrote their criticism in the Barhaspatyasutra (3rd century BC) as follows: "If the animal sacrificed in the Jyotistoma rite will soon reach heaven, why doesn't the performer just sacrifice his father immediately?" During the development of Hinduism and Buddhism in India, Buddhist kings like Ashoka influenced their subjects by prohibiting the performance of sacrifices. During Ashoka's reign, an edict was enacted and inscribed on a stone, with the following words: "This is an edict from one dear to the gods, King Piyadasi.

Killing animals cannot be carried out forever." From here, social reactions regarding the book of sacrificial procedures (Brahmins) can be traced. According to Panini, there are two kinds of Brahmins, namely Old Brahmins and New Brahmins. In Old Brahmins—such as Aitareya Brahmins for the Rigveda—sacrifice was actually made, but in New Brahmins such as the Shatapatha Brahmana, the sacrificial animal was released after being tied to the sacrificial stake. This was a reaction from the rise of Sramana religions—such as Buddhism and Jainism—which resulted in the laying down of the concept of ahimsa in among practitioners of the Brahmin scriptures. In accordance with the concept of ahimsa, many Hindus follow vegetarianism (not eating meat) out of respect for higher forms of life. Some devotees abstain from eating meat only on certain days. The eating culture also varies according to the community and For example, some castes have few vegetarians anism, while coastal communities tend to depend on seafood. Estimates of the number of lacto-vegetarians in India (covering people of all religions there) vary between 20% and 42%. : purity (satwam), zeal (rajas), and indolence (tamas). Therefore, the rules of healthy eating will be something that helps cleanse one's heart. Based on these reasons, Hindus are advised to avoid or minimize consumption of foods that do not improve liver hygiene. Some examples of the food in question are shallots and garlic, which are believed to have the nature of rajas (a state characterized by being rebellious and selfish), and meat (the meat of any animal), which is believed to contain the trait of tamas (a state characterized by anger). , gluttony, and envy).

Vegetarianism is advocated by a number of schools of Hinduism—including Vaishnavas and Saivas—which prohibit animal sacrifices, but are discouraged by schools of Hinduism which allow animal sacrifices. In general, animal sacrifices are performed by Hindus from the Sakta sect, (several) Hindu communities from the Sudra and Kshatriya groups, adherents of Hinduism in East India, and adherents of Hinduism in Southeast Asia. In general, Hindus who eat meat will not want to eat beef. In Hindu society, the cow is believed to be a human caretaker as well as a maternal figure, and they respect it as a symbol of unconditional love. Therefore, the practice of slaughtering cows is officially banned in almost all states in India. Today, there are many Hindu religious groups that emphasize the strict practice of vegetarianism. One well-known example is the ISKCON (International Society for Krishna Consciousness) movement, which obliges its followers not only to abstain from eating meat (including fish and poultry), but also to avoid certain vegetables/plants that are considered to have negative effects, such as shallots, garlic, and mushrooms. The second example is the Swaminarayan movement. Followers of this movement are also very loyal not to consume meat, eggs and fish. A number of Hindus choose to live as ascetics (Sanyasa) in an effort to attain "moksha" or other forms of spiritual perfection. Ascetics commit to a simple life, abstain from sex, do not seek worldly goods, and contemplate God. Hindu ascetics are called sanyasin, sadu, or swāmi, while the women are called sanyāsini. People who break away from worldly bonds gain high respect in Hindu society because their egoism and worldly attachments they renounce serve as inspiration for people who are still married to struggle in controlling the mind.

Some ascetics live in shrines or hostels, while others wander from place to place in the belief that only God can fulfill their desires. For ordinary Hindus, providing food and necessities for ascetics or sadu is a very great service. The sadus, on the other hand, receive them with respect and sympathy—without regard for poor or rich, good or evil—without needing to praise, criticize, show pleasure, or grieve. Holy places or places of worship for Hindus are generally called temples. Some local terms for Hindu shrines include candi, pura, mandir, devasthana, ksetram, dharmakshetram, koil, deula, wat, and bale sacred. The construction of the temples and the rituals of worship are regulated in several Sanskrit texts called Religions, which deal with individual deities. There are substantial differences in architecture, customs, rituals and traditions regarding temples in different parts of India. Hindus may hold pujas (prayers or services) at their homes or temples. For home worship, Hindus usually make a sacred room or small shrine with an icon or altar dedicated to a particular god or goddess (istadewata), for example Krishna, Ganesha, Durga, local deities, or other respected entities (eg ancestors or guardian spirit). Hindus pray through a murti or pratima, which can be in the form of a statue, phallus, or something else—as a symbol of the god they worship—which is sacred/purified first through a ceremony. Usually, the temple building is dedicated as a place of worship to a main deity and associated secondary deities. There are also temple buildings dedicated to several gods at once. For most Hindus in India, visiting the temple is not an obligation, and many devotees visit the temple only on holidays.

Murti or pratima in the temple acts as a medium between the devotees and God. Murti imagery is considered as a representation or manifestation of God, because Hindus believe that God is everywhere. However, there is a group of Hindus who do not offer pure prayers of any kind; a prominent example is the Arya Samaj school. edit page out log learn more Urine, urine, urine, or urine is the liquid left over excreted by the kidneys which is then excreted from the body through the urinary tract in the process of urination. Urine excretion is needed to remove residual molecules in the blood that are filtered by the kidneys and to maintain body fluid homeostasis. However, there are also several species that use urine as a means of olfactory communication. Urine is filtered in the kidneys, carried through the ureters to the bladder, and finally excreted out of the body through the urethra. Urine consists of water with dissolved materials in the form of metabolic waste (such as urea), dissolved salts, and organic matter. The fluids and materials that make up urine come from the blood or interstitial fluid. The composition of the urine changes during the reabsorption process when molecules important to the body, eg glucose, are reabsorbed into the body via carrier molecules. The remaining fluid contains high levels of urea and various excess or potentially toxic compounds that will be excreted from the body. The material contained in urine can be identified through urinalysis. Urea contained in urine can be a good source of nitrogen for plants and can be used to accelerate compost formation. Diabetes is a disease that can be detected through urine. The urine of a person with diabetes will contain sugar that will not be found in the urine of a healthy person. The main function of urine is to remove waste substances such as poisons or drugs from the body. It is generally accepted that urine is a "dirty" substance. This is related to the possibility that the urine comes from an infected kidney or urinary tract, so that the urine will also contain bacteria. However, if the urine comes from healthy kidneys and urinary tract, medically speaking, urine is actually quite sterile and most of the odor produced comes from urea.

Editor's page that has logged out learn more Illustration is the result of visualization of an inscription using drawing, painting, photography or other art techniques that emphasize the subject's relationship with the intended writing rather than form. The purpose of illustration is to explain or decorate a story, writing, poem, or other written information. It is hoped that with visual aids, the writing will be easier to digest. The special functions of illustration include: The concept of illustration can be traced back to the past through prehistoric wall paintings and the concept of hieroglyphic writing. The golden age of illustration in the United States dates back to 1880, after World War I. This occurred as the popularity of illustrated newspapers, magazines, and books allowed for experimentation of techniques by artists. It was during this time that many illustrators became rich and famous. The theme that emerged was the aspirations of the American people at that time. In Europe, artists during the Golden Age were influenced by the Pre-Raphaelite and design-oriented movements such as the Arts and Crafts Movement, Art Nouveau, and Les Nabis. Examples include Walter Crane, Edmund Dulac, Aubrey Beardsley, Arthur Rackham and Kay Nielsen. At present, illustration is growing with the use of many auxiliary software such as Adobe Illustrator, Photoshop, CorelDraw, and CAD. But traditional illustrations made by hand still hold a high value. In Indonesia, the history of the illustration tradition can refer to cave paintings found in Maros Regency, South Sulawesi province and on the island of Papua. The imprint, which is nearly 5,000 years old, depicts a pile of red terracotta fingers. In addition to cave paintings, wayang beber in traditional Javanese and Balinese entertainment is seen as an illustration that represents the storyline of the Mahabarata story, a tradition that emerged roughly at the same time as the founding of the Hindu kingdom of Sriwijaya on the southern island of Sumatra.

Editor's page logged out learn more Socrates (Greek: Σωκράτης, Sǒkratēs) (c. 470 BC–399 BC) was a philosopher from Greece. He is one of the thinkers of anthropocentrism who lived during the Classical Greek period. Socrates' philosophical thought aims to know humans by understanding the universe through theory. The main concern in Socrates' philosophical thought is the nature of human life. He changed the concern of philosophy from natural philosophy to human philosophy. The approach he uses is rationalism. He examines all fields of thought as long as his studies can use reason. Socrates begins every philosophical thought with curiosity. He then made this curiosity the beginning of wisdom. In his time, he became one of the Greek figures who no longer believed in myths. Socrates lived during the development of sophistic thought. His ability to use the dialogue method earned him the sympathy of the youth. Meanwhile, Socrates was despised by followers of the belief in God and God because he was considered corrupting the morals of the youth and rejecting the existence of a god or God that was recognized by his country. Socrates was one of the figures who introduced the term "philosophy" in educational institutions. Socrates used a philosophical method known as the midwifery method which became the de facto beginning of the development of the inductive method. Socrates' thoughts influenced his students namely Plato and then to Aristotle who was a student of Plato. The influence of Socrates' thoughts spread from his country, namely Athens, to the Western world. His main thoughts are about moral philosophy or ethics. Socrates was born to a father named Sophroniskos, while his mother was named Phairnarete in 470 BC. His father worked as a sculptor, while his mother was a midwife. Socrates married Xantipe.

Socrates' family was a wealthy family so that Socrates received adequate education. Socrates served as an Athenian soldier, but was only interested in philosophy and had no interest in politics. This then makes him live in poverty. Socrates' critical thinking made him arrested, imprisoned and sentenced to death. The imposition of the death penalty was the result of the accusations of the Sophists. Socrates was then executed in 399 BC by drinking poison. The charge laid against him was that he had perverted the minds of the Athenian youths. He died at the age of 70 years. Socrates provides philosophy teaching through the provision of knowledge of something that has been understood by someone. The teaching of Socratic philosophy is referred to as the midwifery method. He likens the process of philosophizing to that of a midwife helping a woman to give birth to her child. In philosophizing, he engages in dialogue. His main concern in philosophy is with what belongs to the human person. Socrates shifted the focus of philosophy from natural philosophy to human philosophy. He uses a critical method in philosophizing, especially regarding ethics. Socrates believes that a lot of knowledge and opinions from humans are pseudo, but humans use them in solving life's problems. He considers that human knowledge about life's problems is unclear and only conjectures. Socrates then examines two knowledges that are a matter of life, namely about happiness and virtue. Socrates begins the study of philosophy with a dialogue that requires agreement on the formulation of the topics being discussed. Submission of descriptions or real examples is carried out in each formulation. After the formulation was set, Socrates held a process of rebuttal which included comparison activities or asking questions. The answers given are in the form of statements that are contradictory or different from the formulations and real examples.

This conflict is then resolved by an induction process that outlines the statement and provides a definition of each term in the statement. In certain cases, analogies are used. Then, from the results of this induction, a general understanding is obtained that includes all useful knowledge and eliminates unnecessary knowledge. Philosophical thinking from Socrates has influenced the practice and theory of education in the Western world, especially in the field of teaching. Socrates developed teaching with the dialectical method. The function of teaching is to train individual accuracy in thinking and testing himself, as well as improving the knowledge he already knows. The Socratic method is used in education to develop students' knowledge independently and not fully influenced by the thoughts of the educator. In the 4th century BC, Socrates was one of the Greek philosophers who demanded that law enforcers prioritize justice over human judgment as law. Socrates views that law is part of a policy order that can achieve general justice objectively. The essence of the law established by Socrates is one of the thoughts that is no longer based on the will of the Gods. Laws have been established based on human power with guidelines for a just life in general. Socrates' opinion is similar to the view of sophism which believes that justice and morals are the essence of law which then becomes a way of life. Socrates' view of law then influenced Plato in thinking about law. Plato also considered law as a means to achieve justice. Socrates is one of the thinkers who considers society to be formed naturally. A society is formed by humans with characteristics that can experience progress or decline. The development of a society occurs without being able to be prevented at all. During his lifetime, Socrates had a student named Plato who became a pioneer of idealistic thinking.

Editor page that has logged out learn more on ASEAN (dark gray)  – Legend] Indonesia (Indonesian pronunciation: in.ˈdo.nɛ.sja]), known as the official name of the Republic of Indonesia or more fully the Unitary State of the Republic of Indonesia, Indonesia is an island nation in Southeast Asia that is crossed by the equator and is located between the continents of Asia and Oceania, so that it is known as a transcontinental country, as well as between the Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean. Indonesia is the 14th largest country as well as the largest archipelagic country in the world with an area of ​​1,904,569 km², and the 6th largest island country in the world, with a total of 17,504 islands. The alternative name used for the Indonesian archipelago is called Nusantara. In addition, Indonesia is also the 4th most populous country in the world with a population reaching 270,203,917 people in 2020, as well as the largest Muslim country in the world, with more than 230 million adherents. Indonesia is a multiracial, multiethnic and multicultural country in the world, just like the United States of America. Indonesia borders a number of countries in Southeast Asia and Oceania. Indonesia borders on land with Malaysia on the islands of Borneo and Sebatik, with Papua New Guinea on New Guinea Island, and with Timor Leste on Timor. Countries that only share sea borders with Indonesia are Singapore, the Philippines, Australia, and the union territory of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands in India. Indonesia is a unitary state with a republican form of government based on a valid constitution, namely the 1945 Constitution of the Republic of Indonesia (1945 Constitution). Also based on the 1945 Constitution, the People's Representative Council (DPR), Regional Representative Council (DPD), and the President are nominated and then elected in general elections. The current capital city of Indonesia is Jakarta. On January 18, 2022, the Indonesian government designated the Archipelago Capital on the island of Kalimantan, which occupies the area of ​​North Penajam Paser Regency, to replace Jakarta as the new capital.

Until 2022, the process of moving the capital city is still ongoing. The history of Indonesia has been heavily influenced by immigrants and colonizers. The Indonesian Archipelago became an important trading area since the 7th century, namely since the founding of Srivijaya, a Hindu-Buddhist patterned kingdom based in Palembang. The Srivijaya Empire established religious and trade relations with the Chinese, Indians and also Arabs. Hinduism-Buddhism religion and culture grew, developed, and assimilated in the Indonesian archipelago in the early 4th to 13th centuries AD. After that, traders and scholars from the Arabian Peninsula brought Islamic religion and culture around the 8th to 16th centuries. At the end of the 15th century, Europeans came to the Indonesian archipelago and fought for a monopoly on the spice trade in Maluku during the Age of Exploration. After being under the Dutch colonial era, Indonesia, which was then called the Dutch East Indies, proclaimed independence at the end of World War II, on August 17, 1945 to be precise. Furthermore, Indonesia faced various challenges and serious problems, ranging from natural disasters, massive corruption practices , social conflicts, separatist movements, democratization processes, and periods of development, socio-economic-political changes and developments, as well as rapid modernization. Indonesia consists of various ethnic groups, languages ​​and religions. Based on the national family, Indonesia consists of indigenous peoples, namely Austronesians and Melanesians, where the Austronesians are the largest in number and mostly inhabit the western part of Indonesia. The Javanese and Sundanese make up the largest ethnic group with a percentage reaching 57% of the entire population of Indonesia. Indonesia's national motto, "Unity in Diversity" (Different but still one), means the socio-cultural diversity that forms a unified country. Besides having a dense population and a large area, Indonesia has nature that supports the 2nd largest level of biodiversity in the world.

Indonesia is a member of the United Nations (UN) and the only member that has ever left the UN, namely on January 7, 1965, and rejoined on September 28, 1966. Indonesia is still declared as the 60th member, a membership that together since Indonesia joined on September 28, 1950. Apart from the United Nations, Indonesia is also a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM), the Asia-Africa Conference (KAA), Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) , Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC), and G20. The word "Indonesia" comes from the ancient Greek word Indus which refers to the Indus river in India and nesos which means "island". So, the word Indonesia means the "Indian archipelago", or the islands that are in the Indian territory; this refers to the similarities between the two nations (India and Indonesia). In 1850, George Windsor Earl, a British ethnologist, initially proposed the terms Indunesia and Malayunesia for the inhabitants of the "Indian Islands or Malay Archipelago". Earl's student, James Richardson Logan, uses the word Indonesia as a synonym for the Indian Archipelago. However, Dutch academic writing in the Dutch East Indies media did not use the word Indonesia, but the term Malay Archipelago (Maleische Archipel); Dutch East Indies (Nederlandsch Oost Indië), or Indies (Indië); East (de Oost); and even Insulinde (this term was introduced in 1860 in the novel Max Havelaar (1859) written by Multatuli about criticism of Dutch colonialism). From 1900, the name Indonesia became more common in academic circles outside the Netherlands, and Indonesian nationalists used it for political expression. Adolf Bastian of the University of Berlin popularized this name through the book Indonesien oder die Inseln des Malayischen Archipels, 1884–1894. The first Indonesian student to use it was Suwardi Suryaningrat (Ki Hajar Dewantara), when he founded a news agency in the Netherlands called the Indonesisch Pers Bureau in 1913.

Broadly speaking, Indonesian history consists of the prehistoric period, the monarchy period, the colonial period, and the republican period. Fossils of ancient humans such as Homo erectus, which anthropologists also nicknamed "Java Man", raise suspicions that the Indonesian archipelago was inhabited between two million and 500,000 years ago. But the truth about this is much debated. From 110,000 to 12,000 years ago, the western mainland of the archipelago (roughly the western islands including present-day Sumatra, Java, and Borneo) was still fused with mainland Asia, forming Sundaland. During that period, around 74,000 thousand years ago, there was an eruption of Mount Toba which is said to be one of the biggest volcanic eruptions in history which caused climate change which is said to have almost destroyed the modern human population at that time. Humanity itself has not actually reached Sumatra yet, waves of migration from Africa have also been temporarily halted due to this eruption. Mount Toba then sank and its caldera formed a large lake with the same name. Around 60,000 years ago, the first wave of human migration which became the ancestors of the Melanesian race arrived in the plains of the archipelago. The end of the ice age at the beginning of the Holocene era (12,000 BC) caused sea level rise and the separation of the Sundaland mainland from mainland Asia, then split to form the archipelago as it is today. These incidents became the trigger for the emergence of a human diaspora. The arrival of the Austronesians from mainland Taiwan who began to arrive in the archipelago around 3500 to 2000 BC caused the Melanesians who had existed earlier there to be pushed into areas far east of the islands, although some of them assimilated/acculturated with these migrants. With the conditions of fertile volcanic soil, abundance of biodiversity, coupled with the ability to cultivate crops that humans had at that time, agricultural activities and settlements began to form and develop rapidly.

Entering the early centuries of AD, small kingdoms began to form and develop in the archipelago. Kandis is thought to be the oldest kingdom in the archipelago, which was founded in the 1st century BC and is located in an area that is currently the province of Riau and its surroundings. However, the existence of Kandis left no evidence of artifacts and the evidence is very difficult for archaeologists to confirm, so that the existence of this kingdom is still often debated by historians. On the island of Java itself, the title of the oldest kingdom on the island of Java is thought to be held by Salakanagara which was founded in the 1st century AD in the area around Cianjur, West Java. This kingdom itself is thought to be the forerunner of Tarumanagara which was founded in 358 AD. The existence of Salakanagara is also still being debated among experts due to the lack of historical evidence. Based on existing historical evidence, the two oldest kingdoms that have been recognized by experts are Kutai Martapura and Tarumanagara in the 4th century AD. Kutai Martapura stands in an area that is currently included in the Province of South Kalimantan. Meanwhile, Tarumanagara stands in the western region of Java Island. From the evidence showing that the two kingdoms had a Hindu-Buddhist pattern, it can be ascertained that Hinduism and Buddhism have developed in the archipelago since at least the 4th century. Several Hindu-Buddhist patterned kingdoms were also formed after that. In Kalimantan, there were once many small Hindu-Buddhist kingdoms, namely Tanjungpura, Kuripan, Nan Sarunai, Selimbau, Negara Dipa, and Negara Daha. Then in Java, several Hindu-Buddhist kingdoms that were formed were Kalingga, Sunda Galuh (Pajajaran), and Kanjuruhan. In Sumatra itself, the other kingdoms that formed were Malay, Tulang Bawang, Keritang, and Jambu Lipo. In the 7th century AD, Srivijaya in the form of a sovereign and Buddhist style was established in the archipelago, which later developed into one of the largest empires (empire) in the archipelago that had ever existed, and made it the longest-standing monarchy in Southeast Asia.

Sriwijaya in its heyday covered most of Sumatra Island, the Malacca Peninsula and the Kra Peninsula, parts of Java, western Kalimantan, to Cambodia and southern Vietnam. Sriwijaya at that time controlled shipping and trade activities in the Malacca Strait which was the main maritime trade route between India and China and was one of the most important shipping lanes in the world. From this trade, many foreign cultures influenced and even assimilated with local cultures. The name Sriwijaya began to fade and is thought to have collapsed in the early 11th century. Dharmasraya then rose to replace Sriwijaya, before being replaced again by Pagaruyung in the 14th century. In the 8th century, Medang, led by the Sailendra dynasty, most of whom were Mahayana Buddhists, existed in the Central Java region and received wide influence. In the 9th century, the dynasty split and some fled to Sumatra, then controlled Sriwijaya, until the fall of the empire in the 11th century. Some experts consider that several Medang kings who are Hindu Shiva as a separate dynasty named Wangsa Sanjaya, while other experts consider that this dynasty never actually existed and is still part of the Sailendra dynasty. Some experts also separated the Medang kings after the government center moved to East Java as a separate dynasty named Wangsa Isyana. After the reign of Airlangga from Medang ended in 1042, Medang was divided into Panjalu (Kadiri) and Janggala. Janggala was conquered by Panjalu in 1135. Ken Arok of the Rajasa dynasty then conquered Panjalu and founded the Singasari (Tumapel) Kingdom in 1222, which ended the rule of the Isyana/Sailendra dynasty in Java. This kingdom fell in 1292 by a rebellion led by Jayakatwang, a remnant of the Isyana dynasty.

However, the rebellion was put down a year later by Raden Wijaya, Kertanegara's son-in-law who was the last king of Singasari. Raden Wijaya founded the Shiva-Buddhist Majapahit. This kingdom in its development became the largest empire or empire in the archipelago, with a very broad territory during its heyday, covering Sumatra, the Malacca Peninsula, the coastal areas and lowlands of Kalimantan, southern and eastern Sulawesi, Nusa Tenggara, Maluku, to the tip of the West Papua. Majapahit especially reached its heyday during the reign of Hayam Wuruk, with Patih Amangkubhumi Gajah Mada, who was very famous for his Palapa Oath which contained a pledge to unite the entire archipelago. Majapahit at that time was known as an agricultural country and also as a trading country that regulated world shipping activities. Majapahit experienced a setback since the influence of Islam grew in the archipelago, and finally collapsed after being conquered by Demak in 1527. Until before the arrival of colonialism in the archipelago, the surviving Hindu-Buddhist patterned kingdoms were Blambangan in the far eastern part of Java Island, as well as the -the former Balinese kingdoms of Gelgel, namely Klungkung, Buleleng, Karangasem, Badung, Tabanan, Gianyar, Bangli, Mengwi (in development joining Badung), and Jembrana. Islam has actually entered the archipelago starting in the 7th century AD. Islam was brought by traders and scholars of Arab, Persian and Indian (Gujarat) nationality. Chinese Muslim traders and sailors, especially the sailor group under the leadership of Cheng Ho, also participated in spreading Islam in the archipelago. Aceh was the first area to become the center of the spread of Islam in the archipelago. The first Islamic sultanate that is known to have existed in the archipelago, especially in Aceh, was Jeumpa which was founded in the 7th century, whose territory roughly covered the present-day Bieruen Regency.

After that, several sultanates were also established in the Aceh region in the early days of the spread of Islam in the archipelago, among which were Peureulak, Lamuri and Linge. In the early 2nd millennium, Islam began to spread to many areas on the island of Sumatra, especially after the collapse of Sriwijaya in the 11th century. Several Hindu-Buddhist kingdoms in Sumatra even later turned into Islamic sultanates. The sultanates that have emerged and existed in Sumatra after that are as follows. Islam did not spread significantly to other parts of the archipelago until the 15th century, when it was introduced and spread widely. Since that time, Islam began to influence the entire archipelago in later times. After Majapahit fell, Islamic-style sultanates stood and developed rapidly in the archipelago, especially in Java. The first sultanates on the island of Java that have been widely recognized were Demak and Cirebon which were founded in the 15th century. However, recently, some experts have found some evidence of an older Islamic sultanate, namely Lumajang, which is estimated to have existed at the end of the 13th century. After that, there were several sultanates that also existed in Java, namely Giri, Banten, Kalinyamat, Pajang, Sumedang Larang, Mataram, Ngayogyakarta Hadiningrat, and Surakarta Hadiningrat. In Kalimantan itself, several Hindu-Buddhist kingdoms turned into Islamic sultanates, for example Selimbau, Porcupine Tanjungpura. Then several new sultanates were also established along with the increasing influence of Islam on the island of Borneo since the 14th century. Brunei, which separated from Malacca in the 14th century, then reached its heyday in the 15th century by successfully controlling the entire coast of Borneo Island. In the 16th century, Banjar was established, developed, and then controlled most of the southern coast of Kalimantan, and had good relations with Demak.

Banjar's glory began to decline in the 18th century and its existence was abolished by the Dutch East Indies colonial government in 1905. In addition, several sultanates that also existed on the island of Borneo are as follows. Islam is thought to have started to develop on the island of Sulawesi in the 16th century. At that time, several Hindu-Buddhist or Animist kingdoms turned into Islamic sultanates and several Islamic sultanates were newly established and developed. The famous big sultanate in Sulawesi is Makassar, which is a combination of Gowa and Tallo). This kingdom in its heyday covered southern and central Sulawesi, as well as the islands of Lombok and Sumbawa, which are currently the territory of West Nusa Tenggara. In addition, several other sultanates in Sulawesi are as follows. In the Maluku Islands, there were two well-known major sultanates, namely Ternate and Tidore which were centered in the area that is currently included in the North Maluku region. The territory of Ternate in its heyday, namely in the 16th century, covered Ternate Island, a small part of Halmahera Island, the central part of the Maluku Islands, the northern and eastern parts of Sulawesi Island, to East Nusa Tenggara. Meanwhile, Tidore during its heyday which also in the 16th century covered Tidore Island, most of Halmahera Island, to West Papua. Several sultanates that have also existed in the Maluku Islands, namely Jailolo, Bacan, Tanah Hitu, Iha, and Huamual. The sultanates that once stood in the Nusa Tenggara Islands, namely Bima, Sumbawa, Adonara, Dompu, Selaparang, Sanggar, and Lamakera. While the sultanates that once stood in Papua were Sekar, Patipi, Fatagar and Kaimana. The glory of the Islamic sultanates began to fade after foreign nations entered and implemented colonialism in the archipelago. Some of them were disbanded by the colonial government after suffering the defeat of the war, and some of them became self-governing areas (zelfbestuur) under the rule of the colonial government.

Indonesia is also a country that was colonized by many European and Asian countries, because since ancient times Indonesia was a country rich in abundant natural products, so that European countries were tempted to colonize and intended to control natural resources for income for their country. -countries that once colonized Indonesia include: When Europeans arrived in the early 16th century, they found several kingdoms that they could easily control in order to dominate the spice trade. The Portuguese first landed in the two ports of the Sunda Kingdom, namely Banten and Sunda Kelapa, but were driven out and moved eastward and controlled Maluku. In the 17th century, the Netherlands emerged as the most powerful of the other European nations, overpowering the United Kingdom and Portugal (except for their colony, Portuguese Timor). The Dutch controlled Indonesia as a colony until World War II, initially through the Vereenigde Oostindische Compagnie (VOC), and then directly by the Dutch government, under the name Dutch East Indies, from the early 19th century. Under the rule of the Cultuurstelsel (Forced Cultivation System) in the 19th century, large plantations and forced cultivation were implemented in Java, eventually bringing profits to the Netherlands that the VOC could not. During the freer colonial rule after 1870, this system was abolished. After 1901 the Dutch introduced the Ethical Policy, which included limited political reforms and greater investment in the Dutch East Indies. During World War II, when the Netherlands was being occupied by Nazi Germany, the Empire of Japan succeeded in controlling Indonesia. After acquiring Indonesia in 1942, the Japanese saw that the Indonesian fighters were cooperative trading partners and were willing to deploy troops when needed. Soekarno, Mohammad Hatta, KH.

Mas Mansur, and Ki Hajar Dewantara were awarded by the Emperor of Japan in 1943. citation needed] In March 1945 the Japanese formed a committee for Indonesian independence. After the Pacific War ended in 1945, under pressure from youth organizations, Soekarno-Hatta proclaimed Indonesian independence on August 17, 1945. After independence, the three founders of the nation namely Soekarno, Mohammad Hatta and Sutan Sjahrir each served as president, vice president , and the prime minister. In an effort to regain control of Indonesia, the Dutch sent their troops. These bloody attempts to suppress the movement for independence were later known by the Dutch as 'police action' (politionele actie), otherwise known by the Indonesians as Military Aggression. The Netherlands finally accepted Indonesia's right to independence on December 27, 1949 as a federal state called the United States of Indonesia after coming under strong pressure from the international community, especially the United States. The Natsir Integral Motion on August 17, 1950, called for the return of the unitary state of the Republic of Indonesia and the dissolution of the United Republic of Indonesia. Soekarno again became president with Mohammad Hatta as vice president and Mohammad Natsir as prime minister. In the 1950s and 1960s, Soekarno's government began to follow and pioneered the non-aligned movement at first, then became closer to socialist blocs, such as the People's Republic of China and Yugoslavia. The 1960s saw a military confrontation against neighboring Malaysia ("Confrontation"), and discontent over growing economic difficulties. Then in 1965 the G30S incident erupted which caused the death of 6 generals and a number of other middle-ranking officers. A new force emerged which called itself the New Order which immediately accused the Indonesian Communist Party of being the mastermind behind this incident and intending to overthrow the legitimate government and change the national ideology to one based on socialist-communist ideology.

This accusation was also used as an excuse to replace the old government under President Soekarno. General Suharto became Acting President in 1967 with the reason to protect the country from the threat of communism. Meanwhile Soekarno's own physical condition was getting weaker. After Suharto came to power, hundreds of thousands of Indonesians suspected of being involved in the communists were killed, while many more Indonesians were abroad, did not dare to return to their homeland, and eventually had their citizenship revoked. The thirty-two years of Soeharto's rule was called the New Order, while the reign of Soekarno was called the Old Order. Suharto implemented a neoliberal economy and succeeded in bringing in large foreign investment into Indonesia and producing large, albeit uneven, economic growth. At the beginning of the New Order regime, Indonesia's economic policies were formulated by a group of economists who graduated from the Department of Economics at the University of California, Berkeley, who were called the "Berkeley Mafia". However, Suharto added to his wealth and that of his family through widespread practices of corruption, collusion and nepotism and he was eventually forced out of office after massive demonstrations and the country's deteriorating economic conditions in 1998. The Transitional Period of the Reform Order or Reform Era lasted from 1998 to 2001, when there were three presidential terms: Bacharuddin Jusuf (BJ) Habibie, Abdurrahman Wahid and Megawati Sukarnoputri. In 2004, the world's largest one-day general election was won by Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, as president elected directly by the people, who served for two terms. In 2014, Joko Widodo, who is more familiarly called Jokowi, was elected as the 7th president. Indonesia is currently experiencing economic, political and religious disputes within the country, and several regions are trying to break away from the auspices of the Republic of Indonesia, especially Papua. citation needed] East Timor officially separated in 1999 after 24 years of being united with Indonesia and 3 years under UN administration to become the state of Timor Leste.

In December 2004 and March 2005, Aceh and Nias were hit by two major earthquakes which in total killed hundreds of thousands of people. (See the 2004 Indian Ocean Earthquake and the March 2005 Sumatra Earthquake.) This incident was followed by the Yogyakarta earthquake and tsunami that hit Pangandaran Beach and its surroundings, as well as the mud flood in Sidoarjo in 2006 which remained unresolved. Indonesia is the largest archipelagic country in the world located in Southeast Asia, and is located between the continents of Asia and the continents of Australia/Oceania, as well as between the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. This country has 17,504 islands scattered around the equator; as many as 16,056 islands have standardized names, and around 6,000 islands are uninhabited. The major islands in Indonesia are Sumatra, Java, Kalimantan (shared with Malaysia and Brunei Darussalam), Sulawesi and Papua (shared with Papua New Guinea). Indonesia is located at coordinates between 6° 04' 30" North Latitude and 11° 00' 36" South Latitude and between 94° 58' 21" and 141° 01' 10" East Longitude, which stretches 5,120 kilometers (3,181 miles) from east to west and 1,760 kilometers (1,094 mi) from north to south. Indonesia's land area is 1,916,906.77 km², while its water area is around 3,110,000 km² with a coastline of 108 thousand km. In general, Indonesia has a tropical climate (group A in the Köppen climate classification; although there are regions with different climate types). The warm waters in the Indonesian region play an important role in keeping the temperature on land constant, with an average temperature in coastal areas of 28 °C, in inland and highland areas of 26 °C, and in mountainous areas of 23 °C. Humidity ranges from 70 to 90%. The main factor affecting Indonesia's climate is not air temperature or air pressure, but rainfall. Seasonal variations in Indonesia, namely the rainy season and the dry season, are related to the movement of the monsoon winds. The west monsoon winds blowing from Asia to Australia through Indonesia from October to February result in heavy rainfall, especially in western Indonesia. Meanwhile, the east monsoon which moves in the opposite direction from April to August does not bring much moisture and causes rain. In addition, there is also a transitional season when the sun crosses the equator which causes the wind to blow weakly and move erratically. However, not all regions of Indonesia have the same rainfall pattern. Apart from the monsoon areas, there are also equatorial regions which are influenced by intertropical wind meeting areas, as well as local areas whose pattern is the opposite of the monsoon pattern. Several studies project that Indonesia will be affected by climate change. Adverse impacts include an average temperature increase of about 1°C in the middle of this century due to unreduced emissions, an increase in the frequency of droughts and food shortages (due to changes in rainfall and seasonal patterns affecting agriculture), as well as various diseases and forest fires. . Rising sea levels also threaten most of Indonesia's population living in coastal areas.

The poor are perhaps the group most affected by climate change. Of about 400 volcanoes, approximately 130 of them are still active. The Indonesian region has a high diversity of living things, so it is classified as one of 17 megadiversity countries by Conservation International. From the point of view of the biogeographic region, Indonesia is included in the Malesia region. Its flora and fauna are a mixture of typical Asian and Australasian species. Alfred Russel Wallace, a natural history expert, hypothesized a dividing line (later called Wallace's line) to distinguish organisms from Asia (Sunda Shelf) and Australia (Sahul Shelf). The biogeographical area which is the transition zone between these two shelves is called Wallacea. In addition, the Weber line and the Lydekker line are also used to determine Indonesia's biogeographical boundaries. Indonesia has about 10% of all flowering plant species on Earth (25,000 species, 55% of which are endemic to Indonesia).

The Indonesian Constitution is the 1945 Constitution of the Republic of Indonesia (1945 Constitution) which during the reform era underwent four amendments, bringing major changes to the legislative, executive and judicial powers. One of the main changes was the delegation of power and authority to various regional entities while remaining a unitary state. Executive power is held by the president who is assisted by the vice president and the cabinet. The President of Indonesia is the head of state and head of government, as well as the supreme commander of the Indonesian National Armed Forces. This institution is bicameral in form consisting of 575 members of the People's Representative Council (DPR) from political parties, plus 136 members of the Regional Representatives Council (DPD) who are provincial representatives from independent paths. Members of the DPR and DPD are elected through general elections for a five-year term. The functions carried out by the DPR are legislation (formulating laws), budget (discussing and approving the State Revenue and Expenditure Budget), and supervision (supervising government performance), while the DPD is a legislative body that is more specialized in regional management. He was born during the Slavery period in Hierapolis, Phrygia (now called Pamukkale, Turkey), lived in Rome until his exile as a slave. Epictetus's thought, through the Stoic school, became a reference for many experts in the field of ethics, especially regarding moral ethics, that humans are able to limit themselves from the temptations of worldly desires, especially the lust to have everything. According to him, humans should examine their respective behavior in terms of their relationship with other parties so that it does not harm other people, but improves the welfare of others, because every other person is actually the extended human family itself, as residents of the earth as their home. Epictetus's real name is unknown, the name was a gift from Nero's ruler and adviser to the emperor in Rome, named Epaphroditus. When he was still a slave, he studied under the philosophers of Stoicism, Musonius, Rufus. For him, being present and learning from Musonius is a gift, it seems he was inspired by Musonius' words, "A happy soul is one that always climbs towards natural objects, flows as it is, which we usually want to reject more and more." In 89 AD, when he gained freedom from slave status, he became a teacher of philosophy in Greece. Then he went to Nicopolis to Southwestern Greece to set up a school. His works were published by his follower Arrian under the title Insights of Epictetus for up to four books. There, Epictetus deepened his struggle with Stoic philosophy, living in limitations, having only -as his motto-, "it is enough for me to live with earth, sky, and a robe." Officially, Epictetus did not write his own works, his work was recorded and published by his follower named Flavius ​​Arrian.

The four books contain summaries of his teachings, based on semi-formal dialogues on practical ethics that supplement the more formal instruction in the Stoic curriculum. His direct style (colloquial Greek; sharp and matter-of-fact) suggests that Arrian has caught the voice of Epictetus himself. Epictetus's thought is based on a person's ethical role in relation to his social world, which is contained in three stages of a practical ethical program, Oikeiosis can be understood as the nature or urge of all living things to defend themselves. According to the theory of oikeiosis, the most basic drive in all living things is to defend themselves. The survival process is related to its relation to every event, every party, and the world. Every human action must weigh the pros and cons of the event, the benefits of the parties here and there, and whether the benefits are for the world. But Epictetus invites humans, in weighing the good and bad, the most important thing is the good of all parties, as widely as possible for the good of the universe which is regulated by the Divine which appears in the natural order. Regarding human life which cannot be separated from relations with the political world of the state and society, Epictetus -as Musonius advises-, claims that a good life is one that is based on familial attitudes (familiriazation) or accuracy (oikeiosis). Oikeiosis contains two interrelated aspects, personal and social. A central feature of personal oikeiosis is the movement from the desire for "favoured" natural things such as health and wealth, to the view that such things are matter neutral (do not affect happiness) as compared to good, the only true good. and the only thing that truly benefits the self. The main feature of social oikeiosis is recognizing the fundamental associative character of human nature and the desire to help others as well as help oneself.
