Editor page logged out learn more Yellowfin tuna or yellowfin tuna (Thunnus albacares) is a large pelagic fish that wanders in tropical and temperate seas around the world. This fish is one of the largest types of tuna, although it is still less big when compared to bluefin tuna and bigeye tuna. Yellowfin tuna is also an important ocean-caught fish due to its high economic value. In world trade, this fish is known as yellowfin tuna (Ingg.) and also albacore (Pr. and Sp.). Adult yellowfin yellowfin has a large body, with a length from the tip of the snout to the tip of the tail fin branch (FL, fork length) reaching 195 cm; but generally up to 150 cm. The shape is long gilig like a torpedo (fusiform), slightly flattened from side to side. The dorsal fin consists of two bundles, separated by a small gap; the second tuft is immediately followed by 8–10 additional small finlets (finlets). The anal fin is followed by 7–10 finlets. In large specimens, the second dorsal and anal fins are sometimes elongated to 20% FL. The pectoral fins are moderately long (22–31% FL), usually reaching the anterior base of the second dorsal fin, but not past the rear. There are two folds of skin (interpelvic prominences) between the pelvic fins. The caudal peduncle is very slender, with a strong lateral keel on each side, each of which is flanked by two smaller keels. Strongly forked tail fin (forked, forked). The back is a dark metallic blue, gradually turning yellowish or silvery on the belly. The second dorsal and anal fins, and the finlets that follow them, are bright yellow, from which they get their name.

The abdomen is sometimes decorated with about 20 dotted lines that are nearly vertical. Yellowfin tuna can weigh over 300 pounds (136 kg), however this is far below the Pacific bluefin tuna (Thunnus orientalis) which can weigh over 1000 pounds (454 kg), and also slightly below the bigeye tuna (Thunnus obesus) and southern bluefin tuna (Thunnus maccoyii). The size of yellowfin recorded in the literature is up to 239 cm in length and 200 kg in weight. Yellowfin yellowfin is an epipelagic fish that inhabits the upper layer of ocean waters above the thermocline layer. Research shows that although yellowfin mostly wade through the upper 100 m of the water column, and relatively rarely penetrate the thermocline layer, this fish is able to dive deep into the ocean depths. A yellowfin studied in the Indian Ocean spent 85% of its time at a depth of less than 75 m, but three dives were recorded to a depth of 578 m, 982 m and the most extreme one was up to 1,160 m. This yellowfin tuna has a habit of swimming fast and in schools with fish of the same size, sometimes mixed with other types of tuna. Its breeding season lasts during the summer. These fish prey on various types of fish, crustaceans, and also cephalopods. In the Halmahera and Sulawesi seas, yellowfin primarily prey on fish (malalugis and anchovies), shrimp and crabs; with malaguis fish (flying fish) occupying the largest portion. Yellowfin yellowfin are found throughout the world's tropical and temperate waters between latitudes 40° north latitude and 40° south latitude. This fish is an important fishing commodity; The FAO Yearbook of Fishery Statistics reports that between 1990 and 1995 yellowfin catches in the west-central Pacific ranged from 323,537 to 346,942 tonnes per year.

In the 6th century AD, the Kushan successors and the White Huns founded a minor dynasty known as the Kabul Shahi. Before the 19th century, the northwestern region of Afghanistan was called Khurasan. Two of Khurasan's four capital cities (Herat and Balkh) are now in Afghanistan, while the regions of Kandahar, Zabulistan, Ghazni, Kaulistan and Afghanistan form the border between Khurasan and Hindustan. Arab Muslims brought Islam to Herat and Zaranj in 642 EL and started expanding eastward; the natives they encountered accepted him while others refused and rebelled. His lands were collectively known to the Arabs as al-Hind because of their cultural ties to Greater India. Before Islam was introduced, the people in the area had religions, including Zoroastrians, Buddhists, Surya and Nana, Jews, and others. Zunbil and Kabul Shahi were first captured in 870 EL by the Saffarids of the Zaranj Muslims. Later, the Samanids extended their Islamic influence to the southern Hindu Kush. It is reported that Muslims and non-Muslims were still living side by side in Kabul before the Ghaznavids rose to power in the 10th century. Afghanistan became one of the major centers of the Muslim World during the Islamic Age of Glory. In the 11th century, Mahmud of Ghazni defeated the remaining Hindu rulers and effectively Islamized much of the region, with the exception of Kafiristan.

The Ghaznavid dynasty was defeated and succeeded by the Ghurids, who flourished and the Islamic empire came to power. Some speculate that the current Nasher tribes are remnants of the Ghaznavid dynasty. In 1219 AD, Genghis Khan and his Mongol army conquered the region. His army is said to have destroyed the cities of Khurasan namely Herat, Balkh and Bamyan. The devastation caused by the Mongol forces forced local residents to return to rural farming communities. Mongol rule continued with the Ilkhanate in the north-west during the Khilji dynasty which ruled over the tribal areas of southern Afghanistan — the Hindu Kush until the conquest of Timur, which founded the Timurid dynasty in 1370. During the Ghaznavid, Ghurid and Timurid periods, this area gave birth to fine monuments of Islamic architecture as well as works of science and literature. In the early 16th century, Babur arrived from Fergana and captured Kabul from the Arghun dynasty. The local Pashtun Ghilzai tribe succeeded in overthrowing Safavid rule, and under the Hotaki dynasty, briefly controlled all or part of Persia itself from 1722-1736. After a brief period under the rule (1736-1747) of the Iranian-conqueror Turko Nadir Shah, one of his top military officers, Ahmad Shah Abdali, himself a Pashtun member of the Abdali clan, called for a loya jirga following Nadir Shah's assassination (which involved many Abdali) in 1747. Afghans/Pashtuns came together in Kandahar in 1747, and chose Ahmad Shah, who changed his last name to Durrani ('pearl' meaning 'pearl' in Persian), to become king. The nation-state Afghanistan as it is known today emerged in 1747 as the Durrani Empire, and expanded beyond the traditional Pashtun realm to include all of what is today Afghanistan, part of Mashad in Iran, and all of Pakistan, and Kashmir as well.

The Durrani Empire lasted for nearly a century until internal conflict, and wars with the Persians, and Sikhs reduced their empire by the early 19th century. However, the current borders of Afghanistan would not be defined until the arrival of the British. During the 19th century, following the Anglo-Afghan wars (fought in 1839-1842, 1878-1880, and most recently in 1919), Afghanistan saw much of its territory, and autonomy devolved to Britain. The British exercised a great deal of influence, and it wasn't until King Amanullah acceded to the throne in 1919 (see "The Great Game") that Afghanistan returned to full independence. During the period of British intervention in Afghanistan, the area's ethnic Pashtuns were divided by the Durand Line and this would lead to tense relations between Afghanistan, and India, and later the new state of Pakistan, over what came to be known as the contentious name Pashtunistan. The historical rulers of Afghanistan were part of the Abdali tribe of Afghan ethnicity, whose name was changed to Durrani on the accession of Ahmad Shah. They belong to the Saddozay segment of the Popalzay clan, or to the Mohammadzay segment of the Barakzay clan, of ethnic Afghanistan. The Mohammadzay often supplemented the Sadozay king with a superior counselor, who served as regent occasionally, and identified with the name Mohammadzay. Since 1900, eleven kings and rulers have been overthrown through undemocratic means: in 1919 (assassination), 1929 (abdication), 1929 (execution), 1933 (murder), 1973 (deposition), 1978 (execution), 1979 ( executions), 1979 (execution), 1987 (abolition), 1992 (overthrow), 1996 (overthrow) and 2001 (overthrow). The longest period of stability in Afghanistan was between 1933 and 1973, when the country was under King Zahir Shah. However, in 1973, Zahir's brother-in-law, Sardar Mohammed Daoud staged a bloodless coup. Daoud, and his entire family were assassinated in 1978 when the communist People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan staged a coup known as the Great Saur Revolution, and took over the government.

The opposition to Afghanistan, and the conflict within, the series of communist governments that followed, was overwhelming. As part of its Cold War strategy, the US government secretly began funding, and training anti-government Mujahideen forces through agents of the Pakistani secret service known as the Inter Intelligence Service or ISI, which originated from disaffected Muslims in this country who opposed the regime's official atheism. Marxists, in 1978. In order to strengthen the local Soviet Communist forces — citing the 1978 Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation, and Good Neighborhood Relations signed between the two countries in 1978 — joined forces on December 24, 1979. The Soviet occupation resulted in a major exodus - the magnitude of the more than 5 million Afghans who moved to refugee camps in Pakistan, and Iran. More than 3 million alone live in Pakistan. Faced with mounting international pressure, and the loss of some 15,000 Soviet troops as a result of Mujahideen opposition forces trained by the United States, Pakistan, and other foreign governments, the Soviets withdrew ten years later, in 1989. For further details, see Soviet war in Afghanistan. The Soviet withdrawal was seen as an ideological victory in the US, which had ostensibly supported the Mujahideen in order to counter Soviet influence around the oil-rich Persian Gulf. After the elimination of Soviet troops in 1989, the US and its allies lost interest in Afghanistan, and did little to help rebuild the war-torn country. The Soviet Union continued to support the regime of Dr Najubullah (former head of the secret service, Khad) until his downfall in 1992. However, the absence of Soviet troops resulted in the government's downfall as it continued to lose ground to the guerrilla forces. As a large part of the elite, and intellectuals were either systematically eliminated by the Communists, or fled to take refuge abroad, a dangerous lack of leadership ensued in Afghanistan.

Fighting continued between the various Mujahideen factions, eventually giving rise to a state of warlordism. The chaos and corruption that dominated post-Soviet Afghanistan in turn spawned a resurgence of the Taliban in response to the growing chaos. The most serious fighting during the growing civil conflict occurred in 1994, when 10,000 people died in factional fighting in Kabul. Taking advantage of the chaotic situation in Afghanistan, including several regional Afghan fundamentalist bedfellows trained in refugee camps in western Pakistan, the Pakistani secret intelligence service (ISI), the regional Mafia (established network of smuggled mainly Japanese electronics, and tires before the Russian invasion, are now involved in smugglers) and Arab extremist groups (those seeking secure operational centers) joined forces, and helped to create the Taliban movement (Rashid 2000). Backed by Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, and other strategic allies, the Taliban developed as a political-religious force, and finally seized power in 1996. The Taliban were able to capture 90% of the country, apart from the Northern Alliance stronghold of Afghanistan mainly found in the northeast in the Panjshir Valley . The Taliban seek to apply a strict interpretation of Islamic Sharia law, and provide safe haven, and assistance to individuals and organizations implicated as terrorists, especially Osama bin Laden's Al-Qa'idah network. The United States, and allied military action to support the opposition after the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks forced the downfall of the Taliban. In late 2001, the main leaders of the Afghan opposition groups, and the diaspora met in Bonn, and approved plans for the formulation of a new government structure which resulted in the appointment of Hamid Karzai as Chairman of the Afghan Interim Authority (AIA) in December 2001. After the Loya Jirga in 2002, Karzai was elected president. On March 3, and March 25, 2002, a series of earthquakes struck Afghanistan, with the loss of thousands of homes, and over 1800 lives.

More than 4000 other people were injured. Earthquakes occurred in Samangan Province (3 March) and Baghlan Province (25 March). The latter is the worse of the two, and causes the most casualties. International authorities are assisting the Afghan government in dealing with the situation. As the country continues to rebuild, and recover, as of late 2005, it is still battling widespread poverty, warlordism continues, infrastructure is virtually non-existent, perhaps the largest concentration on earth of exploding landmines, and other regulations, as well as sizeable trade and trade. illegal opium heroin. Afghanistan also remains subject to occasional violent political jockeys, and the nation's first successful elections were held in 2004 as women MPs were elected in record numbers. Parliamentary elections in 2005 helped to further stabilize the country politically, despite the many problems it faced, including inadequate international assistance. The country continues to grapple with occasional acts of violence from some remnants of Al-Qaeda, and the Taliban, and the instability caused by warlords. And Former King Mohammed Zahir Shah returned to the country, but did not return as king, and only limited ceremonial strength exercises. Under the Bonn Agreement an Afghan Constitutional Commission was established to consult with the public, and formulate a draft constitution. The loya jirga meeting of the constitution was held in December 2003, when a new constitution was adopted creating a presidential form of government with a bicameral legislature. Troops and intelligence services from the United States, and a number of other countries attended, some to maintain the peace, others tasked with hunting down remnants of the Taliban, and al Qaeda. A UN peacekeeping force called the International Security Assistance Force has been operating in Kabul since December 2001. NATO took control of this force on 11 August 2003.

Some countries remain under the control of warlords. On March 27, 2003, Afghanistan's deputy minister of defense, and powerful warlord General Abdul Rashid Dostum set up an office for the North Zone of Afghanistan, and appointed officials for it, defiing the then-interim president Hamid Karzai's order that there be no zone in Afghanistan. Eurocorps took over responsibility for NATO-led ISAF in Kabul 9 August 2004. National elections were held on 9 October 2004. More than 10 million Afghans registered to vote. Some of the 17 candidates who opposed Karzai boycotted the election, charging fraud; an independent commission found evidence of foul play, but ruled that it did not affect the poll results. Karzai won 55.4% of the vote. He was sworn in as president on December 7 — in the country's first national election since 1969, when the last parliamentary elections were held. On 18 September 2005, parliamentary elections were held; Parliament opened the following December 19. On December 20, President Karzai's close ally, and first mujahidin government, Sibghatullah Mojadeddi, was elected to head the top 102 seat house. On December 21, Yunus Qanuni, leader of the Afghan opposition, and Karzai's main opponent was elected to lead the lower 249-seat house of parliament by 122 votes to 117 for the nearest challenger. On August 15, 2021, the Taliban succeeded in taking control of Kabul and the establishment of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. Afghanistan is a mountainous country, although there are plains in the north and southwest. The highest point in Afghanistan is Noshaq with an altitude of 7485 m. Most of the country is dry, and fresh water supplies are limited. Afghanistan has a temperate climate, with hot summers and cold winters.

The country is often the epicenter of earthquakes. Besides its capital Kabul, Herat, Jalalabad, Mazar-e Sharif and Kandahar are the main cities of the country. See also Cities in Afghanistan. Generally, Afghanistan is considered a South Asian country, but there is no clear classification. This is because Afghanistan is located at the crossroads of Asia and is influenced by the various cultures of the countries that surround it. Afghanistan is generally classified as a South Asian country because it is one of the regions of "Greater India", that is, the area influenced by Indian culture and beliefs, such as Hinduism and Buddhism. Still, Afghanistan is where most of India's influence ends, right in the Hindu Kush mountains that stretch from northeast to southwest Afghanistan. Heading west from the Hindu Kush mountains, Afghanistan can be classified as a Middle Eastern country because it is also included in the "Greater Persian" region, that is, an area influenced by Iranian (or Persian) culture and customs, such as language (Afghan Persian is spoken by about 50% citizens) and religion (Islam is embraced by nearly 100% of the population, and the Shi'ite denomination that characterizes Iran makes up 20% of Afghanistan's Muslim population. Afghanistan is also reportedly the birthplace of Zoroastrianism, the official religion of the pre-Islamic Persian empires). This is also supported by Afghanistan's position as one of the most important urban centers of the Persian empires (along with Kurdistan) when this country's territory was known as Khorasan. Geographically, Afghanistan can be considered a Central Asian country along with other "five-stanch" countries to the north which, like Afghanistan, were also influenced by the communist government of the Soviet Union in the mid-20th century. Afghanistan's topography and climate also resembles those of Central Asia, dominated by high snowy mountains and a climate that is normal in summer and very cold in winter.

Following the effective collapse of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan during the 2021 Taliban offensive, the Taliban declares the country an Islamic Emirate. A new caretaker government was announced on September 7. As of September 8, 2021, no other country has officially recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan as the de jure government of Afghanistan. The traditional instrument of government in Afghanistan is the loya jirga (Grand Assembly), a Pashtun consultative meeting primarily held to elect a new head of state, adopt a new constitution, or to resolve national or regional issues such as war. Loya jirgas have been held since at least 1747, with the most recent occurring in August 2020. On August 17, 2021, the leader of the Taliban-affiliated Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin party, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, met with Hamid Karzai, former President of Afghanistan, and Abdullah Abdullah, chairman of the Superior Council for National Reconciliation and former President of Afghanistan. Chief Executive, in Doha, Qatar, with the aim of forming a government (although it is unclear whether Karzai or Abdullah would be directly involved in such a government). President Ashraf Ghani, having fled the country during Taliban advances into Tajikistan or Uzbekistan, appeared in the United Arab Emirates and said he supported the negotiations and was in talks to return to Afghanistan. As of August 2021 , the Islamic Emirate is undergoing a period of political transition with an unofficial Coordinating Council led by senior statesmen in the process of coordinating the transfer of state institutions of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan to the Taliban. The Taliban forces, meanwhile, exercise effective police authority in the country. The Kabul meeting on forming a government was an only men's meeting according to Fawzia Koofi, a former member of the Afghanistan National Assembly, who stated that an only men's government "would not be complete".

Many within the Taliban generally agree that the continuation of the Afghan Constitution may, potentially, be used as the basis for a new state because their objections to the previous government were religious, not political. On August 20, Abdul Ghani Baradar arrived in Kabul from Kandahar to begin formal negotiations with the Coordinating Council on the composition and structure of the new government. Hours after the last flight of American troops left Kabul on Aug. 30, a Taliban official interviewed said a new government would likely be announced as early as Friday, Sept. 3 after Jumu'ah. It added that Hibatullah Akhundzada would be officially named Emir, with cabinet ministers revealed in the Arg in an official ceremony. Abdul Ghani Baradar will be appointed head of government as Prime Minister, while other key positions will be held by Sirajuddin Haqqani and Mohammad Yaqoob. Under the supreme leader, day-to-day governance would be entrusted to the cabinet. According to CNN, the new government will likely be a unitary Deobandi Islamic Emirate. In a report by CNN-News18, sources said the new government will be ruled similar to Iran with Haibatullah Akhundzada as supreme leader similar to the role of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and will be based in Kandahar. Baradar or Yaqoob will be the head of government as Prime Minister. Government ministries and agencies will come under a cabinet led by the Prime Minister. The Supreme Leader will lead an executive body known as the Supreme Council with 11 to 72 members. Abdul Hakim Ishaqzai is likely to be promoted to Supreme Court Justice. According to the report, the new government will take place within the framework of the amended 1964 Afghanistan Constitution.

However, later interviews revealed to News18 that negotiations had not concluded and representatives were still in Kandahar, and that the announcement of a new government would not be made until September 4 or so. The formation of the government was further postponed with the announcement delayed for some time during the week of 6 September, due to concerns about forming a broad-based government that would be acceptable to the international community. But it later added that the Taliban's Rahbari Shura, the group's leadership council is divided between the hardline Haqqani Network and the moderate Abdul Ghani Baradar over the appointments needed to form an "inclusive" government. This culminated in a skirmish which left Baradar wounded and hospitalized in Pakistan. It is speculated that governments will be announced on September 11, 2021, the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, with invitations possibly extending to the governments of Turkey, China, Iran, Pakistan, and Qatar. In early September, the Taliban planned a cabinet for men only, stating that women would not be allowed to "work in high positions" in government and that women were "excluded" from the Cabinet. Journalists and other human rights activists, mostly women, protested in Herat and Kabul, calling for women to be included in Cabinet. The acting Cabinet announced on September 7 is men only, and the Department of Women's Affairs appears to have been abolished. Afghanistan consists of 34 provinces (ولايت; velayat): Before 1979 there were 325 districts then this increased to 329 and in 2004, the number increased to 397. Afghanistan is a relatively poor country, heavily dependent on agriculture and animal husbandry. Its economy was weakened by recent political and military unrest, in addition to a harsh drought with the nation's hardships between 1998-2001.

Most of the population is experiencing a crisis of food, clothing, shelter, and a lack of health care. This condition is exacerbated by military operations, and political uncertainty. Inflation creates many problems. Following the US-led coalition war that led to the downfall of the Taliban in November 2001, and the establishment of the Afghanistan Interim Authority (AIA) resulting from the December 2001 Bonn Agreement, international efforts to rebuild Afghanistan were addressed at the Tokyo Donors Conference for Afghanistan Reconstruction in January 2002, where $4.5 million raised for a trust fund to be administered by the World Bank. Priority areas for reconstruction include the construction of education, health and healthcare facilities, administrative capacity building, development of the agricultural sector, and rebuilding of roads, energy and telecommunications networks. The population of Afghanistan is estimated at 29.2 million people in 2017. Of the 15 million people are men and 14.2 million people are women. Afghanistan is home to a number of tribes. However, due to the absence of adequate soul enumerators, the actual conditions are not known for sure. And what is available now is only based on estimates. Based on records from the CIA World FactBook (updated on May 17, 2005), ethnic demographics in Afghanistan are as follows: Pashto 42%, concentrated in the eastern and southern parts of Afghanistan; Tajiks 27% are centered in the north, and Kabul; Hazara 9% are based in central Afghanistan including Bamiyan; Uzbeks 9%; Aimak 4%; Turkmen 3%; Baluchi 2% and the remaining 4% are Mencius Wakhidan Kyrgyz. There are two official languages ​​in Afghanistan, namely Afgani Persian which is often called Dari (50%), and Pashtun (35%). Some of the other languages ​​are Turkic languages ​​(Uzbek and Turkmen are spoken by 11% of the population), and 30 minor languages, especially Baluchi, and Pashai (4%). Many Afghans speak two or more languages.

Religion in Afghanistan (2008) It is estimated that 99.7% of the entire population of Afghanistan is Muslim and most adhere to the Sunni Hanafi school of thought. According to the Pew Research Center, 90% are denominated Sunni, 7% are Shia Muslims and 3% are non-denominational. The CIA Factbook also estimates on several occasions that there are up to 89.7% Sunnis or up to 15% Shiites. Dr Michael Izady estimates that 70% of the population adheres to Sunni Islam, 25% adheres to the Twelve Imams Shia, 4.5% is Ismaili Shia Islam, and 0.5% belongs to other religions. It is estimated that 30% of Afghanistan's 7,000 schools were badly damaged during more than 2 decades of Soviet occupation, civil war, and Taliban rule. Only half of the schools reported having clean water, with less than 40% thought to have adequate sanitation. Education for boys was not a priority during the Taliban era, and girls were left out of school voluntarily. Regarding poverty, and the violence that surrounds them, a 2002 study by aid group Save the Children said Afghan children were resilient, and courageous. The study praised the strong family and environmental institutions. Up to 4 million Afghan children, possibly the largest number, are believed to have registered for classes for the school year beginning in March 2003. The overall literacy rate of the population is estimated at 36%. Many historical monuments of this country were damaged in the wars of recent years. Two famous Bamiyan Buddhas in Bamiyan Province were destroyed by the Taliban because they were considered symbols of other religions. The Afghans are known as horse riders. Famous sports like Buzkashi are famous there. Before the Taliban came to power, the city of Kabul was home to many musicians skilled in both traditional and modern Afghan music.

Editor page logged out learn more Monazite is a reddish-brown phosphate mineral containing rare earth metals. Monazite usually forms in small isolated crystals. This mineral has a hardness ranging from 5.0 to 5.5 on the Mohs scale and is relatively dense, with a density of 4.6 to 5.7 g/cm3. There are at least four types of monazite, depending on the relative composition of the elements within the minerals: The elements are listed in parentheses in order of relative proportions in the minerals: lanthanum is the most common rare earth element in monazite-(La), and so on. Silica (SiO2) is present in trace amounts, as well as trace amounts of uranium and thorium. Due to the alpha decay of thorium and uranium, monazite contains significant amounts of helium, which can be extracted by heating. Monazite is an important ore for thorium, lanthanum, cerium. Monazite is often found in placer deposits. India, Madagascar and South Africa have large deposits of monazite sand. Deposits in India are particularly rich in monazite. Monazite is radioactive due to the presence of thorium and, less commonly, uranium. Because of its radioactivity, monazite is used in monazite geochronology to study geological events, such as crystallization, heating or deformation of rocks containing monazite. The name monazite comes from the Greek μονάζειν (solitary), via the German term monazite, as an allusion to an isolated crystal. All monazites adopt the same structure, which means that the arrangement of their atoms is very similar to that of other compounds of the M(III)PO4 type. The M(III) centers have a distorted coordination plane surrounded by eight oxides with a long M–O spacing of about 2.6 Å. The phosphate anion is tetrahedral, as usual. The same structural motif has been observed in lead chromate (PbCrO4).

Monazite sand from Brazil was first noticed in sand loads in ship ballast by Carl Auer von Welsbach in the 1880s. Von Welsbach was looking for thorium for his invention of a new lamp shirt. Monazite sand was quickly adopted as a source of thorium and became the basis of the rare earth industry. Sand monazite sand was also briefly mined in North Carolina, but shortly after, extensive deposits in southern India were discovered. Monazite from Brazil and India had dominated the industry before World War II, after which the main mining activities moved to South Africa and Bolivia. Large monazite deposits have also been found in Australia. Monazite is the only commercially significant source of lanthanide production. However, there are concerns over the removal of radioactive decay products from thorium. Bastnasite came to replace monazite in lanthanide production in the 1960s because of its much lower thorium content. There is increasing interest in using thorium for nuclear energy in the future which will bring monazite back into commercial use. Due to its high density, the mineral monazite concentrates in alluvial sands when it is removed from pegmatites by weathering processes. These conditions, called placer deposits, are often beach sand or beach fossil sands and contain other heavy minerals of commercial importance such as zircon and ilmenite. Monazite can be collected as a nearly pure concentrate using gravitational, magnetic, electrostatic separation. Monazite sand deposits are generally of monazite-(Ce) composition. Typically, lanthanides such as monazite contain about 45–48% cerium, 24% lanthanum, 17% neodymium, 5% praseodymium, and small amounts of samarium, gadolinium and yttrium. Europeanium concentrations tend to be low, around 0.05%.

The south African monazite rock, from the Steenkampskraal area, was treated in the 1950s and early 1960s by the Lindsay Chemical Division of American Potash and Chemical, at that time the world's largest producer of lanthanides. Monasit Steenkampskraal which has supplied the complete range of lanthanides. The extremely low concentration of the heaviest lanthanides in monazite justifies the term "rare earth" for the element, with an equivalent value. The thorium content of monazite varies and can sometimes be as high as 20-30%. Monazite from certain carbonatite rocks or from Bolivian tin vein ores is essentially thorium free. However, commercial monazite sand usually contains between 6 and 12% thorium oxide. The original process of "cracking" monazite to extract the thorium and lanthanide contents was by heating it with concentrated sulfuric acid at between 120 and 150°C for several hours. Variations in the ratio of acid to ore, degree of heating, and the degree to which water is then added result in several different processes for separating thorium from the lanthanides. Either of these processes causes the thorium to precipitate as phosphate or pyrophosphate in its crude form, leaving behind a solution of lanthanide sulfate, which can easily be precipitated as double sodium sulfate. The acid method causes the formation of waste acids which must be considered and the loss of phosphate content in the ore. A newer process uses hot sodium hydroxide solution (73%) at about 140°C. This process allows the valuable phosphate levels in the ore to be recovered into trisodium phosphate crystals. The lanthanide/thorium hydroxide mixture can be treated with hydrochloric acid to give a solution of lanthanide chloride, and an insoluble sludge of slightly basic thorium hydroxide. Editor page that has logged out learn more Gudeg (Javanese: ꦒꦸꦝꦼꦒ꧀, translit. Gudhěg) is a typical dish of the Special Province of Yogyakarta made from young jackfruit cooked in coconut milk. It takes hours to make this dish. The brown color is usually produced by teak leaves which are cooked together. Gudeg is usually eaten with rice and served with thick coconut milk (areh), free-range chicken, eggs, tempeh, tofu and krecek fried chili sauce. Gudeg is very popular in Java, this dish is a popular dish as both home cooking and street food. Gudeg is also produced industrially as canned food. Gudeg can also be found outside Indonesia, especially in neighboring countries such as Malaysia and Singapore. Gudeg is made from jackfruit which grows on many islands in the Malay Archipelago, especially in Java, and is an important food crop. A large number of certain spices and seasonings are used in the boiling process, these spices also increase the shelf life of gudeg. In Central Java, there is a legend linking the origins of Gudeg with the founding of the Mataram Sultanate at the end of the 16th century. It is said that at that time the fighters who cleared the forest for the construction of a new national capital in the Yogyakarta area did not currently receive adequate food supplies. Meanwhile, only jackfruit and coconut trees thrive in the forest. When the young jackfruit is hard, and cannot be eaten raw, they boil the young jackfruit in coconut milk in a large metal pot and stir it with a wooden board. The process of cooking like this in everyday Javanese is called hangudek (jw. Hangudek)—"stirring". It is from this word, according to legend, that the name of the food invented by the Mataram soldiers, "Gudeg", was derived.

Gudeg is made from unripe jackfruit flesh. Unlike the flesh of ripe jackfruit, which is soft, bright yellow, oily and tastes very sweet, unripe jackfruit has a dense consistency and is somewhat dry, gummy, whitish or light cream in color and cannot be eaten raw. After peeling the skin, the young jackfruit is cut into small pieces and boiled in boiling water until soft. After that, the pieces of jackfruit are poured over with coconut milk – often mixed with coconut water, seasoned with certain spices and boiled for a long time – usually for 4-6 hours. The color of warm is produced mainly by the spices used. These spices also give the main taste of gudeg, because the young jackfruit's raw flesh doesn't actually have a special taste. Gudeg comes in a variety of colors, from almost white or light cream to dark red or brown. The color variation of this dish has become the nickname for this type of gudeg, warm white and warm red. The white gudeg variation is prepared with spices that don't really change the color of the original product: coriander, galangal, ginger, shallots, garlic, black pepper. In red gudeg, spices and other seasonings are added in addition to the spices above, which give a darker color to the resulting jackfruit pulp. The red dye is usually from teak leaves and Moringa oleifera, usually shrimp paste is also added, which gives a red-brown color. Also, in modern Indonesia, teabags are sometimes added to dishes during the boiling process to give gudeg a darker color and a more intense sour taste. This tea is then removed after the dish is cooked. In all types of gudeg—both dry and wet, or red and white warm—palm sugar is usually added as a sweetener.

This sweet taste is the distinctive taste of gudeg. When served alone, gudeg can be considered a vegetarian dish, as it only consists of raw jackfruit and coconut milk. However, gudeg is usually served with eggs or chicken. Gudeg is often served with white rice and chicken, either chicken opor or fried chicken, pindang egg, egg opor or plain boiled egg, tofu and/or tempeh, and krecek fried sambal (a stew made from crispy cow skin). Gudeg can be packaged into besek (a box made of bamboo) or kendil (clay jar), or canned. Canned gudeg can last up to a year, although it doesn't taste as good as freshly cooked. Warungs and restaurants serving warm can be found in all cities in Indonesia, such as Jabodetabek. Gudeg is a popular dish in Javanese restaurants, and can be found in neighboring countries, such as Singapore. There are several types of gudeg; dry, wet, Yogyakarta style, Solo style and East Java style. Dry gudeg only has a little coconut milk and has a little gravy. Wet gudeg contains more coconut milk. The most common gudeg comes from Yogyakarta, and is usually sweeter, drier and reddish in color due to the addition of teak leaves as a coloring agent. Solo gudeg from Surakarta is more watery and gravy, has lots of coconut milk, and has a whitish color because teak leaves are generally not added. Yogyakarta gudeg is usually called "red warm", while Solo warm is also called "white warm". The East Javanese style gudeg has a spicier taste compared to the sweeter Yogyakarta style gudeg. Gudeg is traditionally associated with Yogyakarta, and Yogyakarta is sometimes nicknamed "The City of Gudeg" (the city of warm). The Yogyakarta gudeg restaurant center is in the Wijilan area, east of the Yogyakarta Palace.

This term is used differently in various fields of study, such as philosophy, mathematics, astronomy, psychology, etc., making it difficult to provide a clear and non-controversial universal definition regardless of the appropriate context. There is also disagreement about whether space itself is measurable or part of a measurement system. Science itself considers that space is a fundamental unit, namely a unit that cannot be defined by other units. The definition of space is usually more spatial in nature, while in reality the space is closely integrated with a group of people with all their activities within a certain period of time, in the study of environmental architecture and behavior, the term setting tends to be used more. The term setting places more emphasis on elements of human activity that are not clearly visible in terms of space. In Geography Studies: An Approach and Spatial Analysis (1981), Nursid Sumaatmadja describes the definition of space. Space is a place on the surface of the earth, either as a whole or only in part, that is used by living things to live. Space can also be interpreted as a container for all human, animal and plant activities on the surface of the earth. Space is not only limited to air in contact with the earth's surface. But also the lowest layer of the atmosphere that affects the earth's surface. Space also includes waters that are on the surface of the earth, namely seas, rivers, lakes, or those that are below the surface of the earth (groundwater) to a certain depth. Quoted from Education Standards, the concept of space is a concept that focuses on the location and spatial distribution, as well as how people organize and manage the space they live in.

editor page logged off learn more Ninurta (also called Ningirsu, Pabilsag and in the Bible Nimrod) is the Sumerian and Akkadian god of war, hunting god, sun god, agriculture god and south wind god. In Sumerian, Nin means god and urta means grain of wheat. Ninurta is often depicted holding his bow and arrows and a sickle-shaped sword. He is also often depicted standing on the back of an odd-looking beast with a lion's body and a scorpion's tail chasing a giant lion with a bird's tail, legs and wings. Ninurta first appears in ancient texts in the early third millennium BC (BC) as the agricultural god of the city of Girsu (from which his other names Ningirsu or city god of Girsu are derived) and the city of Larak (known as Pabilsag). Girsu and Larak were part of Sumer. Ninurta was the child of Enlil and Ninhursag but in some stories, his parents were Enlil and Ninlil. Ninurta was married to Gula, the goddess of healing (although in some inscriptions, as Ningirsu he was married to the goddess Bau). Around 1500 BC, Ninurta was still the god of agriculture. The Assyrian and Neo-Assyrian Empires described Ninurta as the son of the Asur god. During the reign of Ashurnasirpal II (884-859 BC), the large Eshumesha temple and ziggurat (a large structure from the time of ancient Mesopotamia) were built in the new city of Kalhu. Ninurta was also used as protection and aid to military affairs by a number of kingdoms during ancient Mesopotamia from 3300-612 BC when the Neo-Assyrian empire finally fell. Ninurta as the god of war is mentioned in the Epic of Anzû (also known as The Conquest of Zû) where Anzû's bird steals the Plate of Destiny from Enlil.

Ninurta, assisted by Enki, manages to defeat Anzû's bird and bring Enlil's destiny plate back to Nippur. The story of Ninurta is also mentioned in the heroic poem Lugal-e. It is told about his battle against Asag who, in his endeavors, made an irrigation system for the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, learned how to make embankments, analyzed the types of stones and their functions. Basically this heroic poem tells about the nature of the fighter Ninurta and his abilities as the god of agriculture. The story, which is also called O King, Storm of Majestic Splendor, begins with a depiction of Ninurta in the middle of a celebration when he receives a message from Sahur. Sahur is Ninurta's weapon in the form of a mace and can talk. Shahur gives news that over the mountains there has been an uprising by rocks and plants led by a cruel warrior named Asag. Asag himself is depicted as a fearless demon, unable to wield spears and axes. Under Asag's command, rocks fell from the mountain, destroying the city below. Sharur also informed him that Asag was planning to usurp the throne. Ninurta took action immediately, he created a huge windstorm that destroyed his enemies but was unable to find Asag. Shahur's warning to Ninurta not to attack Asag directly at his base, was ignored. Shahur, who saw that Ninurta was desperate, finally flew to Nippur and asked for help from Enlil who gave him power over the stormy winds from heaven and a very great beating weapon. With him, Ninurta managed to defeat Asag. After her victory, Ninurta found that the Tigris did not have enough water and there was a famine. Ninurta then diverted the flow of water from the mountains. He used the crushed stones after the battle against Asag to build dams and irrigation systems.

The result was a bountiful crop of fruit, vegetables and wheat fields. Ninurta's mother, Ninmah then came down from heaven and visited. Ninurta dedicated his work to his mother by calling it Ninhursag or woman from the mountain. After finishing irrigation, the myth about Ninurta then tells how she started selecting, sorting and analyzing rocks. It was at this time that he made his decision against the rocks that had revolted under the leadership of Azag and the rocks that chose to side with him. Some stones were punished by Ninurta to be stones easily eroded by erosion, some were used to crush other stones, some were hewn, hollowed out and polished in various ways. Ninurta punished the limestone and basalt stones for fighting against them by making them into the molds of the goldsmiths. Limestone, punished by its function as a foundation for muddy soils. Stones that favored Ninurta were rewarded by making them precious stones such as lapis lazuli. There are two versions of this story about Ninurta and Anzu. Old Babylonian version (1850-1500 BC) under the name Ningirsu and new Babylonian version under the name Ninurta (1500-600 BC). In this tale, Enlil's Plate of Destiny is taken by the bird Anzu who was originally the guardian of his shrine. This plate holds the destiny of gods and men. Not only that, whoever has it is the holder of power. The Anzu bird had been waiting a long time to steal this plate. From his stand, Anzu could see that when Enlil bathed, he always kept this Plate of Fate. So he waited for the opportunity, took the plate and flew towards the mountains. Enlil orders Adad to retrieve the stolen tablets. But he refused on the grounds that no one would be able to defeat Anzu with the plate in his hands.

Editor's page that has logged out learn more Keroncong is a typical Indonesian type of music that uses string instruments, flute and vocals. The roots of keroncong come from a type of Portuguese music known as fado which was introduced by sailors and slaves to the nation's merchant ships from the 16th century to the archipelago. From mainland India (Goa), this music first entered Malacca and was later played by slaves from Maluku. The weakening of the Portuguese influence in the 17th century in the archipelago did not necessarily mean the loss of this music. The earliest form of this music was called moresco (a dance of Spanish origin, such as polka with a slightly sluggish rhythm), in which Kusbini's re-composed song is now known as Kr. Muritsku, accompanied by string instruments. Keroncong music originating from Tugu is called kroncong Tugu. During its development, a number of traditional Indonesian elements were incorporated, such as the use of the flute and several gamelan components. Around the 19th century this mixed musical form was already popular in many places in the archipelago, even as far as the Malay Peninsula. This golden age continued until around the 1960s, and then faded due to the influx of popular music waves (rock music that developed since 1950, and the triumph of the Beatles and the like from 1961 until now). Nonetheless, keroncong music isstill played and enjoyed by all walks of life in Indonesia and Malaysia until now Keroncong music entered Indonesia around 1512, when the Portuguese expedition led by Afonso de Albuquerque came to Malacca and Maluku in 1512. Of course the Portuguese sailors brought songs of the Fado type, namely Portuguese folk songs with Arabic tones (minor scale, because the Moors Arabs once ruled the Portuguese / Spanish in 711 - 1492.

Fado-type songs still exist in Latin America (former Spanish colony), such as those sung by Trio Los Panchos or Los Paraguayos, or also songs in West Sumatra (Arabic culture) such as Ayam Den Lapeh. In 1661, the VOC administration freed Portuguese prisoners and slaves from Goa (India) in Kampung Tugu on condition that they had to convert from Catholicism to Protestantism, so that the habit of singing the Fado song became mandatory to sing like in the Protestant Church, which is on the major scale. Then in 1880 Keroncong music was born, and early on this Keroncong music was also influenced by Hawaiian songs in the major scales, which also developed rapidly in Indonesia along with Keroncong music (see Music of the Ambon Tribe or The Hawaiian Seniors led by General Police Hoegeng). In its earliest form, moresco was accompanied by string music, such as violin, ukulele and cello. Percussion is also sometimes used. This kind of orchestral set is still used by the Tugu kroncong, a form of keroncong that is still played by a community of descendants of Portuguese slaves from Ambon who live in Kampung Tugu, North Jakarta, which then developed southwards at Kemayoran and Gambir by the Betawi people mingling with Tanjidor music (year 1880-1920). In 1920-1960 the center of development moved to Solo, and adapted to a slower rhythm according to the characteristics of the Javanese. The introduction of "native" keroncong makes it a mixed art, with musical instruments such as: Contrapuntal guitars and rhythmic cellos manage the chord shifts. The violin functions as a melodic guide, as well as a bottom decoration. Flut fills the top decoration, which floats to fill the empty melodic space.

The form of keroncong mixed with popular music now uses a single organ and synthesizer to accompany keroncong songs (in single organ parties, all players can play keroncong, dangdut, rock, polka, mars). Keroncong music is more inclined to chord progressions and the types of instruments used. Since the mid-20th century, at least three kinds of keroncong have been recognized, which can be identified by their chord progression patterns. For musicians who already understand the flow, accompanying keroncong songs is actually not difficult, because it is enough to adjust the prevailing pattern. Development is done by maintaining the consistency of the pattern. In addition, there are also mixed forms and adaptations. After experiencing a long evolution since the arrival of the Portuguese in Indonesia (1522) and the settlement of slaves in the Kampung Tugu area in 1661, this was a long period of early evolution of keroncong music (1661-1880), for almost two centuries, but it has not yet shown an identity. the real keroncong with the sound of crong-crong-crong, so it can be said that keroncong music was not born in 1661-1880. The government initiated the construction of a firebrick building, and the construction of wider roads to connect Shinbashi Station and the foreigner enclave at Tsukiji, as well as important government buildings. The town plan for this area was designed by an Irish-born architect named Thomas Waters. The construction executor is the Contracting Bureau of the Ministry of Finance. Also completed at that time in Ginza, a brick building in the style of Georgian architecture. The buildings in Ginza's "brick city" were originally offered to those who wished to buy.
