The editor's logged-out page learn more Senegal (/ˌsɛnɪˈɡɔːl, -ˈɡɑːl/ ( listen); French: Sénégal; Wolof: Senegaal), officially the Republic of Senegal (French: République du Sénégal ʁepyblik dy seneɡal]), is a a country south of the Senegal River in West Africa. The country is bordered by the Atlantic Ocean to the west, Mauritania to the north, Mali to the east, and Guinea and Guinea Bissau to the south. The Gambia is an enclave within the territory of Senegal. The 300 km long Gambia River flows in Gambia. Cape Verde is located 560 km from the coast of Senegal. The capital city of Senegal is Dakar. The name "Senegal" comes from the Wolof word "Sunuu Gaal", which means "Our Boat". Senegal has a land area of ​​nearly 197,000 square kilometers and has a population of approximately 15 million people. Senegal's climate is that of the Sahel, but it also experiences monsoons. Senegal has a population of over 13.5 million, about 42 percent of whom live in rural areas. Density in this area varies from about 77 inhabitants per square kilometer in the west-central region to 2 per square kilometer in the east. In the mid-15th century, the Portuguese landed on the coast of Senegal, followed by traders representing other countries, including France. Various European powers—Portugal, Holland, and England—compete for trade in this area from the 15th century onward. In 1677, the French took control of what had become a minor point of departure in the Atlantic slave trade—the island of Gorée next to modern Dakar, used as a base for buying slaves. European missionaries introduced Christianity to Senegal and Casamance in the 19th century. It was only in the 1850s that the French began expanding into the Senegalese mainland after they abolished slavery and began promoting abolitionist doctrine, adding native kingdoms such as the Waalo, Cayor, Baol, and Wolof Empires.

The French colonies progressively invaded and took over all the principalities except Sine and Saloum under Governor Louis Faidherbe. Senegal's resistance to French expansion and the imprisonment of the slave trade that benefited them was led in part by Lat-Dior, Damel of Cayor, and Maad a Sinig Kumba Ndoffene Famak Joof, king of Sine, resulting in the Battle of Logandème. On 4 April 1959 Senegal and French Sudan merged to form the Federation of Mali, which became fully independent on 20 June 1960, as a result of the independence and transfer of powers agreement signed with France on 4 April 1960. Senegal was divided into 14 regions, each each administered by a Regional Council which is elected based on population size at the Arrondissement level. The country is further subdivided by 45 Departments, 113 Arrondissements (both of which have no administrative function). Regional capitals share names with their respective regions: Senegal has a population of over 13.5 million, about 42 percent of whom live in rural areas. Density in this area varies from about 77 inhabitants per square kilometer in the west-central region to 2 per square kilometer in the east. Senegal has various ethnic groups and, as in most West African countries, several languages ​​are spoken. Wolof are the largest ethnic group in Senegal at 43 percent; Fula and Toucouleur (also known as Halpulaar'en, literally "Pulaar-speakers") (24%) are the second largest group, followed by Serer (14.7%), followed by groups like Jola (4%), Mandinka (3%), Maures (or Naarkajors), Soninke, Bassari and many smaller communities (9%). About 50,000 Europeans (mostly from France) and Lebanese and a smaller portion from Mauritania and Morocco live in Senegal, mainly in towns and some retirees living in resort towns around Mbour.

Most of the Lebanese work in trade. Also located mainly in urban areas are small Vietnamese communities as well as a growing number of immigrant traders of Chinese origin, numbering perhaps several hundred people each. There are also tens of thousands of Mauritanian refugees in Senegal, mainly in the north of the country. According to the 2008 World Refugee Survey, published by the US Committee on Refugees and Immigrants, Senegal had a population of refugees and asylum seekers of approximately 23,800 in 2007. The majority of this population (20,200) are from Mauritania. Refugees live in N'dioum, Dodel and small settlements along the Senegal River valley. French is the official language, spoken at least by everyone who has spent several years in the educational system that originated in France (Quran schooling is even more popular, but Arabic is not widely used outside of reading contexts). Most people also speak their ethnic language although, especially in Dakar, Wolof is the lingua franca. The Pulaar language is spoken by the Fula and Toucouleur ethnic groups. The Serer language is widely spoken by Serers and non-Serers alike (including President Sall, whose wife is of Serer descent); as well as the Cangin language, which is spoken by the Serer ethnicity. the Jola language is widely spoken in Casamance. Several Senegalese languages ​​have the legal status of "national languages": Balanta-Ganja, Hassaniya Arabic, Jola-Fonyi, Mandinka, Mandjak, Mankanya, Noon (Serer-midday), Pulaar, Serer, Soninke, and Wolof. Senegal is a secular country. Islam is the dominant religion in the country, followed by around 94% of the country's population; the Christian community, accounting for 5% of the population, are mostly Roman Catholics but there are still some Protestant groups. One percent have animist beliefs, particularly in the southeastern region of the country.

Some Serer people follow the Serer religion. Senegal is renowned for its West African tradition of storytelling, carried on by storytellers called Griots, who have preserved West African history for thousands of years through stories and music. The griot profession is hereditary and requires years of studying its origins, history and music. The griots gave a voice to a generation of West Africans. The African Renaissance Monument was built in 2010 in Dakar and is the tallest statue in Africa. Dakar also hosts the film festival, Recidak. Since Senegal borders the Atlantic Ocean, fish is a very important ingredient. Chicken, lamb, peas, eggs and beef are also used in Senegalese cuisine, but not pork, as the majority of the population is Muslim. Peanuts, Senegal's main crop, as well as couscous, white rice, sweet potatoes, lentils, cowpeas and various vegetables, are also commonly included in many dishes. Meat and vegetables are usually boiled or marinated in herbs and spices, then poured over rice or couscous, or eaten with bread. A popular fresh juice in Senegal is made from bissap, ginger, buy (pronounced 'buoy', which is the fruit of the baobab tree, also known as "monkey bread fruit"), mango, or other fruit or wild trees (the most famous soursop, which is called corossol in French). The desserts are rich and sweet, combining native ingredients with a style characteristic of the French impact on Senegalese culinary methods. They are often served with fresh fruit and are traditionally accompanied by coffee or tea. There are many sports in Senegal. Wrestling and football are the two most popular sports. Senegal will stage the 2026 Summer Youth Olympics in Dakar, making it the first African nation to stage an Olympic games.

Wrestling is Senegal's most popular sport and has become a national obsession. It has become a way for many young people to escape poverty and is the only sport that is recognized as a sport that developed from Western culture. Football is a popular sport in Senegal. In 2002, the team finished as runners-up in the African Cup of Nations and became one of only three African teams to ever reach the quarter-finals of the FIFA World Cup, beating previous champions France in their first match. Popular players from this team include Sadio Mané, El Hadji Diouf, Papa Bouba Diop, Khalilou Fadiga and Henri Camara, all of whom have played in Europe. In 2022, Senegal managed to win the Africa Cup of Nations after beating Egypt in the final. Basketball is also a popular sport in Senegal. The country has consistently become one of the dominant basketball powers in Africa. The men's team performed better than any other African team in the 2014 FIBA ​​World Cup, where they reached the playoffs for the first time. The women's team has won a total of 19 medals at 20 African Championships, more than twice as many medals as any other competitor. In 2016, the national basketball association in the US, known as the NBA announced the launch of an Elite Academy in Africa, more specifically in Senegal. The country hosted the Paris-Dakar Rally from 1979 to 2007. The Dakar Rally was an off-road automotive sports event that started from Paris, France to Dakar, Senegal. Participants drive off-road vehicles to traverse difficult geography. The last race was held in 2007, before the 2008 rally was canceled the day before the event due to safety concerns in Mauritania. The Ocean X-Prix which is part of the Extreme E electric off-road championship is also being held in Senegal.

Editor's page logged out learn more Oceania is a term that refers to a geographical or geopolitical area consisting of a number of islands located in and around the Pacific Ocean. Oceania is the region on Earth (often considered a continent) with the smallest land area and the second smallest population after Antarctica. In a narrow sense (based on French explorer Jules Dumont d'Urville in 1831), Oceania includes Polynesia (including New Zealand), Melanesia (including Papua New Guinea) and Micronesia. Meanwhile, in a broad sense, Oceania also includes Australia and Maritime Southeast Asia which also includes the Malay Peninsula. However, sometimes Hong Kong, the Korean Peninsula, Japan, Taiwan, the Aleutian Islands, Sakhalin Island, the peninsula in northeastern Russia, and the Alaska Peninsula are also considered in the Oceania group. Most of Oceania is made up of small island nations. Australia is the only country that is both an island and is still being debated between islands and continents, while Papua New Guinea, Malaysia and Timor Leste are countries that have land and sea borders, both of which share a border with Indonesia. The countries of Oceania have independence under different terms from their colonial powers, and enjoy constitutional provisions which vary according to their circumstances. Australia, for example, is a member of the British Commonwealth, thus recognizing King Charles III as their King, while French Polynesia is a pays d'outre-mer ("overseas country") of France. Ecologically, Oceania is one of the world's eight terrestrial ecological zones. The Oceania ecological zone includes Polynesia except New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, New Caledonia, Fiji, the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu which are classified as the Australasia and Southeast Asia Maritime ecological zones including the Malay Peninsula and Micronesia which are classified as the Asian ecological zone.

Editor's page logged out learn more Epigraphy (from Greek: ἐπιγραφή epi-graphē, meaning "writing", "inscription") is a branch of archeology that attempts to study written objects that date back to the past. One example is the inscription. Inscriptions are a source of written evidence (in the form of writing or pictures) in the past which can provide information about events in the past, the origin of a king or figure or genealogy or calendar. The person who first paid attention to inscriptions was Thomas Stamford Raffles as in his book The History of Java in 1817. Research on inscriptions developed around the 1850s. Linguistic knowledge is indispensable for understanding ancient languages. Epigraphy specifically studies the decipherment of words and understanding the contents of an ancient inscription. Decomposition of words in terms of form, type, style of script, and language that is still used or not used anymore. In epigraphy, research is done on newly discovered inscriptions as well as those that have been previously studied. The distinctive feature of epigraphy is transliteration which aims to make it easier to read an inscription. Epigraphy has differences and similarities with philology. What these two scientific disciplines have in common is that they both study ancient writings. The difference is, epigraphy only studies ancient writings on inscriptions, while philology only studies ancient writings in manuscript form. Another similarity between epigraphy and philology is the method used in the form of text criticism. Epigraphy aims to make the inscriptions found in excavations readable. Furthermore, the purpose of this epigraphy cannot be separated from the purpose of archeology. The goal of archeology is to reconstruct past history based on what can be recovered with skill and mastery of excavation methods on ancient objects.

If the remains are in the form of inscriptions, the epigrapher will manage them so that they can be known when they occurred, who the government figures were and what the contents contained in the inscriptions. Epigraphers, who are also called epigraphers, have the ability to analyze inscriptions with their ability to read ancient writings, both in the form of ancient letters and ancient languages. The task of an epigrapher is not only to examine the inscriptions that have not been published but also to re-examine the inscriptions that have been published in a provisional transcription. Then the epigrapher must translate the inscription into the language used today so that other researchers, particularly historians, can use the various kinds of information contained in the inscriptions. In carrying out their duties, epigraphers encounter many kinds of obstacles. According to an Indonesian archaeologist who specializes in epigraphy, Drs. Hasan Djafar, the first problem is that many inscriptions, especially stone inscriptions, are already in a state of disrepair, making it difficult to read them. The epigrapher has to read the worn passages over and over again to get a satisfactory reading. By mastering the forms of ancient letters with all their twists and turns, and by constantly comparing the old letters with those that are still clear, an epigrapher tries to get the most complete reading possible. Second, faced with translating the inscriptions. Knowledge of the ancient languages ​​used in the inscriptions is still not enough to fully understand the meaning contained in the texts. Epigraphers are like detectives who find out about life and past events through secret codes in the form of letters or pictures through their ability to analyze. So that people, especially historians and archaeologists, get clear and valid historical information.

Page editor logged out learn more Slavery or servitude is an act or condition that makes a person a slave, which is a property object owned by another person. Slavery usually occurred with enslaved people being made to do some form of work and their location also being determined by the person who owned them. Historically, when people were enslaved, it was often because that person was in debt, broke the law, or suffered a military defeat: The duration of their slavery could be a lifetime, or a period of time before they were granted freedom. An individual is usually enslaved against his will or under duress, although there is also voluntary slavery done to pay debts or to obtain money for a specific purpose. Throughout human history, slavery has been an aspect of civilization, and was once legal in most of the world's societies, but is now outlawed in all countries of the world. In traditional slavery (chattel slavery), people who are legally enslaved are considered the private property (chattel) of the slave owner. In economics, the term de facto slavery refers to the forced labor conditions experienced by the majority of slaves. In 2019, around 40 million people, of whom 26 percent were children, were enslaved worldwide despite being illegal. In the modern world, more than 50 percent of people are enslaved to perform forced labor, usually in factories in a country's private sector. In industrialized countries, human trafficking is a modern form of slavery; in non-industrialized countries, debt bondage is a common form of enslavement, such as captive domestic service, forced marriage, and child soldiers. The word slave (English: slave) in English was adopted from the Old French sclave.

In Medieval Latin it was sclavus and in Greek σκλάβος. Use of the word arose during the Early Medieval Period, when Slavic peoples from Central and Eastern Europe (Saqaliba) were often enslaved by Moors from the Iberian Peninsula and North Africa. There is debate among historians about whether terms such as "forced laborers" or "enslaved persons" were better used than "slaves" for victims of slavery. According to those who proposed changing the terminology, the term slave perpetuated the crime of slavery by reducing its victims to nouns and non-humans. Other historians prefer slaves because the term is more familiar and shorter, or because it accurately reflects the inhumane practice of slavery, and vice versa, people say it implicitly indicates a level of autonomy possessed that slavery simply did not exist. As an institutionalized social practice, traditional slavery denies human agency or autonomy and legally degrades their human status and status into goods (chattel) owned by their owners; therefore slaves are supposed to give birth to slaves; children of slaves were also born as slaves, under the legal doctrine of 2100 BC, the Law of Ur-Nammu ("4. If a slave marries a slave, and the slave is set free, he does not leave the house. 5. If a slave is married a freedman, she must leave her firstborn child to its owner....") or legal doctrine in 1662 CE partus sequitur venttrem ("That which is born follows the womb"). Like livestock, they can be bought and sold at will. By law, slaves could be used sexually in any way their owners wanted; women have no right to refuse.

In the Antebellum period in the United States, many enslaved women were forced to become pregnant and give birth repeatedly, with no information regarding who impregnated them; their children are usually taken from them and sold, as if they were calves. Although several common forms of slavery have occurred throughout human history, the specific idea of ​​slavery of persons as goods described above reached its peak in America. Beginning in the 18th century, the abolitionist movement saw slavery as a violation of everyone's rights as human beings ("all men are created equal"), and sought to abolish it. This movement was successful; the last Western country to abolish slavery was Brazil in 1888. The last third world country to abolish slavery was Mauritania, which maintained the practice of slavery until 1981. Another form of chattel slavery is sexual slavery, which often takes place in a military context, including incarceration in " rape camps" or "consolation stations", "comfort women", "forced marriages" to soldiers and other practices involving the treatment of women or men as property. All of these practices were violations of the fundamental international norms (jus cogens) which prohibit slavery. Indenture, otherwise known as bonded labor or debt bondage, is a form of forced labor that involves a person pledging himself or herself on a loan/debt. The form of forced labor required to repay the debt, and the duration, may not be specified. Debt-related forced labor can be passed down from generation to generation, with children required to pay off the debts of their ancestors or parents. Slavery This is the most widespread form of slavery today. Forced labor related to debt bondage is most prevalent in South Asia. Money marriage refers to a marriage in which a girl is, usually, married to a man to pay off a debt her parents owe.

The Chukri system is a bondage system found in parts of Bengal whereby a woman can be forced into prostitution to pay off debts. The term "slavery" has also been used to refer to a state of legal dependence on another person. For example, in Persia, the situation and life of slaves could be better than that of ordinary citizens. Forced, or precarious, labor is the term used to describe someone who is forced to work against their will, under the threat of violence or other punishment, but the general term precarious labor is also used to describe enslavement of property (chattel), as well as any other situation where a person is obliged to work against his will, and a person's ability to work productively is under the full control of another person. citation needed] This may also include institutions not normally classified as slavery, such as peasant slavery, compulsory military and penal labor. Although some non-free workers, such as farm slaves, have some legal or traditional de jure rights, they lack the ability to terminate their working arrangements and are often the target of forms of coercion, violence, and restrictions on their activities and movements outside the workplace. citation needed] Trafficking in persons, for example, involving women and children forced into prostitution is the fastest growing form of forced labour, with Thailand, Cambodia, India, Brazil and Mexico having been identified as major hotspots of commercial sexual exploitation of children. . In 2007, Human Rights Watch estimated that 200,000 to 300,000 children served as soldiers in the conflict at that time. More girls under 16 work as domestic workers than any other category of child labour. They are often sent to the cities by their parents who live in poverty in rural areas such as restaveks in Haiti.

Forced and early marriages are often considered a type of slavery. Forced marriage continues to be practiced in several parts of the world including parts of Asia and Africa and in immigrant communities in Western countries. Sacred prostitution is when women and girls are promised to priests or people of a higher caste, as is the practice of Devadasi in South Asia or fetish slaves in West Africa. Marriage by kidnapping occurs in many parts of the world today, with a 2003 study finding a national average of 69% of marriages in Ethiopia were consummated by kidnapping. The term slavery is often used pejoratively to describe any activity in which a person is forced to perform that activity. Some argue that conscription and other forms of government forced labor amount to "state-operated slavery". Some libertarians and anarcho-capitalists view government taxes as a form of slavery. Some animal rights advocates have used the term slavery to refer to the condition of some or all animals owned by humans, arguing that their status is the same as that of human slaves. The labor market, as institutionalized under contemporary capitalist systems, has been criticized by mainstream socialists and by anarcho-syndicalists, who use the term wage slavery as a pejorative for wage labour. Socialists contrast trade in commodity labor with slavery. Cicero is also known to have made such comparisons. In practice, a slave was privately owned by individuals and also came under state ownership. For example, kisaeng were women of lower caste in pre-modern Korea, who were owned by the state under a government official known as a hojang and required to provide entertainment to the nobles; in the 2020s some kisaeng were denoted by the Kippumjo (North Korean pleasure brigade — tasked with serving the country's rulers as concubines).

"Tribute labour" is mandatory work for the state and has been used in various repeated incidents such as corvée, mit'a and repartimiento. The internment camps of totalitarian regimes such as the Nazis and the Soviet Union emphasized the importance of the labor provided in the camps, leading historians to refer to such a system as slavery. Economists have modeled the circumstances under which slavery (and variants such as peasant slavery) appeared and disappeared. One observation suggests that slavery became more desirable for landowners when land was abundant but labor was scarce, so land rents fell and paid workers could demand higher wages. If the opposite were the case, it would have been more expensive for the landowner to look after the slaves than to hire paid laborers who could only charge low wages because of the level of competition. So, first slavery, and then peasant slavery gradually declined in Europe as the population grew. These forms of slavery were reintroduced in America and in Russia when large areas of land existed, but only a small population existed. Slavery was more common when forms of labor were relatively simple and easy to control, such as working large-scale monoculture crops such as sugarcane and cotton, where output depended on economies of scale. This allowed labor systems, such as the gang system in the United States, to become prominent on large plantations as field workers toiled with factory-like precision. Then, each work gang is based on an internal division of labor that assigns each gang member to a task and makes each worker's performance dependent on the actions of the other workers. The enslaved cut the weeds surrounding the cotton plants as well as the excess sprouts.

The gang of plows followed behind, raking up the soil near the plants and throwing it back around the plants. Thus, the gang system works like an assembly line. Since the 18th century, critics have argued that slavery hindered technological progress because its focus was on increasing the number of slaves performing simple tasks rather than increasing their efficiency. For example, it has been argued that because of this scant focus on forms of work, technology in Greece – and later in Rome – was not applied to facilitate physical labor or improve manufacturing. Scottish economist Adam Smith said that free labor was economically better than slave labor. However, Smith continued, it would be nearly impossible to end the practice of slavery in free, democratic, or republican systems of government because many legislators or political figures were slave owners, and would not punish themselves. He further stated that slaves would be better able to gain freedom under a centralized government, or a centralized authority such as a king or church. Similar arguments appear later in the work of Auguste Comte, particularly with regard to Smith's support of the concept of the separation of powers, or what Comte called "the spiritual and temporal separation" during the Middle Ages and the end of slavery. As Smith stated in his Lectures on Jurisprudence, "The great power of the clergy consorting with the king could free the slaves. But this required the condition that the authority of the king and the clergy must be great. When either of these authorities wished to continue the practice of slavery, slavery would continues…” Even after slavery became a crime, slave owners could still earn high profits. According to researcher Siddharth Kara, the profits generated worldwide by all forms of slavery in 2007 were $91.2 billion.

The profit, second only to drug trafficking, is linked to global criminal enterprises. At the time, it was estimated that the average global selling price of a slave was around $340, with a high of $1,895 on average for trafficked sex slaves, and as low as $40 to $50 for debt bondage in parts of Asia and Africa. The average annual profit made by a slave in 2007 was $3,175, with the lowest average being $950 for forced labor and $29,210 for trafficked sex slaves. About 40% of the annual profits of slaves are generated by traded sex slaves, representing more than 4% of the world's 29 million slaves. Throughout history, slaves dressed in distinctive ways, such as rarely wearing footwear, as they were usually forced to go barefoot. This is largely due to economic reasons, but it is also characteristic, especially in South Africa and South America. For example, Cape Town's slave laws stated that "Slaves must be barefoot and must carry a permit." It also placed slaves at a physical disadvantage due to a lack of protection against environmental conditions and in situations of confrontation, thus making it more difficult for them to escape or rebel against their owners. This is the case in most countries. Most of the images from the historical period show slaves barefoot. Brother Riemer said, "slaves], even in their most beautiful garments, were obliged to go barefoot. Slaves were forbidden to wear shoes. This was the chief sign of the difference between the free and the bonded and no exceptions were permitted." According to the Bible, shoes have been considered a badge of freedom since ancient times: "But the father said to his servants, Bring the finest robes, and put them on; and put the ring on his hand, and the shoes on his feet]" (Luke 15:22: KJV).

This aspect can be seen as an informal law in areas where slavery existed because anyone who is seen barefoot in public is considered a slave. In certain societies this rule continues. Tuareg still unofficially practice slavery and force their slaves to go barefoot. Another widespread practice is branding, either to explicitly mark them as property or as slaves for punishment. Depending on the time and country, slaves sometimes had limited legal rights. For example, in the Province of New York, it was punishable by a 1686 law to intentionally kill slaves. There were also certain legal rights attached to nobi in Korea, to enslaved people in various African societies, and to black female slaves in the French colony of Louisiana. Giving slaves legal rights was sometimes based on morality, but sometimes it was also based on self-interest. For example, in ancient Athens, protecting slaves from mistreatment could simultaneously protect people who might be mistaken for slaves, and giving slaves limited property rights could encourage slaves to work harder for more profit. In the southern United States before the abolition of slavery in 1865, a legal treatise in favor of slavery reported that slaves accused of crimes usually had legal rights to counsel, freedom from double harm, the right to be tried by a jury in more serious cases, and the right to a grand jury indictment, but they lacked many other rights such as the ability for white adults to control their own lives. Some scholars distinguish ancient forms of slavery from slavery which was largely based on race. An ancient type of slavery, sometimes called "just servitude", was imposed on prisoners of war, debtors, and other vulnerable persons.

Race-based slavery began to develop exponentially starting in the 14th century. Some writers even said at that time that slavery was intrinsically immoral. Slavery predates written records and exists in many cultures. Slavery was rare among hunter-gatherer populations because it required large economic surpluses and population densities. Thus, although in the era of hunter-gatherers there were already wealthy hunter-gatherers and extraordinary resources, such as the American Indians in the salmon-rich rivers of the Pacific Northwest coast, slavery only became widespread with the invention of agriculture. during the Neolithic Revolution about 11,000 years ago. In the earliest known records, slavery existed as an established social practice. The Code of Hammurabi (c. 1760 BC), for example, stipulates death for anyone who helps a slave escape or who shelters a fugitive. The Bible mentions slavery as an established institution. Slavery was practiced in almost every ancient civilization. These slavery practices included debt bondage, punishment for crimes, slavery of prisoners of war, slavery of foundlings, and slavery of the descendants of slaves. Slavery existed in Pharaonic Egypt, but studying it is difficult because of the complexity of the terminology used by the Egyptians to refer to the different classes of slavers throughout history. Interpretations of the textual evidence of the slave class in ancient Egypt are difficult to distinguish simply by the use of different words. However, it seems that three types of slavery existed in Ancient Egypt: traditional slavery (chattel), debt bondage, and forced labor. Slavery existed in ancient China as early as the Shang Dynasty.

Slavery was used largely by dynastic governments as a means of maintaining the public workforce. Records of slavery in Ancient Greece refer to the time of the Mycenaean Greek Civilization. Classical Athens had the largest slave population, as many as 80,000 slaves in the 6th and 5th centuries BC. As the Roman Republic developed and expanded, entire populations throughout Europe and the Mediterranean were enslaved. The slaves were used for labor, as well as for entertainment (eg gladiators and sex slaves). Oppression by this minority elite eventually led to a slave revolt (see Roman Servile Wars); The Third Slave War was led by Spartacus. By the end of the Republican era, slavery had become one of the pillars and sources of Roman wealth, as well as Roman society. It is estimated that 25% or more of the population of Ancient Rome was enslaved, although the actual percentage is disputed by scholars and varies from region to region. Slaves represented 15–25% of Italy's population, mostly prisoners of war, mainly from Gaul and Epirus. Estimates of the number of slaves in the Roman Empire show that the majority were scattered throughout the provinces outside Italy. Generally, slaves in Italy were native Italians. Foreigners (including slaves and freedmen) born outside Italy are estimated to make up 5% of the total in the capital, which is the largest number. Those from outside Europe are mostly of Greek descent. Jewish slaves were never fully assimilated into Roman society and remained an identifiable minority. These slaves (especially foreigners) had higher death rates and lower birth rates than native peoples and were sometimes subjected to mass evictions. The average age of death for slaves recorded in Rome is seventeen and a half years (17.2 years for males; 17.9 years for females).

By this time, slavery was widespread in Africa, following both internal and external slave trade. In the region of Senegambia, between 1300 and 1900, nearly a third of the population was enslaved. In the early Islamic countries of the western Sahel, including Ghana, Mali, Segou, and Songhai, about a third of the population was enslaved. During the trans-Saharan slave trade, slaves from West Africa were transported across the Sahara desert to North Africa to be sold to Mediterranean and Middle Eastern civilizations. The Indian Ocean slave trade, sometimes called the east African slave trade, was multi-directional. Africans were sent as slaves to the Arabian Peninsula, to the islands of the Indian Ocean (including Madagascar), to the Indian subcontinent, and then to the Americas. These traffickers captured the Bantu (Zanj) people from the interior of what are now Kenya, Mozambique and Tanzania, and brought them to the coast. There, slaves were gradually assimilated in rural areas, especially on the islands of Unguja and Pemba. Slavery in Mexico can be traced to the Aztecs. Other Amerindian peoples, such as the Inca of the Andes, the Tupinambá of Brazil, the Muscogee of Georgia, and the Comanche of Texas, also practiced slavery. Slavery in Canada was practiced by indigenous people and European settlers. The slave-owning communities that later became part of Canada were, for example, fishing societies, such as the Yurok, who lived along the Pacific coast from Alaska to California, in what is sometimes described as the Pacific Coast or North West Coast. In addition, some of the indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast, such as the Haida and Tlingit, are traditionally known as fierce warriors and slave traders who raided as far as California. Slavery was also hereditary. The descendants of enslaved prisoners of war were also slaves.

There were several communities in British Columbia that continued to segregate and ostracize the descendants of slaves until the late 1970s. In the Middle Ages, slavery also existed in India, Japan and Vietnam. Many Han people were enslaved during the Mongol invasion of China. According to Japanese historians Sugiyama Masaaki (杉山正明) and Funada Yoshiyuki (舩田善之), during the Yuan dynasty, many Han people owned Mongolian slaves. Slavery in Korea existed before the Three Kingdoms period of Korea. Slavery had been considered "of great importance in medieval Korea, perhaps more so than in other East Asian countries, but by the 16th century, population growth made slavery unnecessary". Slavery declined around the 10th century but reappeared in the late Goryeo period when Korea also experienced many slave rebellions. In the Joseon period in Korea, members of the slave class were known as nobi. Nobis were not socially different from freedmen (i.e., middle and common classes) other than the yangban ruling class, and some had property rights, and legal and civil rights. Therefore, some scholars argue that it is inappropriate to call them "slaves", while some scholars describe them as slaves. The nobi population can fluctuate to about a third of the total, but on average the nobi make up around 10% of the total population. In 1801, the majority of the government's nobi were released, and by 1858, the nobi population made up about 1.5 percent of the Korean population. The slave trade on a large scale was mainly in the South and East of early medieval Europe: the Byzantine Empire and the Muslim world were the goal, while the pagan Central and Eastern Europe (along with the Caucasus and the Tartars) were the source. Viking, Arab, Greek, and Radhanite Jewish traders were all involved in the slave trade during the Early Middle Ages.

The European slave trade peaked in the 10th century after the Zanj Revolt reduced the use of African slaves in the Arab world. Slavery in early medieval Europe was so common that the Catholic Church repeatedly outlawed it, or at least forbade the export of Christian slaves to non-Christian lands, as for example in the Council of Koblenz (922), the Council of London (1102) (which aimed primarily at the sale of English slaves to Ireland) and the Council of Armagh (1171). Peasant slavery was also widely accepted. In 1452, Pope Nicholas V issued the papal bull Dum Diversas, to grant the kings of Spain and Portugal the right to reduce "Saracens (Muslims), pagans and other unbelievers" to perpetual slavery. This legitimized the slave trade as a result of the war. Consent to slavery under these conditions was reaffirmed and expanded in the Pope's bull Romanus Pontifex of 1455. In England, slavery continued to be practiced after the fall of Rome, and was part of the Hywel Dda laws governing slaves in medieval Wales. The slave trade increased after the Viking invasions, with trading centers located in Chester and Bristol supplied by Danes, Mercians, and Welsh who raided each other's borders. By the end of the 11th century, almost 10% of England's population were slaves. William the Conqueror introduced laws preventing the sale of slaves abroad. According to historian John Gillingham, by 1200 slavery in the British Isles had ceased to exist. Slavery was never legalized in England and Wales. In 1772, in Somerset v Stewart, Lord Mansfield stated that the practice of slavery was also not supported in England by common law. The slave trade was abolished by the Slave Trade Act 1807, although slavery remained legal in areas outside Europe until the passage of the Abolitionist Slavery Act 1833 and the Indian Slavery Act 1843.

However, as the British began to have colonies in America, and particularly from the 1640s, African slaves began to appear in England and remained in existence until the eighteenth century. In Scotland, slaves continued to be sold as movables until the late eighteenth century (on 2 May 1722, an advertisement appeared in the Edinburgh Evening Courant announcing that a stolen slave had been found and would be sold to pay a fee, unless claimed within two weeks). For nearly two hundred years of the history of coal mining in Scotland, miners were bound to their "masters" by the Act 1606 "Anent Coalyers and Salters". The Colliers and Salters (Scotland) Act 1775 declared "many coal miners and salt merchants in the practice of slavery" and proclaimed emancipation; those who started work after July 1, 1775 would not become slaves, while those who were already in a state of slavery, after 7 or 10 years, depending on their age, could apply for a Sheriff's Court decree granting their freedom. Few slaves could apply for a Sheriff's Court edict. This situation continued until the 1799 law established their freedom and made this slavery illegal. The Byzantine-Ottoman wars and the Ottoman wars in Europe brought large numbers of slaves to the Islamic world. To manage its bureaucracy, the Ottoman Empire created an elite army of janissaries whose job was to arrest hundreds of thousands of Christian boys through the devşirme system. These children were well cared for but legally were slaves owned by the government and were not allowed to marry. They are never bought or sold. The Sultanate assigned them a large administrative and military role. This system started around 1365; and ended in 1826, leaving 135,000 janissaries.

After the Battle of Lepanto, 12,000 Christian galley slaves were recaptured and released from the Ottoman fleet. During this time, Eastern Europe experienced a series of Tatar invasions, the purpose of which was to pillage and capture people to be sold as slaves to the Ottoman Empire. Seventy-five Crimean Tatar raids were recorded in Poland–Lithuania between 1474 and 1569. Slavery in Poland was outlawed in the 15th century; in Lithuania, serfdom was formally abolished in 1588; but then there is peasant serfdom. Medieval Spain and Portugal were the scene of almost continuous Muslim invasions of predominantly Christian areas. Periodic raiding expeditions were sent from Al-Andalus to destroy the Christian kingdom of Iberia. These expeditions then brought back booty and slaves. In the attack on Lisbon in 1189, for example, the Almohad caliph Yaqub al-Mansur took 3,000 captive women and children, while his governor of Córdoba, in a subsequent raid on Silves, Portugal, in 1191, took 3,000 Christian slaves. From the 11th to the 19th centuries, North African Barbarian Pirates engaged in ghazi and raided European coastal cities to capture Christian slaves who were then sold in slave markets in places such as Algeria and Morocco. The maritime city of Lagos was the first slave market created in Portugal (one of America's earliest colonizers) for the sale of imported African slaves – Mercado de Escravos, opened in 1444. In 1441, the first slaves were brought to Portugal from northern Mauritania. In 1552, 10% of Lisbon's population were black African slaves. In the second half of the 16th century, the King relinquished his monopoly on the slave trade, and the focus of the African slave trade shifted from importation into Europe to the direct transportation of slaves to the tropical colonies of the Americas.

– especially Brazil. In the 15th century a third of slaves were sold back to African markets in exchange for gold. In Kievan and Moscow Rus', serfs were usually classified as serf farmers. According to David P. Forsythe, "By 1649 up to three-quarters of Muscovy peasants, or 13 to 14 million people, were serfs whose material life was almost indistinguishable from that of slaves. Perhaps another 1.5 million were legally enslaved, with Russian slaves serving Russian masters ." Slavery remained an important practice in Russia until 1723, when Peter the Great turned domestic slaves into domestic servants. Russian agricultural slaves were formally converted to farm laborers as early as 1679. In Scandinavia, thralls were abolished in the mid-14th century. In the early 1960s, Saudi Arabia's slave population was estimated at 300,000. Together with Yemen, Saudi Arabia only abolished slavery in 1962. Historically, slaves in the Arab World came from various regions, including Sub-Saharan Africa (especially Zanj), the Caucasus (especially Circassia), Central Asia (especially Tartar), and Europe Middle and East (especially Saqaliba Slavs]). Some historians claim that as many as 17 million people were sold into slavery on the coasts of the Indian Ocean, the Middle East and North Africa, and about 5 million African slaves were bought by Muslim traders and brought from Africa across the Red Sea, Indian Ocean and the Sahara desert between 1500 and 1900. The captives were sold throughout the Middle East. This trade increased as sophisticated ships enabled increased trading activity and a greater demand for labor on plantations in the region. It is estimated that tens of thousands of captives are taken every year. The Indian Ocean slave trade was multidirectional and changed over time.

To meet the demand for manual labor, Bantu slaves purchased by east African slave traders from southeast Africa were sold in cumulative large quantities over the centuries to buyers in Egypt, Arabia, the Persian Gulf, India, European colonies in the Far East, Indian Ocean islands. , Ethiopia and Somalia. According to the Encyclopedia of African History, "It is estimated that in the 1890s the world's largest population of slaves, some 2 million people, was concentrated in the territory of the Sokoto Caliphate. There the use of slave labor was very common, especially in agriculture." The Anti-Slavery Society estimates there were 2 million slaves in Ethiopia in the early 1930s out of an estimated population of between 8 and 16 million. Slave labor in East Africa was drawn from the Zanj, Bantu people who lived along the East African coast. The Zanj were for centuries sent as slaves by Arab traders to all countries bordering the Indian Ocean. The Umayyad and Abbasid caliphs recruited many Zanj slaves as soldiers and, in early 696, there was a rebellion of Zanj slaves against their Arab masters in Iraq. The Zanj Rebellions, a series of uprisings that took place between 869 and 883 near Basra (also known as Basara), located in present-day Iraq, are believed to have involved enslaved Zanj who were originally captured from the African Great Lakes region and areas further south in East Africa. This rebellion then involved more than 500,000 slaves and freemen imported from across the Muslim empire and claimed more than "tens of thousands of lives in southern Iraq". Zanj brought as slaves to the Middle East were often used in hard agricultural work. As the plantation economy boomed and the Arabs became wealthier, farming and other manual labor was seen as degrading work.

The resulting labor shortage caused the slave market to increase. In Algiers, the capital of Algeria, captured Christians and Europeans were forced into slavery. Around 1650, there were as many as 35,000 Christian slaves in Algiers. According to one observation, piracy by Barbary pirates in coastal villages and ships stretching from Italy to Iceland, is estimated to have enslaved 1 to 1.25 million Europeans between the 16th and 19th centuries. However, this estimate is the result of extrapolation assuming that the number of European slaves captured by Barbary pirates was constant over a 250 year period: There are no records of how many men, women and children were enslaved, but it may have been possible with roughly calculating the number of new captives needed to keep the population stable and replace slaves who died, fled, ransomed, or converted to Islam. On this basis it has been estimated that some 8,500 new slaves were needed each year to increase the number - some 850,000 captives from 1580 to 1680. By extension, during the 250 years between 1530 and 1780, the figure could easily have reached as high as 1,250,000. Davis's estimate has been disputed by other historians, such as David Earle, who say that the true picture of European slaves is clouded by the fact that corsairs also confiscated white non-Christians from eastern Europe. In addition, the number of slaves traded was hyperactive, with overestimates relying on peak years to calculate the average over centuries, or millennia. There is therefore wide fluctuation from year to year, particularly in the 18th and 19th centuries, given the import of slaves, and also given the fact that, prior to the 1840s, there are no consistent records.

Middle East expert John Wright says modern estimates are based on recalculations from human observations. Such observations, in the late 16th and early 17th centuries, include some 35,000 European Christian slaves held during this period on the Barbary Coast, across Tripoli, Tunis, but mostly in Algiers. The majority were sailors (mainly British), brought in on their boats, but others were fishermen and residents of coastal villages. However, most of these captives were people from countries close to Africa, especially Spain and Italy. This eventually led to the bombing of Algiers by an Anglo-Dutch fleet in 1816. Under the Omani Arabs, Zanzibar became East Africa's principal slave port, with as many as 50,000 enslaved Africans passing through it annually during the 19th century. Some historians estimate that between 11 and 18 million African slaves crossed the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, and the Sahara Desert from AD 650 to 1900. Eduard Rüppell describes the disappearance of Sudanese slaves transported by foot to Egypt: "after the Registered bey campaign of 1822 in mountains of the southern Nuba, almost 40,000 slaves were captured. Despite mistreatment, disease and traveling through the desert, almost 5,000 people made it to Egypt." WA Veenhoven wrote: "The German doctor, Gustav Nachtigal, an eyewitness, believed that for every slaves who arrived at the market three or four died en route . . . Keltie (The Partition of Africa, London, 1920) believed that for every slave the Arabs brought to the coast, at least six died en route to or during the slavers' stampede. Livingstone puts the figure as high as ten to one."

Systems of servitude and slavery were common in parts of Africa, as they were in much of the ancient world. In many African societies that practiced slavery, enslaved people were not treated as commodity slaves and were granted certain rights in a system similar to indentured slavery elsewhere in the world. Forms of slavery in Africa are also related to kinship structures. In many African communities, individual slavery was used as a means of increasing one's influence and broadening one's connections. This made slaves a permanent part of their master's lineage and the children of slaves could be closely related to the larger family ties. Children of slaves born into families could be integrated into their master's kinship group and rise to prominent positions in society, even to the level of chiefs in some cases. However, stigma often persisted and there may have been a strict separation between slave members of the kinship group and those related to their masters. Slavery was practiced in many forms: debt bondage, prisoner-of-war slavery, military slavery, and criminal slavery, all of which were practiced in various parts of Africa. Slavery for domestic and court purposes was widespread throughout Africa. When the Atlantic slave trade began, many local slave systems began supplying captives to slave markets for goods outside Africa. Although the Atlantic slave trade was not the only trade in slaves from Africa, it was the largest in volume and intensity. As Elikia M'bokolo wrote in Le Monde diplomaticique: The continent of Africa is running out of human resources by all possible routes. The route passed is across the Sahara, through the Red Sea, from the ports of the Indian Ocean and across the Atlantic Ocean.

Slavery was carried out for at least ten centuries on behalf of Muslim countries (from the ninth to the nineteenth century).... Four million enslaved people were exported via the Red Sea, another four million via Swahili ports in the Indian Ocean. Approximately nine million people along the trans-Saharan caravan route, and eleven to twenty million across the Atlantic Ocean. The trans-Atlantic slave trade reached its apogee in the late 18th century, when the largest number of slaves were captured on raiding expeditions into the interior of West Africa. These expeditions were usually carried out by African kingdoms, such as the Oyo (Yoruba) Empire, the Ashanti Empire, the Dahomey kingdom, and the Aro Confederation. It is estimated that about 15 percent of those captured died during the voyage, with mortality rates much higher in Africa itself, especially in the process of capturing and transporting Africans to ships. Slavery in America remains a contentious issue and played a key role in the history and evolution of several nations leading to revolutions, civil wars, and various uprisings. To establish itself as an American empire, Spain had to fight a relatively powerful New World civilization. The Spanish conquest of indigenous peoples in America included using indigenous people to do forced labor. The Spanish colonists were the first Europeans to use African slaves in the New World on islands such as Cuba and Hispaniola. Bartolomé de las Casas, a 16th-century Dominican monk and Spanish historian, participated in the campaign in Cuba (in Bayamo and Camagüey) and was present at the Hatuey massacre; his observations of the massacre led him to champion a social movement that would no longer use indigenous people as slaves. Additionally, the alarming decline in the indigenous population has prompted the first royal laws protecting natives.

The first African slaves arrived on Hispaniola in 1501. England played an important role in the Atlantic slave trade. The "slave triangle" was pioneered by Francis Drake and his associates. Many whites who arrived in North America during the 17th and 18th centuries were contracted as indentured servants. The transformation from indentured servitude to slavery was a gradual process in Virginia. The earliest legal documentation of such a shift dates back to 1640, when a negro, John Punch, was sentenced to lifelong servitude and forced to serve his master, Hugh Gwyn, for the rest of his life, for attempting to escape. This case is significant because it shows the difference between the punishment of a black man and the two white indentured servants who fled with him (one described as Dutch and one as Scottish). This was the first documented case of a black man being sentenced to life in prison and is considered one of the first legal cases to make a racial distinction between black and white indentured employees. After 1640, plantation owners began to ignore the expiration of their servants' contracts and kept them as slaves for life. This was shown in the 1655 case of Johnson v. Parker. In this case, the court ruled that one black man, Anthony Johnson of Virginia, was granted possession of another black man, John Casor, as a result of a civil case. This case was the first instance of a court ruling in the Thirteen Colonies stipulating that a person who had not committed a crime could be held as a slave for life. In the early 17th century, most of the labor in Barbados was provided by European indentured servants, primarily English, Irish and Scottish, with African slaves and Amerindian slaves providing some of the labour.

The introduction of sugar cane from the Brazilian Dutch in 1640 completely changed society and the economy. Barbados then had one of the world's largest sugar industries. As yields from new crops increased, so did a shift in the ethnic composition of Barbados and the surrounding islands. A workable sugar plantation required a large investment and a lot of heavy labour. Initially, Dutch traders supplied equipment, financing, and enslaved Africans, as well as transporting most of the sugar to Europe. In 1644, the population of Barbados was estimated at 30,000, and about 800 people were of African descent, with the remainder being of English descent. These small British farmers were eventually bought out, and the island was made into a large sugar plantation worked by enslaved Africans. In 1660, there were nearly 27,000 blacks and 26,000 whites who were enslaved. By 1666, at least 12,000 white farmers had been bought out, died, or left the island. Many of the white people who remained became increasingly poor. In 1680, there were 17 slaves for each indentured servant. In 1700, 15,000 enslaved whites became free and 50,000 Africans who remained enslaved. Due to the introduction of slave laws, which created differential treatment between Africans and the white working and plantation-owning classes, the island became less and less attractive to poor white people. Slave laws were implemented in 1661, 1676, 1682, and 1688. These slave laws led to several planned slave revolts, but none were successful. However, poor whites who owned or obtained the means to emigrate chose to leave the area. Plantation owners increased their purchases of enslaved Africans to grow sugar cane.

Slavery in Brazil had begun long before the start of Portuguese colonization in 1532, with members of one tribe usually being captured and enslaved by another. When the Portuguese colonizers entered, they relied heavily on native labor during the early phases of colonization to maintain a subsistence economy, and the natives were often captured by expeditions called bandeiras. The import of African slaves began in the mid-16th century, but the enslavement of indigenous people continued into the 17th and 18th centuries. During the era of the Atlantic slave trade, Brazil imported more African slaves than any other country. Nearly 5 million slaves were brought from Africa to Brazil during the period 1501 to 1866. Until the early 1850s, most enslaved Africans arriving on the coast of Brazil were forced to depart from West Central African ports, mainly in Luanda (now Angola). Today, with the exception of Nigeria, the country with the largest population of people of African descent is Brazil. Slave labor was the driving force behind the growth of Brazil's sugar economy, and sugar was the colony's main export from 1600 to 1650. Gold and diamond deposits were discovered in Brazil in 1690, which then fueled increased imports of African slaves to fuel new markets that this profitable. A transportation system was developed for the mining infrastructure, and the population soared with the arrival of immigrants who wanted to take part in the mining of gold and diamonds. The demand for African slaves did not diminish after the decline of the mining industry in the second half of the 18th century. Cattle farming and food production developed after population growth, both of which depended heavily on slave labor. 1.7 million slaves were imported into Brazil from Africa from 1700 to 1800, and the rise of the coffee industry in the 1830s further fueled the expansion of the slave trade.

Brazil is the last country in the Western world to abolish slavery. Forty percent of the total number of slaves brought to America went to Brazil. By comparison, the United States received about 10 percent of the total number of slaves. Despite being abolished, there are still people working in slavery-like conditions in Brazil in the 21st century. In 1789, the Kingdom of Spain began efforts to reform slavery as the demand for slave labor in Cuba grew. The king issued an edict, Código Negro Español (Spanish Black Codex), which established provisions for food and clothing, limited the number of hours worked, limited punishments, required religious instruction, protected marriages, and prohibited the sale of children away from their mothers. The British made other changes to the institution of slavery in Cuba. But industrial plantation owners often break the law and protest against it. They perceive these restrictions as a threat to their authority and interfere with their private lives. The slave owners did not protest all the rules in the Codex because many of the rules in it they felt were common practice. They object to attempts to limit their ability to apply corporal punishment. For example, the Black Codex limits canings to 25 and requires canings "not cause serious bruising or bleeding." Slave owners assumed that slaves would interpret these restrictions as a weakness of the slavery system, which would eventually lead to resistance. Another contentious issue was the limited hours of work "from sunrise to sunset"; The plantation owners responded by saying that the cutting and processing of the cane required 20 hours a day during the harvest season. The slaves who worked on the sugar plantations and in the sugar factories often experienced the harshest conditions.

Field work was rigorous manual labor that slaves started at an early age. The working day lasts nearly 20 hours during the harvest and processing period, which includes cultivating and cutting crops, hauling carts, and processing cane with dangerous machinery. The slaves were forced to live in baracons, where they were forced in and locked by padlocks. At night, they sleep for about three to four hours. The conditions for the baracons are very harsh, very unhealthy and very hot. Usually the place has no ventilation; the only window is a small barred hole in the wall. The Cuban slavery system was based on gender so some tasks were performed only by male slaves, some only by female slaves. Slave women in Havana from the 16th century onwards performed tasks such as operating the city's taverns, restaurants, and inns, as well as being laundresses and domestic workers and servants. Slaves also served as city prostitutes. Some Cuban women were able to find freedom by having children with white men. As in other Latin cultures, there are looser boundaries with mulatto or mixed-race populations. Sometimes men who took slaves as wives or concubines freed them and their children. As in New Orleans and Saint-Domingue, mulattoes began to be classified as a third group between European colonizers and African slaves. Freed people, mostly of mixed race, represent 20% of the total Cuban population and 41% of the non-white Cuban population. The orchard owners asked the Afro-Cuban slaves to have children to reproduce their labour. These slave owners also wanted to pair a strong, large black man with a healthy black woman.

They were placed in barracks and forced to have sex and create offspring from “cattle” cubs, which would sell for around 500 pesos. The planters needed children to be born to replace the slaves who died under the harsh system of slavery. Sometimes if the overseers didn't like the quality of the children, they separated the children from their parents and sent the mothers back to work in the fields. Both women and men were subjected to violent punishment and degrading harassment. Slaves who misbehaved or disobeyed their masters were often placed in storerooms deep in the boiler house, where they were left for days, and often two to three months. These boiler rooms are made in two types: reclining or standing type. In those days, women were punished, even when pregnant. They were subjected to the whip: they had to lie "face down on the ground] which had been dug up to protect their bellies." Some slave owners reportedly whipped pregnant women on their stomachs, so that they often had miscarriages. Their injuries were treated with "tobacco leaf compresses, urine and salt." Slavery in Haiti began with the arrival of Christopher Columbus on the island in 1492. The practice of slavery was very damaging for the natives. Following the dwindling of the native Taíno population through forced labor, plague and war, the Spaniards, under the advice of the Catholic priest Bartolomeu de las Casas, and with the blessing of the Catholic church began to engage in serious kidnapping and forced labor of African slaves. During the French colonial period beginning in 1625, the economy of Haiti (then known as Saint-Domingue) was based on slavery, and the practice of slavery there was considered some of the most brutal in the world.

After the Treaty of Ryswick in 1697, Hispaniola was divided between France and Spain. France received the western third and later named it Saint-Domingue. To develop it into sugarcane plantations, France imported thousands of slaves from Africa. Sugar was a profitable commodity crop throughout the 18th century. In 1789, about 40,000 white colonists lived in Saint-Domingue. Whites were outnumbered by the tens of thousands of African slaves they imported to work their plantations, which were primarily intended for sugarcane production. In the north of the island, slaves were able to maintain many ties to African culture, religion and language; these ties were continually renewed by newly imported Africans. Blacks outnumbered whites by about ten to one. The French Code Noir ("Black Code"), prepared by Jean-Baptiste Colbert and ratified by Louis XIV, laid down rules regarding the treatment of slaves and the freedoms allowed. Saint-Domingue has been described as one of the most efficient and brutal slave colonies; a third of newly imported Africans died within a few years. Many slaves died from diseases such as smallpox and typhoid fever. They have a birth rate of about 3 percent, and there is evidence that some women abort fetuses, or commit infanticide, rather than letting their children live in slavery. Slaves who made it to Haiti from trans-Atlantic voyages and slaves born in Haiti were documented in Haitian archives and transferred to the French Ministry of Defense and Ministry of Foreign Affairs. As of 2015update], these records are in the French National Archives. According to the 1788 Census, Haiti's population consisted of nearly 40,000 white people, 30,000 free people of color, and 450,000 slaves.

The Haitian Revolution of 1804, was the only successful slave revolt in human history and hastened the end of slavery in all French colonies. This rebellion made Haiti the first country to permanently outlaw slavery. Jamaica was colonized by the Taino before the arrival of Columbus in 1494. The Spaniards who arrived later enslaved many of the Taino people; some fled, but most died of plague from Europe and from overwork. The Spaniards also introduced the first African slaves. The Spanish conquistadors did not take women with them on their first expeditions. They took Taíno women as their wives, who then produced mestizo children. Sexual violence against Taíno women by Spaniards was also common. Although the slave population of Africa in the 1670s and 1680s never exceeded 10,000, by 1800 it had risen to over 300,000. In 1519, Hernán Cortés brought the first modern slaves to the area. In the mid-16th century, Mexico's second viceroy, Luis de Velasco, outlawed Aztec slavery. The shortage of manpower occurred because the Aztecs were killed or died from epidemics. This led to African slaves being brought in, as they were not susceptible to smallpox. In return, many Africans were given the opportunity to buy their freedom, while others were eventually granted freedom by their masters. When Ponce de León and the Spaniards arrived on the island of Borikén (Puerto Rico), they enslaved the island's Taíno tribe and forced them to work in the gold mines and in the construction of forts. Many Taíno people died, mainly from smallpox, because they had no immunity to it. Other Taínos committed suicide or left the island after the failed Taíno uprising in 1511.

The Spanish colonists, fearful of losing their workforce, complained to the courts that they needed labor. As an alternative, Las Casas suggested the import and use of African slaves. In 1517, the Kingdom of Spain allowed its subjects to import twelve slaves each, and because of this, started the slave trade in the colony. African slaves were legally branded with hot irons on their foreheads to prevent their "theft" or lawsuits challenging their captivity. Colonizers continued this branding practice for more than 250 years. They were sent to work in the gold mines, or in the ginger and sugar fields on the island. They were allowed to live with their families in a hut on their master's land, and were given plots of land so they could farm, but they were also subjected to harsh treatment; including sexual harassment because the majority of colonists came without women; many of them married Africans or Taínos. Their mixed-race descendants formed the first generation of the early Puerto Rican population. The slaves faced severe discrimination and had no opportunity to advance themselves, even though they were educated by their masters. The Spanish considered the Africans superior to the Taínos, because the Taino did not want to assimilate. In contrast, the slaves had little choice but to adapt. Many converted to Christianity and were given the surnames of their masters. In 1570, the colonists learned that the gold mines had been exhausted, thus demoting the island's status to that of a garrison for passing ships. The cultivation of crops such as tobacco, cotton, cocoa and ginger is the basis of its economy. With increasing demand for sugar on the international market, large plantations are increasing their labor-intensive cultivation and processing of sugarcane.

Sugar plantations replaced mining as Puerto Rico's main industry and kept the demand for African slavery high. After 1784, Spain provided five ways for slaves to gain freedom. Five years later, the King of Spain issued the "Royal Decree of 1789", which established new rules regarding the slave trade and added restrictions on granting freedman status. The decree gave its subjects the right to buy slaves and to participate in the thriving slave trade in the Caribbean region. In the same year, a new slave law, also known as El Código Negro (Black Man's Law), was adopted. Under "El Código Negro", a slave could buy his freedom, if his master was willing to sell, by paying the asking price in installments. Slaves were allowed to earn money during their free time by working as shoemakers, cleaning clothes, or selling the produce they grew on their own land. For the freedom of their unbaptized newborn child, they pay half the price for a baptized child. Many of these freed people then began to settle in the areas that became known as Cangrejos (Santurce), Carolina, Canóvanas, Loíza, and Luquillo. Some of them became slave owners. Despite this path to freedom, from 1790 onwards, the number of slaves more than doubled in Puerto Rico as a result of the dramatic expansion of the island's sugar industry. On March 22, 1873, slavery was legally abolished in Puerto Rico. However, the slaves there were not freed, but had to buy their own freedom at whatever price their final master set.

Anti-slavery treaties were signed by more than 50 African rulers. In 1839, the world's oldest international human rights organization, Anti-Slavery International, was formed in England by Joseph Sturge, who campaigned to outlaw slavery in other countries. In 2007, there was a celebration to mark 200 years of the abolition of the British slave trade through the works of the British Anti-Slavery Society. In the 1860s, David Livingstone's accounts of the atrocities in the Arab slave trade in Africa caught the attention of the British public and revived the flagging abolitionist movement. The Royal Navy throughout the 1870s attempted to suppress "this abominable Eastern trade", particularly in Zanzibar. In 1905, France abolished indigenous slavery throughout most of French West Africa. On December 10, 1948, the United Nations General Assembly adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which stated that freedom from slavery is an internationally recognized human right. Article 4 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states: No one shall be enslaved; slavery and the slave trade must be outlawed in all its forms. In 2014, for the first time in history, great leaders from many religions, Buddhist, Hindu, Christian, Jewish and Muslim met to sign their joint commitment against modern slavery. The declaration they signed called for the abolition of slavery and human trafficking by 2020. The signatories included: Pope Francis, Mātā Amṛtānandamayī, Bhikkhuni Thich Nu Chân Không (representing Zen Master Thích Nhất Hạnh), Datuk K Sri Dhammaratana, Chief High Priest of Malaysia, Rabbi Abraham Skorka, Rabbi David Rosen, Abbas Abdalla Abbas Solimary, Deputy Secretary of State of Al Azhar Alsharif (representing Mohamed Ahmed El-Tayeb, Grand Imam of Al-Azhar), Grand Ayatollah Mohammad Taqi al-Modarresi, Sheikh Naziyah Razzaq Jaafar, Special Counsel Grand Ayatollah (representing Grand Ayatollah Sheikh Basheer Hussain al Najafi), Sheikh Omar Abboud, Justin Welby, Archbishop of Canterbury, and Metropolitan Emmanuel of France (representing Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew).

Groups such as the American Anti-Slavery Group, Anti-Slavery International, Free the Slaves, Anti-Slavery Society, and the Norwegian Anti-Slavery Society continue to campaign to abolish slavery. On May 21, 2001, the French National Assembly passed the Taubira law, which declared slavery a crime against humanity. Apologies on behalf of African nations, for their role in trafficking their nationals into slavery, remain an open issue because slavery was practiced in Africa even before the first Europeans arrived and the Atlantic slave trade was carried out with a high degree of complicity on the part of some societies. Africa. The black slave market was supplied by established slave trading networks controlled by local communities and individuals in Africa. There is ample evidence citing case after case of African control of segments of the slave trade. Several African countries such as Calabar and other parts of southern Nigeria have economies that depend solely on this trade. Africans such as Imbangala from Angola and Nyamwezi from Tanzania became intermediaries or itinerant groups that fought with other African countries to seize Africans destined for Europeans. Several historians have made important contributions to the global understanding of the African side of the Atlantic slave trade. Arguing that African traders determined the pool of trade goods received in exchange for slaves, many historians argue that African agents were ultimately responsible for the slave trade. In 1999, President Mathieu Kérékou of Benin issued a national apology for the central role Africans played in the Atlantic slave trade. Luc Gnacadja, minister of environment and housing for Benin, later said: "The slave trade is a shame, and we regret it." Researchers estimate that 3 million slaves were exported out of the Slave Coast which borders the Bay of Benin.

President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana also apologized for his country's involvement in the slave trade. The issue of apology related to reparations for slavery and is still being pursued by many entities around the world. For example, the Jamaican Reparations Movement approved its declaration and plan of action. In 2007, British Prime Minister Tony Blair made a formal apology for Britain's involvement in slavery. On February 25, 2007, the Commonwealth of Virginia expressed "deep regret" and apologized for its role in the institution of slavery. In a US first, the apology passed unanimously in both houses of parliament as Virginia nears the 400th anniversary of the founding of Jamestown. On 24 August 2007, Mayor Ken Livingstone of London publicly apologized for Britain's role in the colonial slave trade. "You can look across there to see the institutions that are still benefiting from the wealth they created from slavery," he said, gesturing to the financial district. He claimed that London was still tainted by the horrors of slavery. In particular, London outfitted, financed and insured many of the ships, which helped finance the construction of the London wharves. Officials in Liverpool, the city that was once a major slave trading port, apologized in 1999. On July 30, 2008, the United States House of Representatives passed a resolution expressing an apology for American slavery and the discriminatory laws that followed. In June 2009, the US Senate passed a resolution apologizing to African Americans for "fundamental injustice, cruelty, brutality and inhuman slavery". The news was welcomed by President Barack Obama, the first president who is of African descent. Some of President Obama's ancestors may have been slave owners.

The Tigris River (Old Persian: Tigr, Assyrian Aramaic: Deqlath, Arabic: دجلة, Dijla, Turkish: Dicle; in the Bible as Hiddekel) is a river in Mesopotamia that flows from the mountains Anatolia in Turkey through Iraq and empties into the Persian Gulf, about 1,900 km long. Together the river Euphrates characterizes the area of ​​Mesopotamia. The length of the Tigris river is 1,850 km, emerging from the Taurus Mountains in eastern Turkey about 25 km southeast of the city of Elazig and about 30 km from the sources of the Euphrates river. This river then flows 400 km through Turkish territory before becoming the border between Syria and Turkey. This 44 km long section alone is located in Syria. The remaining 1,418 km is entirely within Iraqi territory. The Tigris joins the Euphrates near Basra, and from this union to the Persian Gulf this mass of water is known as the Shatt-al-Arab. According to Pliny the Elder and other ancient historians, the Euphrates river originally opened into the sea separate from the Tigris. Baghdad, the capital of Iraq, is located on the banks of the Tigris river. The city port of Basra is in the Shatt al-Arab. In ancient times, many of the great cities of Mesopotamia stood on or near the Tigris, drawing water from it to irrigate Sumerian settlements. Notable cities include Nineveh, Ctesiphon, and Seleucia (Seleucia on the Tigris), while the city of Lagash is watered by the Tigris via a canal dug around 2400 BC. The ancient Greek form of Tigris is borrowed from the old Persian Tigrā, which is taken from the Elamite ti-ig-ra, which is derived from the Sumerian idigna. Names of the river Tigris in the languages ​​important in this area: ἡ, ὁ Τίγρις, -ιδος , hē, ho Tígris, -idos The name of the river Tigris appears twice in the Hebrew Bible and the Old Testament of the Christian Bible.

Editor page out log learn more Aztecs were a Mesoamerican civilization that flourished in central Mexico during the Postclassic period from 1300 to 1521 AD. Aztec society consisted of various ethnic groups that inhabited central Mexico, especially the Nahuatl-speaking peoples who inhabited most of Mesoamerica from the 14th to the 16th centuries. The Aztec civilization gave birth to a number of city-states (altepetl). Some of these combined to form alliances, political confederations, even empires. The Aztec Empire was a confederation of three city-states formed in 1427, namely Tenochtitlan (the city-state of the Mexica or Tenochca people), Texcoco, and Tlacopan. The city-state of Tlacopan was formerly part of the Tepanek Empire centered on the city-state of Azcapotzalco. Although often used as a specific designation for the Tenochtitlan Mexica, the term Aztec was also used as a general term for the city-states and Nahua peoples of central Mexico during pre-Spanish times as well as during the Spanish colonial period (1521–1821). The definition of Aztecs and Aztecs has long been a topic of scientific discussion since the German scientist, Alexander von Humboldt, made use of it common in the early 19th century.
