Most of the peoples of central Mexico in the Postclassic period shared basic Mesoamerican cultural features, and a large number of Aztec cultural characteristics cannot simply be called unique to the Aztecs. For the same reason, the notion of "Aztec civilization" is best understood as one of the special scopes of the general civilization of Mesoamerica. The civilization of central Mexico includes the cultivation of maize, the division of society into aristocrats (pipiltin) and commoners (macehualtin), the worship of many gods (Tezcatlipoca, Tlaloc, and Quetzalcoatl), and the xiuhpohualli calendar (365 day calendar) which is inserted by the system the tonalpohualli calendar (260 day calendar).

What is distinctive about the Mexica people of Tenochtitlan is their patron deity named Huitzilopochtli, the twin pyramids, and pottery known as Aztecs I through IV. Since the 13th century, the Valley of Mexico has been the center of a dense population and a center for the growth of city-states. The Mexica came later to the Valley of Mexico, and founded the city-state of Tenochtitlan on the arid islets of Lake Texcoco, but later became the most powerful people in the Aztec Empire. It was a tributary empire that extended its political hegemony far beyond the Valley of Mexico by subjugating other city-states throughout Mesoamerica in the late Postclassic. The Aztec Empire was formed in 1427 as a union of the city-states of Tenochtitlan, the city-states of Texcoco, and the city-states of Tlacopan. These three city-states allied to defeat the Tepanek people from the city-state of Azcapotzalco who controlled the Valley of Mexico. Shortly thereafter, Texcoco and Tlacopan were demoted to junior partners in the alliance, and Tenochtitlan became the most powerful. The empire expanded its reach by combining commerce and military conquest. The Aztec Empire was not a territorial empire that controlled a region by placing large military garrisons in conquered provinces, but an empire that ruled over its vassal city-states by cultivating friendship with its subordinate rulers through marriages between the ruling dynasties. and by means of spreading the ideology of the empire to its vassal city-states. The vassal city-states were obliged to pay tribute to the Aztec Emperor, who was titled Huey Tlatoani as an economic ploy to limit communication and commerce between the surrounding countries which forced these countries to depend on the center for luxury goods.

This mandala of imperial power extended as far south as Mesoamerica through the conquest of city-states as far south as Chiapas and Guatemala, and covered Mesoamerica from the coast of the Pacific Ocean to the coast of the Atlantic Ocean. The size of the Aztec Empire's mandala reached its peak in 1519, before the arrival of a small group of Spanish conquistadores under Hernán Cortés. Hernán Cortés allied with city-states opposed to the Mexica, particularly Nahuatl speakers from the city-state of Tlaxcalteca as well as other city-states in the Valley of Mexico, including Texcoco, a former Mexic ally in the Alliance of the Three Peoples. After Tenochtitlan fell on August 13, 1521, and Emperor Cuauhtemoc was captured, the Spanish founded Mexico City on the ruins of Tenochtitlan. From Mexico City, the Spanish launched an effort to conquer and incorporate Mesoamerican tribes into the Spanish Empire. With the collapse of the Aztec Empire in 1521, the Spanish empowered the city-states of the former Aztec Empire to rule native peoples through their own nobility. These native nobles swore allegiance to the King of Spain and converted to Christianity, at least nominally, in order to gain recognition as royalty from the King of Spain. The nobles acted as intermediaries to convey tribute and mobilize labor on behalf of their new masters, thus making possible the establishment of the Spanish colonial government. Much is known about Aztec culture and history from archaeological evidence found in excavations such as the famous Templo Mayor excavations in Mexico City, from native writings, eyewitness accounts of Spanish conquistadores such as Hernán Cortés and Bernal. Díaz del Castillo, and in particular of the commentaries on Aztec culture and history compiled in the 16th and 17th centuries by Spanish clergy and Aztec scholars in both Spanish and Nahuatl, for example the famous Florentine Codex.

The Florentine Codex is a collection of twelve bilingual (Spanish and Nahuatl) written works with illustrations compiled by a Franciscan friar named Bernardino de Sahagún with native Aztec sources. An important contribution to knowledge about the Nahua people after the Spanish conquest was the training of native scribes to write texts in the Latin script in Nahuatl, especially for local needs during the Spanish colonial period. At its heyday, the Aztec civilization had a rich and complex repertoire of mythological and religious traditions, and produced outstanding works of architecture and fine art. The words aztecatl asˈtekat͡ɬ] (singular) and aztecah asˈtekaʔ] (plural) mean "people of Aztlan", which is the mythical place of origin for several ethnic groups living in central Mexico. This term was not previously used as an endonym by the Aztecs themselves, but is found in various Migration histories of the Mexica that tell of tribes leaving Aztlan together. In one of the histories of these wanderings leaving Aztlan it is said that the patron god of the Mexica tribe, Huitzilopochtli, said to his followers in the wandering that "now your name is no longer Azteca, you are now called Mexitin (Mexica)". Today the term "Aztec" is often used as a specific designation for the Mexica people of Tenochtitlan (where present-day Mexico City is located) which was located on an island in Lake Texcoco. The Mexica Tenochtitlan people themselves call themselves Mēxihcah (Nahuatl pronunciation: meːˈʃiʔkaʔ], a tribal title also used by the people of Tlatelolco), Tenochcah (Nahuatl pronunciation: teˈnot͡ʃkaʔ], a special designation for the Mexica of Tenochtitlan, excluding the Mexica Tlatelolco) or Cōlhuah ( Nahuatl pronunciation: ˈkoːlwaʔ], a designation that refers to the nobility that forms the basis of kinship ties between them and the people of Culhuacan). Texcoco, and the Tepanek people of Tlacopan.

The Acolhua people, the Tepanek people, and the Mexica people are the tribes that make up the Aztec Tribal Alliance. This alliance ruled over a country that is now often called the "Aztec Empire". The use of the term "Aztec" as a designation for an empire centered in Tenochtitlan has been criticized by Robert H. Barlow who prefers to use the term "Culhua-Mexica", and by Pedro Carrasco who prefers to use the term "Empire of Tenochca". In his writings, Pedro Carrasco argues that "Aztec terms are useless in trying to understand the complex ethnicities of ancient Mexico and in trying to identify the dominant element in the political entity we are studying". In other contexts, the term "Aztec" can refer to all the city-states and their peoples, who share many historical and cultural similarities with the Mexica, Acolhua, and Tepanek people, and who often also use Nahuatl as the lingua franca. franca. One example is the use of the term "Aztec" in the book Law and Politics in Aztec Texcoco by Jerome A. Offner. In this sense, "Aztec civilization" can be taken to mean all the cultural patterns that were most prevalent among the peoples who inhabited central Mexico at the end of the Postclassic period. The term "Aztec" can also be expanded to include all groups in central Mexico that were included in the mandala of the Aztec Empire, both politically and culturally. nb 3] When used to describe an ethnic group, the term "Aztec" refers to people who spoke Nahuatl in central Mexico during the Postclassic period according to Mesoamerican chronology, specifically the Mexica, an ethnic group who had established a mandala centered in Tenochtitlan. The term can also refer to ethnic groups associated with the Aztec Empire, such as the Acolhua, Tepanek, and other groups within the empire.

Charles Gibson mentions the names of groups in central Mexico that are included in the scope of his study entitled The Aztecs Under Spanish Rule (1964). These groups include Culhuaque, Cuitlahuaque, Mixquica, Xochimilca, Chalca, Tepanek, Acolhuaque, and Mexica. In ancient times, the term generally applied to all ethnic groups that spoke Nahuatl, and the language was also previously called the "Aztec language". Based on modern terminology, this ethnic group is called the Nahua people. Meanwhile, in linguistics, the term "Aztec" is still used to refer to a branch of the Uto-Aztec language family (sometimes also called the Yuto-Nahua language family) which includes Nahuatl and its closest relatives, the Pochutec and Pipil languages. For the Aztecs, the term "Aztec" was not an endonym for any particular ethnic group. It is an umbrella term referring to several ethnic groups (and not all of them speaking Nahuatl) who claim descent from the Aztlan people. Alexander von Humboldt was credited with coining the modern use of the term "Aztec" in 1810, as a term referring to all peoples who shared trade, customs, religion, and language ties with the Mexica state and the Alliance of the Three Peoples. In 1843, following the publication of William H. Prescott's history of the conquest of Mexico, the term "Aztec" was used most frequently, including by 19th-century Mexican scholars who saw the term as a way of distinguishing modern Mexicans. with the Mexica people in pre-conquest times. The exact use of this term is still debated, but "Aztec" is still the most common term. The information available about the history of the Aztecs comes from a variety of sources. Archaeological remains (from pyramids to thatched huts) can be used to understand Aztec life.

However, archaeologists also need information from other sources to interpret the historical context of an artifact. There are many historical sources written by the natives as well as by the Spaniards at the beginning of the colonial period. These texts contain invaluable information about the history of the Aztecs in precolonial times. These sources show the political history of various Aztec city-states and the lineages of their rulers. In addition, Aztec history is presented in the codices. Some of them contain only images and often include glyphs. After the Spanish conquest, many other historical sources were written down in the Latin alphabet by literate Aztecs or by Spanish friars who interviewed the natives about their customs and stories. An alphabetic and pictorial text of significant historical origin is the Mendoza Codex from the early 16th century, named for the first Spanish regent of Mexico (and the codex itself may have also been commissioned by him). The codex was compiled to inform the Spanish monarchs about the economic and political structure of the Aztecs. The codex contains information about the names of the governing societies that were conquered by the Aztec Alliance of Three, the tributes paid to the Aztecs, and the class/gender structure of their society. In addition to the codex, there are also dates written by Nahua historians that record the history of the people under which they ruled. These dates are illustrated histories which are then converted into dates written in the Latin alphabet. Several chroniclers and chroniclers belonging to the indigenous population are Chimalpahin of Amecameca-Chalco; Fernando Alvarado Tezozomoc from Tenochtitlan; Alva Ixtlilxochitl from Texcoco, Juan Bautista Pomar from Texcoco, and Diego Muñoz Camargo from Tlaxcala.

There are also historical records compiled by conquistadores, such as Bernal Díaz del Castillo who wrote about the history of the conquest. The Spanish brothers also documented this in the form of chronicles and other historical records. One of the brothers who compiled important historical sources was Toribio de Benavente Motolinia, one of the first twelve Franciscan missionaries to arrive in Mexico in 1524. Another Franciscan who contributed to preserving Aztec history was Fray Juan de Torquemada, author of Monarquia Indiana . Diego Durán of the Dominican Order also wrote extensively on pre-conquest religion and Mexica history. In addition, the Florentine Codex is an invaluable historical resource on Aztec religion, politics, social structure, calendar, botany, zoology, commerce, and crafts in precolonial times. The codex also contains a history of the Spanish conquest from the Mexica point of view. The codex was compiled in 1545-1576 in the form of an ethnographic encyclopedia written in Spanish and Nahuatl by the Franciscan brother Bernardino de Sahagún and by native informants and scribes. Another source of information is the culture and customs of present-day Nahuatl speakers. Research on the Aztec civilization itself is often based on a multidisciplinary, scientific methodology, combining archaeological information with ethnohistory and ethnography. Scholars are still debating whether the city of Teotihuacan was inhabited by Nahuatl speakers, or whether the Nahua people had not yet arrived in central Mexico in the Classical period. In general, experts agree that the Nahua people were not native to the central Mexican Highlands, but that they gradually made their way to the region from northwestern Mexico. After the fall of Teotihuacan in the 6th century AD, several city-states arose in central Mexico.

Some of these (including Cholula and Xochicalco) may have been inhabited by speakers of Nahuatl. According to one study, the Nahua people originally inhabited the Bajío region. The population peaked in the 6th century, but then declined due to drought. The decline in the population of the Bajío coincided with the arrival of new groups in the Valley of Mexico, so it is possible that they were Nahuatl speakers who came to the area. During this process, they displaced speakers of the Oto-Manguean languages. The Nahua people who were originally a nomadic group of hunter-gatherers later mixed with civilizations in Mesoamerica and absorbed their religious and cultural practices, which later became the basis of the Aztec civilization. After 900 AD, in the Postclassic period, a number of cities inhabited by Nahuatl speakers had become powerful cities. Some of them are the cities of Tula in Hidalgo, Tenayuca and Colhuacan in the Valley of Mexico, and Cuauhnahuac in Morelos. The Mexica people have described the history of their arrival in the Valley of Mexico, as recorded in ethnohistorical sources from colonial times. The ethnonym Aztec (Nahuatl: Aztecah) means "a person from Aztlan". Aztlan is believed to be their northern origin. Therefore, this term applies to all people who declare themselves as descendants of people who come from that place. The story of the migration of the Mexica tells how they traveled with other tribes, including the Tlaxcalteca, Tepanek, and Acolhua, but in the end the god Huitzilopochtli ordered them to separate from the other Aztec tribes and take the name "Mexica". By the time they arrived, there were already many Aztec city-states in the region. Some of the most powerful of these are Colhuacan in the south and Azcapotzalco in the west. The Tepanek tribe of Azcapotzalco later expelled the Mexica from Chapultepec.

In 1299, a Colhuaca ruler named Cocoxtli allowed the Mexica to settle in the arid region of Tizapan. There, they assimilated into the Culhuaca culture. Colhuaca's royal lineage can be traced back to the legendary city-state of Tula. Through marriage to Colhua families, the Mexica could make the same claim. After briefly living in Colhuacan, the Mexica were again driven out and they were forced to wander. According to Aztec legend, in 1323, the Mexica saw the appearance of an eagle perched on a nopal cactus and eating a snake. This sighting fulfills the prophecy that they will establish a settlement of mema in that place. So the city of Tenochtitlan was founded on a small, swampy island in Lake Texcoco. 1325 is usually considered the founding year of the city. In 1376, the Mexica royal family was also founded after Acamapichtli (son of a Mexica father and Colhua mother) was elected the first Huey Tlatoani in the city of Tenochtitlan. Within 50 years of the founding of the first Mexica royal family, the rulers of the royal family submitted to Azcapotzalco and paid them tribute. Azcapotzalco itself had become a regional power during Tezozomoc's reign. Mexica helped send troops to aid Azcapotzalco in his wars of conquest, and in return Mexica received a portion of the tribute levied from defeated city-states. With this, Tenochtitlan's political and economic position began to develop. In 1396, after Acamapichtli's death, his son Huitzilihhuitl (Nahuatl: "hummingbird feather") came to power. He married Tezozomoc's daughter, as a result Tenochtitlan's relationship with Azcapotzalco remained close. Huitzilihhuitl's son Chimalpopoca became ruler of Tenochtitlan in 1417.

Then, in 1418, Azcapotzalco waged war against the Acolhua tribe in Texcoco and killed their ruler, Ixtlilxochitl. Even though Ixtlilxochitl was married to Chimalpopoca's daughter, Mexica continued to support Tezozomoc. Tezozomoc died in 1426, and his sons then fought for power. In the midst of this conflict, Chimalpopoca died; it is likely that he was killed by Tezozomoc's son, Maxtla, who saw him as a competitor. Itzcoatl, brother of Huitzilihhuitl and uncle of Chimalpopoca, was selected as the next Mexica tlatoani. The Mexica also went to war against Azcapotzalco, and Itzcoatl initiated an alliance with Nezahualcoyotl (son of the previously murdered Texcoco ruler) in the war against Maxtla. Itzcoatl also allied with Maxtla's sibling, Totoquihuaztli, who served as ruler of Tlacopan. So Tenochtitlan, Texcoco, and Tlacopan came together to lay siege to Azcapotzalco, and in 1428, they succeeded in destroying the city of Azcapotzalco and sacrificing Maxtla. Thanks to this victory, Tenochtitlan became the most powerful city in the Valley of Mexico, and the alliance between the three city-states became the foundation of the future Aztec Empire. After this event, Itzcoatl tried to consolidate Tenochtitlan's rule by conquering the city-states south of Lake Texcoco, including Culhuacan, Xochimilco, Cuitlahuac, and Mizquic. Itzcoatl then launched an attack on the Morelos Valley and succeeded in subduing the city-state of Cuauhnahuac (now Cuernavaca). In 1440, Motecuzoma I Ilhuicaminanb 4] (literally "he looks somber like a ruler" or "he shoots into the sky"nb 5]) was elected tlatoani. He was the son of Huitzilihhuitl and sibling of Chimalpopoca. He had been a warlord serving for his uncle, Itzcoatl, during the war against the Tepanek. Whenever a new tlatoani came to power in the dominant city-state, it was not uncommon for cities that had previously been subdued to rebel and refuse to pay tribute.

Thus, the tlatoani began their reign by waging "wars of coronation", often against underlings who dared to rebel, but also occasionally to demonstrate their reliability by conquering new territory. Motecuzoma tempts the cities around the Valley of Mexico by asking for labor to enlarge the Templo Mayor. Only the city of Chalco dared to disobey the tlatoani's orders, and hostilities between the cities of Chalco and Tenochtitlan lasted until the 1450s. Motecuzoma then reconquered the cities of the Morelos Valley and Guerrero, and later also reconquered new territory in the Huaxtec region in northern Veracruz and the Mixtec region in Coixtlahuaca and most of Oaxaca. He also penetrated into the central and southern Veracruz region by conquering Cosamalopan, Ahuilizapan, and Cuetlaxtlan. During this time, the city states of Tlaxcala, Cholula, and Huexotzinco became Tenochtitlan's main rivals, and they sent troops into the cities Tenochtitlan attacked. Thus, Motecuzoma launched a small-scale war against the three cities. This war was called the "War of Flowers" (Nahuatl: xochiyaoyotl), and its aim was probably to wear them out of battle. Motecuzoma also strengthened the political structure of the Three Aztec Alliance. His brother, Tlacaelel, served as his chief adviser (Nahuatl: Cihuacoatl) as well as being the man who initiated political reforms, strengthened the power of the nobility (Nahuatl: pipiltin), enacted a number of laws, and started the practice of permitting rulers in the newly created territories. the conquered to remain in power provided he declared his allegiance to the Mexica tlatoani. In 1469, the person who became the next ruler was Axayacatl (Nahuatl: "water mask"), who was the son of Tezozomoc (son of Itzcoatl) and Atotoztli (daughter of Motecuzoma I). the Zapotecs on the Isthmus of Tehuantepec.

Axayacatl also conquered the Mexica city-state of Tlatelolco, which was located in the northern part of the island where Tenochtitlan was founded. The ruler of Tlatelolco named Moquihuix was previously married to the sister of Axayacatl. Allegations of cruel treatment of his wife were used as a pretext to invade Tlatelolco so that Tenochtitlan could control its market. Axayacatl then conquered the central Guerrero region and also fought against the Otomi and Matlatzinca tribes in the Toluca Valley. The Toluca Valley is the region that separated the Aztecs from the Tarascan state of Michoacan. Axayacatl then waged war against Taraska (Nahuatl: Michhuahqueh), but in 1478–79, Taraska drove back the Aztec forces. Axayacatl suffered a heavy defeat at the battle of Tlaximaloyan (now Tajimaroa), as a result most of his 32,000 soldiers died in battle and he was barely able to escape to Tenochtitlan with the rest of his army. After Axayacatl's death in 1481, his older brother, Tizoc, was elected ruler. To coincide with his coronation, he waged a "coronation war" against the Otomi tribe in Metztitlan, but he failed and was only able to get 40 captives to sacrifice in his coronation ceremony. This was seen as a sign of the new ruler's weakness, resulting in many tributary cities revolting, and Tizoc's brief reign was preoccupied with trying to quell rebellions and retain territories previously conquered by his predecessors. Tizoc died suddenly in 1485, although it is possible that he was poisoned by his brother, Ahuitzotl, who later succeeded him as tlatoani. Tizoc is best known for the origin of the name the Tizoc Stone, a monumental sculpture (Nahuatl: temalacatl) depicting Tizoc's conquests. The next ruler was Ahuitzotl (Nahuatl: "water monster"), brother of Axayacatl and Tizoc.

He had been a war leader during Tizoc's reign. As usual, Ahuitzotl began his reign by waging a "war of coronation" that quelled rebellions in the Toluca Valley and conquered Jilotepec and various areas of the northern Valley of Mexico. The military campaign into the gulf coast in 1521 was also very successful. In addition, Ahuitzotl is known for he enlarged the Templo Mayor and inaugurated it in 1487. For the inauguration ceremony, they invited the lords of all the cities that had been subjugated. They then witness a terrible human sacrifice ceremony. Some sources estimate that 80,400 captives were killed in four days. It's likely that the actual number of victims was much smaller, but the figure was still in the thousands. Ahuitzotl also erected monumental buildings in places such as Calixtlahuaca, Malinalco and Tepoztlan. After an uprising broke out in the towns of Alahuiztlan and Oztoticpac in northern Guerrero, he ordered all residents in those towns to be massacred and replaced by settlers from the Valley of Mexico. He also set up defenses in Oztuma to deal with threats from the Taraska nation. Motecuzoma II Xocoyotzin is best known as a ruler during a time when the Aztecs were undermined by the Spaniards and their allies in Mesoamerica. He rose to power after Ahuitzotl's death. Motecuzoma Xocoyotzin (Nahuatl: "he looks somber like a ruler, youngest son") was a child of Axayacatl, and also had previous experience as a warlord. His reign began as usual. He launched the "coronation war" to show his skills as a leader. He attacked the fortified city of Nopallan in Oaxaca and subdued the empire's adjoining territories. He conquered many areas in Guerrero, Oaxaca, Puebla. He even managed to conquer the Xoconochco region in Chiapas. In addition, he launched a flower war against Tlaxcala and Huexotzinco, and succeeded in forming an alliance with Cholula.

Domestically, he made social mobility difficult for the common people (Nahuatl: macehualtin) who wanted to become pipiltins by demonstrating their reliability in warfare. He also issued rules limiting the types of luxury goods that commoners could enjoy. In 1517, Motecuzoma heard news of the arrival of foreign troops on the coast of the Gulf of Mexico near Cempoallan. He sent messengers to greet them, and he ordered his subordinates in the region to keep him posted when any other foreigners arrived. In 1519, he received news of the arrival of a Spanish fleet led by Hernán Cortés. Cortés then went to Tlaxcala and formed an alliance with the Aztecs' sworn enemy. On November 8, 1519, Motecuzoma II received Cortés and his troops at the southern entrance of Tenochtitlan, and he invited them to stop in Tenochtitlan as guests. When Aztec troops destroyed a Spanish encampment on the shores of the Gulf of Mexico, Cortés ordered Motecuzoma that he execute the commanders responsible for the attack, and Motecuzoma complied. By this time, the Spaniards had Motecuzoma captive in his own palace. Motecuzoma's subordinates saw this clearly, and so they hated the Spaniards even more. In June 1520, strife resulted in the massacre at the Templo Mayor, and then the Mexica rebelled against the Spanish. Motecuzoma died during this conflict, probably killed by the Spaniards when they fled Tenochtitlan or by the Mexica themselves because he was branded a traitor. Motecuzoma's relative and advisor named Cuitláhuac succeeded him as tlatoani and he worked to defend Tenochtitlan against the Spanish and native peoples allied with them.

He only reigned for 80 days; it is probable that he died of a variola plague, although early historical sources do not give a cause. He was succeeded by Cuauhtémoc, the last Mexica tlatoani. He remained persistent in defending Tenochtitlan. However, the city of Tenochtitlan eventually fell to the Spanish, and he was captured on August 13, 1521. Thus began the Spanish colonization of central Mexico. Cuauhtémoc was held captive until he was tortured and executed on orders of Cortés (supposedly as a result of treason) during the failed expedition to Honduras in 1525. The highest ranking class in Aztec society was the pīpiltinnb 7] or nobility. The pilli status was hereditary and conferred various privileges, such as the right to wear beautiful clothes and use luxury goods, as well as the right to own land and direct the workers of the corvée. The most powerful aristocrats are called teuctin. They may also hold high government posts or become warlords. Overall, the nobility group makes up around 5% of the population. The common people are called mācehualtin. Initially this class included the peasants, but later also included all the lower classes of workers. Eduardo Noguera estimates that only twenty percent of the Aztec population made their living in agriculture and food production. The other eighty percent were warriors, artisans, and merchants. Ultimately, most mācehualli worked in arts and crafts. Their works became the city's main source of income. Macehualtin could be enslaved (Nahuatl: tlacotin), for example if they sold themselves to aristocrats out of debt or poverty, but slave status was not hereditary. Some macehualtin are landless and work under a ruler (Nahuatl: mayehqueh), while most of the common people are members of the calpolli which allows them to work the land in the calpolli.

Commoners could gain the privileges of royalty by demonstrating their reliability during war. If a soldier captured the enemy, he earned the right to wear certain symbols, weapons or clothing, and the more prisoners he captured, the higher his rank and dignity. In the Aztec family system, inheritance went to sons and daughters. Therefore, women can own property like men, as a result they enjoy considerable economic freedom. Men and women in Aztec society were required to fulfill their gender roles. Men worked outside the home as farmers, traders, artisans and soldiers, while women took care of the household. Even so, women can also become petty traders, doctors, priests, and midwives. In addition, fighting was a highly valued activity in Aztec society, and women's work is metaphorically likened to war. Women's work was also considered equally important in maintaining the balance of the world and in satisfying the gods. Therefore, experts describe Aztec gender ideology not as an ideology that regulates gender hierarchies, but as an ideology with complementary gender roles; in other words, the roles are separate, but considered equal. Among the nobility, marriage is often used as a political strategy. The lower nobility married off their daughters to men from more prestigious lineages, and this more prestigious status would then be passed on to their children. Nobles often practiced polygamy. However, polygamy was not common among the common people, and some sources even state that the practice was banned. The main unit of political organization in the Aztec civilization was the city-state, called altepetl in Nahuatl (meaning "mountain of water"). Altepetl is led by a ruler called tlatoani.

In each altepetl, there is a capital which is the center of religion, economy, and politics. Altepetl is also the ethnic identity of its inhabitants, although altepetl may be inhabited by groups speaking different languages. Each altepetl considers itself separate from all others, and wars are often waged by one altepetl against another. With this, Nahuatl-speaking Aztecs from one altepetl would form solidarity with speakers of other languages ​​who lived in the same altepetl, but were enemies with Nahuatl speakers in other altepetls. In the Basin of Mexico, the altepetl divided into calpolli, which served as the organizational unit for the common people. In Tlaxcala and the Puebla Valley, the altepetl consisted of teccalli units headed by a lord (Nahuatl: tecutli) who controlled the area and distributed land rights among the people. Calpolli was once a territorial unit where people worked and cultivated the land, because the land was not privately owned. Sometimes calpolli also become a kinship unit such as a network of families connected to each other through marriage. Calpolli leaders may or may not be members of the aristocratic class, and if they are, they can represent the interests of the calpollis in the altepetl government. In the Morelos Valley, archaeologist Michael E. Smith estimates that altepetl typically had a population ranging from 10,000 to 15,000 inhabitants, and covering an area of ​​70 to 100 square kilometers. In the Morelos Valley, the altepetls are smaller. Smith argued that the altepetl was not a territorial unit, but a political unit composed of citizens loyal to its ruler. He distinguishes between the two, because there is an area with small settlements loyal to different altepetls.

The Aztec Empire was ruled indirectly. Like European empires, the Aztec Empire was inhabited by various ethnic groups. However, the two cannot be equated, as the Aztec Empire was a system of tribute collection and not a centralized system of government. Historian Ross Hassig argues that the Alliance of the Three Aztecs should be classified as an unofficial or hegemonic empire, since states did not have absolute power over conquered territory; they only asked for tribute, and the military would only be deployed to those areas to ensure the payment of tribute. The Alliance of the Three Aztecs was also a disjointed empire; for example, the region of Xoconochco which is located in the far southeast is completely disconnected from the Aztec core region. The hegemonic nature of the Aztec Empire can be seen in the fact that local lords were restored to power after their city-states were conquered, and the Aztecs usually did not interfere in local affairs as long as tribute was paid. These city-states were made obedient by means of a network of elites who were linked together through marriage relations or other kinds of exchange. Even so, the Aztec Empire was able to expand their territory by controlling strategic areas on the border. Their approach to this kind of territory is direct, and they don't hesitate to send troops to conquer and control the territory. Strategic areas were often not subject to tribute. The Aztecs even attempted to solidify their rule in the region by deploying troops, installing a puppet ruler, or even moving the population from the center. Thus, the territories that lay outside the Aztec core of the Valley of Mexico were distinguished by their strategic importance. Some areas were made tributary provinces, and the tribute ensured economic stability in the empire, while others were strategic provinces that served as the basis for expanding territories.

Although the form of government of the Aztec Alliance of Threes is often referred to as an "empire", in fact most of the territory of the empire was divided into various city-states called altepetl. Altpetl is ruled by a tlatoani from a legitimate noble family. At the beginning of Aztec history, altepetls experienced rapid growth and competition. The altepetl was still the main form of organization at the local level even after the formation of the Alliance of the Three Aztecs in 1427. One of the reasons why the Aztec Empire was able to maintain its hegemony was because the altepetl was a powerful regional political unit. Like other peoples in Mesoamerica, the Aztecs relied heavily on maize farming. Besides maize, major crops in the Aztec civilization included beans, pumpkin, chili peppers, and amaranth. Intensive farming was made possible by the humid environment of the Valley of Mexico and the presence of lakes and marshes. One of the most important methods in such environments is chinampa, artificial islands that can transform shallow water into highly fertile plantations that can be cultivated all year round. Chinampa is made from layers of mud that come from the bottom of the lake and also from various plants. The artificial islands are separated by small canals, and farmers can move from one island to another by canoe. The soil in the chinampa is very fertile, and an average of seven times a year can be harvested. Based on the current yield of chinampa, it is estimated that one hectare of chinampa can feed 20 people, while 9,000 hectares of chinampa can feed 180,000 people. The Aztec people further advanced their agriculture by building irrigation systems. Although most agricultural activities take place outside of densely populated areas, there are also small-scale farming methods within cities.

Each family had a plot of land planted with maize, fruits, herbs and other important crops. After Tenochtitlan became a large city, water was supplied through an aqueduct from a spring on the lake's edge, and they also set up a system for collecting human waste to be used as fertilizer. Thanks to their ability to grow crops, Aztec agriculture was able to meet the food needs of residents in large cities. Lakes are also a rich source of protein from aquatic animals such as fish, amphibians, shrimp, insects and insect eggs, as well as waterfowl. Thanks to the availability of a variety of protein sources, they have little need for the meat of domesticated animals (they only have turkey and dogs), and experts have estimated that the inhabitants of the Valley of Mexico do not lack protein. Thanks to a surplus of food, the Aztecs were able to work outside the field of food production. In addition to ensuring the availability of food at home, women make woven fabrics from agave and cotton. Men also made ceramics, obsidian and chert tools, or luxury goods such as beads and bird feathers and musical instruments. Sometimes all of the calpollis do only one kind of craft. In several archaeological sites, large areas have even been found that only focus on one craft only. The Aztecs did not make much metal work, but they had mastered the technology of smelting gold, and they fused gold with other precious stones such as jade and turquoise. Items made of copper were usually imported from Taraska. Products are distributed in market networks; some markets specialize in one type of commodity (for example the dog market in Acolman), while others trade a wide variety of goods. Markets are regulated by inspectors who determine what items can be sold and also punish those who deceive consumers or sell counterfeit or substandard goods.

Cities usually have weekly markets (every 5 days), while markets in big cities open every day. Cortés reports that the market in the center of Tlatelolco is visited by 60,000 people annually. Several sellers of goods in the market are small-scale sellers; farmers sell their crops, artisans sell their vessels, and so on. The rest of the traders are professional traders who come from one market to another to make a profit. Pochteca is a long-distance merchant who belongs to guilds. They traveled to various regions of Mesoamerica and brought back exotic luxury goods, and they acted as judges and overseers in the markets of Tlatelolco. The Aztec economy was highly commercialized, but land and labor were not considered commodities, although some nobles could trade certain types of land with each other. There were several types of money in the Aztec civilization. Low value goods are purchased using cocoa beans (which must be imported from the plains). In Aztec bazaars, a small rabbit cost 30 chicks, a turkey egg cost 3 chicks, and a tamale equals one chick. For more expensive items, the money used was a standard length cotton cloth called a quachtli. There are all kinds of quachtli, from 65 to 300 cocoa beans worth. The money needed to support the life of a commoner for a year in Tenochtitlan is 20 quachtli. Altepetl, which was conquered by the Aztecs, was forced to pay tribute. The tribute was usually in the form of the most valuable items in the local area. Several pages in the Mendoza Codex list the tributary cities and the types of tribute they paid. The tribute given was not only in the form of luxury items such as bird feathers, beautiful clothes, or greenstone beads, but also in the form of items for daily needs such as clothing, firewood, and food.

Tribute is usually paid two or four times each year. The results of archaeological excavations in the provinces that were once ruled by the Aztecs show that the Aztec rule in the region brought its own benefits and disadvantages for the people in the province. On the one hand, the Aztec Empire supported trade activities, and exotic goods from obsidian to bronze were enjoyed by both commoners and royalty. Their trading partners also included the Purépecha (also known as the Taraska), who supplied the Aztecs with bronze tools and jewelry. On the other hand, the tribute levied by the empire was a great burden on the common people, as they had to work even harder to be able to pay the tribute. Meanwhile, the nobility usually benefited from imperial power because the imperial structure of government was not direct. The empire depended on local kings and nobles and offered them privileges if they helped keep order and keep paying tribute. As well as having a rural agricultural tradition, Aztec society had also developed an urban tradition with a complex system of institutions, specialization, and hierarchies. Urban traditions in Mesoamerica began to emerge in the Classical period after the founding of large cities such as Teotihuacan (with a population of over 100,000). By the time of the Aztec awakening, urban traditions were already deeply embedded in Mesoamerican society. City centers themselves act as religious, political, and economic centers. The Aztec capital was located at Tenochtitlan, which is today the seat of Mexico City. The city is built on a number of islets in Lake Texcoco. This city is a planned city according to political, religious and practical principles. The city plan is based on a symmetrical layout that divides the city into four sections called campans (directions).

Tenochtitlan is centered on the sacred area which is where the Great Pyramid of Tenochtitlan stands with a height of 50 m. Houses were made of wood and clay, roofs of reeds, but pyramids, temples and palaces were generally made of stone. The city is traversed by canals which are used as transportation routes. Anthropologist Eduardo Noguera estimates that the city's population is as high as 200,000 based on the number of homes and also by combining the population of Tlatelolco (formerly a separate city, but later a suburb of Tenochtitlan). When all the islets in Lake Texcoco and their coastal areas are considered, the population is between 300,000 and 700,000. Michael E. Smith made a smaller estimate, namely 212,500 residents in Tenochtitlan on an area of ​​1,350 hectares. Meanwhile, the second largest city in the Valley of Mexico during the Aztec era was Texcoco with a population of around 25,000 people spread over an area of ​​450 hectares. The city center of Tenochtitlan is a sacred area surrounded by walls. In the area are the Templo Mayor, temples to other gods, ball fields, calmecac (a school for nobles), tzompantli hangings displaying ceremonial sacrificial skulls, warriors' houses, and merchants' palaces. Around the sacred area, there are palaces built by tlatoani-tlatoani. The main building in the city of Tenochtitlan is the Templo Mayor ("Great Temple"), which is a large pyramid with two staircases leading to two twin shrines - one dedicated to Tlaloc, the other to Huitzilopochtli. It was at the top of the pyramid that human sacrifices were made during ritual celebrations, and the human sacrificed corpses were then thrown down. The shrine has been enlarged several times by adding new levels, and each time a new level is completed, a dedication and dedication ceremony is held.

After this shrine was rediscovered in the center of Mexico City, offerings were found which are now on display at the Templo Mayor Museum. In his article entitled "Symbolism of the Templo Mayor", archaeologist Eduardo Matos Moctezuma surmises that the shape of this temple symbolized the Mexica's view of the universe. The Mexica believed that the world was made up of horizontal and vertical planes. The horizontal plane consists of the four cardinal directions, while the vertical plane is related to the heavens and the underworld. It is at the center of this shrine that the horizontal and vertical planes meet, or in other words the place where the heavens and the underworld meet and where the four directions of the universe originate. Therefore, Matos Moctezuma believes that this shrine is the embodiment of this myth. Other major cities in the Aztec civilization included the centers of several city-states around Lake Texcoco, such as Tenayuca, Azcapotzalco, Texcoco, Colhuacan, Tlacopan, Chapultepec, Coyoacan, Xochimilco, and Chalco. Cholula is the largest city in the Puebla Valley, and it is also the largest pyramidal temple in Mesoamerica. Meanwhile, the Tlaxcala confederation consisted of four smaller towns. In Morelos, Cuahnahuac is the temperature town of Tlahuica, who speaks Nahuatl, while Tollocan, in the Toluca Valley, is the capital of the Matlatzinca people, who are both Nahuatl speakers and speakers of Otomi and what is now Matlatzinca. Most Aztec cities had a similar layout, with a main square in the center of the city and a large pyramid with two steps and two temples facing west. The Aztec religion basically consisted of ritual practices dedicated to various gods. Like other religions in Mesoamerica, it is usually classified as an agriculturalist and polytheistic religion with animist elements.

Sacrifices to the gods were a central element in Aztec religion, considering that these were done as a sign of gratitude or to continue the cycle of life. The main gods worshiped by the Aztecs were Tlaloc (god of rain and storms), Huitzilopochtli (god of sun and war and protector of the Mexica), Quetzalcoatl (god of wind, sky and stars), and Tezcatlipoca (god of the night, magic , divination, and destiny). The Templo Mayor in Tenochtitlan has two shrines at the top, one of which is dedicated to Tlaloc, the other to Huitzilopochtli. Quetzalcoatl and Tezcatlipoca had separate shrines near the Templo Mayor, while the high priest of the Templo Mayor was nicknamed "Quetzalcoatl Tlamacazqueh". Other important deities are Tlaltecutli or Coatlicue (goddess of the earth), Tonacatecuhtli and Tonacacihuatl (pair of deities associated with life and sustenance), Mictlantecutli and Mictlancihuatl (pair of deities who rule over underworld and death), Chalchiutlicue (goddess of the lake and springs), Xipe Totec (god of fertility and natural cycles), Huehueteotl or Xiuhtecuhtli (god of fire), Tlazolteotl (goddess associated with birth and sexuality), and Xochipilli and Xochiquetzal (gods of song, dance and games). In some areas (especially in Tlaxcala), Mixcoatl or Camaxtli served as the main deity. Several historical sources mention the existence of the god Ometeotl who may have been the god of duality between birth and death, male and female; this god probably combined Tonatecuhtli and Tonacacihuatl. Apart from the main gods, there are dozens of minor gods associated with certain elements or concepts. As the Aztec territory expanded, so did their number of gods, as they absorbed the gods worshiped by conquered peoples. In addition, the main deity has many other manifestations or aspects, resulting in a small group of deities with related aspects.

Aztec mythology can be known from a number of historical sources written during colonial times. One myth called the "Legend of the Suns" describes the successive creation of four suns (or ages), each ruled by a different god and inhabited by different beings. Every age will be ended by a disaster that will start the next age. During the process, the god Tezcatlipoca became hostile to Quetzalcoatl, and they destroyed each other's creations. The current sun, the fifth sun, was created when one of the lesser gods sacrificed himself at a bonfire and turned into the sun, but it only started moving after the other gods sacrificed themselves and offered their lives to it. Based on another myth explaining how the earth was created, Tezcatlipoca and Quetzalcoatl teamed up to defeat the giant crocodile Cipactli and make it into the earth, so that humans were allowed to dig up its flesh and plant their seeds, provided they offered blood to Cipactli in exchange. Also, according to the story of the creation of mankind, Quetzalcoatl traveled with his twin sister Xolotl to the underworld and brought bones which were then ground into corn by the goddess Cihuacoatl. The resulting dough was shaped like a human and then took on life after Quetzalcoatl gave it his own blood. Huitzilopochtli is a deity associated with the Mexica, and he appears in accounts of the origin and migration of the tribe. During their travels, Huitzilopochtli (who existed in the form of a divine bundle carried by a Mexica priest) kept the tribe in conflict with their neighbors wherever they settled. According to another myth, Huitzilopochtli defeated and dismembered his sister the goddess Coyolxauhqui and four hundred of her brothers on the hill of Coatepetl. Depictions of this myth can be seen on the south side of the Templo Mayor (also called Coatepetl), while at the base of the stairs is a large stone monolith depicting the dismembered body of the goddess.

Aztec religious life was centered on the calendar. Like most peoples in Mesoamerica, the Aztecs used two calendars together: a 260-day ritual calendar called tonalpohualli, and a 365-day solar calendar called xiuhpohualli. Each day has its own name and number in each calendar, and the combination of the two dates appears only every 52 years. Tonalpohualli is generally used for divination purposes. The calendar consists of 20 day markers and numbers ranging from 1-13. Meanwhile, xiuhpohualli consists of 18 "months", and each "month" consists of 20 days, plus 5 "blank" days at the end of the cycle before the new xiuhpohualli cycle begins. Each "month" is named for a particular ritual observance that begins each month, and many of these are linked to agricultural cycles. Scholars are still debating whether the Aztecs made adjustments to their calendar for leap years, and how they did it. Monthly rituals involve all residents and are held in every home, at the calpolli temples, and in the main holy areas. the celebrations held mostly included dancing, re-enactments of mythical stories by people pretending to be gods, and food, animal, and human sacrifices. Once every 52 years, the two Aztec calendars again reach their starting point, and a new calendar cycle begins. This event is celebrated with a ritual called Xiuhmolpilli or "New Fire Ceremony". During this ceremony, old pottery was destroyed in all homes, and all fires in the Aztec civilization were extinguished. A new fire is then lit on the chest of one of the human sacrifices, and a runner will carry the new fire to the various Calpolli communities to distribute the fire.

Meanwhile, the fireless night is related to the fear that the evil spirit tzitzimime (which is associated with the stars) will descend from the sky and devour the earth to end the fifth sun. The Aztecs believed that death was necessary to perpetuate creation. Deities and humans alike have a responsibility to make sacrifices so that life can continue. As described in the Aztec creation myth, humans were responsible for ensuring that the sun would continue to rise, and they also had to sacrifice something to keep the earth fertile. Thus, human and animal blood sacrifices were made, depending on which god had to be satisfied and what kind of ceremony was being performed. Priests for certain gods sometimes had to shed their own blood. Cannibalism is even practiced in some rituals. The captives and members of their families ate the flesh of the captives, but it is not certain whether this practice was widespread in the Aztec civilization. Although human sacrifice was a widespread practice throughout Mesoamerica, the Aztecs (according to their own historical records) sacrificed so many lives that no other civilization in the Americas could rival them. For example, to purify the Great Pyramid of Tenochtitlan in 1487, the Aztecs report that they sacrificed 80,400 captives over a period of four days, and this sacrifice is said to have been made by the tlatoani Ahuitzotl. However, this figure is not accepted by most experts, and it is possible that the number of victims is exaggerated. Due to the large amount of human sacrifice in Aztec rituals, many experts have wondered what made them so eager to sacrifice human lives. In the 1970s, Michael Harner and Marvin Harris argued that they did this so they could eat human victims, as described in the Codex Magliabechiano.

Harner claims that high population pressures and the absence of domesticated herbivorous animals resulted in a deficiency of the amino acids needed by the human body. Although experts agree that the Aztecs did perform human sacrifices, the suggestion that cannibalism was a widespread practice in Aztec society is not supported by consensus. In 1977, Harris published the book Cannibals and Kings which reiterated the claim (originally made by Harner) that human sacrifice was one of the foods enjoyed by royalty, because the Aztec diet lacked protein. This claim is disputed by Bernard Ortíz Montellano. He has researched health, food, and medicine in the Aztec civilization. While it is true that the Aztec diet lacked protein, he pointed out that the Aztec diet was rich in vegetable protein. Ortiz also said that human sacrifices were more often done at harvest time, that the protein obtained from human sacrificed meat was not large, and that nobles could easily consume animal protein. Today, most scholars try to explain this practice in terms of Aztec ideology, and they also argue that the ritual sacrifice of warriors from conquered nations was a way of demonstrating political power, thus substantiating the rulers' claim that they were endowed with divine authority. . This activity was also considered important in preventing rebellions in the conquered territories, and it was especially important in the Aztec state, which had tenuous political ties. The Aztecs valued fine arts and crafts which they called toltecayotl. This term refers to the Toltec peoples who lived in central Mexico before the rise of the Aztec city-state. The Aztec people considered the Toltec culture to be the highest culture.

Fine arts produced by the Aztec people include writing and painting, singing and poetry, sculpture and mosaics, as well as ceramics, plumage, and metals (including copper and gold). The artisans who create these arts are called tolteca. The Aztecs did not have the sophisticated script that the Mayans did. However, like the Mayans and Zapotecs, they used a writing system that combined logographic signs with phonetic syllable signs. An example of using a logogram is the image of a mountain representing the word tepetl (which also means "mountain"), while an example of a phonetic syllable mark is the image of the tooth tlantli to represent the syllable tla in words completely unrelated to teeth. By combining these two, the Aztecs were able to symbolize the names of people and places. The narratives are usually presented in the form of a sequence of pictures using different iconographic settings, such as footprints to show the way, burning temples to depict conquests, and so on. Epigrapher Alfonso Lacadena has shown that the syllable signs used by the Aztecs could represent all of the most frequently used syllables in Nahuatl (with a few exceptions), but most scholars think that the phoneticism of these signs only took hold after the conquest. after the Spaniards introduced the principles of phonetic writing to the Aztecs. Other scholars, notably Gordon Whittaker, feel that the syllabic and phonetic aspects of Aztec writing are less systematic and more creative, and he believes that Aztec writing never developed into the fully syllabic writing system of Mayan writing. The Aztec writing instead used a variety of phonetic markers. The figure on the right shows the use of phonetic signs to write place names according to the Mendoza Codex dating from colonial times.

The place at the very top is "Mapachtepec", literally meaning "On Raccoon Hill". Above the mountain glyph "TEPETL", there are phonetic signs "MA" (hand) and "PCH" (moss) to spell out the word "mapach" ("raccoon") phonetically rather than logographically. Two other place names, namely Mazatlan ("Place of Many Deer") and Huitztlan ("Place of Many Thorns"), use the phonetic element "TLAN" which is represented by teeth (tlantli). The "MAZA" (mazatl = deer) glyph was combined with the "TLAN" tooth signature to produce "Mazatlan", and similarly the "HUITZ" (huitztli = thorn) glyph was combined with the "TLAN" tooth signature to produce "Huitztlan". Song and poetry were highly valued in the Aztec civilization. Poetry performances and contests are often held during the festivities. There were also dramatic performances involving actors, musicians and acrobats. In addition, there are several types of cuicatl (song): Yaocuicatl dedicated to the god(s) of war, Teocuicatl for gods and creation myths, xochicuicatl for flowers (the symbol of poetry and showing the highly metaphorical nature of poetry, which often has implied meaning). Meanwhile, "prose" is called tlahtolli. An important element in Aztec poetry is the use of parallelism, that is, the repetition of the same forms. Aztec poetry also contains diphrasms, namely metaphors that express an abstract concept by using two more concrete concepts. For example, the Nahuatl way of expressing the word "poetry" is in xochitl in cuicatl, which means "flower, song." Many poems of this kind were collected during the conquest. Sometimes, poetry is attributed to certain writers, such as Nezahualcoyotl (tlatoani Texcoco) and Cuacuauhtzin (ruler of Tepechpan), but it is not certain whether the poetry was actually written by them personally. Important collections of Aztec poetry include the Romances de los señores de la Nueva España (collected in 1582, probably by Juan Bautista de Pomar)nb 8] and Cantares Mexicanos.

The Aztec people produced various types of ceramics. The most common are polished, non-slip, polished orange ceramics. Red ceramics contain red slip, while polychrome ceramics are ceramics with white or orange slip decorated with orange, red, brown and/or black painting. The most common type of ceramic is "black on orange" ceramic, which is orange ceramic decorated with black painting. Aztec ceramics with black on orange are chronologically divided into four, namely Aztec I and II (1100–1350), Aztec III (1350–1520), and Aztec IV (early colonial era). Aztec I is characterized by painted flowers and glyphs for day names; Aztec II has paintings of grass over calligraphic shapes such as s-curves or loops; Aztec III has very simple lines; Aztec IV follows patterns from pre-Columbian times, but also adds European-influenced flowers. Each region has its own variety, and archaeologists are still trying to refine the order of the four styles. Vessels that are usually used for daily purposes are pots made of clay for cooking (comalli), bowls and plates for eating (caxitl), pots for cooking (comitl), molcajete or a kind of mortar and pestle used for grinding chilies (molcaxitl). , as well as a brazier and a saucer. The vessels were heated in a simple furnace or even in an earthen pit at a low temperature. Polychrome ceramics were imported from the Cholula region (also known as the "Mixteca-Puebla style"), and these were considered luxury items, while black-and-orange ceramics made by local people were used for daily needs. Aztec painting was made in animal skins (especially deer), in lienzo fabrics made of cotton, and in amate paper made from tree bark (eg the bark of Trema micrantha or Ficus aurea trees).

The surface of the material is coated with gesso so that the image becomes clearer. The Nahuatl art of painting and writing is known by the metaphor in tlilli, in tlapalli, which means "black ink, red pigment". There are a handful of books containing Aztec paintings. Of these books, it is not certain whether they were written in pre-conquest times, but some codices may have been produced shortly after the conquest before the tradition of painting was disrupted by the turmoil that swept through Mesoamerica. If some codices were indeed produced in the post-conquest period, they may have been copied from pre-Columbian originals. The Codex Borbonicus is thought to be the only pre-conquest Aztec codex that has survived to this day - it is a calendar codex that contains counting days and months and indicates the patron deity for each period. However, there are also experts who feel that the style of this codex is in accordance with the style of codices made after the conquest. The Spanish colonial government sometimes commissioned Aztec tlacuilos (codex makers), for example the Mendoza Codex. The Spanish government also occasionally commissioned codices describing pre-colonial religious practices, for example the Ríos Codex. However, codices with information on calendars and religious practices were systematically sought after and destroyed by the church. Meanwhile, other painting books (particularly those related to history and tribute) are still being made. Although the codex produced in southern Puebla near Cholula also describes Aztec gods and describes religious practices shared by the Aztec people of the Valley of Mexico, it is not considered an Aztec codex because it was created outside the Aztec "core region". However, Karl Anton Nowotny argues that the Borgia Codex (painted in the Cholula region and in the Mixtec style) is "the most important work of art of any extant manuscript".

The Aztecs made sculptures of stone and wood, but most of these woodcuts have been lost to the ages. Aztec rock carvings range in size, from small statues and masks to gigantic monuments. Many of the sculptures are made in a very realistic style, including animals such as rattlesnakes, dogs, jaguars, frogs, turtles and monkeys. The Aztec civilization also produced a number of monumental stone carvings which are still preserved today. Such carvings usually serve as decoration for religious buildings. The most famous Aztec rock carving is the Aztec calendar stone or "sun stone" discovered in 1790. Excavations at Zócalo in the same year also unearthed a 2.7 meter high andesite statue of Coatlicue; this statue depicts a khthonic goddess in the form of a snake with a skirt consisting of rattlesnakes. The Coyolxauhqui stone depicting the dismembered body of the goddess Coyolxauhqui was discovered in 1978 at the bottom of the stairs leading to the top of the Templo Mayor. There are two sculptures which are characteristic of the Aztecs and are associated with ritual sacrifices. The first is the cuauhxicalli or "eagle vessel", which is a large stone bowl often shaped like an eagle or jaguar and used as a vessel to place a human sacrificed heart that has been removed. The second is the temalacatl, which is a monumental stone disk covered with carvings, and prisoners of war tied to this boulder to be sacrificed by being forced to fight. There are also smaller rock carvings depicting gods. The style used in religious sculpture is austere, possibly to create an impression of power in the minds of those who see it. Although Aztec stone carvings are now preserved in museums as colorless stone, they were originally decorated in polychrome colors, sometimes also covered with plaster first.

According to historical records from the Spanish conquistadores, the stone carvings were also decorated with precious stones and metals inlaid into the plaster. One of the most valuable works of art in the Aztec civilization were feather crafts, that is, works decorated with colorful mosaics of feathers. Fur craftsmen were a highly skilled and respected class, and they were called amanteca. The name comes from the Amantla area in the city of Tenochtitlan which is where they live and work. Fur craftsmen had to go through lengthy training, and documentation in Tenochtitlan and Tlatelolco shows that fur craft skills were passed from parents to children. Overall, there are three ways to make fur crafts. The first way is by tying feathers to produce three-dimensional objects such as fans and head coverings. The second way is to stick feathers on a surface to produce a mosaic. An example of a product that can be produced in this way is a shield. The third way is to weave fur on textiles. The feathers used range from duck, turkey, crow, waterfowl, to exotic birds such as macaws, parrots, hummingbirds, or even the highly prized quetzal. "Normal" bristles are often used as an undercoat in the mosaic-making process, although some are made into separate crafts. These furs were obtained from trade as well as from tribute. Fur crafts are difficult to care for and maintain, so that today the number of Aztec fur crafts remaining does not reach ten. Mexico City was founded on the ruins of Tenochtitlan. The new city slowly covered Lake Texcoco and the old structures. Meanwhile, Aztec warriors were formed together with Tlaxcala warriors, and Aztec warriors participated in various military campaigns waged by Spain in the northern and southern Mesoamerica regions.

Thus, Aztec culture and the Nahuatl language were still widespread at the start of the colonial period, as Aztec warriors established permanent settlements in the new Spanish-colonized territories. The Aztec ruling dynasty still ruled San Juan Tenochtitlan, which was part of Mexico City, but later the Spanish kept only puppet rulers in the area. One of them was Andrés de Tapia Motelchiuh who was appointed by the Spanish. Other former Aztec city-states are also still inhabited by native peoples who are ruled by a gobernador of native background. At first, the office was often hereditary, and gobernador was the same as tlatoani, but the two offices later became separate in many Nahua towns. The native governors were in control of the political affairs of the natives, and they also maintained a system of tribute collection and forced labor to benefit the encomiendas of the Spaniards. Encomiendas were the giving of labor and tribute from certain groups of native peoples to the Spaniards who were bestowed with these privileges. At the start of the colonial period, several native governors were able to amass wealth and rank on a par with the Spanish encomenderos. The number of indigenous people in Mexico declined in the post-conquest era. The cause was the spread of viruses that had never existed on the American continent before, so that the natives did not have immunity against these viruses. In 1520–1521, variola broke out in Tenochtitlan and was one of the causes for the fall of the city; other outbreaks struck in 1545 and 1576. There is no consensus on the population of Mexico at the time the Europeans arrived. According to early estimates, the Valley of Mexico had a small population, as Kubler put out the figure of 200,000 in 1942.

However, in 1963, Borah and Cook used pre-conquest tribute registers to calculate the number of tribute payers in central Mexico, and they estimated the population to be between 18 and 30 million. This very high estimate has been criticized for relying on unfounded assumptions. Archaeologist William Sanders made his estimate based on archaeological evidence of homes, and he estimated the Valley of Mexico's population ranged from 1-1.2 million. Meanwhile, Whitmore used computer simulations based on colonial censuses to show that the Valley of Mexico in 1519 had a population of 1.5 million and that of Mexico as a whole had 16 million people. Therefore, to estimate how much population declined in the 16th century, all depends on the estimated population in 1519. Estimates of the percentage decline in population in the Valley of Mexico range from 50% to about 90%; Sanders and Whitmore themselves estimate that the population decline rate was as high as 90%. Even though the Aztec Empire had collapsed, some members of the highest elite were still able to enjoy their status during the colonial era. An example is the main heir Motecuzoma II and his successors. Motecuzoma's son, Pedro Moctezuma, had a son who married a woman from the Spanish nobility, and the child born from this marriage received the title Conde de Moctezuma. From 1696 to 1701, the title of Virreyes de Nueva España was held by titleholder Conde de Moctezuma. In 1766, the holder of the Conde de Moctezuma title became the Grande of Spain. In 1865 (during the Second Mexican Empire), the title Conde de Moctezuma (then held by Antonio María Moctezuma-Marcilla de Teruel y Navarro) was created Duke, and the title de Tultengo was later added by King Juan Carlos I in 1992.

Meanwhile, Motecuzoma's two daughters (Doña Isabel Moctezuma and her younger sister, Doña Leonor Moctezuma) received encomiendas from Hernán Cortes. Doña Leonor Moctezuma was married twice to a Spaniard, and passed on encomiendas rights to his daughter born in his second marriage. During the colonial era, the Nahua people were also able to maintain various aspects of their social and political life. The Spanish nation formed two separate political societies, namely the republica de indios and the republica de españoles. The natives belong to the republica de indios. Meanwhile, the república de españoles includes not only Europeans, but also Africans and people of mixed blood. The Spaniards recognized the native elites as aristocrats in the Spanish colonial system, retaining the status differences that existed from pre-conquest times, and using these aristocrats as intermediaries between the Spanish colonial government and the common people. They were allowed to become elites as long as they converted to Catholicism and remained loyal to the Spanish Empire. The Nahua governed societies during colonial times had considerable autonomy in managing local affairs. The Spanish rulers had little understanding of the indigenous political system, but they recognized the important role of the native elites and the pre-existing system. They changed the political system by making the altepetl the basic unit of government. In colonial times, altepetl was renamed to cabecera (although they still use the name altepetl in local Nahuatl language documentation), while outer settlements ruled by cabecera were called sujeto. In Cabecera, the Spaniards formed town councils like in Iberia called cabildos, which usually continued to carry out the roles held by the ruling group in pre-colonial times.

As a result of the decline in population caused by disease outbreaks, settlement patterns changed and new cities were founded. These towns were often filled with people who were forcibly displaced under the congregate policy imposed by Spain. Indigenous people living in areas rarely moved to form new communities, thus facilitating Spanish efforts to spread Catholicism and exploit native labour. The Aztec civilization has left many kinds of legacies to the world. Aztec archaeological sites have been excavated and opened to the public, while artifacts are on display in museums. Place names and loanwords from the Nahuatl language are widespread in Mexico. Aztec symbols and mythology have also blended with Mexican nationalism and become part of the country's coat of arms. In the 19th century, the image of the Aztecs as uncivilized barbarians began to change due to the romanticization of the Aztecs as an indigenous group with a highly developed culture that could rival ancient European civilizations. After Mexico succeeded in gaining independence from Spain, the romanticization of the Aztecs was utilized in the narrative used to form a new nation which was a blend of Europe and America. Aztec culture and history had been an integral part of the process of forming Mexican national identity following the country's independence in 1821. In Europe in the 17th and 18th centuries, the Aztecs were seen as barbaric, violent, and culturally lowly. However, before Mexico gained independence, the American-born Spaniards (criollos) had traced Aztec history in the search for a symbol of pride separate from Spain. Scholars use Aztec writings, such as those compiled by Fernando de Alva Ixtlilxochitl, as well as those of Hernando Alvarado Tezozomoc and Chimalpahin to understand Mexico's past from the point of view of writers from indigenous backgrounds.

Historian D.A. Brading stated that this quest became the cornerstone of "creole patriotism". The 17th century clergyman and scholar Carlos de Sigüenza y Góngora managed to obtain a collection of manuscripts from a Texcoco nobleman named Alva Ixtlilxochitl. Creole Jesuit Francisco Javier Clavijero published La Historia Antigua de México (1780–81) while he was in exile in Italy following the expulsion of the Jesuits in 1767; in the book, he traces the history of the Aztecs from the time of migration to the time of their last ruler, Cuauhtemoc. His goal in writing the book was to defend Mexico's past from all kinds of accusations made by contemporary writers, such as Pauw, Buffon, Raynal, and William Robertson. Archaeological excavations in the main square of Mexico City in 1790 managed to find two giant stone carvings that were buried not long after the city of Tenochtitlan fell to the Spanish. The two remains that were found were the famous Aztec calendar stone and the statue of Coatlicue. The book Descripción histórico y cronológico de las dos piedras by Antonio de León y Gama, published in 1792 examines the two stone remains. A decade later, German scientist Alexander von Humboldt spent a year in Mexico. One of the books he published at that time was Vues des Cordillères et monuments des peuples indigènes de l'Amérique. Humboldt is a figure who has introduced the Aztecs to scientists and audiences in the West. With regard to religion, a colonial painting of the Virgin of Guadalupe depicts Our Lady hovering on a nopal cactus which is part of the founding myth of the city of Tenochtitlan. Juan Diego is a Nahua person who is said to have seen such apparitions, and he associates Our Lady's dark appearance with Mexico's Aztec past.

After Mexico won independence in 1821 and became a monarchy called the Mexican Empire, its flag bore the traditional Aztec symbol of an eagle perched on a nopal cactus hump. Above the head of this eagle is a crown which is the symbol of the new Mexican monarchy. After the monarchy was overthrown in 1822, the eagle on the new republic's flag was crownless. In the 1860s, after France founded the Second Mexican Empire under Maximilian of the House of Habsburg, the Mexican flag still contained the eagle and cactus emblem emblazoned with monarchical symbols. The empire itself did not last long and the French army was defeated, so the republic was re-established, and the flag also became simpler as before. The eagle and cactus emblem itself has also become the official symbol of the Republic of Mexico, and now these symbols adorn official buildings. In Mexico in the post-independence period, there was a feud between Hispanistas (mostly consisting of conservative Mexican elites) and Indigenistas (mostly liberal Mexican elites). Hispanistas categorically refuse to make Mexico's ancient civilization a national and group pride. Although the Mexican Republic's flag bears the Aztec symbol, the conservative elite disliked the indigenous people and did not want to associate them with a "glorious" past. During the reign of President Antonio López de Santa Anna, Mexican intellectuals who were pro-indigenistas did not receive much support. After the overthrow of Santa Anna in 1854, scholars interested in Mexico's native past became increasingly active. Liberals tended to sympathize with the natives and their history but felt that the critical problem to be solved was the "Indian Problem".

Thanks to the commitment of liberals to achieve equality before the law, indigenous figures who managed to rise in rank (such as Benito Juárez who has a Zapotek background and rose through the ranks of liberals to eventually become the first native Mexican president, or scholar and politician Ignacio Altamirano whose background is behind Nahua) felt that liberalism was the perspective needed to move forward. Regarding efforts to investigate Mexico's indigenous past, the moderate liberal José Fernando Ramírez is a figure who has made many contributions. He served as director of the National Museum and conducted studies using codices, but at the same time kept his distance from the clashes between liberals and conservatives that resulted in civil war. Mexican scholars researching Aztec history in the late 19th century include Francisco Pimentel, Antonio García Cubas, Manuel Orozco y Berra, Joaquín García Icazbalceta, and Francisco del Paso y Troncoso. In the late 19th century, the Aztec civilization began to become a national pride in Mexico. This era was dominated by a liberal military hero named Porfirio Díaz. He was a mestizo originally from Oaxaca and served as President of Mexico from 1876 to 1911. The policy of opening up to foreign investors and modernizing the country with an iron fist to stop riots took a toll on native Mexicans. Despite this, the Díaz government funds archaeological research and efforts to protect and preserve ancient monuments. As a result, "experts find it better to focus on Indians who have been dead for centuries." One of President Díaz's policies was to erect a Monument to Cuauhtémoc on Paseo de la Reforma, Mexico City. This monument he inaugurated in 1887.

Later, in the world's fairs at the end of the 19th century, the Mexican pavilion strongly demonstrated its indigenous past, especially with regard to the Aztecs. Mexican scholars such as Alfredo Chavero helped build a cultural image of Mexico during the exhibitions. The Mexican Revolution (1910–1920) and the struggles of indigenous peoples have prompted the government to support a political and cultural movement called indigenismo. Symbols of the Aztec past are also present in various places, especially in Diego Rivera's Mexican muralism. In their works, Mexican writers such as Octavio Paz and Agustin Fuentes have studied the use of Aztec symbols by the modern states of Mexico, and they have criticized the use of indigenous culture for political purposes, but at the same time they have also used symbolic expression in their works. For example, Paz criticized the design of the National Museum of Anthropology which shaped the view that Mexican history culminated in the Aztec period as a nationalistic appropriation of Aztec culture. Nahuatl is now spoken by about 1.5 million people, mostly in the mountainous region of central Mexico. Modern Mexican Spanish also has hundreds of loanwords from Nahuatl, and many of these words find their way into the vocabulary of common Spanish or even other languages ​​around the world. Place names in Nahuatl are scattered throughout various parts of Mexico, particularly in areas that were once Aztec centers. In addition, Nahuatl names can also be found in cities founded by Aztec warriors who assisted the Spanish conquistadors. As a result, cities that did not originally speak Nahuatl came to be known by their Nahuatl names. In Mexico City, there are various names honoring Aztec rulers, including the stations Moctezuma (named after Motecuzoma II) and Cuauhtemoc on line 1 of the Mexico City Metro.

Mexican dishes still use basic ingredients that originated in Mesoamerica, such as corn, chili peppers, beans, pumpkin, tomatoes and avocados. The Spaniards then introduced basic ingredients from the Aztecs to various parts of the world, so that now there are borrowed words from the Nahuatl language in various languages, such as chocolate, tomatoes, chilies, avocados, tamales, tacos, pupusas, chipotle, pozole, and atole. In addition, Mexican dishes have also spread to various countries, as a result of which the Aztec culinary heritage can be said to have spread globally. Today Aztec images and Nahuatl words are used to create a sense of authenticity or exoticism in Mexican marketing efforts. The idea of ​​the Aztec people has captured the imagination of Europeans since our first encounter with them, and has been the source of inspiration for many iconic symbols in Western popular culture. In his book entitled The Aztec Image in Western Thought, Benjamin Keen argues that Western thinkers usually view Aztec culture through the lens of their own cultural interests. The Aztec people and figures from Aztec mythology appear in Western culture. The name Quetzalcoatl, the feathered serpent god, has been used in the name of a genus of pterosaurs, Quetzalcoatlus, a large flying reptile with a wingspan of up to 11 meters (36 feet). Quetzalcoatl has been featured frequently in books, films and video games. D. H.
