Lawrence gave the title Quetzalcoatl to an early draft of his novel which was eventually changed to The Plumed Serpent at the urging of the publisher, Alfred A. Knopf. American writer, Gary Jennings, wrote two famous historical novels set in Mexico during the Aztec period, namely Aztec (1980) and Aztec Autumn (1997). These two novels were so popular that four more in the Aztec series were written after his death.

Zohary and Hopf note that it is not certain which natural type of Trigonella strain was later domesticated as fenugreek but it is believed that the plant was introduced for cultivation in the Near East. Clabet remains have been found at Tell Halal, Iraq, (based on radiocarbon analysis dated to 4000 BC) and the Bronze Age at Lachish, as well as dried seeds found in Tutankhamen's tomb. Cato the Elder lists fenugreek with clover and vetch as crops grown to feed cattle (De Agri Cultura, 27). The main production of klabet is Nepal, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Argentina, Egypt, France, Spain, Turkey, Morocco and China. India is the largest klabet producing country in the world in the Rajasthan, Gujarat, Uttaranchal, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Haryana and Punjab regions, which are the largest production centers in India, accounting for 80% of the country's total production. Qasoori Methi, more popular for its appetizing aroma, comes from Qasur, Pakistan, which is fed by water from the Sutlej River, in India and Pakistan in the Punjab region. (sources: T. Jilani PhD, Arizona, DASD 2007) The yellow to amber-colored klabet seeds are often used to make pickles, curry powder and curry paste, and klabet is often associated with Indian cuisine.

the dried leaves or called tamani methi (or kasoori methi in India), after the Kasur region of Punjab Province, Pakistan, where the plant is widely grown - has a bitter taste and pungent aroma. When harvested as a green seed it is called Samudra Methi, in Maharashtra, especially around Mumbai, where it is often grown near beaches that have sandy soil, hence the name (Samudra meaning sea in Sanskrit. Fenugreek seeds are believed to increase milk production. From the results of the study it was found that klabet is a potent stimulator for milk production which is estimated to have the ability to increase breast milk by as much as 90%. Non-clinical test reports show that klabet can function as a antiviral because it can cure fever common in volunteer groups. These results can be continued for clinical trials in the future. Arthritis has a low incidence rate in India which consumes large amounts of clambola. Drinking 1 cup of tea made from fenugreek leaves per day can reduce discomfort in cases of arthritis. Fenugreek seeds are a rich source of polysaccharides (polysaccharide) and galactomannan (galactomannan). Clabet seeds are also a source of saponin compounds such as diosgenin, yamogenin, gitogenin, tigogenin, and neotigogens. Other active constituents are mucilage, volatile oil, and alkaloids such as choline and trigonelline. Clabet is known as a medicinal ingredient in mainland China under the name Hu Lu Ba, which is believed to be efficacious as a warmer and strengthens the kidneys, relieves fever and relieves pain.

The movement is named after the French reformer John Calvin. Sometimes this variant of Protestant Christianity is called Reformed theology. There are also those who call it Hervormd theology, Hervormd faith, or Hervormd traditionalists. Reformed theology was developed by theologians such as Martin Bucer, Heinrich Bullinger, Peter Martyr Vermigli, and Huldrych Zwingli and was also influenced by English reformers such as Thomas Cranmer and John Jewel. But because of John Calvin's great influence and role in the confessional and ecclesiastical debates throughout the 17th century, this tradition has come to be commonly known as Calvinism. Today, the term also refers to the doctrines and practices of the Reformed Church, of which Calvin was one of its first leaders, and this system is best known for its doctrines of predestination and total desolation.-45. John Calvin's international influence in the development of Protestant Reformation doctrines begins when he was 25 years old, when he began writing his first edition of the Institutio: Teaching the Christian Religion in 1534 (published in 1536). This work underwent a number of revisions during its lifetime, including an impressive translation into colloquial French. Through the Institutes along with Calvin's polemical and pastoral works, his contributions to confessional documents for use in churches, and his generous contributions in the form of commentaries on the Bible, Calvin exerted a major personal influence on Protestantism. He was just one of many others who influenced the doctrines of the Reformed churches, although he eventually became the most prominent. Reformed churches, as well as Calvinistic ones, belong to the second stage of the Protestant Reformation, when Evangelical churches began to form after Martin Luther was expelled from the Catholic Church.

Calvin is a French refugee in Geneva. He had signed the Augsburg Lutheran Confession of Faith after it was revised by Melanchthon in 1540, but his influence was first felt in the Swiss Reformation, which was not Lutheran in nature, but rather followed Ulrich Zwingli. From the start it was clear that the doctrine of the Reformed churches developed in a direction independent of Luther, under a number of writers and reformers, including the later prominent Calvin. Much later, when his fame was associated with the Reformed churches, his entire body of teachings came to be referred to as "Calvinism." Although much of Calvin's practice took place in Geneva, his publications spread his ideas about the true reformed church to many parts of Europe. Calvinism became the theological system of the majority church in Scotland (see John Knox), the Netherlands, and parts of Germany (especially the neighboring Netherlands) and was influential in then-independent France, Hungary, Transylvania, and Poland. Calvinism was once popular in Scandinavia, especially Sweden, but was later rejected after the Uppsala synod in 1593 preferring Lutheranism. Most settlers in the Mid-Atlantic and New England, USA, were Calvinists, including French Puritans and Huguenots and Dutch settlers in New Amsterdam (New York). The Dutch Calvinist settlers were also the first successful European colonists in South Africa, dating back to the 17th century. They became known as the Boers or Afrikaners. Most of Sierra Leone is inhabited by Calvinist settlers from Nova Scotia, who are mainly black loyalists, that is, black people who fought for Britain during the American War of Independence. John Marrant founded a congregation there under the auspices of the Huntingdon Connection. Others say that Lusitania means "City of light". The Romans, such as Pliny Senior (Natural History, 3.5) and Varro (cited by Pliny), speculated that the name Lusitania was of Roman origin, as when Pliny said lusum enim liberi patris aut lyssam cum eo bacchantium nomen dedisse lusitaniae et pana praefectum eius universae: that Lusitania got its name from the lusus attributed to Bacchus and the lyssa of his Bacchantes, and that Pan was its governor. Lusus is usually translated as 'game', while lyssa is a loan word from the Greek λυσσα, 'drunk' or 'wrath' (and is sometimes the personification of both). Other translations take both words as their proper names: Lusus and Lyssa become the living companions of Bacchus. Os Lusíadas of Luís de Camões, who describes Lusus as the founder of the Lusitania, follows this translation. The Lusitani people, who are an Indo-European people and may have come from the Alps, settled in the region in the 6th century BC, but historians and archaeologists are still uncertain about their origins.

Some modern writers regard them as indigenous peoples who were culturally and possibly through intermarriage made Celtic. This hypothesis is also supported by Avienus, who wrote ORA MARITIMA, which was inspired by documents from the 6th century BC. Researcher Lambrino defends the notion that the Lusitanians were a tribal group of Celtic origin related to the Lusones (a people who inhabited the eastern region of Iberia). Likely, both tribes came from the mountains of Switzerland. But some others argue that the Lusitanians are an indigenous Iberian ethnic group, which was formed due to mixed marriages between various tribes. The first areas colonized by the Lusitani were probably the Douro valley and the region of Beira Alta (now Portugal); in Beira they remained until they defeated the Celtic and other tribes, then they expanded their territory to include the area of ​​Estremadura before the arrival of the Romans. The Lusitanians are mentioned for the first time in Livy (218 BC) and are described as Carthaginian mercenaries; they reportedly fought against the Romans in 194 BC, occasionally allying themselves with other Celtiberian tribes. In 179 BC the praetor Lucius Postumius Albinus celebrated a victory over the Lusitani, but in 155 BC, first under Punicus (possibly a Carthaginian general) and later Cesarus, the Lusitani reached Gibraltar. Servius Sulpicius Galba built a deceitful truce, but when the Lusitani celebrated this new alliance, he massacred them, selling the survivors into slavery. The Romans had other victories with the proconsuls Decimus Junius Brutus and Marius (113 BC), but the Lusitani fought back with a long guerrilla war; they were later joined by the troops of Sertorius (a renegade Roman general) and were finally defeated by Augustus. 152 BC – From this time the Roman Republic had difficulty recruiting troops for the wars in Hispania, which were considered particularly brutal. Editor's page logged out learn more Uttarakhand (Hindi: उत्तराखंड), is a state of the 27th Republic of India as of November 9, 2000. Uttarakhand is bordered by the Tibet Autonomous Region (China) to the north, and Nepal to the north. east. While in the west it is bordered by the states of Himachal Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh in the south. The state's capital is Dehradun. This state is often referred to as the Land of the Gods (Hindi: देव भूमि, Dev Bhumi) because many holy Hindu temples are found in this area. The area is traditionally referred to as Uttarakhand in Hindu scriptures and Sanskrit, a term derived from the Sanskrit "Uttara" (उत्तर) meaning north, and "khaṇḍ" (खण्ड्) meaning a country or a part of a country. Uttarakhand has an area of ​​53,566 km². Uttarakhand is home to several important educational institutions, including Asia's oldest engineering college, the Indian Institute of Technology at Roorkee and Govind Ballabh Pant University of Agriculture & Technology at Pantnagar University. Other important educational institutions are the Indian Military Academy in Dehradun, Forest Research Institute in Dehradun, Uttaranchal Institute of Technology in Dehradun. Uttarakhand has a terrain extending from the Ganges Plain south over the foothills of the Himalayas to the lofty Nanda Dewi mountain range (7816 m), the highest mountain situated entirely within India. The state of Uttarakhand consists of two mountainous regions in the western Garhwal and Kumaon in the east, and within the narrow strip of the Southern Ganges Plain. In the mountains there is Mount Garhwal which is considered sacred because it is the source of water from the Ganges and Yamuna rivers. According to the 2011 Census of India, Uttarakhand has a population of 10,086,292.

The editor page has logged out learn more Detergents are mixtures of various ingredients, used to aid cleaning and are made from petroleum-derived ingredients. Compared to soap, detergent has the advantage of having better washing power and not being affected by water hardness. In general, detergents contain the following ingredients: Surfactants (surface active agents) are surface active agents that have different ends, namely hydrophilic (like water) and hydrophobic (like fat). This active ingredient functions to reduce the surface tension of water so that it can release dirt that sticks to the surface of the material. Basically, surfactants have ionic properties (electrical charge) and are categorized into three types of surfactants, namely: 1. Anionic Surfactants Anionic surfactants carry a negative charge so they react with positively charged ions in hard water. To note, hard water contains magnesium and calcium compounds. Anionic surfactants react with compounds in hard water to neutralize them. 2. Cationic surfactants Anionic surfactants carry a negative charge so they react with positively charged ions in hard water. To note, hard water contains magnesium and calcium compounds. Anionic surfactants react with compounds in hard water to neutralize them. 3. Nonionic Surfactants Because nonionic surfactants have no charge, they do not ionize in water. This type of surfactant helps clean oily stains through the emulsification process. Builder is a key component that can help optimize the way surfactants work. This booster or builder works to reduce calcium and magnesium ions so that the detergent can clean properly. Sodium tripolyphosphate (STPP) is an example of a widely used reinforcer. STTP is also able to maintain alkaline conditions when washing greasy dirt, is able to protect the washing machine from rust, and helps keep dirt in the washing water so it doesn't stick to clothes again.

The editor page has logged out learn more Preventive medicine (English: preventive medicine or preventive healthcare) or prophylaxis (derived from the Greek "προφύλαξις" to guard or prevent) is the science and art of preventing disease, prolonging life, and promote physical and mental health. Disease and disability are influenced by environmental, genetic, disease agents, and lifestyle choices and are dynamic processes that begin before a person becomes aware that he or she is affected. Every year, millions of people die from preventable causes. A 2004 study showed that about half of all deaths in the United States in 2000 were caused by preventable behaviors and exposures. Among the leading causes of these deaths are cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease, accidental injury, diabetes mellitus, and certain infectious diseases. The study also estimates that 400,000 people die each year in the United States due to poor diet and a sedentary lifestyle. According to estimates by the World Health Organization (WHO), of the approximately 55 million people who died worldwide in 2019, three-quarters of them died from non-communicable diseases, including coronary heart disease, stroke and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Preventive medicine is becoming increasingly important due to the increasing prevalence of chronic diseases and deaths from these diseases worldwide. There are many efforts to prevent the disease, one of which is preventing youth from smoking through the provision of information. Both adults and children are advised to visit a doctor for routine check-ups—even if they feel healthy—to screen for disease, identify risk factors for disease, discuss healthy and balanced lifestyle behaviors, follow immunization progress and including its repeat administration, and maintain relationships well with health care providers.

The Vedas are a collection of ancient literature from the ancient Indian era which are numerous and extensive. In Hindu teachings, the Vedas are included in the Sruti class (literally "that which is heard"), because Hindus believe that the contents of the Vedas are a collection of revelations from Brahman (God). The Veda is believed to be the oldest literature in human civilization that still exists today. In the early days of the revelation, the Vedas were passed down/taught in an oral system—teaching by word of mouth, which at that time had not yet been invented in writing—from teacher to student. After writing was found, the Rishis put the Vedic teachings into written form. The Vedas are apaurusheya in nature, because they come from revelation, were not composed by humans, and are eternal. Maharesi Byasa, rearranged the Vedas and divided the Vedas into four main sections, namely: Regveda, Yajurweda, Samaweda and Atharwaweda. These were all composed at the beginning of the Kaliyuga. Etymologically, the word Veda is derived from the word vid, which in Sanskrit means "to know", in the Indo-European language family it is rooted from the word weid, which means "to see" or "to know". weid is also the root word for wit in English, as is vision in Latin. Upaveda is a derivative of the Veda which is a more specific department of science in life applications. Upaveda is classified into several majors, including: Several fields of knowledge such as Jyotisha (Astrology), Tantra, Shiksha and Vyakara (Grammar) are also based on the Vedas. The Vedas contain the concept of creation which is primitive and straightforward. One of the concepts of creation is conveyed by the example of plants.

The editor's page has logged out learn more Titus is a male name in Greek/Roman. This name is especially known in the New Testament records of the Christian Bible as a Christian in the first century AD who had a significant contribution in maintaining the unity and integrity of the congregations that had existed in the early church. At a time when problems arose in the Christian congregation in the first century, and solving them required courage and obedience, one man who successfully faced more than one such challenge was Titus. As a fellow worker with the apostle Paul, he made a real effort to help others do things in the Christian way. Titus was indeed a co-worker the apostle Paul could rely on in helping to keep the Christian congregation clean in the first century. Hence, Paul told the Christians in Corinth that Titus was 'a fellow worker for them.' Titus was an uncircumcised Greek who later converted to Christ. Paul refers to him as "the true son according to the faith shared," so Titus may have been one of the apostle's spiritual children. Titus accompanied Paul, Barnabas, and several other companions from Antioch, Syria when they went to Jerusalem in about 49 C.E. to discuss the question of circumcision. It has been suggested that because the conversion of uncircumcised "heathens" (in the sense of "non-Jews") was being discussed in Jerusalem, Titus was brought along to demonstrate that both Jews and Gentiles could gain God's approval regardless of their circumcision. or not. Some former Pharisees who after accepting Christianity became members of the congregation in Jerusalem argued that converts of Gentiles were required to be circumcised and observe the Jewish religious Law, but this argument was challenged.

Forcing Titus and other Gentiles to be circumcised was tantamount to denying that salvation depended on God's undeserved kindness and on faith in Jesus Christ and not on the works of the Law. It is also tantamount to rejecting the evidence that Gentiles, or people from other nations, have received God's Holy Spirit. When the circumcision issue was resolved, Paul and Barnabas were given full authority to preach to the nations. At the same time, they and their colleagues, including Titus, also try to always pay attention to the poor. Titus is then mentioned in the inspired account some six years later, when he was in Corinth as Paul's messenger to organize a collection for the saints. However, when Titus did this work, he found himself in a tense situation. Paul's letter to the Corinthians reveals that it was first addressed to the Corinthians to "cease mingling with fornicators." He must tell them to remove the fornicators from their midst. Yes, Paul wrote a strong letter to them, doing so "with many tears." Meanwhile, Titus was sent to Corinth to help collect donations being made there for needy Judean Christians. Likely, he was also sent to observe the Corinthian response to Paul's letter. Anxious to find out, Paul may have sent Titus from Ephesus across the Aegean Sea to Corinth, with instructions to report back as soon as possible. If the mission was completed before sailing was decommissioned for the winter (roughly mid-November), Titus could have gone to Troas by ship or taken the longer route via the Hellespont.

Paul probably arrived at the agreed meeting place in Troas early, since the riot sparked by the silversmiths caused him to leave Ephesus sooner than anticipated. Hence, Paul struck out overland in the hope of meeting Titus along the way. At this time in mainland Europe, Paul may have been traveling along the Via Egnatia, and finally he met Titus in Macedonia. Paul could feel relieved and rejoiced at receiving the good news from Corinth. The congregation had handled the apostle's counsel well. Although Paul wondered what kind of welcome his envoy would receive, God helped Titus to fulfill his commission. Titus was received with "fear and trembling". In the words of commentator W. D. Thomas, "we may presume that without weakening Paul's condemnation, Titus] argued skillfully and wisely before the Corinthians, convincing them that Paul, in delivering these words, had only their spiritual welfare in mind. ". As time went on, Titus came to love the Corinthian Christians because of their obedient attitude and the positive changes they made. Their commendable attitude has been a source of encouragement to him. What about the other aspect of Titus' mission to Corinth — organizing the collection for the holy ones in Judea - Titus had been working on that as well, as can be deduced from information found in 2 Corinthians. The letter was likely written in Macedonia in the fall of 55 C.E., shortly after Titus and Paul met. Paul wrote that Titus, who had initiated the collection, was now being sent back with two unnamed helpers in order to complete it. Sincerely interested in the Corinthians, Titus was very willing to return.

When Titus made his way to Corinth, he evidently took Paul's second inspired letter to the Corinthians. Not only was Titus a good organizer, but he could also be entrusted with complex tasks in difficult situations. He is brave, mature, and determined. Certainly, Paul considered Titus up to the challenge from the "very great apostles" from Corinth. This impression of Titus is confirmed when he is again mentioned in the Bible, in another difficult assignment. Likely, sometime between 61 and 64 C.E., Paul wrote a letter to Titus, who was then serving on the Mediterranean island of Crete. Paul left him there to "correct the things that were not good" and to "assign elders in city after city." In general, the Cretans were known as "liars, harmful beasts, idle gluttons." Therefore, in Crete, Titus was again required to act with courage and determination. The task required a great deal of responsibility, for it could define Christianity on the island. Under inspiration, Paul helped Titus by detailing the criteria for prospective church overseers/elders. Even today, these requirements are still taken into consideration when appointing Christian elders. The Bible does not indicate when Titus left Crete. He was there long enough because Paul asked him to look after the needs of Zenas and Apollos, who stopped there on their way at an unspecified time. But Titus couldn't be there too long. Paul was to send Artemas or Tychicus there, and then Titus was expected to meet the apostle at Nicopolis, which was probably the leading city in northwestern Greece.

Editor's logged out page learn more The Republic of Benin, formerly Dahomey, is a country in western Africa. The country is bordered by Togo to the west, Nigeria to the east, and Burkina Faso and Niger to the north. During French colonial rule and after independence on August 1, 1960, the country was named Dahomey after its predecessor kingdom, the Kingdom of Dahomey. On November 30, 1975, the country was renamed Benin following the Marxist-Leninist military coup. The Bay of Benin borders this country and the name of the bay is taken from the name of the Kingdom of Benin which is located in present-day Nigeria. The African kingdom of Dahomey arose in Benin. Since the 17th century, the kingdom was ruled by the oba, far beyond the borders of present-day Benin, covering most of West Africa. This prosperous kingdom was an "exporter" of slaves and traded with the Portuguese and the Dutch. But chaos here eventually resulted in Dahomey being colonized by the French in 1892. In 1904, Dahomey became a part of French West Africa, no longer Dahomey. In 1958, Dahomey was granted autonomy, and full independence was achieved in 1960. A period of turbulence followed independence, and there were several coups and regime changes before Mathieu Kérékou took power. Kérékou embraced Marxism, and the country was renamed "Benin". In the late 1980s, Kérékou abandoned Marxism and made the decision to re-establish democracy. He was defeated in the 1991 election, but won again in 1996. The overall shape of the country is bounded by the Niger River in the north and the coastal plains in the south, with the east being slightly rugged. The northern part of the country is mainly composed of semi-arid savannas and mountains. Its highest point is Mount Sagboroa at 658 m. The south of the country consists of a spreading marshy coastal plain, lakes and lagoons such as Lake Nohoué or the lagoon at Porto Novo.

Most of the population lives on the coast, where most of Benin's major cities are concentrated, particularly Porto Novo and Cotonou. The country is located in the intertropical zone, the climate is dry and humid, compared to the rains, which occur 10 times (April to July and September to November). The International Court of Justice at the Hague declared on 12 July 2005 the border between Benin and Niger included the islands on the banks of the Niger and Mékrou rivers: the 16 new islands were assigned to Benin, and Lété to Niger. The climate is tropical, hot and dry along with the seasonality of the geography across the country, the seasons are clear and alternating. Stretching 900 to 1300 mm of water, the areas that receive the most rain are in the southeast corner, Cotonou to Porto Novo, between Atacora-Natitingou and Djougou, the Dassa and Ndali regions north of Parakou. Maximum rainfall is in the south (equatorial climate), in mid-March to July, and rainfall decreases in November/December. Monsoons, blow from April to November, in the southeast. The dry Harmattan blows in the opposite direction of the monsoons, November to May, producing an orange dust. The humidity level, always high, is between 65 and 95%. Average temperatures include 22 and 34°C, hot in April and May (right after the Harmattan blows for 6 months, after monsoons that bring rain). There are several lakes in Benin, including: Lake Ahémé, Lake Aziri, Lake Nokoué, Lake Porto Novo, Lake Sele, Lake Toho, and Togbadji Lagoon. Benin's politics take place within the framework of a presidential representative democratic republic, in which the President of Benin is the head of state and head of government, and a multiparty system takes various forms.

Executive power is held by the government. Legislative power is held by the government and the legislature. The judiciary is independent from executive and legislative powers. Its current political system descends from the 1990 constitution of Benin and the transition to democracy in 1991. Benin is divided into 12 departments: Benin's economy remains undeveloped and dependent on subsistence agriculture, cotton production, and regional trade. The average growth in output has actually stabilized at 5% in the last 6 years, but a fast growing population has offset this growth. Inflation has decreased over the last few years. In order to develop further growth, Benin plans to attract more foreign investment, place greater emphasis on tourism, facilitate the growth of food and agricultural product processing systems, and promote new information and communication technologies. The 2001 privatization policy continued in telecommunications, water, electricity and agriculture despite the government's initial reluctance. The Paris Club and bilateral creditors have reduced debt, while pressing for accelerated structural reforms. Benin is composed of 40 different ethnicities, the most numerous of which are the Fon, who make up 49% of Benin's population. Other ethnicities include Adja, Yoruba, Somba, and Bariba. In terms of currency, this currency began to be used on January 1, 1999, but physically it was only used on January 1, 2002. Euro banknotes everywhere have the same appearance and picture, but the reverse side of the coins varies in each country. The coins of each country are marked with the identity symbol of each EU member state in the Eurozone (Eurozone). The euro is the second largest reserve currency as well as the second most traded currency in the world after the United States dollar. As of December 2019, with over €1.3 trillion in circulation, the euro has one of the highest combined values ​​of notes and coins in circulation in the world. In July 2012, the euro fell below US$1.21 for the first time in two years, following worries over Greece's debt and Spain's troubled banking sector. The euro is divided into 100 cents (also referred to as euro cents, especially when to distinguish it from other currencies, and referred to as the common side of all penny coins). In the legislative act of the Community, the plurals euro and cent are spelled without the s, as opposed to normal English usage. Otherwise, the normal English plural is used, with many local variations such as centime in French. Coins issued in denominations of €2, €1, 50c, 20c, 10c, 5c, 2c and 1c. To avoid using the two smallest coins, some cash transactions are rounded to the nearest five cents in the Netherlands and Ireland (by agreement of both parties) and in Finland (by law).

This practice is discouraged by the commission, as is the practice of certain shops refusing to accept high-value euro notes. The design of the euro banknote has a common design on both sides. The design was created by Austrian designer, Robert Kalina. Notes are issued in €500, €200, €100, €50, €20, €10 and €5. Each banknote has its own color and is dedicated to an artistic period of European architecture. The front of the banknote has a window or gate while the back has a bridge, symbolizing the relationship between the states within the union and with the future. While the design is supposed to be without any identifiable characteristics, early designs by Robert Kalina were of certain bridges, including the Rialto and Pont de Neuilly, and were later made more general; the final designs still bore a very close resemblance to their specific prototypes; so they're not really generic. The monuments look similar enough to the different national monuments to please everyone. The special euro currency symbol (€) was devised after a public survey narrowed down the ten original proposals to two. The European Commission then chose a design by Belgian designer Alain Billiet. The Jaruk process is intended to preserve food, which is generally vegetables and eggs, so that it lasts longer and can be consumed at a later date. The preservatives used for the men'Jaruk process are tamarind, warm boiled water and salt. Just like other fermented foods, the Jaruk process increases the content of lactic acid bacteria, total phenolic and antioxidant activity. Lactic acid bacteria function to produce lactic acid which is useful for inhibiting the activity of spoilage bacteria and pathogens. The needle process only requires the material to be extracted, water and salt and a storage container. Generally, the material to be scooped must be washed thoroughly, then cut into small pieces and stored in a container. Storage life can be from days to more than a month. Jaruk Kalangkala uses Kalangkala fruit as the main ingredient for its jaruk process. The process of making Jaruk Kalangkala is by boiling the kalangkala fruit along with other spices such as chili, shallots, garlic, sugar and salt. After finishing boiling, this jaruk is left for 1 hour or more before it can be consumed. The penjarukan process will produce a savory, salty and slightly sour taste which will increase your appetite. Jaruk Manday uses Cempedak outer skin that has been peeled and washed clean and cut into small pieces. The pieces of cempedak skin are then stored in a container with water and salt for at least 7 days. After the needle or fermentation process is complete, the texture of the jackfruit skin which was initially hard will become soft and ready to be processed again. The more salt given, the manday jar will last longer than usual.

Jaruk Tarap is basically the same as Jaruk Manday, namely using Tarap fruit and soaking it in salty water which is stored in a container. But the difference is the part of the fruit used and the cut. In jaruk tarap, the fruit is cut crosswise so as to produce thick round pieces and use the flesh of the fruit that is still young. The manufacturing process is to separate the fruit pulp to be used from the skin, then put it in a jar and sprinkle with salt and let it sit for one day so that it seeps into the fruit flesh. Editor's page logged out learn more Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health science Astrobiology (sometimes called exobiology, exopaleontology, bioastronomy, and xenobiology) is the study of the origin, evolution, distribution, and future of life in the universe. This interdisciplinary field of science includes the search for habitable environments both within and outside the Solar System, the search for evidence of prebiotic chemistry, life on Mars and other bodies in the Solar System, laboratory and field research on the origin and early evolution of life on Earth, and studies of the potential of life on Earth. live to adapt on Earth and in outer space. Astrobiology makes use of molecular biology, biophysics, biochemistry, chemistry, astronomy, physical cosmology, exoplanetology and geology to investigate the possibility of life on other worlds and help identify biospheres that may differ from those on Earth. The origin and early evolution of life is an integral part of the discipline of astrobiology. Astrobiology is concerned with the interpretation of existing scientific data. Astrobiology is concerned with itself primarily with hypotheses that conform to existing scientific theories. This interdisciplinary field includes research on the origin of planetary systems, the origin of organic compounds in outer space, rock-water-carbon interactions, abiogenesis on Earth, planetary habitability, research on biosignatures for the detection of life, and studies on the potential for life to adapt to challenges on Earth and in outer space. Biochemistry may have begun shortly after the Big Bang, 13.8 billion years ago, during the habitable age when the universe was only 10-17 million years old. According to the panspermia hypothesis, microscopic life — distributed by meteoroids, asteroids, and other small Solar System bodies — may exist throughout the universe. According to research published in August 2015, very large galaxies may be more favorable for the creation and development of habitable planets than smaller galaxies like the Milky Way.

Nonetheless, Earth is the only place in the universe known to man to harbor life. Estimates of the habitable zone around other stars, sometimes referred to as the "Goldilocks zone" have coincided with the discovery of hundreds of exoplanets and new insights into extreme habitats. here on Earth, suggest that there may be more habitable places in the universe than was thought until recently. Current studies of the planet Mars by the Curiosity and Opportunity probes are underway to look for evidence of ancient life as well as plains associated with ancient rivers or lakes that may have inhabited it. The search for evidence of habitability, taphonomy (associated with fossils), and organic molecules on the planet Mars is now a major goal of NASA and ESA. Even if extraterrestrial life is never discovered, the interdisciplinary nature of astrobiology, and the cosmic and evolutionary perspectives it brings, could still yield a variety of benefits on Earth. The term was first proposed by the Russian (Soviet) astronomer Gavriil Tikhov in 1953. Astrobiology is etymologically derived from the Greek ἄστρον , astron, "constellation, star"; βίος , bios, "life"; and -λογία, -logia, study. Synonyms of astrobiology vary; However, synonyms are structured in relation to the most important sciences implied in their development: astronomy and biology. A close synonym is exobiology from the Greek Έξω, "external"; Βίος, bios, "live"; and λογία, -logia, study. The term exobiology was coined by molecular biologist and Nobel Prize winner Joshua Lederberg. Exobiology is considered to have a limited scope limited to the search for life beyond Earth, whereas the subject area of ​​astrobiology is broader and investigates the relationship between life and the universe, which includes the search for extraterrestrial life, but also includes research on life on Earth, its origins, evolution and limits.

Another term used in the past is xenobiology, a word used in 1954 by science fiction writer Robert Heinlein in his work The Star Beast. The term xenobiology is now used in a more specialized sense, meaning "biology based on alien chemistry", either of extraterrestrial or terrestrial (possibly synthetic) origin. Because alternative chemical analogues to some life processes have been created in laboratories, xenobiology is now considered a surviving subject. While astrobiology is an emerging and developing field, the question of whether life exists elsewhere in the universe is a verifiable hypothesis and thus a valid line of scientific inquiry. While once considered outside the mainstream of scientific inquiry, astrobiology has become a formal field of study. Planetary scientist David Grinspoon refers to astrobiology as a field of natural philosophy, which bases speculation on the unknown, on known scientific theories. NASA's interest in exobiology first began with the development of the US Space Program. In 1959, NASA funded its first exobiology project, and in 1960, NASA established the Exobiology Program, which is now one of the four major elements of NASA's current Astrobiology Program. In 1971, NASA funded an extraterrestrial intelligence search (SETI) search for radio frequencies of the electromagnetic spectrum for interstellar communications transmitted by extraterrestrial life outside the Solar System. NASA's Viking mission to Mars, launched in 1976, included three biological experiments designed to search for the metabolism of life now on Mars. Advances in astrobiology, observational astronomy, and the discovery of a large variety of extremophiles with the extraordinary ability to thrive in the harshest environments on Earth have led to speculation that life may develop on many extraterrestrial bodies in the universe.

A particular focus of current astrobiological research is the search for life on Mars because of this planet's proximity to Earth and its geological history. There is growing evidence to suggest that Mars previously had large amounts of water on its surface, water being considered an important precursor for the development of carbon-based life. The mission designed specifically to search for present-day life on Mars was the Viking program and the Beagle 2 probe. Viking's results were inconclusive and Beagle 2 failed minutes after landing. A future mission with a strong astrobiology role is the Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter which is designed to study Jupiter's frozen moons — some of which may have liquid water — should the mission not be aborted. In late 2008, the Phoenix lander investigated the environment for past and present microbial habitats on Mars, and researched the history of water there. The European Space Agency's astrobiology roadmap from 2016, identifies five main research topics and defines several key scientific goals for each topic. The five research topics are: 1) Origin and evolution of planetary systems 2) Origin of organic compounds in outer space 3) Rock-water-carbon interactions, organic synthesis on Earth, and steps leading to life 4) Life and habitability 5) Biological signatures to facilitate the detection of life. In November 2011, NASA launched the Mars Science Laboratory mission carrying the Curiosity rover, which landed on Mars in Gale Crater in August 2012. The Curiosity rover is currently investigating environments for past and present microbial life on the planet Mars. On December 9, 2013, NASA reported that, based on evidence from Curiosity studying Aeolis Palus, Gale Crater contains an ancient freshwater lake that could have been a hospitable environment for microbial life.

The European Space Agency is currently working with the Russian Federal Space Agency (Roscosmos) and developing the ExoMars astrobiological rover, which will launch in July 2020. Meanwhile, NASA is developing the Mars 2020 astrobiological rover and sample depository for later delivery back to Earth. When searching for life on other planets like Earth, a few simplifying assumptions are useful for reducing the size of the astrobiological task. One is the assumption that most life forms in our galaxy are based on carbon chemistry, as are all life forms on Earth. Carbon is famous for the incredibly wide variety of molecules that can be formed around it. Carbon is the fourth most abundant element in the universe and the energy needed to make or break bonds is just at the right level to build molecules that are not only stable, but also reactive. The fact that carbon atoms bond easily with other carbon atoms makes it possible to form very long and complex molecules. The presence of liquid water was an assumed requirement, as it is a common molecule and provides an excellent environment for the formation of complex carbon-based molecules that could eventually lead to the emergence of life. Some researchers posit mixed ammonia-water environments as possible solvents for various other types of hypothetical biochemistry. The third assumption is to focus on planets orbiting stars like the Sun to increase the likelihood of planetary habitability. Very massive stars have relatively short lifetimes, meaning that life may not have time to emerge on planets orbiting them. Very small stars give off so little heat and warmth that only planets in very close orbits around them would not freeze and in such close orbits and these planets would "lock in" to the star.

The extremely long life span of red dwarfs could allow the development of habitable environments on planets with thick atmospheres. This is important, because red dwarfs are the most numerous stars in the universe. (See Habitability of red dwarf systems). Since Earth is the only planet known to harbor life, there is no clear way of knowing whether this simplification assumption is true or false. Research on communication with extraterrestrial intelligence (CETI) focuses on crafting and deciphering messages that can theoretically be understood by other technological civilizations. Communication efforts by humans include broadcast mathematical languages, pictorial systems such as the Arecibo message and computational approaches to detecting and deciphering 'natural' language communication. The SETI program, for example, uses radio telescopes and optical telescopes to search for intentional signals from extraterrestrial intelligence. While some well-known scientists such as Carl Sagan have advocated sending messages into outer space, scientist Stephen Hawking warns against it, arguing that aliens may attack Earth solely for its resources and then leave. Most astrobiology research related to astronomy falls into the category of exoplanet detection, the hypothesis being that if life arose on Earth, it could also arise on other planets with similar characteristics. To that end, a number of instruments designed to detect Earth-sized exoplanets have been considered, most notably NASA's Terrestrial Planet Finder (TPF) and ESA's Darwin program, both of which have been cancelled. NASA launched the Kepler mission in March 2009, and the French Space Agency launched the COROT space mission in 2006. There are also several less ambitious ground-based efforts underway. The goal of this mission is not only to detect Earth-sized planets, but also to directly detect the light from these planets so that they can be studied spectroscopically.

By examining planetary spectra, it will be possible to determine the basic composition of the exoplanet's atmosphere and/or surface. With this knowledge, it is possible to assess the likelihood of life being found on that planet. NASA's research group, the Virtual Planet Laboratory, is using computer modeling to generate virtual planets to see what they would look like to TPF or Darwin. It is hoped that once these missions come online, their spectra can be cross-checked with that of this virtual planet for features that might indicate the presence of life. An estimate for the number of planets with intelligent communicative extraterrestrial life can be obtained from the Drake equation, essentially an equation that expresses the probability of intelligent life as the product of factors such as the fraction of potentially habitable planets and the fraction of planets on which life is likely to arise: N= R∗ × fp × ne × fl × fi × fc × L{\displaystyle N=R^{*}~\times ~f_{p}~\times ~n_{e}~\times ~f_{l}~\ times ~f_{i}~\times ~f_{c}~\times ~L} With: However, while the reasoning behind the equation is convincing, it is unlikely that it will have a reasonable margin of error any time soon. The problem with the formula is that it cannot be used to generate or support a hypothesis because it contains factors that can never be verified. The first variable, R*, the number of stars, is generally limited to a scale of a few magnitude levels (10n). The second and third variables, fp, star with planets and fe, planet with habitable conditions, are being evaluated for systems around these star systems. Drake originally formulated the equation simply as an item on the agenda for discussion at the Green Bank conference, but some applications of the formula have been taken literally and related to simplistic scientific or pseudoscientific arguments. Another related topic is the Fermi paradox, which proposes the argument that if intelligent life is a common condition in the universe, there should be clear signs of it.

Another active area of ​​research in astrobiology is the formation of planetary systems. It has been suggested that peculiarities of the Solar System (eg, the presence of Jupiter as a protective shield) may have greatly increased the likelihood of intelligent life emerging on our planet. Biology cannot state that a process or phenomenon, by being mathematically possible, must exist forcibly on a celestial object. Biologists define what is speculative and what is not. The discovery of extremophiles, organisms capable of surviving extreme environments, is a core research element for astrobiologists, because such organisms are important for understanding the four frontiers of life on a planetary scale: potential panspermia, forward contamination due to human exploration efforts, human colonization of the planet. , and the exploration of extinct and extant extraterrestrial life. Until the 1970s, life was thought to depend entirely on energy from the Sun. Plants on Earth's surface capture energy from sunlight to photosynthesize sugars from carbon dioxide and water, releasing oxygen in the process which is then consumed by oxygen-responding organisms, passing their energy up the food chain. Even life in the depths of the oceans, where sunlight cannot reach, is thought to obtain its food either from consuming organic detritus that rains down from the surface of the water or from eating animals that do. A planet's ability to support life is thought to depend on its access to sunlight. However, in 1977, during exploratory dives into the Galapagos Rift at the Alvin underwater probe, scientists discovered colonies of giant tubeworms, clams, crustaceans, clams, and various other creatures swarming around underwater volcanic features known as hydrothermal vents. These creatures thrived despite having no access to sunlight, and it was soon discovered that they comprised an entirely independent ecosystem.

Although most of these multicellular life forms require dissolved oxygen (produced by oxygenic photosynthesis) for their aerobic cellular respiration and are thus not completely independent of sunlight themselves, the basis of their food chain are bacterial forms which obtain their energy from the oxidation of reactive chemicals, such as hydrogen or hydrogen sulfide, which comes out of the interior of the earth. Other life forms that are completely decoupled from energy from sunlight are the green sulfur bacteria which capture geothermal light for anoxyogenic photosynthesis or the bacteria which carry out chemolithoautotrophy based on the radioactive decay of uranium. This chemosynthesis revolutionized the study of biology and astrobiology by revealing that life does not have to depend on the sun, it only needs water and an energy gradient to exist. Biologists have found extremophiles thriving in ice, boiling water, acids, alkalis, nuclear reactor water cores, salt crystals, toxic wastes and in a variety of other extreme habitats previously thought to be inhospitable to life. It breaks new ground in astrobiology by greatly expanding the number of possible extraterrestrial habitats. The characteristics of these organisms, their environment and evolutionary pathways, are considered important components for understanding how life could have evolved elsewhere in the universe. For example, some organisms that are able to withstand exposure to a vacuum and outdoor radiation include the lichen fungi Rhizocarpon geographicum and Xanthoria elegans, the bacteria Bacillus sapensis, Deinococcus radiodurans, Bacillus subtilis, the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the seeds of Arabidopsis thaliana (mouse ear watercress), as well as Tardigrada invertebrate animals. While tardigrades are not considered to be truly extremophiles, they are considered extrotolerant microorganisms that have contributed to the field of astrobiology. Extreme radiation tolerance and the presence of DNA protection proteins could provide answers as to whether life can survive away from the protection of Earth's atmosphere.

Jupiter's moon Europa and Saturn's moon Enceladus are now considered the most likely locations for extant extraterrestrial life in the Solar System due to their shared subsurface oceans of water, where radiogenic heating and tides allow liquid water to exist. . The origin of life, known as abiogenesis, as distinct from the evolution of life, is another ongoing area of ​​research. Oparin and Haldane postulated that conditions on early Earth were conducive to the formation of organic compounds from inorganic elements and thus to the formation of many of the chemicals common to all forms of life that we see today. The study of this process, known as prebiotic chemistry, has made some progress, but it remains unclear whether life could have formed in this way on Earth. An alternative hypothesis of panspermia is that the first elements of life may have formed on other planets with more favorable conditions (or even in interstellar space, asteroids, etc.) and then been brought to Earth - the panspermia hypothesis. The cosmic dust that pervades the universe contains complex organic compounds ("amorphous organic solids with mixed aromatic-aliphatic structures") that can be made naturally, and rapidly by stars. Furthermore, one scientist suggested that these compounds might be related to the development of life on Earth and said that, "If this is the case, life on Earth might be easier to start because these organic materials could serve as the basic building blocks for life." More than 20% of the carbon in the universe can be associated with polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), a possible starting material for the formation of life. PAHs appear to have formed shortly after the Big Bang, are widespread throughout the universe, and are associated with new stars and planets.

PAHs are exposed to interstellar medium conditions and transformed through hydrogenation, oxygenation and hydroxylation, into more complex organics - "a step along the path to amino acids and nucleotides, the raw materials of protein and DNA, respectively". Astroecology concerns the interactions of life with the environment and resources of outer space, on planets, asteroids and comets. On a larger scale, astroecology concerns the resources for life about stars in galaxies through the cosmological future. Astroecology seeks to measure future life in space, addressing this area of ​​astrobiology. Experimental astroecology investigates the soil resources of a planet, based on extraterrestrial materials found in meteorites. The results showed that Mars chondrite materials and carbon could support the cultivation of bacteria, algae and plants (asparagus, potatoes), with high soil fertility. These results support the argument that life can survive on watery asteroids and on similar materials imported to Earth via dust, comets and meteorites, and that such asteroid material could be used as soil for future space colonies. On the largest scale, cosmoecology concerns life in the universe during cosmological epochs. The main sources of energy are probably red giant stars and white and red dwarfs, which sustain life for up to 1020 years. Astroecologists suggest that their mathematical model can measure the amount of potential future life in space, enabling an expansion of biodiversity that could potentially lead to a wider variety of intelligent life forms. Astrogeology is a planetary science discipline concerned with the geology of celestial bodies such as the planets and their moons, asteroids, comets and meteorites. The information gathered by these disciplines allows a measure of the potential of a planet or natural satellite to develop and sustain life, or the habitability of a planet.

An additional discipline of astrogeology is geochemistry, which involves the study of the chemical composition of Earth and other planets, the chemical processes and reactions that govern the composition of rocks and soil, the cycles of matter and energy and their interactions with a planet's hydrosphere and atmosphere. Specializations include cosmochemistry, biochemistry and organic geochemistry. The fossil record provides the oldest known evidence of life on Earth. By examining the fossil evidence, paleontologists can better understand the types of organisms that arose on the ancient Earth. Some regions on Earth, such as the Pilbara in Western Australia and Antarctica's McMurdo Dry Valleys, are also thought to be analogous to geological regions on Mars, and as such, may provide clues as to how to look for past life on Mars. A variety of organic functional groups, consisting of hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur, and a number of metals, such as iron, magnesium, and zinc, provide for the wide variety of chemical reactions catalyzed by living organisms. In contrast, silicon interacts with only a few other atoms, and large silicon molecules are monotone compared to the combinatorial universe of organic macromolecules. Indeed, it appears that in general terms the basis of life elsewhere would be similar to that on Earth, if not in detail. Although terrestrial life and life that might have arisen independently of Earth are expected to share many similar—if not identical—foundations of life, they are also expected to possess some unique biochemical qualities. Whatever extraterrestrial life forms may emerge, their tendency to change their environment chemically like life on Earth may reveal their presence. People have long speculated about the possibility of life in conditions other than Earth, but speculation about the nature of life elsewhere often pays little attention to the constraints posed by biochemical properties.

The possibility that life throughout the universe may be carbon-based is supported by the fact that carbon is one of the most abundant of the elements heavier than hydrogen and helium. Only two naturally occurring atoms, carbon and silicon, are known to serve as the foundation of molecules large enough to carry biological information. As the structural basis for life, one of the important features of carbon is that, unlike silicon, it can easily engage in the formation of chemical bonds with many other atoms, thereby enabling the chemical flexibility necessary to carry out metabolic reactions and biological propagation. Thought about where life might occur in the Solar System has historically been limited by the understanding that life is ultimately dependent on light and warmth from the Sun and, therefore, confined to planetary surfaces. The four most likely candidates for life in the Solar System are the planet Mars, the Jovian moon Europa, and Saturn's satellites Titan and Enceladus. Mars, Enceladus and Europa are considered potential candidates in the search for life primarily because they may have underground liquid water, a molecule essential to life as we know it for its use as a solvent in cells. Water on Mars has been found frozen in its polar ice caps, and newly carved trenches recently observed on Mars suggest that liquid water may exist, at least temporarily, on the planet's surface. At the low temperatures and low pressures on Mars, liquid water tends to be very salty. As for Europa and Enceladus, huge global oceans of liquid water exist beneath the icy outer layers of these moons. This water may be warmed to a liquid state by volcanic vents on the ocean floor, but the main source of heat is probably tidal heating.

On December 11, 2013, NASA reported the detection of "clay-like minerals" (specifically, phyllosilicates) that are often associated with organic matter, in Europa's icy crust. The presence of minerals may be the result of collisions with asteroids or comets, according to scientists. Additionally, on June 27, 2018, astronomers reported the detection of complex macromolecular organic matter on Enceladus and, according to NASA scientists in May 2011, "emerges as the most habitable place outside Earth in the Solar System for life as we know it". The space object that has the potential to support extraterrestrial life is Saturn's largest moon, Titan. Titan has been described as having conditions similar to those of Earth at the start of its formation. On its surface, scientists have discovered the first liquid lake outside Earth, but this lake appears to be composed of ethane and/or methane rather than water. Some scientists suggest that these liquid hydrocarbons might replace water in living cells different from those on Earth. After studying the Cassini data, it was reported in March 2008 that Titan may also have an underground ocean composed of liquid water and ammonia. Measuring the ratio of hydrogen and methane levels on Mars can help determine the possibility of life on Mars. According to scientists, "...a low H2/CH4 ratio (less than about 40) indicates that life is possible and active." Other scientists recently reported methods for detecting hydrogen and methane in the atmospheres of extraterrestrial bodies. The complex organic compounds of life, including uracil, cytosine and thymine, have been formed in the laboratory under extraterrestrial conditions, using starting chemicals such as pyrimidine, which is found in meteorites. Pyrimidines, like polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), are the most abundant carbon-rich chemicals in the universe.

The Rare Earth Hypothesis posits that the multicellular life forms found on Earth may actually be rarer than scientists have thought. This provides a possible answer to the Fermi paradox which asks, "If extraterrestrial aliens are common, why are they obscure?" This seems to contradict the principle of mediocrity assumed by the famous astronomers Frank Drake, Carl Sagan, and others. The Principle of Mediocrity suggests that life on Earth is not extraordinary, and is more likely to be found in countless other worlds. Research into the limits of environmental life and how extreme ecosystems work is ongoing, enabling researchers to better predict what planetary environments are most likely to sustain life. Missions such as the Phoenix lander, the Mars Science Laboratory, ExoMars, the Mars 2020 rover to Mars, and the Cassini probe to the Saturn satellite aim to further explore the possibility of life on other planets in the Solar System. The two Viking landers each carried four types of biological experiments to the Martian surface in the late 1970s. It is the only Martian lander to carry out experiments looking for specific metabolism by microbial life currently on Mars. The lander uses a robotic arm to collect soil samples into a closed test container on board. The two landers were identical, so the same tests were carried out at two places on the Martian surface, Viking 1 near the equator and Viking 2 farther north. The results were inconclusive and are still being debated by some scientists. Beagle 2 was the UK's failed Mars lander mission and was part of the European Space Agency's Mars Express 2003 mission. The ultimate goal is to look for signs of life on Mars, past or present.

Despite landing safely, he is unable to properly use his solar panels and telecommunications antenna. The Mars Science Laboratory (MSL) mission landed the Curiosity rover currently operating on Mars. The mission launched on 26 November 2011 and touched down at Gale Crater on 6 August 2012. The mission's objectives are to help assess Mars' habitability and in doing so, determine whether Mars is capable or was ever capable of supporting life, gather data for future human missions, study the geology of Mars, its climate, and further assesses the role water, an essential ingredient for life as we know it, plays in forming minerals on Mars. The Tanpopo mission is an orbital astrobiology experiment investigating the potential for interplanetary transfer, life, organic compounds, and possibly terrestrial particles in low Earth orbit. The aim was to assess the panspermia hypothesis and the possibility of natural interplanetary transport of microbial life as well as prebiotic organic compounds. Early mission results showed evidence that some strains of microorganisms can survive for at least a year in space. This might support the idea that clumps of microorganisms larger than 0.5 millimeters could be one way for life to spread from one planet to another. The ExoMars rover is a robotic mission to Mars to search for possible biosignatures of Martian life, past or present. This astrobiological mission is currently being developed by the European Space Agency (ESA) in partnership with the Russian Federal Space Agency (Roscosmos), planned for launch in 2020.

The Mars 2020 rover mission is being developed by NASA for launch in 2020. It will investigate astrobiologically relevant environments on Mars, investigate surface geological processes and their history, including assessment of past habitability and potential for preservation of biosignatures and biomolecules in accessible geological materials. by rides. The mission's Science Definition team proposes that the rover collect and package at least 31 core rock and soil samples for future missions to bring back for more definitive analysis in a laboratory on Earth. The rover can carry out measurements and technology demonstrations to help human expedition designers understand the dangers posed by Martian dust and demonstrate how to collect carbon dioxide (CO2) which can be converted into a resource for making molecular oxygen (O2) and rocket fuel. Europa Clipper is a mission planned by NASA to launch in 2025 that will carry out detailed reconnaissance of Jupiter's moon Europa and will investigate whether its deep ocean can accommodate conditions suitable for life. This mission will also assist in the selection of future landing sites. Icebreaker Life is a lander mission that was originally proposed for NASA's Discovery Program for a 2021 launch opportunity, but was not selected for development. The mission will feature a stationary lander that will be a close copy of 2008's successful Phoenix and will carry an enhanced astrobiology scientific payload, including a 1-metre-long core drill for ice-cemented soil samples on the northern plains to conduct a search for organic molecules and evidence of current life. or the past on Mars. One of the main goals of the Icebreaker Life mission was to test the hypothesis that the ice-rich soils of the polar regions have significant concentrations of organics because they are protected by ice from oxidants and radiation.

Summarizing one of the islands of the Lesser Antilles, Barbados is located in the eastern part of the group. Barbados is known for its tourism industry and is known as the Little England or 'Little England' of the Caribbean. This is due to the strong British influence on this island. The island of Barbados is located 2,585 km southeast of Miami, United States of America and 860 km from Caracas, Venezuela. The original inhabitants of this island are the Arawak tribe. The tribe was later driven out by the Caribbean Indians in the early 14th century. In the early 15th century Spanish conquistadors arrived in Barbados and had taken the Caribbean tribes as slaves. As a result, the rest of these clans have moved to adjacent islands. Portuguese explorer Pedro a Campos had stopped on this island in 1536 during his journey to Brazil. He had named this island Los Barbados ('those who bear the beard'), probably after seeing the island's 'fig' tree, which had long hanging roots hanging down like a beard. Barbados was uninhabited when the English came to settle in 1627. Captain John Powell landed on Barbados in 1625 and declared this deserted island a British colony. Two years later, his brother Captain Henry Powell landed with 80 sailors and 10 slaves. The group had founded the first European settlement at Jamestown, on the West coast and now known as Holetown. By the end of 1628 the population of the colony had grown to 2,000 people. After a few years, colonists have cleared a lot of wilderness and planted tobacco and cotton. In the 1640s they replanted these fields with sugarcane.

Their plantations were the largest sugarcane plantations in the Caribbean islands, and the production of sugar was very profitable for the planters and settlers in Barbados. Due to the high demand for sugar, the slaves were brought from the African continent and worked in the existing sugar plantations until 1834 when the slavery system was abolished. But the economy of Barbados still depends on sugar, "rum" and "molasses" until the 20th century. In 1639, the settlers on this island formed a Legislative Assembly, which was the second parliament established in the British colony after Bermuda. All this time the people of Barbados were loyal to the King and after King Charles I was beheaded in 1649, Oliver Cromwell, the Prime Minister of Great Britain sent his army to Barbados to get their recognition. His army arrived in 1651 and a year later the 'Articles of Capitulation' were signed, which were the basis of the "Charter of Barbados". This charter guarantees the government of Barbados headed by a governor, independent representation, and freedom from taxation without local authority. When the King system was restored in 1660, this Charter gave more freedom to the people here. Racial discrimination is rampant on this island. Although the slavery system was abolished in 1834, there were still many slaves who were more comfortable living on the plantations. Blacks who refused to be slaves, were forced to live in wild settlements. When the economy fell (known as (The Great Depression) in the 1930s, unemployment increased, and living conditions became more and more acute until chaos broke out in these islands. To overcome political instability, the British had to give in to the black reformers and involve them into the country's political process. One of them was Grantley Adams, who 1 decade later was appointed as the first Prime Minister.

Barbados had attained self-governing status in 1961 and achieved independence in 1966. After World War II the sugar industry had declined, while the tourism sector had boomed. By the early 1990s tourism had become the largest sector in Barbados. Barbados is a somewhat flatter and steeper island in the mountainous center with the highest peak at Mount Hillaby (336 m). The island has a tropical climate, with a rainy season between June and October. The dry season is also between February and May. The capital is Bridgetown. Other major cities include Holetown and Speightstown. The Queen of Barbados is Queen Elizabeth II (1966-2021), more commonly known as the Queen of the United Kingdom. He is the head of state of Barbados and is represented by a Governor-General. In Barbados, Queen Elizabeth is known as "By the Grace of God, Queen of Barbados and of Her other Realms and Territories, Head of the Commonwealth." Barbados is divided into 11 regions or Parishes: On November 30, 2021, Barbados officially became a full-fledged Republic with Sandra Mason as the First President who became head of state replacing Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain.

At the handover of this independence, Rihanna was appointed as a national hero, and was attended by Prince Charles as a representative of Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain. Although its status has changed to that of a republic, Barbados remains part of the Commonwealth of Nations (Republic within the Commonwealth of Nations). Historically, Barbados' economy has depended on the cultivation of sugarcane and related activities, but in recent years it has developed in the production and tourism sectors. Tourism Finance Beaches and public services are the main source of foreign exchange, as well as the light spending sector. The government is always trying to reduce the unemployment rate, promote foreign workers, and private companies are still owned by government-owned companies. The economy had been in decline in 2001 due to humidity in tourism and consumer spending. Over 90% of the people of Barbados (also known as the Bajan) are black, and most of them are descendants of slaves who worked in the sugar fields. The rest of the population is European and Asian. The 2010 national census conducted by the Barbados Statistical Service reported that the population of Barbados was 277,821, of which 144,803 were women and 133,018 were men. The life expectancy of a resident of Barbados in 2020 is 80 years. The average life expectancy is 83 years for women, and 79 years for men. Barbados and Japan have the highest centenarian cases per capita in the world. Christianity is the largest religion in Barbados, with the largest denomination being Anglican at about 23.9% of the population in 2019. Other Christian denominations with a significant following in Barbados are the Catholic Church which is administered by the Roman Catholic Diocese, as well as the Pentecostals which have percentage reached 19.5% of the population.
