The editor page logged out learn more Lent (Latin: Quadragesima, "period of 40 days") is the period of Christian penance leading up to Easter. Lent begins on Ash Wednesday and ends about six weeks later, after sunset on Maundy Thursday or Holy Saturday (Easter Eve), depending on local denomination or customs. However, Lent practices continue until sunset on Holy Saturday. In Eastern Churches, both Eastern Orthodox, Eastern Lutheran, and Eastern Catholic, Lent ends at midday on Holy Saturday. Lent is a time when the faithful prepare for Easter with prayer, penance, repentance, charity, simple living and self-denial. Catholics, Eastern Orthodox, Oriental Orthodox, and Anglicans, Lutherans, Calvinists (including Presbyterians and Congregationals), Methodists, Moravians, Protestant Unions observe Lent. Some Anabaptist, Baptist, and Nondenominational Christian congregations also observe Lent. During Lent, many Christians observe the practice of fasting and abstaining from certain luxuries in order to emulate the practice of penance of Jesus Christ while seclusion in the desert for 40 days. This act is called a Lenten sacrifice. Many Christians also observe the spiritual disciplines of Lent, such as reading daily devotions or praying according to the Lenten calendar, with the goal of drawing closer to God. The Stations of the Cross service, a devotion to remember the sufferings of Christ carrying the cross all the way to his death on the cross, is also often carried out. In honor of Lent, many Catholic, Lutheran, Anglican, and Methodist churches do not decorate altars with floral wreaths, and cover crucifixes, church statues, and other religious symbols in mauve. Throughout the history of Christendom, several groups of people marked Lent by abstaining from meat, especially among Lutherans, Catholics, and Anglicans.

According to tradition, Lent lasts for 40 days, to commemorate the 40 days that Jesus ascended and was tempted by the Devil in the desert before working openly, as narrated in the Gospel of Matthew, the Gospel of Mark, and the Gospel of Luke. The last week of Lent is Holy Week, which starts on Palm Sunday. According to the history of the New Testament, the events of the crucifixion are commemorated on Good Friday, while the events of the resurrection of Jesus are celebrated with great fanfare at the beginning of Easter Sunday, the first day of Easter. The term "leaning" (before Easter) was originally used by Indonesian Catholics as a substitute for the phrase "fasting period", an old term which is a translation of the word vastentijd from Dutch. The term "fasting period" highlights the practice that is done. In other countries, terms that are synonymous with "fasting period" are postní doba in Czech, Fastenzeit in German, and fasten or fastetid in Norwegian. Other languages ​​use terms that can be translated as "great fasting" in Indonesian, for example الصوم الكبير (assaumul kabir) in Arabic, wielki post in Polish, великий пост (vieliki post) in Russian, and великий піст (velyky pist) in Ukrainian. The Greek and Latin terms for Lent highlight the period of time. In modern Greek, Lent is called Σαρακοστή (Sarakostí), a derivation of the old Τεσσαρακοστή (Tesarakostí), meaning "40 days". The Latin equivalent is quadragesima. This Latin word is the origin of the term Lent in the Romance languages ​​(quaresma in Catalan, Occitan and Portuguese, carême in French, coresma in Galician, quaresima in Italian, păresimi in Romanian, caresima in Sardinian , cuaresma in Spanish, cwareme in Walon) as well as languages ​​outside the Romance family (kreshma in Albanian, garizuma in Basco, korizma in Croatian, carghas in Irish and Scottish Gaelic, kwaresima in Swahili, kuwaresma in in Tagalog, c(a)rawys in Welsh).

Romanian also has the term postul mare which means "great fast", while Dutch also has the terms veertigdagentijd and quadragesima which mean "period of 40 days". Most Christians observe Lent starting on Ash Wednesday and ending on Maundy Thursday. The six Sundays are not counted, because each one is a "little Easter," the commemoration of Jesus' victory over sin and death. One notable exception is in The Archdiocese of Milan observes the Ambrosian Rite, in which Lent begins on the Sunday 6 weeks before Easter. Since the Second Vatican Council, the Roman Catholic church has designated Good Friday through Holy Saturday as the first two days of the "Easter Triduum" and no longer as the last two days of Lent, although Lent commemoration continues until the "Easter Vigil". In churches that follow the "Constantinople Rite" (eg Eastern Orthodox and Eastern Catholic churches), the 40 days of Lent are calculated differently, as are the different dates for Easter. Fasting begins on Clean Monday, including every Sunday, ending on the Friday before Palm Sunday. The special days of Lazarus Saturday ("Lazarus Saturday"), Palm Sunday and Holy Week are considered separate periods of fasting. This entire Lent is called the "Great Lent". In the Oriental Orthodox church, there are a number of local traditions during Lent. The Coptic Orthodox Church, Ethiopian Orthodox Church and Eritrean Orthodox Church observe the 8 weeks of Lent, which excludes Saturdays and Sundays, 40 days of fasting. The traditional carnival celebrations that precede Lent are held prior to fasting. The most famous is in Rio de Janeiro; alongside carnivals in Trinidad & Tobago, Venice, Cologne, Mobile in Alabama and New Orleans in Louisiana.

This event is known as Mardi Gras or "Shrove Tuesday" or "Fat Tuesday". Fasting during Lent was more severe in ancient times than today. Socrates Scholasticus notes that in some places all animal products were prohibited, while in others fish and birds were permitted, fruit and eggs were prohibited, and in others only bread was eaten. There are places where devotees abstain from food for a whole day; in others only one meal a day, or abstaining from food until 3 p.m. In many places, this fasting custom ends in the evening, where people only eat small meals without vegetables or alcohol. In the early Middle Ages, foodstuffs containing meat, eggs and dairy were generally prohibited. Thomas Aquinas argued that "they give more pleasure (than fish), and much nourishment to the body, so that eating them gives more advantages to the seminal processes, which when in excess give encouragement to the passions." However, dispensations for dairy materials were awarded as donations for the construction of a number of churches, including the "Butter Tower" in Rouen Cathedral. In Spain, the rules for the "Holy Crusade" (updated regularly after 1492) permitted the eating of milk and eggs during Lent in exchange for contributing to the conflict. Giraldus Cambrensis in his Itinerary of Archbishop Baldwin through Wales reports that "in Germany and the arctic," "the pious," ate the tail of the beaver as "fish" because of its resemblance to a fish and easy access. In western society this custom is now looser, although in the Eastern Orthodox, Oriental Orthodox and Eastern Catholic Churches, taboos still apply to all animal ingredients including fish, eggs, birds and milk from animals (goats or cows, not from soybeans or coconut), so only plant foods (vegetarians/vegans) are eaten during their 44 days of Lent. In the Roman Catholic Church it is expected to abstain from eating meat or other food every Friday throughout the year, unless that Friday happens to be a holiday.

On Ash Wednesday and Good Friday it is obligatory to observe abstinence and fast; while the details of the provisions are determined by each bishop. (Can. 1251-1253) Important days of Lent: In the Roman Catholic church, the Easter Triduum is a three-day observance that begins with the opening hymn of Mass for Holy Communion. After the observance of Maundy Thursday afternoon, the sacred host is solemnly taken from the altar to the repository where believers are invited to worship the "holy body of Christ". The following day, a liturgy was held commemorating Christ's suffering at 3 p.m. This service consists of readings from the Scriptures mainly from the Gospel of John about the Passion of Jesus Christ, followed by prayers, adoration of the cross of Jesus and then a Communion at which the hosts consecrated the evening consecrated before are distributed. The Easter Vigil in the evening between Holy Saturday evening and Easter Sunday dawn begins with a special fire and candle blessing with a Bible reading related to baptism, then singing Gloria in Excelsis Deo, the blessing of water, baptism and confirmation for adults, then the congregation is invited to renew their baptismal vows; finally the Mass was carried out as usual starting from the Preparation of the Offering onwards. Holy Week and Lent, depending on Christian denomination and local custom, end with the Easter Vigil on Holy Saturday evening or at dawn on Easter Sunday. There is a custom in some churches to hold morning services in an open field. In Roman Catholic, Lutheran, and many Anglican churches, priests dress in purple during Lent. On the 4th Sunday of Lent, it is okay to wear pink. In some Anglican churches a type of unbleached linen or muslin called Lenten array is worn during the first 3 weeks of Lent, then red during the Passiontide.

Koteka is a garment to cover the male genitalia in the culture of some of the indigenous people of the island of Papua. Koteka is made from the muzzle of the taong-taong bird (Riambo) and pumpkin skin. The mouth of the taong-taong bird can be obtained by hunting, this bird lives around this area, because the shape of this bird's mouth can function as a means of covering the male genitalia. Pumpkin (lagenaria siceraria) is a type of pumpkin that is white and long. This pumpkin is grown and processed to form what is called a koteka which is used by men. Contrary to popular belief, the size and shape of the koteka are not related to the status of the wearer. Size is usually related to the user's activities, going to work or ceremonies. Many of the tribes there can be recognized by the way they use the koteka. The short koteka is used when working, and the long one with decorations is used in traditional ceremonies. However, each tribe has a different form of koteka. The Yali people, for example, like the long shape of the pumpkin. While the Tiom people usually wear two pumpkins. Over time, the koteka became less and less popular for everyday use. Koteka is prohibited from being worn on public transport and in schools. Even if there is, koteka is only to be traded as a souvenir. In mountainous areas, such as Wamena, the koteka is still used. To take pictures with the wearer, tourists have to reach into the pockets of several tens of thousands of rupiah. In coastal areas, people find it even more difficult. Since the 1950s, missionaries have campaigned for the use of shorts as a substitute for the koteka.

The editor's logged out page learn more In its basic sense, a republic is a country in which the ultimate branch of government stems from the people, not from the principle of hereditary aristocracy and is often headed by a president. The term comes from the Latin res publica, or "public affairs", which means that the kingdom belongs to and is controlled by the people. But the republic is different from the concept of democracy. There are cases where a republican state is ruled in a totalitarian way. For example, South Africa, which has been a republic since 1961, but due to apartheid, about 80% of its black population is prohibited from participating in elections. Of course there are also republican countries that carry out democratic representation. The concept of republics has been used for centuries, with the most famous republic being the Roman Republic, which lasted from 509 BC to 44 BC. Within the Republic, principles such as anuality (holding the government for one year only) and "collegiality" (two people holding the post of head of state) were practiced. In modern times, the head of state for a republic is usually only one person, namely the president, but there are also some exceptions, for example in Switzerland, there is an assembly of seven leaders who also serve as heads of state, called the Bundesrat, and in San Marino, the position of head of state is held by two people. . Republicanism is the view that a republic is the best form of government. Republicanism can also refer to the ideology of many political parties that call themselves Republicans. Some of these are, or have their roots in, anti-monarchism. For most republican parties are just a name and these parties, and those associated with them, have little in common other than their names. Many argue that a republic is more democratic than a monarchy.

The origin of the name Finland (Suomi in Finnish) is unclear but is most likely derived from the proto-Baltic language zeme meaning "land". According to an earlier theory the name is derived from suomaa or suoniemi.

Finnish exonyms are similar to Scandinavian place names Finnmark, Finnveden and hundreds of other toponyms that start with "Fin(n)" in Sweden and Norway. Some of these names are evidently derived from finnr, the Germanic word for traveler/discoverer and later thought to mean nomadic "hunter-gatherer" or slash-and-burn farmer as opposed to Germanic sedentary farmer and merchant and sea pirate. It is unknown how, why and when "Finnr" came to mean Indigenous Finns in particular (from where the name spread from the 15th century onwards to mean the entire population of the country). One of the first documents that mention "land of the Finns" are 2 rune stones. There is 1 in Söderby, Sweden, with a finlont inscription (U 582) and 1 in Gotland, a Swedish island in the Baltic Sea, with a finlont inscription (G 319) dating from the 11th century. According to archaeological evidence, the area that is today Finland was settled around 8500 BC before the Stone Age. Artifacts from sourdough have almost the same characteristics as those found in Estonia, Russia, and Norway. The first people were hunter-gatherers using stone tools. The first ceramics appeared around 5200 BC, before the Combed Ceramic Culture was introduced. The arrival of the Corded Ware culture to the southern coast of Finland around 3000 and 2500 BC probably coincided with the start of agriculture. Although agriculture emerged, hunting and fishing remained an important part of the economy. The Bronze Age (1500–500 BC) and the Iron Age (500 BC–1200 AD) are characterized by contact with other cultures in Fennoscandia and the Baltic region. There is no agreement on when the Uralic and Indo-European languages ​​were first spoken here. As part of the Northern Crusades, the Swedish king established his colonies in Finland gradually in the 12th and 13th centuries with 3 wars namely the 1st, 2nd and 3rd wars against Finns proper, Tavastians and Karelians.

Swedes colonized the coastal area in the Middle Ages. In the 17th century, Swedish became the main language for administration and education; Finnish is spoken by farmers, clergy, and local courts in Finnish-speaking areas. During the Protestant Reformation, the population of Finland gradually converted to Lutheranism. In the 16th century, Mikael Agricola published the first book written in Finnish. Finland's first university, the Royal Academy of Turku, was founded in 1640. Finland suffered from a severe famine in 1696–1697, during which one third of Finland's population died, and a major epidemic a few years later. In the 18th century, wars between Sweden and Russia led to the occupation of Finland twice by Russia, namely during the Great Northern War (1714–1721) and the Russo-Swedish War (1742–1743). It is estimated that almost a generation of youth was lost during the Great Northern War and the destruction of the city of Helsinki. Two Russo-Swedish wars in 25 years made Finns realize how dangerous their position was between Sweden and Russia. Elite voices in Finland later argued that relations with Sweden were very risky, after Gustav III's War (1788–1790), Finnish elites wanted to separate from Sweden. By the late 18th century, the political elite in Finland had realized that Russia and Sweden were repeatedly using Finland as a fighting ground. Therefore, they seek autonomy. Some, even before the Russo-Swedish War 1788–1790, notably Col G. M. Sprengtporten, supported Gustav III's 1772 coup. On 29 March 1809, after being taken over by the armies of Alexander I of Russia in the Finnish War, Finland became an autonomous Grand Duchy of the Russian Empire until the end of 1917. In 1811, Alexander I annexed the province of Vyborg to the Grand Duchy of Finland. In the Russian era, Finnish began to gain a place.

Around the 1860s, a Finnish nationalist movement known as the Fennoman emerged. Among its accomplishments were the publication of the national epic in Finland –Kalevala – in 1835, and the Finnish language gaining legal status with Sweden in 1892. The Finnish famine of 1866–1868 killed 15% of the population, making it one of the worst famines in European history. This famine prompted the Russian Empire to ease financial regulation and increase investment in the previous decades. Economic and political development is very fast. GDP per capita is still half the United States and a third the United Kingdom. In 1906, general suffrage was adopted in the Grand Duchy of Finland. However, relations between the Grand Duchy and the Russian Empire soured when the Russian government tried to tighten Finland's autonomy. For example, this general suffrage means nothing in practice because the emperor is not obliged to approve any law adopted by the Finnish parliament. Thus the desire for independence increased, first among radical liberals and socialists. After the February Revolution of 1917, Finland's position as part of the Russian Empire was questioned, particularly by the Social Democrats. Since the head of state was the Russian tsar, it is unclear who was the chief executive of Finland after the revolution. Its parliament, controlled by social democrats, passed the Power Act policy to give parliament supreme authority. This was rejected by Russia's Provisional Government which then dissolved parliament. General elections were then held, in which the right-wing party narrowly won. Some members of the Social Democrats rejected the results and still claimed that dissolving parliament was illegal. The two equally powerful political blocs (right-wing parties and social democrats) became enemies with each other. The October Revolution in Russia changed many things. Suddenly, right-wing parties reconsidered their decision to block the transfer of supreme executive power from the Russian government to Finland, as the Bolsheviks took power in Russia.

On December 6, 1917, they declared Finland's independence. However, the country only achieved formal independence on January 3, 1918 and border disputes were resolved after the Treaty of Tartu was signed in 1920. In 1917, the country's population was around 3 million. Credit-based land reforms came into effect after the civil war. About 70% of workers are in the agricultural sector and 10% in the industrial sector. The largest export markets are the United Kingdom and Germany. During World War II, Finland fought the Soviet Union twice: first in the Winter War between 1939–1940 after the Soviet Union attacked Finland and the Continuation War in 1941–1944, after Operation Barbarossa in which Finland was united with Germany (although not as an ally). For 872 days, the German army laid siege to Leningrad, the second largest city of the Soviet Union, aided indirectly by the Finnish army. After fighting off a major Soviet offensive in June/July 1944, Finland finally reached an armistice with the Soviet Union. This was followed again by the Lapland War of 1944-1945, in which the Finnish army succeeded in expelling the German army from the north. The country was forced to sign the Finnish–Soviet agreement i.e. Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation and Mutual Benefit, also known as the YYA Agreement in 1948. This agreement with the Soviet Union included obligations, boundaries and concessions to Finnish territory in addition to the 1940 Moscow Peace Treaty. This agreement is important to ensure Finland's survival as a democratic capitalist country. Basically in this agreement, Finland was obliged to become a neutral country during the Cold War and to prevent any attack on the Soviet Union through Finland. As a result of these 2 wars, Finland ceded almost all of Karelia, Salla and Petsamo to the Soviet Union.

This region covers 10% of their land area and 20% of their industrial capacity, including the ports of Vyborg (Viipuri) and Liinakhamari (Liinahamari). Nearly all of the population, about 400,000 people, left the area. Finland was never occupied again by Soviet troops and managed to maintain its independence despite the loss of 93,000 troops. Finland rejected the Marshall Plan, out of respect for the Soviets. Even so, the United States provided covert development assistance and assisted the Social Democratic (non-communist) party in hopes of protecting Finland's independence. Conducting trade with Western countries, such as Britain and paying for improvements to the Soviet Union made this country transform from a country that was originally based on an agrarian economy into an industrial country. For example, the company Valmet was originally created to make materials for war repairs, but after the repairs paid off, Finland (which was poor in natural resources such as oil and iron) – was finally able to resume trading with the Soviet Union in the form of bilateral trade. In 1950, 46% of Finnish workers worked in agriculture and one third lived in urban areas. New jobs in manufacturing, services, and trade quickly drew residents to cities. The average births per woman fell from a peak of 3.5 in 1947 to 1.5 in 1973. As a population boom entered the workforce, the economy was not producing enough jobs, and thousands of people migrated to more affluent Sweden. Emigration reached its peak in 1969-1970. The 1952 Summer Olympics brought in foreign tourists. Finland participates in trade liberalization at the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Officially claiming to be a neutral country, Finland placed itself in the gray zone between the Western countries and the Soviet Union. The YYA Agreement (Finno-Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation and Mutual Benefit) of 1948 provided flexibility for the Soviets to influence Finnish domestic politics.

This was reinforced by President Urho Kekkonen against his political opponents. He maintained effective relations with the Soviets starting in 1956, which was also important to his popularity. In politics, there is a tendency to avoid any policies and statements that could be construed as "anti-Soviet". This phenomenon was referred to as "Finlandization" by the German press. Despite maintaining good relations with the Soviet Union, Finland was still a Western European market economy. Various industries benefited from bilateral trade with the Soviets, which also explains the support for pro-Soviet policies in business in this country. Economic growth skyrocketed after the war, and by 1975 the country's GDP per capita was ranked 15th in the world. Finland negotiated the European Economic Community (the predecessor to the European Union), a treaty that eliminated customs duties between countries starting in 1977, although Finland did not fully join. In 1981, worsening health conditions forced president Urho Kekkonen to retire after 25 years in power. Finland reacted warily to the collapse of the Soviet Union, but quickly integrated itself into the West. On September 21, 1990, Finland unilaterally declared the Paris Peace Agreement obsolete, 9 days after German reunification. Faulty macroeconomic calculations, a banking crisis, the collapse of its single largest trading partner (the Soviet Union), and a global economic downturn sent the country falling into recession in the early 1990s. The recession peaked in 1993, but 10 years later the country's economy is growing every year. Like other Nordic countries, Finland decentralized its economy since the late 1980s. Financial policies and product markets were relaxed. Several state companies were privatized and tax cuts were also applied. Finland joined the European Union in 1995, and the Eurozone in 1999. Much of the economic growth in the late 1990s was driven by the phenomenal success of the mobile phone manufacturer Nokia, which controlled 80% of the market capitalization of the Helsinki Stock Exchange at that time.

The country's population is now aging with a birth rate of 10.42 per 1,000 population per year, or a fertility rate of 1.8. With a median age of 42.7 years, it has the most mature population; with half of voters estimated to be over 50 years old. Located between 60° to 70° north latitude, and 20° to 32° east longitude, Finland is one of the northernmost countries on earth. Of the other world capitals, only Reykjavík is more northerly than Helsinki. The distance from the southernmost point—Hanko—to the northernmost point—Nuorgam—is 1,160 kilometers (720 mi). Finland is a country of thousands of lakes and islands; 187,888 lakes and 179,584 islands. One of its lakes, Saimaa, is the 5th largest in Europe. Finland's terrain is mostly flat with a few hills and its highest point, Haltitunturi at 1,328 m, is in the northern tip of Lapland. Besides numerous lakes, the landscape is also dominated by pine forests (about 68% of the land area) and some arable land. Most of the islands are in the southwest, part of the Åland archipelago, and along the southern coast in the Gulf of Finland. Finland is one of the few countries in the world that is still growing. Due to the isostatic uplift that has occurred since the last ice age, the country's area is also growing by about 7 square kilometers every year. The climate in Southern Finland is a northern temperate climate. In Northern Finland, especially in Finland's Lapland, a subarctic climate predominates, characterized by very cold winters and warm summers. A quarter of Finland's territory lies within the Arctic Circle, and consequently Finland experiences the midnight sun. At Finland's northernmost point, the sun does not set for 73 days in summer, and does not rise for 51 days in winter.

Finland has a variety of fauna. There are at least 60 species of mammals, 248 birds, 70 fish, and 11 reptiles and frogs today, many of which migrated from neighboring countries thousands of years ago. Finland's large mammals include the brown bear (the national animal), the gray wolf, the wolverine and the American deer. The Saimaa ringed seal, one of three species of seals in the world, is found only in Lake Saimaa in southeastern Finland and only 300 individuals remain today. This animal became the logo of the Finnish Nature Conservation Association. Finland uses a parliamentary system with a parliament. The President of Finland is responsible for foreign policy while the executive power is exercised by his cabinet, the Valtioneuvosto or Statsrådet, which consists of the prime minister and ministers for various departments. The Finnish parliament, called the Eduskunta or Riksdag, has 200 members and is the highest legislative authority in the country. This parliament can amend the Finnish Constitution and override the presidential veto. Legislation can be proposed by the cabinet or by Eduskunta members who are elected for four years with proportional representation. Finland is made up of 19 regions (Finnish: maakunta, Swedish: landscape). Regions are governed by regional councils which function as forums for cooperation between communes in one area. The main tasks of the regions are regional planning and business development and education. In addition, public health services are usually organized by region. Currently, the only area holding regional council elections is Kainuu. The other regional councils are elected by the commune councils, each commune sending representatives in proportion to its population. In addition to the intercommunal cooperation forum, each region has a Center for Employment and Economic Development which is in charge of local administration for labour, agriculture, fisheries, forestry, and entrepreneurship affairs.

The Finnish Defense Forces regional offices are responsible for regional defense and for the administration of conscription within the area. The regions represented dialectal, cultural, and economic variations better than the earlier provinces, which were purely administrative divisions of the central government. Historically, regions were divisions of historical provinces in Finland, areas that represent dialect and culture more accurately. Currently, Finland has 6 administrative provinces (lääni, pl. läänit). Provincial authorities are part of the executive branch of the national government; a system which has not changed drastically since its founding in 1634 to a new division into "grand provinces" in 1997. Since then, the six provinces are: The Åland Islands enjoy a degree of autonomy of their own. According to international agreements and Finnish law, Åland's regional government handles some matters that fall to provincial authorities in Mainland Finland. Local government is further organized by Finland's 432 communes. Since 1977, there has been no administrative distinction between "towns", communes and other municipalities. Apart from the communes, Finland is also divided into 20 regions. Finland is an industrialized country, has a free-market economy, with a per capita production roughly equal to that of the United Kingdom, France, Germany and Belgium. The largest economic sector is services (66%), followed by manufacturing and refining (31%). The primary sector is only 2.9%. For international trade, the important sector is manufacturing. The largest industry is electronics (22%); machinery, vehicles, other metal products (21.1%); wood industry (13%); and chemistry (11%). Finland has timber and several mineral and fresh water resources. Forestry, paper manufacturing, and the agricultural sector are sensitive sectors for the population. The Greater Helsinki Region generates one third of GDP. In 2004, the OECD stated that high-tech manufacturing was the second largest after Ireland.

Finland's international trade accounts for one-third of its GDP. Trade with the European Union accounts for around 60% of the total. The country's main trading partners are Germany, Russia, Sweden, the United Kingdom, the United States, the Netherlands and China. Trade rules are governed by the European Union, of which Finland is a party. Finland is also the only Nordic country to join the Eurozone. Finland's climate and soil type make growing plants difficult. The country is located between 60° and 70° north latitude with a short growing season and harsh winters. Annual rainfall is usually sufficient, but often only in winter, leaving summers dry. Therefore, farmers rely on crops that can be harvested quickly and can withstand freezing temperatures. Agriculture in this country runs efficiently and productively-compared to other European countries. Forestry plays an important role in the country's economy, making it one of the world's leading timber producers and providing the wood processing industry with competitively priced raw materials. Like agriculture, the government plays an important role in forestry, regulating tree cutting, improving engineering, and creating long-term plans to ensure that the country's forests are sufficient to supply the industry. In 1984, the government through the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry launched the Forest 2000 plan which stated that it would increase forest products by 3% per year but still maintain them for recreation or other uses. The private sector provides employment to 1.8 million people. The average salary in the private sector was 25.1 euros per hour in 2004. As of 2008, the country's average purchasing power has been about the same as Italy, Sweden, Germany and France. In 2006, 62% of the labor force worked in companies with fewer than 250 employees.

The unemployment rate was 8.7% in 2014. Pension money and health insurance are important provisions for old age. The home ownership rate is 60%. As of 2006, there were about 2.4 million households in Finland. The average household is 2.1 people; 40% live alone, 32% with two people and 28% with three or more people. Residential buildings total 1.2 million, and the average space is Template:Conv per person. 74% of households own a car. There are about 2.5 million cars and 400,000 other vehicles. About 92% of the population owns a mobile phone and 83.5% (2009) List of countries by number of internet users|with an internet connection at home. According to Invest in Finland, personal consumption grew by 3% in 2006 and consumer trends are towards high-tech and durable products. In 2006, the energy market was around 90 kWh and in winter the demand was around 15 gigawatts. This means energy consumption per capita is around 7.2 tonnes of oil equivalent annually. Industry and construction consume 51% of total energy. Finland's hydrocarbon resources are limited to peat and wood. About 10–15% of electricity is generated from hydropower, which is low when compared to neighboring Sweden or Norway. In 2008, renewable energy accounted for 31% of total demand, above the European average of only 10.3%. Finland has 4 private nuclear reactors which produce 18% of the country's energy needs and one research reactor at the Otaniemi campus. The fifth reactor built by AREVA-Siemens with a capacity of 1600 MWe has experienced numerous delays and is scheduled to operate in 2018–2020, a decade longer than it should have been. About 5–17% of electricity needs are imported from Russia, Sweden or Norway. Government spending on road maintenance is around 1 billion euros, and is covered by vehicle and fuel taxes which annually generate 1-1.5 billion euros.

The main international gateway is Helsinki Airport which served 15.3 million passengers in 2013. Oulu Airport is the second busiest airport in the country. There are about 25 airports that have scheduled flights. Helsinki Airport is home to Finnair, Blue1 and Flybe Nordic. The government spends around 350 million euros on the maintenance of 5,865 kilometers (3,644 mi) of rail lines. Rail transportation is handled by VR Group, which has a market share of 5% for passengers and 25% for cargo. Since 12 December 2010, Karelian Trains, a joint venture between Russian Railways and VR Group, operates the Alstom Pendolino high-speed train between Finlyandsky stations in Saint Petersburg and Central in Helsinki. This service is called "Allegro" and it takes 3.5 hours from Helsinki to Saint Petersburg and vice versa. The price of port logistics is relatively cheap. Vuosaari Port in Helsinki is the largest container port after completion in 2008 and the others are Kotka, Hamina, Hanko, Pori, Rauma and Oulu. In Turku there are ferry connections to Tallinn, Mariehamn and Stockholm. The Helsinki-Tallinn route, one of the world's busiest seaborne passenger routes, also includes a helicopter lane. Finland rapidly industrialized after World War II, its GDP per capita level matching that of Japan or Britain in the early 1970s. The two main driving industries are the "metal industry" (metalliteollisusus) and the "forestry industry" (metsäteollisusus). The "metal industry" includes shipbuilding, automobiles, engineering products (machinery and electronics), metal production (steel, copper, and chrome). The world's largest cruise ship is built in a Finnish shipyard. While those included in the wood industry (metsäteollisusus) include forestry, timber, pulp and paper. Many major pulp and paper industries operate here, among them Ahlstrom, M-real and UPM.

Even so, Finland's economy is currently diversified, expanding into branches of electronics (Nokia), metrology (Vaisala), fuel transportation (Neste), chemistry (Kemira), engineering consulting (Pöyry), and information technology (Rovio, famous for Angry birds). According to the Economist Intelligence Unit's September 2011 report, Finland ranks second after the United States in the 2011 IT Industry Competitiveness Benchmarking which relies on 6 key indicators: overall business environment, technology infrastructure, human resources, legal framework, public support for industry development, and research and development. Tourism is a growing industry in Finland and has in recent years become an important aspect of its economy. In 2005, Finnish tourism grossed over €6.7 billion, growing 5% over the previous year. Much of the sudden growth can be attributed to the globalization and modernization of the country as well as a resurgence in publicity and positive awareness. Finland's many attractions attracted more than 4 million visitors in 2005. Finland's landscape is covered with dense evergreen forests, undulating hills and is complemented by an intricate array of lakes and mainland islands. Much of Finland is pristine and virgin as it has 35 national parks from the southern coast of the Gulf of Finland to the high forests of Lapland. It is also an urbanized area with lots of cultural events and activities. Commercial ferries between the main coastal cities and ports of the Baltic region, including Helsinki, Turku, Tallinn, Stockholm and Travemünde, play an important role in the local tourism industry. In brief, Finland's population consists mostly of a Finnish majority and a Finnish Swedes minority so the official languages ​​are Finnish and Swedish. Other minority languages ​​are Russian and Estonian.

Finland's population is mostly concentrated in the south. The cities in the area are the Helsinki Metropolitan Area which includes Helsinki, Espoo and Vantaa. The other cities are Tampere, Turku, Oulu, Lahti, Kuopio and Jyväskylä. Religion professed by residents in Finland is Christian 100% of the total population of Finland with the distribution of Church Denominations: Finnish Lutheran Church 95% of the total population of Finland. The rest is the Finnish Calvinist Church 3% of the total population of Finland, the Finnish Catholic Church 1% of the total population of Finland and the Finnish Orthodox Church 1% of the total population of Finland. Finland has two main official languages: Finnish and Swedish. The other official languages ​​are Finnish, Romani and Sign Finnish. Other important foreign languages ​​are Russian and Estonian. The commonly spoken languages ​​are Finnish (92% of the population) and Swedish (6% of the population). The current use of foreign languages ​​is English (63%), Swedish (41%), German (18%) and French (3%). Nearly all primary and secondary education is organized at the municipal level. While almost all schools were initially private, today only about 3% of students are in private schools (mainly specialist language and international schools), much lower than in Sweden and other developed countries. Pre-school education is rare compared to other EU countries and formal education generally begins at the age of 7. Elementary school is generally for 6 years and junior high school is 3 years. The flexible curriculum is regulated by the Ministry of Education. Education is compulsory for children aged 7 to 16 years. After junior high school, graduates can go straight to work or enroll in a trade school or gymnasium (high school).

Trade schools offer vocational education and about 40% of students choose this path after graduating from junior high school. The gymnasium has higher entry requirements and is specially prepared for Abitur and higher education. Graduates from both types of schools formally meet higher education requirements. For higher education, there are 2 types: work-oriented polytechnics and research-oriented universities. Education here is free and most of the cost of living is paid for by the government through student benefits. There are 20 universities and 30 polytechnics in the country. The University of Helsinki is ranked 75th in its 2010 Top Universities ranking. The World Economic Forum ranks higher education in Finland as the best in the world. The composition of foreign students is around 3%, one of the lowest in the OECD, for skills programs around 7.3%, below the OECD average of 16.5%. About 30% of higher education students continue in science-related fields. Forest restoration, materials research, environmental science, neural networks, low-temperature physics, brain research, biotechnology and genetics, and communications are fields that made many contributions. Finland is very productive when it comes to scientific research. In 2005, Finland ranked fourth in terms of scientific publications per capita among OECD countries. In 2007, 1,801 patents were issued in Finland. In addition, 38 percent of Finns have a bachelor's degree, one of the highest percentages in the world. Like its people, Finnish culture is very indigenous and is widely represented in the Finnish language. Throughout prehistoric and historical times in this area, confluence and concurrent cultural influences came at the same time from all directions. As a result of 600 Swedish rule, Swedish cultural influence can still be seen. Today, cultural influences from North America also predominate.

In the 21st century, many Finns have experienced cultural contact from distant regions, such as Asia and Africa. Through tourism, young Finns in particular have come in contact with people from outside Finland by traveling abroad to work and study. There are still differences between regions, especially minor differences in accent and vocabulary. Minorities such as the Sami, Finnish Swedes, Romani and Tatars maintain their own culture. Many Finns are emotionally connected to the countryside and nature, as urbanization is still a relatively recent phenomenon. Finland comfortably won the first Eurovision Dance Contest in September 2007. The press in Finland is the freest in the world. Currently, there are about 200 newspapers, 320 popular magazines, 2,100 professional magazines, 67 commercial radio stations, 3 digital radio channels and 5 national general radio channels. Each year, around 12,000 book titles are published and 12 million records are sold. Yle, a Finnish broadcasting company, operates 5 television channels and 13 radio channels in 2 languages. Yle is funded through a mandatory television license and fees for private broadcasters. All TV channels are broadcast digitally, both terrestrial and cable. Apart from communications, Finland also has the highest position in the World Economic Forum's NRI (Network Readiness Index) index - an indicator to determine the level of development of a country's communications and information technology. Finland took first place in 2013 and 2014. About 79% of the population uses the internet. Finland had 1.52 million broadband internet connections at the end of 2007 or 287 per 1,000 residents. All schools and public libraries are connected to the internet and most residents have cell phones. In October 2009, the Ministry of Transport and Communications committed to ensure that everyone in Finland can access the internet at a minimum speed of 1 megabit-per-second starting July 2010.

Depending on the presence of impurities such as soil particles or air bubbles, it can appear transparent or a more or less opaque bluish color. This freezing generally occurs when water is cooled below 0°C (273.15K, 32°F) at standard atmospheric pressure. Ice can form at higher temperatures under higher pressures, and water will remain as a liquid or gas down to -30°C at lower pressures. In the Solar System, ice is abundant and occurs naturally from Mercury as far as the Oort cloud object. Outside the Solar System, ice forms as interstellar ice. Ice is abundant on the Earth's surface – particularly in the polar regions and above the snow line – and, as a general form of precipitation and deposition, plays a key role in the Earth's water cycle and climate. Ice falls from the atmosphere as snowflakes and hail or occurs as icicles or spikes. Ice molecules have eighteen or more distinct phases (packaging geometries) that depend on temperature and pressure. When water is rapidly cooled (cooling), up to three types of amorphous ice can form depending on their pressure and temperature history. When cooled, the slowly correlated tunneling of protons occurs below -253.15°C (20 K, −423.67°F) giving rise to macroscopic quantum phenomena. Nearly all the ice on the Earth's surface and in its atmosphere is a hexagonal crystal structure denoted as ice Ih (pronounced as "ice one h") with small traces of cubed ice designated as ice Ic. The most common phase transition to ice Ih occurs when liquid water is cooled below 0°C (273.15 K, 32°F) at standard atmospheric pressure.

Ice can also be precipitated directly by water vapor, as occurs in freezing. The transition from ice to liquid water and from ice directly to water vapor is sublimation. Ice is used in a variety of ways, including cooling, winter sports and ice sculpture. The word "ice" is taken from the Dutch language ijs because in Indonesia there is no natural ice. In Malaysia, "ice" is usually called "water stone" besides ice. In the language of the aceh tribe, "éh". As a naturally occurring crystalline inorganic solid with an ordered structure, ice is considered a mineral. It has the usual crystal structure based on that of the water molecule, which consists of one oxygen atom covalently bonded to two hydrogen atoms, or H – O – H. However, many of the physical properties of water and ice are controlled by the formation of hydrogen bonds between the oxygen and hydrogen atoms. adjacent; Even though the bond is weak, it is still important in controlling the structure of water and ice. An unusual property of water is that its solid form — ice frozen at atmospheric pressure — is approximately 8.3% denser than its liquid state, equivalent to a volumetric expansion of 9%. The density of ice is 0.9167 –0.9168 g/cm3 at 0°C and standard atmospheric pressure (101.325 Pa), while water has a density of 0.9998 –0.999863 g/cm3 at the same temperature and pressure. Liquid water is the densest liquid, with a density of 1 g/cm3 at 4 °C and becomes less dense as the water molecules begin to form hexagonal ice crystals when the freezing point is reached. This is because hydrogen bonds predominate intermolecular forces, which results in less dense packing of molecules in a solid. The density of ice increases slightly with decreasing temperature and has a value of 0.9340 g/cm3 at -180°C (93 K).

Editor page logged out learn more Emerald (Be3Al2SiO6) is a green to dark green gemstone or precious stone. Emerald is a beryl silicate mineral (contains beryllium) and its green color is caused by chromium traces. The presence of vanadium and iron that accompanies chromium traces will cause the various zones of the green color. Emerald has a high hardness (7.5 on the Mohs scale). Producers of high quality emeralds are Colombia, Siberia, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Brazil. Currently, the emerald mine in Russia (Siberia) has been closed due to the lack of deposits in it. Stone mining in Brazil and Colombia is still ongoing, where more than 60% of emeralds sold in the market come from Colombia. Not all emeralds that come from Colombia are of high quality, some are of low quality. This low quality stone often has many defects in the form of cracks or cracks in it. To beautify the appearance of these deformed emeralds, traders usually provide treatment oiling. The presence of oil (oil) that covers the cracks in the emerald stone will make the defects invisible to the naked eye. But if the oil evaporates or is washed away by water, the crack will appear again. This oil treatment is called CE (Clarity Enhancement). There are 3 levels, namely Major, Moderate and Minor. Emeralds that have many defects fall into the Major category. Usually if it is not often given oil, then the stone will quickly turn into many cracks. Emerald stones treated with this oil need to be cared for properly so that they maintain their beauty. Continuous exposure to sunlight, rinsing water and soap can make the oil inside the emerald come out so that the defects in the stone will be visible again.

Editor page out log learn more Lymphocytes (English: lymphocyte) are white blood cells found in the immune system of vertebrates. Lymphocytes primarily play a role in adaptive immunity. Lymphocytes are generally divided into B lymphocytes (B cells), T lymphocytes (T cells), and natural killer cells (NK cells, natural killer). B cells are so named because they develop in the Bursa Fabricus (in birds) or in the bone marrow (in humans). While T cells are so named because they develop in the thymus. B cells play a role in humoral immunity (involving antibodies), while T cells play a role in cell mediated immunity (cell mediated immunity). The function of T cells and B cells is to recognize specific "non-self" antigens during a process known as antigen presentation. Once the cells have identified the invader, they generate a specific response that is adapted to eliminate the particular pathogen or infected cells. B cells respond to pathogens by producing large amounts of antibodies which then neutralize foreign bodies such as bacteria and viruses. A subset of T cells, called helper T cells (Th cells), produce cytokines that direct the immune response, while another T cell, called cytotoxic T cells (Tc cells), produce toxic granules containing enzymes that induce the death of target cells. Upon activation, B cells and T cells leave memory cells, which "remember" any specific pathogen encountered, and are able to mount a strong and rapid response if the pathogen is detected again. NK cells are part of the innate immune system and play a major role in host protection from tumor and virus-infected cells. NK cells differentiate infected and tumor cells from normal and uninfected cells by recognizing changes from surface molecules called MHC class I. NK cells are activated in response to a family of cytokines called interferons.

Editor's logged out page learn more Vermont is a United States state located in the New England region of the Northeastern United States. This state ranks 45th on the list of the largest states in the US with a total area of ​​24,902 km², as well as 43rd on the list of states with the largest land area. Vermont's population is only 608,827, and it ranks second (after Wyoming) as the state with the least population in the US. As the only state in the New England region that does not have a coastline with the Atlantic Ocean, to the west of Vermont are the Green Mountains, and Lake Champlain to the northwest. To the south, Vermont is bordered by the state of Massachusetts, to the east by New Hampshire, to the west by New York, and to the north by the Province of Quebec. In ancient times, Vermont was home to the Abenaki and Iroquois Native Americans. The territory that is now the state of Vermont was once claimed by France, but became British after the French lost the Indian-French War. Over the years, control of this area became a bone of contention between neighboring colonies, particularly between New Hampshire and the Province of New York. The Green Mountain Boys militia group opposed settlers who received land rights from neighboring colonial governments that eventually became an independent nation. Vermont became the 14th state to join the United States after 14 years of independence as the Republic of Vermont during and after the American Revolutionary War. Vermont is the main producer of maple syrup in the United States. The state capital is Montpelier, while the largest city is Burlington.

Vermont is located in the eastern United States in the New England region. Area 24,902 km² (45th largest state): land area 23,955 km² (43rd widest) and water area 948 km² (47th largest). In comparison, Vermont is roughly the same area as El Salvador, but smaller than Haiti. The west bank of the Connecticut River forms the eastern boundary of Vermont state with New Hampshire (the river itself is part of New Hampshire). Lake Champlain, which is the largest lake in Vermont, is the sixth largest freshwater lake in the United States, as well as being the boundary between Vermont and New York in the northwest. The distance of the state of Vermont from north to south is 256 km, the widest distance from east to west is 143 km to the Canadian border, while the shortest distance from east to west is 60 km to the border with Massachusetts. Right in the middle of the state of Vermont is the city of Washington which is located 5 km east of Roxbury. Vermont comprises six physiographical regions: the Northeast Highlands, the Green Mountains, the Taconic Mountains, the Champlain Lowlands, the Vermont Valley, and the Vermont Piedmont. The origin of the name Green Mountains (Green Mountains, or French: Verts monts) is not clear. Some authorities say the mountains are named the Green Mountains because they are more forested than the White Mountains (White Mountains) in New Hampshire or the Adirondacks in New York. Meanwhile, some authorities say that the mountains are named the Green Mountains because there is a kind of green mineral stone there. In the southwest of the state of Vermont are the Taconic Mountains, while the fertile Champlain Valley is northwest of Lake Champlain.

Editor's page that has logged out learn more Paleonthropology is a science that studies the origin and development of humans with ancient human fossils as its research object and is one of the branches of Biology and Anthropology. Paleoanthropology comes from the Greek: παλαιός (palaeos) "old, ancient", anthrōpos (ἄνθρωπος), "man", understanding of humanity, and -logia (-λογία), "science"), which is a combination of the disciplines of paleontology and physical anthropology, is a science that studies humans in the past which are found in hominid fossils such as petrified bones and footprints. Since the time of Carl Linnaeus, great apes have been considered the closest relative to humans, based on morphological similarities. In the 19th century, it was thought that the closest relatives to humans were chimpanzees and gorillas, and based on their similarities, it was suggested that humans share a common ancestor with African apes and their fossils must be found in Africa. This branch of science is thought to have appeared at the end of the 19th century when important discoveries were made that led to the study of human evolution. This is the discovery of Neanderthal humans in Germany, Thomas Huxley's work entitled Evidence as to Man's Place in Nature, and Charles Darwin's work entitled The Descent of Man is an important beginning of paleoanthropological research. The modern branch of paleoanthropology began in the 19th century with the discovery of the "Neanderthal man" (found in 1856, but similar bones have been found elsewhere since 1830), and with evidence suggesting that it was a caveman. The idea that humans are similar to great apes had been around for some time, but the idea of ​​the biological evolution of species in general was not recognized until after Charles Darwin published On the Origin of Species in 1859.

Editor page logged out learn more Indium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol In and atomic number 49. It is a post-transition metal that makes up 0.21 ppm of the Earth's crust. Indium is very soft and malleable, having a higher melting point than sodium and gallium, but lower than lithium and tin. Chemically, indium is similar to gallium and thallium, and most of its properties fall between gallium and thallium. Indium was discovered in 1863 by Ferdinand Reich and Hieronym Theodor Richter by spectroscopic method. They named it after the indigo line in its spectrum. Indium was isolated the following year. Indium is a minor component in zinc sulfide ores and is produced as a by-product of zinc refining. The metal is used primarily in the semiconductor industry, in low melting point alloys such as solder, in high pressure vacuum sealers, and in the production of transparent indium tin oxide (ITO) conductive coatings on glass. Indium has no biological role, although its compounds are mildly toxic when injected into the bloodstream. Most of the occupational exposure is through ingestion, which absorbs indium compounds less well, and inhalation, which absorbs quite well. Indium is a very ductile silvery-white post-transition metal with a bright luster. It is very soft (Mohs hardness 1.2) like sodium, and can be cut with a knife. It also leaves visible lines on the paper. It is a member of group 13 on the periodic table and its properties lie mostly between that of its vertical neighbours, gallium and thallium. Like lead, a high-pitched screeching sound is heard when indium is bent – ​​the crackling sound caused by twinkling of crystals.

Like gallium, indium is able to wet glass. Like the two, indium has a low melting point, 156.60°C (313.88°F); higher than its lighter homologue, gallium, but lower than its heavier homolog, thallium, and lower than tin. Its boiling point is 2072°C (3762°F), higher than that of thallium, but lower than that of gallium, in contrast to the general melting point trend, but decreasing trend with that of the other post-transition metal groups due to the weak metallic bond with few delocalized electrons. The density of indium is 7.31 g/cm3, greater than that of gallium, but lower than that of thallium. Below the critical temperature, 3.41 K, indium becomes a superconductor. At standard temperature and pressure, indium crystallizes in a face-centered tetragonal crystal system in the I4/mmm space group (lattice parameters: a = 325 pm, c = 495 pm): this is a slightly distorted en:face-centered cubic structure, where each indium atom has four neighbors at a distance of 324 pm and eight neighbors slightly further away (336 pm). Indium displays a ductile viscoplastic response, which is found to be size independent of tension and compression. However, it has a size effect in bending and indentation, associated with a length scale at the 50–100 μm level, relatively large when compared to other metals. Indium has 49 electrons, with the electron configuration Kr]4d105s25p1. In compounds, indium most often donates its three outer electrons to indium(III), In3+. In some cases, the 5s electron pair is not donated, resulting in indium(I), In+. The stabilization of the monovalent state is related to the inert pair effect, whereas a relativistic effect stabilizes the 5s orbital, which is observed in the heavier elements. Thallium (the heavier indium homologue) exhibits a stronger effect, causing oxidation to thallium(I) to be more probable than to thallium(III), whereas gallium (indium's lighter homolog) usually exhibits only the +3 oxidation state.

Thus, although thallium(III) is a moderately strong oxidizing agent, indium(III) is not, and indeed many indium(I) compounds are strong reducing agents. While the lowest energy required to introduce s electrons into a chemical bond is for indium among the group 13 metals, the bond energy decreases along the group from top to bottom so that for indium, the energy released in forming two additional bonds and reaching the +3 state is not always enough to exceed the energy required to engage the 5s electrons. Indium(I) oxide and hydroxide are more basic while indium(III) oxide and hydroxide are more acidic. The reported number of standard indium electrode potentials, depending on the reactions studied, reflect the reduced stability of the +3 oxidation state: Indium metal does not react with water, but is oxidized by strong oxidizing agents such as halogens, giving indium(III) compounds. It does not form a boride, silicide, or carbide, and its hydride InH3 is at its best transition state in ether solutions at low temperatures, and is not stable enough to polymerize spontaneously without coordination. Indium is slightly alkaline in aqueous solution, exhibits only slightly amphoteric characteristics, and unlike its lighter homologs aluminum and gallium, it is insoluble in alkaline solutions. Indium has 39 known isotopes, with mass numbers ranging from 97 to 135. Only two isotopes occur naturally as ancient nuclides: indium-113, the only stable isotope, and indium-115, which has a half-life of 4.41× 1014 years, four orders of magnitude greater than the age of the universe and almost 50,000 times greater than natural thorium. The half-life of 115In is very long because the beta decay to 115Sn is spin-restricted. Indium-115 makes up 95.7% of the total indium.

Indium is one of three known elements (the others being tellurium and rhenium) in which the stable isotopes are less abundant in nature than the long-lived primordial radioisotopes. The most stable artificial isotope is indium-111, with a half-life of approximately 2.8 days. All other isotopes have half-lives shorter than 5 hours. Indium also has 47 meta states, of which indium-114m1 (half-life approx. 49.51 days) is the most stable, being more stable than the ground state of every other indium isotope other than the primordial isotope. All decays are isomeric transitions. Indium isotopes lighter than 115In mainly decay via electron capture or positron emission to form cadmium isotopes, whereas other indium isotopes from 115In and greater decay preceded by beta minus decay to form tin isotopes. Indium(III) oxide, In, is formed when indium metal is burned in air or when its hydroxide or nitrate is heated. In adopts a structure like alumina and is amphoteric, that is, it is capable of reacting with both acids and bases. Indium reacts with water to produce indium(III) hydroxide, which is readily soluble and amphoteric; with alkalis gives indate(III); and with acid to give indium(III) salts: Sesquicalcogenides are also known, analogous to sulfur, selenium, and tellurium. The compound is a Lewis acid, somewhat similar to the better known aluminum trihalide. Again like related aluminum compounds, InF3 can form polymers. The direct reaction of indium with pnictogens gives the III-V semiconductors which are gray or semimetallic in color. Many of them slowly decompose in moist air, so careful storage of semiconductor compounds to prevent contact with the atmosphere is essential.
