In 1863, the chemist Germans Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter tested ore from a mine in the vicinity of Freiberg, Saxony, where they dissolved the minerals pyrite, arsenopyrite, galena, and sphalerite in hydrochloric acid as well as distilling crude zinc chloride. Reich, who is color blind, appointed Richter as his assistant to detect the colors of spectral lines. Knowing that ores from the area sometimes contain thallium, they looked for the green emission spectral line of thallium. Unexpectedly, they found a bright blue line instead. Because the blue lines did not match any known elements, they hypothesized a new element in the mineral. They called it indium, from the indigo color they saw in the spectrum, after its Latin name, indicum.

Richter isolated the metal in 1864. A 05 kg (11 pound) ingot was presented at the 1867 World's Fair. Reich and Richter then fell apart when the last person claimed to be the sole discoverer. Indium is formed via a very long s (slow neutron capture) process (up to hundreds of years) in low to medium mass stars (range in mass between 0.6 and 10 solar masses). When an atom of silver-109 (the isotope that makes up about half of all existing silver) catches a neutron, it undergoes beta decay to become cadmium-110. Captured further neutrons, will form cadmium-115, which decays into indium-115 via another beta decay. This explains why radioactive isotopes are more abundant than their stable isotopes. The stable indium isotope, indium-113, is one of the p-cores, whose origin is not fully understood; Although indium-113 is known to be a direct product of the s and r processes (fast electron capture), and is also a very long-lived derivative of cadmium-113 (with a half-life of about eight quadrillion years), it also does not reveal the entire indium veil. -113. In the Earth's crust, indium occurs rarely as the free metal granules, too rare and small to be of commercial interest. Indium is the most abundant element in the Earth's crust at approximately 160 ppb, about as abundant as cadmium. Fewer than 10 indium minerals are known and none of these significant deposits. Two of them are dzhalindite (In(OH)) and indit (FeIn). Indium tends to coexist with zinc in sulfide minerals because the two elements have similar atomic radii and chemical properties. Based on the indium content of zinc ores, the total economically viable reserves of indium are about 6,000 tons, and the Royal Society of Chemistry warned of the serious risk that indium supplies could run out within a century.

However, Indium Corporation, the largest indium processor, stated, based on increased yields during extraction, that recovery is possible from a wider range of base metals (tin, copper, and other polymetallic deposits) and from mining investments, and that long-term supply of indium is sustainable. reliable, and sufficient to meet the increasing demands of the future. The limitations of indium mineral deposits and the fact that indium is abundant in the sulfide deposits of lead, tin, copper, iron, and especially zinc, have made zinc and lead production the main source of indium. Indium is leached from the slag and dust of zinc production. Further purification is carried out by means of electrolysis. The exact process varies according to the exact composition of the slag and dust. The main production of indium comes from residues generated during the processing of zinc ores, but it is also found in iron, lead, and copper ores. China is the main producer of indium (390 tonnes in 2012), followed by Canada, Japan and South Korea with 70 tonnes each. Cominco's Teck processing plant at Trail, British Columbia, is the largest single-source producer of indium, with production of 32.5 tonnes in 2005, 41.8 tonnes in 2004 and 36.1 tonnes in 2003. The Malku Khota mine in Bolivia operated by the South American Silver Corporation is a large indium resource with proven reserves of 1,481 tons and estimated reserves of 935 tons. The Mount Pleasent mine in New Brunswick, Canada, which is operated by Adex Mining Inc holds most of the world's resources indium. The main consumption of indium worldwide is the production of Liquid Crystal Displays, (LCDs). Worldwide production in 2007 was 475 tonnes per year from mining and 650 tonnes per year from recycling.

Demand has increased sharply in recent years with the increasing popularity of computer monitors and LCD televisions, which currently account for 50% of indium consumption. Increasing manufacturing and recycling efficiency (especially in Japan) maintains a balance between demand and supply. According to UNEP, the recycling rate of indium is less than 1%. According to forecasts, indium supplies remain for less than 14 years, at current extraction rates, requiring additional recycling. In 1924, indium was discovered to have the valuable property of stabilizing non-ferrous metals, and this became the element's first significant use. The first large-scale application of indium was for coating bearings in high-performance aircraft engines during World War II, to protect against damage and corrosion; however this is no longer the primary use of the element. New uses have been found in fusible alloys, solders, and electronics. In the 1950s, small indium grains were used for the transmitter and collector of PNP bipolar junction transistors. In the mid and late 1980s, the development of indium phosphide semiconductors and indium tin oxide thin films for liquid crystal displays (LCDs) generated a great deal of interest. By 1992, thin film applications had become the largest end use. Indium(III) oxide and indium tin oxide (ITO) are used as transparent conductive coatings on glass substrates in electroluminescent panels. Indium tin oxide is used as a light filter in low pressure sodium vapor lamps. Infrared radiation is reflected back to the lamp, which increases the temperature inside the tube and improves lamp performance. Indium has many applications related to semiconductors. Some indium compounds, such as indium antimonide and indium phosphide, are semiconductors with useful properties: one precursor is usually trimethylindium (TMI), which is also used as a dopant semiconductor in compound semiconductors II–VI.

InAs and InSb are used for low temperature transistors and InP for high temperature transistors. InGaN and InGaP compound semiconductors are used in light-emitting diodes (LEDs) and laser diodes. Indium is used in photovoltaics as a semiconductor for copper indium gallium selenide (CIGS), also called CIGS solar cells, a second generation type of thin-film solar cell. Indium is used in PNP bipolar junction transistors with germanium: when soldered at low temperatures, indium does not stress germanium. Indium wire is used as a vacuum seal seal and thermal conductor in cryogenic and ultra-high vacuum applications, in manufacturing applications such as gaskets that deform to fill gaps. Indium is an ingredient in the gallium-indium-tin gallinstan alloy, which is liquid at room temperature and replaces mercury in some thermometers. Other alloys of indium with bismuth, cadmium, lead, and tin, which have a higher, but still lower, melting point (between 50 and 100 °C), are used in flame retardant systems and heat regulators. Indium is one of many substitutes for mercury in alkaline batteries to prevent the zinc from corroding and releasing hydrogen gas. Indium is added to some dental amalgam mixtures to reduce the surface tension of the mercury and allow easier amalgamation with less mercury consumption. Indium's high neutron capture cross-section for thermal neutrons makes it suitable for use in control rods in nuclear reactors, typically in an alloy of 80% silver, 15% indium, and 5% cadmium. In nuclear engineering, the (n,n') 113In reaction is used to determine the magnitude of the neutron flux. Indium has no metabolic role in any organism. In the same way as aluminum salts, indium(III) ions can be toxic to the kidneys when given by injection.

Editor page logged out learn more Kathmandu (Nepali: काठमाडौं) is the capital and largest city of Nepal. This city of 3.2 million people is located in the Kathmandu Valley in central Nepal, near the Vishnumati River. The Kathmandu Metropolitan Area, which includes Patan, Lalitpur and Bhaktapur, has a large population of around 5-6 million people. Kathmandu is also the largest metropolis in the Himalayan region. Nepali and Nepali Basha/Newari are the most spoken languages ​​in the city. Kathmandu, also known as the City of Temples, sits about 1,400 meters (4,600 feet) above sea level in the bowl-shaped Kathmandu Valley in central Nepal. This valley has historically been referred to as the "Mandala of Nepal" and has been the cultural center of the Newar or Nepami people, a cosmopolitan urban civilization at the foot of the Himalayas. This city was formerly the capital of the Kingdom of Nepal which played host to the palaces, mansions and gardens of the Nepalese aristocracy. Since 1985, the city has been the headquarters of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC). Currently, Kathmandu is the seat of government of the Republic of Nepal which was established in 2008; and is part of Province Number 3 in administrative geography of Nepal. Kathmandu has been for many years the historical, artistic, cultural and economic center of Nepal. The city has a multiethnic population with a majority Hindu and Buddhist and is home to the Newar ethnic group. Religious and cultural celebrations have become a major part of the life of the people living in Kathmandu. Tourism is an important part of the economy; In 2013, Kathmandu was ranked third in the world out of ten future travel destinations by TripAdvisor, and ranked first in Asia.

Learn more. Fluorine is a chemical element with the symbol F and atomic number 9. It is the lightest of the halogens and occurs under standard conditions as a pale yellow, highly toxic diatomic gas. As the most electronegative element, it is highly reactive, as it reacts with all other elements except argon, neon and helium. Among all the elements, fluorine ranks 24th in universal abundance and 13th in terrestrial abundance. Fluorite, the principal mineral source of the fluorine which gives the element its name, was first described in 1529; because it was added to metal ores to lower their melting point in order to make smelting easier, the Latin verb fluo meaning 'to flow' gave the mineral its name. Proposed as an element in 1810, fluorine proved difficult and dangerous to separate from its compounds, and several early researchers died or suffered injuries as a result of their experiments. It wasn't until 1886 that the French chemist Henri Moissan isolated elemental fluorine using low-temperature electrolysis, a process still used for modern production. Industrial production of fluorine gas for uranium enrichment, its greatest application, began during the Manhattan Project in World War II. Due to the high cost of purifying pure fluorine, most commercial applications use fluorine compounds, with about half of the fluorite mined being used in steelmaking. The remaining fluorite is converted to corrosive hydrogen fluoride on its way to various organic fluorides, or to cryolite, which plays a key role in aluminum refining. Molecules containing carbon–fluorine bonds often have very high chemical and thermal stability; their main uses are as refrigerants, insulating electrical and cookware, and PTFE (Teflon).

Drugs such as atorvastatin and fluoxetine contain C−F bonds. Fluoride ions from dissolved fluoride salts inhibit cavities, and are therefore used in toothpaste and water fluoridation. Global fluorochemical sales total over US$69 billion annually. Fluorocarbon gases are generally a greenhouse gas with a global warming potential 100 to 23,500 times that of carbon dioxide, and SF6 has the highest global warming potential of any known substance. Organofluorine compounds often persist in the environment because of the strength of the carbon–fluorine bond. has no known metabolic role in mammals; some plants and sea sponges synthesize organofluorine toxins (most commonly monofluoroacetate) that help prevent predation. The fluorine atom has nine electrons, one fewer than neon, and the electron configuration is 1s22s22p5: two electrons in the inner shell that are filled and seven in the outer shell that require one more to be filled. The outer electrons are ineffective in shielding the core, and experience a high effective nuclear charge of 9 − 2 = 7; this affects the physical properties of the fluorine atom. The first ionization energy of fluorine is the third highest of all the elements, behind helium and neon, which complicates the removal of electrons from the neutral fluorine atom. It also has a high electron affinity, second only to chlorine, and tends to gain electrons to be isoelectronic with the noble gases neon; it has the highest electronegativity of any element. The fluorine atom has a small covalent radius, about 60 picometers, similar to that of its neighbors in the same period, oxygen and neon. note 1] The bond energy of difluorine is much lower than that of Cl2 or Br2 and is similar to that of a peroxide bond that is easily cleaved; this, together with high electronegativity, leads to easy fluorine dissociation, high reactivity, and strong bonding with nonfluorine atoms.

In contrast, the bonds with other atoms are very strong due to the high electronegativity of fluorine. Unreactive substances such as steel powder, glass shards, and asbestos fibers will react quickly with cold fluorine gas; wood and water spontaneously combust under a fluorine jet. The reaction of elemental fluorine with metals requires a variety of conditions. Alkali metals will cause explosions and alkaline earth metals show strong activity in large quantities; to prevent passivation from forming a metal fluoride layer, most other metals such as aluminum and iron must be powdered, and the precious metal requires pure fluorine gas at 300–450 °C (575–850 °F). Some solid nonmetals (sulfur, phosphorus) react violently in liquid fluorine. Hydrogen sulfide and sulfur dioxide readily combine with fluorine, with sulfur dioxide sometimes exploding; sulfuric acid exhibits much less activity, requiring high temperatures. Hydrogen, like some alkali metals, reacts explosively with fluorine. Carbon, like a black light, reacts at room temperature to produce fluoromethane. Graphite will combine with fluorine above 400°C (750°F) to give carbon monofluoride which is nonstoichiometric; Higher temperatures produce gaseous fluorocarbons, sometimes explosively. Carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide react at or just above room temperature, while paraffin and other organic chemicals produce vigorous reactions: even haloalkanes, such as carbon tetrachloride, are normally inflammable, but can explode. Although nitrogen trifluoride is stable, it requires an electrical discharge at high temperatures for reaction with fluorine to occur, because of the very strong triple bond in elemental nitrogen; Ammonia can react explosively. Oxygen cannot combine with fluorine under ambient conditions, but can react using an electric discharge at low temperature and pressure; the products tend to disintegrate into their constituent elements when heated.

The heavier halogens react readily with fluorine as does the noble gas radon; of the other noble gases, only xenon and krypton react, and only under special conditions. At room temperature, fluorine is a diatomic molecular gas, pale yellow when pure (sometimes described as yellow-green). It has a characteristic pungent and biting odor like a halogen which is detected at 20 ppb. Fluorine will condense into a bright yellow liquid at −188°C (−306°F), a transition temperature similar to that of oxygen and nitrogen. Fluorine has two solid forms, fluorine α and β. Fluorine β crystallizes at −220°C (−364°F) and appears transparent and smooth, with the same disordered cubic structure of recently crystallized solid oxygen,note 2] unlike the orthorhombic system of other solid halogens. Further cooling to −228°C (−378°F) induces a phase transition to the hard, opaque fluorine α, which has a monoclinic structure with dense, angular molecular layers. The transition from β to α fluorine is more exothermic than fluorine condensation, and can lead to violence. note 3] There is only one naturally abundant isotope of fluorine, namely the stable 19F isotope. It has a high gyromagnetic rationote 4] and extraordinary sensitivity to magnetic fields; because it is also the only stable isotope, it is used in magnetic resonance imaging. Eighteen radioisotopes with mass numbers from 13 to 31 have been synthesized, of which 18F is the most stable with a half-life of 109.77 minutes. Other radioisotopes have half-lives of less than 70 seconds; most of it decays in less than half a second. Isotopes 17F and 18F undergo β+ decay and electron capture, the lighter isotopes decay via proton emission, and the isotopes heavier than 19F undergo β− decay (the heaviest through delayed neutron emission).

Two metastable isomers of fluorine are known, 18mF, with a half-life of 162(7) nanoseconds, and 26mF, with a half-life of 2.2(1) milliseconds. Among the lighter elements, the abundance value of fluorine at 400 ppb (parts per billion) – 24th among all the elements in the universe – appears to be surprisingly low: other elements from carbon to magnesium have abundances as much as two twenty times or more than fluorine. This is because stellar nucleosynthesis involves fluorine, and the other fluorine atoms created have a high nuclear cross-section, allowing collisions with hydrogen or helium to produce oxygen or neon, respectively. Beyond this temporal existence, three explanations have been proposed for fluorine's existence: Fluorine is the thirteenth most common element in the Earth's crust at 600–700 ppm (parts per million) by mass. Although not believed to occur naturally, elemental fluorine has been shown to be present as an occlusion in anthozonite, a variant of fluorite. Most fluorine occurs as fluoride-containing minerals. Fluorite, fluorapatite and cryolite are the most significant industrially. Fluorite (CaF2), also known as fluorspar, abundant worldwide, is a major source of fluoride, and fluorine. China and Mexico are the main suppliers of fluorite. Fluorapatite (Ca5(PO4)3F), which contains most of the world's fluoride, is an accidental source of fluoride as a by-product of fertilizer production. Cryolite (Na3AlF6), used in aluminum production, is the most fluorine-rich mineral. Economical natural sources of cryolite have been depleted, and much of it is now being synthesized commercially. Fluorite: A pink globular mass with crystal facets. Fluorapatite: Long prism-like crystals, without luster, at an angle out of the rock like aggregate. Cryolite: A parallelogram-shaped outline with diatomic molecules arranged in two layers. Other minerals, such as topaz, contain fluorine.

Fluorides, unlike other halides, are insoluble and do not occur in commercially advantageous concentrations in brines. Trace amounts of organofluorine of unknown origin have been detected in volcanic eruptions and geothermal springs. The presence of fluorine gas in the crystals, estimated by the smell of crushed anthozonite, is disputed; a study in 2012 reported the presence of 0.04% F2 in anthozonite, attributing these inclusions to radiation from the presence of small amounts of uranium. In 1529, Georgius Agricola described fluorite as an additive used to lower the melting point of metals during smelting. note 5] He wrote the Latin word fluorēs (fluorine, flow) for fluorite rock. The name later evolved to fluorspar (still commonly used) and then fluorite. The fluorite composition was then determined as calcium difluoride. Hydrofluoric acid was used in glass etching from 1720 onwards. note 6] Andreas Sigismund Marggraf first characterized it in 1764 when he heated fluorite with sulfuric acid, and the resulting solution corroded his glass vessels. The Swedish chemist Carl Wilhelm Scheele repeated the experiment in 1771, and named the acidic product fluss-spats-syran (fluorsparic acid). In 1810, the French physicist André-Marie Ampère predicted that hydrogen and an element analogous to chlorine was hydrofluoric acid. He also proposed in a letter to Humphry Davy dated August 26, 1812 that this then unknown substance could be named fluorine from fluoric acid and the -in suffix from the other halogens. This word, often with modifications, is used in most European languages; however, the Greek, Russian, and some others, following Ampère's later suggestion, took the name ftor or its derivatives, from the Greek φθόριος (phthorios, destructive).

The New Latin name fluorum gave the element its current symbol, F; FL was used in some early papers. note 7] The early studies of fluorine were so dangerous that some 19th century researchers considered it a "fluorine martyr" after having an accident with hydrofluoric acid. note 8] Isolation of elemental fluorine was hindered by the extreme corrosiveness of elemental fluorine itself and hydrogen fluoride, and because of the lack of a simple and suitable electrolyte. Edmond Frémy postulated that the electrolysis of pure hydrogen fluoride to produce fluorine was feasible and he devised a method for producing anhydrous samples from acidified potassium bifluoride; instead, he discovered that the (dry) hydrogen fluoride that was produced did not conduct electricity. A former Frémy student, Henri Moissan, persisted, and after much trial and error found that a dry mixture of potassium bifluoride and hydrogen fluoride was a conductor, allowing electrolysis to occur. To prevent rapid corrosion of the platinum in his electrochemical cell, he cooled the reaction to very low temperatures in a special bath and fabricated the cell from a more resistant mixture of platinum and iridium, using fluorite plugs. In 1886, after 74 years of effort by many chemists, Moissan was able to isolate elemental fluorine. In 1906, two months before his death, Moissan received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, with the following citation: In recognition of the great service rendered by him in the investigation and isolation of elemental fluorine ... The whole world has admired the great experimental skill with which you have studied note 9] The Frigidaire division of General Motors (GM) experimented with chlorofluorocarbon refrigerants in the late 1920s, and Kinetic Chemicals was formed as a joint venture between GM and DuPont in 1930 with the hope of marketing Freon-12 (CCl2F2) as one of the refrigerants.

It replaced earlier and more toxic compounds, increased the demand for kitchen refrigerators, and became profitable; in 1949 DuPont had purchased Kinetic and marketed several other Freon compounds. Polytetrafluoroethylene (Teflon) was accidentally discovered in 1938 by Roy J. Plunkett while working on refrigerants at Kinetic, and its excellent chemical and thermal resistance led to its accelerated commercialization and mass production in 1941. Large-scale production of elemental fluorine began during the World War II. Germany used high-temperature electrolysis to manufacture tons of burners planned for chlorine trifluoride and the Manhattan Project used large quantities to produce uranium hexafluoride for uranium enrichment. Because UF6 is as corrosive as fluorine, gas diffusion plants require special materials: nickel for the membrane, fluoropolymer for the seal, and liquid fluorocarbon as a coolant and lubricant. This growing nuclear industry later fueled the postwar development of fluorochemicals. Fluorine has a rich chemistry, covering organic and inorganic domains. It combines with metals, non-metals, metalloids, and most of the noble gases, and almost exclusively assumes an oxidation number of −1. note 10] The high electron affinity of fluorine results in a preference for ionic bonds; when it forms covalent bonds, they are polar, and almost always singular. note 11] The alkali metals form ionic monofluorides and are highly soluble; they have the cubic arrangement of sodium chloride and its analogue chloride. The alkaline earth difluorides have strong ionic bonds but are insoluble in water, with the exception of beryllium difluoride, which also exhibits some covalent character and has a quartz-like structure. The rare earth elements and many other metals form mostly ionic trifluorides. Covalent bonds are prominent in tetrafluorides first: the covalent bonds of zirconium, hafnium and some actinides are ionic with high melting points, note 12] whereas the covalent bonds of titanium, vanadium, and niobium are polymeric, melting or dissolving no more than 350 °C (660 °F).

Pentafluoride continues this trend with its linear polymers and oligomeric complexes. Thirteen metal hexafluorides are known, note 13] all are octahedral, and most are volatile solids, but MoF6 and ReF6 are liquids, and WF6 is a gas. Rhenium heptafluoride, the only metallic heptafluoride that has been characterized, is a low melting point molecular solid with a pentagonal bipyramidal molecular geometry. Metal fluorides with more fluorine atoms are highly reactive. Hydrogen and fluorine combine to produce hydrogen fluoride, in which the discrete molecules form groups with hydrogen bonds, which are more like water than hydrogen chloride. It boils at a much higher temperature than the heavier hydrogen halides and unlike them is miscible with water. Hydrogen fluoride readily hydrates on contact with water to form aqueous hydrogen fluoride, also known as hydrofluoric acid. Unlike other hydrohalic acids, which are strong, hydrofluoric acid is a weak acid at low concentrations. note 14] However, it can attack glass, something that no other acid can. The binary fluorides of the metalloids and p-block nonmetals are generally covalent and volatile, with varying reactivity. Period 3 and heavier nonmetals can form hypervalent fluorides. Boron trifluoride is planar and has incomplete octets. It functions as a Lewis acid and combines with Lewis bases such as ammonia to form adducts. Carbon tetrafluoride is tetrahedral and inert; note 15] its group analogues, silicon and germanium tetrafluoride, are also tetrahedral but behave as Lewis acids. Pnictogens form trifluorides which increase reactivity and basicity at higher molecular weights, although nitrogen trifluoride resists hydrolysis and is not basic.

Phosphorus, arsenic, and antimony pentafluorides are more reactive than their respective trifluorides, with antimony pentafluoride being the strongest neutral Lewis acid known. Chalcogens have various fluorides: unstable difluorides have been reported for oxygen (the only known compound with oxygen in oxidation number +2), sulfur, and selenium; tetrafluorides and hexafluorides exist for sulfur, selenium, and tellurium. The latter is stabilized by more fluorine atoms and a lighter central atom, so that sulfur hexafluoride is very inert. Chlorine, bromine, and iodine can each form mono-, tri-, and pentafluorides, but only iodine heptafluoride has been characterized among all possible interhalogen heptafluorides. Many of them are strong sources of fluorine atoms, and industrial applications using chlorine trifluoride require similar precautions as those using fluorine. The noble gases, which have complete electron shells, resisted reacting with other elements until 1962 when Neil Bartlett reported the synthesis of xenon hexafluoroplatinate; xenon difluoride, tetrafluoride, hexafluoride, and several oxyfluorides have been isolated since then. Among other noble gases, krypton forms a difluoride, and radon and fluorine produce a compound suspected to be radon difluoride. The binary fluorides of the lighter noble gases are very unstable: argon and hydrogen fluoride combine under extreme conditions to produce argon fluorohydride. Helium and neon do not have long-lived fluorides, and no neon fluoride has ever been observed; helium fluorohydride has been detected for milliseconds at high pressure and low temperature. The carbon–fluorine bond is the strongest organic chemical bond, and provides stability to organofluorines. It is hardly found in nature, but is used in artificial compounds. Research in this field is usually driven by commercial applications; the compounds involved are quite diverse and reflect the complexity inherent in organic chemistry.

The substitution of hydrogen atoms in alkanes by more and more fluorine atoms gradually changes several properties: the melting and boiling points decrease, the density increases, the solubility in hydrocarbons decreases and the overall stability increases. Perfluorocarbons,note 16] in which all the hydrogen atoms are substituted, are insoluble in most organic solvents, react under ambient conditions only with sodium in liquid ammonia. The term perfluorinated compound is used for what would be a perfluorocarbon were it not for the presence of a functional group,note 17], often a carboxylic acid. These compounds share many properties with perfluorocarbons such as stability and hydrophobicity, while functional groups add to their reactivity, allowing them to attach to surfaces or act as surfactants; Fluorosurfactants, in particular, can lower the surface tension of water more than their hydrocarbon-based analogs. Fluorotelomeres, which have some non-perfluorinated carbon atoms near the functional groups, are also considered as perfluorinated. The polymer exhibits the same increased stability afforded by substitution of fluorine (for hydrogen) in discrete molecules; the melting point generally also increases. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), the simplest fluoropolymer and perfluoro polyethylene analogue with the structural unit –CF2–, exhibits this change as expected, but its very high melting point makes it difficult to form. Various PTFE derivatives are less resistant to temperature but more malleable: fluorinated ethylene propylene replaces some of the fluorine atoms with trifluoromethyl groups, perfluoroalkoxy alkanes do the same with trifluoromethoxy groups, and Nafion contains perfluoroether side chains capped with sulfonic acid groups. Other fluoropolymers retain some of the hydrogen atoms; polyvinylidene fluoride has half the fluorine atoms of PTFE and polyvinyl fluoride has one-fourth, but both behave like perfluorinated polymers. Elemental fluorine and nearly all fluorine compounds are produced from hydrogen fluoride or its aqueous solution, hydrofluoric acid.

Hydrogen fluoride is produced in a furnace by an endothermic reaction of fluorite (CaF2) with sulfuric acid: The HF gas can then be absorbed in water or liquefied. About 20% of the HF produced is a by-product of fertilizer production, which produces hexafluorosilicate acid (H2SiF6), which can be degraded to release HF both thermally and by hydrolysis: The Moissan method is used for the industrial production of a number of fluorines, via the electrolysis of potassium fluoride/hydrogen fluoride mixtures: Hydrogen and fluoride ions are reduced and oxidized at the steel housing cathode and carbon block anode, below 8–12 volts, to produce hydrogen and fluorine gas respectively. The temperature is increased, KF•2HF melts at 70°C (158°F) and being electrolyzed at 70–130°C (158–266°F). KF, which acts to provide electrical conductivity, is very important because pure HF cannot be electrolyzed as it is almost non-conductive. Fluorine can be stored in steel cylinders having a passive interior, at temperatures below 200°C (392°F); otherwise, nickel can be used. Regulating valves and pipes are made of nickel, and pipes may use Monel instead. Frequent passivation, together with strict exclusion of water and oil, must be practiced. In the laboratory, glassware can carry fluorine gas under low pressure and anhydrous conditions; some sources instead recommend a nickel-Monel-PTFE system. While preparing for the 1986 conference to celebrate the centenary of Moissan's achievement, Karl O. Christe reasoned that the chemical manufacture of fluorine had to be feasible because some metal fluoride anions lack stable neutral partners; their acidification could potentially trigger oxidation instead. He devised a method that developed fluorine at high yields and at atmospheric pressure: Christe later commented that the reactants "had been known for over 100 years and even Moissan could come up with this scheme."

As late as 2008, several references still confirmed that fluorine was too reactive for any chemical isolation. Mining of fluorite, which supplies most of global fluorine, peaked in 1989 when 5.6 million metric tons of ore was extracted. Restrictions on chlorofluorocarbons lowered this value to 3.6 million tons in 1994; since then, production has increased. Approximately 4.5 million tonnes of ore and US$550 million in revenue were generated in 2003; a subsequent report estimated 2011 global fluorochemical sales of $15 billion and estimated production figures of 3.5 to 5.9 million tons, and revenues of at least $20 billion. Float separates the mined fluorite into two main metallurgical grades in equal proportions: 60–85% pure metspar is almost all used in iron smelting while 97%+ pure acid is mostly converted to hydrogen fluoride the main industrial intermediate. At least 17,000 metric tons of fluorine are produced annually. It costs only $5–8 per kilogram as uranium or sulfur hexafluoride, but is many times more expensive as an element because of its challenging handling. Most of the processes that use large amounts of free fluorine use in situ generation under vertical integration. The largest application of fluorine gas, consuming up to 7,000 metric tons per year, is in the preparation of UF6 for the nuclear fuel cycle. Fluorine is used to fluorinate uranium tetrafluoride, which is formed from uranium dioxide and hydrofluoric acid. Fluorine is monoisotopic, so any difference in mass between UF6 molecules is due to the presence of 235U or 238U, which allows uranium enrichment by gas diffusion or gas centrifugation. Approximately 6,000 metric tons per year are used to produce the inert dielectric SF6 for high-voltage transformers and circuit breakers, eliminating the need for the dangerous polychlorinated biphenyls associated with oil-filled devices.

Several fluorine compounds are used in electronics: rhenium and tungsten hexafluoride in chemical vapor deposition, tetrafluoromethane in plasma etching, and nitrogen trifluoride in cleaning equipment. Fluorine is also used in the synthesis of organic fluorides, but its reactivity often requires prior conversion to the milder ClF3, BrF3, or IF5, which together allow calibrated fluorination. Fluorinated drugs use sulfur tetrafluoride instead. As with other ferrous alloys, about 3 kg (6.5 lb) of metspar is added to each metric ton of steel; fluoride ion lowers its melting point and viscosity. Besides its role as an additive in materials such as enamels and welding rod coatings, most acidspar is reacted with sulfuric acid to form hydrofluoric acid, which is used in steel pickling, glass etching, and alkane cracking. One-third HF is used to synthesize cryolite and aluminum trifluoride, both of which flow in the Hall–Héroult process for aluminum extraction; charging required by their reaction with smelting equipment. Each metric ton of aluminum requires approximately 23 kg (51 lb) of flux. Fluorosilicates account for the second largest share, with sodium fluorosilicate used in water fluoridation and sewage treatment, and as intermediates on their way to cryolite and silicon tetrafluoride. Other important inorganic fluorides include cobalt, nickel and ammonium. Organofluorides consume over 20% of mined fluorite and over 40% of hydrofluoric acid, with refrigerant gases dominating and fluoropolymers increasing their market share. Surfactant is a small app but generates over $1 billion in annual revenue. Due to the dangers of the direct hydrocarbon–fluorine reaction above −150°C (−240°F), industrial production of fluorocarbons is indirect, mostly via halogen exchange reactions such as Swarts fluorination, in which chlorine chlorocarbons are replaced by fluorine by hydrogen fluoride under a catalyst. .

Electrochemical fluorination of the hydrocarbons is subjected to electrolysis in hydrogen fluoride, and the Fowler process treats them with a solid fluorine carrier such as cobalt trifluoride. Halogenated refrigerants, called Freons in an informal context, note 18] are identified by the number R which indicates the amount of fluorine, chlorine, carbon and hydrogen present. Compounds such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), R-11, R-12, and R-114 once dominated organofluorines, with peak production in the 1980s. Used for air conditioning, propellant and solvent systems, production was below a tenth of this peak in the early 2000s, after widespread international bans. Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) are designed as substitutes; Their synthesis consumes more than 90% of fluorine in the organic industry. Important HCFCs include R-22, chlorodifluoromethane, and R-141b. The most important HFC is R-134a with a new type of molecule, HFO-1234yf, a hydrofluoroolefin (HFO) that became popular due to its global warming potential of less than 1% of HFC-134a. Approximately 180,000 metric tons of fluoropolymer were produced in 2006 and 2007, generating over $3.5 billion in annual revenue. Sales on the global market were estimated at just under $6 billion in 2011 and are predicted to grow by 6.5% annually until 2016. Fluoropolymers can only be formed by polymerizing free radicals. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), sometimes referred to as Teflon, represents 60–80% by mass of world fluoropolymer production. Its greatest application is in electrical insulation because PTFE is an excellent dielectric. It is also used in the chemical industry where corrosion resistance is required, in pipe coatings, tubing and gaskets. Another major use is in PFTE-coated fiberglass fabrics for stadium roofs. The main consumer application is for non-stick cookware. The snapped PTFE film becomes expanded PTFE (ePTFE), a fine porous membrane that is sometimes referred to by the brand name Gore-Tex and used for rainwear, protective clothing, and filters; ePTFE fibers may be made into dust seals and filters.

Other fluoropolymers, including fluorinated ethylene propylene, mimic the properties of PTFE and can replace it; they are easier to form, but are also more expensive and have lower thermal stability. Films of two different fluoropolymers replace glass in solar cells. Chemically resistant (but expensive) fluorinated ionomers are used in electrochemical cell membranes, of which the first and most prominent example is Nafion. Developed in the 1960s, it was initially used as a fuel cell material on spacecraft and later replaced the mercury-based chloralkali process cell. More recently, fuel cell applications have resurfaced with efforts to fit proton exchange membrane fuel cells into automobiles. Fluoroelastomers such as Viton are crosslinked fluoropolymer blends used primarily in O-rings; perfluorobutane (C4F10) is used as a fire extinguishing agent. Fluorosurfactants are small organofluorine molecules that are used to repel water and stains. Although expensive (compared to pharmaceuticals costing $200–2000 per kilogram), they generated over $1 billion in annual revenue in 2006; Scotchgard alone made over $300 million in 2000. Fluorosurfactants are a minority in the overall surfactant market, which is largely taken up by much cheaper hydrocarbon-based products. Applications in paints are burdened by compounding costs; these uses were valued at only $100 million in 2006. About 30% of agrochemicals contain fluorine, most of them being herbicides and fungicides with some plant regulators. Fluorine substitution, usually of a single atom or at most a trifluoromethyl group, is a powerful modification with effects analogous to those of fluorinated drugs: increasing biological residence time, crossing membranes, and altering molecular recognition. Trifluralin is an outstanding example, with large-scale use in the US as a weed killer, but it is a suspected carcinogen and has been banned in many European countries.

Sodium monofluoroacetate (1080) is a mammalian poison in which the two hydrogens of acetic acid are replaced by fluorine and sodium; it interferes with cell metabolism by replacing acetate in the citric acid cycle. First synthesized in the late 19th century, it became known as an insecticide in the early 20th century, and was later used in its current uses. New Zealand, 1080's largest consumer, uses it to protect kiwis from the invasive common Australian brushtail possum. Europe and the US have banned 1080.note 19] Population studies from the mid-20th century onwards have shown topical fluoride to reduce dental caries. This was first associated with the conversion of tooth enamel hydroxyapatite to the more durable fluorapatite, but studies in fluoridated teeth disproved this hypothesis, and current theory involves fluoride aiding enamel growth in small caries. Following studies of children in areas where fluoride is naturally present in drinking water, controlled fluoridation of public water supplies to fight tooth decay began in the 1940s and is now applied to water that supplies 6 percent of the global population, including two thirds of the American population. Reviews of the scientific literature in 2000 and 2007 associated water fluoridation with a significant reduction in tooth decay in children. Despite such support and evidence of the absence of adverse effects other than largely benign dental fluorosis, opposition still exists on ethical and safety grounds. The benefits of fluoridation have diminished, possibly due to other sources of fluoride, but are still measurable in lower income groups. Sodium monofluorophosphate and sometimes sodium or tin(II) fluoride are frequently found in fluoride toothpastes, first introduced in the US in 1955 and now ubiquitous in the developed world, along with fluoride mouthwashes, gels, foams, and varnishes.

Twenty percent of modern medicines contain fluorine. One of them, the cholesterol lowering drug, atorvastatin (Lipitor), generated more revenue than any other drug until it became a generic drug in 2011. A prescription asthma combination Seretide, a top ten revenue drug in the mid-2000s, contains two active ingredients, one of which is – fluticasone – fluorinated. Many drugs are fluorinated to delay inactivation and extend the dosing period because the carbon–fluorine bond is very stable. Fluorination also increases lipophilicity because the bonds are more hydrophobic than carbon–hydrogen bonds, and this often aids in cell membrane penetration and bioavailability. Tricyclics and other pre-1980s antidepressants have few side effects due to their nonselective interference with neurotransmitters other than serotonin targets; fluorinated fluoxetine was chosen and was one of the first to avoid this problem. Many current antidepressants receive similar treatment, including the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: sitalopram, its isomers esitalopram, and fluvoxamine, and paroxetine. Quinolones are artificial broad-spectrum antibiotics that are often fluorinated to enhance their effect. They include ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin. Fluorine is also used in steroids: fludrocortisone is a mineralocorticoid that can increase blood pressure, and triamcinolone and dexamethasone are strong glucocorticoids. The majority of inhalational anesthetics are highly fluorinated; the halotana prototype was much more slender and powerful than its contemporaries. Later compounds such as sevoflurane ether and fluorinated desflurane taste better than halothane and are nearly insoluble in the blood, allowing for a quicker wake-up time. Fluorine-18 is often found in radioactive tracers for positron emission tomography, because its half-life of nearly two hours is long enough to allow transport of it from the production facility to the imaging center. The most common tracer is fluorodeoxyglucose which, after intravenous injection, is taken up by glucose-demanding tissues such as the brain and most malignant tumors; Computed tomography can then be used for more detailed imaging.

Liquid fluorocarbons can hold large volumes of oxygen or carbon dioxide, much more than blood, and have attracted attention because of their possible use in artificial blood and liquid respiration. Because fluorocarbons are usually immiscible with water, they must be mixed into an emulsion (small droplets of perfluorocarbons suspended in water) to be used as blood. One such product, Oxycyte, has gone through early clinical trials. This substance can help endurance athletes and has been banned in sports; the death of a cyclist in 1998 prompted an investigation into their abuse. Applications of pure perfluorocarbon liquid inhalation (which uses pure perfluorocarbon liquid instead of an aqueous emulsion) include helping burn victims and premature infants with lungs that are not working properly. Partial and complete lung filling have been considered, although only partial filling has had significant tests in humans. Alliance Pharmaceuticals' efforts reached clinical trials but were abandoned because the results were no better than normal therapy. Fluorine is not essential but in small amounts it is known to be useful for strengthening tooth enamel (where the formation of fluorapatite makes the enamel more resistant to attack, from acids produced by bacterial fermentation of sugars). Small amounts of fluorine may be beneficial for bone strength, but this has not been definitively established. Both the WHO and the Institute of Medicine of the US National Academies publish the recommended daily allowance (RDA) and tolerated fluorine intake, which vary by age and sex. Elemental fluorine is highly toxic to living organisms. Hydrofluoric acid is a contact poison with greater danger than many strong acids such as sulfuric acid even though it is a weak acid: it remains neutral in aqueous solutions and can penetrate tissues more rapidly, either through inhalation, ingestion or skin, and at least nine US workers have died from 1984 to 1994 due to the accident. Editor's page logged out learn more In Greek mythology, Alcmene (Greek: Aλκμήνη) was the Mother of Heracles. Alcmene was the son of Electryon, king of Mycenae. His mother may have been Anaxo, daughter of Alcaeus and Astidamia, or Lysidis, daughter of Pelops and Hippodamia. Hesiod describes Alcmene as a woman of great beauty, wisdom and respect for her husband. According to Apollodorus, Alcmene went with Amphitryon to Thebes, where Amphitryon was purified by Creon (king of Thebes) from accidentally killing Electryon. Alcmene refused to marry Amphitryon until she could avenge the death of her brothers. However, during Amphitryon's expedition against the Taphos and Telebos peoples, Zeus disguised himself as Amphitryon and visited Alcmene. Extending one night to three times longer, Zeus sleeps with Alcmene (which causes Alcmene to become pregnant) and tells of Amphitryon's victory over the Telebos. When Amphitryon finally returned to Thebes, Alcmene told him that Amphitryon had come the night before and slept with him, and Amphitryon learned from Teiresias what Zeus had done. In Homer's Illiad, when Alcmene is about to give birth to Heracles, Zeus announces to all the gods that on that day a son of Zeus will be born who will rule all around him. Hera, after asking Zeus to swear on this statement, descended from Olympus to Argos and made Sthenelos' wife (daughter of Perseus) give birth to Euristheus at only seven months, while at the same time, Hera prevented Alcmene from giving birth to Heracles. This resulted in the fulfillment of Zeus' oath falling on Euristheus, not Heracles. According to Ovidius' Metamorphoses, Alcmene experienced difficulties trying to give birth to Heracles. After seven days and seven nights of agony, Alcmene reached out and begged Eileithyia, the goddess of birth.

However, when Eileithyia visited Alcmene, she was ordered by Hera to stop the birth. Arms folded and legs crossed, Eileithyia muttered an incantation to prevent Alcmene from giving birth. Alcmene struggled with pain, cursed the sky and was dying more and more. Galanthis, an Alcmene servant who was nearby, observed Eileithyia's actions and quickly deduced Hera's plan. She then announced that Alcmene had safely given birth to her child, to which Eileithyia was shocked and jumped up. As soon as Eileithyia jumped, Alcmene was released from the spell and was able to give birth to Heracles. As punishment for tricking Eileithyia, Galanthis was turned into a weasel but he stayed with Alcmene. In Pausanias' story, Hera sends witches to prevent Heracles from being born. The witches managed to prevent the birth until Historical, daughter of Teiresias, thought of a trick to trick the witches. Like Galanthis, the Historical announced that Alcmene had given birth to his child. The deceived witches finally left and allowed Alcmene to give birth. In contrast to the above stories, an alternative version is presented in Amphitryon, a comedy drama by Plauto. In this story, Alcmene summons Zeus who then gives a miracle to Alcmene to give birth quickly and easily. After thunder and lightning appeared, the baby was born without anyone's help. There are two opinions regarding Alcmene's death. According to the people of Megara, Alcmene was walking from Argos to Thebes when he died at Megara. The Heracleids (sons of Heracles) could not agree on where Alcmene would be buried. Some wanted Alcmene's body brought back to Argos, while others wanted it buried in Thebes (since Amphitryon was also buried in Thebes). Finally, Alcmene was buried in Megara on the advice of the Oracle of Delphi. The second version comes from the people of Thebes: when Alcmene died, he was turned to stone.

The editor's page has logged out learn more Blanquism refers to the concept of revolution generally attributed to Louis Auguste Blanqui (1805–1881) who argued that a socialist revolution must be carried out by a relatively small, highly organized group of secret conspirators. After taking power, the revolutionaries used the state to introduce socialism. This concept is considered a particular type of "putschism", hence the view that political revolution must take the form of a putsch or coup. Blanquism was distinguished from other forms of socialist currents (notably Marxism) in a number of ways: in contrast to Marx, Blanqui did not believe in the primary role of the working class, nor in the popular movement, what he believed was that revolutions must be carried out by a small group of dedicated and professional revolutionaries, who may establish a provisional dictatorship by force. This dictatorship could enable the implementation of the basis for a new order, after which it would be given to the people. In other respects, Blanqui was more concerned with the revolution itself than with the future of society it would produce. If his thinking is based on proper socialist principles, it is rarely carried out until it results in a genuine socialist society. For the Blanquists, the abolition of the bourgeois social order and revolution was sufficient, at least for their proximate purposes. The Central Revolutionary Committee (CRC) was a French Blanquist political party founded in 1881 and dissolved in 1898. The CRC merged into the Socialist Revolutionary Party in 1898. The term "Blanquism" is often used controversially to accuse some revolutionaries of their failure to unify praxis them with the masses of the working class. Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels distinguished their concept of revolution from Blanquism. Rosa Luxemburg and Eduard Bernstein criticized Vladimir Lenin's concept of revolution as elitist and essentially Blanquis.

A doctor who has completed special education in psychiatry is known as a psychiatrist. Before becoming a psychiatrist, a doctor must first undergo medical education. Then, the doctor must attend a four-year period of specialized training and education specifically studying the field of psychiatry. Upon completion, the doctor will be given the title of mental health specialist or psychiatrist. Child and adolescent psychiatry has a focus on dealing with children's problems with their emotions and behavior. Because the problems in these children have an impact on the function of learning and socialization. These problems are often not felt by parents directly, so children with these problems come to a psychiatrist for treatment in quite severe conditions. Psychiatric disorders in children and adolescents can lead to suicide, depression, bipolar, schizophrenia, substance abuse, conduct disorders, and eating disorders. One of the methods used in dealing with the behavior of children and adolescents is the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire method, or abbreviated as SDQ. The SDQ method is an instrument used for behavioral screening that is used for children and adolescents, with an age range of 3-17 years. The screening data is used to describe the behavior of children and adolescents regarding the strengths and difficulties they face. The SDQ method has a scale or dimensions, which are divided into five dimensions, namely prosocial behavior, hyperactivity, behavioral problems, emotional symptoms, and relationships with peers. Geriatrics is a branch of medical science that studies health and medicine for people who have entered the elderly stage, in which it discusses health services for the elderly by examining all aspects of health in the form of promotion, prevention, diagnosis, treatment and rehabilitation.

The characteristics of geriatric patients include entering the age of 60, having an atypical clinical appearance, decreased organ function, impaired functional (physical-mental) status, nutritional disorders, and polypharmacy. In addition, signs of geriatric patients are reduced energy and concentration, and disturbed sleep, loss of appetite, weight loss, and somatic complaints. Geriatric people are very likely to experience a major depressive episode with a melancholic appearance with symptoms of depression, hypochondriasis, low self-esteem, feelings of uselessness, suspicious ideas and suicidal ideation. Consultation Liaison Psychiatry or abbreviated CLP is a branch of psychiatry that has a role as a liaison to produce cooperation between psychiatrists and other specialists. In addition, consultation liaison psychiatry has a role to play in maintaining psychiatry as a discipline to assist diagnostic, psychopathological, and prognostic co-morbidities in the medical setting. CLP also has a goal to deepen psychiatric aspects, both in evaluation, therapy, diagnosis, prevention, research, and education. In addition, he is tasked with finding cases of psychiatric problems. Forensic psychiatry is a branch of psychiatry that deals with the assessment and treatment of someone who is serving a sentence in a prison or special hospital. Forensic psychiatrists must be knowledgeable about law and health. In the field of law, forensic psychiatry also plays a role in terms of proving criminal responsibility, and plays a role in determining whether or not the accused is guilty. Community psychiatry is a mental health service for the community with practical principles and needs. Community psychiatry has the goal of providing basic needs-based therapy and care to the community. In addition, community psychiatry also provides fact-based services for all patients with mental disorders.

Tannin (from English tannin; from Old High German tanna, meaning "oak tree" or "chestnut tree") originally referred to the use of vegetable tannins from oak trees to tan animal bones (raw hides) into cooked hides. durable and flexible. Today, however, the definition of tannins is broadened to include a wide variety of large polyphenolic compounds which contain sufficient numbers of hydroxyl groups and other suitable groups (eg carboxyls) to form tightly bound complexes with proteins and other macromolecules. Tannin compounds are found in many types of plants; these compounds play important roles in protecting plants from predation by herbivores and pests, as well as in growth regulation. The tannins contained in the young fruit give rise to a chelate (astringent) taste; changes that occur in tannin compounds over time play an important role in the fruit ripening process. The tannin content of organic matter (litter, twigs and wood) which dissolves in rainwater (along with various humus substances), makes stagnant water in swamps and peat swamps blackish brown like tea water, known as black water. ). The tannin content also makes this kind of water taste rough and a bit bitter. Tannins are mainly used by people to tan leather so that it is durable and easy to use. Tannins are also used to tan (coarse) nets, ropes and sails to make them more resistant to seawater. In addition, tannins are used as dyes, adhesives, and mordant.

Climate (from the English word derived from the Ancient Greek word "klima", meaning inclination) is usually defined as the average weather over a long period. The standard average period is 30 years, but other periods may be used depending on the purpose. Climate also includes statistics other than averages, such as the magnitude of daily or year-to-year variations. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) 2001 defined climate as follows: Climate in the narrow sense is usually defined as "average weather," or more precisely, as a statistical description in terms of the averages and variability of relevant quantities over periods ranging from months to months. -months to thousands or millions of years. The classic period is 30 years, as defined by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). The most frequently used surface variable quantities are temperature, precipitation, and wind. Climate in a broader sense is the state, including a statistical description, of the climate system. The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) defines "normal" climate as a "point of reference" used by climatologists to compare current climate developments with past or what is considered 'normal'. A normal climate is defined as the arithmetic mean of the climatic elements (eg temperature) over a 30 year period. The 30 year period is used because it is long enough to filter out anomalous variations between anomalies, but also short enough to be able to show longer climate developments.

It was the WMO that set up a technical commission for climatology in 1929. In 1934, Wiesbaden complied with a technical commission establishing a thirty-year period from 1901 to 1930 as the reference time for climatological standard normals. In 1982 the WMO agreed to update climate normals, and these were subsequently finalized based on climate data from 1 January 1961 to 31 December 1990. The difference between climate and weather is summed up by the popular line "Climate is what you expect, weather is what you get. ". Other climate determinants are more dynamic such as oceanic thermohaline circulation causing 5°C (9°F) warming in the north Atlantic Ocean compared to other ocean basins.
